The pizzas range from about $20-$30. Deep dish pizzas come in 9" & 12." Thin crust pizzas come in 12" and 16." There are also plain cheese pizzas, and you can basically build your own by adding toppings for ~$2-$3 for each topping. 
Our server informed us that deep dishes here typically take about 25 minutes, which isn't too bad compared to baking times for most deep dish pizzas. 
Apparently, the wait times during weekend peak dining times can be rough. For lazy people like me, I'd rather opt for delivery.
author: Joy W.

description: I mean who doesn't love Little Star?  The cornmeal crust is amazingggg. My biggest complaint is they are not great with substitutions or removals from their pizzas.  I find it's much easier to just build my own, although then you're not getting as good of a deal for as many topics.  I detest onions and got a pizza with onions on it - and you can't just pick them out since it's deep dish.  We didn't have time to wait around for another pizza (it's deep dish and takes time!) so I ate crust that night.
author: Amanda B.

description: Very yummy pizza, but kind of pricey. We went on a Sunday night and only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table. Would recommend!
author: Alex F.

description: great pizza and good service.  now THATS hard to find these days.  parking a bit tuff but not impossible.  a nice assortment of salads.  we had beers but the wine list was pretty good too!  a pleasant dining experience with friends.
author: Kay C.

description: I haven't had deep dish pizza since I visited Chicago over a year ago. My cousin wanted to try this place out so we did. We got here right before they closed and they were really nice and let us order take out. Since it was deep dish, it took like 30min. The deep dish pizza was amazing. The crust was really good. We also got a thin crust that was tasty. Overall, solid pizza place. The deep dish was really heavy though so be prepared to share.
author: Juan F.

description:
Go to their website and join the waitlist so that they'll text you when they have a seat for you for dinner. 

Burrata appetizer was heavenly-- must get! ~$13

For their pizzas, go with deep dish! They also allow one topping substitution free of charge. Buttery crust, sauce on top of toppings and cheese (which I predict is so that the sauce won't make the crust soggy and compromise the deep dishes' structural integrity). Friendly service. Pizzas 9in ~$20, 12in ~ $30.
author: Y W.

description: Little Star is a quality choice for pizza. They serve deep dish with a corn bread crust. Not as good as Chicago style, but certainly a satisfying pie. They also have really good gluten free crust, if you're into that. Unfortunately they aren't open for lunch, but give them a try for dinner!
author: Justin J.

description:
This place is so overrated its unbelievable.

20$ for a medium pepperoni Pizza. 

Two things I know about San Fran

1) everything is more expensive..

Ok? but 20$ for a medium pizza? Really?

2) San Fran is a very healthy city...

So healthy that you can't recognize horrible pizza?



Reading through the reviews I see a ton of locals like it and the out of towners should just stay away.
author: Nicole B.

description: I got the margarita deep dish pizza. It was the best pizza I've ever had. The crust melts on your mouth. The atmosphere was amazing and the service was great!
author: Taylor K.

description: Delicious food and outstanding service. They have gluten free options! Get on wait list and order in advance. Overall good for quick bite.
author: Amir P.

description: Easily the best deep dish I've ever had. I come here every time I'm in the bay. Brought homies and they're we're all raving about it as well after hours of doubting me. Go for the Mediterranean. It's not on the menu but they still make it. Ask what's on it cuz it's one of their best tbh. The second would be there self named Little Star- for not having any meat at all, this pizza is good on it own. The cheese at this place will stretch longer than any of my past relationships so you know it's quality.
author: Tommi G.

description: I am from Chicago and love the cornmeal crust deep dish pizzas.  This is the best pizza I have had in the city... yum.  The two restaurants (Mission and Divisadero) have slightly different menus - I like both but if I had to choose I would say check out the Divisadero location.  You can call ahead and they will start your pizza for you so you don't have to wait too long because the deep dish takes about 30 minutes.
author: Alison K.

description:
Little star is always a good idea. The classic deep dish is some serious business, one of the best pizzas in the neighborhood. People are particular about how they like their pizza. The deep dish is layered in cheese,  tomatoes,  bell pepper, sausage and onion. The crust is a golden corn meal brushed with either butter or olive oil, I'm not sure what.

I can see why some people might not like it as much as other types. One things for sure, it's unique. 

I mostly get take out but I have dined inside the establishment a few times. They have great salads,  great drink selections and a great atmosphere. 

They also have a kids pizza, it might not be on the online menu but they have one. It's small but kids like it.

For locations perfect for takeout if you live in the neighborhood. It's fast and delicious, call ahead and pick up. Life is good.
author: Ben M.

description:
So I came in checking this place out as part of our road trip from L.A to redwoods national park in Northern California. 
Had the deep dish pizza with sausage. Don't remember the name of it... and that's pretty much my dining experience, not much stood out besides the crust. Maybe I came in with my hopes too high. 
Don't get me wrong, good pizza place- just not the best pizza I have tasted.
author: Diego H.

description:
I feel like im supposed to love this place cuz its ridiculously yelpy. I give it a 3.5. I realized that I am not a deep dish kind of gal. I literally feel like Im just eating tomatoes on top of bread and cant even taste the fixings. Seven of us split two pizzas, wings, and the garlic bread. The cool thing about this place is that while you are waiting, they will place your order and they will time it so when you finally get seated, the pizza should come out fairly shortly after. That is efficiency at its finest but likely you will be waiting 45 minutes on a weekend night. There are bars around while you wait. Parking can be tough but you just gotta search for days.

Classic - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells. Like I said before, with all the sauce, I didnt even taste the toppings. 
Little Star - Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. I could see the spinach and definitely tasted the feta but meh.
Chicken Wings- These tasted weird. They were a bit spicy and something about it...couldnt put my finger on it but something was off....the skin tasted fake? I derno
Garlic bread- This was pretty much cheese bread. Barely tasted any garlic and it was just like a slice of cheese pizza.

This place is alright but it seemed like a lot of people were getting the thing slice pizzas. I do admit that the crust is bomb and crunchy and fried haha.
author: Amy H.

description:
While their deep dish pizzas look and smell so amazing, this review is for their vegan normal dish pizza. It's the vegetarian pizza with no cheese add spinach. we also got it gluten-free so kudos to them for having a vegan/gluten-free option!!!

While the pizza felt lacking (I mean what is pizza without cheese am I right?) in flavor and the crust was prone to cracking due to the gluten-free dough, it was actually pretty good as far as vegan pizzas go. The marinara sauce they use was really good, kind of sweet but tangy at the same time. If you ever need a pizza joint with a vegan option, this is it!
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Got the classic deep dish pizza.Cornmeal crust is deliciousss. It's a great pizza place, especially if you're looking to have a good deep dish pizza, and with a glass of wine too ;)
author: Jeana Y.

description:
Fives Stars as kudos for doing a fabulous job in a niche market.
My foodie friends have insisted I indulge many times.
Personally, I have never had a Little Star pizza I enjoyed. I eat organic vegetables and cheese on a daily basis (no bread). That is all they are. If on a rare occasion I choose to go for it with a pizza, I want a real pizza.
author: Blair C.

description: It ok but it ain't no Zachary's. Squash the bay areas deep dish pie challenge by giving it a try. You wont be disappointed. Get's crowded and there can be a wait. Overall a nice dining experience and an average Chicago Style deep dish
author: Frank B.

description: We stopped here last night before our trip home and it was worth the crazy drive around in circles trying to find a parking spot. We literally drove around blocks for 45 minutes just trying to find a parking spot (not their fault of course). I almost gave up on them because when I drove by it looked so closed up and dark I thought maybe it was an inappropriate bar scene for the two teenagers that were with me.  Fortunately after walking in it was a very intimate, cozy experience with clean bathrooms, kind servers, delicious food and reasonable prices. $5 appetizers on the weekdays. We had a classic deep dish, food wait was just long enough to let us chat but not so long that we were like wtf. Everybody there was comfortable and happy and the whole vibe was amazing. The pizza was DELICIOUS. I'm super picky about my food since I am an experienced cook and this pie was worth every dollar. Which was priced at $29 for a large deep dish. Which fed 3 people til full with an appetizer. I see complaints about price but honestly you get what you pay for. Quality costs and I am grateful for what they do here. Don't be cheap guys pay that extra few bucks for good food. The only part I would say is not good about this place is the outside presentation. It looks closed off and dark. Not inviting or open even. I would suggest getting a clear glass door and taking down the curtains or whatever it is that blocks the windows. The place is too small to be that dark in the front it's easily missed and easily misconstrued to be a bar
author: Angelina P.

description: I've never had deep dish pizza before but my goodness, this place is so delicious! The sauce was really delicious and the crust was nice and crispy around the pizza. I got one that had barbecue sauce and chicken and the other half had sausage and pineapple. Everything was so delicious and next time I'm in the area I will definitely be going to get pizza here!
author: Hailey S.

description:
Now, that's a deep dish pizza.

From start to finish Little Star did not disappoint. All of your sense will tingle with excitement throughout your visit! 

Little Star is rocking an old school jukebox that plays tunes that make you say, "OMG do you remember this one?" Your taste buds will be tickled not only by the taste of your pizza, from the sauce to the fresh mozzarella, there will be a sweet symphony of flavors in your mouth that only a bite of pizza can explain. (If it's on the menu get the meatball pizza and add artichokes!) Little Star offers and makes specialty champagne drinks, that can only be explained as amazing. Take into consideration, too, these drinks don't come in a flute, they arrive in beer glasses! And to top off the last two senses, the artwork needs to be mentioned. The artwork is done by a local artists, and I am sure you can purchase any of this work if you see something that really sicks out. 

Try to hit this place during lunch, you will have the whole restaurant to yourself. Plus, you can get a little nap in after you devour your deep dish pizza.

I cannot wait until I visit Little Star Pizza again, until then I will just dream about that pizza.
author: Kendal Ann M.

description:
5 stars for amazing service! This is actually my first Yelp review, and the exemplary service I received has compelled me to turn my Twitter fingers into Yelp fingers (haha).

I walked in with my boyfriend on a Saturday evening around 5 and we were seated immediately. Awesome. The interior is nice and the music was cool. Queen was playing in the background, and any establishment that plays Freddie Mercury is okay with me.

We ordered the spicy chicken wings as a starter and these were delicious! My boyfriend actually polished 10 of them off within a few minutes. We also ordered the large Classic deep dish pizza. The food came out promptly and we were checked on regularly. 

After a few bites of our pizza, our server (her name was Mer) came and informed us that they accidentally gave us the Little Star pizza instead of the Classic that we originally ordered. Now, my boyfriend and I are pretty easy going people. We actually didn't notice the difference and thought the pizza was delicious, and we were fine with what we received. But the staff apologized profusely and went above and beyond by giving us a discount for the error AND firing up a Classic pizza for us to take home without us asking! 

I was in awe. Honestly, who does that!? I was surprised and really pleased with their professionalism and generosity. It's hard to find establishments that really care about their customers, and I'm really happy with Little Star's service. We'll definitely be back. Thanks so much to Mer and the rest of the staff for the wonderful service (and the delicious food!)
author: Jeantelle L.

description: The deep this is the only way to go here. We are thin crust has way too much granular corn meal on the bottom. But the deep dish is tasty and chock-full of vegetables both the little star version and a vegetarian version. The small deep dish goes along way in the large deep dish is a marathon. Eating in can be fun especially with their little bar if you're solo, but I usually just do takeout.
author: David A R.

description:
Twinkle, twinkle Little Star
How I wondered what you were
Back when 5 years young with my taste buds sprung
Hooked on lunchables pizza cause no deep dish, son. 
Craved for cheese on triangular slice
Wished for the best pizza and hopes were high

Twinkle, twinkle Little Star
High school wished I had a car
Pockets deep like the New York Thin Crust
Possibilities like toppings, endless
Sherane, Lucy, Whitney, first dates
Sausage, Spinach, Olives, still straight
Cruising life with no thoughts no worries
Irony is I foolishly wished it hurried

Twinkle, twinkle Little Star
College life and pizza bars
Six dollars each for a sweet dark Porter
Paid my passage with laundry quarters
Three glass in want three glass more
Pizza washed down in liquor store
Wished for ID for all my friends
and year twenty one that never ends.

Twinkle, twinkle Little Star
Waistline has come very far
12 inch diameter for the bigger slice
36 inch waist for the denim size
32 bites of ways deep marinara
26 years of life as an era
Cheese stretched long like young imagination
Passport stamp to youth on short vacations
Parmesan trickles like an hour glass
Chase the waitress as I chase my past
Wish for days of looser pants
Wish this pizza shared with Thursday Fam

Twinkle, twinkle Little Star
Through the ages, Little Star
35 and working late
Perfect for fiancé date
43 and bumble bees
First deep dish for my mini-me
65 and feel alive
Retire with a pint glass on my mind
81 and still not done
One more slice, just one last one.
Thank you, Little Star, for all the pies
Wish to pass along the happy times
author: Ringo M.

description: Second best pizza in San Francisco after Arizmendi, and the best if you're going for deep dish. Get the classic as a deep dish. Whenever I stray from that go-to favorite I regret it. I don't think their thinner crust is nearly as good as their deep dish. They also have yummy Field Work IPAs on draft. A favorite Friday spot for next-level pizza and beer for this local.
author: Celie H.

description:
I ordered the cheese deep dish. Good pie but not quite in the top-tier of Chicago style deep dish.  Reminded me more of a Sicilian slice than deep dish. 

This pizza would definitely fall into the top of the second tier of Chicago's DD styled pizza. 

Bottom line: solid slice regardless of the style but please dont use the bs line i am from _____ so this makes me an expert.
author: Chris C.

description:
Pretty good, but sorry I think Patxi's is just a little bit better LOL. I don't think I fancy the cornmeal crust much, but the toppings and sauce are really flavorful. 

Service could use some work. I think by now everyone should know that SF places are full of bratty millenials. I'm pretty sure this was the place I called to ask about specials or types of pizzas, and the girl on the phone rudely told me that I could look at specials and pizzas on the website too. 

I don't give a f#!% what the website has, it takes 5 seconds to answer a potential customer's question over the phone, or go over specials. Don't be a entitled jerk. 

May or may not be back.
author: Marquis A.

description: Yuuuummm! This place was soo good! I hate that I didn't take a picture but their deep dish  pizza was perfection! The crust was very flaky compared to other deep dish pizza crusts that get really dry,  this one was the exact opposite. The marinara sauce was sweet and savory the perfect combination. We ordered wings, which were very tasty, and garlic bread which was cheesy and crispy(bomb). It went perfect with the marinara sauce! If you are in San Francisco, it is a must to come to this spot! Even if you are across the bridge (like me) go to SF and be a tourist, who knows you might stumble upon a gem like Little Star Pizza as well!
author: Jacky F.

description: Wanted to take in one last unique stop in San Fran before heading home, and Yelpers helped again!  Little Star deep dish was delish!! Cute little place, nothing fancy, but a true little gem that's definitely worth seeking out. Great crust, great sauce, cheesy --YUMMY!!
author: Kim H.

description: Finally, some good pizza!! I ordered the deep dish meateor 2.0, it was delicious.  Service is okay they try to serve you with a smile, but pizza was outstanding.
author: Lex R.

description:
Full disclaimer for this review: I grew up in Chicago, so I'm looking at the deep dish pizza from that point of view. Little Star deep dish pizza is not like Chicago deep dish pizza. Pizza is very much a subjective thing, so I'll tell you what my preferences are so you can compare. My favorite deep dish place in Chicago is Pequods. Gino's East, Giordano's, Uno's etc., none of those rival Pequods to me. Why do I like Pequods? Because of the caramelized crust, because of the huge and generous sausage and pepperoni toppings, and the way that when they serve it, the cheese is just oozing from each slice. 

Why don't I like Little Star as much? Because this pizza feels like a healthy version of deep dish to me. That might sound weird, but this pizza has a higher concentration of tomatoes to cheese than any deep dish pizza I've ever had in Chicago. It just tastes way too tomatoey for me. The cheese doesn't have that super ooey gooey thing going on here. The toppings aren't as decadent and bursting from the pizza. And I'm not a huge fan of that cornmeal crust.
author: Lin Z.

description: Really good deep dish pizza. I recommend the Little Star pie with ricotta, spinach, mushrooms, onion and garlic- so tasty. Righteous Diet Coke in and ice cold can, frosted glass, and ice. A great evening.
author: Michael B.

description:
Always wanted to come here after recommendations from my coworkers and housemate. And I'm glad I had an opportunity to try it out. 

As a party of 2, we were seated within 15 minutes and we ordered the following:

- Small Half And Half Deep Dish Pizza (1/2 Classic + pepperoni and 1/2 Brass Monkey aka Little Star + sausage)
- Spicy Chicken Wings

The pizza was the star of the show. I've had deep dish pizzas in Chicago (i.e. Lou Malnati's and Giordano's) and I have to say, this blew those away. There's something about the corn meal crust that adds a great flavor and feels a bit lighter. The brass monkey was enjoyable, as the combination of fixins felt very reminiscent of lasagna. The Classic was my FAVE! The texture and flavor combinations of the meat with green pepper, mushrooms and onions were delicious!

In conclusion...Little Star is packed with Big Star flavor!
author: Vincent L.

description:
So, so, so delicious!

My friend and I ordered a small deep dish pizza, half classic and half Little Star ($1 to mix pizzas). The portion was just right, the flavors were awesome, the pizza was perfectly cheesy, and the cornmeal crust was absolutely divine (in both flavor and texture). I loved both, but if I had to recommend one of the two, I'd actually choose the Little Star.

Really conveniently located near the Independent and Bi-Rite (read: dessert). Arrive early to avoid the wait! As with all deep dish pizza places, you'll need to wait 30 mins for your pizza.
author: Kelly R.

description:
I went to Berkeley and have sworn by Zachary's pizza for the larger part of my life.  When I first had little star my eyes grew wide.  F* Zachary's, I'm all about Little Star.  What makes it better?

- The sauce is right.  It's not sour, and it's not too-plentiful.  It's just the right amount, and it tastes great

- There aint no soggy stuff around.  They cook the pizza just right so the crust is crunch and crispy

- It just... is.... better.

Great service, good wine selection, great prices.  Can't beat Little Star.  I love their pizza!
author: Christine L.

description: The pizza is different than the usual, which in this case is the main plus. It's not incredible, and certainly nothing to write home about. Very expensive, but it's different, so there's that.
author: Jeremy E.

description: Great deep dish pizza. Been going to the different locations for years and always great food and service.
author: Mike K.

description: So I've been coming here for a couple years now, always great pizza. But today I was super bummed with the service. I called in a large deep dish Togo. Then ten minutes before it was ready my girl and I came in and sat at the bar and had a beer till it was ready. Half way through the beer we were asked to get out of our seats and make way for a reservation. We said cool just let us finish our beer. But no. They need the seats right now. Now up till that moment I never knew they reserved seats at the bar. But that's not the point. If you need my seats after I spent $45 and tipped on top of that. Then give me at lease ten minutes before you need me to move. The kids at Little Star need to learn how to deal with customers that keep them in business. Their rudeness makes me want to drop a great pizza for all the other pizzas out here in SF.
author: Domingo N.

description: First meal in San Francisco and it was very pleasant to find such a good pizza right around the corner of where I lived. The ambience was very pleasing as it is very chill and lay back spot for groups or families that is looking for good pizza and can accommodate the amount of people going. We went with 8 people and ordered Little star (vegetarian) with salami and chicken. I got to say the cheese and spinach combining with the tomato sauce was really well balanced and flavourful. If you guys are in San Francisco, do try their deep dish and little star, it's taste and ambience will pay for itself.
author: Chi K.

description: I "don't like" deep dish pizza but this was AMAZING. It's also better than Pi Pizzeria in St. Louis (lived there for 5 years)-- which supposedly has the same recipe. Maybe SF has better ingredients but this pizza was delicious!
author: Charlene B.

description:
Dark and cozy space that's deliciously comforting or sexy/dark depending on the time of day or night you're there.

Time stands still but for the wood-fired ovens that churn out either deep-dish or thin-crust pizza from 12-10/11 weekends, 5-10pm weekdays. 

We chose the olive oil/cornmeal thin crust and made it half 'n' half; Meateor (sausage, pepperoni, mushroom and onion) and the White pizza (juicy halved cherry tomatoes, thinly sliced zucchini with mozzarella and a sprinkling of goat cheese).

(Play on words: they should offer the "Neateor" with tofu, spinach, garlic & shallots- who's with me?) 

Both our halves were delicious and complementary: One was light and lemon- y and the Meateor, delicious and filling with generous helpings of sausage and pepperoni. I particularly liked the smoky taste of the white onion grilled in a wood-fire oven. 

They had a couple choices of hip beer on tap; I didn't notice if they had wine.

Photos of their Caprese salad look insanely good so I may have that as an add-on next time.

It's good to finally try this nearly legendary spot that's just a few blocks from my home. 

"About time!" people would say.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Tremendous! Delicious vegetarian options - we had half and half of Margherita and mushroom. Excellent service too.
author: Danguly D.

description: The ingredients were fresh and everything tasted super good. The pizza was enough also for 3 persons. This place is popular for a reason, so plan ahead with a reservation or an early call for takeout!
author: Aydan M.

description:
Came here as a tourist on the recommendation of a college friend who spent a decade living in San Francisco. As we were still learning to navigate the Muni, we ended up walking quite a few blocks more than we probably needed to, but it was totally worth it. 

Being from the Midwest I know deep-dish pizza (Chicago and Detroit-style pizzas are their own distinct things) but Little Star put its own delightful spin on it... Fresh-tasting is the best way to describe it. Satisfying and yummy. Vibe was funky and friendly. Waiter was slightly weird, but in the sweetest possible way. I loved it and will be back the next time I visit the Bay Area.
author: David T.

description:
You know this place has good deep dish pizza when you eat deep dish in Chicago and it's nothing compared to the deep dish here. I was so disappointed when I had pizza in Chicago.

It has been years since I've eaten here, but I just got back from Chicago and I just had to write this review because I still dream about the pizza from here, especially having a mediocre experience in Chicago where deep dish is supposed to be amazing. 

I remember spreading roasted garlic (straight from a whole bulb of garlic) onto my bread here. Omg. Amazing. 

Wait for me, my love. I'll be back.
author: Tiffany T.

description: I haven't had deep dish pizza in a long time, and this place made me feel foolish for it!  My wife and I are from Texas. We were recommended this restaurant from our friend (who also lives in Texas), and it was amazing!  We were very hungry, got the Mixed Salad and 1 deep dish 50/50 Pollo and Meateor pizza, and walked out stuffed, happy, and with leftovers!  I'd be back if I didn't live across the country.  But that probably won't stop me from returning at some point!
author: Mark W.

description: Great crispy crust pizza! Put our name on web based waiting list, arrived and was seated right away on a busy Friday night. Service was good too which is always expected yet nice to actually get these days!
author: Christy D.

description: Excellent service. Delicious salad and pizza. Great prices. Nice ambiance. Two thumbs up!
author: Anna E.

description: Fantastic food, our appetizer was really good and the pizza was great!
author: Charles B.

description:
Deep Dish, thin crust it doesn't matter. Little Star always seems to hit it out of the park. Sure the pizzas can be a tiny bit expensive but if you really think about it, how much more is it for a pie from as opposed to one from a dinky hole in the wall? $3-4 more bucks doesn't match the quality you get here. 

The best thing I would have to say about this establishment is the unique taste of the crust. Whomever thought up of a corn meal based crust you deserves to be up there with Aristotle.
author: Jethro P.

description: Really amazing deep dish pizza. I love the whole roasted garlic cloves studding the pizza. Service is friendly and gracious, and the hipsters lining up at the door don't ruin the comfortable ambiance of a neighborhood pizza house
author: Elizabeth O.

description: Little Star's deep dish pizza with its cornbread crust for extra special amazingness is the only deep dish pizza I like. Period. I actually dislike deep dish; I am a thin crust gal through and through. But wow is this place fantastic. The vegetarian Little Star pizza, in particular, is the titular pizza for a reason--get it!
author: Harley H.

description: I love deep dish and this place has never disappointed. I've dined in and had it delivered and the quality hasn't suffered.  My only complaint is that they don't have black olives as a topping.
author: L. W.

description:
Little star has been in my bookmarks for some time. When the roommate said he was craving pizza, I suggested Little star. Finally, I get to try their pizza! I know they're known for their deep dish, but I wasn't in a deep dish kind mood, so we stuck to their thin crust pizzas. We got take out of the following:

Spicy chicken wings ($11.50) - Pound of wings served with baby carrots & blue cheese dressing. I was expecting the usual buffalo wings, but I was pleasantly surprised. The wings were juicy, crunchy and had a nice little kick. 

Half White pie & half Pesto chicken ($19.50 for a small 12") - I couldn't decide which pizza I wanted, so I went for the half and half. The White pie ($19.25 for a small 12") came with a garlic infused olive oil base, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes & feta. The Pesto chicken ($19.50 for a small 12") came with a pesto base, roasted chicken, roasted red peppers, mushrooms & onions. Being the carnivore that I am, I was surprised that I liked the White pie the best. The zucchini,  tomatoes and feta made it very simple and delicious. And I loved the garlic olive oil base. I enjoyed the Chicken pesto as well. Who can go wrong with chicken and pesto sauce?! But I could have done w/o the roasted red peppers. I felt like the pesto, chicken, mushrooms & onions already made it a good slice. The peppers seemed out of place.

Meateor ($19.50 for a small 19") - Sausage, pepperoni, mushrooms & onions. This was the roommate's pizza. He loves meat pizzas so this was perfect for him! I love a good pepperoni & mushroom pizza, so I'm glad he picked this one so I could have a slice! I loved the quality of the toppings and pizza, but this one suffered since I got it for take out. It wasn't hot and melty like it should have been. Who wants lukewarm meat and cheese?!

I'd love to come back and try their deep dish pizzas. Would probably go for another half and half so I can try more things!
author: Elena N.

description: This was an AMAZING PLACE. Good pizza if you are in the area. Friendly staff and good ingredients. I highly recommend this place.
author: Amiyah P.

description:
I went to college in Chicago, the deep-dish capital of America... and HATED deep dish pizza. I don't get it. Too much sauce, too much cheese, flimsy crust... why ruin a good pizza?? I somehow managed to avoid deep dish for the last 5+ years.

Then, my boyfriend convinced me to try Little Star (hey I'll give everything a second chance). I had low expectations and not that much of an appetite. We ordered the original (small) with extra pepperoni and a couple drinks.

The pizza blew my mind, from the delicious sauce and toppings to the yummy cornmeal crust. WHY did I wait so long to try this place?? Yes it is heavy, but soooo good.

Service was great, the line wasn't too bad (for SF), and the vibes are cool. Nice wine and beer menu.

Little Star, you're my new favorite.
author: Vivian H.

description:
This place is super close to my house so it's my go to pizza spot. Honestly I think Zachary's is the best deep dish in the Bay Area (speaking as a Chicago native) but since Zachary's is in the east bay, this is a close second. Their thin crust is bomb too and it has never taken me over an hour to get my pizza (usually 30 mins or so). 

I've never eaten inside the restaurant so I can't speak for the ambiance or table service but the staff is always super friendly when I pick up my pizza. 

They also have great ingredient combinations for a specialty pizza!
author: Sarah F.

description: Very good excellent deep dish Chicago style pizza nice flavor Pizza Pizza sauce and Pizza dough Full of flavor
author: Frankie L.

description: This place used to be good but it has completely gone downhill. The crust is dry and tasteless. You pay so much for toppings and they're barely there. We paid $50+ for two pizzas which is CRAZY, and threw out most of both. There's so much better out there.
author: Nancy R.

description:
Deep dish pizza! Craving something hearty and delicious? Come here, and yes it's not like Chicago deep dish pizza. If everyone tried to be the same, what a very bland and un-colorful world this would be, n'est-ce pas? The crust is very unique because it has this crispy, crumbly texture to it that I've never experienced before. Pizza dough, for me anyhow, is one of the most important things in determining wether or not the pizza is good. It's hard to make dough, and when you have an establishment that not only does something unique, but makes it darn tasty, well....the rest of the ingredients will follow suite.

This place is awesome, there is a wait and I'm not sure of the traffic times, but expect it. There's a grocery store down the street that serves great ice cream, do that while you wait.
author: Will H.

description: the service was excellent and staff were friendly.  my gf and i had the half and half meator and classic pizza with wings.  a bit greasy but good.  we both liked the classic.  also made it in time before happy hour!  nice date place.
author: Stephen C.

description:
I always thought I liked deep dish pizza but I guess I was wrong when I came to the best deep pizza.  Numero uno ruined me because I liked their deep dish pizza so I anticipated this to be better.

The pizza was so different from what I imagined.  My anticipation of the yummy pizza was also strong that it was a disappointment.  After eating their pizza I now prefer thinner pizza.  

I didn't like all the filling inside the deep dish and there was so much sauce and it was just so thick that you couldn't eat more than one slice.  We ordered like 3 whole pizza for 5 of us that was way too many.  

I am not saying the pizza didn't taste good but it was not my favorite to have deep dish.  I rather taste the toasty pepperoni and be able to hold the pizza rather than use a knife and fork to eat pizza.
author: Toma C.

description: The thin crust was amazing! I had ordered the pizza with corn, red peppers and goat cheese. The combination was fantastic. The service is great too.
author: Vrunda S.

description: I'm a little biased since I'm not the biggest fan of deep dish pizza. Compared to deep dish pizza in Chicago like Lou Malnati's, this one did not make the cut. It was way too watery and there was almost a bed of tomato juice as I lifted up the first slice - making the crust all most and not crunch :( BUT compared to other deep dish pizzas in the city I think this is the best SF has yet to offer so far. Would only come back if I was really really craving some deep dish, but wouldn't make a special trip out for it.
author: Megan K.

description:
You will not find a better deep dish pizza. For the past two years I've tried to make it here whenever I'm in SF, and they've never disappointed. I recently got back from Chicago where I tried the top 3 recommended deep dish (what Chicago is known for) and I was completely let down due to the fact that I put my expectations above Little Star. None of them came close. 

The garlic bread is really good, and the deep dishes are amazing. A friend told me to get the meateor (pepperoni/sausage/onion) and I've stuck to it. Surprisingly (since I don't normally do leftovers) the deep dish are amazing the next day after being heated up. 

This is a great place to go with friends, or a date.
author: Carlos B.

description:
As I grow older, my love for simple foods like pizza continues to grow. When I was little, I didn't really care for it, but now I'm just in love.

This was my first official time eating deep dish pizza (first time didn't count because it was cold and flat from elsewhere).

All I can say is WOW. My friend and I split the 9" Little Star Deep Dish Pizza (Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic) and it was more than enough for the both of us. It costs $19.50 and takes about half an hour to make. It is definitely worth the wait. 

I just want abs....olutely all the bread in the world. For those who love those carbs as much as I do, you will die with the first bite of your pizza. The crust is SO GOOD... I'm dreaming about it right now. You know your pizza is perfectly baked when it's crunchy and fluffy at the same time. The cheese, tomato sauce, and veggies (topped with chili flakes of course) blend together all so well.

The atmosphere and ambiance is perfect for a date. Service is excellent. I will be back!
author: Lincy H.

description: Overpriced & overhyped. If the food tasted amazing I wouldn't feel as bad to splurge a little but when you splurge with high expectations and the food is just mediocre it's really disappointing. I would not come back here again. One star for little star
author: Yalda H.

description:
Solid Chicago style pizza that doesn't taste like you're eating 1,000 calories per slice.

Came here with a group of 4 people on a Saturday night without a reservation. We waited about 10 minutes to get a table, but were allowed to place our order ahead of time. Upon being seated, we ordered an appetizer of spicy wings (only deep dishes can be pre-ordered). Overall, service was speedy and both our appetizer and pizza came out at appropriate times.

The wings were pretty special--on a totally different level than the Popeyes a couple blocks down the street. They were moderately crisp without being overly drenched in oil which I liked. They were, on the other hand, pretty spicy in a peppery kind of way.

Now, for the pizza. We ordered the Mediterranean Chicken which had chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bells, green olives, onions, and feta cheese. A stray away from the typical meat lovers Chicago style pizza, but still a deep dish and just as savory. The acidity from the artichoke and olives blended perfectly with the seasoned chicken and marinara. The pizza tasted really special aside from the fact that it was a deep dish. The crunchy yet buttery crust was also really unique and appealing.

I must still be mesmerized by my meal from last night, but I can't yet say whether Little Star trumps Zachary's.. They both have great things going for them and I feel that even though both establishments serve deep dish pizzas, they are unique in their own ways that it'd be unfair to compare the two. Love them both though and I'm definitely a fan! 4.5 stars
author: Diana B.

description:
Ooooooh man. Better movie-night food there is not.

We ordered ahead of time for takeout since the place was very busy every night we had walked by since I got in town. There was some confusion as to which number to call for takeout versus for reservations, but the food trumped this slight inconvenience.

We ordered a thin crust sausage pizza which was adequate, but didn't blow me away. The highlight came with the deep dish pan pizza. We got the plain cheese pan pizza and I have never been so delighted by a plain pizza. At first I thought they had made a mistake and forgotten to add cheese when, in fact, they had layered the chunky tomato sauce (which was more a thick chutney-style sauce full of large pieces of tomato) over the cheese. 
This was a game-changer! We all agreed that the pan pizza reigned supreme and we gobbled it down in minutes. I swear I blacked out to an empty pizza box. 

The salad we ordered was also pretty freakin' surprising! It could not have been more vibrant, with cherry tomato slices, nuts, fabulous greens, etc. This. Salad. Was. Amazing.

I don't know what the dine-in experience is like, but I can guarantee that the food will leave you stuffed and yet wanting more. Hopefully you have a good friend with you who knows when you've had enough.
author: Andi P.

description:
First time here & came because of all the great reviews. Went around 6pm on a weekday & were seated right away. We ordered the garlic bread, which was good & a small Classic deep dish pizza to share. The pizza was delicious & I especially loved the crust & the cornmeal flavor. 
I do, however, think they could improve a bit on the atmosphere - kind of dark & depressing.  Overall, great place to grab a pizza.
author: Karey B.

description: Best pizza i've ever tasted in my entire life. Cant even call it pizza it's art. And still, i had the gluten free crust. That says ALOT about the quality of the food. 5 out of 5 easy!
author: Fanny M.

description:
My anticipation to try Little Star, has finally arrived on Sunday!

We ordered up the Brass Monkey Deep Dish on their (not so) Secret Menu and it was a bit of a letdown.  I mean, you can't go wrong with pizza for one thing, but their deep dish pizzas lacked this homely tomato sauce flavor.  The crust was good with a light crunch to it, but their deep dish pizza, wasn't hitting it off for me.  I've had better.

Their wait time and notification on when they have seats ready for you, was efficient.  

Service sufficed as well as their deep dish pizzas.

Little Star Pizza wasn't boosting with umph, to make it a Big Star Pizza!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Best deep dish in SF imo. A small and some wings are plenty for two people. A bit pricey but well worth it.
author: Ned W.

description:
So maybe I'm not a Chicago deep dish expert; I'm still a fan of Little Star. 

Why? Let me count the ways:

First: it's relatively easy to get a table on a weeknight around 6:30 (pre-Independent show). 

Second: friendly, down to earth staff. Not up in your face, but they don't forget about you either. 

Third: accurate order-table pizza arrival estimates. 

Fourth: tasty, tasty pizza. I prefer the deep dish, but thin crust usually has more interesting toppings. 

There's still some room for growth, though:

-I always end up VERY thirsty a couple hours later (high sodium factor, especially in the deep dish-- I think it's the tomatoes). 

-even when it's empty and my partner knows what we want to order while I'm on the next bus behind him, their "no seating incomplete parties" still applies and they wouldn't take the order. Not a huge deal, but these pizzas take at least 30 minutes-- help yourselves move the tables faster by allowing orders!
author: Krista L.

description:
Reasons why I love: 
-huge portion sizes
-delicious deep dish pizza without feeling overwhelmed with sauce
-you can split the pizza into two different types
-$3 PBRs
-great service
author: Derrick W.

description: Visiting the city and  after being recommended to try this restaurant and reading reviews, we went tonight and I ordered a Pollo pizza for take out. We waited 45 minutes for the pizza (I knew it would take at least some time cause we got DD). We took the pizza home, opened it up and realized IT WAS NOT POLLO. It was one of their other feature pizzas. There was no chicken, bacon or spinach, instead it was corn, sun-dried tomatoes and chillies. Not at all similar!!! We couldn't make it back to see what happened so ate some of it because we were hungry before putting it aside, and now I am writing this review. I am wondering how that could have happened. Vibe was great in the restaurant but so disappointed I didn't get my Pollo.
author: Kathleen L.

description:
I must be crazy since I actually think the deep dish pizza here is very delicious... If you are not into deep dish pizza, I would challenge you to try it out and tell me what you think. The crust is so nice that I can't stop eating it. And it has a lot of cheese inside to fulfill my craving for cheese as always. 

I tried classic and little star deep dish pizza, and somehow I'm all for the little star one. I like sausage on pizzas a lot, but I really enjoy the overwhelming tomatoey flavor paired just with plenty of cheese and vegetables. It sent my taste buds to heaven.

And, their chicken wings appetizer is great too!!! It's definitely good for sharing with a large group, as it has more than 20 wings inside I swear... And I couldn't help but having 8 wings before our pizza finally came out... It's fried to the right amount and seasoned perfectly with enough spiciness. Might be a challenge for some people! Just one more reason why you need to try Little Star.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
I love pizza and I'm sad because I'll never have any pizza as good as the one I had here. The deep dish pizza is perfect, the tomato sauce is so delicious and the crust is amazing.
My gf has an diary allergy so we asked dairy free and they provided which is awesome!
We also had the chicken wings (she did not use the cheese sauce) which were so yummy and tasty. 
I would definitely come back and also I will recommend to everyone that travels here.

Best food I've had in this trip.
author: Cristobal K.

description: I'm not normally a huge fan of deep dish pizza but I decided to try this place due to the high reviews and wow I'm so glad that I came here. I ordered the pound of wings appetizer for my girlfriend and I and the wings were small but there were so many and they were very easy to eat. We had the sausage pizza which was amazing. The crust was crunchy all of the way through and the middle was like other deep dish pizzas I've had where it's an inch of cheese. The amount of cheese was about the same as a normal pizza and the rest of the deep dish was sauce and ingredients. I even had some leftovers from the pizza and they still tasted amazing the next day. I would highly recommend this place to anyone going to sf for dinner.
author: Jeffrey B.

description: I really like this place! We got take out a couple times, the small size always fills both my boyfriend and me, and we usually have leftovers afterwards. Toppings are filling. Price is a bit expensive but the flavors are worth what you pay for.
author: Alice S.

description:
Deep Dish Pizza is the star attraction of Little Star, but the starburst wasn't the depth of the pizza pie ... the stars were the startlingly delish crust and toppings. While one huge Little Star Pizza obliterated my starvation, I was left a little starstruck by the friendliness of the starlet Hostess, a spicy starter of Chicken Wings, and a deep-dish pizza destined for stardom.

   Star light, star bright,
       At Little Star Pizza tonight;
   I wish I may, I wish I might
      Have the Deep Dish I wish tonight

A Large Deep Dish Pizza ($25) -- half Classic (Sausage, Mushrooms, Bell Peppers, and Onions) and half the Daily Special (Meatballs & Ricotta) -- was recommended by the hostess who placed the order prior to seating us. These 2 inch pizzas do take a little time. She was cool. The pizza was cooler. Our small group agreed the Meatball side was the better of the two. The the crust was near perfect ... strong and dry enough to hold the hefty toppings while soft enough to be delicious. (4 stars)

Spicy Chicken Wings ($11) was our appetizer. The wings were a little spicy. A single order was full pound of Wings served with a few Baby Carrots and basic Blue Cheese Dressing. (4 stars)

Parking meters were turned off on the street the evening we went, so, it surprisingly was easy to find a spot. Good luck. 

Little Star Pizza is a little pizza joint with some big pizzas and totally worthy of four little twinkling stars.
author: Michael S.

description:
My bf and I had little star as take out so i can't comment on much about the service here. We did call around 8ish and they quoted us 30 mins, for the pizza to be ready. When i got to little star to pick up the pizza, it had just come out because the boxes were so warm!!

Small CLassic: 5/5: WOW, i love this pizza! The crust was not at all soggy or greasy, it had a thick, cornmeal like crust which was delicious. It also had a good amount of sauce where it didn't make the pizza soggy or hard to hold. When i had patxis it was the exact opposite of little star. over sauced, too little toppings and a soggy crust. The toppings were plentiful, i can say i got plenty of meat , sauce and cheese in the pizza. It was better than what i had anticipated. Definitely coming back here for pizza again.

Garlic bread: 4/5: Delicious! i like that it looked like a pizza and that it was cheesy, but i wish there was a bit more garlic. Some pieces that they cut had no cheese and no garlic. Even distribution would be nice. But overall, really good garlic bread!

I would probably do takeout again, just cause the parking situation in this neighborhood is terrible. also the wait probably would have been long on a saturday night because the place isn't too big. Definitely coming back for more pizza!

Total for 2: $30
author: Stella J.

description: Came her on the spur of the moment before heading back to the east bay and glad we stopped! This place is top notch for pizza and deep dish if you like that...we had a thin crust and basically built our own toppings and the thin crust was flavorful and crunchy the pizza itself was delicious!!! We also had the garlic bread with a house made sauce and spicy wings those were perfectly seasoned with just the right amount of heat!! Loved them, if you're in the area for good pizza, wings and beer this is the place!!!
author: aiko b.

description:
OMG OMG OMG!  As most Yelp reviews attest, this pizza is amazing.  If you're in the mood for deep dish pizza in SF, this is unequivocally your spot (for thin crust / normal pizza, I'm still a major fan of Long Bridge Pizza Co. in the Dog Patch).  I can't speak to the restaurant service since I've only ordered take out but it was fairly dark, small, and generally intimate for a pizza place.  Since all of the pizza is made to order and Little Star is very popular, I recommend placing your order well in advance of when you plan to eat (~20 - 40 minutes) depending on time of day and day of week.  

The cornmeal crust really IS amazing and the ingredients are wholesome enough that you won't feel (too) gross the next morning.  Even if you're not a fan of deep dish pizza, I recommend giving Little Star a try - it may make you a deep dish convert.
author: Tom G.

description: Amazing pizza. Good people. I hope this place is there. This makes the area better than others!
author: Claire H.

description:
I already start drooling for this place a few blocks away!!!! SO impressed by their deep dish pizzas and the crust is my favorite part! 
If you love carbs/deep dish, like I do, you'll go crazy for this place like I did. Before I found Little Star, my favorite was Zachary's... But the cornmeal crust from here! It's a game changer. Crunchy on the outside, fluffy on the inside. Perfection. I could just eat it everyday. 

They don't have as many options on the menu for the deep dish, but the classic and little star combos are delicious. Other options are Mediterranean (chicken), vegetarian, and cheese. 
$1 upcharge for half-half pizzas. 

My table of 3 got the large 12" deep dish (half classic, half little star) to share the 8 slices between us, and it was perfect to have us completely full at the end.
The small 9" is good to share for 2! 

The place is cute and perfect for a date, or even groups. I'll definitely be back... Like today.
author: Audrey D.

description: Loved this place! The deep dish pizza was soooooo good, as well as the garlic bread. Fantastic customer service. A bit pricey, but would definitely come back.
author: Tony A.

description:
Every time I walk down Divisadero, I've nearly missed it for it's lack of display. Only one sign gives it away. Little Star PIzza doesn't require any marketing, I suppose. The recommendation of many San Franciscans as I've come to learn, had left me with little choice but to try this place. While parking in this neighborhood may not be easy, consider parking a few blocks down or around. Be sure to bring your friends, but not your bosses. 

The Caprese Salad: You'll find that the basil in this salad over powers much of the rest, as the other ingredients are more for texture than taste. The Caprese ends up being a good start for those who want a little bite rather than leafy greens. It isn't too oily as well, which I absolutely loved about this appetizer. 

The deep dish Mediterranean Chicken: Served in the famed Chicago deep dish style that may resemble Zachary's across town or in Berkeley, you'll find that this pizza pie will fill you up and more. Being good enough for two to three hungry guys the pie took a while to arrive to our table during a busy pre-dinner hour. You'll note the pie is filled with sauce that may ooze from your mouth as you try to fork and knife your way through it. The bread on the pizza pie isn't too thick, and so that leaves plenty of room for all the chicken, artichoke hearts and onions. 

While I may have left with bad breath, I can safely say my stomach was given some comfort food. Little Star Pizza is a gem, and among all the pizza joints in Bay Area this one sticks out. You can tell they want to stick to a small menu because they focus on a craft, and that is to make really amazing pizzas.
author: Mohib Q.

description: Deep dish pizza great, THIN crust pizza  HATED IT!   boring waste of money . Virtually undetectable tomato sauce .
author: K. K.

description:
We came around 8pm on a Saturday night and the place was packed. It was a 45 minute to 1 hour wait, and they ask for your number so they can contact you if you want to wander around. We decided to just wait on their couches and about 40 minutes later we were seated at the bar.

The bar seating is decently roomy and the plus side is fast service / drinks. We ordered the garlic bread and customized our own thin crust pizza. 

The garlic bread was basically like a small cheese pizza and extremely tasty. The custom thin crust pizza had cheese, garlic and olive oil base, pesto, and chicken. 

Everything tasted fresh although garlic bread + large thin crust pizza was too much for 2 people. If you want to order garlic bread, I'd recommend ordering small thin crust pizza.
author: Edward W.

description: Love love love this pizza!! The crust has a great flavor and the way they pile the thick sauce on top of the toppings melts my heart. They took  a NY thing mixed it with the Chicago crust to make something out of this world! I also got their cheesy bread and put zucchini on it ... Im very picky about my pie, this place nailed it. I highly recommend it, and try to eat it there every time I pass threw SF.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Ooey gooey cheesy deliciousness. You can literally smell the amazing pizza from half a block away. Follow your nose and go in - you really can't go wrong.

Came back here yesterday for the first time after a while. Ahhhh, the pizza is just so delicious - I'm getting hungry again just thinking about it. The deep dish pizzas are clearly the way to go. Don't bother even thinking of getting anything else. The cornmeal crust is amazing - only pizza where I actually look forward to getting to the crust.

The salads are fine too, but let's be honest. You're not coming to Little Star for the salads. Garlic bread is so-so.. You basically get a hunk of bread with a whole head of garlic on the side. Basically, you just need to stick with the deep dish pizzas - if you do that, you wont go wrong.

Oh, and happy hour! $4 house wine! I stopped listening at that point, but I think there are other happy hour specials as well :)
author: Gowri R.

description: I was looking forward to try the deep dish pizza...ah it was mediocre. Zachery's in the east bay still have the best deep dish.
author: anita s.

description: The best deep dish I've had outside of Chicago. Most places have super thick crust that gets soggy. Not here! Tons of toppings and the crust is the perfect thick was and flavor. Would 100% go back and try the other pizzas. One large is perfect for 3-4 people.
author: Sam B.

description:
SF food royalty for the everyperson. My boo introduced me to this place a few months ago, and it's all I can do to not stop by at least once a month! Here's what I've had in the past:

Mixed salad - even the small was huge!
Little Star (with and without sausage - that option is called "brass monkey") - incredible. I don't typically like feta, and luckily the taste isn't discernable. And I actually think the pizza without meat may be more delicious!
Vegetarian pizza - very good, but I prefer the Little Star.

Quite difficult not to overeat, but I'd say two slices of a large deep dish are more than enough for a full meal. Anything else = tummy ache!
author: Shendi X.

description: I usually prefer thin crust pizza, but Little Star's deep dish pizza defiantly hits the spot. So delicious!!
author: Anela M.

description:
Hands down my favorite place to get deep dish pizza! The bf and I love coming here. The wait is so worth it! We always get a small "Classic" with chicken instead of the sausage. The small is definitely enough for 2. But, today we got a large and obviously had some slices leftover to take home. 

We've also tried the mixed greens salad in the past and it's pretty standard. Their wings are decent. You really can't go wrong with their deep dish though. I love their sauce and the ingredients are fresh every time. Always a winner in our book! As far as drinks are concerned, the bf usually gets an Arrogant Bastard beer and recently I tried the Hey Kool-Aid champagne cocktail and it was alright.

Parking can be difficult. It takes us on average 20-30 mins to find parking. The longest we've ever had to wait was 30 mins. Don't be dissuaded by the long wait for a table. I feel like some people are impatient once they hear that they have to wait for an hour or longer and they just walk away. That just gives others the chance to get seated faster. We were once told that the wait for a table for 2 was going to be an hour and 15 mins. But, they texted us within 30 mins and a table had opened up for us. So, don't give up right away.

I mean, what else is there left to say that hasn't already been said? This place is great and their deep dish is amazing, granted I haven't had deep dish anywhere else. But, I don't mind staying loyal to this place. The service is always good too and I think it's neat how they send you a text when your table opens up if you aren't waiting inside. Hurry, you won't be disappointed!
author: Fallon P.

description:
Love love love the namesake: deep dish little star. Add artichokes to make it even better. Been getting the same thing for 15 years - Cannot get enough!

The mixed greens salad is also delicious. Homemade dressing and large chunks of Gorgonzola - yum!

Now you can call ahead and put your babe if the list. Ten stars.
author: Stacey R.

description:
The best deep dish in the city! Little star excels with its balance of crushed tomatoes and salty mozzarella cheese. Give yourself 30 minutes for any deep dish request and order before you get on the bus headed home from work (my plan). Their chili flakes are spicy and ingredients are fresh -- I've never been disappointed! 

Monday's are for meatballs! Remember to call and ask for the thin crust special if you're looking for something lighter. Be prepared for a wait, but know that everything delicious takes time. 

Thanks for the extra 10 pounds I've gained this year, little star! It was the best investment I've ever made :)
author: Isidro M.

description:
Little Star Pizza, you deserve a big star. 

I couldn't have ended my trip in San Francisco on a better note than I did at Little Star Pizza. With more than 2,000 reviews I had expected this place to be somewhat of a tourist trap, but it did not feel like it one bit. The space was small and quaint, giving it a cozy feeling especially with the dimmed lighting. I ordered the Mixed Salad and Mediterranean Chicken Deep Dish. In hindsight I would've completely skipped the Mixed Salad since the deep dish is where it's at! The cheese was perfectly ooey-gooey and not greasy like other deep dish pizzas from my past. Be warned that these pizzas are heavy so keep that in mind when planning your after-meal activity (i.e. don't be like me and walk 2 miles up steep hills immediately after).
author: Tiffany C.

description: All right! Someone who does deep dish right in SF! We've been to their Mission location as well and the staff is great at both.
author: Kristi L.

description:
Got lucky and found parking right in front! 

I stopped by Little Star on Thursday for dinner around 6:30pm with a few friends. Luckily there was no line at all and maybe a handful of diners at the tall tables near the bar. 

I'm gonna start by saying that I've never had a deep dish pizza before and one of my good friends told me that this may possibly be the best place to get some in sf.

The 4 of us were seated at one of the tables on the left side if the restaurant. The artwork here is pretty unique and the dim lighting puts a relaxing/romantic ambience on the dining experience (not a bad place for dates). The bad part about this is that it's difficult to take a good picture.

Our waitress was very attentive and always came by to make sure everything was okay. We ended up ordering the classic and Mediterranean chicken deep dish pizza to share (both small); our waitress informed us that a small pizza is 6 slices and feeds about 2 people. Honestly, I can eat quite a lot and surprisingly, 3 slices filled me up! Anyways, after ordering the deep dishes, our waitress told us that the pizzas would take about 30 or 35 minutes to cook so we decided to order some garlic bread so we wouldn't starve. 

The garlic bread came out in about 5 minutes and was basically a mini pizza. It was warm, fluffy, cheesy goodness that disappeared as soon as it came. The pizza arrived just on time passing a little over 30 minutes and we began to dig in.

Don't be embarrassed to take advantage of the forks and knives to avoid getting your hands messy with the pizza stuffings. The best of this particular pizza has got to be the crust; it is literally the best pizza crust ice ever had, it had this amazing crunch and wasn't too hard to bite through. The ingredients were all super fresh and meshed well with the flavors we ordered.

By the time we finished, there was a line going through the door but we weren't rushed whatsoever. In fact, or waitress helped refill our water pitcher and boxed the rest of the pizza for us. 

Overall, the service at Little Star is superb and the deep dish pizzas are amazing. Be prepared to wait at least 30 minutes for your order, and trust me, it's worth it.
author: Wiseley F.

description:
Disclaimer: ONLY for thin crust pizza. Sadly...I'm not a fan of deep dish :( Which, I know, is NOT their speciality, but hey. I wanted good pizza.

I've had the Italian Combo, Pesto Chicken, and Meateor.  I must say, this is what I would call comfort pizza. My favorite would have to be the Italian Combo - only because I added sun-dried tomatoes. I mean...who wouldn't?!  They don't really skimp on toppings, not too greasy, and a pretty good size.  You can do half and half for extra charge and add whatever toppings you'd like for another extra charge. Worth it in my opinion!

Pretty damn good pizza ... and I know my pizza.  I like the comfort-feel of it and the fact that it was hearty, yet not dripping with grease making you feel extremely bad about eating it. 

Cozy little place to eat if you choose to!  You can drink at the bar while you wait for a table.  Overall, I really like this place!! Reviews say deep dish is the way to go, but if you're not a fan, their thin crust is still really really good.
author: Steph S.

description:
Fast and friendly service. They have a handy feature on their website that allows you to add yourself to a waitlist before you get there. 

The pizza was very good. Not amazing destination pizza, but really good. 

Tip: everyone in your group needs to be there before they'll seat you, so this is not the best spot for casually meeting up with a large group.
author: Ashley Z.

description: Such a great little spot, and when I say little, I mean little. Even though we were able to get a table in the front window I still felt very squished in my seat and weaving my way to the bathroom and when it was full standing over a middle aged man as he fed his son pizza praying the bathroom door would open soon. The pizza is worth the tiny spot or get it to go and head up to the park. We went to The Independent after so it is in good distance of the venue.
author: Alison Q.

description: The music, the service, the salad and the gluten free pizza all came together for an awesome dinner.
author: Valerie P.

description:
I used to fear deep dish because the crust has classically been my least favorite part of the pizza and a bad tomato sauce could also ruin everything.  Perhaps it had to do with growing up on Domino's deliveries and thinking that was how all crust was created.  I always left it behind and never second guessed my approach, so the thought of deep dish was understandably troubling when the main composition of the pizza was more of the thing I detest.

So my first time at Little Star (circa 2008), 3 of us met for dinner and I reluctantly agreed to share a deep dish if we could also get a thin crust pizza (with pesto, b/c why subject myself to too much of a scary thing?).  Well that thin crust sure was tasty and just how I like my pizza....but that deep dish! whoa! I must admit I'd never had deep dish before, so I didn't really know what to expect, but I was very pleasantly surprised.  The heartiness of the toppings met with the crispiness of the crust was actually quite delicious.  There is just something about that cornmeal crust that's buttery and crispy and nothing like the bland over-inflated crust of my childhood.  

I was an infrequent diner at Little Star until I moved to an apartment a block away.  That's when everything changed.  Well, and my deep dish consumption increased.  Every time I go I order a deep dish Little Star and add sausage.  I just can't bring myself to try something else because the Little Star is just so perfect (I mean it is their namesake, no?).  Many a night I ordered a small deep dish to go, would trudge the 2 block roundtrip in the bitter San Francisco  wind and return home with my bounty.  4 slices for dinner, 2 for lunch the next day.  Mmmm.  Now that's if you're a hearty eater, like me...for many only 2 slices suffice to fill up.  Plus you shouldn't overlook sides and apps here.  The garlic cheesy bread satisfies the niche of returning me to my childhood favorite, the kale is delicious yet I tell myself it's healthy so it's all good, the salad (even a small) is piled high.  Plus they've often got a nice mix of lesser known beers on tap.

Alas I no longer live next door so my cravings for Little Star oft go unanswered.  So brave the elements, try to avoid the crowds, and take a chance on their deep dish...it's my favorite in the entire city.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: Pizza as good as advertised. Was able to get a table quick on a Mon nite but can see why other nites can be crowded. Watched lots of takeout orders while we ate.  The appetizers (garlic bread n hot wings) held us till deep dish arrived. Still had leftovers. But 3 college kids and a 60 something left satisfied and would return or order for takeout.
author: Simon S.

description: No honey?! Wtf? It's one of the only reasons why I came here...... Because my experience at blue line was amazing and they introduced me to honey on their pizza! Or else I would just go to Patxi's. Honey makes them different. Supes disappointed
author: Beverly H.

description:
We ordered a mixed green salad, Classic Deep Dish (9inches), and 2 glasses of wine. A small 9 inch pizza seems small, but it was actually more than enough for 2 people.  I'm not a fan of deep dish, but this pizza had the near perfect proportions of toppings/ingredients.

Perfect for 2 people. bill came to $46 plus tip
author: Angelica C.

description: The pizza was excellent. I had the deep dish vegetarian pizza which was great in taste. Good for pickup and casual dining.
author: Dhiman S.

description:
Phenomenal Epic deep dish pizza with the best chuck fresh tomato sauce. Honestly never thought tomato sauce could be so orgasmic.
Looks very close to a Chicago deep dish pizza.
Crust made from cornmeal that just crumbles in your mouth.
Amazing pizza toppings like New York.
Very Guormet!!
author: Hung L.

description: Delicious San Francisco pizza! I tried the thin crust and it was excellent -- and judging by the thousands of reviews, I'll have to go back for the deep dish. I ordered Little Star via Postmates to avoid the wait and it was a great experience.
author: Connie Q.

description: After a long day of moving into my new place, I decided to treat myself by coming here for dinner with a friend. The last time I been to Little Star was probably 5 years ago in Berkeley, so when I realized that there was one nearby, I had to come! Plus, I do miss the deep dish pizzas from Chicago. So we arrived around 5:30pm on a Friday night with an hour left of happy hour, whoo! We ordered the Crispy Kale ($5), Spicy Chicken Wings ($9), and BYO Deep Dish Pizza: small Cheese ($14) with Sausages ($2.75) and Feta ($1.85). To begin with the appetizers, the kale completely exceeded my expectations. It was baked with parmesan cheese on top, which was so delicious! A little bit of veggies to balance out your meal is always nice as well. For the wings, they were tiny but came in plenty. The flavor was okay, but still pretty good with the ranch dressing as a good snack before the main course. I was very excited for the pizza and it was just as great as I remembered it. It is comparable to the ones I've had in Chicago and is super filling. Never underestimate a deep dish pizza with all the fillings inside of it! I didn't taste so much of the feta, but still good. I only finished one slice, so took my other two home. They were even better the next day --yum! This is the spot for some good ol' comfort food with the dim-lit setting, which was quaint and intimate.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
So good! Would definitely recommend. 
Get the wings - a whole pound, enough to share with a big group, very well seasoned and cooked and comes with refreshing, crunchy carrots, and the deep dish - cornmeal crust is where it's at! So delicious.
author: Melody Y.

description:
Stopped in to try the deep dish pizza. We were unable to spot the place from the outside with their little sign, but managed to find it with the street address so NBD. Happened to be happy hour when we got in (weekdays 5-6) so we got an order of the chicken wings and garlic bread. The chicken wings were juicy and had just enough spice. I did not care for the dipping sauce that it came with. 

The marinara sauce that comes on the pizza and as a dipping sauce for the garlic bread is delicious! A fresh, robust, chunky sauce with a great balance of sweet and tart. I could eat it by the spoonful. 

We also ordered a classic deep dish pizza with added pepperoni. It was good but I just don't think I care for deep dish pizza. Regardless, the ingredients are of good quality and most importantly, taste fresh. 

Service was sub-par. We weren't clear who our server was and we were never asked how our meal was. Though, they were quick to pack us up, clear the dishes and present the bill. Felt like they were happy to get rid us out (even though the dinner crowd hadn't even arrive and there were plenty of empty tables). 

The marinara sauce deserves a 5 and food overall is a 4.5. Service and experience? 3 would be generous.
author: Kim G.

description: I eat a lot of pizza. There are only 3 pizza places I would have a 5 to in SF. Little Star is one of them. I've never had a deep dish pizza quite like this one. There is a perfect hint of cornbread taste in the crust that keeps you wanting more. The garlic bread is just covered in cheese (and not bad cheese). It's a must see spot.
author: Matt F.

description:
True test of a pizza...it tastes dam good the next day cold straight outta the fridge: It Does

Little Star is the best. I reviewed the Valencia location four years ago and my opinions of this great pizzeria have only grown over the years.

Their crust is just amazing: Thick buttery goodness.

Their Toppings are awesome: Fresh chunks of really tasty tomatoes, tasty sausage, rich, yet not over the top cheese....and other seasonings that make one amazing pie.

Their classic salad is a wonderful addition to an amazing pie...and great by itself as well. Fresh mixed greens, gorgonzola, cherry tomatoes, and toasted walnuts...all tossed in a light dressing.....Im getting shivers thinking about it.

The restaurant itself is tiny and dark. I usually get it to go and to that account parking is rather tricky so time accordingly.
author: David G.

description:
Great garlic bread .. also tried little star deep dish .. yummmm.. they have happy hours menu with some goodies on weekdays .. wasn't crowded on a Monday evening .
Don't accept Amex--jfyi
author: Feedback M.

description: The worst place to order the food out!!! You can wait for hours! Hostess n cashier are super arrogant!
author: Asel B.

description: Little star is a great pizza for your deep dish aficionados. They also have delivery via caviar which is cool if you live/work in the city. I had not had it for awhile but remembered it was quite good and I ordered it once again. I had the Little star which is " spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions and garlic" and it was delicious , especially with the signature crust.
author: Rod M.

description:
After trying pizza Delfina a while ago, I decided I wanted to try more pizza places, and Little Star Pizza seemed to rank pretty high up there. I walked in with my friend, and we were in our sneakers and casual attire. To our surprise, this place has a classy, dimly lit ambiance, with candles adorning every table. Definitely seems like a nice date place. We were torn between the deep dish classic and deep dish little star pizza, so we ended up with a small 9 inch deep dish with half of each! It took a grueling 30 minutes for it to be made, so we ordered an appetizer of garlic bread as well.
Overall, the pizza and garlic bread were both delicious! I preferred the classic to the little star though. The little star was a little too cheesy for my taste, but both were great! I would love to come back!
author: Corinna T.

description:
Amazing pizza and salad.  
Great service.
The waitress was nice and competent.
 And they have pacman!
author: Shay D.

description: Little star is pricey, but at the same time it's really good pizza. The deep dish is the best around in my opinion. It doesn't compare to Chicago but in Frisco, it's hard to beat.
author: Shaw D.

description: I must start by saying: WOW the deep dish is AMAZING!!!!! great service, delicious hot pizza. I'm vegetarian, and I ordered the deep dish with mushrooms, and it was great!!!! GREAT Crust, GREat sauce and general deliciousness.
author: Ian O.

description:
Between 4 friends, we split a large and each got to enjoy two hearty slices. I highly recommend getting the Little Star Deep Dish and adding sausage. Perfect combination of toppings. I also liked how their deep dish didn't feel overly saucy and of course, the corn meal crust!!! 

We got our deep dish to go on a busy Saturday night, and the overall wait took about 45 minutes. I'm hoping to dine in next time because the ambiance seems great.
author: Michelle C.

description: I gave Little Star another try, this time going into the restaurant and eating it there instead of delivery. There was such a difference this time and I'm not sure why because there should be lots of fillings whether its delivered or eaten in house, but it was yummy! The whole thing tasted so fresh, the crust was interesting, and it was chock full of cheese and other fillings this time! I definitely would eat here again!
author: Jen B.

description:
Best pizza in San Francisco. Period. 

I have been a life long lover of pizza but was never really a fan of deep dish...until I had Little Star. Do yourself a favor and order the garlic cheese bread + deep dish pepperoni, you will not be disappointed.
author: Curtis C.

description:
This place was great! I really really enjoyed my time here at Little Star Pizza.

When we first entered the place, I was prepared to wait a long time because I have been to the one in Berkeley. Its been around 2 years since. The wait was not very long if you prefer to stay at the bar. When we waited they suggested us to look at the menu and order while we wait because it takes about 30 minutes to make the pizza. We decided to customize our order and have a small size. 

THE SMALL IS GOOD FOR 2 PEOPLE... expect to not have any leftovers. 

The bartender was very attentive and courteous. She gave us water right away and asked if we wanted to order appetizers. We said no but bought a bottle of wine. The bartender wasn't really knowledgeable with the pinot grigio so she offered to let us try it before we bought the bottle, which was such a perfect idea. It was like a little mini wine testing. haha. But we ended up buying the pinot grigio. It tasted delicious!

Our customized pizza had:

1.)Salami
2.)Fried garlic
3.)Pesto
4.) 1 side mushrooms because my boy hates mushrooms. lol
5.) I forgot... sorry... lol but i know we had 5. 

It was the BEST COMBINATION EVER!!! Little Star should make this a dish because right when we took our first bite all we said was... "OMG.." simultaneously.. lol 

Anyway, Just come here.. its really really good... and I don't even like pizza.
author: Christopher G.

description: I can't even remember the last time I had deep dish pizza- so I was really excited to try this place on my recent visit to San Francisco!   We went for the classic pizza, and it was so amazing and delicious- and I loved the cornbread crust as that was something I have never had before!   My only issue was that there were a little too many tomatoes on top- so it felt like the tomatoes and sauce overpowered the rest of the taste.   Once I removed some it tasted great!
author: Sarina G.

description: We order from here all the time using the Caviar food delivery service.  I love their Little Star Deep Dish - spinach blended with ricotta, mushrooms and onions.  So good im drooling just thinking about it.  Its also amazing as left overs (if there is leftovers).  They have the best crust.
author: Sheenie L.

description: Delicious!! Try the garlic bread with artichokes and a Fieldwork IPA to go with the terrific pies
author: Scott D.

description: Great pizza!  Deep dish style with tasty sauce and many topping options.  When we are in SF we always get a Little Star pizza.  The place is always packed so we usually call in and pick up the pizza to avoid a long wait... all though it can still be hard to get through on their phone line.
author: Dave J.

description:
I tried for the first time Little Star Pizza (Dip Dish) last Wednesday, April 12.
