It was very delicious and I strongly recommend it.

The manager on duty was very friendly and efficient to take care of my order.

I ordered it over the phone and picked it up on time as was promised.
author: Jay S.

description: I feel like I was supposed to love the pizza here, but it was just okay and nothing super special. You can order deep dish or thin crust. My friend and I decided to go with the deep dish. We got the special that day, BBQ chicken pizza with pineapple and cilantro on top. The crust was very crunchy and didn't have the soft inside I was expecting. It was a more crunchy and dry crust. We were informed that it would take 30 minutes to come out so we also ordered a small mixed salad to share. The salad was fresh with just enough dressing which was nice. The salad and 9'' pizza was perfect to share between 2 people coming out to about $20/person. Overall, the food and service was good, but it didn't stand out to me.
author: Christie L.

description: Not going to lie.....the best pizza I have had outside of Chicago. And we're in San Fransisco. Great ingredients. Tasty sauce. Crisp crust. Don't go anywhere else if you are a pizza purist like me. 5 thumbs up!
author: Steve S.

description: It's always super busy so I've actually never eaten in, only ever done takeout, so I can't comment on a dine in experience. But food wise, it's pretty solid! I've only had the deep dish, and it's really filling. One small pizza was enough to fill me and 1 other friend. It was the perfect amount and prevented me from overeating :) we got the Classic with pepperoni substituting out the sausage. The cornmeal crust really stood out to me - it was super flavorful and really delicious with amazing texture. Not too hard, not too soft. I usually don't finish all my crust but I ate it all! The cheese, sauce, and toppings in the deep dish were all done well with good balance, though the bottom of the pizza does get a tad soggy.
author: Grace D.

description: Delicious sauce! The cornmeal crust is truly unique and tasty - definitely worth trying. Had a thin and thick pizza. Both solid. It's nice to find a pizza place that can do both Chicago deep dish and a great thin crust as well.  We had the Little Star deep dish and the Greek thin crust.  Both excellent choices that we would repeat next time.
author: Heather E.

description: Wings are great and pizza is really good, too. Great staff/service. I liked the soda selection. Worth it.
author: Sean S.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE. Amazing food and honestly the nicest staff ever. I left my backpack, and the server literally ran 3.5 blocks to return it to me!!! Ahhh!!! Love you little star!!!
author: Noah L.

description:
Soon after my review posted, the owner sincerely apologized for the long delay that we experienced and did his best to make things right.  I'm very appreciative; I'm very high on businesses that care about their customers, and I believe Little Star is such an establishment!

As for the pizza, I still really like their deep dish.  However, the crust was a little hard for me the last visit, not the way I like it.  Otherwise, delicious!
author: East Bay R.

description: I waited years and finally I made it back to eat some of this Delicious Pizza! There is no words and pictures that can do their food any justice! Little Star is a must when in SF!!!
author: Maria G.

description:
Not that this place needs any more glowing reviews (I mean, they only have 2,300+ reviews!)... but I wanted to throw my two cents in since I feel very strongly about pizza. As someone who recently moved from Chicago, I'm supposed to "know" what good "deep dish" is. Alright, sure I do. But, I'll admit... *whispers* I actually prefer California-style or New York-style pizza. *ahem* Anyway, having said that, my boyfriend and I went in the other night to Little Star. Knowing I'm not wild about deep dish (I'm an Angeleno), my boyfriend (who is a native Chicagoan) was happy to know I was pleased with Little Star. 

First off, for deep dish pizza, this met the requirement of being hearty. Yet Little Star managed to pull off the near-impossible(!): hearty but not disgustingly heavy. Let me break this down... the crust was slightly buttery, slightly golden, but not drenched in butter like the "typical" deep dish pizzas of Chicago. (I mean, those are downright pies -- which, again, many Chicagoans love but I do not.) Secondly, the deep dish (we ordered the classic) filling had the right proportions of cheese, tomato sauce, sausage, onion, and bell pepper. In other words, there wasn't one ingredient (technically, they aren't "toppings" since this isn't CA or NY style) that dominated. My boyfriend and I split a small 9" pizza (six slices). We wound up eating 3 slices each which - for deep dish pizza - sounds like quite the feat, but again, this was light enough where we needed to eat all three to be full. Personally, I think this is a good thing. I'll say it once more... Little Star managed to do the impossible: eat lots of deep dish without feeling gross afterward.

In terms of service, Little Star also delivered! No, not deliver pizza (*womp womp* insert bad joke). Little Star provided all-star service! Upon entering, the hostess took my cell number and said we'd be texted when our table was ready (she quoted us 35 minutes... it took about 25 that night). She was friendly and sat us at the bar (though I do wish she would've let us know we'd be taking seats at the bar). Our server was also the restaurant's bartender. She was friendly and checked in on us at all the right times. I didn't feel like she was lurking or un-attentive. I also ordered a glass of sauvignon blanc which went well with the pizza. The restaurant itself has no cohesive decorative theme. In fact, it's unclassifiable. It's modern yet vintage and then there are relics of random nostalgic toys and figurines hanging on shelves (especially near the bar area). I couldn't make sense of it, but somehow, this mishmash of design didn't distract from the experience. Lastly, this place can get pretty loud (I mean us millennials can't shut up even with all our smart phones). I wouldn't suggest bringing your folks visiting town here. Unless they thrive off high decibels and occasional bursts of screams, shouts, and laughter, they shouldn't dine here. Save Little Star for your friends' night out or (like in my case) a meal with your boo.

Aaaand finally, while they are known for their deep dish, I'd like to come back to try their thin crust (or as my Chicago-born boyfriend jokes, "California and New York flatbreads") (Psh!). We made a deal: I tried the deep dish for him, he needs to try the thin crust for me. This is what happens when a Southern Californian and a Midwesterner are in a relationship.
author: James Z.

description: This is one of the top 3 pizza spots in San Francisco. Fantastic pie with fantastic service. Its a loaded deep dish that might have you done after a slice but definitley 2. The crust is made of cornmeal(cornbread). Its a full course meal all in the slice. 2 thumbs up.
author: Reggie M.

description:
Was visiting SF for the weekend, and found this place nearby where we were staying. It's a very small place, with dim lighting, both a great place for a date or coming with friends. 

The wait was a little less than 30 minutes during dinner time, but fortunately we were able to get some wine and beer while we waited. The rosé was decent priced and very light and tasty. We also got a dark beer suggested by the bartender since they didn't have the one on the menu, and it was just as good. Unfortunately, I forgot the name, but it was a dark, light-tasting beer. It went great with the hot wings we ordered as an appetizer.

However, the star of the night was definitely the classic deep dish pizza. The ingredients tasted fresh and the tomatoes were chunky and sweet but not overbearing. All the ingredients harmonized well together. Although the wait for the pizza itself was a little long, it was definitely worth it. 

The service was friendly and helpful. The waiter suggested the specials and was constantly visiting our table. We Will definitely visit again when we're in town.
author: Herbert D.

description:
Always amazing, always fresh. 
I only get deep dish and I'm always beyond satisfied.
Ingredients are top quality and everything is made fresh and in house.
Best pizza  tomatoe sauce, amazing fresh mozzarella, fantastic dough flavor and always perfectly cooked. I can't ask for more
Best Chicago style pizza in SF hands down.
author: Zeek I.

description:
We came here exhausted and a little burnt out after attending a wedding in Sonoma and driving back to San Fran the next day for one last night in town before our flight back to Cleveland. The whole trip was pretty whirlwind and we really just needed food at this point. I had gone on a walk while my husband napped, but nothing was really catching my eye, so we headed out in the opposite direction for dinner and stumbled across this little joint. I can't wait to come back! 

We started with the mixed salad for three of us and it was perfect. I honestly could have just eaten that whole bowl of salad and been happy. After a weekend of vacation and celebrations, some greens were necessary. But when the pizza came, I knew that there was no way to come here for salad only. Seriously. We got the little star pizza, because how could we resist on our first visit? It only seemed right. The spinach and feta were creamy and delicious, as were the mushrooms. I'm not the hugest fan of deep dish pizza, but this was pretty amazing. I think I enjoyed this more than the deep dish pizza I had while visiting Chicago. I can't wait to come back and perhaps try their thin crust, though. I'm a sucker for a good thin crust.
author: Kaitlin D.

description: Pizza is really yummy, good menu. Like to stop there when visiting SF. Though dark and little place, would add more light. Kid friendly. Good staff.
author: Peter G.

description:
I use to drive every month to chicago, just to get a taste of their deepdish pizza. Since i moved here in the bay area, ive been in search for a place that would satisfy my craving. With the high rated reviews, yelp led me to Little Star. 

The wait time was around 30 mins, not bad for a friday night. We had to wait outside because the place was packed. Its nice that they have a txt system were you can check your wait status.

We ordered Chicken wings which were nicely flavored but overcooked, the meat was left very dry.

We ordered the classic deepdish, sauce was nicely flavored and meat was good, but crust was bland and hard. Chicago's deepdish crust is flavorful and flaky...

Place was very loud! Will not be good for kids.
author: Batchie B.

description: Excellent gluten free pizza!  My BF loves his deep dish. (And it really looked amazing). Also loved the kale appetizer. Happy hour all night on mon and tues. Unfortunately the service wasn't the great and we sat at the table near the front door with a curtain dividing us from the people waiting. People kept bumping me through the curtain and almost spilled my wine several times. Lucky for them the food spoke for itself. We will be coming back often.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I was at my aunt's place which was a few blocks away so my dad and I decided to walk here for dinner on a Friday night.  I didn't see a whole lot of parking on the street so that could be an issue for anybody not walking.  It took a couple of minutes before anybody noticed us at the door.  There were a lot of people here and at the bar.  The lighting gradually got darker was we approached the back where our table was.  There were candles at each table so at least there was some kind of lighting to read the menu. 

Our waiter told us a 9 inch pizza would be enough for two people and if it were two hungry people, then an appetizer would be enough in addition to the 9 inch deep dish pizza.  We ordered two Blue Paddle Pilsner ($4.75 each), the Spicy Chicken Wings ($11), and a 9 inch pizza that had half with the Mediterranean Chicken ($19.75 for 9 inch and $25.50 for 12 inch) and the other half with the Classic ($19.50 for 9 inch and $25 for 12 inch).  We felt that should be enough for both of us. 

The Spicy Chicken Wings came out first and there were 10 pieces.  It was pretty tasty and good.  I didn't think it was spicy, but it was pretty hot temperature-wise.  I nearly burned my fingers trying to hold it, but I also don't have callus on my fingertips since I haven't played guitar for a long time.  The pizza came later (maybe 30 minutes after we ordered) and it looked like one topping for the whole pizza but it wasn't.  The side with the Mediterranean Chicken was good as well as the side with the Classic.  When the pizza was hot, then it tasted good; however, as it got cooler, the pizza's taste went down as well.  The Blue Paddle Pilsner was not bad and I wouldn't have known what else to order since the selection on tap was limited to beer I've never drank before. 

Overall, pretty good food and I would recommend trying their deep dish pizzas.
author: Daniel H.

description:
My friends from the Golden Gate City advise that there at two Chicago style deep dish pizza restaurants that I must try if I'm in Northern CA. One is Patxi's and the other being Little Star. From the rumorville, Patxi's has the better sauce on top, while Little Star has the better crust on the bottom.

THE SLICE IS RIGHT
I ordered the smaller 9 inch size, rather than the larger 12 inch, knowing very well that these deep dish pizzas make your stomach quite full. One half of the Classic and the other fifty percent as the Little Star. It takes about 25 minutes to prepare. The Classic contains sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green bells. The Little Star has spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic. I'll make sure to add sausage to the Little Star next time, but more on that later.

I pretentiously favored the Classic, given that it had the combination of toppings that I liked. But, the side that contained the Little Star was far superior. Probably because of the salty and tangy taste of the different cheeses that the other half lacked. For not having any meat topping whatsoever, it was quite scrumptious.

The crust felt rather delicate, yet crisp with a flaky quality. Just the right amount of lightly sweet tomato sauce and seasoning. I normally don't enjoy deep dish pizzas that are super thick and bready, when it's so hard to chew because there's so much of the cornmeal crust. This however, was different. For those of you that's had the deep dish pizza crust at Masa of Echo Park in Southern CA, this version is way, way better.

If you're gonna have the Deep Dish, you gotta try the Thin Crust, right? I also heard that the Spicy Chicken Wings are worth a valiant effort, as well as the Cheesecake for dessert. Here's a link to their online website, in case you want to window shop their everyday menu. (http://www.littlestarpizza.com/index.html)

THE HIDDEN MENU
Two pies that are absent from the usual are - the Brass Monkey & the Abba Zabba (aka the Half Baked). Remember, how I said that I'd add sausage to the Little Star pizza? Well, that's the Brass Monkey. Almost like a lasagna, but not soggy. The Abba Zabba is any pie that's half cooked and then thrown into a TO GO box. At home, you cook it for another 25 minutes until it's ready to be served.
author: Chris C.

description: okay ...I'm in the 'hood' and this is my go to pizza parlor. BUT it is the best...I love their deep dish pizza (classic) and their wings and their burratta salad (the best).....You can not go wrong...
author: michael N.

description:
Little Star is a popular pizza place everyone raves about on Divisadero. 

It is sort of like Chicago/New York Pizzerria meets San Francisco Wine Bar. 

It has a darker, neutral grey colored decor, with 2 rows of tables and a bar in the back right. They have a decent list of wines, listed on the chalk board at the end of the bar. Whites, Reds, Draft Beers, bottled beers. 

The pizza can be deep dish a la The Windy City,  or thin crust a la Big Apple. The combos are fairly unique and have good ingredients, more for the foodie than the little league team. 

I had a small Greek pizza, that had sun-dried tomatoes, feta, olives, roasted garlic for $19. I helped to wash that down with a decent Malbec, normally $7.75 but I think I got the HH price of $6. Not sure if it was French or Argentina, but my guess is Argentina. Which was my small gesture of support for their loss in the World Cup finals today. 

The total was about $27. I couldn't finish the small pizza, as it was more of a medium size, with a nice thin crust, good ingredients, and stringy, melted cheese, but in a thin way, not an unmanageable thick gooey mess. So I took home a few slices. 

Parking is a b*tch on the city streets, so a lot of neighborhood types, and a few lucky parkers. The City lifted the Sunday Parking meters from activity, thank heaven those greedy city council types went too far with that one, which helps. I think it will help businesses in the City on Sundays too. 

Little Star is a Little Star. Good food, but think of it as a Wine Bar with good casual food, rather than a pizza place for your sports team. The prices will fit the former, not the latter.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
This place was perfect. We sat immediately, ordered, and were able to eat and make our show at the Independent just on time. We had the thin crust pizza: half pesto chicken and half Italian combo. It was delicious. Personally I preferred the Italian combo, but both were good and had a wonderful mixture of flavors. 

The garlic bread was super garlicky though which I love! I can't say it did any favors for my breath, but my taste buds sure enjoyed it. A very good pizza place with good vibes and awesome food!
author: Edwin A.

description:
Best pizza in the city, hands down. And as a native Chicagoan - it's one on the top 5 deep dishes you'll ever have.

Don't sleep on the thin as well. The cornmeal thin crust is amazing.
author: Bill J.

description:
delicious deep dish

friendly service

great cornmeal crust

the spinach pizza is absolutely delicious

definitely give it a try!!
author: Hemesh P.

description: Cool atmosphere, waiter was really nice...the pizza was just decent. I didn't care for the margarita pizza. We were seated quickly which was nice and got our in a good amount of time.
author: JoAnna E.

description: Great dining experience!!! Went to this place while visiting San Francisco and was not disappointed. They are located in a nice little area of SF not to far from downtown. The friendly customer service , dim lighting and casual environment only enhanced the atmosphere. I had the delicious spicy chicken wings with a Wyders pear cider for my appetizer. The Classic Little Star deep dish was the main course and was more than enough for two people.  If you come to The City you must visit.
author: Jamie C.

description: Ordered a white pie with meatballs as an addition (+$3) and it was SO GOOD. The meatballs were that night's special and was made in house. Adding a bit of a meat to an otherwise vegetarian pie sans tomato sauce was really a great call in my family's opinion. Granted, we didn't finish the pie, but we were very satisfied with our choice. The salad we ordered to start off our meal was fresh and dressed well....but raw onions are the bane of all my food experiences.
author: Elaine Y.

description: So the jury (Me, myself and I) has deliberated on the best Chicago style Deep dish this side of  Route 66! There is no clear winner. Zachary's (Berkeley) is amazing. Patxi's (San Francisco) too. Little Star is clearly a Yelp favorite, well deserved. The spot and area is nice. "The 5 Painted Ladies" of San Francisco are right around the corner. To me. It's a clear 3 way tie. 15 out of 10 stars for all 3! If you like a corn bread like crust, then Little Star  easily wins. Honestly, ALL 3 have amazing sauces (THATS A tie)! Patxi's starter salad and wings are better. Zachary's (I didn't partake in starter rounds, so no comment). Overall, I am a happy camper!!!!
author: Guillermo M.

description: We were looking for a go-to pizza parlor after moving back to SF from Brooklyn. Fresh mozzarella, oh baker where art thou? We're still searching for you, but the thin white pizza at Little Star is a mighty replacement for our mutant ninja turtle needs. If you aren't into feta cheese like me, which comes standard in the white pie, they allow a substitute ingredient in its place. In my case, I always go for the pepperoni or mushroom as a replacement depending on my level of carnivorousness. Oh yeah, the cornmeal crust adds a interesting twist of texture that I've never yet encountered before. They don't do delivery, but I've never had a problem calling in, getting an ETA, and dropping by to pick up without having much of a wait.
author: David L.

description: Great deep dish pizza. Hard to find good pizza in California but this place is awesome. The homemade sauce is excellent. One slice and I was full. They won't seat you until your entire party arrives though which is a bummer.
author: Lisa D.

description: This is the BEST pizza in the Bay Area. I love their staff at every location. Drinks, food and everything is always on point. You all do it right! Highly recommend the Divis location!
author: Amber C.

description:
The servers were really friendly and the wait time is not too long. While we wait, the hostess asked if we want to put in the order for a deep dish pizza since it takes bout 20 mins to make so once we get a table, it will be ready faster for us.

We ordered the small half and half deep dish (half pesto chicken and half classic) but they gave us the half Mediterranean and half classic. They switched our order with another table. The couple next to us got our order and we got their order. The server offered to make another small pesto chicken for us and the small Mediterranean for the couple on a thin crust instead. The kitchen made an extra large pesto chicken on a thin crust so the server gave it to us instead. Even though it's the wrong order, they fixed it right away which is a major plus. 

The Mediterranean was a bit bland to me or maybe because all I taste was the tomato sauce. I love the pesto chicken. You can taste the pesto and the garlic; plus the chicken is not too dry because usually the chicken gets a bit dry in pizza. If you love meat, the classic pizza is a good choice.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I came here By myself back in January. The server was very accommodating and he mentioned the special to me which wasn't on the menus it had meatballs ricotta cheese mushrooms and bell peppers. It was delicious just a warning it takes about 30
Mins to make a deep dish piZza! But it was worth the wait and the server kept checking up on me. So it was great!! I'd come back here again for sure if I was in SF :-)
author: Steffany D.

description: One of the few deep dish places in the city the service is terrific. The deep dish is pretty close to real Chicago style and is and the Kale and Caprese salads are very good.
author: N A.

description: We had the Pollo deep dish. By far the best pizza I've had anywhere, and I've lived in Italy. I love deep dish though, so that may be a bit biased. Nonetheless, it's amazing and I'd def be back
author: Daniela A.

description:
I'm not a fan of pizza but WOW.

We were in the neighborhood and decided to try little star. Parking took a few mins to find, all metered street parking. When we walked up, the place was packed! The waiting area was crowded and all tables were taken. Because it's so packed it can get quite noisy inside. I'm not surprised such a high rating and reviewed place has quite the wait. So be prepared for that. We weren't willing to wait so we ordered the little star to go. They freshly bake each pizza as they're ordered. So if you're planning on taking out you should call in advance and when dining in, expect to wait 30 mins for your pizza. 

It came out real hot. Too bad we had to drive back to East Bay. By the time we sat down to eat the pizza, it wasn't piping hot but still decently hot. Now the little star is a deep dish pizza with spinach, feta, ricotta, mushrooms, onions and garlic. The edge of the crust is nice and crispy while the inside was fluffy. The toppings on top were delicious. The combination of everything was just heavenly. 

I will definitely return to dine in and try some other combinations.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Finally got around to trying this place. Let it be known that I'm not a huge fan of deep dish pizza... I ended up eating 3 slices all by myself. So satisfying and had so much flavor! We ordered the "little star" and added sausage to it- you must add sausage! I can't imagine the pizza having the same taste without the added sausage. We shared the 9in and that was perfect for the two of us. Definitely left stuffed and satisfied!
author: Reina C.

description:
I get it, I get it, Little Star is a big star in the Alamo hood. Just check out the wait times. But hey, they're worth it. 

I am normally not a huge fan of deep dish pizza, but I think just because it's called pizza. It should clearly be called Cheese and Tomato Pie, don't you agree? I did, however, reluctantly go for the cavernous pie, and I was pleasantly surprised. Good sausage to cheese to salty crust ratio, but again. Not. A. Pizza. 

The atmosphere is wooden and dark, and perfect. Definitely a date spot. We sidled up to the bar, and had  their ginger champagne cocktails and wings while we waited, both were excellent. Be aware the hot wings are more of a dry rub, but they have a nice kick and are nice and juicy. 

You know how I feel about the pizza. 

Mr. Big Star/
Who do you think you are/ 
SF Little Star/
Lalala la laaaa
author: Evelyn A.

description:
What else can really be said!? 
This is some of the best deep dish I've ever had. I highly recommend going with more than you think you're going to eat. It might be even better reheated a few days later!
Mmmmmm
author: Sam A.

description:
I went here for my birthday meal last night, and let's just say I made a great decision. This place is definitely worth the wait (yes, expect there to be a line). 

The pizza here is oh so good- especially the White Pie (thin crust). This pizza is just fantastic! I normally only eat pizza with red sauce, but I was very impressed with the White Pie. It's simple, but very flavorful. 

The Little Star deep dish is really good as well, but surprisingly- I like the White Pie better. Normally, I would prefer deep dish over thin crust, but the White Pie completely won me over. 

Our server (Paul, I believe that's his name- hopefully I didn't get it wrong!) was incredibly friendly and very attentive. The place is warm and intimate- great dinner place all around. 

I will definitely be back! 

Ps. the salad here is good as well.
author: Becky W.

description:
LOVED IT!

This is one delicious spot. Thanks Yelp for sending me straight to good eats.

We went here late after seeing Daniel Tosh and all we kept smelling was pizza at nearby joints.

We ordered a small deep dish with tomato, onion and spinach. The pizza came piping hot and all the ingredients were amazing. The mozz was so cheesy and delicious. It had an awesome flavor. 

We also ordered as an app the garlic bread. Needless to say, we didn't take anything back to the hotel.  The ambiance was cool, good music and the staff were really nice.

Pro Tip: A small pizza is enough for 2 to share.

All in all, a 5 star experience and I can't wait to go back!
author: Kelly M.

description:
Absolutely fantastic deep dish!

As a native Chicagoan, I think I have pretty good standards when it comes to deep dish.  And this is probably the best I've had outside of the Windy City.

We just got a small sausage deep dish, and were glad we did.  It only took 40 minutes to prepare, which is super fast for deep dish.  The corn meal crust really tipped the scales on this place... A little thicker than I'm used to, but top notch nonetheless.

I highly recommend this place to any pizza fans  visiting San Francisco!
author: Jay J.

description:
Once again, this place stands the test of time. 

Ordered my togo order via Postmates to arrive prior to turning on some Steel Magnolias with a southern friend whilst we imbibed enough wine to kill a small mammal. 

The order consisted of a large caprese, spicy chicken wings, and the classic deep dish, add pepperoni. Guzzled a few bottles of Groth with it.

The pizza: not for beginners. It's cornmeal crusted, toasted to a perfect golden suppleness. Piled onto it is boatloads of cheese, sausage, onions. Topped with a rich and hearty tomato sauce that is decadent, perfect. I add to it some lovely spicy pepperoni slices for added mouth explosion. 

This review is kind of turning me on. I think I have a problem with my addiction. Clearly.

The service inside is always on point, their beer is always a great selection, and I can't describe how much I look forward to making another order. No other pizza I've encountered in the world compares to that of little star. Sorry Chicago.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Go with an empty stomach!
2 of us, who were both hungry, couldn't finish one of the large deep pan pizzas! We had the little star pizza which was delicious. Friendly staff too.
author: Cat B.

description:
Was craving Little Star during this holiday visit in SF.  Decided to order it for the fam.  SF is the best during the holiday season approaching Dec 25th -I notice that there isn't ANY traffic and my guess is that it's the slowest time of year for the city. Highly recommended you come by in the winter season : )
Anyways, let's get to it... Here's what I ordered:

Garlic Bread (Appetizers) 2x
$15.00
Very garlicy. Very nice. Warm bread topped with butter, fresh garlic, mozzarella & fresh basil

Spicy Chicken Wings (Appetizers)2x
$29.90
Spicy. But wouldn't order it again, since Little Star is known for it's pizza. My brother and his husband recommended a place in this city called "Wing Wings" that specializes with chicken. A pound of wings served with baby carrots & blue cheese dressing

Classic (Deep Dish Pizzas)
Deep Dish Size: 12" Large ($6.95)
$30.90
Very good and the reason why I was craving the Chicago style pizza. Heavy, but not too heavy. Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells

White Pie (Thin Crust Pizza)
Thin Crust Pizza Size: 16" Large ($6.50)
$29.45
Excellent. Would order it again. Garlic infused olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta

Money wise. Here's how it looked:
Subtotal: 105.25
Tax: 9.21
Delivery Fee: 11.98 and yes I was way too lazy to walk and pick it up because I'm in full R&R vacation mode. Sorry SF locals
Discount: -2.00
Delivery Tip: 33.00
Total: 157.44
author: Joel J.

description:
It is pizza but AMAZING!!  Server is amazing attentive but not annoying.  Good selection of tap and bottle beer.  The appetizer salad is good for two people. 
We have had the thin crust each time and it is great each time!!  This time we split a pizza veggies on one side and meat on the other and the cooks worked hard to keep everything separate. 
So worth the stop. Great pizza and atmosphere.
author: J G.

description:
Damm good Chicago deep dish pizza!

Better than anything in LA not as good as in Chicago 

Salad was meh and the can soda is pretty ghetto 

Small restaurant with an awkward layout but that pretty much sums up SF spots

This one place saved my SF trip because it drives me crazy how people always say how amazing SF food is but it's actually just above average ... Maybe you should travel some before you exclamation best ever lol 

Two big thumbs up from a person who is a die hard Chicago style pizza IN CHICAGO lover :)
author: Esmond K.

description:
First and foremost: DAMN. The pizza at this place was AMAZING.

My fiancé and I were out on the prowl for some Chicago deep dish while visiting SF, went to the almighty Yelp and settled on this little place! I say "little" because the restaurant itself is almost a hole in the wall type of place. But don't let appearances fool you!

We were greeted right as we walked in by the hostess and then told to order our take out in a little corner off of the bar. We ordered a large cheese pizza (with added mushrooms for a little extra charge) and some garlic bread. Both of these were exquisite! There were chunks of tomato in the sauce on top (this is Chicago style anyway!) which, as my fiancé Ben explained, was "surprising but great"! They were generous with the mushrooms, which overall added to the great flavor. The garlic bread was wonderful as well- highly recommend!

This place is small and I would try to make a reservation (if possible, not too sure)! The lighting is dim but it added to the relaxed vibe I got. I really enjoyed looking at all of the artwork on the walls while waiting for the bathroom (there's only one!).

Overall, great experience and we will definitely eat here when we come back to San Francisco!
author: Audrey A.

description:
TL;DR
Great deep dish pizza place. Ask about the special of the day. Can have different toppings on different halves. Order ahead for deep dish (takes about 40 min). Small: 2 people, large: 4 people.
---
I was out with AT and some of our friends and decided to have some pizza. And when you're in Lower Haight, of course you want to go to Little Star. One in our group was vegetarian, so we weren't sure if we would have to do a full vegetarian pizza. Lo' and behold, Little Star was able to do half-and-half. We ordered a large pizza with half Mediterranean chicken, half vegetarian. Note: small-good for 2 people; large (8 pieces)-good for 4 people.

Of course we decided to order ahead, since we knew deep dish pizzas take a while to bake. The estimated time was something like 40-45 min. In the meantime, we checked out some of the shops on Divis. We arrived just before the estimate window, and were  seated anyways. Note that the interior is small, so you may not be able to get a table without waiting (unless you're lucky like we were). Upon being seated, we were asked if we were interested in the daily special, which sounded amazing. Unfortunately, we had already ordered and our pizza was probably just about ready by that point. So make sure to ask about the special, even if ordering ahead!

All in all, one of my favorite pizza places ever.
author: Julia N.

description: $25 for a deep dish small half and half pizza with extra chicken. I think it's pretty pricey for that tiny pizza. It's definitely a two-ish person pizza (6 slices). It also wasn't as flavorful as I thought it was going to be. I could mostly taste tomato, even though we ordered sausage, spinach, garlic, mozzarella, and mushroom in it. I feel like we could mostly taste the tomato and only the texture of the meat. I think they're a bit lax on that considering how much we spent on it. It was a 40 minute wait for our pizza. I think they could do better.
author: Lyra C.

description:
Grabbed a Chicago style pizza here one hungry day in SF. The people I was with weren't fans of Chicago, but in natural fashion I pushed for it simply because it was more food! haha. Quantity aside, this pizza was delicious!! I ignored all signs that my body was satiated and pushed for more knowing the pizza will not be this good the next day as leftovers. 

The place is very dark, and has a quiet feel, though I wouldn't say romantic. Just dark and quiet. WORTH THE STOP if you're nearby! Walk it off at nearby Alamo Park!
author: Stephen R.

description: I asked the waiter what the best tasting items on the menu were. He suggested for us to order salad, bread sticks, and a deep dish pizza. The salad and breadsticks were fine, but the pizza was not very good. It took almost an hour to get to the table, and I was looking forward to it since it was supposed to be the "little star" of our meal. It was okay..
author: J L.

description:
In response to my candid (ok - honest) review, the owner pointed out that it is MTA's fault that they don't have a loading space (sure - blame it on the City, but perhaps a valid point? Difficult to know) . . . .but wouldn't a reasonable (pizza) restaurant owner find a delivery service to (I don't know) circumvent the pizza take-out (clearly impossible due to MTA policy)/delivery conundrum? 

I'm just saying - A+ pizza plus F- service = epic fail/non-starter. . .
author: Rachel S.

description:
Pizza heaven!

Came here on a Saturday night. The place was packed! We went to a bar next door to get drinks while waiting. The restaurant is also close to Fly Bar as well.

The restaurant provides a dark intimate atmosphere, which is perfect for either large groups or for a date. We ordered a couple appetizers to start and two pizzas. 

Appetizers:
Cheese Bread: Just what you expected! The cheese bread consisted of a thin warm layer of cheese and herb flavor on top of crisp buttery bread. I could have eaten 10 of these if the pizza didn't come out.

Chicken Wings: Classic dish and flavor. The quality is a lot better than the quality of typical chicken wings at a bar. The dish came with ranch and celery which paired well.

Pizzas:
Classic: I've had quite a few deep dish pizzas, and this was probably one of the best ones I've had. The cheese, sauce, mushroom, and sausage were all perfectly balanced and not overpowering at all. The deep dish filling was perfect with the crust. 

Note: The pizzas take about 30 -40 minutes to make! Be sure to order ahead when waiting with the waiter so when your party is seated the pizza wait won't be long.

WINE: The restaurant offers a wide variety of wine with the Pizza. Amazing options to cleanse your palate with the pizza flavor for a delicious bite each time.

Overall, I'll be coming back on my next pizza craving!
author: Stephen C.

description:
They have some of the best pizza I've ever had, deep dish or otherwise. The cornmeal crust is delicious and unique. Baked perfectly so it's a bit crispy on the outside but a little bit soft in the middle without being mushy. The toppings are always fresh and just the right amount. All of their ingredients are fresh for that matter and top quality. 

I usually order takeout and it's a 30 minute to an hour wait time. They are always busy!  So definitely go ahead and order as early as you can. I've eaten in once or twice and the atmosphere was great though the service was not top notch. Not bad either, but definitely something to work on if they want more people to eat in and spend some more on their great beer list!

They have a veggie option and will make it without cheese upon request. They generally let you substitute one topping free of charge. 

It's a little pricey at $30 for a large, but compared to the "cheap" pizzas around here which run at only about $10 less, it's well worth the extra $ for top notch taste and quality.
author: Natalie W.

description:
This deep dish here is alright. I know it's a fierce competitor to Zach's in Oakland and Patxi's within SF, but I thought the overall experience was okay. 

We ordered the off menu "Brass Monkey" which is their original "Little Star" pizza but with additional sausage. Perhaps the spinach made the pizza crust on the bottom too soggy but I prefer my deep dish crust to be more firm. With that said, the overall pizza was lacking the robustness that I'm used to like at Patxi's. Overall taste was still very flavorful. I managed to devour half the pizza instead of the usual 1-2 slices when eating Chicago style pizzas.

Service is simple since you order your pizza as you wait in line.When you're finally seated, the pizza is dropped off & you're left alone to enjoy it.

If you're not already aware, Little Star pizza is all over the peninsula underneath the brand "Blue Line" pizza so there's no need to brave the long lines at this location if you're outside SF. But if you're in the city & prefer to stand in long lines like the rest of us (http://sanfranciscowaits.tumblr.com/), the usage of noshlist.com for table wait listing is very welcome.
author: Steven C.

description: Some of the best damn Chicago-style deep-dish pizza I've ever had. Brass Monkey for the win!
author: Colin S.

description:
My confession: 
I fully rejected the idea of coming to Little Star Pizza when I heard they specialize in deep dish pizza. I turned my nose up at the thought that the great reviews were accurate. I wanted to scream "no way!" when a friend suggested coming here for dinner, but I decided to be polite and cave in. 

My revelation: 
Wow, every deep dish pizza I've ever had elsewhere has always been a sloppy soggy mess -- but not at Little Star. This pizza was actually really great. What makes this pizza stand out is that the crust. It's phenomenal. It's not doughy, undercooked, and disgustingly soggy. It is in fact excellent. It is crisp and delicious and holds the toppings in-tact. It has made me a convert. The thin crust pizza was thicker than I normally like but I enjoyed it as well. Little Star does it right.   

My experience: 
Mind blown and rash opinions disproved. $40 for two small pizzas (and two sodas) split across three of us. We had the deep dish Brassmonkey (Little Star Pizza + Sausage) and a thin crust White Pizza. This proved to be a perfect amount of food.
author: Meana K.

description: I love Pizza and this is the best Pizza I have ever eaten. It is delicious and the service is really good. I came there with Steven, and he also spoke highly of this restaurant. I will come back for the Pizza again. Great experience.
author: Michael G.

description:
Seems like all the popular places in SF have at least an hour wait. My group and I were tired from sightseeing earlier in the day and didn't want to have to wait another hour to eat. And we didn't want to compromise the quality of our meal for time. We came across Little Star and it was the answer to our foodie dilemma. 

We called in our order for take out which was a large pizza half little star and half vegetarian toppings with an order of wings and the caprese salad. It was just a 30 min wait for the food to be ready so we made a quick market run for drinks. When we got back the order was ready to go. 

Headed home and started to dig in! It was all we had hoped for! The deep dish pizza was perfectly done. Wings nicely spiced. And the caprese salad was fresh!

If you're looking for great food with out the wait I would definitely recommend Little Star. I look forward to trying out their other deep dish pizzas the next time I'm in SF.
author: Leda T.

description: This is hands-down my all-time favorite pizza.  Even if you don't like deep dish, just give it a shot.  If you don't like it, you have terrible taste and probably listen to jazz fusion
author: Erik G.

description:
Very good for both deep-dish and thin crust pizza. Deep dish is the closest I've tasted to Chicago pizza outside of Chicago (just needs those long links of sausage instead of the bits) though a bit heavy for regular pizza night.

Thin crust is delicious for traditional pepperoni - just not many interesting pizzas. 

Also wish they had a better salad/appetizer selection. Sometimes you need some greens with your pizza and nothing on their salad menu is that exciting.
author: Alana R.

description: Another great lunch at Little Star Pizza. We drove two hours to order the Greek Style Pizza, garlic bread and the mixed salad with Gorgonzola...yum!
author: Faith S.

description:
The deep dish pizzas here are amazing. I've tried the classic deep dish pizza and the meatero thin crust pizza, they're freshly made and with the perfect ratio of meat to cheese to crust. FYI there's a 30 minute wait for deep dish pizzas, so I recommend placing an order as soon as you're placed on the waiting list for a table. 

Service is good-the servers are fast and attentive.
author: Ruby K.

description: My boyfriend and I were hungry after checking out the Painted Ladies, and followed the Yelp reviews to Little Star Pizza! We were the first to arrive, as they just opened for lunch. We ordered the Caprese Salad that came with plenty balsamic vinegar and olive oil, rustic bread, green and calamata olives, fresh tomatoes and mozzarella. We ordered the 9" deep dish classic + pepperoni thinking we wanted a "light" lunch...well, we were wrong! This filled us up, but our stomachs were happy. The crust was delicious, and I don't like crust. It wasn't soggy or greasy like most deep dish pizzas I've had. The red sauce was perfectly seasoned, and the proportion of the toppings was well balanced. A+ for service too!
author: Lisa U.

description:
So so so delicious and worth it! 

Even though it is known for deep dish, the thin crust is also solid. I came in a group of 4 and we split a Little Star and a thin crust special of the day, which was basically like the Pesto Chicken but it also had some bacon (bonus!) on it. I was surprised to find I loved the thin crust more! 

Can't wait to come back. Great for sharing and large groups, and even for taking home.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I might get some shit from my fellow Yelpers, but Little Star Pizza just did not do our deep dish cravings justice. First off, we walked in at 9:30 pm when they close at 10, so our waitress was grumpy and gave us attitude the entire night until we turned around and asked for the bill; her attitude did a total 180. 

We ordered a deep dish and built our own-mushrooms, salami, sausage, and sundried tomatoes. Save the sundried tomatoes for a pesto pizza because they just don't go great with the tomato stuff on their standard deep dish pizzas. The sundried tomatoes added a sour flavor. As for mushrooms, salami, and sausage, there was not much of any at all. I actually forgot we ordered salami until I ate the leftovers the next day in a brightly lit room and saw a piece. The cornmeal crust had good texture but wasn't impressed with the flavor. Something was missing, but we couldn't seem to pinpoint what. 

We asked the waitress how big a small size was and the size she made with her hands looked like a tiny frozen personal sized pizza so we ordered a large. LIAR. Big mistake. The large wasn't as big as a normal large sized pizza elsewhere, but the small definitely wouldnt have been as small as she had shown. The two of us each had one slice then tapped out cause it was so rich and had so much cheese on it-the one thing we actually enjoyed. $36 for a pizza is a no-no when Costco sells better tasting and same sized deep dish pizzas for $10. Sorry, but you have been outshined Little Star!
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
Loved the thin crust pizza we got with pepperoni, olives, spinach and anchovies. Really nice crispy crust. I could have used a bit more spinach but other than that, I was really happy with our pie!

The wait can be long but we left our cell number and went to another bar for a drink while waiting.
author: Ada C.

description:
First off, the garlic bread is absolutely spectacular. I'm a sucker for good bread and this stuff was to die for. Little Star bakes it similarly to pizza with a bit of cheese, garlic and butter. It's a little bit cheesy, a little bit garlicky and a whole lot of delicious.

Now the pizza. I shared the larger 12'' deep dish pizza of the day (meatballs, ricotta cheese, mushrooms, and spinach) with my lunch buddy. Just a warning, deep dish pizzas take 30 minutes to bake so if you don't order before coming, there is a little bit of a wait. The pizza itself was dressed with quite a lot of the toppings. However, in my opinion there was a little too much tomato sauce and too little cheese. Eating it reminded me more of eating pasta than pizza. The crust which, personally, is a highlight of pizza paled in comparison to that of the garlic bread. However, the combinations of the toppings was yummy.

I would have given Little Star 3 stars had I just reviewed the pizza. However, the garlic bread really put my experience over the top. Thumbs up!
author: Robert L.

description:
This place is like crack for pizza addicts - best pizza ever! I've had deep dish pizza in Chicago - and this (almost) beats it. Why? The ingredients. I have *never* tasted fresher toppings than on the pizzas here (probably true for most of SF anyway) 

Their chicken wings look really plain, but are beyond delicious. Whimsical decor, a jukebox and great food - what's not to like
author: Vishal J.

description: They were very accommodating for our party of 8 and a large stroller.  Although it was a squeeze, we all made it work.  I like that they're flexible with ordering split pizzas too.  I can't remember what we tried but we did a salad, a thin & thick crust pizza, it was good.
author: Meredith K.

description:
What an adorable little find in SF! This was by far the best restaurant we ate at all trip! The place is very small, maybe around 20 tables with a small bar. 

We ended up doing 1 small pizza, half of thin crust pesto chicken and the other half was their special. Their special was an olive oil based sauce with tomatoes, garlic, basil, and goat cheese. DELICIOUS!!! 

We enjoyed that this restaurant had deep dish pizzas as well as the thin crusted ones too! We weren't terribly hunger so the thin crust was perfect for us!

Their bar was limited, 2 white wine selections, about 5 red wines, a few champagne cocktails, and about 5 beers. It was perfect for us but if you are looking for a big bar menu this isn't for you.
author: Jena D.

description: The best deep dish pizza I've found. I daydream about it often and it brings me so much joy to eat. I'm sensitive to dairy and my sister is lactose intolerant, but we gladly deal with the stomach pain and 45 minute drive for this meal. So delicious and so worth it.
author: Taylor O.

description:
Little Star was recommended by a colleague, and it certainly didn't disappoint! I'd say the deep dish is about as good as you'll find outside of Chicago. However, to me, it still doesn't compare to deep dish pizza from Chicago (there's just something about it... mmm...).

I came by myself while on business, and was seated promptly. The service was pretty straightforward (I knew what I wanted when I walked in, and only had 45 minutes or so to order and eat) but helpful. The pizza itself was the best deep dish I've had in the Bay Area, and I ate THE ENTIRE THING! I'd definitely come back.
author: Ezra B.

description:
We went to Little Star, because we had heard it compares well to Zachary's.  Well, Little Star isn't Zachary's, but that's not a bad thing.

The wife doesn't care for the soggy stuffed crust at Zachary's, so the crust at Little Star won rave reviews from her. The cornmeal crust is nice and thick and slightly crunchy, and the cheese and tomato sauce kicks it up a notch in a big way. The sauce is very similar to Zachary's.  All in all, it's delicious, delicious, delicious.

Just don't get the garlic bread, it was a dud.

So yeah, Little Star is good, in a different way than Zach's, but also in a similar way.
author: Nadeem A.

description:
45min wait on a Sat night (7:30pm) for 4.

1 deep dish and 1 thin crust (both Small sizes) was enough for 4 girls. Had leftovers. 

- Classic deep dish = yum!
- Thin crust chicken pesto = meh, not as much taste. Albeit I was sick so only half of my tastebuds were functional. But still. 

$20 per small/9" pizza = bit pricey. 

Atmosphere = a nice, water-served-in-glass-bottles type place. Not your typical hole-in-the-wall pizza joint.
author: An Y.

description: Meatball pizza with house made meatballs. rivals any Chicago deep dish. Amazing. I was blown away. Definitely worth the $'s. You won't be disappointed. Trust me.
author: Bill T.

description:
Officially my favorite Chicago style deep dish pizza in the Bay.  Friendly staff.  I'm a fan!

I'm T-C[hung]ry.  Let's Eat!
author: Thomas C.

description:
I really can't complain. I've been to the one in Albany before, and was in SF and craving some deep dish so we decided to hit his place up. This place is just as great as the Albany location. 

I'm not sure if it's the best deep dish in the Bay, but it's pretty damn close. The deep dish is out of this world. Don't get anything else. 

Overall, this place deserves all the price it's receiving. Couldn't find any faults. The place is real homey as well. Only problem, is good luck with parking.
author: Benny H.

description:
We ordered to go so I didn't actually eat at the restaurant, but just looking inside the restaurant I was a little surprised. Usually when I think of a pizza place I think of a bright, loud restaurant with maybe a basketball game on...you know what I'm talking about! But this restaurant has a very nice atmosphere unlike what I'm used to...so I think it's definitely a nice place to go to on a date.

We ordered the small deep dish classic pizza. For two people, it's the perfect size. And it's so delicious! I'm a VERY picky eater...I don't like onions, mushrooms, olives, bell peppers...I can keep going on and on. Well..the classic happens to have mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers. Great. But.....I still loved it. Yeah...that's how good it was! I HATE combination pizza but this deep dish pizza is too amazing..!

Minus one star because I wasn't crazy over the crust. It was very.....eh.
author: Cathy C.

description:
On Vacation and a local friend took me and my GF to this place.

Interesting cocktails and beer selection. Appetizers were the chicken wings which were excellent. They came with a spicy "cajun" like breading which looked unappealing but was very good and hard to stop eating.

Pizza was great and the crust was a stand out from other Deep Dish pizzas. The crust was a corn bread flavor and texture and was not soggy or greasy. Very good with the mix of toppings and was too heavy or too light on any one element. By the way, I ate the leftovers cold, it was still good the next day.

Only complaints is that the restaurant was a bit small and crowded but I excepted as this is a great pizza place and popular with the locals. Do not miss out if you are in town.
author: Chad M.

description: Came here because of outrageous reviews. Came and was put on the wait list which was not bad because we got parking right out front and waited in the car. They have a great waiting system that uses text to tell you how long your wait is - very convenient. The service there is a1. I liked the pizza it was different the corn meal crust is great however I didn't care to much for the sauce it was too much for me. It's a tad pricey but if you like this style of pizza you will most likely love it. I would definitely come back again to try a different dish.
author: Lily A.

description: Thin-crust vegetarian pizza, NO cheese ADD spinach: a vegan's dream! The staff is friendly and the pizza is delicious (now if only they would open a North Bay location...)
author: Jenny S.

description: These guys make the greatest pizza ever! I love the deep dish with cornbread crust! Even their thin crust pizza's are amazing as well. They have lots of choices and many other items to try. We order using a food app and have never been at the location. All their ingredients are fresh and really taste great! Super good chicken thin crust, or sausage, both! Thank you for providing us with such great pizza's and an awesome deep dish!!!
author: Kirk M.

description: Great pizza..some of the best wings I've ever had..and i am a wing person so I have tried them all over the u.s. I can't wait to go back to Frisco next month to get some. Definitely recommend this place. And it will be somewhat of a wait it's a small place.
author: Tiffanie G.

description: Pizza is amazing, should be named BIG star pizza!  Whether you order thin or deep dish, you will not be disappointed.  We tried thin crust selections of  Margherita and Pear and Bacon (Pancetta chunks of love), both are excellent, crust is thin and crunchy, toppings are perfectly proportioned (that's important to me!).  Deep dish we dabbled with the Little Star and Classic.  I'm usually not a deep dish pizza fan, but this deep dish delivers with not too much crust or cheese, perfect balance of sauce, veggies, cheese and sausage.  I'll be back next trip to the SF!
author: Lisa G.

description: We were too lazy to drive over to Zacharys in East Bay, so tried this place as alternative.  Deep dish was pretty good but definitely not quite as good as Zacharys. Crust is different, a bit crispier almost pizza hut like. Thin crust was just average at best. Certainly if no time constraint then Zacharys worth the East Bay drive.
author: Mikey L.

description: Extraordinary pizza. Fair administration. A significant hold up. Useful for supper. Like most profound dish puts, the pie will take a while. It's justified, despite all the trouble however.
author: Paige C.

description: Popped my deep dish pizza cherry at little star and I have to say... I'm a thin crust person so I want excited to try something different. We ordered Mediterranean chicken and a side of garlic bread. The garlic bread was really tasty. The pizza itself was good but it didn't taste like pizza... It was too heavy and I felt like its more of a pie. The cornmeal crust gave it a different crunch which I enjoyed. I think I would give this place a second try.
author: Judy V.

description:
Little star is good, but I  am surprised at how much love it gets. I guess being a Midwesterner, I have high expectations for my deep dish pizza.  

My biggest frustration w little star is the fact that I think their "specialty pies" don't have the best flavor combos. They kinda seem to throw a bunch of common things together, but none of them are particularly compelling to me. Also, I always try to balance flavors (so pair a salty topping with a sweet or spicy or sour topping) and they don't really seem to do that as much here. Creating your own topping combos gets really expensive! 

Anyways, if you're looking for a hearty Chicago style deep dish- def check it out. Staff is nice and friendly and while you wait, you can put an order in for your deep dish so that you're not waiting too long :)
author: Alison H.

description:
Pretty good. I came here on a friend's recommendation and tried their deepdish. We got a 12 inch cheese and added fresh mozz, meatball, and sausage. It was fantastic. I order from paxti's all the time, and I would say that the pizza here was on par, maybe better? I'll need to try some other toppings before I can make that determination fully.

I will say though, that I loveddd the crust. It had a very cornbread-like consistency to it, which was very unique. The only thing was, the crust was quite thick. That's about my one and only complaint. 

Other than that, the service was great and the price was right. The place has a real dim romantic way about it. I kind of liked that as I came with my gf for a spur of the moment late dinner. 

There was no wait, and I got the best parking spot possible, right out front. But then again it was a monday night at 8:30pm. I would expect parking to be very difficult in this location during more peak days/hours.

Bottom line: recommended. I hope you guys start delivering because then I wouldn't be able to stop myself..
author: Kevin W.

description: Great vegetarian deep dish. Loved the sauce and cornmeal crust. Salad was good, but obviously the pizza stole the show.
author: Melissa G.

description: I'm very grateful that Little Star Pizza is in my neighbourhood. Not only it's walking distance from my place but it is also the first restaurant that introduced me to Chicago Style Pizza. All their deep dishes pizzas are amazing with my personal favourite being the vegetarian. You also can't go wrong the Wings and the hip decor. A true SF stable
author: Krishan S.

description:
This place is located in the heart of NOPA on Divisadero St. Parking can suck, but you just have to get your hands on some of this pretty good pizza.

They're more known for their deep dish pies, but I didnt have 45 minutes to wait so I got thin pepperoni instead. I kind of regret not getting the deep dish and just waited like 30 minutes more because my pepperoni was pretty darn good. Imagine how more awesome it would have been if I've gotten the better deep dish pie.

No biggie, settled with the thin pepperoni pizza. Nicely cooked, crispy crust. Great stuff. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/__I9HmtBMV4dDkEgT22V4g?select=9koyvzx8gpUojSE2DaCMvw

Beers here as well, cheap for SF at around $5 a pint. And they're open relatively late. I'll comb back for more...next time...a whole deep dish for myself...yah yah..I'm greedy and a glutton.
author: Mike C.

description:
Since parking can be a hassle in this neighborhood (and we don't live in Lower Haight anymore), we order out and have it delivered. They are a great alternative to Paxtis, especially since Patxi won't deliver everywhere in the city. However, don't think you'll get Chicago style pizza here. It's thin crust, but gooey, delicious sauce with a broader variety for vegetarians than your standard bell peppers and onions. 

Also, they do have salads, which I wish came in a larger portion. 

So, in case you don't live nearby, order through trycaviar.com- they feature Little Star and a plethora of other great finds in San Francisco.
author: Carolina S.

description:
I really like this place. 

This was my first time at this location, but I dined at the Mission restaurant a few months ago and only had good memories. There was quite the wait on a weekend night, so we went across the street for some drinks before returning. They easily accommodated our party of 8 and we pre-ordered our pizzas so that they were ready shortly after we sat down. No complaints, great pizza place.
author: Candace R.

description:
I dream about the day I am united with Little Star Pizza once again. 

If I were Superman, Little Star Pizza would be my kryptonite. I would live out my last days in the Fortress of Solitude happily munching on their deep dish pizza and guzzling some beer and that would be my life.

Luckily, I live across the coast so my road to obesity has been side tracked...for now. I could wax poetic all day about their thick buttery crust, robust and zesty tomato sauce, mozzarella cheese, and Italian sausage.

A few tips:
+ The deep dish will fill you up pretty quickly!
+ Come early, the place can fill up quick!
+ Wear a cave hat with a light attached to it, the atmosphere is pretty dark.
+ Don't plan on going out afterwards.. A siesta should be the only thing listed in your social agenda after eating here!

Ugh, I've done it again. I've made myself hungry writing a Yelp review. Now to satisfy my pangs with lackluster grocery store purchased frozen "Pizzeria Uno" brand pizza...
author: Kimberly S.

description:
I like their pizza here, but I'm going with a 1 star because the waiter was pretty rude. I joined a group of friends and he said "I never do this, but I'll make an exception this one time." What, to join a table? I could have just walked in and sat down and taken one. The place was empty and nobody was sitting in any of the other nearby tables.

Anyway, when the meal was done, I had a slice of pizza where only the crust was left. He asked if I needed a box and I said no thanks. Then he told me I should get a box to go and give my pizza crust to a homeless person. What? Who's going to want my pre-eaten pizza with just the crust left? Come on man. So he insisted on this and brought the box out. I'm all about helping out the homeless, but I can't in good conscience go around offering someone just the crust for a single slice of my already eaten pizza.
author: jared t.

description: I came in around 2pm when it was a bit empty. Thankfully. My party and I ordered a thin crust small pizza with half Italian combo and half special. I don't recall what is in the special, but it was on the side with a lemon. The pizza took roughly 10-15 minutes to get served after placing the order. The crust was crisp and not too heavy. The ingredients went together pretty well and the lemon juice took my slice of pizza to the next level. The special is not on the menu. so it might be different each time. I think there was also goat cheese in the special pizza. I'd definitely return for more.
author: Kosmo Z.

description:
With over 2,000 reviews I'm sure I can't contribute something that someone else has not already said.  We arrived about 15 minutes before the kitchen closed and they were gracious about taking our pizza order.  
Drinks were served and we waited.
After a while out came this pizza with a 2.5 inch crust filled to overflowing with fixings.
It was delicious that night as well as for breakfast the next morning.

Word to the wise--------------come hungry.
author: E A.

description: We really enjoyed the atmosphere and the service. The dd meateor pizza hit the spot just right. I also had their pomegranate Sunrise which was delicious. We ended the night with a brownie and strawberry lemon gelato. Everything was delicious.
author: Nicole A.

description: I'm usually skeptical about going out and ordering pizzas since we can get pizza for a cheaper price, but you have got to try the deep dish! The deep dish pizza was to die for. My boyfriend constantly craves it and we are definitely returning. Around the area, there are also little shops that you could walk around in. This place is on my top pizza locations!
author: Michelle H.

description: Yup one more vote for these guys. Different deep dish- not exactly pure Chicago style but very good. I happen to like heavy rich sauce. Small size feeds three easily. A gem.
author: E F.

description: I've been raving about the crust on the deep dish pizza for days. They have a nice happy hour menu that includes a caprese salad and a kale "salad" (steamed kale baked with a cheesy layer- delicious!). This could be a tasty date spot or a great place to share a pizza with a group of friends!
author: Margie S.

description: Great pizza and ambience! My boyfriend and I shared a small Little Star pizza and it was so delicious! Deep dish is the way to go. The slices are very tender, so it's gonna be a fork and knife kind of meal! I need to give an honorable mention to their beer selection. I think there were only 5 to pick them but OH MY GOSH they were delicious. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed the Arrogant Bastard Ale, and an IPA that I can't recall unfortunately. All in all, it was a great meal!
author: Jenny N.

description:
This place is a hole in the wall! I came to Frisco for vacation and this place was a must! 
This place is very simple in the inside. You would never imagine that they would serve such good pizza! 
So let me begin with WOW! Whenever I go back to San Francisco I will most defenetly go to this place!! 
I got the thin crust chicken pesto pizza!!! It was yum yum!
author: Mariel G.

description:
I've been on some sort of pizza craze constant crave lately, so last night I ventured over to Little Star to try their deep dish pizza. We ordered the spring mixed salad and the classic deep dish pizza with added roasted garlic. (For some reason I've also been oh so into garlic :)) I also ordered their pear cider($5) which was soo good. it reminded me of the fruity flavored kombucha. The spring mixed salad was tasty and refreshing - topped with walnuts, gorgonzola cheese (mm), cherry tomatoes and chopped onions. 

For the pizza, I enjoyed it but I wasn't amazed. Maybe I had high expectations due to the price ($20 for a small which has 6 deep dish slices) or maybe I'm not used to seeing SF prices for food. Customer service was excellent though :)
author: Kayla O.

description: WARNING* finding parking to eat here fucking sucks. You better be handicap so you could get some decent parking or have a loading zone truck. It was hella busy for a Tuesday afternoon. The lighting was really dim inside and really loud. For appetizer we had the garlic bread which was hella good. I do recommend going there for that. Main course we had pesto chicken pizza thin. Had to say, pretty let down. I've been to the one in Albany and their pesto chicken is way better. Overall not too happy. Just glad I had that garlic bread.
author: Mike P.

description:
Food: 4.5 stars
Price: 4.5 stars
Service/Atmosphere: 4.5 stars

I'm rounding up here and giving five stars to this pizzeria because that deep dish was the best darn pizza I've had in over a decade. The only reason I'm not giving them 5 stars across the board is I'm leaving room for something more gourmet however I suspect that's just stupid because it's difficult to imagine anything better. Sure I have a soft spot for deep dish and yes, we didn't order anything else but, since eating there, I can't stop thinking about my next visit and if I will be able to pry myself away from the exact same meal and order something different. 

We ordered the "Little Star" deep dish which is a vegetarian option with spinach, blended ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic. I had a number of concerns, which were all misplaced! I was worried that the mushrooms would be soggy and overpowering but they had been thinly sliced, pre-cooked, really just the perfect note. I was expecting the spinach, cheese and onions mixture to be wet and stringy but again, it was expertly balanced and my leftovers didn't show the slightest signs of sog. I contemplated what the addition of meat would bring to such a meal and the answer is not a thing. Much like the coveted Taqueria Cancun burrito, the vegetarian version is supreme. The 9" pie provided enough food for two people and leftovers for the next day.

We also ordered a small salad, a couple glasses of wine and dulce de leche gelato, which hit the spot nicely and didn't leave a hole in our wallets.

To sum, this is the ideal little pizza place. Fast service, great prices, high-quality ingredients and a nice selection of beer and wine. Yum yum, nom nom, heck yes and when can we go back?

PRO TIP: Leftovers heat up well in the toaster oven!
PRO TIP: Everything tastes better with a fried egg on top (breakfast pizza anyone?).
author: Sam S.

description: WoW The best deep dish in the game... they know what they are doing here. Worth $30 a pie
author: Johnny L.

description: Very delicious. I have personal space issues, though, so I'd recommend picking up a pizza as opposed to eating in the restaurant.
author: Kelsey M.

description: I'm normally a fan of thin crust pizza but tried a deep dish here for the first time and all I have to say is WOW! It was amazing! The restaurant has a dark and cozy feel to it and the service is good. Our pizza took a little longer than usual to be prepared and the manager came over to apologize and gave us a 50% discount cause of the wait which was cool.
author: heela k.

description:
Had the special deep dish pizza. 

It was packed with meat, fresh and flavorful marinara sauce, and the other veggies. It was definitely heavier than thin crisps but not overbearing. 

Parking is bad for this place. I dont know about calling this place a must try in SF but it is very very good.
author: David P.

description: First time having a good deep dish pizza (I'm not usually a fan). There was an hour wait, but we ordered when we put our name on the list since it takes a while to cook. Bottle of wine and delicious pizza? Oh yes. The roasted garlic may be my favorite topping. Really nice crust texture, crunchy yet spongy on the inside. Flavorful and great for sharing. Fun date night!
author: Zara S.

description:
Pizza = 5 star
Service - zero stars.  Our female waitress(with glasses) was horrible.  She never asked us what we wanted to drink, my daughter said she would like water and the waitress turned around and walked away without asking me.  She never smiled and never made eye contact.  I decided to have a glass of wine and i had to get up and go find her.  Everything else about the place was great, except for this one miserable person.
author: Dan R.

description: Very tasty pizza and amusing service. They fulfill orders in a timely manner and are reasonably priced. If you're in the mood for pizza I would strongly recommend it, and I'm from New York!
author: David S.

description: Deep dish, thin crust? Doesn't matter because they are both so bomb! Little Star pizzas are always on point. I mean i've seriously been here 50+ times and the pizza always comes out just right. Good place to hang out with some friends too, maybe grab a drink and watch the game.
author: Mike P.

description: This was first on my list when I got to San Francisco. I went thru all the reviews and pics beforehand and knew I wanted to try something claiming to be authentic deep dish. I was impressed. I went with the small special which was housemade meatballs, ricotta, mushroom, red bell peppers, and spinach with a cornmeal crust. It was fantastic! We also had some garlic cheese bread which was good. Atmosphere was dark and crowded but showed that this was the spot to be in. I would highly recommend the pizza joint. We even spent $30 roundtrip cab fare from union square to get there and it was still worth it.
author: Nate D.

description:
Little Star was really good but I don't think I could eat this more than once.  We had the deep dish special with sausage and ricotta and it was delicious. Fruity tomato sauce, flavorful sausage and the best crust I've ever had on deep dish. I don't know how they get it to crisp so much.

The downside is it's incredibly heavy and more lasagna feeling than pizza.  I'm a New York pizza girl but I'm glad I tried it.
author: Emily H.

description:
The deep dish crust is deeeee-licious! The pizza was pretty good, but that crust is what I'm still thinking about. 

We got the large deep dish classic and it fed my husband, two toddlers, and myself with three pieces left over. No need to get your own unless you want to take it all home. (Just consider every piece twice the amount of a normal-sized slice.)

The ingredients were fresh, the pizza was flavorful, and my husband says it's the best deep dish he's ever had.
author: Ashley E.

description:
First time having real deep dish, and I will be back. The service is awkward, but the pizza is helllllla good so you get 5 stars. $36 for a large deep dish, an appetizer and a coke, not a bad deal. I usually eat like a cow, but with all the flavor I could barely make it past one piece and I feel like ill be satisfied till tomorrow. It's not the everyday type of place, but ill be back within 2 months. 


BTW, the large deep dish comes with 8 huge pieces.. Good for like 3-4 people.
author: Smash S.

description:
When the moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie that's amore!

And amore it was! Had the vegetarian deep dish but wanted to substitute 2 of the veggies for different ones (no bell peppers and no zucchini instead, fresh tomatoes and pesto sauce) Our server said he could do one substitution at no charge but would have to charge us for the other one.  Really? At $18 for a small vegetarian pizza that is ridiculous,  especially when one of the substitutions was just pesto sauce! 

What made this pizza so yummy was the crust - it was sweet, yet savory and was just overall delicious.

The reason for the 3 stars is the additional charge for substitutions. When people pay that much for a pizza and want to make equal substitutions (I wasn't substituting sausage or caviar for bell peppers for goodness sake) just let them do it with no additional charge!

Lastly, be sure to give yourself plenty of time to eat, as our pizza took about 45 minutes to arrive at our table.
author: Heather K.

description: Deep dish is absolutely amazing and they do it so well. Keep in mind that it does take about 30 minutes to cook, so be ready to order as soon as you get there. I would highly encourage you to order your pizza first, then start with appetizers and enjoy each others company because its gonna be a minute. But when that pizza comes out, your life will change forever. Great job!
author: Ryan N.

description:
Little Star Pizza is one of the best Chicago-style deep dish pizzas in the Bay Area.

With a wooden bar and a casual atmosphere, you won't mistake Little Star Pizza on Divisadero for anything other than the pizza joint it is.  No white table cloths here, just great deep dish pizza worth driving across The City for.

Served with melted butter and olive oil, the sourdough garlic bread ($5.75) is a good choice to take the edge off your hunger. While tasty and piquant, the spicy chicken wings ($11) are not your traditional Buffalo wings. The delicious Caprese salad ($11), with fresh, soft mozzarella slices and tomatoes that tasted as if they were just picked, was topped with shredded basil and presented in a mixture of olive oil and balsamic vinegar--the embodiment of summer. 

With spinach, ricotta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic, the Little Star ($19/$24.50) puts other deep dish pizzas to shame.  The cornmeal crust was perfectly cooked--just toasted enough, not burned.  The deep dish Mediterranean chicken pizza ($19.75/$25.50) was also fantastic.  The cheese was melted, but not greasy, and the combination of artichokes, feta, and green olives was a perfect foil for the tanginess of the tomato sauce.

Service is friendly, if a little rushed.  While there is a good selection of beers on tap and by the bottle, oenophiles may be disappointed, as the wine choices were rather limited.

For deep dish pizza, Little Star is really a star.
author: CJ G.

description:
I made my husband choose where we'd eat for lunch. No suprise its Chicago style pizza. I was all for it because there are few places around the Bay that serve real Chicago pizza. This place is small and very hipster. They have a jukebox with random music from Andre 3000 to 90s grunge. Theres awesome artwork on the walls and other unique detailing like the hostess desk is a dresser. 

The menu is fairly small which I like. We order the vegetarian deep dish. I really liked the crust the most. I believe I tasted cornmeal. They also serve specialty soda and beer. Oh and the glasses are chilled which is a nice touch.

The waiter was on point. Super friendly and came to our table multiple times. 

I highly suggest trying this little pizza spot out!
author: Malia W.

description:
Little Star = a cute/cozy spot with solid pizza. 

We did NOT get their deep-dish pizza because 1) I don't really like deep dish and 2) it takes 30m to come out of the kitchen here, while the thin crust only takes 15m (my table was impatient). The think crust pizza was good - clearly fresh made with quality ingredients, and a large was enough to feed two people with a couple slices leftover. I like the creative combinations and options on the menu (e.g. zucchini, sun-dried tomatoes, feta, ricotta, artichokes, etc.) - the special of the day was good, too. I was not super impressed with the actual taste/texture of the crust and found myself leaving it on the plate, where I usually look forward to finishing those last couple of bites!

We ordered the "garlic bread" to start, which was basically an individual-sized pizza with garlic and cheese on top. We also got the caprese salad which was quite good - fresh sliced tomatoes, mozzarella, basil and a couple different types of olives in a yummy drizzle of olive oil and balsamic vinegar. 

I really liked the Blue Star Wheat beer - and the bar was a great spot to hang out while we waited for our table.
