I would recommend this spot for a date or intimate gathering with friends. I'd also guess it's a lot better for folks who like deep-dish pizza! (Doesn't seem like the thin crust was really their specialty.)
author: Catie F.

description:
Definitely go for the deep-dish Chicago style.  It ain't Zachary's out in the East Bay, but its darn close and the best Chicago-style pizza that SF has to offer.  No need to go crazy with the toppings.  It all gets buried underneath a 1/2" layer of chunky tomato sauce.  We got half of our pizza with just cheese and the other half with spinach and chicken.  There really wasn't much difference between the two halves, except for the price. 

Tip 1:  If you are doing the deep-dish Chicago Style, try just a plain ol' cheese. 

Tip 2:  If you are doing take-out, call at least 45 mins ahead.  This is not a regular pizza.  It takes longer to cook.

Tip 3:  Save the drive out to the East Bay for Zachary's.  This place is just as good.
author: Sudarat P.

description: Great pizza, cool vibe, noisy without being too much so. Ate here while moving daughter into dorms at USF. Will definitely return when coming up for visits.
author: Eddie V.

description:
For West Coast deep dish pizza, Little Star is fantastic -- much better than Patxi's. I love that Little Star's pizza crust has a ton of flavor, that cornmeal crunch is delicious. Not to mention, the fresh tomato sauce is outrageous. 

If you're craving meat, order the Classic deep dish at Little Star and you will not go wrong. A large is plenty of food to share amongst 4-5 people. If you're not feeling meat that day, go for the Little Star Pizza -- Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. I've also ordered the Little Star Pizza and added sausage, which is delish!

If you have room for side dishes, their garlic bread is fluffy, carby, and tastes like a small pizza of its own. 

In addition to the awesome grub, the vibe inside the restaurant is very relaxed.. a great place to hang out with friends and dive in on pizza and brewskis. Food is great, service is great, and they deliver! So, what are you waiting for?
author: Helen W.

description:
Ice cold beer and deep dish pizza. You can't go wrong with this place. 

I walked in and swooped a table for two immediately even though the place was really busy. The atmosphere is cozy,classy and low key. The waitress was very attentive and genuinely friendly. She explained that the special was some kind of squash pizza. Not really my style but it sounds interesting and i was kinda curious to see what that would look like. 

We ordered a large deep dish with Sun dried Tomatoes , Chicken, Sausage and Extra Mozzarella. It was impressive, this thing had some girth lol. I ordered an Arrogant Bastard and the combo between the two was nice. We all know how strong that beer is. Serving it with Chicago Style Deep Dish Pizza is perfect because I had to stay sober for my drive home later and it kept me on point for the night. 


My one  recommendation would be a larger table for two near the back. With a large pizza, drinks,water,shakers,plates etc... My table was super crowded and i was worried about knocking stuff over.  I talk with my hands and i'm clumsy


I highly recommend  this place and I like the neighborhood. Going back ASAP
author: Dan J.

description: Great little pizza joint. Pretty casual, but great atmosphere if you're looking for somewhere with table service and pretty cheap pizza and beer.
author: Catherine M.

description:
Yup, this beats Zachary's. I was quite doubtful and thought it would be overrated, but it is indeed wonderful. I bought take-out, but definitely want to eat in the restaurant some time. The ambience is super nice, kinda romantic and dimly lit. I ordered the "little star pizza" and split it with my friend for $20. 

Here's how it differs from Zachary's.
1) The crust here is more like pizza crust, less like flaky pie crust. It tastes better.
2) Zachary's pizzas are very tomato-heavy, which is great if you love tomato, but I prefer to have more other toppings on my pizza. Little Star puts a LOT of toppings but still gives that right amount of tomatoes for a deep dish pizza.
author: Amanda C.

description: This restaurant is amazing, the deep dish Chicago style pizza is incredible and so is the garlic bread. The pizza is wonderful, I would recommend it to anyone!
author: Riley G.

description: Delicious Pizza. Got seated immediately on a Thursday night. We got a half med and half special pizza and entered a food coma after the second slice. Service was good, however, they did forget to give us the garlic bread we ordered. They didn't charge us though, so we just let it go. They serve Cock & Bull Ginger Beer, which is super gingery. More gingery the better though. Super good. The pizza we got was perfectly cooked and super good. However, in SF if I had to choose a deep dish pizza I like better, it has to be Patxi's because they have the honey that you can use with the crust. My favorite bay area pizza though still is definitely definitely Zachary's. If you're coming here with a group of friends, one of the pluses about this place was that they were happy enough to split our bill with four different credit cards.
author: Julie L.

description:
This is my second time being here. My party of 4 ordered a large white vegetarian flat pizza overloaded with feta and a large vegetarian deep dish, and it was plenty. I enjoy  feta, so the overpowering taste of feta was delicious to me - not so much to my brother. The deep dish was ok. I don't think it had enough veggies in it. It had a lot of mozzarella melted in it, so it felt like I was just eating pizza sauce, mozzarella... and olives. Honestly - not sure what other veggies were in it. Regardless, still tasty. 

The ambiance was hip, I guess. The acoustics of the room was quite poor, but I saw their cushion-type things on the ceilings as an attempt to help with the loud noise. The place is also really dark. If you have hearing loss or trouble hearing in background noise... this place isn't the best for dining in.
author: Connie L.

description: The deep dish pizza is the best pizza I've ever eaten, with chiken, peperoni and mushroom
author: Bertha M.

description:
Upon arriving, I was told the pizza would take up to 30 min. My response: YES, IT SHOULD.

I am from Italy. Good pizza, as in proper & effortlessly delicious, must take a vero pizzaiolo's  time and attention. How fast can a pizzaiolo knead the dough into the right thickness, ladle the perfect amount of "sugo" so the end result is neither soggy nor dry, and slide the pizza with the halo of crust into a well-fed brick oven?

Well, I don't know if that's what they do. But when you're told that a soufflé must be ordered in anticipation, you're receiving pillowy and piping peauty (for the sake of alliteration). The deep-dish pizza was no different! Hot and ready, like me at the table.

The art shows in how wonderfully crusty the crust was. Don't know what I mean? The bottom and sides of the deep-dish were golden and toasted to a delightful crunch, while the "sugo"  permeated the middle and ridges of the pizza making  softer, doughy, yet cooked, goodness. Timing and precise oven temperature created the harmonious two-toned textures that entered my body.

Service? Our server facilitated our dinner. Extremely attentive and minimally intrusive. With great company and so much of my attention divested into the tantric red moon on our table, I would have shooed at her with my paws.

Deep-dish pizza at Little Star is an experience much appreciated from outside the borders of the Boot. Utterly excellent.
author: Olivier K.

description: I love thin, cripsy NY pizza!!!!!  Now I love Little Star and Blue Line pizza too!!!  I thought I would never love deep dish after going on the hunt for great deep dish pizze for 3 days in Chicago and leaving unfulfilled.  Zachary's through my days at Cal was a goto place but there was not love, just like.  It's nice to have more than one pizza love now.  I do wish they would have the Goddess salad dressing available at all their locations and parking wasn't the huge challenge it can be at Little Star.  But small price to pay for love.
author: S. C.

description:
The deep dish pizza was amazing! Ordered the sausage, bell peppers, and black olive pizza, minus the mushrooms. The sausage mixed perfectly with the other ingredients and the hearty tomato sauce. If you love Zachary's Pizza in Berkeley, CA, you'll love Little Star. 

The mixed salad (no walnuts) could have used a bit more vinaigrette, but it was very good.
author: Marc B.

description: Forgot to post this long ago but I recommend this place in the NOPA district, hands down. Went in there stoned as hell with a couple of my friends and wasn't dissatisfied by both service and the food! They knew we were STARVIN', and served us up just right!
author: Natalie G.

description: Favorite deep dish pizza in all of SF! Love this place I just don't recommend eating in if you have a larger party because of the very limited tables but definitely a MUST TRY!
author: Paty O.

description:
* Food:
o Presentation: Clean, definitely not messy. Even if it was, I would still nom on it! :) (5/5)
o Temperature: Hot hot hot! (5/5)
o Quality: The best! (5/5)
o Dishes ordered: Half classic & half mediterranean deep dish pizza and garlic pizza. OMG!
o Tastiest dish: I absolutely love their deep dishes. Nothing beats it! I love their classic, mediterranean, little star, and absolutely anything this place makes. (X/5)

* Service:
o Attentive: Always quick! (5/5)
o Knowledgeable: Yes! (5/5)
o Friendliness: Yes! (5/5)

* Restaurant:
o Atmosphere: Always packed! People know what's good. :) (5/5)
o Cleanliness: Very clean and organized. (4/5)
o Cost vs. value: It's not the cheapest pizza but oh so delicious! (X/5)

* Will I revisit restaurant? Yes! This is my go-to pizza place. Note: I normally do not like pizza but ever since I've tried the pizza from Little Star, I have fallen in love with their deep dish. Forget Zachary's or Patxi's!
author: Mindy - Oishii Moments S.

description:
Located in the heart of Western Addition on Divisadero, this cozy location is practically unnoticeable while driving by. 

I had a great experience at their El Cerrito location however I was not completely wow'd as many others were at this one. Personally I don't know if I agree that they offer the best deep dish however they are up there and in good company with Zachary's and Patxi's. Perhaps it was my choice of toppings however the overall taste somehow was lacking for me although I can't quite put my finger on it. I did like the cornmeal crust and size small was perfect to share for two. Ingredients appeared to be good. They are quicker than Paxti's and our pizza was ready in 30 minutes opposed to Paxti's 45. 

I'm gonna have to give them another go and try their other toppings.
author: Esther A.

description:
The girlfriend and I were going to get Mexican in the mission but after a friend of ours mentioned that he had Little Star the other night, we were hooked. I've heard of this place many times but never had the opportunity to go. We quickly changed plans and ordered a pie for pick up. 

Maybe I'm spoiled by Chicago, or maybe it was an off night, but I might be one of the few that thought this place was just 'ok'

Zachary's and this place come close to being authentic, but ultimately something was missing. It could be the sauce that tasted a bit flat, or the size of the sausage that was tiny in my opinion. Don't get me wrong it was good, but I think people over hyped this place and my expectations were that of a Giordano's or Pequod's in Chitown. 

BTW, Pequod's is probably the best I've had. Look up the pictures here on yelp and you'll know what I'm talking about when I saw tiny sausage! 

Also the chicken wings were a bit dry but the redeeming factor was the caprese salad. That was probably my favorite dish of the night lol! 

I want to give them another chance and I will come back!  I'm hoping it was just an off night and the second time will be spot on.
author: Andrew S.

description: Great service. Called in for a Togo order and she answered all my questions and helped us figure out what pizza would fit our needs. We are excited to try the classic and original pizzas.
author: Lauren C.

description: In the top 3 if not the best Pizza in San Francisco, Little Star - Paulines - and Gialinas. The deep dish is the best you'll ever eat in the city, amazing texture and love the cornmeal crust. The crust is seriously on the level of a fine french pastery.  I've never been to Chicago but this Pizza makes me want to go - if you love Zachary's Pizza in Berkeley and are looking for that experience you have to go here. They put so much sausage on that it covers every square inch of the pie. Hat's off, job well done.
author: Carson C.

description: Little Star has been my go to for years. I am normally I very healthy eater, so little star is a cheat night for me, but I do feel that the amount of marina to cheese is a far better and tastier ratio than places like Patxi's. We almost always order pick-up at this point. For two people (with large appetites) we get the small Little Star Pizza with chicken and a small mixed green salad. Some nights there will be one leftover piece, other nights.... none. Expect the order to take 30 min. More than a few times I've called right when I land at SFO, or I'm stuck in bay bridge traffic and picked up my order on the way home - always makes me so happy to be home in SF :) Yum!
author: Jessica D.

description: Not much to say... If you like pizza, if you like deep dish pizza, if you want to fall in LOVE with pizza, come here! I was impressed with the pizza & drinks! Plus they have a happy hour!
author: Lei F.

description:
This is the best damn pizza I've ever had. Before I came here, I had never eaten a deep dish pizza. I've always been a fan of thin crusts. 

I'm came here in 2012 and I was blown away by the awesomeness of three pepperoni pizza. When friends ask what they should do and see in San Francisco, I tell them to go here. So tasty.
author: Andrew D.

description: I love little star, it may be because deep dish is always amazing, but Little Star does it right ! I have eaten in at the restaurant, which usually there is a bit of a wait , and I've ordered to go. The quality and service is always excellent. If you're a fan of deep dish and in SF, look no further, this is your place. I love all the different pizza combos and every time I go I always order the chicken wings-- they are a must !!
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Okay, the pizza is good. But you knew that already. A few other things:

- The prices are a little upsetting. $19 for a small pie just hurts my heart. 
- There is always a wait. Why? Because it's small. There are only 10 or so tables.
- Service is sad. The hostess and waiter were in outer space for most of our meal.

Again, the pizza is very good but it comes at a price. And a wait. And a strong tolerance for a clueless waitstaff. Enjoy.
author: Nick K.

description: This is my favorite pizza in the city.  The crust is delicious with cornmeal crusting.  The pizza itself uses super fresh ingredients.  I'd recommend starting with their deep dish and moving to thin crust.
author: Jay R.

description: Amazing. Every. Time.  The Brass Monkey pizza is consistently one of the best i've ever had.  The crust, the chunky tomato sauce, the tasty sausage.  And the salad, while pretty simple, rocks my world every time I eat it too.  Its usually just the wife and I eating, but I love it when we have others with us so that I can order the amazing chicken wings as well.
author: Christopher R.

description: I grew up eating pizza in Chicago and this place can hold up to any of the best in Chitown! The crust is delicious and the pizza doesn't come out soggy! The service is awesome and the feel of the place is still definitely San Francisco! I highly recommend them!
author: Dr J.

description:
Dang. This place is seriously dangerous.  Their deep dish is the business. I suggest trying sausage, fresh mozz and a drizzle of pesto. My husband and I ordered this one to-go a week ago and it was by far our favorite pizza to date (we go once every couple of weeks). 

If you are pizza lover, there will be something on the menu here for you!
author: Tyler L.

description: Had the buffalo chicken pizza. BOMB! So delicious. The guy on the phone was super helpful, the delivery guy was really nice, and it was delivered very quickly. I will definitely be ordering from them again!
author: Monica C.

description:
Yes, yes, yes!!!!!!!

The hype is real. Little Star Pizza is a shining beacon of hope in San Francisco's pie world.

I came here with some seasoned regulars, who ordered the spicy chicken wings (which are a bit dry but come with blue cheese sauce) and two thin cornmeal crust pizzas to share.

I can't speak for the deep dish, but the thin crust pizzas are so. damn. good. I can't get over how flavorful the cheese is?! And garlic olive oil base is brilliant.

Little Star truly takes pizza to another level -- one that does SF proud! Even the New Yorker at the table agreed.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Really good traditional pizza. I had the "Meateor" which came out as good as most thin crust is. But it wasn't ultra-thin --which I prefer, hence the 4 stars not the fifth...

Ate at the bar, excellent service and interesting conversations with both local customers and out-of-towner former locals who came back for the pizza. This is a very comfortable small local place that has great service and great food. The price is also very good, I had a small pizza, a really good salad and three ;-) beers for around $50. I spent far longer sitting at the bar than I expected to, and that was because there was really no reason to leave given the overall experience and the conversations. Great local place!

I really would have given 5 stars if the pizza was in my preferred style (ultra thin with some blackened crust)... But they make it the way they want and it was really delicious!
author: Vic W.

description:
Little Star continues to shine in this neighborhood and City!  The service is amazing, food consistently good, and they have a great beer selection.  Moreover, Little Star never disappoints.

They now take credit cards and have a delivery service that is prompt and inexpensive.
author: Kiki I.

description:
Pizza was wonderful, both the deep dish and the "normal!  Serivce was SUPER, friendly, fast and on top of it!

In fact, I'm going back tonight!
author: Peter S.

description: Amazing!! We ordered the thin crust and it was one of the best pizzas I have ever had! Too bad it is a little far from us and they don't deliver.
author: Giovanna R.

description: Hands down the best pizza in San Francisco. I've tried a dew of their thin crust pizzas and they're all delicious. And the crust is just perfect.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I'm in love with Little Star Pizza! I had such a great dinner last night. My sisters and I started with the garlic bread, with butter, olive oil, and a subtle taste of garlic but not too overwhelming. There were six pieces, and they weren't too filling. I definitely recommend patrons to start with this delectable appetizer. 

We then ordered the Italian combo thin crust pizza. It had pepperoni, salami, onions, green bells, black olives, pepperoncini; it's your essential meaty pizza. So good! It was a little salty, so I recommend ordering a diet coke on the side to wash down the goodness.

Pizzas are in the pricier range, but you pay for the ambience and great service. This is a great date place, so bring your significant other here and eat your hearts (and stomachs) out.
author: Joanne K.

description:
Fantastic deep dish pizza. Will be back. Definitely better than paxtis pizza. There can be a wait, but they text you a link to show your place in line and time remaining. They follow up with a text when you're close, and a text when your table is ready. Too awesome and allows you to do more than "just wait." 

Highly recommend.
author: Frankie S.

description:
Stars: 3.5

I went to Little Star on a Monday night and it was not packed. We walked right in and got seated right away. It is a small place. I don't like the lighting though. It's too dark for my liking.

We ordered three items:
1. Wings - little, tiny but delicious! The blue cheese dip wasn't too strong which is also good. There's a slight kick to it.
2. Large special - It was like a combo of the Little Star and the Classic. We wanted this because it had meatballs (basically, meat)! So we tried it. I really like this one. I like the flavors in it. There's definitely a lot of tomato sauce but I thought it went well.
3. Large Mediterrean - We wanted chicken, and I personally wasn't a big fan of it. I think I am biased because whenever there's artichoke hearts and chicken, I want my creamy white sauce instead of tomatoes on it.

I think the best part of the pizza is the crust. The crust is so good. So for three of us, this was a lot of food. Maybe we should have went with the small. We overestimated ourselves. 

Note:
They do take cards (Visa/Mastercard) even though they have an ATM machine in front!
author: Margaret L.

description:
HANDS DOWN BEST DEEP DISH PIZZA IN THE SAN FRANCISCO/BAY AREA.

Little Star is to me is like what the holy Mecca is to the Muslims. 
-- and after a good year or so of stuffing my cheeks with their delish deep dish, I've found the perfect words to describe my affinity for Little Star's 'Classic' (Sausage, mushroom, onions & green bellpeppers) DD pizza. 

You know how every Deep Dish place has their niche? Little Star's DD has the best crust my tongue has ever laid its buds on. The cornmeal crust is like the annoyingly, consistent Employee of the Month; doin' it's job of soaking in all those flavors from the sauce + toppings. The cheesiness and marinara sauce are well-balanced. Like damn, hitting it out of the ballpark every time. 4 for you, Glen Coco!

You best believe I nor anyone I've eaten here with has left a crumb on their plate. It's the first pizza I've had where dousing it in Sriracha (my usual for pizza/any food, really) NEVER crossed my mind. That's saying plenty. 

This is my ideal date night spot, as the place has a solid mood light game going on. Heck, I wouldn't mind being PROPOSED here one day (it's all about sentiment people, a pizza parlor can have just as much romance as the Eiffel Tower). A girl can dream, right?
author: Kat L.

description:
Came here for our 9 year olds birthday based on the reviews. It more than lived up to expectations. We had both a thin crust and their deep dish. Both were phenomenal. Even our normally picky 15 year old ate the thin crust with goat cheese! 

What they don't put on the menu are the personal size pizzas for kids for $4 each. Considering we had three kids under 9 with us, this was a very welcome bonus. They even let our birthday girl put as many toppings on the kids pizza as she wanted, even though they're supposed to only be one topping. 

Wait staff was attentive and incredibly friendly. We will definitely be back.
author: Autumn S.

description:
I'm sorry to be a downer. The service was cool the ambience was great. I friggen loved the cheese bread, but the deep dish pizza wasn't that great. The price point was a little higher than your average pizza, but still within the range of a decent date meal. I didn't like that while it was cold & rainy & instead of there being a heater on they've got a fan running... Why? 

Let's stick to what really matters though, the food. If not for the cheese bread this place wouldn't have been worth the trip. The sauce on the deep dish wasn't good. I'm a big sauce guy. I love making my own sauces & trying pretty much any sauce there is. The sauce on their deep dish was lame. 

Plan on spending $30-45 for dinner for two, stick to thin crust. Other than that, this place was okay. The problem is that there are other cheaper & tastier date spots. In a city full of choices, this one sits just above average on the scale. 

CHAD
author: Chad L.

description: The most delicious pizza. I have never had a cornmeal crust deep dish pizza before I moved to SF.  I can honestly say pizza is my favorite food and this is hands-down, my favorite.  Their salad with goddess dressing is also delicious. I usually get the salad, one deep dish pizza and one of their regular flat bread pizzas (which are also delicious) and eat with 4 people total. (2 women, 2 bros).
author: C. L.

description: My brother and I were hungry for pizza, and this restaurant was the closest to our location. I'm so glad we stopped in! We split a mixed salad and a deep dish half classic/half Little Star pizza. A small was enough for both of us to share. Best pizza I've had in a long time!
author: Emily D.

description:
Bomb pizza place! Not usually a big pizza fan, but this is really good

Got the California pizza and definitely recommend that one
author: Alec H.

description:
Surprisingly the simplistic mixed green salad is very good. It's so lite and simple and tasty with the Gorgonzola.  4 stars

We got the Little Star Pizza, it was a solidly good pizza. The cornmeal crust was really good. We got a small. It was enough for two people. 4 stars

The service could have been better. The waitress only came back nice towards the end of the meal to see how we were. 3 stars
author: Ahmed A.

description: Got little star via door dash tonight. Showed up on time but luke warm. I quote my kid..."is this little caesars?"
author: Cliff P.

description:
I live in the neighborhood but do not come here nearly as often I could or should.  

Friendly, accommodating hostess and waitpersons, a decent list of craft beers (but a marginal wine list as in BYOW) and did I mention PIZZA?   

Oh yes, pizza!  Sublime pizza.  To-die for pizza.  Deep dish pizza.  Thin crust pizza with amazing crust.  Generous and fresh toppings.  And I don't even really like pizza.  

My seven year old daughter has now proclaimed its thin crust to be "the best in the whole world" twice and her twin brother insisted that I write this Yelp review and give Little Star five stars.  

He then later recanted and said that maybe I shouldn't write the review or maybe just give it fewer stars - like may be one or two - because if I awarded Little Star five stars then too many people will come and we'll have a hard time getting a table.  Smart kid.

I am giving it five stars anyway.  If you see my boy, just don't tell hime that I'm one of the reasons for the long wait.  I'm going to blame it on great pizza.
author: Craig S.

description: This place is so cozy, and its location is great. I love their deep dish pizza, the classic one but you can not go wrong with any one of them! The chicken pesto thin crust pizza is great too. Their garlic bread is really good.
author: Nouf A.

description:
My favorite pizza place in city. I love the chicken deep dish and the wings are just out of the world. 

North coast beer was good
author: Sahil B.

description:
Pizza is one of my weaknesses.  I love cheese and I love savory food.  If you leave a pizza in front of me, I will keep eating until I pop!  

I finally got a chance to try Little Star before a show at The Independent.  My friend and I ordered a small mixed salad and a small Brass Monkey(Little Star with sausage) to share.  The small salad was definitely enough for two people to share.  It was enough to hold us over until our pizza came.

I've never been to Chicago to try their deep dish pizza, but I must say that Little Star makes a damn good pizza.  There were plenty of toppings, and plenty of cheesy goodness.  My taste buds and tummy were quite happy.  We both had 2 slices and still have leftovers to take home.  

This is a definite must try if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Patra I.

description:
Sis brought me here after one of the holiday parties she was dragging me to and boy am I glad she did. 

The restaurant is a little small and clustered. But besides that it was excellent. Ordered the little star deep dish and it was DELISH!!! 

Everything tasted so fresh and flavorful!
author: Veronica R.

description:
It's staggering to think about how many pizza joints there are in the Bay Area.  Even if you consider only the ones in a single category, say Chicago-style, there are still more of them then there are Doyles in Boston.  That makes it all the more impressive that Little Star is so outstanding that it's one of only three pizzerias in the Bay Area good enough to be included in the "Holy Trinity" of Chicago-style deep-dish pizza joints.

Which of the Trinity is the best of the best?  I've weighed in with my opinion before:  http://www.yelp.com/biz/patxis-chicago-pizza-palo-alto#hrid:rIQ6W8ebPxMBcGCOd1VkAQ Several of my friends have also weighed in with theirs, and horror of horrors: our opinions differ!  With the other two Holy Trinity pizza joints still fresh in my mind from recent visits, I set out to revisit Little Star at the end of February.  Maybe I'd change my mind, maybe my friends would change theirs; either way, you can't go wrong with pizza as good as this, and Yelpers that are this cool!  I organized a small PYE and set out to meet uber-Elites Cecilia S., Janice C., Bobby L., and Peter L. for an evening of world-class pizza, drinking, and (eventually) Karaoke.  Our first stop was Little Star in Western Addition.

The first of us hit Little Star at 5:30 and immediately proceeded to the bar (we Elites have our priorities straight); a table became available just as the third and fourth of our number arrived.  The atmosphere is a little dark, but decidedly classier then your average pizza joint.  The very friendly and accommodating staff served up some excellent recommendations about toppings, and got our pizza and drink orders started in short order.  

First up, we got an order of garlic bread for the table.  The garlic bread is a 
loaf of warm sourdough served with a blend of butter & extra virgin olive oil and a bulb of roasted garlic. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/__I9HmtBMV4dDkEgT22V4g?select=9zl79X8GugMmlChpiTMTNw As I didn't know Peter was coming loaded for bear, I ordered a Red Tail on draft to compliment the bread.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/__I9HmtBMV4dDkEgT22V4g?select=J1o2YGM2OylQBpRqlUcfjQ

Deep dish being Chicago style pizza's claim to fame, we ordered a large Little Star - Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic, to which we added sausage, as we're all unrepentant Carnivores. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/__I9HmtBMV4dDkEgT22V4g?select=6IEfuIUvVz5Ko2DKoXOVMA Because diversity is the spice of life, and (more importantly) because Yelpers eat like Grizzly Bears coming out of hibernation, we also ordered a White Pie - Garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/__I9HmtBMV4dDkEgT22V4g?select=BYJZd609SPcwcpqCtx67Dg

Janice C., who quite out of character started out the evening drinking water, traded up her beverage when Peter L. arrived; he brought a couple of outstanding bottles of Imagery wine to share!  With Janice leading the charge (you don't think our vesper knew Peter was bringing premium vino, do you?), we had no problem demolishing both the wine and the pizza in short order.  Thanks Peter - next time, it's my turn to bring the wine! :-)

The $64,000 question - just how good is their pizza?  I for one am convinced that Little Star unquestionably belongs in the "Holy Trinity"; their corn-meal crust is without equal, their sauce and their toppings are first tier, and every slice of their pies drips with lush, gooey, cheesy goodness.  For my money, while I think Chicago style pizza is at it's best with double-crusted variants like those that can be found at Zachary's and Paxti's, I'd happily consume mass-quantities of Little Star pizza multiple times a week.  Mammon only knows what I was thinking on my first visit to the Little Star on Valencia Street - five stars all the way!

Now, on to the drinking and Karaoke!
author: Glenn G.

description: It was good. I wish it had more topping on the deep dish under the sauce, but it tastes good and the prices are fair
author: Sara H.

description: Hands down the best deep dish pizza joint in the bay! I've tried Paxti's multiple times and even Zachary's in Berkeley, but their pies don't compete with Little Star. The sauce is thick and flavorful, and I love the cornmeal crust.  The chicken wings are also on point, and have a nice spicy seasoning on them.
author: Bella C.

description: Very good! Come early for a table, even on a Sunday night. Delicious pizzas (both thin crust and deep dish), reasonable price, and nice ambiance.
author: Jan Z.

description: Love this place! I've only done take out but it's always ready when they say and always a very friendly staff.
author: Tom B.

description:
The last time I went to Mission one after SF marathon.
This was the second time to eat at Little Star, and this time it was after Kaiser Half Marathon. Of course it's the best after the run.
author: Kaori M.

description: This is really the best pizza in the city. So good that even  when they don't answer their phone to take orders,  I still want to give them five stars!
author: Eric B.

description:
best pizza i have ever tasted in the bay area
never had chicago style pizza but this spot by far the best..
author: Alfonso D.

description: One of my favorite pizza places in San Francisco!  It gets pretty packed packed during the evening when it's dinner rush so get here early if you don't want to wait!  The staff is very friendly and provide great service.  I usually order my own pizza (thin crust with sausage, basil, sun dried tomatoes) along with a light appetizer like caprese salad.  Good thing I live a couple of blocks away from here or I would eat pizza every single day.  Not that that's a bad thing!
author: Mei W.

description: We have been here almost a handful of times -- we have spent a fair share of time in Chicago and will admit that this pizza rivals chicago deep dish in terms of taste and quality. As vegetarians we enjoy the Little star, which comes with spinach and ricotta as well as garlic and feta. The tomato sauce is delicious. This is not a stuffed pizza (like patxis or zachary's -- or giordanos) but is a deep dish (like lou malnatis, gino's east or pizzeria uno). We have never been disappointed here and can recommend it to chicago natives and deep dish lovers without hesitation. We have tried both the garlic bread and roasted kale as appetizers and would recommend skipping the appetizers. The wine selection pairs well with the pizza.
author: T K.

description:
It's a 3.5 star place for me, because...

THE FOOD was simply good*. Not delicious, not just okay either but right in between. I probably wouldn't rush to come here again, but it's not like I would say no to it if a friend wanted to go. :) We had the deep dish classic with a few extra toppings. I'm personally not the biggest fan of deep dish pizzas because they are way too loaded for me, but my bf wanted the deep dish, so yeah... ;) They put a lot of tomato sauce on top of everything on the pizza, which for me was the biggest mistake. It overshadowed the other toppings a lot.

THE STAFF was super nice! 

THE PLACE was casual but trendy. I liked it.

THE PRICE was a bit too high. We wanted to share a large one and planned to take half home for the next day. On their website they say that the large one feeds 3-4 people. If that was true, the price of 26$ would be fine. However, the two of us almost ate the entire thing - we only had one piece left. 

Good for groups up to four people!

*My Food Ratings:
Mindblowing
Delicious
Okay
Not good
Horrible
author: Saskia C.

description: Delicious ~ everything!  Tried the garlic bread, the Caprese salad and then 5 of us shared two pizzas. We ordered a pesto chicken thin crust and a meteor deep dish. Wow!!  To top it off, excellent service. I can't wait to return and try another selection!!
author: Ann B.

description:
My girlfriend and I are in from Chicago and were looking for a good bite our first night in town. Although skeptical, we decided on Little Star, even though we eat enough pizza in the Windy City.... Holy cow are we happy we took the plunge. The hour wait on a Tuesday at 7 were well worth it when we had our pizza. Ordered a little star with sausage and it was incredible. 

I can't think of a better slice of pizza I've ever had - Lou Malnatis and Giordanos are great but should take a few notes from these west coast geniuses.
author: Mike M.

description: Deep Dish was amazing but I actually liked the thin crust even better it was amazing! Great food, location and service. Definitely a place to go if you want pizza in SF.
author: Dakota G.

description:
That crust doh! 

I love how they add cornmeal to the crust -- killer! 
I've never had Zachary's so I can't compare in terms of the local faves -- bummer because I used to live so close. But after having tried the deep dish in Chicago, I have to say I enjoyed the Little Star Pizza more. The pizza was all veggie and even the two men at my table were silently nodding and chewing in happiness despite the lack of meat. 

We also ordered the wings app which came with carrots and celery sticks. The wings were pretty darn good too! Juicy and tender with a nice kick. 

We expected to wait for a while, but they were super quick and we were seated after 5-8 mins of waiting. 

The decor is nothing special -- dim lighting, small tables. 

-1 star because of the somewhat high price point for a small pizza and I'm still waiting for a deep dish pizza to REALLLY blow me away.
author: Erica H.

description: Would have given 4 stars BUT...1) they added gratuity of 18% for a bill that was 5 ppl and $70. Ridiculous. Had they not down that I probably would have tipped more than 20%. Also, the bathroom is disgusting. They obviously haven't cleaned it all day. Finally, the crust was not very good on the deep dish. Thin crust was a little better. Overall extremely disappointed.
author: Teresa N.

description:
So it seems San Francisco has numerous pizza options on hand for any crusty adventurer. I was curious to try out this deep dish spot as soon as I'd heard about it from my roommate. 

I'll say off he bat that I wasn't disappointed. The cornmeal crust of the deep dish was light and amazing, but still thick enough to to control the whole goodness that was the meat and cheese inside. 

We started out with 3 orders of the wings for 6 people, which might seem ambitious for some but really was just enough to ignite our appreciate before digging into three pizzas. 

We ordered two thin crust and one deep dish, and while the thin crust was good I personally wasn't the biggest fan of it. Some might also not be into tomatoes, and to those I'd suggest not long for the deep dish. 

Overall I'll def be back and this is a great spot to check out with friends. Little star is good by me!
author: Justyn W.

description:
A friend first introduced this place to me years ago and I felt closer to heaven with each bite I took.  Unfortunately I was swept away and longingly thought about the pizza shop in SF which I would proclaim to everyone was my favorite in the US.  Years later, I find myself in SF and with a bit of apprehension returned to Little Star.  Did time blow my expectations out of proportion???

Nope, Little Star was just as amazing as I remembered.  We had the chicken pesto, and I look forward to going back soon for the white pizza.  Kudos to a wonderful establishment for keeping its quality all this time despite its growing popularity.
author: Wendy F.

description:
Overall Impression: No doubt in my mind the best deep dish pizza I have ever tasted.

Cost: 20 for a specialty small (6 slices) that will easily feed 2. We had leftovers because the slices were so filling... and so delicious!

Taste: Out of this world. We ordered the Chicken Mediterranean that had sweet bell peppers, fresh green olives, artichoke hearts, chicken breast, and a hearty marinara sauce. They use VERY FRESH ingredients for which there is no substitute, and the flavors are to die for! 

Customer Service: The waiters are attentive, and they actually started cooking our pizza before we were even seated because they knew that it would take extra time to cook a deep dish. Once we were seated, the food came out very fast. Great system.

Ambience/Atmosphere: I think they were going for a hip Italian eatery/bar type of theme. Drink prices were actually very cheap relative to other bars in SF.
author: Kevin T.

description: My friend and I called in our order for pick up. We ordered the deep dish pizza and it was amazing. The pizza was hot and fresh when we got it home. I could eat this every night and be happy. (If I didn't end up weighing 500 pounds that is) Quality is excellent and you get good portions for what you pay for. The pizza took a reasonable amount of time and when we walked over it was easy to pay for and pick up. This is a great option for grabbing pizza to eat at home. I would love to dine in next time though to see that that is like as well.
author: Lacey L.

description:
Welp, never coming back to this place.

Do you enjoy being served by cute waiters & waitresses (one was even wearing an Iron Maiden t-shirt! Zany!) in a shout-at-each-other environment frequented by white hipsters? Here is your own personal Mecca!

Do you really like waiting 45 minutes for an overpriced (and by then, cold) pizza they told you would take 15 minutes to bake? Welcome to paradise, my friend!

If you're in the area, and looking for pizza, go to Stella Doro Pizza (basically next door). Cheaper, faster, and oh, they don't keep you waiting for almost an hour for even a small pizza. Crazy, I know!
author: Mark S.

description: This place is awesome! The chicken wings are a must and the small green salad is AMAZING! It's perfect for two or even three people. Catch them during happy hour. For a perfect meal for two...grab an order of chicken wings and a small salad. Your satisfied without the guilt.
author: Alicia D.

description: Why the hype?! After trying Zachary's I knew I had to come to the competition to try it out. Parking was super difficult, but luckily it was pretty empty so we were able to be seated immediately. We ordered a deep dish and the garlic bread. The garlic bread was good and came with fresh basil, but I wish it was served with marinara dipping sauce. There wasn't a huge beer selection and no tvs which really sucked because it was the Giants playoffs game that night. As for the dining experience it was way too dark in there and epic fail on not carrying honey for the crust. Now the size of pizza was hella small and a little on the salty side. I'm definitely team Zachary's.
author: Cristal C.

description: the best deep dish pizza in the Bay Area. definitely rivals the ones i had in Chicago, and a bit disappointed i don't go there as often as i should. stick with the classic deep dish.
author: Mike C.

description:
Recently tried out Little star based on the great reviews, and I'm so glad that it lived up to expectations and that I've found myself some awesome deep dish pizza in SF!
The service: Front start to finish, the service on my trip was flawless. Welcoming hostess plus a waiter than never let our glasses be empty and always with recommendations made for an awesome trip. With their apparent success, it would be easy to let this fall to the wayside, but they haven't! 
Food: We got the garlic bread to start based on recommendation. It was as good as described and pretty huge actually. My only issue with it was that it was a little similar to the pizza, which was what was coming next, so I felt a little like we ordered two of the same thing. Not their fault and it was definitely good, but just something to keep in mind. For pizza, my fiancee and I shared the Little Star deep dish (Duh! How could we not get their titled pizza on our first visit?!). It was everything we had hoped it would be and more! The ingredients were all clearly fresh and it was packed. One small was definitely enough for two medium hungry people. We had leftovers too! It was a little greasy, but hey, it's pizza! Can't expect completely healthy. There were pretty few options on the menu, which I think is a sign of a good restaurant that knows what it does well.
Atmosphere: Super SF-y. Fairly small, a little dark, and very hipster. I dug it! They had curtains I assume to help keep the noise a little lower, which I thought worked well. 

Overall: I was super stoked after my visit to LS. From service to food it was spot on. The price was appropriate for what you get and the whole vibe was great. I can't wait to come by again! My only complaint is that I'm just outside the delivery territory (although to be fair, it is through an outside service, so not their fault). I'll just have to wait a little longer to get my deep dish fix!
author: Brad M.

description: Best pizza we have had since moving to California ! Great sauce, great cheese! We go the thin crust and were blown away! Their happy hour was excellent we got two beers and some appetizers that were very tasty. The spicy wings were an interesting flavor but good. The garlic bread was really good! Totally willing to travel into the city for this pizza!!
author: Katie R.

description:
This place was recommended to me by an SF native as one of the best pizza places and was later told by roommate who is a foodie that this is her go to pizza restaurant as well. So I've had this place in mind to try for awhile.

Came here for dinner and had a 20 min. wait. The hostess took my name and number so they could notify us when the table was ready. My friend and I just went around the neighborhood until then. The neighborhood and outside of the restaurant has a totally different feel compared to when you walk in the restaurant. The interior is nice inside but it was really packed. 

Service was great. The atmosphere was chill and the lighting was dim. As for the pizza, it was really good! We made our own pizza by adding pepperoni and sausage onto a medium thin crust. Even after all that hype and the long wait to finally try this place, it did not disappoint. I was happy with the overall experience. I'd recommend eating here if you're in SF and looking to eat some pizza.
author: Jen D.

description:
Came here with a friend. I had heard stories about waiting for hours before being able to eat. When he suggested getting together around 5, I thought it would have been perfect to come to Little Star Pizza - early! It was a surprisingly light meal - for eating a bunch of carbs. 

We got the garlic bread - It was like garlic bread with some cheese on top. Yum! Then we got a pizza half classic, half little star. The friend didn't want to get little star - but honestly, you have to get pizza that named after the place. Only makes sense. Great service and had a great time!
author: Nina Y.

description: The best. Honestly, the best deep dish pizza I have EVER had. I'd like to write a long, drawn out review but there's no need. It's delicious, just go and try it.
author: L M.

description:
Ordered the Little Star Small Deep dish pizza for take out. Called in probably only 10mins in advance. Then I only had to wait like 5 mins in the restaurant and the pizza was done! Super fast! 

The pizza was delicious! It was a bit heavier on the cheese than I remember it, but all together, it was really good! I forgot how much I like their "corn meal" crust! It gives the pizza an extra texture that you don't normally get at other places! Love it!!
author: Amiee H.

description: Not quite sure why this place has such high reviews. We went here tonight with high expectations. My wife and I ordered the chicken wings which were very spicy and came with the blue cheese dipping sauce. We asked for ranch and they don't carry ranch. What kind of pizza place  does not carry ranch dressing? Next we ordered a deep dish small pizza and asked for no mushrooms. The pizza came out and It had mushrooms on it. The crust was hard and the pizza just lacked flavor. If you're craving good pizza I would definitely not recommend this place. Plus it is extremely pricey for the low quality of food that you get.
author: Michael F.

description:
Well, I live near Zachary's pizza in Oakland so I do know some good Chicago Style pizza. I thought this place was just okay. We had a big group go over since friends from out of town were visiting and one friend lives in the area. We walked over grabbed the pizza and brought it home. The pizzas were pretty cold and just okay in terms of flavor. The mixed green salad though was very very good.

I would probably go back if someone suggested it, but there are so many places in the area to try that I may suggest another.
author: Jennifer S. C.

description: Deep dish goodness.  Busy but great atmosphere.  Hostess was awesome, we had a drink across the road while we waited for a table.  Worth the wait and more.
author: Dan O.

description: I love this place! I've watched it grow from the very beginning. The food is great (when I could eat cheese), now get the salad and chicken wings. Still loving it. Are you all going to experiment with soy cheese? Hope so!
author: Portia O.

description:
It's a good thing this place was near eh place my friends and I were staying at because their pizza was really great! We were yelping pizza places one night and noticed the 2,000+ reviews of this place. We read some of the reviews and were convinced to try it out; good thing we called early enough to do a pick up before they closed.

We ordered two large deep dish pizzas--- Classic and Mediterranean and a side do garlic bread. Pretty darn expensive pizzas but then again their pizza was hearty and big. About one and a half can fill you up. I really liked the Mediterranean one so I will definitely order that one again in the future 

There was 5 of us and we had hella leftovers the next morning but it was really good leftovers!
author: Jorgess M.

description:
I know it's just pizza, but Little Star has a special place in our family's heart. When we came back from our honeymoon in Asia and needed a cheese fix, my wife and I went to Little Star for our first meal back in SF. After our baby was born, I called Little Star and brought it back to the hospital (they're very convenient to Kaiser).

My personal favorite is The Classic, which is the deep dish pizza with sausage, peppers, and mushrooms. When I'm rolling with the wife, who's vegetarian, we usually pick up a Little Star (spinach, mushrooms, ricotta, feta) or just a straight-up Cheese. 

These are all deep-dish, mind you. I've tried the thin crust, which is fine, but the deep dish is where Little Star really shines. That cornmeal crust is just phenomenally good, and although the first melty slice usually gets the fork and knife treatment, I can usually hand-hold the rest of them - that's how strong (and yet delicious) the crust is.

I also highly recommend their mixed salad to start. It's a delicious mix of greens, cherry tomatoes, onions, walnuts, blue cheese, and vinaigrette. It's going to knock your socks off and prepare your belly for the main event.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Told us our table was ready, so we herded all 10 people over from drinking at Fly Bar, only to find that it wasn't ready. Weird, but I guess they want everyone there so they can seat you? 

order deep dish when you put your name in so it's ready when you are seated.

The pizza is of course really good, and our server was really nice about adding two additional people halfway through the meal to an already cramped table. 

this and patxi's are deep dish pizza staples!
author: Sonya Z.

description: Been going here since it opened and little about the pizza has changed. It's too good to make any drastic changes and that's s good thing. Walking around the neighborhood after work you can usually smell trails of others walking home with it and it smells so good!
author: Raylan W.

description: Due to growing up within easy driving distance to Zachary's pizza, I was a tad skeptical of Little Star before I tried it.  Could it truly be as good as the excellent stuffed pizza I was born and raised on in the East Bay? The answer: yes!  I actually give Little Star the edge over Zachary's in a couple of areas including their corn meal crust and the chill vibe working.  Although parking is tough, the pizza makes it worth it!  The craft beer selection was solid last time I went.  You could even walk (or roll if you ate entirely too much pizza) a couple blocks to the Independent post dinner.
author: Murray B.

description:
The five star reviews are spot on, so here's another one!

The BF and I were feeling like some pizza after we spend a few hours at the Russian Festival, so I suggested we try Little Star as it was only a short walk away. I was surprised when we walked in and there were only a few people inside since it was prime eating time on a Saturday. We were seated right away and our waitress was super nice and very attentive =)

We ordered the chicken wings and the classic deep dish pizza to share. I was looking forward to the pizza so I didn't give the wings a second thought until my boyfriend told me I had to try them. Holy crap these were AMAZING! I usually like my wings nice and saucy, but I was blown away by these wings, they were dry but so tasty!! Nice and tender with a subtle spicy kick that creeps up on you as you keep eating. Delicious.  Our pizza followed about 10 minutes later and we dug in. SO NOM. I can't remember the last time I had deep dish but I don't want to go anywhere but Little Star from here on out. The crust was perfectly crispy and had a delicious bready, handmade flavor. Also NO SOGGY, GREASY RESIDUE!! The crust was totally dry and perfect. I'm not a big cheese fan but no worries as there was the perfect amount in our pie, along with a copious amount of toppings. But what really pushed this pie over the top was the addition of the delicious tomato sauce on top which had chunks of tomatoes to give a tasty texture. I could eat that sauce straight it was so yummy.

Can I come back tomorrow? I loved everything about this place, the food, the people, the ambiance, it was PERFECTION. This is my go-to pizza place for sure, I can't wait to go back! We already decided we are getting the Mediterranean Pizza next ;)
author: Sam F.

description:
Five stars for the food, but maybe not the service! I was really thrilled to be introduced to a deep dish pizza place that was using fresh ingredients and a cornbread crust! I usually don't love pizza, I know weird, but both the classic and the little star were delicious! The sauce was rich and perfectly seasoned and I can't begin to describe my love story with the crust.

The service was not great, I came with a party of five and it took us forty five minutes to be seated, maybe even an hour.
There are not too many large tables at this location and it's hard to seat more than 3!  The manager was a little condescending and  rude but we visited on a Tuesday!
author: Shruti S.

description:
OOOO yea .... Chicago deep dish in San Francisco - only BETTER ! 
I ve had deep dish in Chicago and was not a big fan of it. I usually enjoy thin crust pizza's but this one blew my mind ! 

They have ample space and a nice cosy atmosphere. I came here with 2 friends on a tuesday night and we were seated immediately. I was craving for some hot pizza and thats what I got !! 

a must try in the hood !
author: Priyanka P.

description:
Prior to my experience here, I've never had deep dish pizza before. Sacramento isn't known for their deep dish pizza so I never bothered to try it. After our New Years festivities, we decide to try this place for a hearty meal. This place is a little bit hard to find because there outside is pretty plain with a small sign in front. The inside is very nice with a bar and wood tables. It only fits about 30 people max so it may not be ideal if you have a large group of 10+.

We sat down and I ordered (split between two) the spicy chicken wings with the Little Star Deep Dish Pizza with a nice beer. The wings were awesome. Deep fried perfectly so the skin is soo nice and crispy! The wings had just enough spicy for a good kick. The pizza was delicious! Very hearty with a lot of spinach. I couldn't get through three slices without tapping out. And for about 25 bucks (splitting wings, pizza, beer, and tip) I say it was a successful post New Years Meal. I will be coming back very soon
author: Andy H.

description: Hard to find a good deep dish pizza. This is a good deep dish pizza. Try it.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
We really loved the thin crust pizza.  We added roasted garlic and basil and it was perfection.  We also got the  deep dish classic which was very good but most of us didn't like the crust.   All of the Ingredients seem really good quality. 

So, we are glad we tried the deep dish but would never order it  again. We definitely will come back for the thin crust.

Service was very nice. We arrived at noon and we got our pizzas 30 minutes later

We walked here after viewing the Painted Ladies houses.  It was especially memorable, because there was an estate sale in one of the homes, and we got to go inside and look around .
author: Foodlover B.

description:
First time I tried the special pizza. 
after a 20min wait I discovered a tasty and crunchy pizza more like a "tarte" for the french people. 
The staff is nice, the place small and intimate. 
The price are very correct for the good quantity and quality :)

I recommend this place
author: Laura B.

description: I just have to write a review on the best restaurants we visited while in san fran. .While this one isn't on guy fiore s list, it's one that was recommended by my husband's customer who moved to so cal from San fran. ..little star indeed..we circled the whole entire block looking for this spot! !but....it was worth it! Man I've never had a pizza like lasagna thick!!!! We ordered which I apologize forgetting the name but it's the locals favorite, ordered large size and we thought maybe it wouldn't be sufficient enough for four people cuz we're a family that can really chow down....oh hell no..This one was so thick and big that one slice will definitely fill you up!!no kidding! Plus a side order of their delicious salad...perfect dinner! !! Highly recommend! !!!! Very nice , very friendly and awesome pizza!!!!!
author: Lisa F.

description:
The pizza is great.  The service is great too with highly intelligent servers... 

Not quite as good as a deep dish in Chicago  but the best I've had in the Bay Area...
author: Ben H.

description:
I've had pizza in Chicago, and pizza in Brooklyn, and this place is as good as it gets for California deep dish. 

I'm a fan of pizza (surprise). Part of how I judge a city is by its best pizza joints. I've tried to make it a point to visit the best rated pizza shops in every major city I've walked through. From the folding thin crust of coal-fired Brooklyn slices, the generous pies of Chicago, to the fresh wood-fired oven Neapolitan pizza of Tony's Pizza Napoletana here in SF and innumerable shops in-between, I've somehow managed to refine a fairly snobby palate for the end product of cooking tomato and cheese on dough.

Most places with mediocre to decent ratings manage them with the portions. It takes more than a lot of food to make me remember it, though. I need personality/flavor to keep me coming back. National chains reliably suck at accomplishing this, and everywhere else just throws heaps of frozen, processed or greasy food at you. Little Star manages to avoid all of that with a standard of memorably good pizza. 

Though I've had several types here, my weakness is the deep dish. It's the only thing I've had that comes close to standing up to the immensely flavorful Lou Malnatti's in Chicago. Little Star deep dish crust is crispy and substantial, the cheese is real, and its tomato sauce rivals most. The ingredients aren't limp or bland. While this is a deep dish, the similarities with Sicilian style pizza are only good: the bottom is the crispiest, and the dough above that soft and pillowy. It's a quality crafted gourmet pizza, and you realize it the minute you sink your teeth into its old-world perfectly ratioed wedges.

The thin crust is above serviceable if you're a homesick New Yorker, but I wouldn't be tempted to call it better than a Di Fara's (good flat pizza in SF can be found at Tonys Pizza Napoletana, or Emilia's Pizzeria in Berkeley). Still, it's some of the best you're likely to find on the West Coast. The deep dish is where Little Star shines.

The last I checked they don't sell by the slice, and the cost is a bit steep as you add more ingredients, but for the quality, it's easily worth a visit. This isn't drunk food. It's where you go to get quality pizza.
author: Brian S.

description: My favorite pizza place in the city! My fiance and I would go every friday or Saturday as "our spot". We would get the deep dish half cheese/half pepperoni and black olive, plus garlic bread. The crust on the deep dish is a great corn meal, almost sweet flavored dough, with a good crunch! We love the atmosphere and the staff (especially Kat!), everyone is very nice, helpful and friendly. Would recommend to anyone wanting some good food and a friendly, casual atmosphere!
author: Karisa A.

description:
Why is the Brass Monkey #60 on 7x7's list of The Big Eat SF?  Because it's freakin AMAZING, possibly even life changing!  You can probably get the pickiest eater to eat his spinach by presenting him with this pizza!

It was early on Friday night when we decided to finally try out Little Star.  We decided to do take out instead of eating there since we knew parking would be hard & that it would be crowded there.  The promise time was quicker then I thought, 25 minutes.  Double parked, picked it up & off we were back to the house.

Brass Monkey we finally ate you!  The ricotta and feta cheeses give the pizza a nice creamy and smooth taste of cheese without having to worry about never ending cheese when you cut it (though I'm guilty of sometimes liking this).  The sauce was really good too with plenty of herbs. I loved the garlic which complimented the veggies, and the sausage was juicy.  The crust was perfect too..mmm nom nom!  If you don't do meat, then you have to try the Little Star, which is exactly the same thing but without the sausage.  Oh Little Star, me love you long time...if only you took card, then I may just love you forever!
author: Cat C.

description:
Again, it's all about the cornmeal crust. Their prized possession!
It's named "Little Star Pizza" for a reason... BIG hint for which pizza to order. *wink wink*

And yes to confirm, still... better than Zachary's.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
I lived in the Midwest for a few years while in college, and the best Chicago deep dish pizza I ever had was at Uno in Cincinnati. That was my first experience.. ever since I've been searching for something similar or better.

I think Little Star just filled in that void. A really really delicious pizza. The sauce is spectacular. I do like the cornbread crust, not my favorite but it tastes really good. We had the large special.. meatballs, feta, spinach, mushrooms I think. Totally enjoyed it but could only eat 2 slices.. it's HUGE! That's ok took it home and had it for lunch at work the next day hahaha Also ordered the garlic bread.. which is like a mini pizza with melted mozzarella and garlic yumminess.

We'll be back! To try the thin crust.. maybe. I love deep dish!
author: Vol T.

description:
Best deep dish pizza in the US.  The cornmeal crust is crispy and doughy and fan -freaking-tastic.

I get the large (guess what? it is only $5 for more than double the pizza - who could order the small when you can have amazing leftovers?)

My suggestion is the sausage mushrooms and green peppers (but I sub the green peppers for spinach and it is my fav).

I try to avoid getting a bottle of wine (it doubles the price for dinner, but sometimes I cannot resist) so if you were going to get a large pizza for $24 it could feed you and your man tonight and both of you again for lunch the next day! deal-city.
author: Amy W.

description:
I want to give Little Star 4 stars... but I can't justify it.

Is it one of the top 5 "Chicago Style" places in the Bay Area? Yes. 
Is that saying much given the lack of options in the Bay? No.

Crust - pleasingly solid base that withstood the sauce well but overcooked and had very dry edges. A great cornmeal texture but lacking any real flavor. Not terrible but not great. I've had better cornmeal crusts.

Sauce - Very... average. In a deep dish the sauce is what defines the pizza and this was not sweet, not tart, not herbed, not spiced, not.. well anything much. Just... a tomato sauce. Felt like a great base for the sauce I wanted in there. Again, not bad... just not great. Almost dull.

Cheese - good ricotta, nice cheese base, but would have preferred more of it. Probably my fav part of the pizza overall, just needed more.

Meat - couldn't taste it through the sauce but it had a good texture. 

Service - Minimal. Friendly staff but they are terrible at setting expectations (pizza took about 40 mins to get to our table... 20-30 is fine but it wasn't even that busy) and don't really pay any attention to you once you've sat down.

Overall... it's a decent enough pie I suppose but it's mostly popular as far as I can tell due to the novelty of this style in SF. Which is also how it justifies its kind of too high prices. Certainly not worth it unless you're in the area and only then because it's different. 

Would I go back? Sure, but I won't be seeking it out any time soon and that's a shame: I think it could be amazing if it just... tried harder. But it's SF... so it doesn't have to.
author: Gregory W.

description:
Zachary's is better

Came here to get their famous chicago style deep dish pizza. The decor here is dim for a slightly romantic atmosphere.

Spicy Chicken Wings ($11)
1lb of slightly seasoned chicken wings that was either heavily peppered or slighlty brunt. Good flavor but dont expect it to be your traditional buffalo wings. 3.5/5

Mediterranean Chicken chicago pizza ($20 for a small 9')
I think this pizza would have benefited greatly if they used a white sauce instead but the flavoring isnt as good as zachary's. The freshness was there but I felt something was missing. 3/5

Overall, decent place for pizza with the a decent selection of deep dish and thin crust but not the best around.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Do you see the 5 glowing stars for this review?

I've been thinking of powerful words to really bring home how I feel about Little Star Pizza.  

I had a first draft. 

And a second draft.  

Then I gave up. 

It was my  first time having LSP the night of our happy hour at Madrone.  Yes, I'm making a grand statement when I say "it's damn good deep dish pizza".  Wait.  Scratch that.  

It's not a grand statement.  It's a fact.

We called in our order for take-out and promptly picked it up in 30 mins.  A small Classic deep dish with sausage, mushrooms, onions and green bell peppers.  But savvy yelpers know to ask for the Brass Monkey which is not on the menu.  (It is #60 on the Big Eats SF list.)

A little bit over half an inch thick crust topped with ricotta and feta cheese, sausage, spinach, onions, garlic, mushrooms. Everything just seems to marry well together.  It's like lasagna on a pizza pie. You may automatically conclude that this deep dish is chewy, but it's not.   You take that first bite.  Your teeth literally sinks into the heavenly crust.  The billion nerve endings on your taste buds get excited by the zesty sauce and as the chunky tomatoes hit it full force, it makes you salivate for more.   

More.  

Judging from the 1000+ reviews on this place, it's safe to say that LSP has mastered the art of deep dish pizza awesomeness.  

5 glowing stars.
author: Janice C.

description:
You know, when you're in love with something, you want to find something close or like it.
 
That's how I was with thin crust pizza from Italy. I have not found a place that could resemble close to it, until now....

Thank you Little Star Pizza for the delicious thin crust pizza and delicious pomegranate sunrise champagne drink.

The ambiance was nice, the service was friendly, and the food was bomb. If you're craving for a pizza place to go to, I suggest Little Star Pizza.
author: Justina L.

description:
Great deep dish pizza in the bay area. You can customize the pizza however you want it. I got a small deep dish divided into half little star (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic) and classic  (half sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bell)

Cute ambiance with a nice server. Had a great time here.
author: Noel K.

description: Yum, yum, I love Little Star's thin pizza...I've even eaten leftovers for breakfast!  My favorite spot to order delivery from whenever I'm in town. Not cheap...just reliably delicious.
author: Lynn S.

description:
This place is mmmm mmmmm good. If asked to pick between Little Star, Patxi's, and Zachary's, I would honestly take any of the three!

I went to the Divis location on a weekday and there was no wait - always a bonus point in my book. Three of us shared a deep-dish pizza (I think it was the vegetarian or Mediterranean combo) and a large salad. Both were fabulous and it was plenty of food for us (me + two hungry dudes).

The decor and ambiance is nothing special, but I think the quality of the food and service count for more.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
I'm from Chicago (does that automatically make me an authority?) so I've had my share of deep dish. The pie here is pretty much on par with what I could get back home. Portions are generous, ingredients are high quality. 

Pros: because pizza. Good pizza, good topping selections and pre builts. They let us order ahead of time and come in to sit and eat, saved half an hour of wait time since the deep dish pizzas take a while to cook. Price is reasonable. 

Cons: a bit too salty, and the menu isn't very deep. The host at the front door wasn't the best, confrontational instead of welcoming. 

Pro tip: call and see if there is a long wait for tables. If not, order your pizza ahead and when you pick it up, ask to eat in instead. Can't guarantee it will always work but it's worth a shot.
author: Patrick T.

description: As if this place needs another review... Outstanding pizza! Better than anything I have had in Chicago. Great service as well. Had a salami and tomato topped Deep dish... I'd be a fool not to come back!
author: Krys L.

description: THIS PLACE IS SO GOOD! Little Star Pizza is such a great pizzeria on Divisadero Street. We stopped by after seeing what great reviews it had and I'm glad we did. There was a fairly long line when we get there since they don't take reservations, and there were mostly large parties ahead of us. When we checked in for a table the hostess asked for my number and I immediately got a text showing how long I've been waiting and how many people are in front of me. Our wait was about 45 minutes and was killer because of the aroma of the pizzas. There's little couches to sit on or you can wait outside but most chose to stand outside to avoid clustering the entrance. When you are waiting they can also take your order so that once you are seated you immediately get your food since the pizzas take about 35 minutes to make. When we finally were seated and got our pizza it was like heaven on earth. I've never had such great flavorful deep dish pizza. The crust was everything with a flight crunch and almost cornmeal taste. I can't wait to try the different pizzas on the menu.
author: Melanie B.

description:
I'm from Chicago, so I know the real deal with deep dish, and Little Star is a fake!

(Now that the obligatory disclaimer is out of the way, I can begin my review for real...)

Little Star is fantastic pizza.  After an earlier run-in with a highly recommended SF pizzeria, I was skeptical of Yelp's reviews of Bay-area pizza joints.  But Little Star is a big slice of happiness.

It's small, and kinda hard to find.  Their sign doesn't even light up.  I was dining alone, so I sat at the bar to avoid a 30-minute wait.

I began with their garlic bread.  It's basically a sliced sourdough loaf with a cup of melty butter and half a garlic clove.  It's up to you to scoop out the garlic and administer that and your butter as you see fit.  Initially, this annoyed me, but it was so good, I let the do-it-yourself assembly slide.

Then came the pizza.  I ordered a small deep dish pepperoni.  The sauce is the best part.  It's fairly chunky and zesty.  For any Chicagoans out there, it reminded me a bit of Giordano's.

The crust was surprisingly well done.  It was thick, but light.  Even when you get to the notoriously difficult-to-manage end of a slice, it remained good.  It looked similar to Pizzeria Uno/Due, but tasted far better.  They even had some cornmeal action on the bottom - a nice touch.

The only place where Little Star's non-Chicago roots were painfully evident was the cheese.  In the midwest, we know cheese.  Some of us wear it to football games.  It's a passion.  In California, I assume cheese is a 4-letter word.  It conjures thoughts of cholesterol and the human manatees Chicago is famous for.  So maybe that's why Little Star skimped a bit on the cheese.

That said, I was more than happy with my visit to Little Star.  And if I ever make it to San Francisco again, I'll be back.  And for those of you in San Francisco looking for an equally awesome pizza treat when visiting Chicago, look up Lou Malnati's.

(Important Note: Little Star does *not* take credit cards.)
author: Ben B.

description:
When I visited to Little Star Pizza with my another friend, I had a salad and he had the pizza but the salad wasn't look fresh because the greens were brown around the edge and huge.  The pizza was just .OK!! 

I thought might be its due to late night visit when almost everything has been finished , btw staff management was good so my over all level of satisfaction is "Ok"\
author: Rob D.

description:
Solid deep dish, but not the best I've had--even outside Chicago. Crust was by far the best part! I thought they were a little stingy on the ingredients though... I could taste so much tomato sauce and had to look for the sausage. That's a quick fix! I ate half a small pizza and wasn't even that full, surprisingly. (They said small pizzas are for 2-3 people, and larges are for 3-4 people... But those are for not-hungry people or for lunchtime appetites.) Decently priced for deep dish though!

I was waiting for friends, and they told me I couldn't sit until everyone was there, even though the place was half-empty. Rules are rules, I suppose. My waitress kept avoiding eye contact with me, even though I was thanking her every time and she would just walk away. Very strange.

Pretty cozy place though. I'd definitely come back if they would fill their deep dish a little more.
author: Kimberly Y.

description: Don't be worried about the chunks of garlic you see on your breadsticks; you're going to love them. The pizza is great and worth the wait.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Hands down, the best pizza I've ever had!

I came here with my boyfriend at around 2ish on a Friday afternoon. Luckily, we parked right in front of Little Star. With a name like Little Star, I was expecting a bright cheerful restaurant, but Little Star is far from that. It was really dark despite the beautiful sunny weather we were having in SF. Although it was dark, Little Star is cozy and tastefully decorated with lots of hand painted artwork.

Our hostess/waitress was also very sweet and nice. She greeted us with a warm hello and brought us our water in a jug before we could get settled in our seats. She told us about their special and I was instantly sold. After looking at the huge menu, my boyfriend settled on a small deep dish sausage and pepperoni pizza and I settled on the small special which was an olive oil based pizza topped with bacon, broccollini, sharp cheddar, and garlic (all the things I absolutely love!) The wait was about 15-20 minutes for our orders which was pretty long but well worth it!

Once I took that first bite, I was like "OMG GIVE ME MORE!" At pizza places, I usually have up to 2 slices and I'm done but that wasn't the case at Little Star. Good Lord, I must've had at least 3-4 slices plus a slice of my boyfriend's pizza. SO GOOD! The special was absolutely delicious! The bacon was crunchy, the broccollini was fresh, and the garlic? Well, spread it before biting into your pizza or else you'll get a whole lotta garlic! The deep dish pizza was also very good! If you like lots of tomato sauce on your pizza, then you'll like their deep dish pizzas. The cornmeal crust was my favorite! SO good! The small sizes are not as small as you think; enough to share between 3 people.. or eat by yourself. ;) The total came out to under $40 for two pizzas -- a little pricy, but totally worth it!

I can't wait till I go back!
author: Joyce E.

description:
I'm from Chicago, and it's no exaggeration to say that I ate pizza at least 4-5 times per week while growing up. I know a thing or two about pizza. And I think Little Star could easily be a solid pizzeria in Chicago. 

The skinny: The sauce is delicious and has a nice twang. The cheese is ooey-gooey and has a subtle milky, yet peppery flavor, and the cornmeal crust is a nice mix of chewy and crunchy. Happily recommended!
author: Don W.

description: Really solid pizza.  I'm not usually a deep dish type of person (I generally prefer a new york style pizza), but this stuff was really good.  I wasn't too greasy.  Fresh ingredients, friendly service.
author: Paul W.

description:
My first time eating here, and my last at this location. The pizza was very good, I give them that, though the sauce on the thin crust pizzas leave something to be desired the deep dish is delightful. But sadly the service is awful. My party arrived in two parts, myself and one member first, where we were greeted and seated promptly, off to a good start. I asked for water because its no longer complimentary (pretentious but expected from this sort of establishment) and we mentioned two other members were late. Fine. Eventually our party showed up, and Little Star was still nice. We placed our orders, two small pizzas, a deep dish and a thin crust, and the gentleman took out order and went on his way. Having worked in pizza places I wondered what the time would be for the deep dish, they usually take a while but nothing was mentioned. We had some drinks and awaited our pizza. Just after our beers arrived another couple was seated near us. Then another. Then after we finished our beers a large mob of drunken soccer fans just leaving a World Cup party was seated. And pizzas? Well one couple to my right got one, we were ignored. Then another group. Then the squawking gaggle of idiots started getting there's. 

Bottom line we ordered at 2:40 pm on a Sunday and received our first think crust at 3:40. The deep dish was another 10 minutes. No word about it, no "hey we got busy" no "we forgot" not even a "hey we burnt it".
