He'll we didn't even get a thank you for waiting. Or even asked if we wanted a second round of drinks. If your in the neighborhood, go to the Taqueria down the street.
author: Izzy F.

description: We walked in to Little Star Pizza after a long day of travel and were almost knocked off our feet with the delicious-smelling tomato sauce inside. The payoff once we ordered and got our food (a half traditional, half chicken deep dish pizza) did not disappoint. I was a big fan of the crust, which was really tasty and not as greasy as traditional deep-dish pizzas. We also had a caprese-style tomato/basil/mozza salad which really hit the spot. Top it off with excellent casual but professional service. I would go again for sure.
author: Heather W.

description:
I'm giving them a 4 because I have yet to try a true deep dish pizza so I can't really compare.

But, I have tried Little Star in the past and they never disappoint to deliver a bomb pizza. The thick crust, thick tomato sauce, and melted cheese inside is a slice of pizza heaven! The ingredients in this pizza is different from your average pizza. One of the best things about Little Star is that their crust is more like cornbread and has a sweet taste to it. If you're not a fan of tomatoes, you might not like the sauce too much. Their sauce is very thick and has huge chunks of tomatoes in it. I brought one of my SF friends here on my visit and they weren't a big fan of LS bc they hated the huge chunks of tomatoes. (Weird right?)

But, if you're not a fan of tomatoes, they do offer other varieties that I'm sure are quite tasty too.

If you want something different in your diet, come by Little Star and prepare for a pie of goodness. If you're a pizza lover you won't be disappointed!
author: Hanna P.

description:
If you're looking for true deep dish pizza, this is not it. That being said, it's not a bad pizza.  

In any case, the pizza is pretty good. The cheese is tasty and of good texture. The crust is decent (could be a little crispier and have more of a butter taste), but the crust also isn't as tall as a true deep dish is supposed to be. If I can pick up the slice of pizza and eat it like a normal hand tossed pizza with relative ease, we are not dealing with a true deep dish pie. Not a bad attempt, but not quite there yet. Little Star provides a decent meal in any case. Restaurant has nice ambiance and good service, nothing over the top.

As a native Chicagoan, I have come to the conclusion I will never be satisfied with eating deep dish pizza in the Bay. Little Star provides a quality meal in any case, but it's not what I would consider a new favorite. I'd be happy to return, but I'm in no rush to do so.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Being a pizza lover (really, what American isn't), I loved this place. Honestly, it is extremely rare to find a place that not only serves both Chicago-style deep dish and thin crust, but also pulls it off well.

Was in town seeing some old friends, so naturally we went out drinking and to grab some pizza. For the latter, end your search and just come here. We ordered a pie of the thin crust and one the of the deep dish and were not disappointed. I did think their thin crust was better than the deep dish, but that isn't an insult at all, especially since GOOD deep dish outside Chicago is really hard to find. Definitely going back on the next trip.
author: David R.

description: Wow!!! Everything about this place was absolutely enjoyable!!! The environment was clean, cool, and friendly with hip. The staff was very helpful, kind, and friendly. We had a party of four and ordered a mixed salad that definitely fed all of us and was delicious.  And a combination of two kinds of pizza on one pie. Italian Combo and the Pollo were both great! Definitely would recommend this place and will go back when we visit again.
author: Patricia T.

description: Tried little star pizza for the first time. Had their greek/mediterranean pizza and a chicken deep dish pizza both of which were good. The waitstaff was incredibly friendly as was the hostess. Despite it being a busy new year's eve night.
author: Pranav K.

description: I've been coming here for years and the corn meal crust deep dish pizza is amazing. The "Classic" (sausage, onion, mushroom, pepper) deep dish is a must have here. The wings are also delicious if you want an appetizer. My last meal here I had dessert for the first time at Little Star, usually I'm too full after pizza, and the pumpkin cheesecake I had was very tasty and seasonally appropriate. I now live in Washington DC and I like Little Star so much that I make it a point to come back when I'm in town.
author: Wayne L.

description:
Man that cornmeal crust is good. Like really good. Man....

Um... yea go eat there, I don't really know what to say, this is the best deep dish in the bay area with the closest competition being the notably inferior zacharys in the east bay.
author: Misha T.

description:
It was tasty. We got the thin crust little star, add anchovies. 

The deep dish takes 30 mins to make. We were trying to catch a movie on van ness, so we couldn't wait. But, the thin crust was delish. Next time, trying that deep dish for sure!
author: Ari C.

description:
The restaurant has a cozy ambiance--candle-lit, toasty, quiet conversations. The service was quite prompt. We were also spared waiting at the restaurant for our table, for while they do not take reservations, they do take phone numbers to notify you when your table is ready. 

The food was very filling; for our group of four, we ordered garlic bread and a large, classic deep-dish pizza and were full. We were even able to substitute one pizza topping for free. The bill was $8/person--a great deal. All in all, we would highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Kate P.

description: We walked over here (about 15 blocks) and it was so worth the round trip.  The crust was light, flaky and tasty.  A good robust sauce and great cheese.  Not big fan's of the brand of pepperoni but there wasn't much so it wasn't off putting.  We also tried their spicy dry rub wings...very tasty!  This is our new favorite pizza in SF!!!
author: A. S.

description: SO GOOOOOOD. I always order Italian combo as deep dish and garlic cheese bread. So... So.. Good. I have it at least once a month and its still as great for take out as it is dining in.
author: Tina D.

description: My personal favorite for deep dish. I prefer it over Zacharys, Patxi's, and Masa in L.A. And I like this location over the one in the Mission. They just know how to get the taste right!
author: Roy K.

description:
Pushy, obnoxious staff in a claustrophobic environment that is not so much homey and quaint as it is annoying and grating. Epic fail. 

P.S. See my some 400 "tips" to get a sense of how fair and balanced I generally am.
author: Edward Y.

description: Great meatball starter. The deep dish pizza is very good. Excellent for good pizza. Environment is clean and very calming with candles. We had s fantastic dinner. Customer service is good.
author: Sharon O.

description: The pizza was SO SO good. Friend and I shared a salad, pizza and bottle of wine. Didn't have to wait long at all for a table. Took away one star since we did end waiting ages for our pizza. Luckily we hadn't seen each other in a while so we had lots of catching up to do - and the couple on a date next to us were very entertaining ("You haven't seen Spring Breakers? You have to - its the epitome of American cinematography!" - for real.)
author: Kathleen G.

description: The service was exceptional. No more than a 10 minute wait. Our group included 5 people. 2 kids, 3 adults. The waitresses and waiters and very kind. When I received my food,  it was DELICIOUS. I was in love with the cornbread crust of the deep dish pizza. No complaints. Very Good!!
author: Alex O.

description:
Chicago style deep-dish is one of my favorite comfort foods. Great on a rainy day or on a sunny one for that matter. It's just great.

I like mine loaded to the brim with "stuff" and Little Star knows how to do that. I love the Mediterranean Chicken but feel free to make your own (mushroooms, onions, olives, garlic, pepperoni, sun-dried tomatoes... mmmm mmmm mmmm)
author: Anna R.

description: Tasty pizza with friendly, efficient service!  Obviously a huge local favorite as the take out line never diminished in size during the entire time 90 minutes were eating there. Highly recommend this Divisadero pizza place.  You'll leave a happier human...
author: Spider W.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm not a deep dish pizza fan, so the deep dish pizza review is based on my friends' overall love for Little Star's deep dish pizza.

Deep dish: Everyone loves the deep dish, especially the one with pepperoni and sausage. 

Thin crust: I liked it. I would go back and eat this pizza. 

The wait...well, it's a pretty good pizza place overall, so the wait, as with most good restaurants, is pretty long. Last time I went, we waited an hour for our table. Service is super friendly. Parking in the area can be a nightmare though, so maybe carpool with friends if you can.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Great pizza and wings! Friendly services. Long wait during peak hours. 

Do not order a thin crust pizza to go!! I will never do that again. Pizza was not good at all for some reason!
author: Jangalina J.

description:
yayyyyyy they are open for lunch on fridays and saturdays so when we came on a friday afternoon around 1230, not a soul in there! YAY FOR US and parking around the block since they JUST did street cleaning. WHOOO

we ordered
spicy wings- yummy!!! lots of herb flavor and spicy and the dipping sauce that was blue cheese was really good. i hate blue cheese but the sauce was YUMMMM i wanted more!
the regular deep dish - we got a small and we were definitely stufffed by the time we finished it! the crust really was perfect. oooeey goooey cheese MMMM

glad we got to try it without a crazy wait! waitress was really nice and attentive!
author: Christine M.

description:
This is the third location we tried. I still prefer the original Mission location because they mince up thier veggies and finely slice thier meatballs, however, we were in the area for dessert at Candybar and wanted dinner afterwards.

We came in a little after 7pm and while putting our name down on the list, we were told we could pre-order our pizza (funny how the other locations never mentioned that?)

Our wait was not horrible, about 35min. After sitting down to our table, our pizza came about 10min later. We got the veggie deep dish (substituting regular garlic with roasted) 

Pizza was delicious as always, though the veggies were kinda huge and thick and I could barely taste the roasted garlic. My hubby also ordered the wings (OK but nothing special) and I also ordered thier cheesecake to go, after reading so many reviews of how great it was.

The cheescake was nothing too special, decent but not the best I've had. I still prefer Charlie's Cheesecake works in San Jose. 

One minor complaint with this location is that iced tea is not listed as (Bottled Honest tea or the flavlor) and don't get me wrong I LOVE Honest tea but NOT for $3 bucks when it costs less than half that in stores. The reason this bothered me was that I was expecting a refill with the amount of food we got as I have at thier other locations but obviously, it being bottled, they weren't going to do that. So if I'm expected to pay so much for iced tea, I expect refills!

TIP: Go right at opening or no later than 7pm, unless you wanna wait longer than 30min. I also HIGHLY suggest pre ordering your pizza so you aren't waiting for another 30min once seated. I also think it's courtous to others as well because it also shortens thier wait. Parking is a hit or miss.
author: Petra S.

description:
Hands down the best deep dish pizza I have ever had...including infamous Chicago pizzas.  (Blasphemous!  But true).  The Brass Monkey (which is the Little Star with sausage) is life changing.

The proportion and flavors of the spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic, and sausage is PERFECT.  I'm usually more a thin crust fan because I find deep dish too tomato-y and soupy, but Little Star is the exception.  The crust is perfectly buttery and crispy, and the decadent toppings are nothing short of fantastic.

I would give this location 4 stars instead of the 5 I gave the Valencia location because the garlic bread here does not provide an entire bulb of garlic, and the pies I have had here seem a little bit runnier.  Still, would come back in a heartbeat.

Overall, the BEST deep dish pizza in SF and beyond!
author: Carrie C.

description: So glad I was able to eat here for dinner. Hands down the best deep dish in SF. If this was in Chicago it'd be right up there with the big boys. It's full of flavor and the ingredients taste fresh. The garlic bread is delicious as well.
author: Sam P.

description:
Saw all the reviews about the Brass Monkey, and so I ordered it. Total letdown. Not sure what all the hype is... Tastes like a spinach lasagna. 

Don't get me wrong... Good quality, but not exactly what I'd call "best pizza in SF"
author: Jessica W.

description:
Deep dish leads to overfull bellies.

Overall, amazing.

We started with a few drinks, beer and wine, nothing exciting, just what you'd want while digging in to deep dish.

Shared an order of the spicy chicken wings.  Great flavor and looked like they had been thrown on the grill for a second which gave them an awesome slightly charred and smokey flavor.

The dish.  

We ordered two small pies (definitely enough for 3 people) Mediterranean chicken and a Cheese with Pepperoni and Sausage.  Both pizzas were amazing. The biggest surprise for me was the crust as it seemed to be cornmeal based which was awesome.  One of my dining companions mentioned that some people get honey to eat with the crust (which I can understand it, but still thought it was weird.)

Both were loaded with cheese and just the right amount of sauce, filled with toppings.  The Chicken had artichokes, red bell peppers, feta cheese and olives, and we added pepperoncini too.

I'd definitely return to indulge and maybe I'll bring a small bottle of honey too..
author: Dan H.

description: The most amazing deep dish pizza I've ever had. I've only ever gotten the take out and even having to take a somewhat long bus ride there and back, the pizza was the best tasting deep dish ever to enter my mouth. The crust is an amazing cornmeal crust which you really wouldn't mind eating, and the toppings/sauce are exquisite. Sometimes it does take a couple of tries to get through to the store when you're calling during the busy hours, but the pizza is always ready at the quoted time. I can't wait for my next visit!!
author: Vicky E.

description:
Would come back here again. For appetizer we had the Caprese Salad and the Garlic Bread. Caprese had some velvety mozzarella slices, fresh slices of sweet tomatoes (tasted like they just picked them from their backyard garden or something) and shredded basil on top a little pool of olive oil with balsamic vinegar and a few scatterings of green olives. Super yummy! My only complaint is I wish they gave more than 2 slices of bread with it. Luckily we had the garlic bread to sop up what was left over after the 2 slices were gone.

Now on to the pizza. We had the Mediterranean chicken...which was so freakin good. Usually deep dish pizza can get kind of heavy and dense but I didn't feel that way with this pizza. The crust was the perfect mix of crusty and puffy. Mozzarella cheese was melted to perfection and the artichokes, feta and green olives gave the perfect briny flavor that complimented the nice sweet tanginess of the tomato sauce that was slathered on top of it all.

We had left overs and they were even good the next day!

Food alone was enough for me to give this place 4 stars. Would have given five but the waiters were kind of unfriendly and cold. I mean they attended to our every need but they seemed really bored and didn't smile at all.
author: Vinny M.

description:
when i was served my very first slice of the classic deep dish, my hand that held my plate dropped about 6 inches at the heftiness of the glorious pizza. 

a good pizza, to me, is all about the cheese and the crust. i'm not a deep dish connoisseur but this was by far the best deep dish crust i've had. the crust, while looked thick, was a suprisingly light and airy cornmeal strip of crunchy goodness. the cheese was thick and melty topped with fresh ingredients, savory sausage, and an overly generous ladeling of tomato sauce.

we also had a special thin crust pizza with corn, bacon, and goat cheese. the crust was very crisp and cracked between the teeth without being too chewy.

too bad we didn't have a chance to try the brass monkey (as it is not on the menu), but there is always next time!
author: Charmaine L.

description: Unique pizza option. This is a cornmeal crust, saucy, complex pie. You literally will be fine eating just one slice. Okay but you gotta have another slice (it's so good). Alright, alright, one more. Whoops, you exploded. Start over.
author: Riley C.

description:
I could easily sum this review up in one sentence:

"I don't like deep dish pizza, but I love Little Star Pizza."

There I said it...but okay some more details. When I first moved to San Francisco, I was told about this place and it definitely wasn't first on my list of places to eat because honestly, I'm not a deep dish pizza fan. So one day I went with a few friends of mine and casually ordered their standard pizza and to my surprise, it was extremely enjoyable! Now, it doesn't convert me into a deep disher but it has elicited my business twice in the 2 weeks following that first encounter! That's how good it is.

I'm more of a NY thin cruster (having lived in NYC for the majority of my young adult life) so if any of you have recs, send them my way!
author: Julia P.

description:
I am such a lucky gal, got to check this off my BIG EAT list from 7x7 and the recommended choice was their brassmonkey deep dish pizza. Came here with a total of 4 and ordered a large 12" pizza + side mixed salad to share. The crust was perfect, not too heavy not too thick, the marinara and oozing mozzarella was divine. We ordered well as we finished everything and left with either: "omg, food coma" to "that was just right!" 

Quick tip: better than Patxis, came here at 6pm on Sunday, no wait.
author: Johanna P.

description:
Hands down the best pizza in SF!! I'm obsessed. I usually get the Classic. Perfect mix of ingredients, not too soggy and not too thick. 

I prefer dining in rather than delivery through Postmates or OrderAhead simply because the pizza tends to arrive cold after waiting 2 hours for delivery, plus $5 - $10 for the delivery, so not worth it.
author: Veronica J.

description:
#33 on the 2011 7x7 List: The Little Star**
#60 on the 2009 7x7 List: The Brass Monkey

**The Little Star is great but get the Brass Monkey, which is Little Star + sausage


-Tasty?  The first time I went to this Little Star was about 4 years ago and the deep dish crust is still memorable.   The Brass Monkey is a 1+up on their signature "Little Star" pizza with the addition of sausage.  Oh, how can anyone not love thee?

The Brass Monkey was hands-down the star of dinner.  I could eat a whole small pie by myself (okay, maybe over a couple of meals).  The Mediterranean chicken pizza (ordered by J's friend who doesn't eat mammals) was good but not as awesome as the Brass Monkey!!

-Service:  Water refill service is good; the waitress was a little motherly telling us to finish our food.  We had one slice of two different pizzas to be taken home by two different people, and she was very good with following through with our wishes.  Yay.

-Ambiance: Nothing has changed in 4 years - it's still a bat cave - i guess they're just ahead of the times with being green.

-Worth the trip/try?  Definitely but go early while the sun is still out like we did, so that you can see what your food and the place looks like, and avoid the wait.
 
Get the deep dish here.   If you want thin crust, there is a million other places out there.

Bring cash.  They have an ATM in the restaurant but I don't trust portable ATMs
author: Winnie L.

description:
Little star is a cute little place with a classy dimmed ambiance at night that's perfect for a date night and a friendly laid back staff.

I went here with some friends and ordered a large deep dibs pizza half classic and half little star. Both were pretty good. We also got the spicy chicken wings which had a nice bite to it.

I took one star away because they don't have ranch or honey. It's crazy to me that a pizza place does not have ranch at all, instead they use bleu cheese dressing. Not having honey is a little more understandable but the crust does taste much better with it. I'll probably be back but next time I'll be sure to bring my own condiments.
author: Amberlynn A.

description:
Little Star like many reviewers have stated --- might have the best deep dish pizza in the entire Bay Area. 

Olga B. and I have been coming for well over a year now --- and always enjoy one of the salads typically the Caprese or Mixed Salad to start along with a beer which is always served ice cold.

Next, we typically grab the "Little Star or Veggie Pizza." The Little Star Pizza's, while they takes 30 minutes or so to arrive - is always on point. Starting with a corn meal crust, the flavors start to rush into your mouth. 

Lastly, while occasionally I have had a short wait to get a table --- the service staff has always been spot on.
author: Brian D.

description: Very good but not great. Expect to wait so don't go when you're really hungry. Service was the highlight of the meal and the garlic bread is sooooo good. The deep dish pizza was good but not as good as I expected. Biggest complaint was that it wasn't hot when it came to the table--lukewarm at best. Not sure why it wasn't cooked longer. Sausage that comes in the classic was really good but wish there was more of it considering how expensive the pizzas are. Overall, it was good to go and say "I ate there" but probably won't be back.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
My friend had posted a pic of the pizza here the day before and it got me craving it! Just so happened I was right across the bay in Oakland and my friends knew the place so we went on over. Since I insisted on going, they brought me, but they admitted they actually preferred Zachary's in their own hood. Oh well, here we are. 

There were 5 of us and of course, it being a Sunday night on a holiday weekend, was pretty busy. We were quoted 45 min wait, so we walked around the neighborhood and came across Oasis café on the corner with $3 beers on tap. I was only halfway through my beer when my friends cell rang "um hi, your table is ready" Tad tells the hostess on the phone, "yeah you told us 45 mins and we aren't done with our beers, but we'll be back in 10 mins" Hangs up. Why does this chick call back and ask where we are?!??! Lol I thought it was hilarious. Ended up having Doug chug the rest of my beer and we strolled over to the restaurant and were seated right away. Other than that phone call, the service was good for the rest of the night.

For our meal we split the large mixed greens salad and a large pesto & spinach pizza. It was a good amount of food for us, everyone got 2 small slices. This pizza is extremely filling! Overall it was pretty tasty, the sauce needed a little something, not sure, but I liked it anyway.
The prices are pretty reasonable. I'd go back.
author: Francesca L.

description: There pizzas are sooooo delicious. I went with a friend and the service was great and the atmosphere of the place was very pleasant
author: Anthony A.

description: For ten years I've held the opinion that Zachary's is better than Little Star but tonight I'm not so sure. The classic deep dish was fantastic. AND the chicken wings are the best I can remember eating. Bonus.
author: Geoff B.

description: Not impressed. Pizza was mediocre at best. Surprising given so many positive 4 star+ reviews.
author: Bill R.

description:
Little Star has delicious deep dish pizza.  They are known for their cornmeal crust in particular. Comparing Little Star with Patxis isn't really fair since although deep dish they are quite different in flavor. I like Patxis slightly better but it's purely a personal preference. 

No idea about wait time or decor as I've only done takeout.
author: Amy L.

description:
Extremely good place. I would say the best pizza in San Francisco, but not the best in the U.S. and that's why I give them a 4 stars instead of 5. The best pizza in the US is at Gino's East in Chicago.

Now more about this place. This place can get extremely crowded and the wait can be insane. I recommend either going before 5pm or after 9pm if you don't like waiting. The ambiance here is dark and noisy but the service is good and the place is clean.

The pizza here is deep dish and I've tried most of them and I got to say they are pretty good and they are worth the wait.

Overall, I recommend at least trying this place once and most likely you will come back for more.
author: Anthony N.

description:
I wish I may, I wish I may eat a Little Star please!  My lady friends took me here as our reward for walking the Golden Gate Bridge.  We earned our deep dish pizza.  It takes about 30 mins. for the pizzas to cook.  But it is super fresh.  You can see the tomato chunks in the sauce, so fresh.  My eyes were bigger than my stomach.  I wanted to eat more, but I just couldn't go beyond two slices.  There was something very different about the crust and it made you want more.

For sure I'd go back here for some more.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Four stars for the food we had I think it was call the white pie so good! The larger size served the 3 of is perfectly.

However the service was awful. Our waiter couldn't look us in the eye and never checked on us we never even got water. We had to wave him down for more drinks. Maybe it was his first day but someone needs to teach him how to poor wine and how to memorize specials
author: M H.

description:
Amazing. Mouthwateringly good, both this place an it's sister restaurant in the Mission. Really like that you can bring your own wine in too.

Deep Dish is the way to go!!!
author: Owen M.

description: So good! You can't go wrong here. Huge portions, everything was delicious. One of my favourite meals in San Francisco. Get the deep dish pizza and the salad.
author: Rose L.

description:
We ordered ahead
Small Little star add pepperoni plus small white pie.
More than enough for two ppl.
A little expensive but the deep dish little star was delicious.
White pie so so.
Would definitely go back for the little star alone!!
author: Sheena D.

description: Little Steeze provides a hearty deep dish pizza that excites the tastebuds and melts the cheese of the soul like a classic pizza parlor should. A bit over priced for pizza, but worth keeping this in the ol' spice rack to sprinkle in between the late night sessions of NY style cheap and greasy slices.
author: Andy L.

description:
Thus far the best deep dish pizza I've had EVER -- and I've visited Chicago. Stopped by one Friday with a buddy of mine. Luckily we were quickly seated as a party of 2. There were other larger parties waiting, but they had a table for 2 readily available.

We ordered the Litte Star topped with Sausage. The sausage complimented the spinach and mushrooms quite nicely. The dough wasn't heavy. It was delicious! A small is more than enough for a party of 2. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Richard P.

description:
Haiku to Little Star:

Little Star deep dish
You fill me and make me fat
I am so happy

My delicious meal included:
+Caprese Salad ($10.50). This was so delicious it changed my view of mozzarella! (I know, I'm odd, but I don't really like cheese normally).

+ A large custom deep dish pizza with sausage, mushrooms, and artichoke hearts ($20ish). I'm a huge fan of normal pizza crust, but that cornmeal crust is SO GOOD. The thin crust pizzas here are good too, but why get thin crust when you could get deep dish?! Between the two of us, we had three pieces of the pizza left. Next time I'll go for the Small.

+ Housemade Cheesecake ($6). Probably unnecessary since I was SO FULL, but who can turn down dessert? I honestly haven't eaten enough cheesecake in my life to be able to compare. I ate a lot of it if that tells you anything...

+ Bottle of Man O' War Sauvignon Blanc. I don't normally become infatuated with wine, but this wine was seriously awesome. It was crisp with a kick to it. 

Overall, the atmosphere is cozy and cute and the food is fantastic. Perfect spot for any occasion :-)
author: Talia G.

description: The pizza was good and the service was excellent!  We ordered a deep and a thin.  The deep was scrumptious and my kids loved the thin crust pepperoni. I wish parking was easier.
author: Mukesh S.

description:
Goooood chicago deep dish pizza in SF. I think we got the spinach ricotta one which had a surprising richness for veggie pizza. 

Over the course of several days, we made our way through a size Small pizza at a decent clip.
author: Ryan S.

description:
(See pics)

Solid 4 stars of pizzas but the ambiance and my beloved Yelpers made it a super 5 stars!

Local pizza joint and we were a big group of Yelpers after CandyBar UYE. We were all hungry and pizza is one thing that is best enjoyed by a big group of friends. Conversations flowing, multiple pizzas ordered, even a couple bottles of wines were consumed.

They served both regular and deep dish styles and all were on the heavier sauce sides, which were great in a windy evening. This place gave a very friendly and dimmed light ambiance. And they quickly put tables and chairs together for our big group. A nice gesture. And everybody went home with a fully happy belly that night!
author: T L.

description: I'm gonna start off with o-m-g! Lol the deep dish is sooo good. It's crunchy and light crust is a part that makes this pie whole. Great sauce, sausage reminded me of a meatball, so good. The large chunks of tomato.. Mmm yummy, and pepperoni with a bit of crunch. All I can say is I'm def coming back here when I'm in the area. Nice staff, great cream soda too :)
author: Leticia M.

description: Great pizza.  I love deep dish.  And the Brass Monkey we got was so good.  Great toppings, crunchy crust, definitely satisfying.
author: Karen L.

description:
Review #200.  I'm dedicating this landmark review towards something that's near and dear to my cholesterolized heart, Chicago mutha fucking deep dish pizza!!  All those midwestern/Chicago transplants in the Bay Area have made San Francisco a heaven for Chicago Deep Dish pizza.

My standard bearer, for Chicago Deep Dish is Lou Malnati's in Chicago, closely followed by Zachary's in Oakland.  Why are these pizzas so good?  It's a combination of buttery crust that just breaks in your mouth ever so easily and the tomato sauce and cheese proportions.  Crazily enough, you can actually have too much cheese and too little tomato sauce, like Giordano's in Chicago.

Little Star Pizza comes close to reproducing what Lou Malnati's does, but it falls just slightly short.  The taste of the crust is great, but that texture falls short.  There's an absolutely buttery, airy flakiness in Lou Malnati's crust.  It makes you crave the crust, which is an amazing feat considering how many of us don't eat crusts on any type of pizza.  Little Star's crust is just slightly too crunchy.

As for the pizza itself, we had the Classic (sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells).  There was no complaint about the pizza at all.  The toppings were plenty, the taste was what I expected.  There was a good balance cheese and tomato sauce.  (holy shit, my mouth is really watering right now).

The wait at Little Star is probably the worst in San Francisco/Bay Area out of all the Chicago Deep Dish places in the city.  Patxi's and Zachary's seem to have better wait times.  We waited 80 minutes for a table of 3 on a Saturday night around 9pm.

Overall a pretty good effort in recreating Chicago Deep Dish.  Less wait time and more buttery crust would get an extra star for me.
author: Kyle W.

description: I love little star pizza especially the deep dish. The service can improve / the wait time. Over all great place to grub on! P.s. please add ranch to your menu thanks!
author: Duke Of Frisco X.

description: The pizza was amazing, we got the deep dish Little Star and you could taste the flavors of each ingredient and the crust stayed crunchy. We sat at the bar and the service was great. We had their Hey Kool-aid drink and it was delicious.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Came here with a few people for a late lunch on a Saturday. They weren't very busy so being sat and service was quick. We picked out the Pesto chicken for our thin crust. This was very good, but a little too much onions for me. All over the top was thinly sliced onions. I did like that the flavors from the other ingredients weren't masked too much. The chicken was not dry - I was happy about that. I actually prefer thin crust. The pizza was very crispy on the bottom and the crust and not burnt. It was great.

For our deep dish we had the vegetarian one. I didn't like this as much because there was too much tomato sauce and tomatoes in it. I did like the zucchini though. The crust was very cornmeal-y, which I didn't like as much, but it had a nice texture.

Overall our meal was good, but next time I will choose different pizzas.
author: Katherine L.

description: All the 5-star reviews are on point! Little star pizza is perfect in every way! We ordered a deep dish cheese with ricotta, roasted garlic, fresh mozzarella, pepperoni and fresh basil. It was delicious! It's too bad we were only visiting for a few days, or we would have definitely broken our rule to not visit any food place more than once on our trip!
author: Barby M.

description: I'm writing this as a Chicago deep dish expert and wow, Little Star definitely upped the ante with the other pizza options around SF. Like everyone else's reviews, the crust was great if you like a crispy Chicago deep dish crust.  Some people prefer a more bread-y crust but this one was more cornmeal-y but not too much (like Gino's East). Came in on a Wednesday night with a friend and was seated right away.  The staff and atmosphere is laid-back.  We had some wine, split a salad and a small pizza.  The serving sizes were just right, however, the only reason why I removed a star is that it's a bit pricy for a tiny pizza.  Deep dish in Chicago doesn't even cost this much.  Regardless, it's delicious and I'm excited to try the thin next time!
author: Louise Z.

description:
My 100th review had to be pizza.  I had very high expectations for Little Star Pizza what with all the great reviews and yummy looking pictures.  It was good pizza but it was not mind blowing, life altering, pizza.  It was not Pequod's Pizza in Chicago.  I'm starting to believe that no other pizza will compare.

Anyway, service was attentive, but we were placed close to the front door and we were freezing!  They started us off with water.  I ordered a diet soda and they brought it in a can, my friend ordered a beer and she said it was really good.  We also ordered the wings.  Those are definitely some of the best hot wings I've ever had.  They were not your typical wings, dripping of sauce, they were crispy and spicy and just plain deelish.

The place is extremely small and it explains why there would be a long wait.  We got there when it opened so we didn't have to wait at all.  I would go back again for their wings alone.  I'd probably get their pizza again but with lower expectations.
author: Analily V.

description: Pizza is good but no where near the best,  little bit overpriced as well.
author: Maher S.

description: We love, love, love this restaurant!!!! Don't be deceived by the exterior once you enter it is a warm and cozy place. The waiters and the food are top notch. Give it a try you will be glad you did
author: Penny P.

description:
I don't need an excuse to come here. I come here because of reasons. 
Reason #1: The pizzas are delicious!
Reason #2: The service is great.
Reason #3: The hot wings are to DIE for! (well, not like...dying dying.)

I've been to two of little Star's three locations and I like how there's is no difference in service/taste just because it's a different location. I enjoy the atmosphere, drinks and the Brass Monkey deep dish pizza. I've made the mistake of ordering a large when a small is sufficient for 2 people with a starter of their ultra delicious hot wings!! 

To make this review short & sweet to the point, come to Little Star and see what's happening to pizza today because you won't want to miss an extremely delicious pie with the freshest ingredients out there. It's literally hot and sexy goodness on a pan.
author: Carol L.

description:
3.5
Delicious pizza, but way more expensive than I expected, seemed rather small. Also could b*tch about the drink prices
author: Kevin J.

description:
Came here on a whim with some friends on a random night. This place is very popular!

We waited about an hour and a half for a table here. But I can say the wait was well worth it! We had an order of wings and it had the perfect amount of seasoning and sauce. Had an amazing spice kick to it!

We ordered the Italian combo, there was 4 us and we each had two slices which was more than enough. The wings and large pizza to share between 4 people was a good amount. 

I want to come back soon to try another pizza, I will try a deep dish next time!
author: Kim L.

description:
I lived in Chicago for 3 years, so I've had the good deep dish there. Not the Giordano crap tourists go to, but the good stuff like Lou Malnati's.

Now that I've established myself as someone that has actually had good deep dish pizza. Little star is very comparable to the best Chicago has to offer. Friends and I got 3 pizzas there. Two of them with sausage, pepperoni, and olives, and the other was the Little Star pizza which has spinach in it. That one happened to be everyone's favorite.

I've also had Patxi's. Little Star is a better.
author: Joshua W.

description:
I've came here once before and actually felt it was overhyped when I had the Classic deep dish and another deep dish I can't remembered (see, it didn't really stick in the books). It was good, I liked it! But it wasn't mind blowing for me to get all hyped about it. Anyways, having had Lou Malnati's in Chicago and craving it ever so badly, I decided to come here again and I'm really glad I did. 

The Vegetarian Deep Dish - Crust was nice and crispy (texture was very comparable to Lou's) And sauce and veggies .. you couldn't go wrong! It was delicious.Their Salads are good too - not over drenched with dressing, which is a plus on my book!

I think if you get there right at 6pm before the rush of dinner time outings, you can beat the wait! We got seating immediately and when we finished dinner around 7ish - by then when we were walking out, there were plenty of people waiting. 

I want to come back and try their thin crust because they had such appealing options but being a fatty, I opted for the deep dish the last two times. haha
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I love the deep dish pizza here.  I've never had a bad meal at little star. Staff always nice.

The salads and wings are good, but I go for the pizza.
author: Click C.

description:
Pretty darn good.  Lots of distinct spices.  Good flavor.  Had the veggie deep dish.  

Small and a bit dark.  But the service was good  wait was minimal
author: San S.

description:
Feels a tad silly writing this when there are already over 2000 reviews, but this place is delicious!

I got the little star + sausage, and the garlic bread.  Usually, I'm not into Chicago-style pizza, but for my first visit to Little Star, I had to try it, right?  Great decision.  The crust is just delightful-- I think they use extra cornmeal or something, and it totally works to prevent sogginess, and maintain crisp-on-the-outside-chewy-on-the-inside-ness, despite the weight of all the toppings.  And the toppings!!  All were perfectly cooked, and the tomato sauce on top tasted so fresh.  Garlic bread was likewise delicious.  A bit like a gourmet version of the cheesy bread you'd find at domino's, but with actual chunks of garlic.

Minus one star for a finicky credit card machine.  Inconvenient when I've only brought my card for takeout.  (Obviously I needed that pizza badly, so I went home to grab cash.)
author: Cynthia C.

description: I'm a huge thin crust pizza fan but man, that cornmeal crust on the deep dish has given my love for thin crusts a run for its money! The crust is the most important piece of the pie (no pun intended) when it comes to pizza and Little Star has got the best crust I've ever had. We got the Classic, which was topped with sausage, mushrooms, onions, and peppers, but any of the deep dish pizzas would be bomb because of that crust. We also got the White Pie thin crust pizza, topped with garlic, zucchini, and tomatoes, which was bomb dot com too despite not having any meat! I was convinced that the deep dish pizza was my favorite but then I would take a bite of the White Pie and change my mind. After killing about quarter of each pizza, it was still a tie. I'll have to come back and eat more to determine the winner.
author: Mymy N.

description:
I am a HUGE fan! I love the thin crust and I also love the deep dish too. Im not a huge fan of deep dish but the Mediterranean is amazing! The Italian Combo is also delicious. They use very good quality ingredients which makes their food taste great! They are also very consistent ,the pizza is always made the same . I am also a big fa of the mixed green salad... Great service great staff! 
So happy of the new extended business hours!!
Casual atmosphere Good for dinner and groups
author: L V.

description:
Little Star steps out from other San Francisco pizzerias to offer deep dish as well as thin crust.  This isn't Chicago Deep Dish, though; it's California Deep Dish, ala Zachary's of Berkeley.  Garlicky, cheesy and full of spinach and other good things.  The white pie is also good.

Little Star is probably second to places like 211, Ragazza and Delfina for pizza quality -- for one thing, their menu selection doesn't really vary seasonally at all -- but they're also more affordable, both in the pizzas and in the wine/beer menu.  This is the pizza place you go to when you're too tired to cook, but don't want to spend a bunch.
author: Josh B.

description:
I had high hopes for this place but their pizzas are nowhere nearly as good as Patxi's.

First impression: What a cute place. Dimly lit restaurant, kind of small, and hey, look, a candle on every table. How romantic.

Second impression: Hmm, the menu is pretty straight forward. It's broken down into 4 sections: appetizers, deep-dish pizzas, thin-crust pizzas, and desserts. Mmm, oh yeah, I definitely want a deep-dish pizza. *******(My boyfriend took me here on a date because I've been ga-ga-ing about how I've never had deep-dish pizza before so we only ordered a deep-dish pizza to share for dinner. We decided on a large classic deep-dish ($24) and alas, the waiting game started.)

Third impression: Checked my cell phone for the time constantly. Damn, I'm hungry. Where's the pizza? Should we order some wings? No complimentary bread and olive oil? Aw phooey.

Fourth impression: *After 30 minutes* Yes! The pizza is here. *Take a bite* Uh...why is it lukewarm? Why is the cheese not melty? Ew.. cold tomato sauce. At least the crust is nice and crunchy.

Fifth impression: Well, that was just A-OK.
author: Annie S.

description: Best pizza I've had in San Francisco, hands down. Both deep dish and thin crust options. High quality ingredients, perfect combinations of flavors for each pizza, and if you don't like any, you can modify each one to your liking, so there's no way to go wrong here. Final thought, having lived in Chicago, I know the secret to a good deep dish pizza is in the crust, and they have that down! Of course nothing compares to the real deal but this is the best option I've found in SF.
author: Louise J.

description:
For sure the best deep dish I've had outside of Chicago!
I love the cornmeal crust; it's crispy and delicious, and the place is definitely pretty hip.

We always get the deep dish Little Star pizza, which has spinach and mushrooms. It's cheezy, tomato-y, garlic-ey and wonderful. I love it.

Their garlic bread is also really tasty. It's pretty much melted cheese on bread; what's not to like?
author: Cami J.

description:
Didn't care for the deep dish at all.  I found it bland even though it was swimming in what appeared to be crushed tomatoes right out of the can. And, cornmeal crust?  Umm--no.  Pizza on the west coast couldn't be more different than pizza on the east coast.  I truly believe that it has become cultural and people like what they are used to--kind of like Red Vines vs. Twizzlers. Tully's coffee vs. Dunkin' Donuts coffee etc.   
To each his own!
Chow on Church/Market makes the kind of pizza that I enjoy. Ditto for Marcello's in the Castro.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night with some homies. There was six of us, and it was a one hour wait. No worries. A cool thing about this place is that once you go in and reserve a table, you can leave and they'll call you once they're ready to seat you. My friends and I went to Alamo Square Park just a few blocks up and killed some time by gazing at the killer view of SF, ha. OH! Also another awesome thing is they'll take your order while you wait for your table. If I recall correctly, their deep dish took 30-45 mins to bake, so good thing we placed our order in while we were waiting. We got our pizza around 10 minutes after being seated! 

Deep dish isn't my fave, but pizza is pizza, and pizza is good. Although, I did really like this one in particular. What everyone said about the crust is pretty much my sentiments. It was overall very tasty and I was satisfied with it. Mind you, I didn't have high expectations, so for people who are deep dish lovers I wouldn't know how you'd react, but it truly seems to be a contender given all of these positive reviews. 

Lastly, parking SUCKS. You've been warned. Enjoy!
author: Christine C.

description:
Always love a great deep dish pizza! Luckily when I went, there was no line, but the food did take a little longer than I expected! Besides that, the service was great and the pizza was delicious!  

I'd recommend this place for a couple of friends getting together or a cute/romantic date! :) dimmed room and candle lit dinners!
author: Elizz H.

description:
I was in the mood for a real pizza. Not the crappy, frozen garbage from a chain store. Real pizza. I did some Yelp research and decided to take a drive up to Little Star and see what's what. My biggest problem with Yelp research is expectations. I read countless 4 and 5 star reviews, I go into the experience expecting a miracle. That's my problem of course. I have always been a high expectations even bigger let downs kinda guy. 

I really want to love Chicago deep dish pizza. Especially when the crust is as perfect as it is at Little Star. Crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. What I don't love is a pizza covered in canned tomatoes. It really prevents me from tasting the fresh toppings. For example, when I order a pepperoni and sausage pizza, I want to taste greasy swine. When I took my first bite, all I got was canned tomatoes. I was hunting and searching for the swine and it was there, but I wasn't happy that I couldn't taste it. I guess I could ask for no tomatoes on top next time, but I have this policy. When I go to a place for the first time, I don't get picky. I order what they do best, I take it the way it's prepared and then I bitch about it. Character defect 101.

I'd definitely go back to Little Star and try it again. I'd definitely ask them if they could hold the canned tomatoes for a rainy day or for someone who loves them.
author: Hector G.

description:
I am not stranger to the lures of corporate America's exploit of the Italian pie. Pizza Hut and I are besties for sure. But sometimes, you have to venture out of those comfort zones and check out what true chefs conjure up. With three SF locations, Little Star Pizza serves up some of the best deep and thin crust pizzas. Luckily, one-third of those locations are a nice stroll down from my humble abode.

Making our own deep-dish creation, it was everything I wanted. A nice thick crust, loaded tomatoes and toppings galore. The restaurant itself was dark, trendy and full of patrons. And though we waited for about an hour, it was totes-mcgotes worth the wait.

And with bicycle delivery via Center City Delivery, Little Star may have to get in bed with one another on a more consistent basis.
author: Jon C.

description:
Good neighborhood pizza joint. I go for lunch or an early dinner to get seated right away because the place usually has a line out the door. 

Great tasting and well priced deep dish pizza. Salad portions are large and are good to share before the pizza arrives. Service was great, super friendly staff that stayed attentive the whole while my deep dish was cooking. However, cocktails are weak (mine was champagne based).

Extra points for being able to call in an order and take it to go!
author: Sandra L.

description:
I can't say that I'm an expert when it comes to deep dish za, but this is definitely the best I've ever had (and yes I have tried it in Chicago). The restaurant has a nice ambiance with a jukebox and a bar on the side for the lonely souls who want to eat alone.

We got the special of the day, which was basically the "Little Star" with meatballs and it rocked. We split one large deep dish and an order of the garlic bread to split amongst 5 people.  We were completely satisfied and full.

Side note: the garlic bread recipe changed a few weeks ago and now it's sort of like a mini garlic cheese pizza. Still tasty.

My selling point for this place: i wanted it so badly once when I as on crutches that I made my way up 5 blocks of Divisadero to go. Worth it.
author: John N.

description: THE BEST PIZZA I have had in America!!!!! not only great pizza BUT great service!! ALYSSA was awesome. Great customer service and so friendly and willing to help! Highly recommend!!
author: Megan G.

description:
Sometimes, when I'm sitting around missing San Francisco and making myself sadpants, I think about the food in San Francisco and...make myself even sadder.  

In The Great Little Star v. Zachary's Debate, I was always a little partial to Zachary's pizza, but Little Star (both this location and the one in the Mission) wins out on ambiance.  Where Zachary's is more of a family-friendly environment, Little Star is more of a warm, hip, even romantic vibe.  The NOPA location is pretty small, but a neat, cozy and hip little space - *sigh* no one does cozy AND hip quite like SF.  Hiphiphip.  And yes, it seriously does have a romantic thing going on - my husband took me here for dinner right before he proposed to me (it should be noted, actual proposal took place in Alamo Square over a shared flagon of whiskey, so, you know, when I say it's romantic, you can trust that I know what I'm talking about because CLASS.)

The wait is almost always really long, but the pizza is outstanding.  Delicious, chunky tomato sauce on top of cheesecheeseandmorecheese, and a delicious crust that I...can't even describe without feeling a little bit like I want to cry, but just know that there is cornmeal and it's crispy on the outside and gooey on the inside and it does this kind of pullapart thing....

Anyway.  Eat at Little Star.  I'm totally depressed now.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Ordered the salad, buffalo wings and 3 pizzas; one thin crust pepperoni, one was deep dish arugula and I forgot the third, but it was deep dish also.
Hands down the best deep dish pizza I've ever tasted...probably the best pepperoni pizza I've tasted too, lol. The wings were a bit too spicy though, and the salad was meh. 

This was the 4th time I came here and it never disappoints. We had a party of 5 in our group and the hostess said it would be about an hour and a half wait. Of course, we waited. One of my friends in the group actually offered the hostess $100 to give us the next table, and to my surprise, she didn't budge; she said she's not going to risk her job doing that kind of stuff and this, kinda sucked, but I respected a lot. 

Every time someone mentions SF, I always recommend LSP :)
author: Isabelle C.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE... and I never thought I'd say that, because I usually don't like Chicago-style pizza.

Both the Little Star and Brass Monkey are to die for. So much garlic... and if you know me, you know that I love to eat anything that makes my breath smell bad ;) ingredients are fresh and flavorful, but not too overpowering. The crust is DELICIOUS... and I am usually not much of a crust girl.

The thin crust classic pizza was just okay. This place obviously doesn't specialize in thin crust pizzas, but it's nice to know that they cater to people that don't like Chicago-style.

Lesson/tip for those of you that don't like Chicago-style: give it a chance at Little Star! You never know ;)
author: Angela K.

description:
This place is better than Patxi's.  Just as yummy as the deep dish I had in Chicago!
Be prepared to wait a bit - I came here on a Sunday night and it was still busy.  Luckily they recommend you pre-ordering so that our pizza was ready right when we got our table.
And I would recommend getting a bigger pizza than you can finish cuz this sh*t is even BETTER the next day!
author: Michele S.

description: I love this place, delicious pizzas, salads, garlic bread and a cool environment. Make reservations as it can be busy.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Excellent pizza! You have to try the deep dish pizza, the crust is so good, you won't regret it. 

The place is nice, good ambiance with ok music. They have a little bar where the serve beers and wine. Perfect place to hang out with friends for dinner!
author: Patrick D.

description:
Go to Zachary's Pizza in Berkeley. Just do it. 

Where do I start?

I came in with high expectations. Where did they fall short: 

1) Took 30 minutes to get my pizza. Maybe I'm not up on the latest pizza baking technologies but that struck me as excessive.
2) Price - a large will run you $20-$23 (and you'll wait 30 minutes). 
3) Crust - I wasn't a fan. Personal preference I'm sure because everyone else at the table swore it was the greatest thing since electricity. 

Sorry, Little Star, I wanted to like you. 

On the plus side - our server was very attentive and helpful. 

The pizza was closer to 4 stars but with the price and wait factored in I dropped the whole place down to a 3 star rating. 

Go to Zachary's Pizza - you can do it SF'ers.  You can leave the bubble that is SF.
author: Carlos A.

description:
My gold standard if I am craving deep dish pizza. My stomach is seriously growling right now just thinking of this place.

All of their pizzas have a unique corn meal crust which is always perfectly cooked and amazingly tasty. I have yet to sample another pizza place with a crust that rivals the one at Little Star.

The Little Star pizza is my go-to. It has spinach and ricotta, as well as mushrooms, garlic, and onions. Or for those of you craving a little bit of meat, order the Brass Monkey. It's off menu, and is basically the Little Star with sausage added to it.  I've had the vegetarian pizza here as well, and while not quite as good as the Little Star, it's definitely worth a try.

I almost always get the garlic bread appetizer. The bread is served nice and warm and accompanied with butter an d an entire bulb of roasted garlic! If you're a garlic lover like I am, or just trying to ward off vampires, you will not be disappointed with this dish.

The only reason why I need to dock off one star is because I have issues with the consistency of this place. I don't know if it depends on who is back in the kitchen or how busy the place is that particular night, but sometimes I leave Little Star feeling happy as a clam, and sometimes the pizza disappoints since it wasn't as good as previous experiences. It's still always satisfying, but some times are better than others.
author: Sally T.

description:
Amazing. The pizza is fantastic and the beer is delicious. Honestly, you will not have a hard time finding a good meal. 

I definitely recommend going for a deep dish pizza. The smaller size is certainly enough to split between two people. Note that it takes 30 minutes to prepare, but it is totally worth it! We usually get three different toppings and it is magical!
author: Sophia A.

description: I would have to agree with most of the review here. this place has one of the best pizzas I ever had. We had the classic deep dish pizza with sausage cheese, and tomatoes. It was perfectly cooked down to the crust. Deep dish pizza is a must. On the other hand. The chicken wing appetizer is plain so it is ok to skip it. This place gets crowded for dinner so make sure you have your party before you come or else you will have to wait.
author: Mav M.

description:
My husband and I were in San Fran and I am glad we tried this place.  We were going to dine in but the wait was a little longer than we wanted so we had a couple beers and ordered a deep dish to go.

The pizza was delicious and the deep dish crust had a cornbread taste and texture.  I would highly recommend  this place to anyone in the area.
author: Katelin M.

description:
Being from the East Coast and KNOWING what fantastic pizza should taste like,  I was happy with this pizza. I got the thin crust, chicken pesto. It was done really well, crunchy, tasty crust. I was into it.  
I'm only leaving off the star cause it's fairly pricey for pizza, even for the city.. it was over $25. Granted, the pizza was filling enough that there was left overs, but still. 

overall, pretty damn tasty.. as good as it's gonna get for California pizza
author: Dayna E.

description:
Eh. Meh. Gawd!!! My boss ordered Little Star Pizza for a work get together and it was so delicious! I'm not a deep dish pizza fan, but this was pretty dang amaza-mundo!

Little Star Pizza has this thick crust which isn't oily and a nice thick red sauce that's got some gusto to it. I really enjoyed the vegetarian pizza as the heavy thick crust was somehow balanced out by the lightness of the delicious green veggies and tomatoes. It's surprising to me that there isn't a ton of cheese on these pizzas but that's sort of what makes it edible. Too much cheese and there's no way I'd be able to finish a slice.

Now Little Star, when are you coming to Hawaii? We are in desperate need of your services...
author: Emi H.

description: Been meaning to try this place for the longest time and finally had the chance to. Came on a Friday night around 7, luckily we found parking right away. Sat and waited about 30-45 minutes for a party of 4. Seated and ordered the spicy chicken wings, a deep dish large brass monkey pizza, and the thin crust large italian combo small pizza. Was debating on getting 2 larges but the waiter was nice enough to say I think that would be too much food (which is nice of him, cause he really didn't have to). The chicken wings were alright, kind of forgettable... but I guess they aren't known for their chicken wings. I've never had a deep dish pizza so this was my first and it did not disappoint. Sure, it was hard to eat (I just gave up and ate with my fork) but it was pretty good. I'm not a huge pizza fan, so I can't go into too much detail, but it was definitely pretty good and worth the wait... I can see why some people go crazy over this place. The Italian combo pizza was good too... just because it had a variety of toppings that complimented each other. Deep dish or thin crust... I think I'm more of a thin crust kind of guy... just because I felt like I was eating a quiche while I was eating the deep dish pizza. May come back to try the little star pizza (but it's basically the same as brass monkey except there is sauage in it) and other pizzas. Worth a try if you're not starving and willing to wait a bit for some pizza!
author: Johnson S.

description: Really amazing pizza! First time having deep dish so I can't compare, but it was phenomenal! A small is a decent size for one person -- had 2 slices left over -- but was a bit pricey ($23). The photos made it look incredibly saucey, but that was because the sauce was on top of the cheese. Take out took 30min, but worth the wait! Would definitely go back!
author: Christy M.

description: Really cool place. I love deep dish pizza.  .,..and what 2000 other people said.  If you like deep dish pizza you can't go wrong here.  I went on a Thursday night and I didn't have to wait that long for a table even though the place was packed. Definitely will head back when I'm in SFO.
author: John S.

description:
Interesting flavors and fun little setting. My friend told me this is their original location. Love all the spots along Divisadero, too- perfect place to begin a night, which is exactly what we did prior to watching the election results at a nearby cafe.

We split a small pear, gorgonzola, and bacon pizza- so good! For a guy who loves to eat and a girl who eats like a bird throughout the day this was a perfect size.

I've been to Little Star in the MIssion before, but this was my first time at this spot. Loved it!
author: Kristin F.

description: Just in a few words ...you gotta try this spot !. You won't be disappointed . Such great customer service and the beer selection accommodates all pizza slices on the menu
author: Yolanda P.

description:
I don't live too far from here, but have only recently visited. How have I not come here sooner?! Was running on a tight schedule, and was about to not come, yet again, but I made it work! We ordered our pizza to go on the phone while on the bus. They said it was going to be a 30min wait (that's how long it takes for the pizza to cook). Fresh everytime..can't ask for more than that! 

We ordered the small classic deep dish. It tasted so good. I'm usually not a fan of the crust when eating pizza, but their crust was so delicious. All the butter in it made it taste super good. The filling was good too. Good amount of filling and the ratio to filling to crust was perfect. I also ordered a slice of cheesecake. The cheesecake was really light and fluffy and not too sweet. One disappointment was that there was no crust! That's my favorite part of cheesecake. But nonetheless it was excellent and I devoured it. 

Next time I want to try their spinach and ricotta deep dish along with a thin crust. Can't wait to go back. (Side note..we went on a Saturday night at around 8pm and the wait was still close to an hour. The restaurant itself is pretty small. Be prepared to wait to sit down and eat here.)
author: Chris K.

description:
I'm so lucky to live close by to this laid back hip place! Otherwise I'll be driving in circles for hours looking for a spot (perk for living in the Western Addition). Hands down the best pizza place in the city. I always order their Deep Dish Pizzas and always yearn for more when I finish the entire pie! Their cornmeal crusts is flaky, fresh and best of all not heavy! Another great selection are their thin crusts pizzas, hearty salads, and their good old fashion spicy chicken wings. If you live in the neighborhood and haven't tired this place, try it out you don't know what you are missing. However if you live not in the neighborhood I
I suggest taking Muni
author: Krishan S.

description:
YUM YUM YUM!

I was vegetarian for the day, so I only had the chance to try the Vegetarian pizza. We ordered a large, half-half--Vegetarian and Classic.

One of the best deep dishes I have ever had..mainly because of the cornmeal crust!!! The cornmeal crust was absolutely amazing!!! Plus, it deserves another star b/c most deep dish pizzas are "watery," but Little Star got it right! The pricing is fair as well. 

Oh, and their selection of beer is delish!!! 

The negatives are:
1) the wait is long..be prepare to wait for 1-2 hours to be seated, depending what time you arrive. 
2) Parking is a pain..we literally drove around 20 minutes looking for parking...

YUMMM, i would come back more often if the wait and parking were not such a hassle.
author: Jen H.

description:
Instead of calling and picking up I finally came here and sat down with 2 friends. The pound of buffalo wings was tasty, about 4 wings each. Also ordered garlic bread. It's baked or heated loaf of bread with butter and garlic on the side. So, spread garlic, then butter, presto, garlic bread.

We ordered a large Classic deep dish. I believe it was sausage, pepperoni, onion, bell pepper? Can't remember, but it was great.

Also, cute hipster chick works there, holla fellow pan handle resident
author: Marty J.

description:
I'm filled with grief and pizza sauce when I come to Little Star since I'm a life long Chicago girl. I've been to Little Star far more times than I'd like to admit and in fact, have been here twice in the past week! I just couldn't overturn the decisions of the other 3 people I was with at the time. But it's a pretty standard and awesome place so of course, I kind of had to oblige. 

First of all, get some reservations in and add about 30 minutes to said reservations to calculate actual seating time. No joke. But the place is so darn tiny, I can't blame them really and you could always order appetizers and beers at the bar so what's the big deal really? Sure there's a ugly horde of people squished in like sardines at the waiting area, the scenery outside is nothing awesome to look at and there's less than 10 actual bar stools but it's all part of the experience.

If I may, I'd like to recommend the caprese salad for all of you mozzarella cheese lovers. Imagine getting the best of the best in regards to salads without the nonsense of lettuce. Gorgeous beefsteak tomatoes, olives, buffalo mozzarella, olive oil and vinagrette with a sprinkling of cracked pepper. How much more perfect can you get with that? I could just about drink/eat that concoction every day. I try to perfect it at home but I'm just not getting something right. It's the basil, it's the size of the mozzarella balls, it's my lack of crack that's standard in all LIttle Star dishes-I just don't know.

I debate over getting appetizers and pizza because the small pizza is just too big for two people. It reminds me of home in a way with the cornmeal crust and the tomato sauce that's not too thin and acidic. My friend and I had the classic and each bite was just magical. It seriously takes me back home each time I bite into it. I can almost see the little finger pinches of the crust which makes me appreciate it that much more. 

Save some room in your tummy and don't go overboard with the pizza 'cause their cheesecake is pretty awesome and there's a gorgeous raspberry to go with it too. If only I was a wealthy independent woman with the metabolism of a hummingbird, I'd be front and center here once a week at least.
author: Jessica K.

description:
The Little Star Pizza with spinach, ricotta, feta, onions, mushrooms and garlic is sooo good. If you're a meat eater, it's even better if you add sausage. 

The wait can be long, but there are plenty of places to go grab a drink in the area...Bar 821, mini bar.
author: Teryll H.

description: Came here 12:30 p.m. on a Sunday and it was pretty empty. Shared the small classic deep dish pizza with my friend. It was excellent. The crust was light. The toppings were plentiful and delicious. The sauce was very friendly. It was a lot of food for the two of us. Also had a beer. Service was just ok.
author: Al D.

description:
Very hood deep dish pizza right in the 
WAD. We went with our 3 kids and it was an ok experience, though some of the clientele seemed to resent this. Salad was good, garlic bread was average. Beer on tap pretty good selection. Would go back definitely.
author: Devon M.

description:
Let me just say, I'm not a deep dish gal, but I do love Little Star. Let me count the ways:

The crust The cornmeal crust is crispy, buttery, and even nostalgic; it transports me back to a flavor I remember on pizzas I liked as a kid. As everyone else has stated, it is powerful enough to change the perspective of a hater like me on deep dish pies. The thin crust pies are also good, though the two I've tried were not as memorable. Overall, the service is friendly, and I have never had any complaints. 

Tip: you can convert any thin crust pie into a deep dish, though just remember, the pie will have tomato sauce on top as a deep dish. In other words, if you convert a white pie to a deep dish, it's going to have red sauce on it.

Constructive criticism: I wish they had a more variety in their appetizers. The selection is very bread and cheese heavy. I would love another vegetable option to stave off the guilt from eating so much bread and cheese for dinner.

All in all, Little Star is a habit I can't shake- I live nearby and find myself here at least once every other week.
author: Alicia L.

description: Great pizza!  We ordered thin crust, white sauce and chicken.  My son finished 90% of the pie by himself.  I normally don't care for pizza but I would come back again and again.  4 stars for the great food and service.  The resturant was small which made for a poor dining experince.
author: Chat T.

description:
Went here on Friday with a group of friends. Its a pretty small place so the wait times can get long and you can't call ahead and put your name down. The food here was really good, especially the garlic bread. In fact, I could have just eaten that and been satisfied.  They have deep dish but they quoted is a 45 minute wait on then so we stuck to the thin crust.

The garlic bread was fantastic. It was basically a mini pizza but with cheese and minced garlic. Needless to say, there was none left over.

The Italian combo was a great pizza and had a good balance between meat and veggies. Usually when I get these types of pizzas the salami and bell peppers tend to overpower everything else for some odd reason but not on this one.

The pesto pizza was great as well. The chicken was well cooked and the pesto was flavorful. I would definitely get this again!
author: Rick W.

description: This pizza is incredible. We went on a Wednesday at around 7:30 and there was no wait (though it was pretty busy). The deep dish takes a while, but it's worth waiting for. Our group tried the Little Star, the Pesto Chicken, and the Meateor all as deep dish pizzas, and oh my god were they delicious. Surprisingly, my favorite was the Little Star, despite the fact that it's meatless! We also tried the spicy chicken wings, which were solid though they were pretty mild. I wish we'd tried one of the pizzas as a thin crust pizza-- the thin crusts on the other tables looked really good, but I was incredibly satisfied with our deep dish extravaganza. I guess I'll have to come back to try more! :)
author: Erin S.

description:
My favorite pizza spot in SF. 

If its your first time here, you must get the Little Star deep dish. The sauce and the corn crust was unbelievable. Once you've had that, also try the Mediterranean chicken deep dish. A large deep dish is enough to feed four hungry people. What I usually do if I want to have some variety: ask to have half the pizza with one style and the other half with another.

I recommend complementing the pizza with an order of spicy chicken wings.

If its nice out, get your pizza to go, get a six-pack, and eat at Alamo square!
author: Alfred L.

description:
Yes... I may be just one of the 1000+ reviews here for Little Star Pizza, but I do hope that my review will have some sort of weigh to it as I purposely seeked out "The Best" pizza joint in SF and I live down here in the nice & sunny southern California area...

It was between either Little Star Pizza or Tony's Pizza Napoletana... Little Star won out this time due to the fact I didn't feel like going into the city on the way to Santa Rosa... but don't worry, next trip up to SF Tony's here I come...

So this is a tiny little pizza joint right offer Divisadero... it can be easily missed but just seek out the little star logo and you will be fine... the building is painting in dark colors but I'm sure you will see people there for the food....

Let's start from the outside and work our way in...

Parking is metered like everywhere else in SF... very limited around the area so good luck... Nina R. and I visited this place at about 2:15pm so we scored a perfect parking spot right in front... however, $0.25 for 8 minutes???  Is "The City" that strapped for cash???  Sigh... I had no change so I had to ask the LS hostess for some change for parking...

Upon entering, the hostess was very nice and cordial and immediately get me the change I needed... so back out I went to pop some coins in for parking...(remember... bring lots of coins!!!  It's gonna run you about $3 bucks or so for sure!)

Place is dimly lit... about 10 tables or so... clean, quiet (during the time I was there), and pretty intimate.....

Bathroom was clean and artistic just like most of the places in SF....

So we went ahead and ordered the Spinach Feta/Mediterranean half and half pie (deep dish)...  

Be prepared.... it took 30 minutes for the pie to come out... yes it's hand freshly made to order, but man.... 30 minutes..... there is at least $1 out of parking already.....

When the pizza came out it was piping hot and cute!  It looked small but the small portion was filling enough for 2 people with left overs... the Spinach Feta was delicious and creamy while Mediterranean tasted healthy than it should be which is not a bad thing....

I do believe it was corn meal crusted... not my favorite cup of tea as I love them buttered up crust baked to crisp that tasted like a Danish butter cookie.... so Little Star take note.... get more butter on your crust please!!!

The bill came out to about $28 + $3 for one pizza... little steep but can't beat the experience...

So here's the Pros and Cons part...

Pros:  Tasty pizza, great service, nice atmosphere, clean bathroom...
Cons:  No parking, expensive price point

I would of given it a 3 star due to parking and the cost, but I did enjoy the experience and the food so bumping it up one star is very fair in my opinion....

Now that I've tackled one of the top pizzeria in SF... I got to compare it to the other one on the other side of the town... Give them a try.... I do believe you will enjoy their deep dishy goodness!
author: Henry C.

description: This is a tiny loud place - The tables are so close together, it's almost like community dining. However, their Chicago-style pizzas are amazing! It's almost as good as Zachs in Oakland. Will definitely visit again.
author: Krish C.

description:
If I ever moved away from the San Francisco Bay Area, Little Star is one of those places I would miss immensely. It would definitely be on my list of must-go to places on my visit here.

Everything about their deep dish pizza is awesome. But the most awesome thing is their crust. When I eat the crust, I must close my eyes. It's like buttah, but crunchy. I think it's because it's a cornmeal crust.

A couple of weeks ago, the boy and I went to Patxi's. Which I've been to many times before as well, but it's been a while. I told the boy - it's not going to be as good as Little Star. He figured it's not that bad. There are not many choices in downtown Palo Alto, so we figured Patxi's was a safe choice.

We were wrong. We took one bite and gave each other knowing-looks... We ate it, we were hungry, but everything was just not right about it. It just isn't Little Star!

I am psyched that their cousin restaurant, Blue Line Pizza is opening up in downtown Mountain View.. finally some good food coming down the Bay!
author: Bonnie H.

description:
Last night I met up with some out-of-town foodie friends for pizza, and was having a difficult time figuring out what was missing from this deep dish pizza.

"Buttery." That's what's missing.

I've been to Little Star on one other occasion, and a couple times to their sister restaurant, Blue Line Pizza, in Campbell. You're greeted with similar fare, your choice of thin crust and deep dish pies with a range of fresh toppings. Sausage. Bell Peppers. Mushrooms. Nothing far out of the ordinary here.

The highlights here are the chunky tomatoes, a good, but not decedent, chewy gooey bite of cheese; and a crunchy cornmeal crust, which you can think of like biting into a crunchy piece of cornbread lightly brushed with oil. It feels almost light.

But there's still something missing that guilty pleasure you can sink your teeth into and wipe from the corners of your mouth; dense with cheese, layered with smoking toppings; held together by that all-important flakey, almost pastry-like crust that you crave for in a good deep dish pie; the one that you anticipate, brace, and save yourself for, like a virgin on their wedding night submitting themselves to a visceral celebration of sense and sin.

In a word: Buttery. That's what's missing.

And it keeps little star from shining brightly in the constellation of great deep dish pies.
author: Tony L.

description:
I'm going to write this review in comparison to the deep dish I've had in Chicago, my favorite being Lou Manalti's. 

I was surprised to find how authentic Little Star's deep dish was compared to it's Chicagoan brethren. The crust was nicely crisp and the sauce was robust and zesty. I would however, preferred my sauce to be more saucy like a stew, rather than thick like a sauce. The meat is what really set this pizza off. The pepperoni and sausage we had were transcendent and I wish i had some to take home!

Our waitress was amazing. Being on a time crunch to see the surrounding areas before the sun set, we asked if we could leave our table (we had already received our drinks) and come back in time for the pizza to be ready. We offered to leave our credit cards for her assurance but she insisted we didn't need to. Now talk about trusting your customer! 

Will come back the next time I'm near Alamo Square!
author: Michael S.

description: Try the classic deep dish. Mmmmm! Never a long wait for a table and the service is great.
author: Brianne A.

description: Pizza heaven.  We tried a small deep dish with half Little Star and half Mediterranean Chicken.  I can't decide which side I liked better because they were both phenomenal.  It costs $1 extra for two kinds on one pizza and be prepared to wait at least 20 minutes for your pie to cook.  The space is small but we did not have to wait too long for a Saturday night.
author: Stacey J.

description:
As a long time lover of Little Star, my favorite is the deep dish Little Star pizza with basil. This cozy restaurant is a must visit for any Chicago transplant as it combines the best of both SF beer and produce and rustic Chicago-style cuisine.
Tip: If there is a wait for your table, put the deep dish order in ahead of time.
author: Carrie H.

description:
Little Star Pizza gets 5 BIG STARS!!!
