I've always been a Thin Crust/New York Style, (however you want to call it) girl. I've never had Deep Dish/Chicago Style until Little Star. I'm sitting at the table, with the menu staring at me, still hesitant to go for Deep dish. My boyfriend gave me a little push so I gave in. :P (Hmmph!)
When our "Build your own Pizza!" arrived at our table, I was still very intimidated by the thick and dense looking thing. Needless to say, I'm glad we went for it!

The cornmeal crust was amazing! :) I've also never had that prior to Little Star! (I know I know...what is this girl doing with her life?! She's missing out!) I love that it wasn't so heavy compared to regular pizza dough, it didn't become soggy even after it was out on the table for a while, and it was crispy!

The first bite of that Mushroom, Spinach, Sausage, and Sun-dried Tomato Cheesy goodness, was a moment of pure indulgence. Just the right amount of tomato sauce, and the kickin' cornmeal crust! MmmMmm! P: 

I can't believe I neglected the other side of delectable pizza my entire life! Thanks for opening up a whole new Pizza World for me!!! ;D
author: Monita H.

description:
There's something profoundly special about a pizza you have to eat with a knife and fork. I've had a few of these Chicago deep-dish types now, from different places, several times each, and Little Star is just the best. 

I almost always get the small Little Star with artichoke hearts as an add-on. Lemme tell you bout this pizza. Usually I think tomato sauce completely take-it-or-leave-it, but this one really tastes like crushed tomatoes and is never too acidic. The spinach is fresh, the mushrooms savory, the top layer of ricotta is pleasantly creamy while the bottom layer of mozzarella is satisfyingly stretchy. I love that the artichoke hearts they use aren't over-marinated and tangy, and preserve the real flavor of the vegetable. 

And the crust. I always save it for last, savoring it like a dessert. This rich cornmeal crust is perfectly crispy like a cornbread muffin top. Eating it is like visiting the southern grandmother I don't have, going back to some roots that aren't mine, but still being enveloped in the warm embrace of home cooking.

If it seems like I don't want my crusts, you are wrong. I want those to be the last flavor I enjoy so I can feel that sheer happiness as long as possible.
author: Mea H.

description:
All I gotsta say is the Mediterrean deep dish is off the hook.  You can't have more than 2 pieces before feeling full, but its so worth it.  I love the corn crust and the fresh ingredients.  Its definitely a go to on a date night.

The staff is nice and the place is quaint.  I would say its my favorite deep dish pizza in San Francisco.  My second favorite would be the Little Start on Solano Ave :)

I highly recommend this place.
author: Mariam A.

description:
Tonight was our lucky night.  My friends Crys, NY and I happened to stumble into Little Star Pizza just before 6pm and got to take part of their Tue/Wed night special (5-6pm).  We ordered an appetizer (the DELICIOUS garlic sour dough bread) and got our pizza 1/2 price.  Our total bill for 3 beers (also happy hour), 2 sodas, garlic bread and a large pizza was less than $30 and less than the large pizza would've been.  We felt like it was our birthdays.  

Ok, that being said, the pizza was good.  Very good.  It's Chicago-style, like Zachary's or Paxti's... which is a style I really appreciate.  The crust might be not quite as thick as the other 2 but it was still unique and good.  Because it's not as thick, it didn't take as long to cook.  (At the other places, you have to order 40min in advance.)  After a bit of appetizer, I could only eat one piece of pizza.  That's ok though... I can't wait to eat the leftovers!

Another note, the restaurant space is really cool.  It has interesting art on the walls and though dim when you first go in, is a cozy, comfy joint.  Our waitress was cool and efficient too.

See ya there!
author: Susan D.

description:
My friends raved so much about this place over the past few years, I decided it was time for me to buckle down and settle the deep dish winner in the Bay Area (for me, that is). Having tried Zachary's on multiple occasions, I hadn't heard much about Little Star except through word-of-mouth.

Let me tell you, this joint is WORTH THE WAIT. Come early so you're not frickin' about to die of hunger by the time you get a table and are actually served your pizza -- it takes time.

I tried the Little Star and the Vegetarian varieties. Both were really great pizzas, but my vote goes to the Vegetarian! Loaded with fresh veggies, all the flavors really stood out and fit well with the sauce and the crust.

Speaking of the crust, I think this was the differentiator between Zachary's and Little Star. While the former had a flakier pastry crust, Little Star's pizza was made of a grainy cornmeal crust, which obviously contains more flavor. Also, corn is an ingredient rarely found in pizza crust, making it that much more unique. Two thumbs up!! 

Definitely THE PLACE for deep dish pizza lover.

Note: I was so tempted to give them a 5-star review, but have to reserve the last star until I try Paxti's.
author: Mansi A.

description:
I have no idea what juju they perform on their food, but this place has the best thin crust pizza I have ever had. Ever. Hands down.

I got their White Pie pizza (garlic olive oil, mozzarella, zucchini, tomatos)  and it changed my mind on how good a no-meat pizza could be.. one with zucchini no less, which I don't usually like! 

I got my pie to go, but the ambience is awesome too; cozy but classy.
author: Safeer J.

description: You really can't go wrong here.  My FAVORITE/MUST TRY is the LITTLE STAR PIZZA! Awesome crust, crispy and not too thick.  All the flavors, spinach, tomato sauce, and ricotta, go together very well!
author: Christine N.

description: Very tasty pizza.  I really enjoyed the deep dish.  The chicken wings are good too!  A bit pricey,  but that's most of SF :-)
author: Jack T.

description: We went here with a group of six, and they accommodated us in a short period of time. Best of all, the pizza is excellent. When someone in the group suggested eating pizza, there was a lot of resistance. They were probably all imagining Domino's or Pizza Hut. But at the end of the meal, all the naysayers were basically admitting what a great idea it was to go. We ordered a deep dish pizza that had spinach, ricotta, and a tasty tomato sauce topping the pizza. We also ordered one with regular crust that was topped with basics (mushroom, pepperoni, etc.) Both were delicious. I will admit that I ate a piece of three-day old pizza last night from this place, and it still tasted good. Little Star Pizza gets five stars from me!
author: Jamie M.

description:
This is the best deep dish in the bay area.  And I think the original location has a slight edge over the Mission location.

People rave about Zachary's.  Well, it's good, but only because they haven't been to Little Star yet.  It's not straight up "Chicago" style - Little Star uses a cornmeal crust.  But that just makes it even better.

I'm not sure how they manage to get you the deep dish so fast.  Maybe because I always get the special, although I think the other ones come out just as fast.  Oh, just because they have the best deep dish doesn't mean you should skip the thin crust - that's amazing as well.
author: masa s.

description:
I love getting a slice in the city.  This place is exactly what you want if you are in the mood for a quick slice of delicious pie, I would recommend it.  I tried the thin crust which was crispy and still chewy and soft in the inside.  The slices are also made to order - nice touch.    There is not much seating, but walking around munching pizza in San Francisco is always a good time.

Spoiler alert - there is no linguica.  For all the Portuguese out there, that is a cardinal sin.
author: Logan S.

description:
A little hipster but if you just ignore them, you'll be fine. If it's you're first time here, you have to order the following:

Appetizer: garlic bread
Pizza #1: deep dish classic (vegetarian)
Pizza #2: white pie
Drinks: red wine
author: Ernie C.

description:
Awesome pizza joint. Typically there are long waits, but host/hostess is willing to take phone numbers and just gives you a call when your table is ready. We put our names in at around 8:00 on a Saturday evening and were told that it would be about 40 minutes- 1 hour. Ended up getting a call around 20 minutes later. Even though it took us a while to get back, they held the table for us until we got there.

Amazing service and amazing food. We got a large deep dish classic pizza and split it 4 ways. There are 8 pieces, which was more than enough for us!
author: Chris D.

description: Little Star is a staple for me and the group of friends. It's not quite authentic Chicago but its fantastic. Always just delicious and satisfying. Definitely definitely worth a go.
author: Jim S.

description:
Ok, I have to eat my words - if my words are like the deep dish pizza served here!

Now that I moved into the neighbourhood, Little Star had become my go-to place for take out when there are friends over. I'm just out of the delivery zone (... why), but that's not going to stop me from getting my pie - Classic or the all veggie Little Star! Friend mentioned their root beer, I've got to give that a try next.
author: Lois W.

description: Made my own Deep dish pizza. Mushrooms, fresh mozzarella, pepperoni, green bell peppers. I liked the pizza but not the crust. Flavorful taste but the crust wasn't great, too buttery. Not too sure if I will come again.
author: Foodie S.

description:
Three and a half stars. We always round up. 

We ordered the 12" Little Star pizza with sausage and no onions and the garlic breads sticks to go. They said we could pick up our order in 45 minutes which was reasonable on a busy Friday night.

Garlic Bread Sticks - These could have been great, but the lack of cheese and a dipping aside made them just average. The hade a decent amount of garlic. For the price ($5.75), would probably order them again.

Little Star Pizza - Nice flavors. The crust was delicious. The cheese combination (ricotta and feta) was perfect, we just wish there was more of the cheese. Also, there was a bit too much sauce for our taste.

Would probably pay the extra to go to Patxi's Pizza in the future, but this is a nice option.
author: Cole-Michelle M.

description:
We've been at Little Star a few times and haven't been disappointed. Of course, their deep dish pizzas are the star here. The crust is always a great combination of the right crispiness (never soggy) and nutty butterness. You can't go wrong with any but our favorite are the Classic and the Mediterranean Chicken. But the real surprise are the Spicy Chicken wings. These are done just right with the balanced combination of spicy/sweet and tender and juicy on the inside. If you love wings, you can't miss these wings. 

Service is friendly, efficient but not fussy. Parking is sometimes tough in the evenings but not impossible.
author: J N.

description:
God, I love this place.  Deep dish is the best and this place does it the best.

And as a bonus, they have Sculpin (a fantastic IPA) on tap for only $5.50!  I can't seem to find a 22 at a store for less than $7 or $8.
author: kevin s.

description:
I've been here on three different occasions now (friends, date, and pick-up), and it has been great each and every time.

Note 1:  There are two locations in SF-- in the Mission and in WestAdd (on Divisadero).  Divisadero location is a bit smaller but you'll have a better chance of getting seats quickly here.
Note 2:  No reservations by phone.  It's a show-and-wait, so plan on signing your name, get a quick tour of the block (or go get 1 drink, no more than that) and you'll be fine.  The list moves up much faster than you'd think.

I'd strongly recommend the Little Star-- whether or not you're vegetarian.  Another dish I really like is the Classic.  I always get the Deep Dish, so can't say much about the thin crust pizzas, but the Deep Dish are just superb-- and this is combining my experience of searching for some of the best deep dish pizzas in Chicago and NYC!!

You should consider getting 1 Large pizza for every 2.5 adults.
author: Eugene L.

description: I was in SF on business and decided to try another highly rated Yelp restaurant. Once again it did not disappoint. The pizza was good and the atmosphere was lively.  The staff was very friendly and checked in frequently even though they were packed.
author: Manny R.

description: This is the first time that we have eaten that little star pizza.  I am from Chicago deep pizza capital.  The white pizza here was outstanding I Highly recommend it
author: Todd S.

description:
Second time at this place and I must say it is far tastier than Dominos, Pizza Hut, and Little Cesars lol. Love that it is close to USF and is somewhat affordable for a little classy restaurant that college students can still enjoy from time to time to make us feel fancy and all.

First time I came with 4-5 other friends and we had three different pizzas- I only remember having one deep dish and the Pesto Chicken.

I had the Pesto Chicken Thin Crust again today! Food came pretty fast, which was a surprise because the place was PACKED! We sat at the bar so we were seated instantly, yay! Nice servers and nice bartender.

Its 25$ for a 16" Pesto Chicken Thin Crust. It's good for 4 people, but the three of us devoured two each, while my guy friend easily gobbled up the 3rd leaving me and my sister with one to take home.

So it was about 10$/person including tip.

I'd say pretty fair for the kind of establishment and quality of the food.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I don't know why this place wasn't filled with people trying to get their hands on some of this pizza. 

There was actually no wait and just 2 other people dining when I came in on Saturday. 

I ordered the Italian Combo from the thin crust side of the menu. It was fantastic! The crust was very thin (duh), sauce was perfectly even, it had pepperoni, salami, onions, green bells, black olives, and pepperoncinis. 

Yum, yum!
author: Cindy B.

description: Fantastic deep dish pizza (especially the crust). Can be crowded, and waits can be lengthy, so plan ahead.
author: Max R.

description: Food was most definitely a 5. We had both deep dish and thin crust. Both were superb. Atmosphere is not the greatest. Weather outside was great but inside was hot and stuffy. Service was just okay. We asked for the bill to be split and he acted like it was way too inconvenient. Soft drinks come out in a can. So, in short, if all you care about is quality of food then this place is definitely for you.
author: Lee S.

description:
Its been a long time since Ive had a horrible Friday, This was one those days. I found out some F@#ker in Missouri got a hold of my debit card numbers and charged up almost 200 bills in 3 separate transactions. For a good half of the day I was pissed, I wanted nothing more than to smash this person's face in with my own two fists. Being a college student and not making that much money can make a guy upset tat he lost almost half a checks worth of money on stuff he didn't buy. After not having much of an appetite all day, I just needed to get out of the house.

My good friend offered to take me out to dinner, even tho his day wasn't going any better. I was seeking comfort food other than my fav bowl of noodles.  When we got to Little Pizza, we found a parking space within a matter of minutes right across the street. We were told that it would be a half hr wait to be seated. I said well we are here already so we mind as wait it out. We browsed the menu and figured out we wanted the Italian Combo Deep dish pizza. The hostess was nice and said that we could do a pre-order for the deep dish while we waited. 

When we were seated, i got to check out the decor and the restroom. There are alot interesting furniture and artwork. The hostesses podium is actually a dresser.  http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/6U4kIcBB6--R5DlGhsFVdQ/l
The Pac Man bathroom sign was super cute! (^^)V  http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SNMZ-Y-Vesl5n3W-oOJJ2g/l

Some other things i noticed were the glasses for water,they were actually half of a bottle and sanded down so it was smooth. http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/fJbJrfZeyxKdF14qIf7JPg/l

I would say this is my first time having something closer to a Chicago style deep dish pizza, my first impression is that theres a lot of sauce on top. To me it masked the flavors of our Italian combo. Maybe that pizza isn't good for deep dish but everything on the pizza was very fresh and tasted good, but the sauce was so strong. The crust was delicious, crisp and different from any other crusts i have ever had.  
http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/DqTwUXYUqOuOTMd517LKiw/l

After eating 3 slices of the deep dish, It still wasn't hitting the spot for me, so i ordered a small Chicken Pesto thin crust. It came out piping hot and after taking my first bite, I noticed that the pesto taste was very pronounced and the mix of onions, chicken, pesto and cheese were perfect. Exactly what my tastebuds were looking for. My only gripe was that the edges were burnt a bit and the chicken was a lil bit overcooked, other than that it was a good pizza. Considering i ate half of that too :X. http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/6q27r5vWaaamiqAKvEtW5A/l

My conclusion about the thin crust: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/__I9HmtBMV4dDkEgT22V4g?select=ZvfIvn_CkWd5dfg5CGGGLA

I would like to conclude with giving props to our waitress CLAIRE! You were awesome, she came back to check on us and ask us if we needed anything. Keep up the good work Claire!

Some Words of advice:

-CASH ONLY! (remember i said my friend was treating, well he didn't have any cash so i had to pay -__-, but at tat point I could care less.)

-If you are waiting to be seated and you have a 30min or so, do a preorder if you are getting a deep dish.

-The place gets noisy btw the music and many people talking at once, prolly not the best place to catch up with someone unless you like talking over the noise.

-Be prepared to wait, this place gets insanely busy
author: Jonathan W.

description:
My family come up to San Francisco and always stop by for a pizza here. Love the deep dish here. 

Best part is that even left over is good after heating it up on the oven for about 5 mins.

Highly recommend this place.
author: Joon P.

description: The garlic bread is amazing. I've never liked deep dish pizza in general, but the crust at little star is really grainy and delicious. So much better than classic Chicago deep dish.
author: Kamya J.

description:
So little star pizza already has more than 2000 reviews - why does it need one more?  It doesn't.  But it is SO good.

My friends and I arrived with a big party and they estimated a half hour wait. The wait was actually an hour, which was very frustrating.  We had been driving in from quite a ways, and we were tired and hungry, and thirty minutes is a long time to underestimate by.

So why the five stars?  Well, it didn't hurt that personal apologies from a manager and free salads helped ease my annoyance, and the pizza is so good.  I'm normally a fan of the cracker thin pizza, but little star pizza's deep dish is wonderful.  I've had the classic deep dish and the vegetarian, and both, it turns out, are worth waiting an hour for.
author: A B.

description:
2 orders of garlic bread (4 stars), 2 large salads (4 stars), 1 large white pie (4 stars), and 1 large Little Star (5+ stars) fed me in a burger king birthday crown + my 9 hungry closest friends and family at my "its not my birthday" preparty.

I was really really hopefully when I took my first bite of deep dish that the hour and 15 minute wait would be worth it, and it absolutely was. I am going to be dreaming about the cornmeal crust and stewed tomatoes for weeks. Perfection. 

Big shout out to the hostess and our waiter for being super awesome!
author: Emily D.

description: Really great all around. Nice atmosphere and aesthetic, really friendly and accommodating staff. Food is really great to top it all off.
author: Andrew L.

description: Great deep dish pizzas. Not greasy at all like others out there. Prices are good value too.
author: Mike B.

description:
I was a bit hesitant to come back as my first experience with Little Star consisted of waiting in line in the cold, being shuttled into the dimly lit, overcrowded dining area and crammed into a table way too small for 3 people to sit comfortably. The deep dish pizza itself was disparagingly soggy and unappetizing.

HOWEVER, come Sunday morning, this place is a breezy little place for an early bite of the 'za. What a change some sunlight, 243% less people and some air can do. I got the thin crust Italian combo and the man sitting across from me got the thin crust classic. Divine combination of flavors and texture. Little Star, you're great! But clearly too crowded for me during the dinner rush.
author: Linda T.

description:
I thought i was a flaky pie crust-y lover.  Spent most of my life near and in Chicago so I was a bit critical of a corn meal and corny based crust, but i have to admit-- it was damn good.

We ordered the "Little Star" deep dish pizza- small, enough for 2 and a vegetarian's dream.

The cheese garlic bread is yummy too- we asked for ranch and they didn't have any so they were very accommodating with getting us some pizza sauce to dip.
author: Angelica M.

description:
Let me set the stage - Bay to Breakers, four hours of straight drinking, lots of walking and hot weather. I wanted food, sleep and maybe another beer. Insert Little Star. 

Oh thank the little stars. Yes we had to wait 40 minutes at 3 in the afternoon for pizza but every bite of that deep dish pizza was blow your mind delicious. I'll be back Little Star, I'll be back. 

Oh and your hosts that let us order our pizza in advance so it was ready when we sat down? Geniuses! Thank you times a million for being so accommodating. :)
author: Krista K.

description:
I had the Chicago style here yesterday and it was very good. We ordered the original (sausage, peppers, and we swapped the onions for black olives) and I must say it was a good pizza.

The crust was tasty and never seemed to become oily. The cheese was sparing, which I consider a good thing. They allowed us to swap out the onions to olives. Thank you!

The only draw back was the wait. It wasn't that crowded, but still it took nearly an hour wait for a pizza. Good Chicago style takes time, but I could imagine on nights and weekends when it is crowded, waiting for a table and waiting for the pizza could make this a place where you have to pre-eat before going.

Overall, a good pizza experience.
author: Robin P.

description:
As a recent college grad I think it goes without saying that I've had my share of pizza and let me say, Little Star, hands down some of the best pizza I've ever had. Whether its their deep dish or thin crust pizza, this place has it down. The first time I went I ordered their daily special; a thin crust pizza with white-sauce, bacon, broccoli & garlic... holy crap. I couldn't get anything for a while. 

When I finally made the switch to the deep dish it was just as magical. Let me just warn you that the deep dish is big and heavy and it actually made me sick because I kept eating it. I think its a good sign when something makes you sick because its so good you just can't stop eating it? 

As much as I love this place I don't know if I would recommend it for delivery or even pick-up. It's restaurant style pizza at restaurant style prices.
author: Eduardo R.

description:
Up date.
As I wrote, we had so much left over "pizza" from the Little Star.
3 days after.
Still no one touched the lousy edible triangular-sponges in refrigerator.
Yes, I call it "LOUSY EDIBLE TRIANGULAR-SPONGES".

In general speaking, don't we all like left over pizza?
Yes, we like left over pizza. 
But not this one. You won't believe how the thick layer of Tomato gets so sour like son of B.
I never threw left over pizza away to garbage can. 
Never!

4th day, all those lousy edible triangular-sponges out of refrigerator to compost bin. 
That's how bad the thing was.
No regret. 
Glad to see that triangular-sponges in GARBAGE, and more room in refrigerator.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Ive been informed by the owner that Little Star imports its prosciutto from Italy and that technically it is prosciutto. I still call it ham. Any prosciutto connoisseur knows it should be prepared in transparently thin slices. When its cut in thick cubes it leans heavily into being ham. 

As harsh as my review is on the thin crust pie, which they are absolutely horrific at making. I have enjoyed their thick crust pizza, which is not really pizza. Its more just pie, but it is good, hence the many positive reviews. I feel I am giving them very constructive criticism as they are getting big heads thinking they can produce great thin crust pizza. Its either one or the other. 

I love pizza debate.
author: H K.

description: Good deep dish, not the best, but if you're in the area well worth the visit.
author: Ed T.

description: Good deep style pizza. Lighter than the standard ones (for me that's a bonus point) but the usual great taste. Love this place
author: Luigi P.

description: I keep searching for a better pizza place and trust me I've searched all over and not just in San Francisco. Little Star pizza is the best by far!! I love the deep dish the crust is perfect and if you're in town stop by and try any of there deep dish pizzas you won't be disappointed. I have ways had great service there and highly recommend you try Little Star Pizza! I just hope they decide to branch out and get a few more locations!!
author: Jennifer B.

description: I usually prefer New York style pizza but I love Little Star's deep dish, especially The Classic. The staff was very friendly and Arrogant Bastard's on tap!
author: Jeff S.

description:
Little Star had a 45-minute wait for a table, but the four of us in our group already expected that. It's clearly a popular spot, and it was a Friday night. We ordered the large Classic deep dish pizza (23" with sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green bell peppers) to share when the hostess took our name after she told us that it takes 30 minutes to cook.

When we sat down, we also ordered the garlic bread and the large mixed salad to share as appetizers. The garlic bread was a few slices of sourdough with a bulb of roasted garlic and side of butter. We all enjoyed it, though I suggest that you get two orders for four people The mixed salad is good too, and the crumbled Gorgonzola was a nice touch.

I was worried that the pizza might be overrated because it's hard to make pizza taste amazing and stand out, but it far exceeded my expectations. The cheese, toppings, and sauce were very well balanced with each other. The cheese had the perfect gooey consistency, and the sausage and cornmeal crust were amazing. 

The service was attentive as well. Our glass water bottle was refilled quickly, and the servers came by to check on us often.
author: Sara L.

description:
The last time I ate Little Star Pizza was about 2 1/2 years ago in the Mission on my way to Dolores Park. However I had my midget terror child (dog) with me, so I was not able to go inside and wait. This time I went with a group of about 8 or 9 people. Since they do not take reso's, we headed over there at about 5:45pm on a Saturday and put our name down on the list. They said it would only be about 15-20 min, so we happily waited at the bar and got a couple glasses of wine. By the time the table was ready he asked if our whole group was there, which they weren't. I asked if he could seat us anyways b/c we were only missing one girl. Luckily he agreed and added an extra chair when we realized we were actually missing two, Ooops! Loved how accommodating they were considering how booked they were! :)

Now onto the food. Once again their deep dish pizza was delish and super filling. Their garlic bread was really good too-- whole roasted garlic, dish of butter and sliced bread to make your own piece. Because I was wearing a rather tight outfit and didn't want to shove my face with carbs, I skipped the bread and went straight for the roasted garlic. Maybe if I hadn't had a bf I wouldn't of done that Lol. Whatever, it was yummy! 

The servers were friendly and helpful, and I liked that they had a jukebox with a wide selection of the bands I liked. The sad part is that we couldn't hear any of our songs where we were sitting...maybe they should slightly up the volume? 

All in all, it's a very tasty pizza spot if you can get in!
author: Sonya D.

description:
This is a MUST GO place in San Francisco. They have the most delicious deep dish pizza! My friends and I had the Little Star Pizza and it was just fantastic! 
We ordered the large pizza for 3 girls and it was a lot of food. If you are coming here with a group of girls, a small size pizza should be plenty.
They also have an amazing selection of micro brewery beer and we didn't have to wait more then 20 minutes to get seated.
I'm definitely coming back to Little Star Pizza.
author: Niley B.

description:
Ok went here with a friend recently. After hearing all the ranting and raving reviews from all my friends and coworker, I have to say I was overall disappointed. We ended up getting the plain deep dish pizza and some chicken wings. Ok the wings were pretty good. They were black pepper galore :) I loved it. Medium sized wings with pretty juicy too. Nothing covered in oil or anything like that.

The pizza on the other hand was just so so. I have only been to a couple other places that specialize in deep dish pizza. The crust was flavorless and a little too hard. The sauce not so good imo. More like I was eating bread with some sauce on it and some cheese. I think the trendiness might have just run away with this place.
author: Greg G.

description:
Little Star + cute & friendly Shorty's delivery girl = fab Friday nite

I've been a fan of Little Star since they opened, especially that crust and the surprisingly un-heavy toppings. Totally outstanding!
author: Mac M.

description:
Amazing.

A little pricy, but for about $25 you get a meal for two, plus enough for breakfast the next morning. And it tastes so delicious. Every time I've eaten here it's been amazing culinary experience, Chicago-style taste that just satisfies.
author: Ben H.

description:
The deep dish is consistently fresh and delicious. Best pizza in SF.

UPDATE: After living in NYC for 2 years, I can honestly say Little Star is among the best.
author: Steve N.

description:
Why did I wait so long to write a review?!

On a cold night, I had a huge craving for pizza and my friend instantly said Little Star Pizza! 

The place was packed and the wait was too long so we got our pizza to go. We ordered the Italian Combo thin crust pizza. The small is a 12" for $18. A bit pricey in my opinion but fast forwarding to me taking the first bite, I'd say yea its worth it. 

The Italian combo consists of: Pepperoni, salami, onions, green bells, black olives, pepperoncini. Just they way I like it.

I would love to come back here and dine in. The restaurant is small and has very dim lighting but for dinner it's perfect. A nice place to have a casual date. Two thumbs up!
author: Angeline H.

description: Little Star may have just jumped the ranks to my favorite pizza joint in SF this weekend. We were having friends over for a few beers before going out and needed an easy dinner. We called Little Start for delivery and decided on a large half white pie and half mushroom and sausage. Delivery was prompt and easy. The pizza was still hot and the pizza itself was delicious! I'd like to try their deep dish at some point but their thin crust is perfect. The white pie came with zucchini and the mushroom and sausage was exploding with flavor. I can't wait to indulge again!
author: Madeline S.

description:
Great pizza. Great spot. Indie staff but not snobby. 
The mushroom and pepperoni is delicious. 
Hard to beat anywhere in SF.
author: Charlie V.

description:
Hands down the best pizza in SF. My husband and I can't agree on whether to get the thick (him) or thin (me) crust, so we order one of both and eat it for three consecutive meals. 

Go with my pick though - the thin crust white pizza is amazing! Who would have though that zucchini on pizza would make it the da' bomb, but it does!
author: Christina S.

description:
Okay wow, I usually don't like pizza, but this place was worth it.

Very cute, sassy little place with wonderful people. They were very friendly and it's a great place to come after work to get something to eat or even stay, have a beer and pizza and chit chat with your friends.

We ordered the garlic bread (a mini garlic and cheese pizza) and their little star deep dish pizza (original). It was so gooood. Mind you, for 3 girls, we were unable to eat all of the lg deep dish pizza (left about a half of it), so if ever, just order a small for you guys. It might be better without too much left overs.

Price wasn't bad with the garlic bread being around $9 i think and the pizza being around $19. 

Pretty good :)
author: Kare B.

description: Very yummy thin crust. Super generous with portions. Had one with sausage mushroom and onion. Would have it again but I really want to experiment with other great looking toppings.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Ok... I'm a deep dish pizza snob....born and raised on chicago pizza and after  trying Zachary's in Oakland, I swore off imitations of Chicago's deep dish pizza. As  I sat on the bar stool, wondering why I was sitting here when I will be heading to Chi-town for the real deal. Well, Lil Star.. u knocked my socks off! I am impressed.... we had the sausage tomatoes garlic deep dish... and WoW... Wow! That was a damn good, no GREAT pizza..The crust.... OMG.... what a great crust... better than any at Edwardo's, Bacino's, Giordana's , Gino's, Lou Malnalti's, the original Pizzeria UNO.... NO one can does a crust like yours! My original thought was, " this is a one-timer", and check you off my list.... I will be back... and when I'm in Chi-town, no need for deep dish.... I found my place in SF!
author: Jay S.

description:
Little Star first introduced me to the world of deep dish pizza and I sure did want to stay a while! Since the pizzas are about an inch thick, a small 9" one can feed a few. Who cares how many calories are in each slice? You can't stop after just one so you might as well go all the way (I was only able to eat 2 slices btw). 

Brass Monkey ($18, off the menu) - The ricotta and feta cheeses made this pizza special. It had a creamier texture and was mouth-watering with the spinach, mushrooms, onions, garlic, and of course sausage. It was amazing how much they were able to fit on top of that crust. Totally to die for! 

Classic ($17.50) - This one was similar to the Brass Monkey but used regular mozzarella cheese, excluded garlic, and subbed the spinach for green bell peppers. Another successful concoction but I preferred the first one...the green peppers just didn't go very well with all that sauce. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/__I9HmtBMV4dDkEgT22V4g?select=7sVx0VbtFsx2tba66gBABA)

The best part about these pizzas was the generous heaping of chunky tomato sauce that topped everything off. So fresh, tangy, and just oh-so-perfect. The crunchy, buttery crust that kept the pizza intact was incredible as well. Mmmm!

I wouldn't be able to eat this all the time but everyone needs an indulgence at Little Star once in a while. Be sure to call ahead if you are planning to pick up your order since they take around 30-40 min to make. 

Hope your first deep dish pizza experience will be as unforgettable as mine!
author: Karen Y.

description: I had a classic deep dish and have nothing but positive things to say about the pizza. Wouldn't get this that often since it cost around 20-25 for a small pie but would not hesitate to go here again if I'm craving deep dish pizza.
author: Carlos R.

description: From the garlic bread to the pizza sauce, this place is delicious. Knocked off a star because their water cups were dirty, but besides that, loved it.
author: Kitty D.

description:
Review for their take-out only.

Tried their large Classic (sausage, mushroom, peppers and onions) deep dish; and their large Pesto Chicken thin crust pizzas.

Pizza = I've had better.  The crust/dough was just way too effin' dry for me.  Yes, I know what 'cornmeal' is, thanks.  But it's way too dry.  I'm not talking about the bottom of the pizza...I'm talking about the dough that's in between the sauce and bottom of the pie...it was like cardboard, sorry!

Wings = spicy and good.   Bleu cheese dressing only...hmmm, but no alternative of ranch dressing, at all.  

Service = friendly enough at the counters.  

Decor = freakin' dark.  I'm not sure how people can see their food.  

Parking = a real pain.  Good luck.
author: Fannie S.

description: The deep dish pizza a yummy in my tummy!-the crust is crunchy with the corn meal added. I prefer this place over Zacharys because there's more flavor to the pizza and crust. Overall the service was wonderful.
author: Paulina D.

description: Best pizza ever!!!!!!! We got the deep dish and also wings and it was incredible. You MUST try!
author: Victoria G.

description: Get the pizza called "little star"!! its delicious!! but be warned it has a strong garlic taste (some people like it, some don't!) Also if you get "The Vegetarian": be warned that I did not find any of the vegetables promised in the pizza except olives.....
author: Anila Y.

description:
This was our last meal in SF...and I havent stopped thinking about it. 
Everything from the fresh gooey cheese, the the freshness of the veggies and meat, to the deliciousness of the sauce is absolutley to die for! 
Ive had Chicago style pizza in Chicago and this is as close and good as it gets. 
I will definitely be going back the next time we make our way to San Francisco. 
But until then I can only dream :)
author: Marie V.

description: Meh...The deep-dish pizza here made me appreciate the real stuff in Chicago even more (if that's possible).
author: Ian T.

description: we decided to go with a thick crust pizza.  the crust was perfectly executed.  it was thick enough to satisfy dough lovers but thin enough to have the perfect crunch and allow room in the stomach for more than one slice.  we're going to go back.
author: Amy J.

description: I love Little Star, it is delicious and filling, and I love the cornmeal crust, but I have to say: this is not pizza. This is tomato/cheese pie :)  (I haven't tried the thin-crust yet).
author: Michelle W.

description: You must try this little Pizzaria! If you like Chicago style Pizza, this is your spot!
author: Sejin J.

description:
This is some seriously damn good pizza!

It's so difficult to compare all the different Chicago deep dish joints because it seems each one offers something a little bit different than the other.

What do I love about Little Star? Hands down, it's got to be the cornmeal crust! There's also something about the way they make their pies that somehow eliminates the sogginess that, say, Zachary's seems to wind up being after 10 minutes of hanging out next to your table.

The wait for a table can be a bit on the long side - but once you're seated, prompt and friendly attention is lavished on you.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Christy L.

description:
9" half veggie half little star. Being from Chicago, this was pretty legit. Crust makes or break it for me, and this had just enough butter to make it feel like home. Great job :) We had the apricot beer to try something different and it was pretty tasty.  We put our name in, but due to the long line, went a few doors down to get a few drinks.  NIght turned out well and no time was wasted :) 

*Fred was happy*
author: Maricris D.

description:
This pizzeria's facade is completely unassuming and the simple, minimalist sign may be left unnoticed by many passers-by. After an "SF short" walk (usually translating to 6 blocks too long to me) of 8 city blocks, I gratefully slipped into the door of Little Star Pizza to try to warm my nearly immobile fingers and toes.

A kitchen error resulted in an extra 15 minute wait on top of the 20 it usually takes for a deep dish to come out of the pizza oven, but the silver lining manifested itself in the form of a complimentary order of chicken wings promptly brought to our table. I can't say for certain whether it was the wonderfully flavorful spices, the abundantly juicy meat, or the on-the-house value that amped up my enjoyment of these, but this chicken was the best I've had in a long time.

Instead of 7x7's recommended Little Star deep dish pizza (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic), we opted for the Classic (a more mainstream combination of sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells) as the prospect of a meatless pizza didn't entirely appeal to us that night.

This double layered pizza certainly didn't skimp on the cheese, and the gooey spread was blanketed by a generous layer of toppings and finished with warm tomato sauce. What really stood out was not what was on the pizza itself, but what the pizza lay on top of. The cornmeal crust was absolutely my favorite part of the meal, and the homey, nutty flavor complemented the rest of the dish surprisingly well.

Though I had hoped my first experience with Chicago deep dish pizza would be in Chicago itself, I'm more than certain that this San Francisco take is a worthy comparison.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
BEST PIZZA IN SF!!!  

The thin crust classic pizza with pepperoni.  BOOM!  The crust is cornmeal crusted :)  The cheese oozes when you lift up a piece, and the toppings cover all corners.  Every single bite is yummmmy in my tummy!  

I'll come back again... very soon!
author: irene u.

description:
We were preparing our taste buds to try Little Star pizzeria whole weekend.
We started off with ordering really sad and boring (meh) pizza from some random, but still very high rated pizzeria by yelp community. We ate it and forgot about the taste, only memories of "never order it again" are still with us.
Then we had frozen Trader Joe pizza - which is always good - very thin crust, quick and hits the spot and won the competition for the best home "baked" pizza :)
And finally for diner we had our 3rd and 4th pizza for the day: Deep Dish Little Star and Tonight's Special thin crust combination.

I am not so fond of the Little Star Pizza - well mainly because i don't like tomatoes and this pizza had too much of it. However the corn crust and cheese was delicious.

Both of us felt in love with the special thin crust pizza. Was amazing.

After eating so many pizzas in one day. Little Star Pizzeria won my heart.

Cheers,
author: Anelya S.

description: Did not live up to the high expectations I had. To be fair, I ordered the thin-crust pizza which was okay but not amazing. My pizza was half meteor and half italian combo. It was a pit pricey and a small is enough for a party of four. If I'm ever in the area, I might go back to try the deep-dish but we'll see.
author: Katherine N.

description:
I waited far too long to try Lil Star. I have always been a Patxi's fan but after getting stuffed with the Chicago style here on sunday I am a convert.  Its all in the cornmeal crust, which is just plain delicious. 

Golden, crispy, buttery, crusty...its like crack.   It puts this Chicago style over the top.  I grew up outside of Chicago and had plenty of the world famous pizza but NONE of those spots had a crust like this.  I would order a side of crust if I could.  Plus the toppings come in a fantastic array topping combos.
author: Dru P.

description:
The pizzas and the wings are AWESOME, but kinda cramped, kinda loud -- so you need to be in the mood for the scene. It's always crowded, so be prepared for a wait.

The service is SO-SO, but hey -- it's a pizza joint.

The wine list is TERRIBLE, so stick with beer.

The parking situation is TERRIBLE, so walk or take a cab.
author: Scott S.

description: Loved the caprese salad and deep dish special pizza. Cheap beer, good ambiance. Good high-low mix.
author: Sara W.

description: Seriously - the most amazing pizza ever!  the crust is what makes it so amazing!  Pizza is probably the one food that I could have every single day for the rest of my life, and I have been all over the world trying different pizzas, and this has to be one of the top pizzas I have ever had. Even after eating Pizza in New York city.
author: Suzanne S.

description:
I've heard a lot of great things about this place, but I can't say I walked away too impressed. Their deep-dish wasn't bad by any means; it's just that the pizza seemed rather ordinary in my opinion.

The one thing definitely worth mentioning though is the fact that Little Star serves cream soda. I friggin love cream soda. But at the same time, it's also never a good sign when you feel better about your soda than the actual pizza. 

3 little stars.
author: Tom P.

description:
thin crust, great cheese and amazing topping combinations! 
I do not miss Boston Pizzas anymore...thanks Little Star! You saved me...:-)
author: Soniya W.

description:
These guy's do it right. Whatever their special is, I'm all about it.  Ordering takeout is a snap - even wit the crowd there.

Had my family in town and decided to try go there and sit down for dinner. They said a 45 minute wait was between us and sitting down so I said ok.
They called promptly 47 minutes later and we walked back and were seated immediately.

It is crowded, but its just big enough to have a cozy dinner with ppl you like. The food impressed everyone.

Will always go back.
author: Ross H.

description:
I've always wondered since my young days why pizza is often times referred to as pizza "pie", but all my qualms and doubts disappeared into thin air the moment I took a bite into Little Star Pizza's Mediterranean Chicken Deep Dish Pizza.

To this day I wake up in the morning dreaming about its crumbling crust, the succulent chicken engulfed in glorious marinara sauce held together by stringy mozarella cheese liberally melted on top... oh man...

If it weren't for the price and the fact that there's always a long wait for your food here due to how popular it is, I would probably eat here everyday and live a short, and happy/fat life until I eventually die of clogged arteries.

Oh, they also have a very unique selection of beer which your waiter/ess/sommelier likes to pair up with the pizza you ordered. They have the mainstream domestic beers here as well as some that I can only presume to be microbrew or local brews. Either way, the pizza and beer here are to die for.
author: Scott S.

description:
Pretty darn delish.

The toppings are fresh and amazing. The tomato sauce is perfect.  The crust is just a tad dense for my liking, but otherwise, a standup pie!
author: Maddie G.

description: My boyfriend & I loved this place. We were hoping for a table but the bar was fine too. Customer service was excellent, and the pizza was sooo good. Really good selection on the menu, and lots and lots of beer. I wish they had more gelato options, but that isn't a huge deal. We'll definitely continue going. c:
author: Briahna E.

description: Great pizza in a great place, lovely jubbly. We shared a large Italian which was most definitely the best pizza, both my wife and I had ever had. Lived up to the reviews that drew is there in the first place.
author: Murray C.

description: The thin crust pizza was incredible! A buttery, crispy crust and delicious fresh ingredients made for an amazing pizza eating experience. I especially love that they have whole roasted garlic and sun dried tomatoes...yum! They also have great Champaign drinks to sip on while you wait for your table. Overall I highly recommend this restaurant and I will most definitely be back for more!
author: Nicole T.

description: I love this place. You won't be disappointed. I especially like the white thin crust pizza + chicken sausage FTW!
author: Amol S.

description: Very good and quick service. The pizza is really COOL!!!
author: Pablo L.

description:
What better way to show my love for Little Star Pizza than to dedicate my 50th review to this deep dish pizza goldmine.   

I was lured to Little Star Pizza by its coveted spot on the 7x7's list of 100 things to eat before you die.  I couldn't resist the temptation of devouring one of the most delicious creations in SF.  Chicago deep dish, watch your back. Little Star Pizza won't go down without a fight.      

To die for pizza:       
- Brass monkey (secret menu item): The Little Star (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic) with sausage  
- Mediterranean Chicken - Chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bell peppers, green olives, onions, feta

Little Star Pizza creates some delicious pies that pack some serious punch.  I'm really at a loss for words when I try to describe the gloriousness of their pizza.  The deep dish pizza is cheesy, loaded with toppings and covered with a layer of chunky tomato sauce.  But the real kicker is the crispy cornmeal crust.  The texture of the crust is well balanced with the spectacular flavors of the toppings.  Be prepared - it will knock your socks off!  

It was a pretty standard wait time for two deep dish pizzas.  The service was great - we were seated almost immediately and our waiter was attentive.  The vibe I got from this LSP location was equivalent to a dive bar - relaxed atmosphere, dim lighting, and chill music.  A perfect place to kick back after a long day to enjoy some cold brewskies and unforgettable pizza.    

Consider yourself warned: CASH ONLY!!!

Brass Monkey deep dish at Little Star Pizza - check! I can officially die happy.
author: Ashley O.

description:
best deep dish in zee deep deesh peetsa world! it's hard to admit this, but it absolutely blew patxi's out of the water, and even kind of stomped on zachary's (my usual go-to, but not so sure anymore...)!

celebrated my 25th birthday here with my family (5) and two extras for a party of 7. on a friday night at 6:45 pm, it was cozily full but there wasn't a crowd of people hovering outside. the line for takeout, however, was about 20 people long. granted it was valentine's day, so people were probably having romantic $$$ dinners elsewhere. there aren't too many tables in the restaurant, but we fit (surprisingly) comfortably at a square table. 

we ordered a mountain of food - the caprese salad, normal green salad, chicken wings, two deep dish pizzas (the original and the little star), and the special of the night (thin crust with bacon, garlic, brussels sprouts). everything was delicious and cooked perfectly. salads were refreshing and crisp, chicken wings were a bit spicy but delicious! the pizza toppings were plentiful and the cornmeal pizza crust was on point. for the newbs, i'd recommend ordering the little star (ricotta cheese, gorgonzola, spinach, garlic, onions). it tasted a wee bit like a lasagna, but it was still so damn good. for the traditional meat lovers, i'd def recommend the original (sausage, mushroom, peppers, onions). disclaimer - i may be missing some ingredients since i'm listing this all from memory, but just note that it was probably the best deep dish evaaaar. 

the total for 2 deep dish pizzas, 1 thin crust, 2 salads, and 1 appetizer, a glass of wine, a beer, and a soda came out to ~$150, which per person is pretty damn reasonable.

only (minor) complaint was that the restaurant was so dark, i couldn't really read the menu without putting it 2 inches in front of my face. i also didn't take any photos of the food... not only because i was so hungry, but also because it was so dark and i'm not about to blind the whole restaurant with my iphone flash!

other than that ... GIVE IT A TRY! the restaurant logo is cute too!
author: Caitlin C.

description:
I got contacted by the owner of this establishment apologizing for my last bad experience here. I am grateful that he actually took the time to acknowledge me and assured that he would take my review as an opportunity to better his business. 

I feel this is important to point out, as it is very comforting that there are still people out there who is serious about the well-being of their customers. I felt that they genuinely want to learn from all the negative experiences and reviews. 

It is great that this Little Star cares. I hope to be able to visit them again.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
There comes a time in every woman's life when she cries from eating the best deep dish pizza ever. Little Star, you made that happen! My heart still has a place for Zachary's but Little Star's crust really is something else. 
My group of 11 came here on a Saturday night and the wait wasn't too bad (20 mins or so). The waitress let us order ahead of time so that by the time we'd be seated, our pizzas will be out. We ordered the classic and vegetarian deep dish pizzas and two other regular pizzas that I forgot. I have heard about their delicious corn meal crust and the hype is true: the crust REALLY is worth the wait. I know people complain about crispy crusts but that's the key to my heart. The pizzas aren't overly drenched with tomato sauce and they've also mastered cheese proportions. Since we had a large group, the waitress made sure our pizzas were double sliced so that each person can try a pizza option more than once. Neat! The waitress was incredibly attentive and came by enough times to make sure we were taken care of. This truly was one of the better service experiences I've encountered in San Francisco. 
BONUS: I didn't realize they had a location in the East Bay so I'll definitely stop by there for my next pizza craving!
author: Annah L.

description:
Ahhh, I need to revisit this place. I only got take-out from this place and I didn't eat the pie until 45 minutes after I picked it up. I guess it wasn't as tasty (not hot and fresh) as it could have been so I can't give a truly accurate rating to Little Star Pizza (also because I didn't eat there). Also when I was eating the pizza, I was standing around trying to find a spot in a busy bar--if I could have sat down and focused, I would have enjoyed the pizza better. At any rate, the pizza was good and I need to try it again.

Oh well, next time.
author: Marlon T.

description: I've coming here for years and was delighted tonight by an incredible new pie!  An olive oil based pie with asiago asparagus garlic and tomato?!  So light and absolutely perfect.  Little Star, thanks for keeping the good things good, and for giving the regulars something new to rediscover.
author: Rochelle R.

description: Great place to eat. Waitress messed up on our dish. We had no clue but she was very honest and gave us another pizza. The pizza was great. Thank you!
author: Daniel C.

description: Decided to give the deep dish pizza a shot I normally go to patxi's but I had a friend recommend this spot. My first disappointment was they didn't offer pineapple for the pizza. The sauce was good but the crust was weird. I really didn't enjoy it at all. I would rather go to patxi's.
author: meme s.

description: Not the deepest, not the cheesiest, not the sauciest, but one of the butteriest. Putting the dishiest aside, if you need your deep dish fix, go to this place
author: Oswaldo G.

description: The Little Star flagship pizza and a glass of red wine is pretty much my choice way to end a day. Just do it. Order ahead by about 35 minutes and make sure you order enough for leftovers.
author: Katie H.

description: The cornmeal crust is so crunchy and it's so NON-greasy.  It's like the tomato sauce is hiding all the good stuff underneath.  I'll make it simple:  it was yummy.   I ordered the small deep dish "Little Star" ($19.71 without tips).  Pizza is ready in 20 minutes.  I came around 6:00 p.m. and there was no wait and no lines.  The place is so easy to miss that I end up walking pass it.  It's next to the Muslim place?  It reminds me of a night club, so dark inside that you have to adjust your eyes.  If you want an intimate place to enjoy your pizza, this is the place.  It's cash only, but they have this ATM machine inside!  The neighborhood has so many "Happy Hour" places.
author: Helen L.

description:
When my friend who I was visiting told me she'd found the best chicago style deep dish pizza place, I was skeptical but open minded. Living in Hawaii and trying other poor examples of the doughy mess I had come to know as deep dish disaster pizza,  my bar for what constitutes good deep dish was set pretty low as is.

Though Friday night was probably not the best night to attempt to dine here without reservations as upon arrival we were warned the wait for a table for 2 would be 30 to 40 minutes.  This was not surprising because 1 - it *was* Friday night and 2 - I had seen studio apartments in Hawaii that rivalled the dining area of this restaurant.

My friend promised it was worth the wait so we grabbed a couple of drinks from the bar, grabbed a menu to peruse and discuss while seated in the waiting area... er... blue comfy chairs in the corner.

We eventually settled on the Little Star with sausage added. When we gave our order to the hostess (who kindly and wisely advised us to place our order with her first in order to minimize our wait time) she told us that we had inadvertently stumbled on a "secret" menu item. Allegedly the brass monkey earned its name as the most frequently ordered menu item by one of the Beastie Boys.

Satisfied with our ordering prowess but dissatisfied with our empty wine glasses we ventured back to the bar for refills.  Luckily as we made our way through the dinner crowd two bar seats opened up.  Happily seated at the bar with a carafe of water and bottle of wine planted in front of us, I have no clue how long our wait actually was.  Whatever the length of time, it was most definitely worth it.

Our pizza eventually arrived from the kitchen and was a perfect circle of mostly red with a golden brown crust outline.  I was immediately apprehensive because it seemed to be the epitome of everything I dislike in a pizza - excessive sauce and overly doughy crusts.  However the moment that first bite hit my lips all was forgiven. The sauce was amazing! Perfectly seasoned and not at all runny. Oh and the crust! I admit, I can be a bit of a crust snob and was certainly expecting to find an uncooked doughy disaster underneath all the topping but I was thrilled that these expectations were proven wrong.  The crust was crispy but not uncomfortably crunchy and overall the pizza just had wonderful flavors!

Overall despite the Friday night rush of people and the inevitable wait because of it, the service was still great and the food was amazing! Whenver I make it back up to San Francisco I am definitely eating here again!
author: Jill B.

description: Loved it! Great pizza good drinks:) came last Friday night and didn't wait at all to sit at the bar. Really quick service and great food with a smile. I got the deep dish pizza and shared it, plenty of food for us but SUPER hungry folks could order two and have leftovers. I wish I had also gotten a regular crust pizza but I can only eat so much at once. I love that they have bell pepper options, you do not have to get green bell peppers, for me that's epic:) thank you Little Star.
author: Kellie S.

description:
We came to Little Star Pizza on our way to Night Life at the Academy of Sciences because it was highly recommended by Yelp and conveniently on the way. It was easy to get in on a Thursday night. 

We opted for a large mixed salad. It was delicious and enormous. We split a small deep dish pizza, half Vegetarian (mushrooms, onions, black olives, red bells, garlic, roasted zucchini) and half Little Star (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic). Both halves were awesome. The crust, as others have noted, is thick and crispy. Both sides were packed with veggies and cheese. We were definitely full after splitting the small. 

Would come back to Little Star next time we're in the neighborhood, for sure.
author: Alden Q.

description: this place is literally the shit. better than zachary's in berkeley. better than patxi's in sf.   we had the deep dish classic, deep dish mediterranean chicken, deep dish little star, and thin crust white pie. they were all motherfreaking delicious, with the white pie probably being the least delicious because it is not blessed with dat DEEP DISH CORNBREAD CRUST, aka the most amazing work of food genius that mankind has ever invented. 5/5 would come again
author: Michelle C.

description: I'm not usually a fan of deep dish pizza, but I feel like this place has some of the best pizza sauce in SF! Also, they manage to produce a pizza with a good balance between crust (arguably the most important part of a pizza) and the toppings (like I said, incredible sauce). Good stuff. Fairly priced. Gets crazy busy on the weekends, but isn't to bad if you go mid-week.
author: Aaron S.

description:
Twinkle, twinkle, little star,
You make the best pizza in SF by far.

In fact I believe that Little Star may be my new favorite pizza joint of all time. 

My friend and I wandered into this dark lit, crowded, cozy restaurant last Friday evening. We were told by the hostess that the wait would be 40 minutes but since all the parties ahead of us had at least 4 people in their groups we were seated at a small 2 person table in the corner of the restaurant within 10 minutes. 

When it comes to food my friend is very boring. He hates almost everything (except cheese and meat), and orders everything plain. He is not a big fan of deep dish pizza because he feels like there is always way too much sauce and not enough cheese. Since he is a big cheese and meat fanatic we ordered a large pizza with extra mozzarella, feta, gorgonzola, ricotta, pepperoni, salami, and sausage. It took about 20 minutes for our pizza to be prepared and brought out to our table. When the waiter brought it to us he said "This has to be the cheesiest pizza I have ever seen leave our kitchen". I actually think this was the cheesiest pizza I have ever eaten. Every bite had tons and tons of melted cheese in it. 

As I said before my friend does not like anything so when I suggested we add pesto sauce to our pizza he looked at me as if I was crazy (he is so boring) so once our pizza was brought to us I asked the waiter for a side of the sauce. Even without the pesto sauce this pizza was great but with the sauce it was phenomenal. I really can't think of a better tasting pizza. 

Our pizza came to about 30 dollars but considering all the toppings we added it was not bad. Our waiter was amazing too. He kept our water glasses full, made sure we had lots of napkins (we needed them), and checked in on us every few minutes to make sure we had everything we needed. 

If your ever find yourself in the city by the bay make sure you check out little star, I know you will love it.
author: Craig R.

description: Great, low key meal!  Did a half chicken-pesto, half greek thin crust.  Both were delicious although I think the Greek won (sundried tomatoes..) Chianti I had with it was decent for the price point. Very nice staff. I'm a pizza snob and I would definitely come again :)
author: Christine O.

description:
The mixed salad is really tasty and the daily pizza specials are always good. Coming from NYC, it's really hard to find good pizza in San Francisco for some reason. But this place never disappoints. It's a little pricey for what you get, but you can be smart about it and order from the right parts of the menu.

Go Little Star!
author: Taylor M.

description:
Paxtis, Zachery's and Little Star? An age-old question here in the Bay Area when it comes to deep dish pizza. I am behind Little Star 110%.

The crust with the cornmeal is just unbeatable. I typically get the vegetarian and those toppings + sauce + the awesome crust = a whole lot of happy. My one qualm: why does it say black olives on your pizza when I know for a fact it is kalamata? You guys aren't fooling me.
author: Raina B.

description: Was in town this weekend with some friends and this spot was highly recommended through some other friends and DAMN were they right!!! Sooo bomb,we got the classic deep dish and the special that evening which had meatballs mushrooms spinach I believe and it was shake your head stomp your feet good, my friends and I are big talkers and we ate in silence mesmerized  by the taste of them there pizzas!!! The hostess was nice and from socal about 10 minutes from my home so I got that chill welcoming vibe,our waitress was also friendly and helpful,just remember it  takes about 30 minutes to cook so go hungry but keep that in mind so you don't get all worked up while waiting,even though trust when I say it's worth it!!!
author: David I.

description:
I love Little Star when I am craving deep dish pizza. I've never been disappointed after leaving, which is an experience I have had at all of heir locations.

The price can be a little much but it is definitely worth it due to the quality. I also love the caprice salad and other appetizers. It can be busy and sometimes a wait but always worth it.
author: Holly F.

description:
I've never been a big fan of deep dish pizza but the Little Star Pizza crust is to die for. It's made from a corn bread type dough so the crust is tasteful, crispy and had just the right amount of bread on the pizza. I had 
about 2 pieces and I was already full.

Ordered the Classic which consisted of your typical sausage, mushrooms, green peppers,and onions. The tomato sauce and the crust is what made the pizza so savory and tasteful. 

I never liked deep dish pizza's because it was always too thick, messy to eat and too much crust but at Little Star Pizza it was just the right amount, I would definitely recommend this place. It's a pretty small place so it's best to go with smaller groups or better yet get it to go.
author: Elsa Y.

description:
Pizza was oh so cheesy with a thick crust (deep dish). Parking can be a challenge on the street, time metered. If I were in the neighborhood again I would absolutely eat here again.

Ambiance is mellow and fun.  Cool place to grab lunch or dinner.
author: Gabby D.

description: Pizza here was legit deep dish - I would know because I'm from Chicago!  Restaurant itself is pretty cozy, bit cramped for seating.  In addition to their delicious pizza pie and good service, I laughed at their dramatic sign: "Due to a shortage, water will only be served upon request" ;)
author: Ubz D.

description:
Little Star puts a California twist on the classic Chicago Deep Dish and gives the Big 3 Chicago joints (Uno/Due, Gino's East, and Giordano's) a serious run for their money. Each slice is savory, with the sweet taste of the succulent tomatoes and crisp greens, mixing together just perfectly with the rich-in-flavor yet not-overbearing cheese. The cornbread crust too is perfect - just the right amount of cornmeal to make it crispy, but not too heavy.

The Golden Gate Bridge. Fisherman's Wharf. The Painted Ladies. Philz Coffee Little Star Pizza. Every visitor to the City by the Bay needs to add Little Star to their TripTik. It's that good.

I think I left my foodie heart at Little Star.
author: Peien L.

description:
This place is fantastic. We went on a Saturday night and had to wait about 45 minutes but it was well worth it. The first thing I noticed (aside from the great dark atmosphere) was that the service was excellent. We were greeted almost as soon as we were seated and our first round of drinks arrived in less than a minute. We always had a full pitcher of water at our table throughout the meal.

We started with the caprese salad which was great. Very fresh ingredients. Fresh mozzarella and tomatoes served in a tasty olive oil and vinegar blend with olives and a couple pieces of bread. Definitely the perfect light appetizer to precede a very heavy entree. 

For dinner we got a deep dish pizza with meatballs (which were a special, not on the normal menu), peppers, mushrooms, and zucchini. I am obsessed with pizza, so I would say this meal appeals to me more than most. But that being said, this was one of the best meals I've ever had. I could taste the freshness of the ingredients. There cornmeal crust was crispy and flavorful. For a deep dish pizza, there was a great balance of sauce to cheese to toppings. Everything about it was delicious.

For the quality and amount of food you can get, the price is very reasonable. We had a large 4 topping pizza, an appetizer, and 3 beers, and walked out paying $65 with tip. I've paid significantly more than that for far inferior meals/dining experiences in this city.

Definitely check this place out.
author: Sam P.

description: So overall, as a foodie I wasn't overly impressed but i thought it was a good fast food of pizza if you're in the area and have the time to enjoy your pizza crispy inside. However, the employees and managers working there are super nice so my overall 3 star of the place goes up to 4 stars because of how nice everyone was. So thank you for that, it's nice that they care about customer service even in a fast food type of environment!
author: Jack Glab 0.

description:
Great deep-dish pizza, fresh ingredients, nice atmosphere (LOUD, though, so don't come here if you're looking to have a conversation), friendly service. 

A little pricey -- worth it for what you're getting, I guess, but maybe a little more expensive than it needs to be.  

They lose a star from me because it's SO incredibly loud when busy, there's often a long wait (small space), and it can take quite a while for your food to come out.  Not their 'fault" -- things take time, they're busy, and the noise is a space/acoustics issue -- so I don't blame them for it, but these are factors that sometimes cause me to choose a different restaurant.

Regardless, this is a must-try place in the neighborhood.  Their signature deep-dish pizza is amaaaazing, and their thin-crust is also very good. Nomz. :)
author: Crys L.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up for good peripherals.  Anyone that reads my reviews knows I'm a big time pizza snob.*

Hard to find location, its quite the hole in the wall.  When you walk in, its a dark space, with blue walls.  Very cool quaint little pizza joint.  Beverage menu is great!  Both my gf and I got soda, even though they had a nice beer menu. The black cherry soda was phenomenal.

The garlic bread appatizer was recommended by a friend.  Its fresh sourdough bread, with a large ball of roasted garlic and butter.  Sorta a DIY garlic bread.  It was good, but kinda more work than I wanted to do for garlic bread.  Great bread though!

We got the classic deep dish pizza with no onions.  Sausage, bell pepper, and mushroom.  It was good.  I enjoyed it alot.  That said, wasn't amazing.  Patxi's is significantly better. I would not get pizza here over Patxi's, although I might choose to go here for dinner instead.  The space is definitely nicer here, than at the Patxi's near castro.

Service was very good.  Prices are very reasonable.  Nothing to really complain at, just not an amazing standout place.
author: Chris A.

description: Fantastic crust....great pizza!  Also a really good salad before the pizza.
author: John C.

description:
Do I really need to add to the plethora of great reviews?

Yes. Because I love it that much.

Here are 5 reasons Little Star gets 5 stars:

1) Bomb. Diggity. Thin. Crust.  Period.  It's not like a Delarosa or Tony's type of paper-thin crust.  Instead, it has a crunchy bottom that's firm and doesn't wilt under the weight of the toppings.

2) Speaking of toppings, stringy cheese.  Without it, pizza just isn't good (hear that, Domino's?).  Oh, and lots of fresh toppings.  FRESH.

3) Not sure if it's because it was Labor Day weekend or whatnot, but I found parking half a block away.  This is a major win in my book.

4) GARLIC BREAD.  Please get this.  At first you may be like, wtf they just gave me a loaf of sourdough bread, a thing of butter and a half head of garlic.  I didn't realize that it was DIY garlic bread.  But then you get a bit of that roasted garlic clove on the bread and you'll be ready to ward off vampires.  But it's so, so worth it.

5) Takes credit cards, nice service, plus a cute restaurant.  Not much more you can ask for, right?

So there you have it, folks.  The next time you want a pizza with oomph, Little Star will not disappoint you one bit.  And if it does, pretend like you've never read this review.
author: Tori S.

description: This place is so great! I live right around the corner, so I try to go during the week so there isn't as long of a wait. Pizzas are great, I've only had the patience to wait for the thin crust, but one of these days I'll get around to one of those amazing looking deep dishes. The atmosphere is very comfortable and homey. Their pizza specials are on point and their salads are great too.
author: Kristina B.

description: Five stars= fantastic food! Service was amazing! Atmosphere was just perfect! Location was great! Would eat again and recommend to everyone!
author: Khawar A.

description:
Yum!  I've been to Little Star a few times and have always had delicious pizza.  I'll admit that their thick crust isn't that appealing as I don't like sauce on top of all of my cheese and toppings, but even then it's a generally tasty pizza.  But this review is about their thin crust.  It's always been delicious and the other night they had an incredible special of gorgonzola, pears and bacon on a thin crust pizza.  It was incredible!  

They also have a nice selection of wine, beer and drinks... I had the champagne and pomegranate drink.  A nice combo that I'd probably get again.  Service is friendly and helpful and the location is nice.  A little small and it can get crowded so get there early or get ready for a wait.
author: Christine N.

description: Garlic bread and Italian combo pizza were absolutely delicious! One of the best pizzas I have ever had!
author: André C.

description:
My friend suggested going for this place for Deep Dish Pizza,

What we ordered: 
Garlic Bread and Pepperoni, Sausage, and Mushroom Deep Dish Pizza

Garlic bread: 
It was made looking like a pizza. Inside there was Garlic, Mozzarella Cheese, Basil on top.  

Review: It was very good with the cheese being stringy and a lot of garlic flavor.

Pepperoni, Sausage, and Mushroom Deep Dish Pizza:
Had thick crust, lots of tomatoes, inside there were a lot of Pepperoni, Mushroom, and Sausage.

Review: I had a the first two slice and then I was feeling pretty much full. Toward the end it got a little salty. I wished there was a bit more mozzarella.

Place:
A little hard to find on the street because of small sign. When you walk in place is pretty dark, has a bar feel. A little loud at times because there was a kid at the next table.

Service:
Waitress was nice and asked how our food was. The wait is a little long for if you are only ordering pizza without appetizers about 20-30 mins.

Overall, I would come back to try their garlic bread and other pizza style crusts.
author: Irene L.

description:
Best pizza by far I ever eaten.

YUMM!!!

WOW! Loves it!

I had the original deep dish pizza. The crust itself was perfectly baked and crunchy and it wasnt oily or TOO cheesy. Yes, I dont like my pizza to be overwhelmed by the cheese because its all about the toppings. 

I'm craving for their pizza right now but too bad they are close on Mondays. =(
author: Carol Y.

description: Always delicious.  Did the smart thing and go there early on Friday to avoid the dinner rush. Was sat immediately and order their special pizza. This one had their house made meatballs and it was outstanding.
author: Dilly M.

description: Best pizza I have ever had. The crust stayed crispy the entire time. Great topping combinations. Easy parking on the street in front of the place. Not from here, but with definitely target this place on my next trip.
author: Stephen M.

description:
Little Star has perfected the art of pizza. 

My friend and I came here for dinner and managed to score a comfortable seat at the bar. The decor is nice even though the bar area is poorly lit. We ordered the deep dish little star and it took about 35minutes to come out (it's faster if you pre-order it, which we didn't do). Totally worth the wait. 

I'm not even exaggerating when I say it was the best deep dish pizza I've ever had. The ingredients were so fresh and complemented each other perfectly. The crust was to die for. If I had my way I'd eat deep dish pizza from here every day.
author: Idk A.

description: best goddamn pizza ever. seriously. coast to coast, new york to chi town to sf, best pizza of all time. I prefer the deep, my lady the thin, either way its amazing,
author: Jonny M.

description: It has nice casual ambience and friendly hospitality. But more than that food was good, after all that is what you go to restaurant for. We tried spicy chicken wings and pesto chicken pizza, both were great. Definitely coming again.
author: Manveer C.

description: We tried the Little Star deep dish pizza at Little star, and it was pretty rad. The place was pretty full, but the wait did not take long. The crust was buttery, and the cheese to tomato sauce ratio seemed just right.
author: George L.

description:
A must if you want some deep dish pizza! 

I've eaten at Dino's and Giordano's in Chicago because it's suppose to be "famous" Chicago pizza where deep dish comes from. Hands down, Little Star is better!

It's a bit pricey, but well worth it. The ambiance is great...kind of intimate since they dim the lights. Be aware that they pass the Health Tax to your bill, so it might be an extra buck or two.

I always recommend this place when I have out of town friends over.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
This is my favorite pizza spot in SF! Went here with the Mr. and we enjoyed the delicious garlic bread, a Caprese Salad (the cheese, tomatoes and basil were AMAZING with that balsamic), and Mediterranean Chicken Deep Dish Pizza.  
Usually with a pizza I feel the ingredients are not in balance with each other, this was not the case at Little Star.  Even the Fetta did not offend and was delicious atop the pizza! 

This place has a great atmosphere, nice lighting, and good beer to accompany the cheesy morsel of your choice! 

We will be returning to Little Star!
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Great pizza. Decent service. Quite a wait. Good for dinner. Like most deep dish places, the pie will take a while. It's worth it though.
author: Grey Z.

description:
I was passing through town and met up with a friend here. Since she's the local, I let her order.  When she said "deep dish" (Little Star) I made a face.  I hate deep dish but I didn't want to be impolite. 

This place changed my mind.  That cornmeal crust is a whole new level. 

Super casual atmosphere, which got more and more crowded as we finished our meal. I'd love to try their thin crust next time I'm in town but this place definitely made me see the more delicious side of deep dish.
author: Desiree Q.

description:
Little Star Pizza holds a big, special place in my heart.
