Let's get one thing out of the way first.  The pizza crust tastes like cornbread, and it's amazing.  Now imagine throwing in a deep dish of ingredients and cooking the combination to perfection.  Awesome.

The interior was a little bit ominous and gloomy looking, but some would probably see it as romantic.  I called in for a pickup, and they gave me a very narrow time estimate (thirty minutes on the dot), and when I got there in thirty-one minutes, voila, there sat my pizza, waiting to be taken, and eaten.

Service there is really nice and friendly, and I would definitely hit up Little Star Pizza to sit down and enjoy the food and atmosphere.

I got the Little Star, which comes packed with spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic, all topped with a generous helping of tomato sauce slathered on top.  For a pizza with this many ingredients, you'd be paying the same price at a Pizza Hut or Papa John's, but for lower quality.  The pizza itself was great.  I think the feta was a little bit overpowering, as it tends to be, but overall, a great title pizza.

I recommend letting the pizza rest a little bit before you dive in.  I know, it's difficult because it smells so freaking good.  But if you eat it immediately, the slice gets difficult to manage from all the melting ingredients and still-flexible bottom crust.  When you let it rest, the bottom crust hardens a little bit, and all the toppings don't come avalanching down when you pick up a slice.

In summary, Little Star Pizza shines brightly in a city inundated by a sea of pizza joints.

GET:  Any Deep Dish Specialty Pizza
author: Michael K.

description:
SOOOOOOOOOOOO YUMMMMMMY!!!!!!

Worth the wait.  Worth the money.  Worth the extra weight you might put on.

Be ready for the food coma that comes after....
author: Jackie J.

description:
Little Star Pizza's "Classic" Deep Dish Pizza was indeed a classic. If you like that cornish-crust on a deep dish pie, this is it.  What else can I write after 1,200 reviews except that you are an idiot if you live in SF or visit the city and have never been here.  It's okay, I have been an idiot until last Saturday.

I plan on going back later for their wings.
author: Dave K.

description:
I'll be real - Chicagoans know this is not real deep dish pizza. The Bay has yet to figure out how to make actual deep dish like Lou Malnati's or Giordano's. 

But putting the obvious aside, the pizza is good. Sauce was on point and ingredients seemed fresh. The crust is tasty and has that slight buttery(ish) taste traditional deep dish pizza crusts provide.

It's probably the best "deep dish style" pizza I have had in the Bay, but still makes me miss the traditional deep dish pizza back home. I'm not rushing to return, but I'll go back if I'm ever craving good pizza.
author: Sara D.

description:
Having returned after a year working out of Chicago, I was starting to have deep dish withdrawal but didn't want to go all the way to east bay for Zachary's -- so happy to have found Little Star!  

Given the limited space, the wait was about 30 minutes on a Sunday night.  Luckily there's a bar with cheap beers ($2 PBRs!) so you can drink while you wait -- still, I just about died watching all waiters walk by with the fresh pies.

IMHO -- it's better than Zachary's.  Ingredients are super fresh and the price is a few dollars cheaper.  The small deep dish is definitely enough to feed two people.  If I could improve the pizza -- it'd be to have fresh tomatoes (instead of the paste) and less cheese.  Personal preference though!

Love for Little Star!
author: Kendra W.

description: This pizza was amazing. It came out quickly and we ordered a small and large thin crust. We started with the pesto chicken which comes in 6 slices so everyone in the group had a slice. We ordered some garlic bread to share that hit the spot while we were waiting for another member of our party to show. Then we opted for the special pizza of the night. I am so glad everyone went for it. The crust was amazing. Thin and crispy. I love anything with butternut squash and let's add sausage and onions to the mix. Do not hesitate to get it. 5 people we all left full after a small and large thin crust pizza, and an appetizer. Next time we will go for the Chicago style pizzas.
author: Kristin M.

description:
I'm petitioning a change in the title of the classic nursery rhyme "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star" in honor of my rating of Little Star's pizza to "Twinkle, Twinkle, Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star."

The deep dish pizza is certainly good and is very filling. The cornmeal crust is very thick and doughy though I usually prefer my deep dish crusts a little more on the buttery side regardless of how much more unhealthy that makes it. The ingredients and cheeses in the Classic and Little Star that we ordered were definitely quality, making for some tasty pizza.

If you are interested in a starter try the caprese salad. The thick slices of fresh mozzarella in this dish are so good.
author: Erich D.

description:
A slice of Little Star pizza can get me pretty full already. Because it is the city's finest pizza place, my boyfriend said that it was time that I tried it, since he lives fairly close the the restaurant. When we went to pickup our order, it was packed with people in the tables and people waiting for their takeout, it really says something about Little Star's popularity. 

It's just me, but I dislike how it's drenched in marinara sauce; I don't think it needs that much sauce.  It could just be that pizza we ordered that was drenched in it, I don't know.  but other than that, it was still one of the best pizza I've ever had. Very impressive, I wouldn't mind going to try out the other pizzas.
author: Harriet W.

description: I'm obviously in the minority here in terms of reviews.  They serve pretty good Chicago Deep Dish Pizza but I didn't think it was as amazing as most people of stated.  The sauce is on the savory side and the topping options are all great.  No problem with the cheese, my problem is with the crust.  The crust itself has a slight amount of flavor but I think the real issue is that it feels a bit airy, if that makes any sense.  It tastes like a pizza hut deep dish crust... which feels cheap.  While it's not at all bad pizza, given the choice I prefer Zackery's for Bay Area Chicago Style pizza.
author: Vincent V.

description:
I've been wanting to eat here since forever and I finally got to last weekend. I heard from the reviews here that this place had a romantic vibe so I brought the wifey with me here for lunch. Maybe it was because it was lunch, and broad daylight, but I didn't really catch that vibe.

We arrived to find the place empty except for one group of people who were already seated. I was surprised because I've heard that the wait time can get very long. We ordered some beers on tap, the spicy  chicken wing appetizer, and the small classic combo+pepperoni.

The chicken wings weren't very memorable, I could probably do without them next time. But I didn't count it against this place because you obviously don't come here to eat chicken wings. The wait for our pizza was roughly 30 min. I was so excited when it arrived because I love Chicago style pizza and I don't get to eat it hardly enough.

The small was perfect for us, about 6 slices, and we split it right down the middle. All the ingredients in this pizza married well for a symphony of tastes and textures. The flavor of the meats were robust but not muted by a red sauce that was overbearing and dense. The red sauce, although at first glace looked heavy, was actually really light and had a hint of sweetness to it. Simply delicious. You can tell too that they use only fresh, quality mozzarella simply by the way it melts away and gets super stringy. 

And lastly the wonderful, buttery, cornmeal crust. Now let me tell you something about me. I'm the kind of person that hates crust. I don't eat the crust on my sliced bread and I hardly ever eat the crust on my pizzas as well. But lemme tell you, the crust on this pizza was so flaky and buttery, I could eat a whole damn pizza of just that crust. It's that delicious! Now I never been to the other Bay Area's claim to fame Chicago pizza joint in Berkeley, Zachary's, but until I can judge firsthand myself and determine otherwise, Little Star pizza rules the roost when it comes to Chicago style pizza. Well most definitely be back!
author: Derrek O.

description:
With 1k+ reviews, I don't really need to say much here, but it might help my network of friends if they're in the SF area. 

DK brought me to Little Star Pizza during a recent trip to SF. We got there around 7 on a Saturday night and ordered some root beers to get us through the 20-minute wait. We sat at a high top right next to the bar. Don't expect roominess and comfort here, unless you're at the room, which is apparently offers the most elbow room out of the entire place. 

We placed an order for a half Classic (sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells) and half Mediterranean Chicken (Chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bells, green olives, onions, feta). We had ordered a couple of root beers and it was perfect. The Classic was way better than the Chicken, so I'd go with that next time. The pizza came out to about $21 with tax. The crust was good, but greasier than Zachary's, and we had to wait entirely too long (it was like 25 minutes) for a small pizza and like no appetizers. We both were comfortably full, and had two slices left between us. And it was entirely way too noisy in there for a conversation. I was pretty much yelling the whole time. So it's good if you're with a bad date and you don't really care what they're yapping about anyway.

TIPS: Don't go with a large group, go early, and sit at the bar or at the high-tops. If you have a group, don't make it bigger than 4, we saw them seat 7 people at a square table for 4. And bring your patience.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
Can't believe I never wrote a review for Little Star before. This is probably one of my most favorite pizza places in all of SF Bay Area. 

Deep dish pizza (5+++) - such tasty sauce generously lathered on top of an incredibly tasty thick crust frosted with corn meal for the perfect crunch and texture. All the ingredients taste very fresh. A large was $19+ and you get so much more food than the $20 you spend at other places for a wimpy lil pizza.

If you plan to take out, call ahead of time (can take 30-40 min). Parking is hard around here so hopefully you can double park and run in and out. 

Bottom line: AWESOME deep dish pizza. Still not quite real Chicago deep dish (less cheese and ingredients on top) but for what it is, incredible. Don't forget, cash only.
author: Jim C.

description: I'll wait for you, Pizza, in good health and in bad.  I'm not a pizza fan--GUILTY!  but my Chicagoan friends are, and this is the closest we can get to deep dish pizza (minus BJ's).  Although they expressed the differences, this is still San Francisco, so let it be known that we gots our own deep dish now.  Little Star doesn't take reservations, and is not an ideal place for parties larger than 6.  Most tables fit 4, but bigger party = more varieties of pizza, right?  That was my mentality coming into this.  With a party of 8, we ordered 3 pizza's: the classic, the pesto chicken thin crust which we made into a deep dish, a thin crust vegetarian piece w/ feta, and chicken wings!  All of it was good, unless the hour just made me hungry.  I typically don't like the crust of pizza, but I think the crust on this deep dish is the best part!  Crunch Crunch.  One restroom to share among all.  Well-composed service.  Pizza can get messy when not handled right.  Wear something you don't mind getting dirty :)
author: Janet T.

description:
I'm from Chicago.  I dislike deep-dish pizza. 

However, this deep dish pizza is different.  It's of a different caliber and style.  We ordered the Classic Deep Dish (with sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells).  The tomato sauce on it was plentiful, but light at the same time - chunky and fresh, it didn't taste heavily processed and heavy, as other places tend to make their pizzas.  The sausage also seemed fresh with fennel and a tinge of spice.  Damn, it was good.  

My friends knew about my aversion to deep dish pizza, and also ordered a Pesto Chicken Thin Crust pizza for me.  Ironically/sadly, I didn't enjoy this as much as I enjoyed the Classic Deep Dish.  This is a dry pizza comparatively, and I wished that there could have been some tomato sauce on this.

We started the meal with the Garlic Bread:  warm sourdough served with butter (blended with perhaps sour cream?) AND the best part.....  a bulb 
of roasted garlic.  I was trying to dig every last bit of garlicy goodness from the bulb, layering it on heavy on the bread, and on my pizza crust.  Yep... I feel pretty ok about sweating out garlic from my pores for the next few days.

Hurray Little Star!  There always seems to be a wait for this restaurant, which is why I haven't tried it sooner.  Get here early!  (There were a few empty tables when I was here at ~6:30pm on a Friday.)
author: Jeanne L.

description: Being from Chicago, I admit I'm a bit picky when it comes to deep dish pizza, and I understand that any deep dish just can't be compared to that of the type in Chicago.  That said, Little Star was pretty darn good.  My roommate and I ordered a large pie for take out on a Saturday night.  The toppings were all fresh, and there was that great tomato-y goodness one expects from this style of pizza.  The only disappointment was the crust - it was a bit dry and crumbly.  Overall, I was quite pleased with Little Star, and definitely will head to them when looking for a taste of home.
author: Chelsea A.

description: Finally got to check this branch out. We got a split thin crust meat lovers/special (bacon, heirloom tomatoes, cotija cheese, and poblano peppers). And a pint of Arrogant Bastard. This must be where pizza goes to the angels.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Ok, now I know I may be the last person in the Bay Area to "discover" Little Star, but I still feel compelled to write this review.

I lived in Chicago for 5+ years and thought I knew everything about deep dish.  I tried Uno, Due, Giordanos, Lou Malnati's, Gino's East, and dozens of Chicago imitators.  I didn't like deep dish the first time I had it.  It was too much like pie, not enough like pizza in its floppy, cheesy deliciousness.  Despite countless years of eating deep dish, I never liked it any better.  

Until Little Star!  I've eaten there twice and been so impressed!  The Little Star pizza is fantastic.  It's the classic spinach, mushroom, onion deep dish.  The crust has a delicious cornmeal crust, is slightly chewy inside, and not overly buttery.  The toppings make the difference - everything is super fresh.  The tomatoes in the sauce were particularly sweet, flavorful, and tart.    

Yum!
author: Pearl L.

description:
This place is pretty good. I prefer deep dish pizza over thin crust because it's so darn good, so I gave this place a try because I've heard so much about their pizzas. We got their garlic bread and little star deep dish pizza with added chicken.

Garlic bread: do it yourself style meaning that they give you a small loaf of sourdough bread, roasted garlic bulbs, and soft warm butter. I like my garlic bread already smoothered in that stuff, but it was interesting making it myself. I found it tasting good.
Little star deep dish + chicken: thick, juicey, and tastey. The crust is cornbready, which is interesting in a good way (you can taste it more in the leftovers). Pretty good for deep dish pizza.

The service wasn't that great, they didn't check in on us as often as I like. We ran out of water and napkins; it took forever to get some more napkins and we never got more water. The atmosphere is dark, I guess to be intimate, but it is so loud. It's kind of small inside, too. The prices were more expensive than I thought they would be. There was no wait when we arrived, which was good because I was hungry :).  Look at the ratings/reviews...give it a try!
author: Monica M.

description:
I visited Little Star Pizza for the first time last Thursday (1/19/12) at around 9:30pm (30 minutes before closing time). I called  them around 9:20pm to see if it's still ok to come since they are closing in less than an hour. The guy on the phone said that's fine and to head over. 

I was very excited to eat here since I've read the reviews and everyone is raving about it. When my boyfriend and I got the restaurant it wasn't what I expected. The ambiance was very chic. It was dimly lit with some heavy black curtains by the windows. There were some art on the walls for sale and I thought that was pretty cool. The host tells me there's a 10-15 minute wait and I said that's fine as long as we will still get served. The place was packed by the way; I got even more excited.

Then everything after we got seated went downhill. After the host showed us to our table he didn't give us any menus or asked if we wanted to start with anything to drink or even said "your server will be right wit you." I guess I'm just anal since I studied hospitality management. After 5-7 minutes with no menu or water, I finally flagged someone down and asked for the menu. I tried to ask for water, but the guy did the raise-one-finger motion; which I really didn't like. It took a couple more minutes for our menu and five more minutes after that to get our waters.

Our server finally came and asked us if we were ready to order since the kitchen will be closing. In my head I'm like we've been sitting here for almost 20 minutes and no one stopped and asked us if we were ready to order. On the other hand, the food was great. We had the classic deep dish which is a cornmeal deep dish crust filled with sausage, onions, green peppers, and mushrooms. It was DELISH. I had Patxi's before and I would prefer Little Star's pizza over theirs. I think it has a good crust to sauce to cheese to toppings ratio. I would definitely buy pizza here again, maybe for pick-up. But the attitude and service we got during my first ever visit was a fail. Maybe after a few months I'll go again, maybe sometime during the day when they're not in a rush to go home.
author: Danna D.

description:
Me and some friend were roaming around SF yesterday and were hungry for a good pizza, I heard about Little Star from yelp and decided to check it out. 

You walk in and you get hit by the great intoxicating smell of cooking pizza!! Loved it!! We were seated promply and ordered a deep dish pizza. Loved the pizza for the price, it was hot and thick.. how pizza should be!

The only things I didnt like was that the place was so dark!! We had to turn on our cell phone lights to see the menu. Also the pizza was great for the price, wasnt crazy amazing but def a good solid pizza.
author: Brandon H.

description:
Plan A: Tried the Thin Crust Pizza, it's Legen.. wait for it ...Legen-Damnit..why did I order that?! 

Plab B: Tried the Deep Dish, it was - wait for it ..what's the word? LEGENDARY.
author: Stephanie M.

description: There is no best pizza..it's a very personal opinion and mine is that the thin crust here is the best I've ever hard. Deep Dish here is better than anything I've had in Chicago. Bottom line - you cant go wrong.
author: Kaushick N.

description:
Best pizza I've ever had! How do they do it? Ok, I have to admit; I was under the influence of a drug that greatly heightens my sense of taste during the consumption of their pizza but I feel like my mind would have still been blown had I been completely sober. The last bite tasted just as good as the first. I want more. Now.

My only complaint is that my friend payed money to hear some songs on the jukebox and it was inaudible. You could hear faint whispers of the music every now and then. If the speakers are turned down that low, they should at least temporarily disable the jukebox to prevent this from happening. Service was also average.

With that said, the taste of the pizza overpowered any thoughts of rating this place 4/5.
author: Tony P.

description: Had the Original deep dish pizza. Awesome I'm a pizza snob and this place turned my nose up. Fresh ingredients and great crust and sause.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Keefe M.

description: had the 9" little star pizza. Best deep dish I've ever had
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I love Little Star! Their deep dish pizza is my favorite in the city and a major plus is that they're super close to my place. Reminds me of my favorite pizza place, Lefty's, back home in San Diego. Their cornmeal crust is probably the best part, but the insides are mighty delicious too. I usually get basil and sausage on my pie.

My advise is to expect to wait about an hour for a table on the weekend. Go and put your name on that list before you're hungry, grab a drink or two from one of the many local bars, then mosey on back when you've got the bunchies (buzzed munchies). By then, your table will be almost ready and you can pre-order your pizza so it's just about ready when you sit down. Last time I went, my pizza beat my salad appetizer to the table! 

Atmosphere is busy and noisy, but not so noisy that I can't hear my boyfriend talk to me from across the table. I mean, there's the occasional squealy high-pitched voiced girl nearby, but that's no one's fault except her parents. 

The staff is awesome and are great at handling their high volume of customers while still being really attentive and nice. Pleasant experience all around.
author: A Mandolin D.

description:
I love pizza and I decided...let me see what has the most and highest reviews on Yelp and give them a try. This led me to Little Star. I was a bit hesitant because I tried Zachary's in Berkeley and honestly it did not blow me away but it was okay. 

Came here for my birthday and it was DELICIOUS! Deep dish takes a bit but my wife and I just enjoyed each other's company. We decided to order some wings to eat something while we wait and the wings WERE DELICIOUS TOO!

The pizza was AMAZING! It taste SOOOOOOOOOO good! I will come back without a doubt. I already began telling my family and friends about this place.
author: Justin W.

description: I always go deep dish and get the garlic bread. The garlic bread comes out quickly while the deep dish cooks. They are both amazing. I've been to Chicago and this deep dish is as good or better than most pies I had there.
author: Logan T.

description: I do NOT like deep dish pizza...but this...this is AMAZING.  We ate at many places in SF and this was one of our favorite places.  It is in the running for the best pizza I have ever eaten. The toppings are fresh and the cornmeal crust is simply amazing. It is a loud, busy atmosphere, so not for those looking for intimate dining.
author: Jocelyn A.

description:
My boyfriend and I were looking for a place to grab dinner in the city.  After looking on Yelp and seeing this place serves Deep Dish Pizza (similar to Chicago style), we decided we had to try!  Great little restaurant, which we happened to get there at perfect timing before the crowd started rolling in (5pm).  We ordered a Pepperoni Dish Dish.  Takes 30 minutes to make-- but that is typical and expected for this type of meal.  Service was great.  Has a juke box to listen to some music. Meal was great, however nothing to compare to Chicago.  The crust was almost like a Fried Cornmeal.  However, for a deep dish pizza on this side of the coast, it's great to get your fix.  I saw a few people order the salad and garlic bread near by and that looked great too.

Would recommend to go in if in area, just not something I would go to over and over again (if that even makes sense)?
author: Sara S.

description: My rating's more like 3.5, but I'll round up because I think I'm only so-so on Chicago-style pizza in the first place, and it would be dumb to hold that against them. I had the the little star. It was good. I can't yet muster a stronger endorsement beyond that.
author: Tom Z.

description: Former Chicagoans turned Californians, we've been on the lookout for good pizza for four years now.  Finally found this place via yelp, authentic deep dish pizza, amazing desserts, and very friendly staff, especially to our family with 4 kids.  A definite must visit.
author: Siraaj M.

description:
This place is pretty dang tasty.  My husband is from Chicago, and I make homemade pizza just about every week.  So it's safe to say, we know good pizza.  

We really like their deep dish.  It is so incredibly flavorful.  The sauce is on point -- the right amount of salt and sweetness, and full of chunky tomatoes.  Their veggies are fresh and delicious.  Their sausage and pepperoni will make you wonder why you ever considered being vegetarian.  Their crust is crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, made with a yummy cornmeal flour.  It's not at all greasy.  

We aren't a big fan of their thin crust, however.  It was ok, but not memorable.  I make a mean thin crust at home, so the standard is high for us.

Their mixed salad is really good, if you're into rabbit food.  The vegetables are so fresh, full of perfectly ripe tomatoes and other goodies.

If you're into deep dish pizza, give this place a shot... it's delicious!
author: Jade F.

description:
YUM!

went for dinner and had a hey kool-aid cocktail with the brass monkey deep dish pizza. the pizza was tasty especially the sausage. i'll definitely go back! can't say its better than zachary's tho...
author: Lynee L.

description:
Ok I can't believe that no one's written this in their review yet...

Brass Monkey - that funky Monkey
Brass Monkey - junkie
That funky Monkey!

Every single time I saw it on the 7x7 list that song would start repeating itself endlessly in my head until I finally caved in and ordered it at Little Star Pizza. After reading about long waits and such, the bf and I decided to order it to-go and enjoyed it's awesomey goodness from the comforts of home (it held up against the car ride very well). The sausage addition to the veggie version was much appreciated as it added a kick of flavor and spices and although it's been awhile since my last Zachary's experience, I would say that's where Little Star would get a one up.

Note: although the Brass Monkey isn't listed on the online menu it does exist so don't be awkward on the phone...
"Um...this might sound weird but do you have something called the brass monkey?...Oh good! Yeah can I get one of those to-go..."
author: Christina L.

description:
This is the location I go to most often for some delicious Little Star Pizza. However, I would say that this location actually has a harder time getting people seated and through the door. Most often, my group has to wait 1+ hrs just to get seated (during peak hours). However, I would say that waiting for that amount of time is WORTH IT! I would say that you have to start with a plate (or two) of their wings before you start to eat their delicious pizza. Their thin crust is really good but I wouldn't come here for the thin crust. I only come here for the deep dish. I absolutely love the corn meal crust and their sausage. 

The only gripe about this place is that they CHOOSE not to allow refillable fountain drinks. It doesn't cost much to get a soda fountain and maintaining and replenishing it is cost effective. If people want the bottled sodas, then let that be an option but don't deny people the deliciousness that comes with drinking unlimited coke with their pizza.
author: Rylan C.

description: Good deep dish pizza , very tasty and the thin crust is good too. The salads are fantastic and I like that the menu is short and too the point.
author: P C.

description: Tried a small pizza with chicken & pesto - delicious! I love the thin crust, and felt it had just the right amount of everything.
author: Meg M.

description:
I've been to little star a few times, probably because its open late, a few blocks from where i live and its pizza.  Disclaimer, it is a dark and cozy, swankish pizza place.  So don't make the same mistake as me when I went the first time.  Went running with a guy and we were hungry and I thought oh ive been dying to try this pizza place and fast forward...it looked like a blindsided him into a date...and spend almost the whole time apologizing that I had no idea it was such a "date like" place.  

I will say, everytime I have gone I have enjoyed the food.  The garlic bread particularly, because it comes out warm with a side of fresh baked garlic and butter.  The wine list and beer list is actually decent while at the same time consistent with a pizza place.  And the service is always good.  The pizza, both thin and deep dish, were good both times.  Did I love little star any of the time? ...sadly no.  But did I really like it everytime?  yes.  Would I drive to NIOPA from another area for little star? no.  Would I walk the few blocks at 9pm at night with some friends for their garlic bread and a beer...absolutely, everytime.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
I had a small deep dish.  Nice sauce.  Great toppings.  The crust was a little hard, in a corn-meal sort of way, reminiscent of Gino's East in Chicago.

However!  You can't be skimping on the cheese in a Chicago style pizza.  It should be a solid wedge of crust, cheese, toppings, and sauce.  Not a lumpy pile of toppings and sauce in a little cheese.  No matter how good the toppings and sauce are.  

I bet they have great regular pizza though
author: John P.

description:
Looking for a light dinner, my 3 girlfriends and I ordered a thin crust pizza instead of a deep dish (I'm not a tomato sauce fan anyway!). We had the pesto chicken with onions and mushrooms. Just the right amount of cheese, thin crispy crust, and quality ingredients. I've had a deep dish at another location and definitely enjoyed the thin crust a lot more! Definitely in my top 3 for pizza in the bay area. My NY girlfriend even mentioned it was better than the ones she's tried in NY!

Go early because a line will form and you're gonna be kicking yourself later once the smell of the pizza hits your nose!
author: Katrina L.

description: I didn't think there would be a deep dish joint that could top my favorite one in Los Angeles (Masa) but Little Star made it look like a Turtle trying to out beat the competition. Impossible. Little star has now became my favorite place to eat deep dish pizza in CA. I ordered a basic pepperoni deep dish pizza and holy shit did it blow my mind. The sauce. The pepperoni. The crust. PHEW. Although I do wish it was a thick crust like Masa but it was still very good and that would be the only thing I would change. The pizza is small but the taste makes up for it. I also ordered garlic bread which I was hesitant about but I'm glad I did, no regrets because it was the best garlic bread ive ever had. Little star challenged my taste buds and won. Why must you be so far :(
author: Kimberly P.

description:
This place is really worth 4.5 stars but Yelp doesn't have that option. 

The boyfriend and I decided to give this place a try after reading some of the reviews on this page- and we LOVED it! The pizza was awesome and we're both huge fans of deep dish pizza. 

Now, I don't know how many other people who have tried Patxis and Zachary's but Little Star Pizza's deep dish is slightly different. Both Patxi's and Zachary's deep dish pizza crust are a bit softer and chewier in comparison and Little Star Pizza's cheese is much stretchier and more chewy. I'm not trying to say who is better because simply put, it's in a different ball park when it comes to deep dish. It's good in a different way. 

The tomato sauce isn't too much to handle, the toppings are just right, the crust is crunchy and the cheese is chewy- it is GREAT pizza. 

We also tried the spicy wings- they were ok - I wouldn't recommend them especially to anyone. 

The staff were friendly and helpful, the place was clean, and there was no wait because we went on a weekday and it was at 5pm. 

Parking may be a little hard to find and it sucks because most parking around the area is limited to 1 hour max (meter parking) and you have to keep running back to feed the meter.

Overall, it's worth it- I really liked the pizza and would love to go back for more.

Note: Deep dish pizza takes about 30mins to make so just an FYI
author: Kelly Y.

description:
I kept hearing from friends and colleagues that this place has the best chicago-style deep dish pizza. Having lived in the midwest and eaten lots of good Gino's East and Giordano's pies, I'm always up to finding more chicago style pizzas in the bay area. I have tried Zachary's, Patxy's and now Little Star.

I ordered a Classic deep dish pizza at Little Star. It was just not a very good pie and didn't have the authentic heartiness that Chicago pie has. Crust was too dry and seemed overcooked. I like cornmeal crust and this light crust wasn't recognizable as cornmeal. The tomato sauce lacked proper herbs and seasoning and as a result overwhelmed all other toppings with more acidity than a good pizza sauce should have. The flavor of the cheese wasn't there either. A good Chicago pie has flavor depth and heartiness - and this pie lacked both. 

The service veered towards neglectful rather than attentive. Our waiter (though seemed nice at first) didn't say much outside of taking our order and didn't check in with us while we waited for 30-40 minutes for the pie. The two other people who dropped off our pie and check were the same - just dropped things off with not much explanation and disappeared.

I came to this restaurant with high expectations due to all the word-of-mouth recommendations and the good yelp reviews. I really wanted to like Little Star because having more places to go to is always a great thing. Unfortunately, Zachary's in Oakland is much better than Little Star even though Zachary's is not by any means the model of a great Chicago style pizza. I didn't expect the bay area to have a lot of good Chicago style pizzas but it disappointed me to find Little Star to be overhyped and under-delivered. 

If the restaurant is reading this review, I would really hope that they do something about the sauce. Zachary's actually used to have a very fresh style sauce that had quite a bit of acidity and they recently improved their sauce to cut down on the acidity and brings out more flavor. Gino East's pizza in Chicago also has a cornmeal crust and is probably similar to Little Star - if I were this restaurant's owner/chef, I would consider tasting Gino East's pizza (which can be shipped frozen to everywhere now) and see why an authentic Chicago pie has so much flavor and soul.
author: Quynh T.

description: Our favorite pizza place in SF! Super yum pizza at very reasonable prices, It is often very crowded, especially on weekends, so we usually call in our order, so that we can just pick up our pizza to go.
author: Terry M.

description:
I call Chicago home, but I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza.  What does this mean?  Unclear, but I'm a huge fan of the deep dish pizza at Little Star in San Francisco.  It tastes great and very fresh, unlike some of the greasy joints back in Chicago that make you feel like you just ate a bomb.  Is there an equivalent to "meat sweats" for pizza eating? 

Very laid back atmosphere, but take out is a good option so you don't have to wait as long for your pizza!
author: Julie H.

description: My favorite deep dish pizzeria ever.  The salad is a great way to start the meal.  Great selection of beers and wines by the glass.  Never have room for desert but never left unsatisfied.  Stay awesome Little Star!
author: Matt H.

description:
Wow - delish!!  Really wish they would open up a franchise in Toronto. Big fan!!!

My bf and I shared a 9" deep dish.  We couldn't decide on just one of the pizzas, so the waitress told us we could split it between the two we wanted (i.e. half and half)...which is just what we did.  We also didnt believe the 9" would be enuf for the both of us, but it definitely was!  I was struggling to eat my half.
We also ordered the garlic bread to fill the time it took to make our deep dish (30 mins), and that turned out to be carb-overload.  The garlic bread is pretty average, and I wish we had ordered a salad.

Anyway, great place!!
author: Emily D.

description:
Oh Little Star, how I love thee...

My dream leftover lunch is a deep-dish cornbread pizza from Little Star.  Absolutely delightful!  

I typically prefer a thin crust pizza, but that's until I came here and had their deep dish cornbread pizza.  I now see the world in a whole new light and oh how I have been deprived!  

The place has a great ambiance with a nice quality (even though small) selection of wine.  Love the staff.  Love it all.  Minus the wait on most given nights.  If you do have to wait, you can squeeze in for a drink at the bar or head across the street to Mini Bar. 
 Make a night of it and enjoy.
author: Lindy C.

description: You'll never be the same.  This is not your typical Neapolitan thin crust crisp pizza. Which I enjoy immensely. But this is an experience. An undertaking.. No a challenge. When this 10 lb monster comes out hot, bubbling and oozing cheese and olive oil you remember what it is to be a man!
author: Mike D.

description:
Some quick reasons for this place being so popular...

1. The ingredients are very high quality. You can really taste the peppers, onions, and of course plenty of tomato sauce in each bite.

2. The presentation when it arrives is nothing short of spectacular. This piping hot smoldering disk of goodness just automatically puts you into ravenous mode! I mean it's one thing to be hungry and crave something, but to be hungry,crave pizza, and get this type of treat is on a different plane of existence.

3. The crust! Love the cornmeal textured crust. It can stand up to all that moisture from the tomatoes and retain the crunch and flavor without getting soggy. Any chance of creating a sourdough cornmeal crust? I

All things considered, this is an amazing pizza, yet I have a reservation. I'm not sure what IT is, but that little IT is what keeps it short from getting the 5 stars. Call me crazy but just serving a great product is 99% of the battle, but that 1% is very elusive indeed!
author: John K.

description:
One of my favorite Chicago-Style/Deep-dish Pizza places in SF.

The cornbread crust is an interesting and delicious modification.

Highly recommend.
author: Ayall S.

description:
Great pizza, best to eat in house.  You can get it to go but again, it's best hot and fresh in the restaurant.  

The "Little Star" deep dish is the best.  "Vegetarian" and  "Classic" deep dish are good too.

Enjoy...
author: Dave B.

description:
This was hands down the best deep dish pizza I have ever tried, and I'm even places it above Gino's East in Chicago which is a pretty big deal. (I hope I don't get beat up for saying that. Joking, mostly.) 

I went with a few friends for a birthday dinner. We started with the Garlic Bread (amazing) and a mixed green salad (also delicious.) We ordered the Little Star Deep Dish pizza and it was phenomenal. Definitely will be back for more epic pizza. (No other word for it. And I am not really a fan of that word, but it is necessary.)

One star off for service. Hoping it was a fluke!
author: Jane F.

description: Visiting the city for a week, and sister's boyfriend decided to order from here. The deep dish was very hearty and delicious, and the crust held up very well. In fact, you could hold a slice in your hand! The garlic bread was indeed garlicky, which we enjoyed immensely. The pepperoni pizza was typical, buy the crust again was perfect. This place was a great find up the street from our rental on McAllister. Would definitely order again when visiting!
author: Eleanor C.

description: I have to say that I was kind of reminded by this place when I was in Italy. Their food is surely fresh and very delicious, the ambiance, one of a kind and very comforting most of the time.
author: Steve Y.

description:
I came here because the Little Star was on the 7x7 list so that is what I got. My friend and I came here on a Thursday and it can get busy. We also got some garlic bread which was delicious. It is definitely not your normal garlic bread. They give you roasted garlic and also home made butter. Spread that around fresh warm bread and it is freaking amazing.

I loved the crust on the little star. it was buttery, cripsy and moist. Service was good but I think the only thing I don't like about the place is the 1 bathroom for everyone. I guess that's all you have to work with but it's just a bummer. Not a big deal though.
author: edward k.

description: I would fly here from Seattle to have their pizza!!!!  Ask for: Little Star Pizza and a beer... you really can't go wrong!
author: Bradley C.

description:
Great pizza, I had the chicken pesto (thin crust) which I would absolutely go back for again.  The garlic bread was pretty tasty with a sliced open roasted garlic bulb brought out to the table...interesting choice but good.  Sodas were out of a can and served with a compost-able straw.  Negative points for that one.

The wait was extremely long...well over an hour and the place was pretty tiny.  You can't fault a place for being busy but this is just a warning if you're looking for a quick evening meal.  Parking is pretty much impossible in the area.
author: Lauren D.

description: The thin crust italian combo pizza is the best pizza i've ever had! We called in for pick up, during sunday night football. No more deep dish for me,from now on.
author: Pickle R.

description:
5 Stars for their thin crust pizza
4 Stars for their deep dish + 1 because the crust was crispy

My favorite part of eating pizza is biting into a freshly baked piece and pulling the mozzarella cheese away from your face again and again because the cheese is so stringy.  That, and flavorful crust that's crispy and still delicious by the time you reach the end of your slice.  It was kind of like eating a cheesy thin breadstick that you buy in packages.  Loved it!

Little Star totally NAILED my criteria for perfect pizza and raised the bar for pizza crust in my book.  The deep dish was good, but I don't think it beats Zachary's.  To be fair, I ate two pieces of the thin crust before even touching the deep dish, so it was a bit cold and I was already full.  I'm willing to give it another shot later this summer since they have that killer half off pizza deal if you order an appetizer!  

It was also nice that the restaurant itself had very San Franciscan touches.  For example, the bathroom sign was made of SF Muni Transfers from February 2006.  I'm guessing its symbolic, so I thought that was totally awesome.  The cups they use here are actually the cut off bottoms of a wine bottle that's sanded down!!

Our waitress was also really on top of our water in take.  My friends and I drink tons of water, and she never failed  to notice when we emptied our jug.  Definitely coming back for more!
author: Anna T.

description: I had their thin crust pizza delivered to me. Their delivery service they partner with is horrible. They came about 1.5 hour after I placed delivery and the delivery guy didn't have change on him. The pizza costed about $22 and I had $40 on me with two 20s. The guy told me it was his first delivery of the night so he didn't have change. I'm confused, isn't it a part of their job to have change? I considered under paying him with a $20 but felt morally wrong. I let him keep the almost 100% tip. I hope the pizza is good at least, I think to myself. The pizza is fucking tiny like 6" for a $22 pizza (well, technically $40) and it was horribly underwhelming. Never ordering from here again. Epitome of San Francisco overpriced bullshit.
author: M H.

description: 4.5 with over 2k reviews...what the hell can I say that you haven't heard already.  Great pies!
author: Dan S.

description:
I love this pizza. I am picky about pizza and I finally found a favorite. The cornmeal type crust on the deep dish pizza and the flavor is divine! I like that they have
Organic salads and interesting beverages. The atmosphere is modern and the staff are friendly. The garlic bread wasn't the greatest but oh well. I could eat this pizza for breakfast right now. So yummy.
author: Jeannie A.

description: Sweet holy moly!  Excellent pizza.  We had the classic deep dish and the garlic bread and everything was delicious.  Very light fluffy garlic bread with melty cheese and the pizza was maybe the best I've had.  We left so satisfied and full and had leftovers for tomorrow.  Thank you for a great meal.
author: Christopher C.

description: Truly so happy SF opened a Chicago style pizza that may even surpass Zachary's in Oakland!  The cornmeal crust is actually a bit richer than Zachary's, so that is a win in my book, but my family actually marks the pies down for the buttery crust.  The service is not pretentious, but the atmosphere is a bit cramped.  Try it!
author: Dame C.

description: Still like Zachary's better. But they are all the way across the bay.  Cornmeal crust is a nice touch on the deep dish along with the nice guey cheese.  Good selection of beers.  Long wait for the deep dish so you will be upsold a salad which are great.  Eat in or Take out. Good Pizza
author: Jerry W.

description:
De-freaking-licious!

My boyfriend and I have spent every weekend knocking down the SF's 7x7 list and this was one he really wanted to try.

We came around 6 pm and it wasn't crowded at all. We were able to get a seat near the windows next to the curtains. We wanted the 7x7 suggested Little Star pizza and he suggested we added sausage to it since my bf and I are such carnivores. 

The ambiance was very hipster and cool looking. The paintings on the wall were very interesting and fun to look at. 

Finally, the pizza arrived and it looked and tasted SO GOOD. We ordered the large deep dish pizza which was extremely saucey and had plenty of toppings. The bottom layer had greens and cheese and the top was a layer of tomatoes and sausage. BEST PIZZA EVER! I'm normally not a fan of deep dish pizzas but this pizza made me want more!

My bf and I ate 2 slices each and were still able to bring 2 slices back home afterwards and it tasted as good the next day as it did there. I plan to come back soon and order take-out :)
author: Vikki K.

description:
Great service, so we generously tipped the female waiter.
The balsamic salad was very tasty, and a regular size is great between 2-3 to share as an appetizer.  
We just ordered the Little Star Pizza, and it was fabulous!  Oh, the crust!!  

Embarrassing to say, but I haven't eaten a crust as tasty as this since 3 years ago at a Pizza Hut in the Philippines.  It's different there... get their ingredients elsewhere and it is a sit down restaurant with tablecloth and folded cloth napkins with waiters.  Overall...this isn't really a cheap eat, but worth every bite!  Going back for sure!
author: Sierra D.

description:
Little star is a fantastic pizzaria. I love the neighborhood and it's got a lot of great food but little star has to be up in the top 3 or at least in the discussion. I was told to get the deep dish and it didn't disappoint. We were lucky enough to get a table by walking in but we've noticed that this place can get pretty busy so setting up a reservation is probably best. Make sure you also keep in mind that if you go with the deep dish it takes 30 mins for them to prepare it. 

We got a deep dish with garlic, sausage, pepperoni, and moz. Super delicious, great service, and the environment was perfect for a casual dinner or a date. Our pizza came out to $25. Not bad for a meal that's going to feed you for at least 2 sittings. I'll definitely be back! I hope you love it as much as I do.
author: Ken C.

description:
Pretty good pizza.

We ordered the italian combo pizza in a large. We thought the price difference was only about $4 and the large is way bigger than the small, so why not - lunch tomorrow too. I was only able to finish a slice and a half. Those portions are really deceiving! Not only do you have loads of goodies stacked up on top - cheese, pepperoni, salami, onions, cheese, green bells, black olives, pepperoncini, did I mention cheese already? Then you have the actual dough, which is thicker than normal. They make it really crispy at the end, I like that :)

Get the garlic bread. They have an interesting twist on it. Instead of melting the spread on the bread, they give you a melted garlic clove with some bread. You spread it yourself. Pretty yummy.
author: Rosie W.

description: Friendly welcome upon entering this little pizza joint.  Seated at table of our choice.   Ordered salad to start - delicious and enough to split between my husband and me. Within about 30 minutes we had a 9" deep-dish vegetarian pizza on our table.  Flavorful toppings, and crust was light and tasty. Attentive wait staff.  Wasn't rushed through meal.  Great meal!  Great experience!  Will come back when we return to San Francisco!
author: Lisa M.

description: I finally got a chance to eat at Little Star Pizza.  My friend and I split the mixed salad and a small classic pizza.  It was delicious.  I will be back!
author: Christy L.

description: Great little place in San Fran, worth checking out. Deep dish is the best, but a lot of other options!
author: Trenton D.

description:
THE BEST!

i dont even LIKE deep dish man... thin crust all the way.. but hot diggity damn this shit was good. ive been waiting for the longest time to try this place out and it did not disappoint! 

ordered a large deep dish, half little star, half mediterranean chicken and shared it with two others. i didn't care too much for the mediterranean chicken, but the little star was sooo yummy! oh blessed corn meal crust! thank god there wasnt a wait either! best time to go would be weekdays ladies and gents! go get some deep dished goodness!
author: amelia g.

description: This is the place to go for deep dish pizza. Thin crust is good too. Tasty wings & salads. I like the deep dish pizza best. This is not your $2 dollar a slice pizza, this is gourmet pizza that is hard to find. Moderately priced. Service is fast and friendly. Casual dining or Take Out. This is San Francisco, parking is what it is.
author: Ron W.

description:
Pizza makes me happy, especially good pizza with a perfect balance of cheese, spinach, tomatoes, and seasonings on a corn meal crust. Mmmm. I could totally go for more right now. After not enjoying Zachary's I was a bit worried I might not like Little Star either but fortunately I was wrong - I loved it. Saturday evening wait was only about 30min for 2 of us and service was prompt. Small beer/wine/sparkling wine cocktail list but it served its purpose. I left full, tipsy, and feeling good - a perfect relaxing dinner after a hectic work week. 

peace, love, and good booze ~ chase
author: Chase S.

description: I love this place.  The vegetarian pizza is so amazing and I absolutely love the crust.  I give it 4 stars because the food is very heavy -- it's hard to move after eating. Anything that makes you feel like this can't be good for you so I only go once or twice a year.
author: Shala M.

description:
I came here after waiting over an hour for a party of 6 on a Saturday night. I'm convinced that all good things are worth the wait, and everyone seems to pee themselves when it comes to Little Star pizza, so I was determined to see what the fuss was about. So we put our names down and went to Mini Bar across the street to have a few drinks to while away the time.

We came back and within a few minutes, we were seated and ordering pizza. I could talk about the salad and the beer we ordered, but let's cut to the chase. Classic deep dish and Mediterranean chicken deep dish pizzas were ordered. And when they arrived, I almost died. 

I firmly believe that the crust is the heart of the pizza, and if the crust is bad, the pizza isn't really worth eating. I was pretty much blown away. The crust is amazing, and unlike anything I've had anywhere else. It's so crispy and delicious, and I really can't get over it. I ate a bajillion slices and took some home because I was just completely flabbergasted at how good their crust was. 

This place blows Patxi's out of the water. It's even better than Zachary's in Oakland. I wish they weren't so crowded on weekends, but if you have time to kill, it's totally worth the wait.
author: Angeline P.

description: Great deep dish pizzas with awesome cornmeal crust, but the best part is the garlic bread with fresh basil and cheese!
author: Rachel A.

description: Long waits on the weekend, but overall, the pizza is pretty good.  It's not the same deep dish pizza you would get in say Chicago due to it's texture and fillings, etc, but it's a different kind of good.  It's really filling too.  I eat a lot but usually 3 slices will do me in.  They have a small, yet commendable micro brew selection.  I recommend the IPA as it goes well with the pizza.
author: Alex G.

description:
Weird a 4 star review from me.  I know, right!?

The pizza was delicious and while not quite as filling as some of the other reviews indicate it was still filling.  The crust was awesome, the cheese plentiful and gooey, the sauce was just good.

I would skip the 9" pizza even if ordering just for yourself.  I read the other reviews that made each slice sound gargantuan and should have known better.  Typical of most yelp reviewers they were delusional.  The slices are plenty filling, but I ate all but 1 slice of the 9" pizza.  Not leaving me enough to satisfy the next day.

LSP had a decent ambiance but again the delusional here seem to think it is a great date spot.  I would avoid taking a date here, at least not if you haven't been dating a while.  This place is to noisy to have any kind of conversation or to get to know someone without yelling.

The service was pretty good.  They were friendly and didn't mess my order up(something I consider to be a required minimum not worthy of a star), but i called ahead for pick up and was told it would be 30 minutes.  It took just shy of 40.  It wasn't a horrible delay and I was in no rush and would rather get the pizza late and just from the oven than have it only take 20 and be ten minutes old when I show up to pick it up.  That said many of the reviews here indicate that they are busy and they should have been able to anticipate based on how busy the place was when I showed up that it would take more than 30 minutes.

The pizza was not cheap, but was more filling than the usual 'Za and was delicious.  If you are on a budget or just looking for something cheap it's not the place for you.  Not cheap but a decent value for the fillingness and delicousness of the pizza.

If you are the typical yelper you would probably consider this a 5 star place.  Unfortunately I have standards and believe 5 stars actually means something.
author: Max Jonathan S.

description:
I have lived in both Chicago and SF, and Chicago deep dishes only wishes it could be nearly this good. 

The deep dish little star pizza is perfection, sweet salty crumbly crust, not too much cheese, tons of fresh not-wilty spinach, and thick, roasty-sweet tomato sauce.

And you can't really top whole heads of roasted garlic with a butter-olive oil combo for DIY garlic bread. 

Only downside is the wait, if the bar is packed just head over to Mini Bar across the street and wait it out with a beer.
author: Erin K.

description: I love going to Little Star! I love their pizza and their salad is delicious!!!! I got the traditional Little Star pizza and was not disappointed. Our waitress Neikki was fabulous! She was nice and patient while we decided on what to order. She was fun and the atmosphere was great!
author: erica s.

description: I really love this place! I'm not in love with the wait time, but I've never met a glass of in-the-meantime red I didn't like. Pizza is great. Love the deep dish. One is either enough to share, or get for yourself to eat cold the next morning for breakfast. Oh, you don't do that? Me either.
author: Ashley J.

description:
I went to LS about 9 months ago, but it was amazing enough to make it my first review.

My buddy and I had just spent 4 hours in the frigid Ocean Beach water surfing and were absolutely starved.

I know these circumstances probably skewed my senses but I still think I had the best pizza of my life here. Our waitress was really warm and attentive as well.

Good date spot, as long as you just order one pizza for the two (or three? we're in SF) of you.
author: Teiki K.

description:
I've been meaning to write this review for a while.  I grew up in Chicago raised on the way pizza should be made.

A few months back we went to Little Star Pizza to get our craving for some real Chicago style pizza. 

I have to admit I was a little hesitant about any place in Cali attempting to make real deep dish pizza but was quickly assured.  Just like Giradano's in Chicago, Little Star has a wonderful crust filled with gooey cheese goodness.  I felt like there was a little party going on in my mouth.

The only reason I gave it three stars was because of the service. Granted it was a busy night but our drinks never got refilled. And after eating deep dish pizza, thirst is bound to happen.

My boyfriend is moving a few blocks away though next month. I'm sure I'll be back :)
author: Rebecca Y.

description: Can't believe what a great experience! The wait was 20 minutes but we were allowed to order the moment we were seated. Actually even before we were seated, the hostess got our deep dish pizza started and then we ordered everything else the moment we were seated. The salad was out of this world fresh and delish! The pizza was amazing. I love this place and come occasionally but this time was just outstanding!
author: shelley p.

description: We beat the dinner rush and got a table with our two kids. It gets loud fast but the pizza is amazing and the staff is great.
author: Sean O.

description:
First off, huge kudos to all of the staff, from the host who courteously and patiently kept us updated on the substantial waiting list, to the awesome girl at the take-out bar and to Patrick, our waiter.  Based on the plethora of 5-star reviews and the considerable delay for a table, I anticipated nothing less than the "Soup Nazi" treatment from the staff; I was pleasantly surprised.

My buddy and I were wisely advised by the many reviews here, to pre-order the deep-dish pizza in advance, since it takes 35 minutes to prepare.  This was good planning, as we were famished, and luckily we got a table at just around the 30 minute mark; pizza arrived about 10 minutes later.  So we ordered a couple of appetizers to share, including their Spicy Chicken Wings (not to be confused for Buffalo style), and the Caprese salad, the latter of which was the highlight of the menu.  The chicken wings could best be described as gummy, but somewhat tasty; certainly no more appealing than what you can get at Original Buffalo Wings further down Divisadero at Lombard Ave... I think we ate about three of them, and tossed the rest.

But really, it's about the pizza.  If this represents the best that San Francisco has to offer, then by all means avoid the city like the plague when you have a pizza craving.  While the pie was hearty and loaded with all the stuff your cardiologist warned you about, it wasn't worth the indulgence.  Sausage that tasted on the verge of its expiration date, ditto for the pepperoni; a lumpy layer of acidic and metallic-tasting tomato sauce; chicken that was roasted to dry flavorless-ness; and a dry cornmeal crust that reminded me of muffins that were on the clearance rack at Safeway.  I think if we weren't nearly starving by the time  this pie was served, this wreck would have gone back to the kitchen for a re-do.  It was edible in a pinch, but barely so.

Again, thank you to all the staff for being courteous.  We tipped 20%, but it would have been nice if the waiter actually asked or cared about the mediocrity he served, but I think he already knew.  Stick to North Beach; there are a handful of places that can make a reasonably tasty pie, even if its only thin-crust.
author: Brian B.

description:
What an amazing pizzeria!!  While I would give the pizza itself 4 stars, the whole experience that includes the ambiance, setting and staff easily elevate this to a full five star dining experience at an incredibly affordable price!  Yes, 5 stars it is!

We came here as a large group of 8 about 30 minutes before closing and were lucky to be seated almost right away.  They accommodated us readily and with a smile :)

This place is small, cozy and packed tight but you still get a lot of privacy for your group at your table- I never felt that my space was being intruded upon.  Simple menu and a fantastic special for the night!

We ordered (reproduced from their menu)
- Garlic Bread - Warm sourdough served with a blend of butter & extra virgin olive oil and a bulb of roasted garlic
- Large deep dish cheese pizza with pepperoni
- Large Italian Combo - Thin crust, Pepperoni, salami, onions, green bells, black olives, pepperoncini
- Large Special - Thin crust, roasted potatoes, garlic and bunch of other veggies I can't remember

I didn't try the Italian combo but I did try a small piece of the deep dish and it was delicious.  But I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza so my favorite for the night was the special - the vegetables were done perfectly.  

Yes, three large pizzas are a lot of food for 8 people and we had the leftovers to prove it :D

Oh, we also killed a couple of bottles of the Sangiovese which was adequate and quite good to complement the pizza.  $10 corkage if you want to bring your own (I'll remember to do that the next time!!!)

Total bill including tips and gratuity for 8 people was about $150 - heck, that's cheap for such a fun filled evening!!!

As mentioned before the ambiance is quite charming, kind of a rustic/modern fusion.  The staff was outstanding till we left well past closing.  We did end up closing the place but left with satisfied stomachs after a fantastic evening with some amazing friends!

~ 5 stars overall for a great experience with food that was perfect for the occasion.

# 230
author: Badri N.

description:
Best pizza I've ever had and I'm talking specifically about their deep-dish. It is in the "Top 5 things I'll miss about San Francisco" when I someday leave the city. Can't beat that cornmeal crust. And do yourself a favor, add their roasted garlic.

I've had their thin-crust and it's good, but why have that when you can have the deep-dish? Price-point isn't ideal ($18/small for 2 people, $22/large for 3-4 people) but it's worth every penny.

Dine-in or take-out are you options. Cash only but if you forget, they have an ATM that only charges 25 cents.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
The pie is delicious, no doubt about it but an hour and a half wait is kind of ridiculous on top of the parking situation. Monday thru Friday work life is stressful enough. I wouldn't come again during peak time. 

The service is attentive without being intrusive. It's a posh spot to enjoy dinner. 

Here's a tip: call them and leave your name AND have a snack before you leave the house. Check in with the host/hostess and then go across the street or down the block for a drink. They can take your phone number and give you a call when you're 5 minutes from a table. 

5 starts for the pizza. -1 star for the crazy wait
author: Wanster L.

description:
It was just OK. Not a bad Chicago style pizza, but Zachary still rocks!! 
I ordered their classic sausage deep dish for a take out. I had a high expectation as reviews here were raving about this dish. It turned out Pizza didn't have a lot of cheese. The tomato sauce was better than Zachary for sure. 
Overall it's just ok.
author: Hendry C.

description: Sure it can be a bit crowded and slow when busy but the food is so amazing I still give it a 5/5. The deep dish is my favorite. The sauce is put on top of the cheese and the wonderful, pie-like crust. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. Anytime I go back to San Francisco I make it a point to go here. They have unique pizzas but also make the classics.
author: Cori K.

description: When a server says, "Well, we're known for our deep dish pizza...." just believe him.  The deep dish is deep, not doughy, perfectly hot and spiced, savory, and pretty darn perfect.
author: Ellen B.

description:
Im not a big deep dish pizza fan (i dont like it even when i was in Chicago)but this place was pretty good.  Lets get on with the pizza...

The wait was 30 minutes.  So my buddy and i grabbed a beer at the bar.  They were knowledgeble and good with the wines.  Great place to people watch.

Buddy and i got here for deep dish pizza.  The pizza was very good.  The ingredients were aweome.  I swear they have someone picking tomatos in the back while you eat.  The crust... THE CRUST WAS RIDICULOUS!!  Corn meal definitly added a different texture to the pizza.  I had one slice and i was done.  Great value for your money if your coming here since the deep dish is super filling.  

Great place if your a pizza lover!
author: Curtis C.

description: So tasty. Best deep dish pizza, period. The cornmeal crust makes my mouth water. Be patient. The pizza is worth the wait and consistently good.
author: Tolu B.

description: Had some absolutely lovely deep dish pizza here! Food and service were both excellent. Only downside is there's no dedicated parking, so good luck finding nearby street parking on busy weekends. We parked at a nearby parking lot at the Fillmore Center Garage, which is about 0.7 miles away. Also, we had to wait 2 hours for our table, so would highly recommend an early meal to avoid the crowd.
author: Siddharth S.

description: Delicious pizza! I came here on a Saturday night with a small child, and the staff was super accommodating in setting up the table with a high chair, closing the door (it was getting a little chilly), and providing a little cup with water. It's not a huge place but it cozy and comfortable enough. We had the thin crust Italian Combo pizza, the crust is not cracker thin, which is just a rip off, but decent thickness. The toppings were all great, but the black olives are super salty. No biggie, i just picked them off. All in all, good pizza in the city. Definitely want to go back and get the deep dish next time.
author: S N.

description: Excellent deep dish pizza. Started with beer and some wings - they have a nice dry rub and a homemade sauce. Got the classic pizza and really enjoyed it. Was extremely full with leftovers to boot when we left. Service was busy but it was easy to flag anyone down if we needed anything. Our server was solid and knowledgeable. Would definitely go back.
author: Carter F.

description:
Would people be mad at me if I said I've had better? 

I still give it 4 stars b/c well, I AM a fan but I guess I was a tad disappointed. There was so much hype around this place that I thought I was going to be blown away. That's what I get for reading too many Yelp reviews first... :P Yeah yeah, it's all subjective right?? Chicago ruined me.

Anyway, we got half Brass Monkey and half Classic. Loved the cornmeal-ish crust and I was definitely satisfied after two heaping slices. Oh and if you're waiting to be seated, you can actually ask the hostess to take your order ahead of time so when you sit down, you get your pizza fairly quickly. Genius idea for the customer and for the restaurant (more business!).
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
Went there on a Saturday night. Tried to go to the one on Valencia first but after circling the area four times looking for parking we decided to chance it and go to the Divisadero location instead. It turned out to be easier to find parking in the Western Addition (BONUS! We went to Chile Pies for dessert after wards).
Anyway, the food..the pizza was VERY good. We did end up waiting about 30 minutes to get a table. The place is a bit small and cramped which is a bit of a contradiction since the place is lit for intimate dining. I think we started with chicken wings and then got the Classic. Up until then I had only had deep dish pizza at UNO's and Pizz'a Chicago in San Jose. This place was pretty good. Kind of pricy though. A few weeks later I went back to Pizz'a Chicago in SJ and spent about the same amount of money for six people than I did here on two.
author: Jose U.

description:
With close to 2000 reviews as of mid-May 2012, Little Star Pizza probably doesn't need me to chime in, but I'm a Yelper so of course I'll add my 2 cents (although I'll be brief).

Had the white pizza (flat crust) and deep dish with spinach & sausage.  Both were excellent.  Not the best pizza I ever had (that honor goes to a place in New Haven, CT) but very, VERY good pizza and VERY YUMMY.  Highly recommended!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My friends and I were driving around the city aimlessly and I said I wanted pizza. Little Star popped up on our handy dandy Yelp app and we decided to give it a shot.

The lighting in this place is set for like a romantic evening. So if you want to bring a date here, do it. I felt comfortable in its surroundings and we were greeted by some nice workers. The menu was simple. We ordered a deep dish pepperoni and sausage which came to us in about 30 minutes. It was just right. I prefer my pizza to have a sweetness to the crust and it totally did. I was stoked. This place totally hit the spot and the price wasn't that bad for four people. I will definitely come here again!
author: miss b.

description:
WOW! I didn't believe the hype and Zachary's was my default for amazing deep dish pizza, but Little Star oh Little Star. My friend and I came in here after chasing down the release of Pliny the Younger at Mini Bar across the street during beer week. We split a large half little star and half classic and had some racer 5 IPA's to go with it. 

The crust on this pizza is incredible! It's the perfect balance of a crunchy, buttery, cornmeal crust that's flavorful enough to withstand the piles of sauce, cheese and toppings. We originally planned on taking it to go, but we couldn't resist and literally inhaled the entire pizza. If you're looking for a deep dish pizza look no further, and if you have extra let me know I'll gladly help you finish! 

Cheap pints of beer as well and make sure to give it 45 min to bake
author: Mike K.

description: The Classic Deep Dish was amazing. A really great pizza. One gripe, however, is that a Little Star does not provide ranch. We also tried the Little Star Deep Dish but it was not nearly as good as the the Classic. Looking forward to coming here again.
author: Simran R.

description:
Tried so many deep dish pizzas and Little Star is the still the best. I've tried pizza in Chicago and the other famous deep dish in the city, Paxti's.

We got a Little Star Deep Dish with Chicken. It was so eff'n good.  It comes with a cornmeal crust, which is my favorite on deep dish pizzas.  Plus, they got all the proper ingredients at the proper portions. I hate over sauced pizzas, don't you?

Plus, they sell Mothership Beer by the bottle! Nothing gets better than awesome pizza and great beer.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Little Star Pizza is in the upper crust of pizzerias in San Francisco.

The deep dish pizzas feature buttery and crisp yet flaky crusts and a rich amount of sauce that still withholds from overwhelming the other pie components.  Since the pizzas are brought to the table piping hot, copious amounts of Parmesan are well received and melt instantly into the sauce.  The smaller deep dish size can comfortably feed 3.

Little Star's thin crust pizzas stay more than deliciously competitive with their deep dish cousins.  The pesto chicken is consistently rich in flavor, and the crust likewise crisp and enjoyable.  

Little Star pizzas are conservative in its greasiness.  An ideal party size of 4 or 5 can enjoy variety by ordering a small deep dish and a small thin crust, while still minimizing wait time.

Despite having to squint to see the contents of your pizza due to the forced, dim mood lighting, Little Star provides a relaxed and stomach-satisfying experience.
author: Andrew M.

description:
What could be better than having one of Little Star's piping hot large Classic deep dish pizzas? Knowing that, chance are you'll have 1-3 slices left over to take home and enjoy the next day! 

I ate in this past Friday and just today reheated two slices for lunch (well one for me and one for my son Dash). I opted to reheat in the oven, and if you don't have one, invest in a pizza stone. Thank you, Little Star, you're my guiding light.
author: Nish N.

description:
Absolutely the best pizza in town..the classic is awesome,add garlic for some extra flava! Also try the Little Star with ricotta and feta,delicious!! The spicy chicken wings app is also a must try.We always get a large deep dish and a large thin crust because it is so nice to have leftovers the next day.
They don't take reservations,and although the wait may be long,it is totally worth it. Have a drink and play some tunes on the jukebox.
author: Shelley M.

description: We ordered the chicken wings and the little star pizza. The wings were really good and the pizza was good as well.
author: Heather R.

description:
Brass monkey pizza is delicious! It's not on the menu, but it's basically the Little Star with sausages. 

Some say it's better than Zachary's, so I had to see for myself. I think Little Star has a better crust  with its wholesome cornmeal texture and crispiness. But, being a fan of tomato sauce, I have a special place in my heart for Zach's and its generous use of good tomato sauce that fills the pie. 

However, the caprese salad here is really, really good! The friendly service is a win too.
author: Linda L.

description: Unchallenged best deep dish pizza in San Francisco. There are a number of places that    beat Little Star for thin crust, but nobody comes close for deep dish.
author: Michael S.

description: I love Little Star Pizza! I am so lucky their Divisadero shop is right in my hood. The pizza is always fantastic. My favorite is the deep dish Mediterranean chicken pizza. I also love the thin crust White Pie, and their mixed salad is just right. They have friendly, attentive wait staff, and the service is always good. I go to Little Star at least twice a month. Sometimes I get a table with a friend, sometimes I sit at the bar and have a beer, and sometimes I order a pizza to take home. They do get very busy, so be prepared to wait for a table during peak hours. It is definitely worth the wait! YUM.
author: Mimi S.

description:
I've always preferred deep dish over thin crust pizza but I never knew how good it could get until eating here!

We got a half Little Star and half classic pizza.  I liked the Little Star toppings more but what really made the whole pizza stand out was the cornmeal crust.

We called in for takeout and in total we had to wait about 45 minutes (from calling to picking up the pizza).
author: S L.

description:
You must be my Little Star
'cause you shine on me even though you're far
I just think of you and I start to grow
And I need your special pie
And baby, you know...

For my 400th review - count 'em 400 (...and I do get depressed thinking of all the time I could have spent solving world peace) - I decided to review Little Star Pizza because I had never tried it before last evening. Ever since I saw Nish wax on about it on "Check Please! Bay Area", I had been curious what the fuss was all about. But like many who caught sight of the place from the outside, I merely shrugged at the sight of the waiting throngs.

Yesterday was a particularly blustery day, and Little Star was not even our first choice. I had actually been meaning to try the bar burger at NOPA. Even though both places open at 5PM, NOPA doesn't serve food until 6, so alas, that will have to wait for another time. Even at a scant 2 1/2 blocks between establishments, it was like barreling through a wind tunnel on Divisadero, though I was heartened to see that Lilly's Bar-B-Q finally replaced their old Brothers-in-Law sign.

If you wait about ten minutes before 5, you get the privilege of waiting in the little cove of a doorway. One by one, the staff - all very skinny and on bicycles (...I hate them) - give the secret knock and enter the door, as we shiver in the cold wind. Jamie W. and I got dibs on the table next to jukebox. No reason except it provided a bit more light than the ones in the back, and we ended up dodging a bullet when a gaggle of shrieking, South Asian girls galumphed toward the back... apparently to raise the decibel level of the place several inches.

We were hungry, famished really, so we ordered the $8 Spicy Chicken Wings as an appetizer. Unlike those served at honky-tonk bars across this great land of ours, these were blessedly not greasy, and the spiciness provided a great kick even when doused in the cooling blue cheese dressing. I would have licked the ramekin dry had I not realized I was in public. Oh...and I ate the accompanying mini-carrot sticks so I could pretend I had a vegetable.

Given the excessive protein content of our appetizer, we went for the small Little Star Special ($17), a smart choice as it turns out. I refuse to call it Chicago-style pizza since a meal at Giordano's or Gino's East could hardly be more different. First, the crust was a lot lighter and crunchier than a standard-issue deep-dish pizza with a cornmeal flavor and consistency similar to what they served at Nancy's in Chicago.

Second, the filling was a lot fresher-tasting, not the heavy tomato sauce I would normally associate with deep-dish pizza. In fact, the fresh tomatoes used in the sauce moistened the bottom just enough to make the crust that much easier to chew without overwhelming it. The equally fresh spinach had obviously been reduced and then mixed with ricotta, feta and sauteed onions. The combination was ideal, and if a deep-dish pizza could ever taste light, they actually achieve that objective here.

I like the place, even though it was a bit too trendy-dark for my taste. Definitely go as early as you can to avoid the inevitable wait. But if you wait, rest assured, your patience will be rewarded. This is one place where the hype may actually be warranted because...

Pie light, pie bright, first pie I ate tonight
Pie light, [Pie bright!] makes everything all right

FOOD - 5 stars...worthy of the hype, at least as far as the Little Star Special and chicken wings are concerned
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...a bit dark, a bit crowded..but a warmish, welcome vibe all things considered
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...fast and unobtrusive...perhaps to increase turnover but met my needs for a relatively quick meal
TOTAL - 5 stars...Nish is right yet again
author: Ed U.

description:
The thin crust White Pie was delicious. I went with a friend, and honestly, we had been hunting for a good Ethiopian restaurant but everything was closed during the daytime. So we walked... and walked... and walked. Until we came across Little Star. I had heard of it but hadn't ate there before so why not give it a shot? Yes, its no Ethiopian food but we decided it will have to do.
