The place was empty and the young hipster guys working there were in their own world it seemed like for the most part. That was ok. The pizza was yummy and I'd go back again. Reasonable prices. Cool.
author: Payal P.

description: Chicago style pizza and a waitress I couldn't quite read. That sums up my experience. The food here is delicious. I had a chicago style pizza with mozarella on top. I'd check the pictures, the food is as good as it looks.
author: Arish A.

description:
Dinner for four. Large Italian Combo Deep Dish.  Spicy Chicken Wings. Beers. Wine. Done.

Wait was what it was, a wait.  Parking was a challenge but there's a parking garage next door for $10.  One restroom.

It's no Chicago Deep Dish. Zachary's still takes the win in comparison. Still, not bad.
author: Patricia G.

description: I'll start by saying pizza is my favorite food item, it always has and probably always will be! I eat it every chance I can and ive worked in a pizza joint for years and still never got tired of it. Little Star has so far been the best pizza ive ever tried!!! I ordered the hot wings, classic deep dish with pesto on top in addition to the red sauce just for extra flavor and a to go order of a large thin crust half white pie half chicken pesto. Well the wings were ok nothing special but I enjoyed them. As for the deep dish WOW so so good me and my girlfriend over ate and wondered why we got another to go. So I paid my tab after stuffing our faces got my to go pizza and went to the car...well I had no reason to even take another bite but I did! I grabbed a slice of the thin crust white pie and it must have been the best bite of pizza ive ever taken!!! Im blown away by Little Star and i highly recommend you stop by here!
author: Bryce H.

description:
Really nice pizzas.  Huge fan.   Flavorful and fresh.  Friendly service.
I've eaten here twice and got the deep dish pizzas each time and love them (got the Little Star and the Mediterranean)!  I've also gotten the Goddess Salad which is great.
author: jay w.

description:
Awesome pizza. Killer cheescake. I usually judge a place by their desserts - and Little Pizza pulled through for me and - then some. Laid back - but very social atmosphere.  The corner juke box was a nice touch. A gem of a place.

Revisted once again - and had the deep dish pizza instead. Phenomenomal. Tomato sauce - on top of the rest of the pizza. Blew my mind - yet was kind on my wallet.
author: Jessica T.

description: Fun jukebox, friendly service. Order the garlic bread to start and the deep dish!
author: Vicki L.

description: Delicious pizza,super packed, but not worth waiting for an hour though......I like Zachery's deep dish pizza better and Pazzia's thin crispy pizza better.
author: Yoko S.

description: My favorite deep dish pizza in the city.  Absolutely delicious wings as well.
author: Ryan W.

description: Once again amazing! I've been a fan of theirs for years and they never disappoint.  Little Star does deep dish pizza, and they do it well.  I had the classic (sausage, mushrooms, onion and green peppers) with pepperoni added and it was excellent.  Little Star does a cornmeal crust instead of a traditional pizza crust.  It's buttery and crunchy and oh so good. The pizza takes about 30 minutes to cook, but it is well worth the wait!
author: Veronica F.

description:
Well, I'm impressed.  I've been eating at Zachary's for a couple decades now and I had yet to find a pizza in the same league.  After sampling the deep dish Classic (eerily similar ingredients to 'Zachary's Special') last night, however, I'm feeling a little unsure of myself.

For the deep dish, I might actually have liked Little Star better for their clever use of the Zach's-style crunchy cornmeal crust and lighter dose of cheese.  I still like Zach's chunky tomato sauce better than any I've tried, and I actually prefer thin crust over there anyhow.  

In all, Little Star makes a damn fine pie and I look forward to return trips to try thin crust and an assortment of other toppings.
author: Geoff D.

description:
Omg, the computer did something and erased my long long review~!!!!!!! im so angry...ARGH...but its ok, this pizza joint is worth my time to write twice for...

Anyhow, so i was hungry, extremely hungry and we were hankering for some pizza. But not just any pizza..a chicago style pizza~!! So after reading all the wonderful things everyone had to say about Little Star we headed towards there. But since I was not smart enough to read the times of the restaurant, when we got there they were not open yet...OMG~!! -_- 

So after heading towards Japantown for a little while we came back and sure enough 10min after they opened, the place was almost packed. Luckily we got a seat and remember i think it might be best to sit towards the wall or towards the back cause I noticed that if you sit in the center the wind might get to you whenever the door opens.

Anyhow, we started off with the chicken wings, which were not spicy just a bit of mild spice to it. They were a little salty for me but quite tastey. The wings were a good size, not too big so you dont get full but not too small where all you are eating is bone and skin. Furthermore it takes the Pizzas about 30min+ to be done so you might as well order something to chew on if your hungry like a salad or the wings are quite good..I wouldnt suggest the garlic bread cause bread will make you full and you wont be able to enjoy the full extent of your pizza with bread in your tummay~ 

So after a bit of time, the pizzas showed up..and yes I said Pizzas with an S. We ordered the Classic and the Mediterranean. Are we crazy? No....well maybe just a little bit..
The Mediterranean was good, artichokes and olives might offset a bit of flavor for some, and the chicken was grilled. Overall quite yummy~
The Classic is by far my favorite. If you enjoy meat you have to order the Classic..hahaha i ate like 5 pieces overall but i think i could of finished that Classic myself...the crust was nice and crunchy towards the end, the toppings were great especially with all the tomato sauce on top and the cheese, it would just pull forever lol.

Overall, this was a success~ as a matter of fact I am having some of those leftovers right now kakakaka~ yay~ o before i go, they dont accept credit cards so if you come in big groups remember to bring enough cash~
author: phillip w.

description:
I heard great things about this place and decided to check it out on Saturday. Right from when we got the the service was sloppy. We were told we will get table in 5 minutes and it took us 35 minutes to get our table. I understand it's a hipster place but that doesn't mean sloppy service.

The beer list is dismissal. I understand they want to serve local but  We have some amazing beers in California. The Blue paddle pilsner made bud light look gourmet. Ditto for their IPA.

Once seated we ordered the chicken pesto pizza and it came out quickly. The pizza was nothing to write about. We get better pie at Delrosa, Baretta or heck Ragazza down the street.

The saving grace was there Capresse salad. I wouls save money and skip the place
author: Subhash J.

description:
Oh my gosh...where do I even begin? Little Star...nom nom nom.

I have had deep dish before, from Patxi's, and thought it was good, but I wasn't completely wow'd. My boyfriend is from Chicago so he is a huge fan of deep dish and suggested that we get Little Star for dinner. I'm so happy that he did because I'm now a fan! 

For appetizer, we ordered the garlic bread - sourdough, roasted garlic, butter & evoo...yum! Loved how they used sourdough instead of french bread or white bread. For pizza, we ordered the Little Star - spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. The spinach, cheese, and the tomato sauce blended together made for a truly amazing pizza. Delicious!

My only complaint was their delivery system. Even though my boyfriend lives in the 'hood, it was pouring, and we didn't want to walk to pick it up. It was an extra $6 for delivery and they only delivered to certain parts of the area so we ended up going to pick it up anyway. Maybe they should try hiring a driver to handle deliveries?
author: Stephanie C.

description: My go to place when I'm craving Chicago style deep dish pizza!  Their salads are also tasty and my friends dig their buffalo wings.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
My absolute favorite pizza place!

I have been to this location at least half a dozen times and look forward to it every single time.  The last two or three times, I started off with the caprese salad - it's SO good!  Perfect starter for the pizza (the pizza will definitely fill you up).  I have always ordered the deep dish pizzas with varying toppings.  It is VERY filling and the pizza melts in your mouth.  The crust is especially yummy!  Service is always on point, they are helpful and friendly w/o being bothersome.

There is pretty much always a wait on the weekends, understandably.  It has always been a great pizza experience.
author: Sofia G.

description: This took me back to when I was in the east coast and also when Lombard street had UNOs. Had a classic deep dish pizza, and garlic bread. Of course the portions are huge. I wished UNOs was still around so that I can compare them. Overall good. The location was not difficult at all on a sunday lunchtime. However, not sure during any other times since parking in the city is pretty much a crap shoot. I also had Paxti but didnt really stand out to me. The customer service was good enough. No complaints. My only gripe was there was no TVs to watch the 49ers game.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Never. Gets. Old.

Get the Little Star deep dish... I guarantee it will not disappoint. Got there around 6 pm on a Saturday night and it was my first time seeing tables a-plenty. I always appreciate their ginger beer and D got an awesome red wine. Never. EVER. Gets. Old.

I would move to the city to eat this every week without the headache of parking I always face. Lucky locals in the area can get their pizzas bike-delivered to the convenience of their home. :P
author: Hannah C.

description:
For the longest time, I've wanted to try this place.  I kept hearing all these good things, and then I started to worry that my expectations might get built too high.  Fortunately, I was not disappointed!

It was a somewhat rainy night, and my friend and I decided to watch a DVD and grab some takeout.  Since pizza isn't the healthiest of dining options, a salad also found its way into our order.  Although it's not your typical bowl of greens, their Caprese salad was really good - the mozzarella tasted fresh and had some quality to it.  In fact, I've already decided it'll be ordered again next time.

As for their pizza, we ordered their thin crust, half White Pie and half Veggie.  Didn't get a chance to try the Veggie side, but the White Pie was also vegetarian and pretty damn good.  I did find myself missing some hearty meat however, so I may have to look into their Italian Combo or Pesto Chicken next time.  The only problem that I had with our pizza was that the crust was a bit softer than I would have liked for a thin crust.  However, it was probably more of a result from the drive back from the restaurant.  I plan on eating there next time, so I'm sure that won't be a problem again.
author: Mike L.

description:
Awesome deep dish pizza. Very much worth the visit.  
Enjoy.
author: Keith D.

description:
My pizza-loving friend: What happened to the good old days when people went out for a slice of pizza? No one does that anymore! 

Me: I think it's because we're no longer in the 7th grade when that actually sounded like an impressive idea for a date. But we should totally go to Little Star sometime. 

The popularity of this place on Yelp alone hints that it's not exactly the pizza parlor of your idealized pre-pubescent fantasies. Nope, it's expensive, fancypants cornmeal crust pizza, and it's actually really good. Expect the sexy lighting, an interesting selection of wine and draft beer, and all that good stuff Yelpers like. However, be prepared to wait, which isn't half bad with lots of awesome places to get a drink nearby (NOPA, I miss you! And yes, I do call it NOPA).

As the 770th reviewer, I don't have much to add, though I can vouch for the lowest ATM service charge I've ever seen (when I lived in the hood I'd stop here to grab cash before gallivanting up or down Divis) and my defeat in only being able to finish a slice and a half of the deep dish Mediterranean Chicken even when I came here ravenous. Little Star Pizza, big round tummy! The caprese salad here rocks, too.

Worth the hype, whether you're 13 or 31.
author: Kate V.

description: Went to Little Star Pizza after a crazy night  in the City, and let me just tell you, it was the BEST pizza I've ever had! What separates this place is that unlike the stereotypical thought of deep dish pizza being really doughy and hearty, this pizza was really light on the crust (which is great since I never eat the crust) and the filling was so fresh. At first, I thought that I wouldn't get full off of the veggies on top of the pizza, but I was amazed how 2 slices of the regular sized "Little Star" filled me up. We also ordered a small House pizza, the last slice put me over the edge...but even so, I will never forget this pizza experience, because it was just so damn gooood :D
author: Tiffany W.

description: I was referred to this place by a friend while I was shopping in Haight. Walked over here ordered a pizza and some fancy water infused with lemonade oh and some wings. The wings were delicious they were not your regular wings they are hella deep fried. The pizza was scrumptious, the dough and crust were exquisite. The tomato sauce used was fresh, like out of the garden fresh. The ambiance was that of like a first date spot. I wish this spot was open late and had like a dj for some background music, just an idea.
author: Justin A.

description:
Finally had a chance to try this place out for their famous deep dish pizzas.

I saw that the 7x7 List has the Little Star pizza listed...so I looked at the menu and noticed that its all veggies (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic)? What's that? No meat? Hmmmm, gotta switch it up a little.

Asked the waitress if we could add sausage to the Little Star and she said of course. In fact, she mentioned that its not on the menu but this is called the Brass Monkey.

Highly recommended and I would definitely order this dish again. We ordered a large...but one slice was enough for each of us and took the rest home.
author: Lester W.

description:
The deep-dish pizza was really, really good (and I'm from Chicago...a deep dish snob). We did a make-your-own version of sausage, fresh mozzarella, and fresh basil that was the perfect combination of flavors. I also tried the Little Star pizza which I liked, but didn't love.

The crust was really well-done, and I thought it was a good cheese to toppings ratio. Service was fine--a little weird--but food was great!
author: K. D.

description: So after putting in another 18 hour day, my BF and I were *not* interested in cooking - so we rang ahead to Little Star (one of the few pizza places that  has actual anchovies  - Yays!) and our thin crust vegetarian with anchovies was ready and waiting for us when by the time we got there - double yays!  We always pick up a handful of napkins because we *know* we'll eat a slice on the way home! Possibly the *best* pizza in SF.   If there is any better, (a) let me know so I can try it out, and (b) if it is 'better' I'm not optimistic that it would be *magnitudes* better.  The staff and clientele are cool, jukebox is quite decent.
author: Tetyana S.

description:
This is a great place for pizza.

I met a friend here on a Tuesday night around 9pm.  There was a 30 minute wait, which we were happy to spend at the bar.  The tap's good, and they have two dollar PBR cans if that's your thing.  As a nice touch, the hostess came by 10 minutes before our table came up and asked if we wanted to pre-order a deep dish (in anticipation of the cook time).  Points for consideration, I'm all about throughput.

We ordered Little Star's classic deep dish pizza with pepperoni as an extra add.  The crust was cooked to perfection.  The sauce was well-spiced and the meats were distinctive (it's actually really rare that I can tell what I'm eating in a deep-dish).  The pizza was filling.  The two of us couldn't finish a 22", and we're both big guys.

The total tab came to $42, which included pizza plus a round of beers.

My only gripe about the place was the lack of selection among the deep dish pizzas.  If I remember correctly, they offered three varieties with the option to customize.  Okay, I understand that allowing me to customize a pizza gives me incredible flexibility -- but I'm lazy!  Pick a few combos that compose well and put it on the menu!

That's a weak gripe, though -- I'd come back here in a heartbeat.
author: Bill H.

description: ....why there have a great vegetarian Pizza like this in the world ?  i eat 2 times a month when the full moon and no moon day , and noe where could take me out of them on that days , thanks
author: Jonathan N.

description:
For a place staffed by 20-something hipsters with stretched ears and big ironic 80's glasses, they sure make a good pie.

We were STARVING after pig-sitting (don't ask) for out of town friends around the corner.  The pizza smelled good.  Our friends warned us about the hipster staff and clientele.  We were so hungry we didn't care.  If we had not have been so hungry, we would have avoided this place like the plague.  Anyway, the service turned out to be friendly and not in-your-face.  And the deep dish pizza was REALLY good.

I gotta admit, though, I do judge a place by "could I bring my parents here."  No.  I could not.  They would feel extremely out of place at Little Star Pizza. So for that I could not give 5 stars.  If it were JUST about the food, I would have given it 5 stars.  Unfair?  Maybe, but those are my priorities.  What's the point of having such delicious food if you can't share it with the ones you love?  If I lived closer I'd definitely order this pizza to go, like our friends do.

Side note - There is a woman that works there that my fiance says is one of the most unfriendly people to walk the earth.  She comes into  the store he owns and he has tried to engage her in conversation, and she will have none of it.  She wasn't our waitperson, though, so I only mention it because from other reviews that I've read, it sounds like they have a tendency to hire bitchy waitstaff.  That doesn't seem like a good way to draw people in.  Just my two cents.  Our big stretch eared tattoo'ed watier was good at his job and didn't bug us.  So he got a good tip.
author: Zelda K.

description:
Little Star: I love your pizzas but Zacharys is just better!

Here is the one difference you Yelpers need to know. The crust here is flakier and butterier than Zacharys. That is what really separates the two. That is all you need to know to decide where to go for the "best Chicago style pizza" on the West Coast.
author: Mark M.

description:
Been wanting to try this place for a few years now and finally got the opportunity last night.  Ordered a small deep dish with sausage, salami and zuchinni.

Can you say M.S.G?!?!?!?!?  I'm still suffering today and it's been over 12 hours.  Couldn't sleep all night as my heart was beating so fast, couldn't stop drinking water, and finally in the morning had the hugest headache ever.  Not sure what exactly it was that had the M.S.G. but my husband thinks it was in the sausage or the salami.  

Every bite was delish, but the after effect is completely miserable and I will never be eating here again.  I'm sticking with Georgio's for my pizza cravings.
author: Ayrn H.

description: Okay, I'm sold. The thick crust pizza at Little Star made me not only a fan of this place, but also a fan of deep dish in general. Well done pizza man, well done.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Amazing deep fish pizza. Fairly competitive with Zachery's!  Great service with delicious pizza. Have no real complaints.
author: Becky S.

description: My first job out of High School was working at a local Round Table Pizza place. I was exposed to many different styles of pizza making (Dough prep and manufacture, cooking techniques that will yield different taste, and toppings) and random weird stuff we use to make for ourselves. After leaving that job and trying different styles of pizza I know good pizza when I see it. I wanted to try some pizza from this place. The atmosphere is good and the workers are super nice and had good knowledge of pizza. I went with what they recommended as their signature dish. Which was a deep dish pizza I cant remember the name. I personally wouldn't call it a deep dish pizza. I would call it just a normal pizza with its edges rolled up. The bread part of the pizza wasn't thick like a normal deep dish should. The tomato sauce on top was watered down/had too much and took away from the appeal of what little star pizza is all about. This could have been the fact that I went there when they're about to close and got the bottom of the can left over sauce. Is this true deep dish pizza? No! Can it be good pizza? Yes I truly believe that they have a good idea if they make some improvements to the pizza.
author: San F.

description:
Appetizer: Garlic Bread- warm loaf of bread and a garlic bulb. Delicious.

Pizza: the Mediterranean. The cornmeal crust was interesting, but the deep dish pizza just wasn't 'deep' enough, needs more sauce or something. I'll eat it again just nothing special.

It's just that the loaf of bread and garlic bulb stood out in my mind more so than the main dish, should be vice versa. Therefore, nothing too special. 

Maybe I'm biased, but as far as deep dish pizza in the bay, no one else does it like Zachery's (in Berkeley and Albany).
author: Jessica T.

description:
I hate crowds...and I hate waiting...
I called for a lg classic deep dish and an order of wings...
40 mins later I went to pick it up. After double parking infront of the garage next door, I walked in and had to squeeze my way through the crowd waiting for their seats and waiting for their pies. Turned out it was a wait before my order was ready. I went to check on my car and saw a toll truck pull up next to me (trying to enter the garage). I had to move my car into another illegal spot and ran inside. 
Finally..my order was ready...
I can't complain--the pizza and the wings were definitely worth the pain in the ass wait...
but next time I am getting two orders of wings...
author: Mimi T.

description:
On a trip to St Louis a few years ago, we were told to visit "Pi" Pizzaria, rumored to be a favorite of President Obama.  We were enchanted with the idea of a deep dish cornmeal crust pizza-but were shocked upon arriving that this place advertised "San Francisco Style Pizza."
...
We were FROM San Francisco and had no idea what would constitute a San Francisco Style pizza.  Regardless, it was lovely and delicious.



Fast forward to Little Star.  A friend of mine heard our travel story and was delighted to inform us about Little Star.  And seriously? We cannot explain why we've been missing out on this for years. It was AMAZING!

The place was packed when we arrived, but they had one table for two tucked away in a back corner.  We were hesitant-since a busy restaurant and a tucked away table usually means you're often forgotten.  But at Little Star, our every need was met before we even knew we needed it!  The staff was super friendly and attentive, and extremely helpful in explaining the menu

And the food. WOW!  Really fantastic.  We had the garlic bread appetizer-and the bread was fresh, the garlic perfectly roasted, and pretty much it was perfect.  

The pizza was ridiculous.  By far my favorite Bay Area pizza now.  Perfectly balanced with fresh ingredients, sauce to cheese ratio, everything.  We dipped our cornmeal crusts in the housemade bleu cheese dressing-which was divine.

Basically, we've found yet another reason to have us cross the bridge and get our noms on in SF.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Monica B.

description: Six words for Little Star Pizza: Thick or thin crust? Get both.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
BEST CHICKEN WINGS EVER!

Oh and the deep dish pizza is effing amazing. Well seasoned tomatoes, delicious toppings, gooey cheese, and a corn meal crust. Seriously, it's the sh*t! My boyfriend who is an east coast native hates deep dish pizzas BUT loves the ones at Little Star. They also have pretty good service, good beers, champagne cocktails, and these fun water glasses that are made from the bottoms of wine bottles. It can get a little stuffy in here on hot days, parking can be a challenge, and there will more than likely be a wait, but it so worth it!

BTW...this place beats Zachary's...
author: Grace C.

description:
Deep Dish Pizza FTW!
My friends and I ordered the Large Brass Monkey which is essentially just the Little Star Deep dish with sausage. The pizza really hit the spot with my pizza craving that night. It's also oozing with TONS of cheese, which made for an extremely filling pizza. I could only fit TWO slices into my stomach where my other friends could only eat one each. Whatever we couldn't finish made for great leftovers for the next day.

We also ordered an appetizer because we were sooo hungry and the pizza takes at least 30 minutes to cook!! The hostess was kind enough to take our order in advance while we were waiting for a table so that once we sat down, she could put it in and we wouldn't have to wait as long. The appetizer we got was the garlic bread. Do yourself a favor and just skip appetizers - it wasn't that great.

Back to the pizza - I love how the crust was made out of corn meal! That was a nice touch along with the pile of fresh tomatos the pizza was topped with. Overall, super delicious. It's fun hipster joint to sit down and catch up with old friends over a nice deep dish pizza!

Last tidbit - large deep dish was $23, with the sausage, it was an extra $2.50.
author: Julia K.

description:
If you like deep dish pizza covered with marinara sauce you have to try this place out! 

We had to wait for a hour to get a able but you can preorder your pizza so your not waiting for another 45 minutes after you sit down. 

Btw: I read great reviews on the garlic bread and had to try it myself but beware its more like DIY garlic bread! They give you French bread/ butter/ cloves of soft garlic! It was good but next time I think I will just go for a extra slice of pizza!
author: Sangeeta L.

description: Not as good as the reviews show. Paxtis deep dish is 10x better! Ambiance is cool the food is ok. It's more of a 3 1/2 stars
author: Thomas P.

description:
Best deep dish pizza I've had in a while.  Definitely look for their Tuesday / Wednesday happy hour special.  Just order an appetizer and you get 1/2 off your pizza!  We opted for the caprese salad, which I must say was one of the best I've ever experienced.  Beer selection was great.  Only drawback was the wait for the pizza was a bit longer than you'd expect, and service can be a bit inconsistent.

Oh yeah - they're closed Mondays
author: John H.

description:
In search for the best Chicago Style deep dish pizza in California and this one has to be one of the best I have tried so far. My friends were raving about this place so I decided to test it out. We ordered the Little Star to go since the place was packed wall to wall and let me tell you it did not disappoint. The Little Star pizza with spinach and ricotta cheese plus much more was deeee-lish! The crust was just as good which with deep dish pizza is just as important as the toppings. I highly recommend you try it! 
Happy dinning!
author: Victoria H.

description:
The skinny - great pizza, good beer and a long wait.

The fat - The pizza is really tasty. Reminds me a Geno's East in Chicago. Very thick crust with the tomato sauce on top. We had a large Classic and a small Mediterraen. Both were very good. The big surprise of the night was the wings. They were really good. A bit spicy and a bit crusty.

Be prepared to wait. The place is not big and the pizza takes a long time to cook.
author: Christopher T.

description:
Little Star is the best Chicago Style pizzeria in the Bay.  And yes, by that I mean to say that they beat out Zachary's.

I actually had the audacity to order a non-deep dish pizza here one time and lo and behold it was just as good as their deep dish varieties.  They have a couple of veggie pizzas, all of which are good.  They will even make a deep dish half one pizza and half another pizza, good for sharing.

It's worth the wait.
author: Raman S.

description:
Good pizza but not 5 stars because it's not Zachary's!  I think I'm a die-hard fan of their more doughy crust.  

Little Star still had good toppings, tons of tomatoes, but their crust is crunchier.  The Little Star pizza was pretty good.  Their meatball special pizza was good, and they use beef meatballs.
author: Hanna H.

description:
Corn meal crust deep dish. Enough Said!!
Started off with garlic bread. Real oven roasted head of garlic with lightly buttered and toasted loaf of bread. You actually squeeze the softened garlic and pop out a clove and spread it on the bread. It was very good and the garlic wasnt too overpowering. We also ordered the large Little star deep dish. I ordered the big large size because I wanted leftovers. The deep dish pizza comes out exactly 30 minutes after you place your order. Hot, fresh, and delicious.
author: Gordon C.

description:
REVIEW IS FOR TAKEOUT ONLY.

Now the "just okay" 3 stars could be the fact that I waited 30 minutes to actually eat the pizza because of the long drive home.  But it's also because they messed up on one of our pizzas.  They gave us a thin crust instead of a deep dish and I really wanted to try the deep!  The take out counter people were very friendly and the wait for our pizza was only 20 minutes!

Mediterranean Chicken - chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bell peppers, green olives, onions, feta.  Very good!  All ingredients went well together and didn't overpower each other (I was worried about the olives because they were cut bigger than normal, the artichoke hearts which can be tart & the feta which is just strong in general).  I couldn't taste the feta distinctively in any bite so they must incorporate it throughout the sauce.  Overall, a very unique pizza and delight to eat.

Pesto Chicken - pesto, roasted chicken, mushrooms, onions.  This was okay.  The pesto is very lightly distributed on the pizza.  Tasted generic.

Spicy Chicken Wings - pound of wings served with baby carrots and blue cheese dressing.  Chicken wasn't very spicy.  They give you 5 pieces of baby carrots.  Nothing special.

Don't get me wrong.  I definitely want to come back for a dine-in visit and see what the pizza is like... deep dish and FRESH.

**Note: They only take cash but there's an ATM machine instead with a transaction fee of only $.25!!  Amazing.
author: Shannon L.

description:
We visited Little Star before a show at the Independent. The pizza is every bit as good as people say (and I don't even like Chicago pizza that much), and the wait is as long as you've been warned about, haha.

We had the Little Star as our pizza choice and sat at the bar, drinking beer. The bartender was cool and attentive.

Probably good for the waistline that this place isn't anywhere near where we live!!
author: Emily M.

description:
Another night of yummy pizza.  I keep expecting that I'll come in and the pizza will suck because it's been good for so long, but thankfully, that is not the case.  Veggie deep dish and pesto chicken thin crust - I inhaled like THREE pieces of the deep dish and the boyfriend was in love with the pesto chicken, AND the deep dish if we're being honest.
Pricey, but not horrifying so, and the pizza makes it worth it.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
There are a couple of things that bug the shit out of me: extremely dim lighting (where i need one of those credit card sized flashlights on them late night infomercials to read the damn menus), and cash only restaurants. 

UPDATE: they will start accepting VISA/MC starting next month. No news on the lighting, but looks like they are trying to earn that 6th star!

Yes, I'm still giving them 5 stars because the superb quality of their pizzas and customer service ultimately trumps all the bad.

Food:
I've already made multiple visits here and I've not encountered a bad pizza yet. They all tasted really fresh and well seasoned. If you don't know where to start off, here are some recommendations: 

Deep Dish:
-Mediterranean Chicken.. i love artichoke hearts!
-Classic: sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells

Thin Crust:
-Pesto Chicken: i'm drooling
-Italian Combo: not super salty like other italian combo pizza i've had else where.

Service:

Staff is extremely friendly and accommodating. Always a smile on their face and a joke in their pocket, they always make my meal at LSP very enjoyable.

LSP is the best pizza in san francisco! I would return every chance i get!
author: Alex C.

description:
Being a Chicagoan for 20+ years, dare I say it? 
(wait for it)
It's better than most places in the Windy City!
(Gasp!)

Srsly. Their deep dish is so much better than Giordanos and the like because the flavors are well balanced, not overwhelmingly cheesy, tomato-y or over-filled with ingredients. The sauce is AMAZING and the crust stays surprisingly crisp with some give despite the ingredients. 

Plus, don't forget the garlic bread. Places like this are like having a slice of the Midwest on the West Coast.  Plus the Pear Cider is amazing!
author: Marie S.

description:
If I had to pick a last meal, this would be high on the list for consideration. I'm pretty sure I have dreams about this place when it's been a while since my last trip.

The corn meal crust really makes a huge difference. It is perfectly dense but not too thick and has such a wholesome taste. The tomato sauce is drier than most other deep dish places so it doesn't drown out the other ingredients. As someone who lived in Berkeley for a few years, I was originally partial to Zachary's deep dish but am now 100% a Little Star convert. 

I've tried all of the deep dish pizzas here but my favorites are the original Little Star with chicken and the classic pizza with no additional changes. 

There have been times that I take my friends here who have never had deep dish pizza or aren't usually fans of deep dish and they always love it. The service is very friendly and professional even when the place gets packed. The wait can be a while on a Friday or Saturday for dinner but they do their best to accommodate you.
author: RJ C.

description:
I've been to Little Star twice now and and while their pizza is good, it's not as good as all the hype would have you believe.

The first time I went with 3 hungry boys and, at the waiter's, we got a single deep dish pizza -- half Little Star and half Mediterranean Chicken. It wasn't enough food! I was content but the boys could have easily eaten another slice each. The Mediterranean Chicken wasn't all that great, but the Little Star was solid.

The second time I went here was again with 3 hungry boys. This time we got 1 deep dish (Little Star) and 1 thin crust (Classic). And again, the Classic was nothing special but the Little Star was good. We walked away with one - maybe two- extra slices.

Little Star is definitely worth trying, especially if you're a deep dish pizza fan, but know that the place is over hyped!
author: Sydney L.

description:
I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza, but Little Star Pizza was actually pretty good. Nothing spectacular. Chicken wings are better than the pizza.

I wasn't that impressed with service or price either. Mediocre at best.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Good, solid pizza offerings. Nice staff. Awesome (if brief) alcoholic and non- alcoholic drink selection. My group split the Greek and classic thin crust pizzas, and though we all claimed not to be very hungry at the start of the meal, somehow all of the food was gone by the end. We also split an appetizer involving some sort of yummy Japanese pepper and a goat cheese dip -- no complaints about the taste, but I wish there had been a but more dip because it was running a little low by the time we got down to the last peppers on the plate. Easy to get to by Muni, parking doesn't seem difficult. Pricing wasn't too bad -- about $15 each with an appetizer and each person ordering a drink.
author: Monica D.

description:
Hearing that I was going to Little Star, a coworker told me two things:
1) go to the new location on Valencia
2) you must have the chicken wings

Well, skipped number 1, because we went to the one on Divisadero.
There was a wait, as expected, but we ordered a bottle of Zinfandel, and it was terrific.  

I ordered wings as well, while we were waiting.  The wings were not spicy, not crisp, and generally unremarkable, though they improved a bit with the provided white sauce.

We finally got seated and ordered the thin crust special, which arrived with remarkable speed.  It was pretty good.

Unlike Zachary's, which I've roughly described as "not what I consider pizza, but amazing", nothing blew me away at Little Star.

I'll probably give it another shot for their deep dish, and maybe that will bump them up to 4 stars, but for now, I'm sticking with 3.
author: dan s.

description:
Yeah, I got the memo way after the fact.  Finally ate there tonight.  Had the Little Star "deep dish classic."

Best Pizza, ever.  What's even cooler is that there was actually parking less than a block away.  In San Francisco!!!
author: Tony U.

description:
This deep dish cornmeal pizza was scrumptious!  I got the classic (which has sausage, mushroom, some bell peppers, and onions?) and as a Chicagoan, I feel like the deep dish here measured up pretty well, and the cornmeal gave it a nice new flavor that I liked.  The only downside was that the wait was soooooo long, so long that eventually we gave in and decided to get take out and even then we had to wait half an hour longer.  So minus 1 star for that.. next time I'll know to order ahead of time and just pick it up.

Edit: Ok, as long as you know it takes forever, it's not too big of a deal.  I RAVE about this place, and honestly, it's better than any deep dish I've had before soooo there's no way I can't give it 5 stars so I'm changing that.
author: Alice M.

description:
First, the essential. It's good pizza. I like the salads, too.

But someone needs to address the escalating prices at this place. It's now over $30 for a SMALL thin crust pizza and regular salad. I think I can do better than that at a lot of steak houses. This is pizza, for God's sake. Pizza.

And it's not that anyone would pay extra for the ambience. It's dingy, with seating that was not built for comfort.

Sad to say, Little Star has priced itself out for me. I can find decent pizza for half the price.
author: John C.

description:
It's all about take-out.  Call in your pizza and pick it up.  I do like eating here when I can, but the wait is usually too long.  

The best deep dish I have had (though I haven't had a chance to sample the infamous Chicago versions).  The sauce is flavorful, love the crunch the cornmeal adds to the crust, the quality of the ingredients also shine through.  There's also the perfect balance between crust and filling.  I've found deep dish pizza from some places tend to be too doughy and Little Star gets it just right.  

I've only had the deep dish here, so can't comment on the Thin Crust Pizzas.
author: Karen T.

description: The Little Star Deep Dish is delicious. Packed with onions, spinach, garlic, ricotta, feta, and mushrooms. Makes for amazing leftovers too. They have a good music selection.
author: Jordan S.

description:
First Little Star experience - tough for me to accurately weigh in since their famous deep dish is laden with tomatoes and I'm not a huge fan. 

I can definitely see why people enjoy their pizzas. Also, the ambiance is really cool and interesting. Service was also good but you should note, deep dishes take about 30 mins to cook so be prepared for that upon ordering.

Also, we got seating right away at like 6:45pm but within 20 mins, there was a long wait. Keep in mind, the earlier the better, otherwise you may have to hang out for a bit.
author: Rachel R.

description: I went to Little Star last night with my best friend.  I had the Little Star deep dish pizza and added pepperoni.  Probably the BEST pizza I've ever had in the world.  Another thing is they take your order the moment you put your name on the wait list so by the time you sit down it's almost ready.  Very cute bars on the same street to go for a drink while you wait.  Love it.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Wonderful deep dish pizza with a cornmeal crust. We had the signature Little Star Pizza ~ spinach-ricotta-feta blend with mushrooms, garlic and onions topped with a delicious tomato sauce. I enjoyed its flavor and cornmeal texture. 

The mixed green salad was a nice balance to the pizza. 
In addition to deep dish pizzas, Little Star's menu also includes thin crust pizza, a variety of topping options, garlic bread, spicy chicken wings, cheesecake and gelato. 

Locations in San Francisco's Western Addition & Mission Districts, as well as Albany in the East Bay. This place is popular, so expect a wait, but highly recommended.

PS: Even the cold leftovers were good for breakfast the next day.
author: Cathy K.

description:
It can't get much better than this. As a former Chicago foodie for half my life enjoying the well knowns like Lou Malnotii's, Gino's East,  and Uno, this is truly just as good as the Best Chicago has to offer.
Puts rings around the other Bay Area Chicago deep dish wanabees. It's perfect !
john monte
author: John M.

description:
Awesome deep dish - although not traditional deep dish - corn meal crust is awesome

Ice cold RACER 5 on tap

The specials are always great.

Expect a long wait during peak hours!!
author: Walker C.

description:
Zachary's,

I'm sorry.I'm not in love with you anymore. No,  It's not you, it's me. I was so young when we met. What did I know about the world then? I was just a little college freshman, new to the Bay Area...you had me at hello. 

Is it someone else? How could you ask me that at time like this?! ? Yes, I've found someone else. 

What? What's that you say? Is it that guy Patxi's I mentioned last summer? No, it's not him. It's...it's someone else. His name is Little Star. 

What? What do you mean what kind of name is Little Star?!?! 

How many times have I seen him?  I first met him in the Mission.

Where else? Alright, I'll come clean, I saw him in the Western Addition, too.  

How long has this been going on you ask? Since October. Why come clean now? Well, frankly, because I just can't go around behind your back anymore.  I just can't do it. I think...I think I love him.  

Flashback to Wednesday January 2nd: 

I waited for a table for almost an  hour on my birthday and I didn't mind at all. Little Star is always worth the wait. I'd never been to this location, only the one in the Mission and I was not disappointed. On the contrary, the service was excellent. I didn't get our server's name but he was so great! He made sure we got the last deep dish of the night, made good suggestions about what we might be interested in ordering and even managed to be sly about brining out a slice of cheese cake for me without me noticing for my  friends to very cheesily sing me happy birthday. 

We ordered hot wings, Caprese salad, a  deep dish Little Star Pizza with sausage and a thin crust classic  with pepperoni and sausage. I HATE pepperoni on my pizza  (I realize I could be the only person in the world who hates pepperoni) and I am not a fan of the sausage, either, but at Little Star everything is delicious. Exceptional as well was the ginormous pomegranate champagne cocktail I had--it's always great when you can get drinks at the bar while you wait for your table. And, if the drinks are free-flowing because  hey shorty, it's your birfday, even better!  

The leftovers the next day for lunch were like re-living heaven. 

I know Little Star doesn't need anymore reviews, but it's just sooo good, I thought another one singing its praises wouldn't hurt.
author: Dee I.

description:
Ate here last night per the recommendation of the lady. I was mesmerized by the 4.5 stars over 1k+ reviews. Little Star does not disappoint.

Her and I shared a small deep dish with roasted garlic, spinach and tomatoes (a twist on our old favorite from Lamonica's in Westwood). The small is definitely big enough for two people, so don't be tempted by the low marginal cost of upgrading to the large.

The pizza here is like no pizza I've ever had before. The crust is crunchy; it kind of reminded me of a graham cracker. Other Chicago style pizza I've had has way more crust, which in my mind is a waste of space. Little Star wastes no time getting to the good stuff. Their sauce is really tasty, perfectly spiced and perfectly thick. The roasted garlic is a great topping choice, as it adds depth to the overall flavor of the pie. The cheese is tasty and melted perfectly. However, if I could go back, I probably wouldn't get the tomatoes as a topping, because they just put one slice of tomato on top of each slice of pizza; there's much better value to be had with another topping.

Little Star offers one of the best pizza meals I've had in a while. You'll end up paying about $12 to get full, but it's definitely worth it. You'll be pleasantly full after 3 slices (with enough room to share a slice of house-made cheesecake).
author: Geoff L.

description: Super delicious! The thin crust was perfect. Not so thin that it got soggy, or cracker like. Great balance of toppings and flavors. A little pricey, but well worth it.
author: Dana S.

description: They do great pizza. Very customizable. The rest of the food is good too and the service is great.
author: Heather R.

description:
After trying Patxi's there is only one other place that does Deep Dish right...that's Little Star Pizza. It's always hard to compare...but I will for my fellow yelpers.

LITTLE STAR PIZZA  (vs.) PATXI's
                          
Sauce: I would call it a TIE...can't taste too much of a difference...both have a good flavor and chunky to smooth ratio is about the same

Appetizers: Litte Star takes it. Their Garlic Bread is SO GOOD. They oven roast a whole garlic clove, drizzle on some olive oil, and salt and pepper it. One of the things Patxi's lacks is their appetizers...there is none =(

Crust: Here is where it get's interesting...Little Star has a better flavored crust (has more of a garlic bread taste to it, and a little more crunchy). But Patxi's has more of a flaky and butter crust. I prefer Patxi's...but I will leave it up to you to decide.

Sizes of Pizza: Patxi's wins on this with their variety of different pizza sizes. Little Star only has 2 choices. I think Patxi's has 3 or 4.

Price: Patxi's has a slight advantage.

Overall taste: Both do it right; fresh ingredients and all around flavor is on point. Give both a try and see which you like :)
author: Nick C.

description:
Got carry out, 25 minutes even though place wasn't busy, but deep dish takes longer. 

Staff: super nice

Crust: cornmeal adds a nice chewy crunch

Deepdish: very saucy

Looking forward to trying the thin crust next time.

The two of us ordered a small deep dish, half little star and half vegetarian, also had salad and still had leftovers for the next day. 6 deep dish slices were too much for us 2 girls, but maybe someone with a larger appetite could finish it.
author: Faina G.

description: This place is my obsession! We always get the deep dish with spinach, mushrooms, and sausage. My mouth is watering just writing this review! Soooo yummy! Best pizza in SF hands down!
author: Francesca G.

description:
Much to my amazement, Little Star knocked me off of my feet.

Little Star is the grown up version of your garden variety of Pizza restaurants.

Carefully situated in the bustling Western Addition area, this tiny venue boasts having the best deep dish in the bay area, rivaling the much praised Patxi's and the famed Zachary's from across the bay.

Their cornmeal crust is unequivocally amazing. Conscientiously baked to utter perfection, the bottom was delightfully light and unusually crispy despite the denseness of the ample ingredients. The crust was grainy albeit crunchy, ideal for dipping.

The toppings were fresh, hearty and in abundance. Their tomato sauce was subtly sweet with a seductive hint of tanginess.

A solid gem in the bay area and definitely worthy of a visit.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Little Star, Oh Little Star... Oh how I could never live without you Little Star!!

Nothing beats the Little Star at Little Star.  The best pizzas I've ever tasted and I had Italian pizza.  I dream about this pizza.  I love the spinach and the melted cheeses topped with the red sauce.  Ooh so scumptous.  I can't deny that this is hands down the best pizza I've EVER had in all of california and i think it beats out Chicago's deep dish any day.  I love the crust and I cannot wait to savor a piece as I enjoy eat bite of deep dish.  Whew!!! I'm so excited just writing about it.  I love love love it there.  

The romantic atomosphere is so nice even when you're with a your girls.  I felt soo good after savory every bite.
author: Daphne A.

description:
ATTENTION ZACHARY'S PIZZA LOVERS:

Little Star offers insanely good deep dish pizza that is indeed very Zachary's-like...Not exactly identical to Zachary's since they use cornbread for the crust, but I like to think of the pizza here as some sort of fraternal twin to Zach's (if u have no clue what zachary's is all about, feel free to reference my prior review on this legendary east bay institution).

In my opinion, Zach's still has an edge and 1-ups Little Star for 2 key reasons:

#1)  TASTE:  The tomatoes at Zach's has more of a zesty sauteed flavor.

#2)  LOYALTY:  Being a Cal Bear 4 life...it would be total blasphemy to say any pizza can ever beat out Zach's of Bezerkley!

So technically-speaking, Little Star is officially my 2nd favorite pizza around.  However, since I don't live in Berkeley anymore and Little Star is a 5 min drive from my current place...the crystal ball sees a lot more of Little Star Pizza in my future (and in my tummy).
author: Justin L.

description: Went there for lunch in the past, and were not too thrilled by their food.  Went for dinner this time, and we thought it was awesome!  Deep dish vegetarian pizza was great. Ordered large pizza for 3 of us. Waited about 30 mins on a Sat night, but ordered the pizza at arrival so it was ready for us by the time we got a table. You'll love the pizza, try it! The garlic bread, not so much! Lol, they give bread & whole pieces of garlic, so would recommend to skip that.
author: Veeral S.

description:
I've had Chicago Deep Dish pizza in Chicago, and while this doesn't beat it, it sure comes close! And I don't have to fly to Chicago to get some, I can just walk around the corner! 

The ambiance is great, the beer selection is good, and the pizza is to die for. A touch pricey, but once you bite into it you'll forget all about the small inconvenience of paying a little more, because it is so worth it! 

I'd start with the Classic as your first pizza, and then branch out from there. 

Happy eating!
author: Riley B.

description:
came here with the bro and sis. we got the standard cheese pizza, no toppings. definitely the real deal. none of that cracker thin cali style pizza. the magic of a pizza for me is in the cheese. the cheese in this pizza was super thick and substantial. like how its suppose to be. the crust i believe is made from cornbread. the lowest layer of the crust (the part where you can touch on the underbelly of a slice) was slightly hard and crispy. so when you bite, you go through the softness of the sauce, cheese, dough until your met with the crispiness of the bottom layer.

only modification i would make is to add more salt to the cheese. but yeah, this is the best pizza i've had in cali.
author: Ferman H.

description:
Popped by in the afternoon with a group of 9, including kids.  We were seated quickly and attended to wonderfully.  The service was quick and our waitress was wonderful, checking in frequently but not too much.

We started with the garlic bread which one of our group called the best garlic bread she has ever eaten!  Our pizza order was all thin crust (ready in 15 minutes instead of the 30 minutes for the deep dish).  What a great texture.  My husband swore off thin crust years ago because of a poorly done pizza.  Little Star redeemed thin crust for him.

Little star's atmosphere is hip and a little artsy.  It was what we day tourists wanted as we showed off the city to our guests.  It was a good find!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
After seeing that Little Star Pizza had over 1700 Yelp reviews and still maintained over a "four star rating", and since we are fans of Chicago style deep dish pizza, we had to try this place. (Just because I am a Toy Schnauzer and of German descent it does not mean my pilate is limited.)  However, after reading the reviews of our fellow Yelpers we knew better than to try to eat "in" so we ordered takeout of their Classic Deep Dish Pizza in a large size. 

We also realized that parking was tough in the neighborhood, so my Dad drove and my Mom dashed in to pick it up which we took home.  Hmmmh, good! 

My Dad says that it is almost--but not quite--as good as the best deep dish pizza he has had from Chicago.  And that's saying a lot for a pizza place 2500 miles away in San Francisco, We'll definitely be back!
author: Finnegan M.

description:
It's the top deep-dish pizza in the Bay Area. Better than Zachary's. Better than Patxi's. Better than Pizza Chicago.

The cornmeal crust is the highlight, but I also appreciate the thoughtful beers-on-tap selection and the dim mood lighting. Sometimes, you don't want to be seen. The limited menu also features a hearty, fresh salad.

There you go, pizza and salad. It's great for budgets, and you'll leave full with leftovers. Since I can walk here, I'd rather go early or on a weeknight, versus waiting an hour at prime time on a weekend.
author: Randy M.

description:
If the Little Star Pizza from the Little Star is a person, I'll marry it, so I can see it every single day and night! 

Even before I tried Little Star Pizza, I already heard so many good things about it from my friends, thus, I was very eager to take my first bite of its pizza. You know how usually when someone hype up a place for you, it never turns out as good. Well, this wasn't the case for Little Star Pizza. The Little Star at the Little Star Pizza contained spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions and garlic. Perfect! It is exactly how I like my deep dish...spinach, cheese and mushroom! The pizza looked very typical, but it tasted super delicious! The amount of tomato sauce was perfect and it had a little spice in it. It was hot, gooey and surprisingly not messy at all (well, I ordered a small). But other than that, I ate half of the small pizza myself, and it was a lot of delicious goodness. Highly recommend it! 

Also, their cornmeal curst is superb! I never really like pizza crust, especially those on the edge, but I would definitely eat this by itself anytime. No other place tastes like it!
author: Mandy C.

description: Great pizza, great service, and excellent cold draft beer.  They have a nice variety of craft brews on tap and by the bottle.  Wine selection looked good too but I didn't have any.
author: Neal G.

description:
I came here on a suggestion from a friend - his favorite pizza place in San Francisco. And I was thinking... this gotta be good. Really good. 

And I looked around and I saw locals dressed up in this pizza joint and I thought "wait... it gotta be real. Really real."

Then I saw the pizzas on some tables and was surprised they were all deep dished. And they all had sauces on top. Then I thought to myself "maybe there's a variation of deep dish pizza that's uniquely 'San Francisco.'". I looked around making sure there's no Chicagoans, and I spotted none right off the bat. And I sighed some relief. 

I'm a tourist in San Francisco, and I didn't want anything New York or Chicago. I wanted Frisco in my plate.

First came the nice and yummy starter of bread, butter, and roasted garlic. It was better than some similar starters I've had in more expensive restaurants. Then came the pizza, and it was yummy, satisfying, and "full," if that made any sense. I thought of excuses... "the Chicagoan deep dish is deeper... and the dough is so pastry like that I doubt it would be replicated in Chicago...." 

And easily I would have given Little Star high marks for their pizzas.

Now I'm back home, looked up Little Star, and found out that everyone's calling the pizza Chicago-style! Imagine how upset I am... I should have tried San Francisco's sourdough pizzas or something else. Doh! 

Now I know how Homer Simpson feels, but thinking about the Little Star pizzas makes me forgive all else. Thank you, San Francisco.
author: Jordan N.

description:
YUMMO...had a "classic" thin crust last night w/ a slice of cheesecake on the side. Fresh ingredients, pizza crust was amazing. Not oily or greasy. Prices were not bad. 

Lost a star cuz the damn wait for so freaking long. We ordered it togo instead.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I grew up in Chicago eating every kind of deep dish pie and I can tell you none of them had a cornbread crust. Call it a SF twist on the whole Chicago style pizza I guess. Aside from that it's pretty darn tasty. We usually do take out which seems to run just about on their quoted time and just remember...... NO CREDIT CARDS!
 'Aint that a bitch.
author: Drea L.

description:
Mmmmmmmm. I'm officially now not a virgin to Little Star. I've lived here WAY TOO LONG for this having happened last night.

Unfortunately no one but me wanted deep dish so I can't give 5 stars.  I just couldn't justify ordering a whole deep dish just for me! Yet, I will say the thin crust pizzas we tried were awesome! The special was an asparagus, garlic and fontina (so incredibly tasty) and then we got a good old fashioned classic with pepperoni and veggies. Also good (but not great like the special).

What really stood out to me was the service: for a very bustling Saturday night, our server handled everything with grace and a continuous smile on her face. Love that.

I'll be back!
author: Meredith R.

description:
I love you little star. You take pizza creations to a whole new level. Thin crust, deep dish, appetizers, all amazing.

Caprese salad was delish, wings great! Not super saucy, they use some sort of special seasoning on the wings. 

I will be back, you guys are the best :)
author: B B.

description: Well i dont think they need another 5-star review, but i just cant help myself from writing. I had their classic deep dish pizza and it was fantastic. I didnt expect the crust to be so crunchy and not as heavy as other pizza place. Service was great, the waitresses and the bartender were very nice and accommodating. The cocktails were alright, not as special tho
author: Alan T.

description:
I'm gonna say this was a solid 3.5.  Not enough to warrant a 4, and 3 stars is more favorable to me, but an understatement.

I have had Chicago deep dish pizza many times.  This place definitely comes pretty damn close.  I must say that topping wise, this place is underwhelming and the tomato sauce has too much parmesan.  From a crust point of view, I think it blows Chicago crusts away.  If they work on their toppings a bit, I'll upgrade my vote.

I think I will do a second review for their thin crusts, but I will definitely go again for their deep dish.

The service is exceptional as well.
author: Adrian E.

description:
I've heard so much good stuff about this place I had to try it out. I'm a true pizza lover and I've had pizzas from all over the world. 

So how does Little Star stack up? I wish I could tell you...

I went into Little Star, got a table and looked over their menu. I wanted a thin crust pizza with some various toppings on top. And then the waitress tell me:

"Sorry, we're out of pizza"

I'm sorry, did I walk into the wrong place? This is Little Star Pizza right? WTF, a pizza place that doesn't have any pizza? I was so disappointed, but I decided to try some of their garlic bread, which I've also heard good things about. The waitress again returns and tells me:

"Sorry, we're out of bread"

About this time I'm looking around thinking I'm on some sad joke show or something. 

Me: So you're out of pizza and bread. Can I get a Heffeweisen beer, the one on their menu?

Waitress: Nope we ran out of those too.

Me: So what DO YOU HAVE?

Waitress: Salads.

So I had a salad, a glass of water, and I left.

I'm sorry, but if you run a pizza place shouldn't you have SOMETHING other then salad when people come in at 7pm? If you're that poorly stocked, then close the f--- down and fire your obviously clueless manager.

I know people who have eaten there and who love it, but now Little Star is nothing other then a joke to me. Pfft....
author: Erik B.

description:
Best Chicago deep dish pizza. better than zachary's.
Couldn't stop, had 4 slices.
author: Roger Z.

description:
3.5 stars for me.  I lived in Chicago for five years and became a deep dish pizza snob (thanks to lou mal's, pequods and gino's).  I think Little Star is the best deep dish in SF...which is kind of like being the tallest midget.  
When I need a deep dish fix, it is the place I go.
author: pablo e.

description:
Update II: After cruising around Divisadero Artwalk, my friend and I were starving and gave LSP another shot. This experience was much better. The pizza was as good as I remembered it being in the past and the entire staff was very friendly.

-----------------------

Update: One of the owners of Little Star was kind enough to send me a polite and professional message apologizing for his employees childish and uncalled for behavior and she has been terminated.  For this I'll up the star count

---------------------
Service: 1 star
Food: 3 Stars

If you flip through my reviews I generally stay away from writing nasty passive aggressive shit about a business; especially a small local business and especially because so many of my friends in the service industry loath yelp because of these types of reviews. Anyways, I seriously doubt this one bad review will sway anyone away from eating at this over-rated pizzeria but here we go...

Based on the few times I've ordered pies from here to-go in the past, I've liked their pizza and I would generally recommend LS to people as one of the better pizza joints in SF. Last night however changed my mind and was a completely different story. 

I don't think the beyond-rude-horrible service had anything to do with swaying my taste buds, but the pizza just tasted below average at best if not kinda funky. I hope the rude waitress didn't spit in it.

The do-it-yourself garlic bread wasn't my cup of tea and again, the service was beyond excusable. I have no idea why we felt obligated to tip our rude waitress? This was the first time in my life I've ever decided to tip under 20%. My friends and I ALWAYS tip at least 20% or higher. I'm sure her jaw dropped when she saw any tip at all on the table after her beyond horrible display of service.

I on the other hand was super polite and friendly to the staff, kept my iPhone in my pocket and politely ordered without asking any annoying or obnoxious questions besides *POLITELY* asking them to please place the sausage so it stays on my half of the pizza because my friend is a vegetarian. I don't consider this to be a strange request in a city full of vegetarians and I'm sure I'm not the fist or last person to make this very simple request. 

The waitress on the other hand completely ignored us in every step of the process. I'm amazed she even took our order. I dropped my napkin and after politely asking her twice to grab me another napkin when she had a moment, I finally walked up to the counter with greasy hands and grabbed a few myself. When the bitchy waitress saw me walking back to the table with a handful of napkins, she didn't even give a flying fuck nor did she apologize for her lack of service. Besides taking our order, almost slamming me in the face with the pizza lifter thingy while placing it on the table and giving us the check which I had to flail and wave my arms to get, she didn't do jack shit. With so many people looking of work now-a-days, I'm surprised they would keep an employee like this?

Ok, I changed my mind, this IS a passive aggressive review and I probably should have told her on the spot, what a horrible childish bitch of a server she was and NOT tip her 15% for the crap service we received but it really didn't sink in till after I got home and started thinking about all of the rude things she did. Hopefully that $6 can buy her tampons.

Fuck you and fuck your fucking pretentious over-rated pizza

I should have gone to Delfina.
author: Thömas F.

description:
I am not necessarily a big fan of heavy, doughy, chicago-style deep dish pizza but seirously, little star proved me wrong.  

It was a lazy (by lazy I mean...I didn't want to fuss with cooking) Sunday and we wanted to get a pizza, a bottle of wine and a movie.  I was kinda psyched about little star because of all of its fame and hype but also a bit apprehensive...what they do best i heard was the deep dish pizza.

We walk in, are greeted by friendly staff, but are offered the pizza menu.  There are a few deep dish and thin-crust (!) pizzas available as well as a few offerings of appetizers and the salad.  

We got a large little star (although I didn't really care for the feta cheese in there), a thing of salad, and a thing of wings to go.  while we were waiting...we had a couple libations in the name of PBR...heh.

The pizza - awesome, flavorful and crunchy crust, awesome tomato sauce, and such perfect spinach/cheese goodness on the bottom below the tomato sauce layer.  It was such a perfect combination of the tanginess, crunchiness, gooeiness and nuttiness from the cheese/spinach.

The wings were also very good - nicely seasoned and moist...it you're looking for buffal style saucy wings...not your thing, but really I loved them.

Mission is a bit far from where I am, but this would be the only place I'd come to whenever I have cravings for the deep-dish style (or perhaps the thin curst) pizzas.
author: Mike P.

description:
I really do not like Chicago style pizza (sorry folks, I'm a Jersey girl deep down inside and only have room in my heart for NY pizza). Little Star changed my mind for a brief moment. 

The menu was totally overwhelming because I just wanted to eat EVERYTHING on it. Even the deep dish pies. The 'Little Star' had a great sauce to cheese to spinach to crust ratio. Just the right amount of cheesiness and tartness. AND the crust wasn't soggy and gross! HEAVEN. 

Friends and I also split the 'Italian Combo' which had nice salty slices of salami and pepperoni that were balanced out with not too salty cheese and plenty of veggies. *sigh* If only pizza was a food group...

I shall return soon, Little Star.
author: Karena Q.

description: My hubby and I split the small mixed salad and a small deep dish vegetarian! Delish and enough food!  Love that salad!
author: Terry K.

description:
T_T...I'm overwhelmed by the love of this fabulous deep dish extravaganza called Little Star. At first glance, you probably thought, uh oh...it's got that low lighting thing going, so how am I supposed to see what I'm eating. Well, all you need is your nose, cause the aroma from our Little Star special was crazy awesome.  Daphne Z. and I got the 9" version of their special, filled with feta cheese, spinach, mushrooms, tomatoes, and garlic...drool...it was delish. I love how the crust on the bottom was thin and not oily *like some other places*, and the crust was never chewy and soggy, perfect.

Parking around here is not too bad, but you gotta look around for the 2 hour free parking, otherwise there's meters.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Best pizza in the city. 

Favorite: Deep dish classic
author: Kai C.

description:
This place certainly lives up to its hype! 

We got the Mediterranean chicken (deep dish) and the white pie (thin crust), and both were delicious!  This is a true Chicago deep dish- tasty crust with perfect texture (crispy on the outside, pillow-y on the inside), loads of cheese in the middle, and flavorful tomato sauce on top.  It's hard to stop eating this pie! The thin crust was great as well, but the deep dish was the winner. 

A couple tips: The waiting area is not big, but give your phone number for the wait list and they will send you a text with a link showing you your place on the list  (thus, easy to take a stroll to Alamo square or get early dessert at Bi-Rite if you're so inclined).  Also, order your deep dish while you're waiting and gets served pretty soon after you're seated!
author: Linda Z.

description: Came here strictly based on Yelp reviews and were not disappointed. Sat at the bar, extremely friendly bartender served us immediately. The Caprese Salad was delicious, another couple of slices of toast would have made it even better. Though not big fans of deep dish, based on the bartender recommendations, we ordered the deep dish Little Star. The pizza is all about the crust. We thoroughly enjoyed our dinner. Cant wait to try their thin crusts next time.
author: Ario E.

description:
The complaints about Little Star are so specific, it's easy to strategize a way around them. To avoid parking problems, I walked over from the Lower Haight. To avoid the allegedly surly staff, I ordered takeout. To avoid allegedly long wait times I allowed plenty of time before hypoglycemia set in.

As it turned out, my pizza was ready exactly on schedule (30 minutes) with only friendly service, and a few minutes later I was enjoying my Presidente. That's the "Mediterranean Chicken" which was served by a Little Star disciple at the White House, combining chicken (not my favorite), artichoke hearts and green olives (yum).

A good deep dish pizza will leave no greasy stain on the bottom of the carton when you get it home, and this one passed with flying colors. Above that cornmeal crust we have the chicken, other condiments, a layer of cheese (though I couldn't taste the alleged feta) and finally a nice sweet and thick tomato sauce.

I'm giving it 4 stars for excellent deep dish pizza, and not deducting for the realization I actually don't like deep dish very much. It's like eating a stew when I'd prefer to savor the individual ingredients. Sorry, Mr. President, I agree with you on most things but not this one. Or Afghanistan.
author: Otis M.

description:
Little Star... So hip. Chics with asymetrical haircuts and dudes with beards galore.

I don't really like this place. Need a reservation? Don't accept them, so hip for the city. You're gonna love the wait! 

I tried 4 different pizzas. Two of them were deep dish, two of them were thin crust. The deep dish was sauce all the way with cornbread crust (i still don't understand the appeal of that). The thin crust pizzas were oily. This place is a hipster palace for sure.

You know what though? The wings were good, 1 extra little star!
author: Paul M.

description:
I'll preface this to say that I'm a thin crust pizza gal, but hubby loves his deep dish.  With the reviews here and the Obama claim to fame, hubby made sure we stopped here on our San Fran trip.

Definitely off the tourist trap and huge line up.  Yelp rocks since we knew about the cash only thankfully!!

Mmmmm garlic bread - yummy.  As for the pizza, the crust is tasty.  I don't know if I haven't had enough deep dish pizzas, but why the heck it is so tomato-ey?  Had the large classic with sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells.  The pizza had so much f-ing tomato sauce that I couldn't taste any of the toppings!

I don't get the hype.  Sticking to my thin crust again.
author: Katie F.

description:
So worth the wait!

I came here on a Friday with a big group, so the wait was quite long.  The waitress let us pre-order as we waited for our table to free up so we wouldn't have to wait as long for our food.

We ordered the garlic bread, spicy chicken wings and two large deep dish pizzas, one Classic and one Mediterranean Chicken.  Awesome, awesome, and double awesome.  This is probably the best pizza I have had so far in the city.  The pizza crust was crispy (unlike other deep dish pizzas I've tried) and the toppings were fresh and chunky.

By the end of the meal, I was completely stuffed, but at the same time, tempted to eat one of the remaining pizza slices.  My brain and stomach were playing a chess match to determine the fate of the remaining pizza slices.  Stomach to brain: check mate.
author: Grant W.

description: It was disappointing especially having paid $22 for a small thin crust takeout pizza. Soggy thin crust, white onion with lots of bits of hard inedible skin (red onion tastes a lot better on any pizza), briny un-rinsed black olives and way to much garlic. I was not offered paper plates, napkins, pepper flakes or packets of parmesan cheese either. Never again.
author: Flower P.

description:
this place is great! walking into a dark or i should say dimly lit restaurant was no where what i was expecting. Cute romantic place excluding the loudness the facility brought in.

The hostess said the wait would be 25-40 minutes for 4people, a bit stuffy and small to wait but it turned out to be only 15 minute wait.  Great service, Great food, great GREAT GREAT bathroom. Gotta be the the cleanest public bathroom i have ever seen EVER. smelled like Dove soap.. if only my bathroom smelled that great!  

A+ and would definitely return here with such great deep dish pizzas being served.. check it out if youre in the city!
author: Em C.

description:
Absolutely delicious!.. coming from a person who doesn't even like cheese all that much.

We got lucky, I suppose, and didn't wait too long.  Also got lucky and found a close parking spot.  Perhaps that was the beginning of good things to come.

Group of us ordered two pizzas.  The pizzas are not as "saucey" compared to say, Zachary's... but they were really really good.  As expected, it's deep dish, so I was pretty satisfied with 3 slices and a pint of beer.

Highly recommended, especially for those who haven't tried before.
author: Eric P.

description:
I had heard so much about Little Star Pizza, and now I know why!

A friend and I decided to have dinner here one night and it was fantastic. It's definitely little old school pizza place meets fun, trendy restaurant. What a great place. I really like the layout and the casual vibe. 

They have a great menu with a lot of food and beverage choices. For an appetizer we had the garlic bread - sourdough, olive oil butter and a clove of roasted garlic. Needless to say it was incredible. For the pizza portion of the evening we opted for the special that evening. Delicious! I don't remember what it was called but it included goat cheese, apple turkey sausage and olive oil. I was impressed and ready to devour that thing. We polished that off with a reasonably priced bottle of wine and had more than enough leftovers for lunch the next day.

Little Star Pizza has just made the top of my pizza place list.
author: Denise S.

description: When you here about the deep dish pizza in San Francisco.... this is the one you're hearing about. It's the bomb! This place is great. Went on a fri evening, just beat the crazy rush. We got the a little before 8 and the wait was 20 min for a party of 2. At about 8:00, 10 people all walked through the door. The host told us the pizzas take 30 min to cook so we ordered while we were waiting. We got seated in about 15 min, ordered an appetizer, that took about 5 min and right when we finished it, our pizza arrived. It was deep dish, crispy thick crust, yum. We got pepperoni on the whole thing, artichoke hearts on half and roasted garlic on the other half. The garlic side was delicious. Loved the thick tomato sauce on top of the cheese. The organic beer and peach iced tea were also great. This place might not be so good for large groups, I didn't see any table that seats more than 4 besides the bar. The dim lighting and cozy tables makes this the best beer and pizza date place. Let's not forget the juke box, great selections and cheap. 3 songs for $1. Thumbs up.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
(Pick up review)
My first taste of their Supreme pizza (sausage, peppers) and it was love at first taste. It was perfectly topped with what tasted like authenticly seasoned Italian sausage, and Fresh veggies. Usually I throw away the crust, but i couldnt do that to Little Star's. I'm looking forward to trying their deep crust pizza for my next visit.
author: Thomas L.

description: As I sit on my couch eating leftovers I figured I should right a review. Because that is the best thing about Little Star, their pizza makes the best leftovers, so always get a large. If you like vegetarian pizza than this places is a must for you. Service is fast, friendly and clean. On weeknights you should be able to get seated just fine, but on the weekends you can expect to wait a bit, but its well worth it!
author: Matt F.

description: I crave Litte Star Pizza crust!! I also had the thin crust which was not as good...but the chicago style pizzas made up for it.
author: Logan N.

description:
Fabulous. I highly recommend trying this place out. 

They know how to make deep dish pizza here. The crust is perfectly baked so that the bottom is lightly crispy and the rest is soft as a pillow. 

The buffalo wings are pretty good too, but I had better. 

They need to get rid of the dim lights so I can see my gorgeous pizza!

 I am so mad at myself that I did not bring my camera that day. :(
author: Karen P.

description:
Why on earth would anyone order anything other than the deep dish pizza?

I can almost hear the haters, "stole Zachary's recipe, blah, blah, blah." But food is to be inspirational, to be improved upon, and Little Star has succeeded in this regard epically. The signature pie is the way to go; nuggets of tomato sauce meet the eye, topping a thick layer of spinach punctuated by roasted garlic with a blanket of motz sitting in creamy ricotta and hugged by a cornmeal crust.

So order a microbrew and dive into the most luscious pizza your mouth will ever meet.
author: Ligaya T.

description: Im rewriting my review because after coming here on sunday at 4 the restaurant was not busy service was great and the food was yummy!! :) thank you little star very professional and customer care was awesome!
author: Ernesto Z.

description: Second time here, just as great and used my previous yelp review to order the white pizza again. Love the thin crust, great garlic tang and topped with seasonal veggies. Also love the spicy chicken wings, great heat, not greasy dunked in the blue cheese=scrumptious. Wine selection, on tap, is great.
