If u don't want to travel to tony's in north beach try this restaurant.
author: Kelly K.

description:
theee best deep dish pizza i've ever eaten. 

we decided to come here because so many people raved to us about it but i was never a deep dish pizza kind of girl because my previous experence was not that great in palo alto. so since it was date night, we tried it anyways.

the restaurant is small and cozy which is very different from a pizza place. we were seated right away and the menu was pretty small so there wasnt much of a variety.

we had:
spicy chicken wings: this plate had ONE POUND of chicken!! sooo much. and it was suuureeee SPICY!!!! they didnt have ketchup on the table but they were nice enough to find some in the kitchen for me because chicken cannot be eaten without ketchup! all in all. it was sooo good.

deep dish pizza with pepporoni, mushroom, sausage, and chicken: the crust was crispy and the inside was moist and sooo good. it had mozarella cheese and tomato sauce on top but it wasnt TOO MUCH..it was JUSt enough and the taste was just undescribably good. we ordered a small and was STUFFED. 

dinner was about 30 bucks with tip. and there was soo much food. soo worth it!!!
author: Linda N.

description: the deep dish pizza is as good as patxi's. coolest staff ever. very nice kids. no pressure, no pretention, totally laid back atmosphere. we had a great time.
author: Sharon C.

description:
Finally, LITTLE STAR!!!!!  It IS all that it's cracked up to be and IS totally worth the 30 min wait!  Well, you wouldn't be waiting too long if you took the sweet hostess' suggestion and ordered your pie while you wait for your table.  (Thanks!)  While you're waiting, grab a drink at the bar and before you know it, you're seated and a deep dish of wonderment appears in front of you.  Yay!

I had to take a moment to stare at it for a bit because the pie is pretty intriguing and smells delicious (Wafting...Wafting...!).  

First question that came to mind was: Is this a fork-and-knife kind of pie or does the crust withstand the weight of the ingredients making it okay to eat with your hands?  Both!  Start off with a fork and knife and cut into the ooey gooey goodness atop the still-crunchy cornmeal crust.  Once at the top, pick it up and devour!  

We had a Classic Deep Dish, with Sausage, Mushrooms, Green Bells and Onion.  Pretty much an outstanding standard pizza, which got us into some pretty outstanding conversation (let's just say our conversation heightened the taste of our pizza...).  Do what you will with that comment, use your imagination.  But DAYAM, it was a good pizza!  Ennnnd Sceeeene!  :)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Classic deep dish is STILL my all time fave!!!!!

MUST have with anchovies though...damn this pizza is so good I'd slap myself!!!!!!!!!

YUM!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jade B.

description:
I am very dubious about deep dish pizza. It just doesn't resemble "pizza" at all. I would probably characterize it as a distant cousin, rather than a direct descendant. Or perhaps half pizza, half lasagna. I mean, the pizza is topped with tomato sauce- something i'm not a fan of, because it disguises all the yummy tantalizing toppings.

However, I put aside my pizza purist attitude for a day at Little Star, and I'm so glad I did. There's a reason why there is often a two-hour wait for this pizza, and it's not just because the place is small. The pizza is really good. I had the Little Star pizza. Their description: Little Star - Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions. OMG delicious!!! The ricotta and feta made the pizza just cheesy enough. Spinach and onions were fresh and tasty. Great combination. But the best part is the cornmeal crust. WOW!! It's crispy, corn-y, and really adds to the pizza. I think this is what sets Little Star apart.

The wings are not bad either. Just spicy enough, paired with a good blue cheese (but microscopic carrots.)

Also loved that they had a decent selection of beers, wine, and some cocktails. Loved the apricot beer, and I don't usually like beer!

Tip: If you have a party of two, wait at the bar for a quick seat.
author: Cathy S.

description: If you come to San Francisco and not eat the deep dish or wings at little star your trip was a waste... Neighborhood precious gem!!! Great beer on draft and even their thin crust is off the charts amazing.  We come here once a month at least and we always bring our over seas friends and fam here... Truly, my fave Nopa treat.
author: blair k.

description:
Was brought here on a rainy stormy night and enjoyed the cosy vibe.  Great ambience, comfortable and happy people all around.  Excellent Pizza - loved the thin crust.  It was crunchy and perfectly done.  Ordered the Italian house wine Sangiovese which  was easy to drink and excellent value at $5 a glass.  The only thing, I wasn't a fan of was the salad which was loaded with sweet toppings and gorgonzola... a simple green or mixed salad would have been better for me, but my friends loved it.  Not bad... just a matter of taste.

can't wait to go back again.
author: Billy B.

description: Ok....so I'm a little bit of a fanatic when it comes to pizza.  Sure I'll eat Round Table (since that used to be my favorite but I use far too many napkins soaking up the grease floating on the top).....but they are a poor substitute for Little Star Pizza.  The best part you ask?  I do NOT have to soak up any grease.  This pizza is delicious and my mouth is watering just writing about it....literally.  It's a bit pricey and out of the way, but well worth the drive and the money.  Did I mention that I love this place?  Just be aware that there is VERY limited seating at this location and a bit drafty when the door is left open.  I would like to see them add a few more appetizers since their menu is very limited.  I can't wait to savor the flavor of Little Star again.....
author: Marie S.

description:
Why do I eat deep dish pizza? I can leave a place like Little Star with a comfortably full belly and then two hours later I'm crazy full. It's like the opposite of Chinese food.  
So, while I vow to never go back here, I have to admit it tasted pretty good.
author: George L.

description:
LOVE LITTLE STAR!....Let me tell you why.  The crust is flaky and buttery but not heavy.  The filling: perfect ratio of all ingredients, which is very important to creating the perfect balance with no one ingredient overwhelming the pie.  I left very happy, thank you little star. I will be back!

***TIP: Take out is okay, but eating there is sooo much better!
author: Gina A.

description:
I must admit, the tomato sauce on the top kinda threw me off ... I'm used to seeing cheese there ... but once I got used to the visual, I had no problem sinking my teeth into Little Star's delectable pizza.  

Definitely will be back to try more ... to be continued.
author: S. I.

description:
PROTIP:

Since we all know SF people LOVE lines....lines for restaurants, bars, clubs, lounges, MUNI, BART... SF people love lines for Little Star too. Do yourself a favor - order once you put your name down. Deep dish takes 30 minutes anyway. 

We split a large deep dish pizza between 4 people (2 boys, 2 girls) along with an appetizer (mozzarella cheese + tomatoes). it was quite delish. you will enjoy your time here.
author: A Y.

description:
BAAAAAAD COMPANY, I CAN'T DENY.

and this pizza's company was bad. good bad.

like bad ass awesome bad.

huge deep dish, meaty, cheese, HEART ATTACK, water, beer, HEART...STOPPING.., hot wings.

get it all.

100% amazing
author: Victor B.

description: Little Star Threepeat.  Err...Hat Trick.  I think I had my best pizza at the Albany spot, but I enjoyed the same cornmeal crust and bottomless pie over here.  I still think Paxti's has them beat (it's the greater cheese to sauce ratio), but paired with a Blue Star Wheat, this is a not miniscule star.  I also finally tried their chicken wings.  I was generally impressed, but they were a bit puny.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Okay, so I'm not a big fan of Chicago style pizza, but I thought i would give Little Star a try, and it didn't disappoint.  I won't go out of my to get a deep dish, but the ones I've tried here are very good.

Caprese salad - Very delicious!  Highly recommended.
The Little Star Deep Dish - The spinach and cheese combo was perfect!  The crust was flaky and there was the right amount of blended cheese to compliment the other ingredients. 
Pesto Chicken thin crust - High quality ingredients, prefect bread to sauce ratio.

The ambiance is cool, the service is great and the meals are always satisfying.  If you don't like Chicago style this place is good; if you love Chicago style pizza, this place is great!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night with my brother and cousin. We were able to get a table immediately, even though the place was pretty crowded. More people started walking in after we were seated, so we were pretty lucky.  

Between the three of us, we ordered a large Classic Deep Dish. I really enjoyed the cornmeal crust. It was both crispy and soft. Not oily at all. I wasn't a fan of the sauce. It had a tangy taste, like tomatoes that come out of a can.  The toppings were good.  Overall, it was a good meal.  We all came out stuffed and still had more to take home.
author: Priya J.

description:
It's very good but falls short of greatness. First of all, Little Star truly is a minute place, so on a busy night, be prepared to wait. We had a party of 10 and arrived at 6:30 on a Sunday evening, but still had an hour's wait. No worries there; there's a small dive bar across the street that happily housed us for a bit. We moseyed on back after about 45 minutes, but still had a while longer to go before getting a table. Luckily, the hostess told us we could order while waiting, which meant our pizza got out faster.

We went deep dish all the way here (except for one "weirdo" in our party from New York, who absolutely had to order a thin crust). The Little Star highlighted by a spinach-cheese blend was the hit of the table. Yet between that, the Veggie, and the Classic (sausage substituted with chicken), they all tasted about the same. That's a bad sign at a pizza place.

The pie crust is absolutely fantastic, if not perfectly fitting for a deep dish pizza. It's cornbread based, but I think I'll stick with traditional pizza dough, thanks. The cheese is absolutely amazing, but Little Star definitely doesn't pay enough attention to the sauce, which is really the highlight of the Chicago-style. The pizza definitely came off a little too cheesy and dry at times.

If it sounds like I'm complaining, I'm not; these are just nitpicky details. On the whole, the pizza was excellent and well worth the wait. But as a truly magnificent deep dish pizza joint? I'm going to have to vote "no" on that.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: Amazing deep dish pizza. I love you I love you I love you. I also tried the special pizza last night, which was olive oil, cheese, prosciutto (thin crust); pretty phenomenal. The classic was great too! Cold glasses= awesomeness :). One of my fave pizza places for sure.
author: Sheeva G.

description:
+1 to the common sentiment of a general dislike of deep dish, but loving it at Little Star.

It was loud, packed, and the wait was long, but then again it was a Friday night. I'm not familiar with the area but it seemed like the place to be in the neighborhood.

We ordered the Little Star deep dish sans onions (for the onion-phobe fiance) and the daily special thin crust. The Little Star arrived with onions, which in my opinion was a necessary topping to balance the tartness of the tomatoes. I can't even remember what was on the thin crust. That's how good the Little Star deep dish was.
author: Elaine C.

description:
This deep dish pizza was REALLY good. I shared a small with one other person, and we were both stuffed after. We also had the garlic bread to start, which was okay, but not overly impressive. The soft butter could use some salt. I am just not a fan of unsalted butter. I was with Jake Z. and he was very upset that the butter and garlic was not cooked on the bread. That is not a big deal to me, but I guess you should know what you are getting yourself into.

Overall I want to eat this pizza again (soon), but I never want to set foot in this restaurant again, it is really damn loud. It is unbearably loud; it is impossible to maintain a conversation.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
LIttle Star was the third stop on me and K's deep dish tour.  We first visited Patxi's in the Marina, then Zachary's in Berkeley and finally Little Star.  This location was small and missed easily from the outside, it didn't look like a restaurant from the street.  Inside, dark lighting and layout made the place seem like a bar rather than a restaurant.

K and I were lucky that we walked right in and were seated immediately at around 630 on a Thursday night.  On our way out, there was a long wait.  We had the usual "special" which is sausage, green peppers and onions.  The wait for the pizza seemed excruciating longer than most deep dish pizza places but maybe that was because I was so hungry that night.  When the pizza came out, the aroma was definitely very appetizing.  When we finally dug in, the pizza was warm and gooey, but the thing you noticed the most was the crust.  The crust was moist, crispy still and a touch of cinnamon included.  It was the best out of the three places but the toppings seemed lackluster compared to the crust.  The crust seemed to be the redeeming feature of LIttle Star.  Everything else was simply average.

If you want a special crust on your deep dish, go to Little Star, if not, go to Zachary's in Berkeley.  It is truly the total package on terms of deep dish.
author: Brian C.

description: Thin crust sausage pizza, and Caprese salad. a weekly meal of mine. delicious!
author: Mister M.

description:
I am a NY pizza kinda girl.  I like thin crunchy crusts....

Little Star Pizza is my deep-dish exception.....because of its CORNMEAL CRUST.  Finally a deep dish pizza that isn't soggy!  I like Zachary's in Berkeley....it's always been my go to deep dish pizza....Oh how it's been knocked down to #2. 

Hello Little Star....new #1. 

They have happy hour from 5-6pm ($1 off alcohol....kinda weak but drinks are reasonably priced to begin with)....considering they open at 5.....eeeeeh.....but getting there earlier is the way to go so probably a better thing in the end :)
author: Hanna J.

description:
I normally order the deep dish here but the other day my pizza pal ordered us a thin crust with pepperoni, basil and pesto. It was anything but redundant. Strangely, there was ***no*** wait for a table for the first time ever! It was a Thursday at 7:30. Go figure...
Usually my girlfriend and I order our deep dish before being seated because the pizza and the wait can take forever, but the thin crust was really almost as amazing, and came to the table very quickly.  I still used a knife and fork, because, well....that's what I do at Little Star.  
The servers and other staff were, as always, friendly and movin' fast.  And they have lots of good looking customers, and champagne cocktails that erupt all over your table. Gotta love that, right? There's nothing about this place that will keep me away except when they are closed at funny times. (Sad face at the window)
author: Adrienne K.

description:
Pizza...Nom nom nom! 

Last week I was hanging out with some friends when they both mentioned they were starving. Originally, the plan was to go to Butter and drown our sorrows (well really mine- it had been an awful week) in fried food and cocktails. Instead, we cracked open a bottle of wine and ordered a pizza.

I'd never been here before, but they swore it was the best pizza ever. We ordered a deep dish with pepperoni, zucchini, and something else- I can't even remember. Although I had zero appetite, I definitely managed to shove a piece of deliciousness down my throat. 

We waited about an hour and then picked our pizza up (8:00 p.m. or so). 

Please note: This review gets three stars, rather than 4, because I'm not a huge fan of deep dish and never have been. BUT as far as deep dish goes, this is pretty dang good pie!
author: Annalise F.

description:
My heart belongs to Zacharys out in the EB, but I have to admit the cruchiness of the deep dish crust of Little Star did have me smiling this evening.

Master P and I went, to give into our pizza craving, and feeling more adventurous and oh so bored of my usual haunts, I convinced him to drive me down to Little Star.

The atmosphere was super hip--a nice change from the uber preppiness of the Pac Heights/ Marina I usually frequent, and the jukebox, the friendly and quick service were all definite pluses.
The roasted garlic and bread was yummy and the pizza great!

The ingredients seemed fresh, the crust crunchy and the pizza hot.

I don't know if I would be thrilled to sit in on a crowded night, but this evening's dinner was perfect--right down to the rockstar parking outside the restaurant.

I
author: Kathy K.

description:
So I'm on a strict cheapish eats budget for the rest of the summer and Little Star had been at the top of my list for months.   After driving around the TL and finding nothing appealing, we somehow ended up on Divis in front of Little Star.

Shared the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish, with feta, green olives, and artichoke hearts.  The pizza took about thirty minutes to arrive, which seemed standard.  One bite and we both agreed that the pizza was fantastic!  It's all about the cornmeal crust, which was crunchy on the outside and soft inside.  Ohh, so good.

I'm not sure what possessed us to get a large, but after about two huge slices, I was completely stuffed.  A 9" pizza probably would've been plenty.

Add on a glass of Racer 5 IPA and dinner for two was $30.  With a serious amount of leftovers the next day.

Cash only and no reservations taken, though we only waited about 15 minutes for a table.  Atmosphere is kind of hipster, but friendly with good service.

Still thinking about that crust.  And it even holds up well after a night in the fridge!
author: Joanne G.

description:
First of all, I want to give Little Star a higher rating. Their pizza is really good and different from the norm (purists beware!) It is almost more like a combination of a quiche, a pie and lasagna than a pizza. Every time I eat it I remember why I like it.

Now, why I'm giving it only three stars:

1. Why don't they take credit cards? I could understand if they were a hole-in-the-wall mom-and-pop establishment, but .... really? They are an established restaurant that should give patrons the option of paying with plastic.

2. Hipster waitstaff. I can't really say they've been rude, but just a bit too flippant/distant, as if they are doing us a favor by waiting on our table. On one particular night, a group of jeans-wearing, trucker-hat-sporting waitstaff were all congregating near the bar and dancing and laughing...now, I don't want to rain on anyone's parade and the service has never been shoddy, but it just isn't what I look for in a restaurant serving experience.

3. Cold (refrigerated) red wine. This was only once, but it was enough!  Still wish I'd sent it back.
author: sarah b.

description:
Little star...I so badly wanted to love you.. but you just don't live up to Zachary's standards.

The cornmeal on the crust kinda weirded me out. Everyone had raved about a flaky crust on yelp but ours definitely wasn't flaky. The inside of the pizza was good, as was the garlic bread and the service - but for some reason it just fell short of what i was hoping to find here.
author: laura f.

description: Pizza was some of the best pizza I've had the chance to eat. If you want a variety of delicious thin crust and deep dish pizzas in San Fran, come here!
author: Kyle P.

description: We love Little Star pizza! Ingredients are fresh, the special thin crust with the pear and Gorgonzola rocks!
author: Michele R.

description:
Ok, I'm from the east coast so I never expect a pizza place out here to be very good, but I've learned not to compare NewYork Style thin crust to any other pizza, anywhere (except Boston).  

That said, the deep dish pizza here is 5 Stars--no joke--if you go to one deep dish place in SF--go here!  I recommend getting the Little Star "little star" pizza, though I always sub artichoke hearts for the mushrooms.  

The reason I give it 4 stars is because the place is so loud inside, and there is usually a long wait.  They are closed Mondays.

Still, the staff is incredibly friendly, and the food is ahhh-mazing. Yum. 
I am already happy for your stomach just thinking about it.. ;)
author: Zoe W.

description:
I had some take out pizza, one thin crust spinach, artichoke, chicken and cheese, one deep dish. 

It was okay..maybe because it was take-out. I didnt even attempt the deep dish, i hate deep dish, its just all sauce, and you can see it.  Maybe next time i will try at the restaurant.
author: kim w.

description:
This isn't my favorite deep dish place in the city (that goes to Patxi's) but you really can't go wrong with a pizza loaded with cheese and sauce, can you? 

I'm sad that I can almost never get a table here, which is kind of the reason we stopped trying. The Little Star and the Classic are my two favorite pies here, and their garlic bread is also pretty damn good. The atmosphere in the Divis location is a little bit too crowded for my tastes, which is probably one of the reasons it's always hard to find a table. 

Service takes a really long time on busy nights, but what do you expect with deep dish? Maybe try ordering it ahead and picking it up if you don't feel like waiting around!
author: Veronica B.

description: Love! My new favorite Pizza place. I've only tried the "little star" deep dish pizza which is delicious. Much better than Patxi's deep dish.
author: Mak T.

description:
K, first, yes it's better than Zachary's. I said it.

We had the classic, had to get a large because they were out of the small deep dish. So, usually the husb packs away like 1/3 of a regular pizza, but with this one, two slices were enough. 

The tomato sauce is really good, I enjoyed it and usually I find tomatoes kinda gross.  Husb said the sauce was too sweet for him, but it was just right for me. There was lots of good flavor from the onions and bells, though the meat and mushroom flavor got a little lost in there. 

I never ever microwave pizza leftovers but had to since the pizza is so dense. Reason being, I don't like mushy crust. However, with this pizza, the crust stayed nice and crisp (except the bottom, which was soft but not soggy). I was impressed. The crust has a delicious olive oil taste that made the pizza heavenly. I don't ever want to have deep dish from anywhere else but Little Star.
author: gabby m.

description:
5/5 stars on the Wing Scale...  

- Quality of product: 3 of 3 stars
- Quality of service: 1 of 1 star
- General feelings of happiness: 1 of 1 star

Came here over a weekend with hubby J and my girlfriend Alicia C. (read her very thorough review!)

First thing I noticed here was well... the line!! Normally, I hate waiting. But their eager-to-please host more than made up for the wait by being so friendly and helpful. He let us know exactly how long the wait might be and the option to pre-order our deep-dish pizza. I appreciate good, helpful peeps... especially when I'm hungry!  

The three of us split a Caprese salad... yummy flavorful tomato slices atop fresh mozzarella. Be it on a salad or in a pizza, the mozz here rocks my world. No joke. We tried their special deep-dish (with meatballs, peppers, topped with dabs of ricotta!!) Little Star's cornmeal crust wasn't super crispy (like I had anticipated) and really held together all the ingredients. Their sauce worked well with the gooey mozz and toppings. Little Star has really edged out my past deep-dish favorites (Zachary's in Berkeley and Gino's East in Chicago).

Very lively atmosphere with fun, chill patrons. Service was quite awesome; their staff just has a great energy about them. I highly recommend this place!
author: Wing Y.

description:
As with other reviews here on Yelp, I will vote on the Little Star vs Zachary's epic battle. 

My vote goes to Little Star Pizza. The crust was the reason for me picking Little Star over Zachary's. Little Star's crust is just more flaky and delicious, where Zachary's crust tends to be a little soggy and not as tasty. As far as the toppings and overall flavor go, they both taste similar to me with their tangy tomato sauce and cheesy/gooey insides. 

Parking is indeed a problem for Little Star though, but definitely worth the effort. Just grab a beer at the bar and all your problems should be solved. 5 Stars!
author: Jeff C.

description:
Yum. This is possibly the best pizza I've ever eaten. Certainly nothing better springs to mind. So far I've tried the classic deep dish (sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers, onions) and the Little Star (spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic), and both were wonderful. The deep-dish crust is tall, fluffy, and flaky, in the style of Pizzeria Uno. The rest of the ingredients are fresh, ripe, rich, and perfectly done.

Next time I think I'll try one of the flat pizzas, perhaps the white pie (garlic olive oil, mozzarella, zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta). I'm curious to see how it stacks up against Slice of New York here in San Jose.

The goodness doesn't end with the pizza either. I highly recommend the caprese salad, made with perfectly-ripened tomatoes, and the garlic bread, which is actually plain bread served with a bulb of soft roasted garlic. The mood is terrific, perfect for a date with nothing but candlelight, a jukebox, and a bar lamp lighting the place.

Service has been excellent every time I've been here. The staff especially impressed me when I accidentally spilled my drink: Both our waiter and the bartender rushed to the table instantly to stop the spill and mop up what had already fallen.

The place has only three significant drawbacks that I've noticed. First, as some other folks have mentioned, you may need to wait a while for a table. However, you can hang out at the bar while you wait, or hop across the street to Bar 821 for a few minutes. Second, seating is pretty tight, and you may end up back-to-back with another customer. Finally, they only accept cash. However, I find these inconveniences minor compared to what you get!
author: Bradd S.

description:
Great pizza in a city devoid of solid pizza places.  I'm not normally a fan of deep dish, but whoaa was I blown away by Little Star.  Each slice is like a meal.  The sauce is perfect, the toppings out of sight, the crust is cooked just right.  The thin custs pizzas are almost equally as good so you can't go wrong either way.  

The wings are kinda whack, as are most wings out here on the west coast.  They are tiny things, cooked to long and coated in a mediocre sauce.  I recommend just to stick with the pizza.

The atmosphere is dark and since its such a small space it gets crowded.  Minus 1 star for extremely long waits and crowd which makes it a hipster haven.  You pretentious hipster fools annoy the hell out of me, but i guess even they can't resist a great pizza.  With almost 2,000 reviews hasn't this place become a little too mainstream for you yet??
author: T.C. J.

description: This is a hipster hangout for sure, but the pizza is good and sometimes the beer on draft is yummy!! The hostess Diana is chill.
author: Taylor M.

description:
mmmmm mmmmm mmmmm mmmmm mmmmm mmmmm...
this is an intelligent review because i am drooling.
I LOVE THIS PIZZA.  It is an indulgent, special treat that I have to wait soooo long for because there is always a line.  If I have a date to go here, I will think about it the entire week before. can't get enough.  I wonder what my personal trainer would say about this one...
author: Anna P.

description: Best pizza thus far in San Francisco. Deep Dish Pizza was delicious!
author: Danny A.

description:
What to say that hasn't already been said? Four and a half stars backed by 1600+ ratings speaks for itself. This place is honestly better than sex... 

Go. Now.
author: Bryan H.

description:
After a long day of work and errands in SF, I made time to stop by Little Star Pizza.  This was probably the most romantic pizza joint I've ever been to.  Candle light dinner, dimmed ceiling lights, music softly playing, cute carafes filled with tepid water.   I was looking forward to their deep dish, but was torn between the Mediterranean Chicken and Little Star.  Luckily the waitress said they can do half and half, which I opted for.  

I definitely liked the Little Star more than the Mediterranean Chicken.  The waitress also noted that she personally thought the Little Star was more delicious.  My friend ordered the special of the day on thin crust, and it was okay.  It had spicy sausage and broccoli raab, which was overwhelmingly bitter.  

Little Star has a pretty good selection of beer on tap.  I enjoyed a nice frosty Blue Paddle Pilsner, while my friend had one of their ales.  Overall, I got my deep dish pizza fix and thoroughly enjoyed the buttery crust and gluttonous cheese.
author: Agent X.

description: Parking sucks..but i love their classic pizza. Its fresh, tasty, and worth the wait.
author: Mike R.

description:
I guess I'm not part of the in-crowd who thinks Little Star Pizza is so great. 

I am a deep-dish pizza fan, and my boyfriend likes thin crust, so after living in the neighborhood for almost a year we decided to give the place a try. We were seated and able to order right away (it was a weeknight), but we must have had to wait for almost 40 minutes to get our food. And when we did get served we got two very mediocre pizzas. 

EXPENSIVE! Beware the "fresh tomato topping" which equates to about one half of a measly Roma tomato sliced so there is a single ring on each piece of pizza. Last I checked, Roma tomatoes max out at around 99 cents a pound, so I got royally ripped off for my half a tomato. 

Thick Crust: very cornmealy, dry, and burnt. BLEH, they ruined one of the best parts of the pizza. There is no dough, just dry, hard junk.

The thin crust was just OK. None of the pizza is that great leftover and I think I threw away the thick crust one because the dry crust sucked even more the next day.

The pizza down the street is way better... for each slice you order you actually get two big ones. We will never go to Little Star Pizza again... ignore the hype. It pretty much sucks!
author: Heidi G.

description:
A review from 2 diff people.

JHW:  This place is one of a kind! Chicago deep dish and new york style pizza together all at once!!! The staff is super friendly and overall just a really fun atmosphere.  The FOOD is AWESOME. We had little star pizza (better than the original deep dish i had in Chicago) and chicken pesto (SOOO FLAVORFUL!!!!).  Both SOOOOOO delicious!!! Must try restaurant.  We're definitely coming back!!!!!

BC:  waiters and hostess was super friendly enjoyed the rustic./grungy atmosphere, suited it well as a pizza joint.
word of advice, don't drink too much beer. or you'll be waiting in line for the bathroom for years on end
author: G_heyhey W.

description:
Went here for my friend's 23rd birthday, and as a pizza enthusiast,  this is one of the best pizza joints I have ever been to. 

Let me start off first by saying that I gave this place 4 stars instead of 5, only because of the wait. We got there around 6:30, and did not get seated until 7:45 or so. But if I had read the reviews, I should have seen that coming in haha. Plus, we had a party of 8.

We ordered the Classic Deep Dish Pizza, and the Pesto Based Thin Crust Pizza.

The Classic Deep Dish was super super good! I had one bite of the crust, and I was in heaven. The crust was probably the best pizza crust I had ever eaten. The toppings were plentiful, and fresh.

The Pesto Based pizza was pretty good, but if I ever come here again, I would definitely recommend sticking to the deep dish. Man... I'm craving pizza just thinking about the crust....

Oh yeah btw, the crust is amazing here.

P.S. Oh yeah, did I mention the crust?
author: Hoyi Y.

description:
Imagine deep dish pizza in Chicago, but take the mid-west-over-kill-on-cheese-for-shock-value.  Other differences: the crust is complex and the sauce has actual flavour. You can actually finish a large between 2 grown men. (make sure you only order one pizza between both)

I'm a bit of a pizza snob, and these guys nailed it. And the best part is - beers and more than enough pizza for 2 came to $34.
author: Alex M.

description: Only had one thin crust pizza so not a totally fair review. Better than chain restaurants but certainly not the best that I have ever had on either the West or East coast.
author: Joe M.

description:
The best deep dish pizza in town. At least that's what I'm told, and plus I've only eaten deep dish pizza here. Pretty much everything I've tried is solid.

Recommendations:
- Caprese Salad
- Chicken Wings
- Deep Dish Little Star

Only a few dislikes:
- You'll wait a while for the deep dish pizzas. They'll try to expedite it as much as possible by allowing you to order if you're waiting for a table, but if you're seated right away, the pizza takes about 30 mins to cook.
- It gets hot in there, so take off all your clothes.

Tip:
Order the deep dish pizza for take out. When you get home, it will have cooled off enough so that the ingredients stay together when you hold it in your hand; you won't have to use a knife and fork. Then, heat up the leftovers in your oven the next day. Tastes even better than when its fresh.
author: Harold C.

description:
Don't know which pie to order? 

Hands down, Little Star Deep Dish Pizza. - The crust is so ridiculously amazing. It would be a gazillion times better if Little Star could make a Deep Dish Pizza with a white/alfredo sauce too though. *hint hint *nudge nudge. :)

I'll be back, fasheezy.

P.S - The whole staff that works here seem super nice. From the Host to the Bartender. Awesome food, awesome service. Can't get any better than that.
author: Valerie N.

description: I'm from the East Coast and I admit that I am a snob when it comes to pizza. I was a bit apprehensive about coming here because I usually don't enjoy Chicago style pizza and prefer a traditional New York slice over the standard SF thin crust. I had no idea what I was missing! Little Star is the best. I still go to Tony's sometimes when I get the craving for a slice but Little Star has become my favorite place for pizza in the city.
author: Ryan S.

description: I tried the Little Star Deep Dish and it was so good. The crust is thin and loaded with tomato, spinach, and cheese. Great vegetarian dish.
author: Suki C.

description:
You'll wait to put your name down, wait to be seated, wait to order drinks, wait to get drinks, wait to order pizza, wait... and wait... and wait... to get pizza.

But when that pizza comes... it was all worth it. Flaky, thick crust. Gooey, piping hot cheese. Mountains of fresh, saucy tomatoes. You eat one piece and you have to have another. You eat another piece and you can barely hobble home, full and happy.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Dear Pizza Hut, Pizza Orgasmica, and Uncle Vito's, 

I don't know how else to say this, but I think we need to go on a break.  I found something better, and that something better is Little Star.

Granted I was not adventurous enough to try their famous deep-dish, their thin crust specialty (half Pesto Chicken & half Italian Combo) was still the best pizza I've ever had.  Seriously.  The best. 

What else was great?  Their garlic bread -- which was served as sourdough bread + garlic clove + garlic butter (all separately).  Yes, this required some manual labor, but it was unique and yummy nevertheless.


...Other pizzas will never taste the same again.
author: Judy C.

description: Fav place for deep dish and fav beer Boont while I wait. Peops are cool and love the jukebox!
author: Wilson L.

description: Came here on a thursday evening for dinner, found it of course by using my favorite tool... the YELP ap! The place has a real nice mellow vibe, not too much noise or clutter just a chill spot! The staff was really friendly and our food came really fast! We ordered thin crust, it was good... but i think next time i should definitely go for the deep dish, i think thats the good stuff! over all it was a good experience i would definitely come here again... seems like there is so much more on the menu for me to discover!
author: Amy D.

description:
After much thought I have decided to go with four stars....although really in all honestly I feel like little star is a 3.5. 
In all honestly the deep dish pizza is pretty good....but just not as good as Patxi's for some reason. 
Also....the apps are kind of booording. The mixed salad is okay, the garlic bread is basically thin sliced bread toasted with a roasted garlic that you spread on yourself, and while I like the spread it yourself style I dont like the fact that its not on fresh bread. 
Oh I also had a glass of the carbet which was rather good.  Boyfriend ordered and ice tea and they brought him a sweetened black tea bottles by Honest Tea. I mean.....common for such a nice place they should really have their own ice tea blend or whatever.
author: Yuliya R.

description:
Unfortunately, my first and only experience with Little Star was a not a good one. Now that I attend UC Berkeley and have access to Zachary's amazing deep dish, who knows if I'll be back.

For my high school teacher's thirtieth birthday, we went out to Little Star. Is it creepy that we're so close to our teacher that we take him out to dinner on his birthday? Considering that he's only 11-12 physical years our senior and that he still plays Magic regularly with his own students, I think not. 

From what I remember, we had dim lighting. We had our deep dish pizza and later ate slices of the cake that we brought. We were content up until the point that we saw our bill with a cakeage fee tacked on that cost more than the cake itself. They didn't mention this fee at all when we brought the cake in. Upon close inspection, one girl in our party found the tiny print on the menu mentioning the per person cakeage fee. Wouldn't it had been courteous if they mentioned to us beforehand. 
Maybe we should stick to Asian restaurants to serve us our cake without extra fees. Really. Do you need to charge if we want one extra dish and fork per person? Petty. 

We're Asian. We're cheap. Pettiness met with pettiness. We were all somewhat disgruntled. However, we decided afterward to go bon-firing at the beach and laughed our troubles away. 

Really, I would've rated this place 4 stars since the pizza was good, but I'm bitter. And I'm sure with its reputation, it can take the hit from a 3-star review. 
Maybe I'll come back someday, post high school and college days of I-have-no-regular-income stinginess.
author: Liana L.

description:
If you take 3 really hungry guys, order a deep dish pesto chicken pizza with light sauce, add some beer and garlic bread on the side, and let sit at a corner table for twenty minutes what happens?

Well as our waitress found out you come back to empty plates and three guys doing a post-Thanksgiving belt loosening.

It was so hard to savor the food because we were all so freaking hungry, but at the same time it was so good we couldn't slow down. It was the classic Catch-22.

I like the vibe of the place. It is cool and trendy and then still dishes up this ridonkulously good pizza. Nice service too. I can't remember out waitress's name but she was cute as hell.
author: Nick B.

description:
We came at an off-hour (around 5:30 PM) on Saturday night and there weren't many people. The restaurant got packed within 30 minutes, though, so I'd advise coming early!

Six of us shared the large Pesto Chicken Thin Crust pizza and large Little Star Deep Dish. 

Although I'd have to say the Little Star Deep Dish was my favorite out of the both, the pesto was still amazing. The Deep Dish also takes a lot longer to cook, and so we were finished with the pesto before it came out (thank goodness we ordered a thin crust because we were starving)

Service- fast and friendly
Ambiance- lovely. Very artsy and chic.
Parking- street parking! Come early.

I really, really wish they had one of these in LA. This was probably one of the best pizzas I have had in my life!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
This is the place I fanasize about when I'm on a diet.  Seriously, there is no better pizza in San Francisco.  Fresh ingredients, flavorful sauces, high-quality meat, and so much more than the sum of its amazing parts.

Little Star doesn't take reservations and has a wait every single night.  I recommend putting your name in and going to Cafe Abir across the street for coffee or wine while you wait.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
After trying LSP two times, i've formed a consistent opinion that I'm ready to share!

Little star pizza is delicious, deep dish goodness. The slices are really heavy, and 1.5 usually fill me up (to capacity). 

The good? It's no LOSS, with their awesome SAUCE! Seriously, it makes the pizza worth while!

I wish the crust were just as delightful, but it always leaves me wanting something more. Don't get me wrong, the crust is great...but It tends to run a bit dry, and just doesn't make the cut when compared to Paxti's incredibly prepped delicioso crust.

If only the two places could join forces...

Other Tips:
Parking: not easy, but you can get lucky. Standard for SF.

The wait: Be prepared, it takes a while. Still worth your time.

Overall, it's a great place to get your deep dish fix!
author: Sabeen c.

description:
This place was really good, but the place is as big as a closet and super packed. I went here for the first time on a friday with a couple of friends and I would say it was worth the wait. The hostess said it would've taken an hour and a half, but some people peaced out so we were stoked! 

This gem is located on the busiest street ever and if I had known it would have taken me an hour to find parking or I'd have to truck it I would've worn comfortable shoes. If you live in the area I would take a taxi or get dropped off. 

Service was okay, our waitress was a little spaced out. We had a couple of drinks at the bar so we didn't really notice until she couldn't find or remember where she put our tab. 

We had the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish and it was amazing! SOOOOO GOOOOODDDDD! YUM! My friend recommended getting the garlic bread, but they were out :(. Well...if they were out then it must have been good. Lame on running out though! 

Overall I'd go back.
author: Tanya S.

description:
I'm the first to admit that I don't really like pizza. I mean, it's good drunk food and I do have the rare cravings for a greasy slice -- but I would never go out of my way and plan a dinner around pizza. After Little Star Pizza, I may have to rethink that philosophy.

Of all the pizza variations, I've always preferred Chicago-style deep-dish pizza, and Little Star is definitely the best I've had. The place has a dark and intimate atmosphere, but it still keeps a lively, gastropub vibe. It's one of those places that is as equally perfect for romantic dates as it is for rowdy group gatherings. From the decor to the food, Little Star Pizza is what I would imagine is the perfect mixture of class and grunge.

We started with the garlic bread, which, to my pleasant surprise, is a fancy do-it-yourself dish. A warm half-loaf of sliced sourdough, two full cloves of roasted garlic, and a ramekin of creamy butter. Although I wish the bread came out hotter, it was a great appetizer.

The large 12" deep-dish pizza was incredible. Half Classic (sausage, onions, bell peppers) and half Little Star (spinach, feta, ricotta, mushrooms, onions, garlic), it came out drenched in marinara sauce on top. Anyone who has eaten at Little Star will tell you that what makes the deep-dish so damn good is the cornmeal crust. Crunchy, crispy, and buttery, the deep-dish crust is unlike anything I've ever tried in a pizza, and it's, frankly, the best pizza crust I've ever had. Wash that sucka down with a ice-cold pint of Racer 5 or Boont Amber (only $4.25 here) and you're golden.

As far as pizza joints are concerned, this is one of the very best.
author: Roy C.

description:
I've only been here twice and both times I've gotten the pesto chicken pizza and garlic bread. I am usually not a fan of thin crust pizzas because they get soggy. But here the thin crust pizzas are so crispy that you can hold up an entire slice without it falling apart. The garlic bread is excellent. They serve the sourdough bread with an entire bulb of roasted garlic so you can spread as much or as little garlic onto your bread as you'd like. I'd highly recommend getting it if you're into garlic. 

The only downer about this place is the parking.
author: Hang N.

description:
Ho. Ly. Crap.
The pizzas here were amazing. I sort of wish my big group of friends wasn't so strapped on time during our trip to SF so that we could eat it all over again as a dine-in... but damn, I digress. Where do I even begin writing about this place? The pizza was amazing. It's blotting out my ability to write coherently, but here goes anyway:

Deep dish: we got half something awesome and half something vegetarian and awesome.
New York style: again with the half something good and half something vegetarian good.
Overall the Chicago Deep Dishes easily won over the New York styles. The deep dish cheese and tomatoes blended together in a way that makes my eyes and mouth water just thinking about them right now :Q_____.... And the New York wasn't that spectacular. It was kind of like any other New York pizza: crispy, thin, tasted a little burnt from the oven.

The garlic bread was also pretty good. They have an interesting philosophy on garlic bread. They sliced open the bottom of a bulb of garlic and baked it with the bread until it got all gooey, and you just pop a clove onto your slice and spread it until it dissolves onto the bread in a delicious little .... *ghhhaaaaaa* :Q_____________
author: Victor T.

description:
After hearing great things from co-workers about both the thin/regular crust and deep-dish pizzas we figured we should try LIttle Star...

We had a friend visiting from Chicago, and while he passed approval on the regular pie, the deep-dish was not up to (his) snuff.

Conversely, my boyfriend and I thought the deep dish was tasty (not the best either of us has ever tried) but the thin crust was waaaaay too cornmealy. The texture was much too grainy.

Overall, the experience was OK. Not great, not terrible. Just OK. And a little pricey.

Oh and their website says they deliver. They do not. You have to call a bike messenger service which charges an additional $6(?) dollars. Not worth it.
author: T T.

description:
Little Star, BIG wait, HUGE disappointment.  We came on a Friday night here, not expecting to wait an hour and forty-five to get seated for pizza.  But, of course, this is precisely what happened.  

I'm all for waiting if something fabulous is coming my way, don't get me wrong.  And I really wanted to like this place, as it comes highly, highly recommended by my Yelp brethren whom I trust so much.  But to be honest, the pizza was sodden and soaked in WAY too much tomato sauce on it to enjoy.  We had the classic Little Star deep dish, and it translated to a big mess of crust, cheese, and sauce that lacked any flavor except for salt (of which there was too much), and turned soggy after 3 minutes out of the oven.  

Maybe next time I'll try to order in to avoid the wait and perhaps try the thin-crust variety.  Until then, you've left a bad taste in my mouth, Little Star!
author: Kira K.

description:
I love this place. Their pizzas are far better then Patxi's and Zachary's.  Although  there is usually a long wait, it is definitely worth it. Usually I just head across the street to Mini Bar,grab a drink, and a table will free up.  Their portions are generous and one deep dish pizza can feed 3 people easily. The thin crust pizza is just ok, and the garlic bread comes with a warm loaf with a whole roasted garlic and butter. YUM!!


Pros: Great pizzas, Yummy Garlic bread, and fun drinks!!

Cons: Cash only, but they have an ATM with a 25 cent service charge.
author: Miranda m.

description:
Really? Better than Zachary's?

Yelp really burned me on this one. As an East Bay lifer now living in Daly City I really wanted some deep dish pizza one night and saw all the reviews and figured I'd give it a try. Never again. See I've actually been to Zachary's and this Little Star hype is some straight up nonsense. 

Little Star pizza has none of the density or flavor that one would and should expect from a deep dish pizza. The graham cracker or corn bread or whatever crust is just inexcusable. 

The staff was nice and the wife claims the crust was 'OK' so I won't 1 star this place but all of you people claiming this is on par with Zachary's are just full of it. Give it up. It's not cool. 

Forget the reviews. Just look at the name.
author: Thom H.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Little Star
2.) Sausage ... Original?



So ... I don't know what the fuss is. But maybe it just doesn't suit my personal tastes. Something about the corn bread crust, and I dunno.  The deep dish ness. They put the sauce on top.. Like they do in, is it, North Chicago style pizza pie. It's alright. I prefer thin crispy crust and super cheesy pizza. yar. Zoweel, to each his own.


SERVICE:
Not bad.

ATMOSPHERE:
Small-ish place. I like the atmosphere. Very modern, trendy, dim lighting good ambiance for a casual date. Has a small bar area, good use of hanging curtains to divide up space.. Few small high tables
author: Angela L.

description: Im a through and through New York style thin crust girl and I have never liked the deep dish styles because I found them soggy and unappetizing every time I tried them. I eventually stopped eating them till I visited Little Star with friends. Their pizzas were game changing for me. I loved EVERY bite! I was pleasantly shocked to find myself polishing off the crusts-which I never eat! Yay!! Thank you Little Star for making me appreciate the beauty of Chicago deep dish. Also a special shout out to the uber friendly n laid back staff :)
author: Natasha I.

description: Went here for the first time to meet a friend who was also there for the first time and loved this place!! He had gotten word that this place was awesome and it was. Very quaint and personal so it's a great place for a first date, and the service and especially the pizza (we got the Mediterranean) was phenomenal!! I have nothing but good vibes and memories of this place.
author: Julian O.

description: Outstanding pizza. Is it the sweet tomato sauce? The corn meal crust? The combination of a Blue Star Wheat that seems to compliment it so nicely? Whatever it is....it works.  Take heed, Gino's East. ;-)
author: Dan B.

description:
My friend and I were in the city and we decided to go out for pizza and I found this place on YELP.

When I first stepped in here, I was kind of surprised. I was expecting a cheesy pizza parlor. The setting seem more date-ish. Lights dimmed candle light dinner kind of thing. I felt kind of trapped and out of pace.

Anyway, I ordered my pizza before I was seated because the hostess told me deep dish pizzas take 30 minutes to cook. When I was seated an hour later, I waited another 15 minutes for the food to come. We ordered the Little Star Deep Dish. It taste so simple and fresh. The best pizza I've ever had in my life. I don't know how I could possibly go back to pizza hut. The crust was so crispy and buttery. The cheese was cooked at the right temperature cause when I took a bite out of it the mozzarella was nice and stringy. The tomatoes were perfectly cooked. So sweet and perfectly seasoned with oregano. We ordered a large and regretted it the instant it got to the table. It's so big! I don't even think the two of us could even finish a small. We still had half the pizza left by the time we were completely full.

If you've been dying for good tasting pizza in the bay. Don't overlook Little Star.

CONS:
Parking is hell, the wait for a table during dinner is insane, and their isn't much room.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Love: The Little Star Pizza with Sausage. Their chicken wings. The fact that they'll take your order while you're still waiting for a table. A highly encouragable BYOWine policy. 

Hate: No option for reservations. The excruciatingly long wait for a table. Once, the hostess at the Mission branch got very snippy with one of the waiting parties (this has never happened as the Western Addition branch, however). I rarely get to stuff my face with Little Star these days unless I'm ordering a pie to go b/c I end up trying to gnaw my own arm off due to starvation.
author: Ida C.

description:
Hate the wait (and weight gain from eating here), but love the food.

My go to's (to go's take a while, so definitely call ahead. I write this while awaiting my takeout) are always the garlic bread ($4.50) and either The Classic or The Little Star + sausage (each $18 for a small, $23 for a large..add a couple bucks more when adding the sausage).  Love the spreadable roasted garlic.  Love the ooey gooey cheese and the crunchy cornmeal crust.

Oh yeah, and specials are on the chalkboard on the side of the bar.

Lastly, cash only.  Don't get gypped by the ATM machine inside.

If only something could be done about the wait (and the parking), Little Star would easily be five stars.
author: Mel T.

description:
Great deep dish pizza. And it's big! Even if you only have one slice, you'll fill up.

Three of us split a veggie pizza and we had plenty to take home. I only regret that I've never tried their thin crust pizza, because that's really my favorite style.

The folks here are really friendly and it's great for dine-in as much as take-out. It's very dark inside, but if you like low lighting, that won't bother you. And the bathroom is really clean!

I plan on coming back soon to try the thin crust!
author: Lowen B.

description:
I am soooo glad that they moved into my 'hood.  
I agree with Monica L. that Little Star *is* better than Zachary's!

My favorite is the Mediterranean...one must order thick-crust here or else it's not worth it. 

Probably the best pizza in the Bay Area.
author: mary r.

description:
I'd happily eat their pizza any day of the week.  But this is a competition -- it's always a competition! -- and it just doesn't hold up against Zachary's.  Mostly it's the crust's fault, which looks and tastes kind of like a thick lump of olive oil and cornmeal.  Looking at a cross-section of a slice, it seems like the hockey-cornpuck base makes up more than half the height of the pie, which means that the luxurious tomato-goo topping is probably getting the short end of the stick.

Little Star, you've gotten well-deserved attention from the pizza-eating masses in San Francisco, but I just don't see it happening had Zachary chosen to cross the bridge when he had the chance...
author: Laurence W.

description: Only been here for take out, but the deep dish never fails to impress. The chicken wings are incredibly original-- blackened and spicy rather than typical saucey BBQ wings. Wings and a small deep dish is the perfect amount for two people, and it's affordable enough to be a great option when it comes to take-out pizza.
author: Will A.

description:
One of the TOP TWO pizzas i've had. The other winner goes to a popular pizza joint in NY. I've never been to chicago, so i don't know how chicago pizza is. I do not like deep dish. I much prefer THIN crust pizza.

But whoa. This blew me away!

Got here on a late sunday afternoon, around 5.30pm. Parking wasn't good and had to park like 4 blocks away. It was surprisingly a full house for being 5.30pm. 

Ordered the garlic bread and spicy wings, which was brought out speedily.

Garlic Bread, the bread was warm but nothing special. However, the butter was melted to perfection. The garlic was, well, a softened whole garlic, which is plenty for your bread and guaranteed stinky breaths!

Spicy chicken wings, a good portion, I didn't count how many, but i would presume there was around 10? delicious and didn't even need the ranch! However, by the time I had finished these (shared) I was regretting the order of 2 appetisers.

The pizza took about an additional 10 minutes. I didn't think it looked big, only 12" long (that's what she said =p) By long, i mean in diameter! But after the first slice, even if you skip the crust...you remember, it is a deep dish with an overload of ingredients on it, leaving the quest to finish the pizza to be a very daunting task. Actually, impossible after eating the two appetisers. I only managed to squeeze in 2 slices and was full for the next 12 hours. Meanwhile, my bf finished 3 slices. The pizza was indeed, very well made. The crust wasn't soggy at all. The best of the pizza was somewhat crunchy and a great foundation for the pizza. I personally preferred the Little Star, even though it lacked the meat, it was filling enough. the Mediterranean chicken had a little sourness from the artichoke and i didn't think it matched well. Overall though, incredibly well made! Water, which was essential, was refilled every so often. 

What's even more amazing was that after 3 days, I had 3 slices of pizza left. I microwaved a slice for 1 minute and toasted it in my toaster oven for another 10 minutes in 350 degree. It was still very good! Not soggy at all! Amazing!

They accept card now!!! Thank goodness! But the ATM is only $0.25 anyways.

***

Tips: Get the little star, get the garlic bread, get the wings, dare i say one of the best wings and pizza ever! One appetizer to share, with a large pizza is enough for 2! Leftovers aren't that bad. Get half and half! Weekends, come early and you wouldn't have to wait for a seat.

Favorites: Little star pizza and chicken wings!

Do not want: Too full. Garlic bread was too stuffy. A little plain on the bread. I expected more?

Last words: Come and get a pizza, you will not regret it!
author: Celine L.

description:
A pleasant surprise.  When I think of most pizza places in San Francisco, I think of hole in the wall joints, but Little Star Pizza is a hole in a wall, but extremely classy.  It has a great ambiance to it (it's small and a reservation is highly recommended) and the service is awesome.

When I went I had 2 types of pizza.  They have a short menu of pizzas that they created, so my friend and I decided to create our own with their long list of available ingredients; they do charge per topping onto a regular cheese pizza.  The thin crust was delicious, well cooked, and tasted very fresh.  The deep dish, it was thick, but not as thick as Zachary's deep dish, but still delicious.  The best part about both were its freshness and such a great balance of flavor.

Little Star also offers alcohol so a glass or bottle of wine goes perfect with it.  This is definitely a good place for a first date; but be prepared to have to talk a little louder than normal if the restaurant is packed...which is most likely going to be the occasion.
author: A. W.

description:
Well, Little Star has redeemed itself for me. After a ridiculously obnoxious experience the first time I came here, I was ready to write this place off. However, the owner saw my overtly negative review and e-mailed me to apologize for my experience--that really impressed me. Little Star is so popular that a few unhappy customers probably wouldn't make much of a difference, but I really appreciate that the owner took the time to try to make things better. That's classy.

The hostess this time was much friendlier. We arrived around 7:30 on a Sunday night, and our wait time was about half an hour -- not horrible, although we ended up just sitting at the bar since I was starving. We ordered the 'Little Star' specialty pizza -- spinach, mushrooms, onions, garlic. Yum. The cornmeal crust was, once again, amazing. Possibly the best pizza crust in the Bay Area. A small pie easily feeds two people, with leftovers to spare.

The service was acceptable this time around, and that's all I really ask. I'd still recommend takeout for those who live nearby since I'd be concerned about a much longer wait, and I'm also not a huge fan of high-top tables, which is a good portion of the seating. However, I'm glad I gave this restaurant another shot, and I'd visit again.

Good job, Little Star. You've earned yourself a few extra stars from me.
author: Jamie T.

description:
1 star to start.

Food (1 star):
We came here for one thing and one thing only, the deep dish pizza.  We ordered a small Classic for the two of us, along with some Spicy Chicken Wings to tide us over while they made the pizza.  The pizza itself was very good, with the perfect blend of tomato sauce and sausage, onion, bell peppers, and my personal favorite, mushrooms.  The only negative was the crust, which was a bit crumbly and just didn't feel right for some reason.  The chicken wings were pretty average, though they were mildly spicy and had a good kick.  The blue cheese dressing that came with them was a nice addition.

Service (0.5 stars):
The service was alright here, they were very busy so we had to wait a while to get the attention of our waiter whenever we needed something.  Because of the long wait, they took our order while we were waiting so it wouldn't take as long to get our food, but it still took about 20 minutes after we were seated.

Value (0.5 stars):
Prices here are almost the same as the local competition (Zachary's, Patxi's).  A small deep dish was more than enough for two people, and the chicken wings were plentiful though a bit on the pricey side.

Experience (0.5 stars):
The restaurant is located in the Mission and we had a really hard time finding parking.  It was very crowded inside, though it was a Saturday night, and there was a nice waiting area.  The restaurant is quite dark inside and tables feel rather crowded as well, unnecessarily so.  Overall, we had a good experience here and wouldn't mind coming back.

Overall:
1.0 - Baseline
1.0 - Food
0.5 - Service
0.5 - Value
0.5 - Experience
=============
3.5 stars
author: Aaron T.

description: Yum! I'm a fan.  I don't typically enjoy deep dish pizza (even though I'm from the MidWest) but this place does it right!  The staff was super nice and the service was good.  We will be back.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
The Viv special is an awesome deal ... it led a car full of yogis to pursue pizza and beer in lieu yoga! It seemed like quite a conflict, but Little Star was the right way to go.

For me, the jury is still out on the Little Star versus Zachary's predicament. I think i prefer Little Star's filling and Zachary's crust. Pizza of choice:
--Little Star's "little star"
--Zachary's "spinach and mushroom"

My two cents.
author: Sarah T.

description:
3 stars for having great tasting crust 'n sauce. Tough customer here.

-1 star for rude, garrulous service. Bless. 

+2 stars for having low light - perfect for making out while waiting for food items...

What? Don't look at me like that. Don't you judge me. :grins:
author: Mark S. I.

description:
Love their deep dish pizza's here.  The corn meal crust combined with the chunky tomato sauce on top makes the pizza most and delicious.  

I always call in my order and pickup.

The Classic and Little Star is what i order and both are amazing.

Best deep dish pizza in town.
author: Vien C.

description: Some good a-- deep dish pizza.  Best in SF.  Better than Paxti's.
author: Al K.

description: Little Star has the best deep dish Pizza in the city! If you go there and don't order the deep dish you were mis-informed about what to eat. Good to order and take home, or eat there. The atmosphere is a little off inside the restaurant...the tables aren't set up to match the unique art and paint on the wall, they could have a better set up...BUT the pizza more than makes up for it! Who cares how you sit when the food is that GOOD!
author: Natalia H.

description: This is not your, "How 'bout pizza tonight?" kind of place. No, not a, "Let's order Little Star and watch the game." This is a, "I'm tired of myself and my life and I am ready to make a change," kind of pizza. Forget what you know about dough. Forget what you know about sauce, cheese, seasonings. Those things mean nothing when it comes to Little Star. NOTHING!!! This place is spectacular. Be hungry, be very very hungry, and be prepared to take home several pieces because you won't finish. Also, it will take 45 minutes plus from the time you order so bring a friend, order a Pilsner and wait for the magic. Thank to Dana Dane for so many awesome nights at this spot on Divisadero!
author: Jaymie C.

description:
I have not had very many deep dish pizza, and certainly not one from Chicago. I wasn't really a big fan of deep dish pizzas just because the crust is usually so thick, I end up getting full from just the crust, so I generally avoided ordering deep dish pizzas.

However, I enjoyed the pizza here very much. The crust is crispy on the side, the pizza is loaded with yummy toppings. The only down side is that there's not enough cheese on the pizza.

I will gladly come back again, and might even try more other places that offer deep dish pizzas because now I know how delicious they can be :)
author: Alice C.

description:
Little Star is like giving birth, the wait will suck but when you have your first bite you'll forget all about it and want to do it again.

Seriously best pizza in the city hands down.  Just as good (if not stolen from) Zachary's in Oakland and a hell of a lot closer (I live in the Mission) and with a better beer selection.  I've never tried the thin crust as I'm a huge deep dish guy.  Pro tip order one size smaller than you first think cause it's so thick you won't be able to eat more than a couple slices.

Little Star is full on win!
author: Jason S.

description:
OMG OMG OMG. Little Star hit every spot and ones I didn't know I had. 

I had been wanting to try Little Star for a long time and finally went last Friday. I was starving after shopping for Halloween costumes on Haight. We walked over and there was about a 20 min wait for a table but immediate seating at the bar, which is full service. We took the bar. 

We ordered the Little Star with sausage added and a Bear Republic Racer 5 IPA while waiting. Maybe I was just very hungry, but it felt like a very long wait for the pizza to cook. But it is deep dish after all. It is totally worth the wait. It was very cheesy with fresh veggies - I loved that the spinach still had a crunch. The crust was very nicely done with a little crunch and provided great texture. It is very filling. I was really stuffed after two slices, but ate another half slice anyway because it was just too good to stop. We ordered the large so we could have leftovers. 

I have been dreaming about Little Star ever since and can't wait to go back.
author: Katherine T.

description:
It's good pizza, but it doesn't exactly blow me away like I thought I would be. 

We came here on a Friday night at around 6:45. Our wait was close to about 25 minutes and the lady told me that if I ordered first, she'll send it to the kitchen so it should arrive when we get seated. I liked this idea because my gf and I were very hungry and the thought of being able to eat as soon as we sit was great.

We decided on the vegetarian deep dish and added sausage. After we got to our table, we also decided to get the spicy chicken wings. I was hoping our pizza was gonna come in the next few minutes. Nope. 

After about 20 minutes, our chicken wings came. These were really good! Spicy but not the kind of spicy that you get from hot sauce or chili, spicy due to some undetectable spices that they coat the chicken in before baking. It hits your tongue but sort of in an indirect way. The heat is definitely there but it isn't overwhelming, it peaks then it slowly disappears, leaving you all confused and wanting to chomp down on the next one. I sensed some cumin and the gf sensed some celery root or coriander. Definitely a puzzler. 

After about 30 minutes our pizza finally arrived. It looked great! It was sauced nicely and the crust looked amazing with the flecks of cornmeal on it. So I took a bite, and it was good, you definitely know it was a vegetarian pizza because there was a lot of different textures from the zucchini, mushroom, and I forget what else was in there. The sausage was a bit bland, and maybe overpowered by the veggies. So after the initial slice, everything started to just wear off. I guess this place is the kind of place where you come with a big group, order a bunch of pies, and then try a slice each. It's good, and I'll definitely be back to try the thin crust pizzas.
author: Derrick L.

description: Back in the day I would hang out with my Divisadero hipster friends and we would gobble deep dish pizza and they would drink PBR and all would be angsty in the world.  My hipster friends have mostly grown up and I'm pretty sure they don't drink PBR any more but the pizza is still fabulous and how kind are the servers for making us a pizza that was half a special a quarter cheese and a quarter something else.
author: Poppy C.

description:
Seriously, Little Star Pizza is the BEST PIZZA EVER. 

I am obsessed with this place. Seriously, I moved back to LA a little over a year ago and everytime I go to SF, a friend goes to SF, family goes to SF.. I request to have a Little Star Pizza brought back...

It's THAT good.

Cornmeal crust is dreamworthy, so do yourself a favor and get a large deepdish. If it's just for you or you and a partner, this baby will leave leftovers. And trust me, you WILL WANT LEFTOVERS!
author: Kat R.

description: I can't say that I know anything about deep dish pizza, but I tried it, and this pizza was fabulous!  The cornmeal crust was awesome, and the sauce was excellent. Honestly, I can't wait to go back. Yumm!
author: Mark W.

description:
Honestly never had deep dish pizza until this place, but after this place I am a fan and a believer. What is there not to like? Just get the normal popular ingredients of a pizza and INCREASE 5 TIMES!!!!!!!!

Their crumbly corn crust is also awesome and inspirational. People who don't like a deep dish from Little Star must be allergic to awesome, in which case there's a Pizza hut down the street.
author: Ken K.

description: Great pizza!   We opted for the thin crust pizza and it was delicious!    Definitely will be stopping by here again on our next trip to San Francisco!
author: Lesley A.

description:
I've been on a deep dish pizza binge lately by visiting the illustrious Bay Area trifecta: Little Star, Paxti's, and Zachary's. I gave them all 5 stars. I love deep dish pizza.

Little Star is a somewhat different style than the other two, and from most deep dish pizza I've had elsewhere. It's not quite as deep; only and inch and a half or so tall. It also has less cheese and more tomatoes, making it *slightly* less heavy - but it's still deep dish pizza. I personally liked this, but as I've made clear, I'm pretty easy when it comes to deep dish pizza.

I have the mixed blessing of having Little Star right near my house. I resisted for the first 6 months I've lived here because I didn't know how great it was, plus I was slightly put off by the wait time (which wasn't bad on the weeknight we went last week). I better prepare for my "Little Star 15."
author: Adam B.

description:
This one baffles me. I think the Pizza is REALLY GOOD. But it's not at all the best I have ever had and the prices are pretty ridiculous. I did enjoy that cornmeal crust a lot. 
The service was nice. Our server was funny and made a few fun jokes with us. He was prompt and hip. I liked him. We didn't feel rushed and we weren't held hostage either waiting on anything.
I liked the Pizza. I'll probably eat here again, but I will order out. The crowd here didn't really do it for me.
author: Jena D.

description: I love this place.  Their crust is just great and I love the big chunks of meatball for their meatball pizzas.  I usually will start with some garlic bread.  It's a really simple dish, bread, some butter/oil spread and roasted garlic.  I'm pretty partial to their deep dish, and don't really even consider getting the thin crust.  I've found that the specials are usually pretty awesome.
author: Ted G.

description: Took my brother here from Texas. Great atmosphere, great vide. Awesome!!!!!food. They also have a great unique beer selection. Can't wait to go back.
author: Joshua D.

description:
when i saw 1600+ reviews.. i was like.. "uh maybe i should not come here, I'm afraid we might have to wait a long time" But I came anyways and there was NO WAIT ON A TUESDAY NIGHT!! WHoa, got a table right away! We were so hungry! The waitress kinda lied though. For two people, we ordered a large deep dish veggie pizza and the waitress encouraged us to order an appetizer b/c the pizza was going to take 30mins to come out. So we ordered garlic bread. The pizza came out in like 15mins or less. We couldn't eat more than half of the pizza b/c the garlic bread filled us up!

Garlic Bread- I like how the garlic is roasted and very easy to spread, I'd skip it though if you have a small appetite. Because all that carb is gonna fill u up quick!

Vegetarian Deep Dish Pizza- Very Yummy! I guess I'm a bigger fan of thin crust but I'm very impressed with their deep dish pizza! It is very good. The crust is perfect!

I'll be back to try their thin crust pizzas next time!
author: A L.

description:
We ate here during the Japan Nite show down the street.  I've never actually had a deep dish pizza as they are not common in southern California.  I'm not sure if they are common in Northern California.
Anyway, the wait was about a half hour.  The places was filled.  I noticed that a lot of people from the neighborhood were ordering the pizza for pick-up.  Lot's of pizzas went through the door as we were waiting.
The hostess was kind enough to let us know that we could order our deep dish pizza while we were waiting (since they take longer to prep).

The pizza was amazing!!!  We ordered he pizza with italian sausage.  Also, VERY filling.  My husband and I shared a small and we couldn't finish it.  Our 3 friends ordered a large and couldn't finish it.  VERY STUFFED.

The wait staff was very friendly and got us out of there in a reasonable amount of time.

If we are in the area again......we will certainly visit again.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Good pizza comes to the 'hood- finally!

Love the juke box, love the food. A touch dark, I could barely see myself or my companions the last time I dined there.

UPDATE 3/10/06:
Was very impressed with Little Star last night. Seems that this spot has definitely grown better with age. The Caprese salad was wonderful, so good I really wanted to ask where they managed to source tomatoes THAT good in early March. The pizza was much better than I remember it being on my last visit, and again, it was the tomatoes that did it.

I also very much enjoyed the Blue Star Wheat beer.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Twinkle twinkle little star...

I love Zachary's.  I love Zachary's with every bone in my body.  I love the pizza, the tight quarters at the College St location and the socialist tendencies (how many restaurants have an ESOP?).  And as people spoke of this so-called challenger, Little Star, I thought, heresy! How could anybody think any place on earth could compare to Zachary's?!?!?

Little Star is in the same league but it does not beat the original.  Zachary's will always be my favorite, but Little Star is quite the rival.  I think Zachary's makes a better pie over all...and I still love the Zachary's art work on the walls, but Little Star has great crust.  And I am not a crust person.

I wanted to hate it, but I couldn't.  A hard-earned five stars...
author: Wendy L.

description:
Look, I've eaten pizza all over the US, and LIttle Star Pizza takes the cake! Why? Because its now four hours since I ate there, and I still have this great taste in my mouth and my stomach is sending happy messages to my brain. 

Look its a little dark inside, yes, but the atmosphere is great inside, just a touch of class, a touch of NY flavor, but you still know you are in CA for pizza. 

Started with the caprese salad, which was made very well with fresh ingredients. Ordered some Ginger Beer, a Sam Adams, and PBR, all served chilled and very tasty. Ordered the Chicken Pesto Thin Crust and the Little Star Deep Dish. 

Lets just say the Chicken Pesto is orgasmic. Bite after bite, I kept looking forward to my next bite. Then we all gazed and put dibs on our next slice. What can I say? You can taste the fresh ingredients, the cheese is just to the PERFECT amount, the mushrooms add intense flavor, and the chicken is cooked to perfection, none of that dried out stuff that happens in the oven. The Pesto sauce wasn't too oily, just the right saltiness, and a little tinge of butter. 

The little star deep dish was also amazing. If you were to compare this to say, Zachary's in Berkeley, this place is much better. Why? Because it doesn't try to overload you with ingredients. Great crispy crust on the edge that isn't hard where you don't want to eat it, but isn't soft where it doesn't hold up the pizza. The tomato and spinach inside was so intense in flavor that I had to chew slowly to juice all the ingredients out. 

And you know what? Those two pizzas, beers, and appetizer turned out $15 after tip per person. Great Great Great. I will definitely go back in a second.
author: Jon H.

description:
Yay!  I finally made it to Little Star Pizza after hearing many rave reviews, and I'm so glad I did!  We arrived at 9 pm on a Thursday night and discovered there was a 30 minute wait, then were pleasantly surprised to be given the option of being seated at the bar just 10 minutes later!  

We dined on a delicious deep-dish pizza topped with spinach, tomatoes, ricotta, and feta - it was super tasty!  I also enjoyed a glass of chianti with my meal.

In addition, the service was great - friendly without being overbearing or intrusive!  Little Star definitely rivals Zachary's in the competition for best Bay Area deep-dish...this place is as good as everyone says it is! (The only negative is the fact that Little Star is cash only...I was glad I happened to have cash on me, since that is often not the case!)
author: Barnali D.

description:
I'm an Oakland girl. I fight fiercely for its honor and that includes our food.

However, I have to say, I like Little Star better than Zachary's. 

Zachary's is really good. There is no denying that. But there is something about Little Star's dough and the toppings that bump it up to perfection. Zachary's can be a little bit soupy sometimes with regards to the tomato on the top. Little Star keeps it extra fresh and not-so-runny.

The Original deep dish is probably my favorite of what I've eaten here. The vegetarian, ironically altered by adding chicken, is also delicious.

Kudos, Little Star. Kudos.
author: Crystal C.

description: yum!  this is legit Za! The white pizza with bacon and roasted corn is a must
