author: S M.
Brian J.

description:
I love Little Star!  I love Little Star!  I Love Little Star!

Their cornmeal crust is perfect!  Try the deep-dish Little Star or Classic.  And try out some chicken wings too!
author: Carol L.

description:
I've heard nothing but great things about Little Star.  After my first experience here, it's hard to argue with the majority of the comments I've read and heard.

I went with a friend who's been here before.  The special was a meatball, ricotta, mushroom deep dish.  Whenever I go to a place for the first time, I make it a point to either get the standard or the special.  I want to give a place the best opportunity to succeed.

It was totally decent.  The meatballs were appropriately spiced, the mushrooms had a nice texture, and they use a good quality cheese.  The sauce was just a hair on the sweet side for me, but everything else met or exceeded expectations.  The one thing I have to say is the crust was amazing; absolutely amazing.

We (two healthy guys) split a small deep dish.  I definitely could've eaten more, but I didn't leave hungry.

Price: 4 stars, totally appropriate for the amount of food (note: cash only)
Ambiance: 4 stars, A little crowded, a little noisy, but an appropriate experience for a pizza joint.
Service: 4 stars, the crowd made seating a challenge, but our server was excellent.
Food: 4.5 stars, I might upgrade to 5 after further dining experiences. 

Overall, I'm a supporter.

One final thing, I didn't try it, but I hear their cheese cake is amazing.
author: Thomas K.

description:
After hearing tons of good stuff about this place, I decided to give it a shot a couple of months ago.

The wait/line for seating was crazy. 

People were dressed anywhere from way down to way up. I think it's safe to assume that the people who were dressed up, were on their way to go someplace else, afterward. Otherwise, they really need to get a life.

The pizza was relatively good, but it had way too much sauce for my taste. It was sour, tangy, red sauce...so much of it, it was like a bread bowl of tomato sauce. However, I did like the dough/crust, despite the strange texture.

The pizza was pretty pricey. I had a small personal pizza, which was $20 +tip. 

I think a lot of people would really enjoy the pizza, but I took a couple of stars off, because I got some crazy allergic reaction to it. Not sure if it was the huge serving of tomato sauce or the grainy-powdery stuff that they put on the dough...kind of a wheatgerm texture, whatever it was made me itch.  :(
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
Awesome.  This is truly a five star place.

Here's what makes Little Star better than the rest:
+ Cornmeal crust.  I was skeptical at first, because I thought the cornmeal crust was a gimmick.  But it's not.  It's a smart way to get a crispy, substantial crust without too much doughy globbiness or grease.  Little Star's crust wins out over Patxi's or Zachary's.
+ Sauce is just the right balance of tangy and sweet.  Little Star's sauce wins over Zachary's (too tangy) but draws with Patxi's.

Here's what put Little Star over the top:  
+ Caprese salad was also top-notch, with vine-ripened hothouse tomatoes that tasted just like summer and creamy buffalo mozzarella.
+ Service was honest, friendly, and no-nonsense.  I love that our waiter admitted to forgetting an additional side, and that the host legitimately tried to figure out how long our wait would be and took down our cell phone number (turned out to be about an hour...)  I also loved that we could preorder our pizza, so we didn't have to wait too long after getting seated to start chowing down.
+++  Bonus points go to Little Star for making me feel young, SF-y and hip.  (Hooray for other patrons' spontaneous clapping and boogying to the jukebox!)
author: Alicia C.

description:
I'm not normally a fan of deep dish pizza, but this place has converted me.  The thin crust pizza is great, but the deep dish pizza is amazing!  I especially recommend the "classic" deep dish, really anything with sausage, their deep dish pizzas don't work quite as well with pepperoni.

The garlic bread is also amazing! It's more like cheesy bread, but not in an overpowering way like the stuff from Dominos. 

I can't speak to the ambiance in the restaurant, only having ever done delivery.
author: June O.

description: Little Star is insanely and dangerously good.  I recommend the Brass Monkey - not on the menu.  It is the deep dish "Little Star" pizza (spinach, feta, mushrooms) and add sausage.  YUM!
author: Chad S.

description: Nom nom nom! The deep dish pizza was amazing! I am all about the carbs & that crust was carb-ilicious :) moving into this neighborhood over the weekend & this will defo be one of the nearby go to places. Word of warning the large is huuuuggeeee. I think a small is enough for 2!
author: Sorcha Sin R.

description: Their deep dish pizza is delicious! There were a lot of people dining here when I went with my friend.
author: LM D.

description:
Hmmmmm...

I am writing this review while eating leftovers from last nights journey to Little Star... so theres a little street credit for my review.

Deep Dish people, Deep Dish.

If you are really going to compare Little Star with Patxis, Patxis clearly wins for the food itself.  For about the same price, you get so much more at Patxis (full off of 2 slices vs not full off 3 slices at Lil Star).  The sauce is very weak at Lil Star (hardly covers the pizza) and the crust is just too hard for my liking.  I'm not saying it's bad pizza, my god, its not. It's just not as good as Patxis.  

Where Little Star clearly beats Patxis is what i like to call the "ambiance factor".  Patxis kind of has a cafeteria like feel to it, while Little Star is a more relaxing dining experience.  

I would go back to Little Star, but I would always prefer to go to Patxis.  

"I can smell a fart from a mile away"
-Adrian Brody
author: John B R.

description:
Soooooo delicious - Classic Deep Dish is our fav.

Friendly staff, always welcoming and know their stuff.

No reservations, but the wait is never too long.
author: Alexis M.

description: I am a fan of their pepperoni sausage deep dish :) I love how their crust tastes soo buttery just like pizza hut :) The Chicken Pesto was my very least favorite. But other than that, i'll be back !
author: linda L.

description: This is the best Chicago-style deep dish I've had outside of Chicago, period. The sausage is fresh and perfectly seasoned, and the vegetables are cooked to the perfect temperature in the pie. Magnificent sauce that's not too sweet, the way they truly do it in the Chi. Fairly priced, and solid beer selection on top of it.
author: Dave T.

description:
Mediterranean deep dish- thumbs up 
Vegetarian thin crust- thumbs up 
Classic deep dish- thumbs up 
Mixed green salad- thumbs up 
Fun beers like Blue Paddle Pilsner- thumbs up 
Service is no fuss and good; and as you can see above, the food is great! I will certainly be back! 
I read several reviews saying that the wait was long but both times I've been we walked right in and sat down...
author: Janell D.

description:
I'm going to jump on the fan wagon and say that Little Star Pizza has a really freaking good Chicago style pizza! 

I have had the honor of eating at Zachary's and now here. I think that Little Star has a slightly different product than Zachary's. Simplicity is how I can best describe it. I love them both though! 

I can't really compare the pizza here to the Chicago joints, but my assumption is that Little Star can probably compete with most joints in the Windy City. I am sure that there are better pie places there though, but for us in the Bay Area Little Star Pizza has a great deep dish.
author: Darryl P.

description:
WTF... I lived in the city practically all my life, how did I NOT know about this place earlier??? It is THE BEST deep dish pizza spot in the city. I used to live in the East Bay and couldn't get enough of Zachary's.... this place is just as good... but the restaurant itself is much better. it's got a great vibe to it, dim lights, great beer selection, and nice employees. 
The pizza's selection isn't too large, but anything you get is good. The chicken wings are delish and the cheesecake is pretty awesome too! 
This is definitely one of my new fav spots! 

Things to note:
They don't do half baked pizza's like Zachary's ( but that's okay)
They DO have a person that does delivery (she bikes there) if you live in the extended area.... ask them about it.. it's kind of cute
A bit of a wait for a table and the pizza... so don't go when you are starving.... BUT definitely worth the wait! 
A small pizza will go a long way! 
Oh, and CASH ONLY (but they have an atm inside that only charges you like 50 cents to use!)

Happy eating!
author: jennifer h.

description: I am a big fan of their Chicago deep dish and their special of the day thin crust. They get creative with the special of the day. Once I had a special with runny eggs and ham and I forget what kind of cheese but it was so good!
author: Chris H.

description:
Crispy Crunchy Crust - filled to the brim
Seasonally Sweet and Delicious Veggies
Pounds of Pure Cheese....

Please someone take me back there once a week.
(at least)

awe man! ...want. more. now.
author: Katy A.

description:
Well, what's the point in reviewing a restaurant with more than 1000 reviews?  I guess it's like voting.  You hope it makes a difference, but probably not.  That being said, yay civic duty!

Alright, task at hand...Little Star tastes exactly like Pi pizza in St. Louis, which was my favorite pizza in the world (and Obama's!).  So, to apply the transitive property...  Little Star = Pi, Pi = my favorite pizza.  Therefore, Little Star = my favorite pizza!  Btw, I'm only talking about the deep dish.  Why would you even consider getting the thin crust?  

The cornmeal crust is like eating a crunchy, perfectly cooked biscuit.  The sauce is not too heavy, has great tang to it, and is beautiful.  The cheese is the perfect amount.  The toppings are always great (I really like the Mediterranean pizza).

Also, the deep dish isn't too heavy.  Patxi's and Zachary's pizzas are like pancakes.  The first slice is great, but after that eating is a chore.  Little Star does not have diminishing returns.

In summary, Little Star is a place where I can eat pizza, thoroughly enjoy it, and not regret it later.
author: Jay W.

description: Tried out their skinny crust Italian yesterday.. And although their specialty is deep dish, their skinny crust didn't disappoint. Everything tasted so fresh.. Their pizza was delicious and their salad was excellent! Huge salad for $5 during happy hour.. Service was great too.
author: Brenda R.

description:
Only beer and wine! Beware. 
Good champagne cocktails and wine selection though. 

Not a huge fan of deep dish pizza but nom nom this was bomb. Great balance between crust, sauce and cheese!
author: Athena W.

description:
While my husband and I are new to San Francisco (we've been living here for about two months now), Little Star Pizza has become our go to place to take out of town guests.

First of all, it's a short walk from our place.  Secondly, the pizza is truly unique and absolutely delicious.  I love how they serve their salad family style, so you can order just one and share it with the table.  And the portions for the pizza are just right, so you don't overeat or have a bunch left over.  I've tried both the deep dish and the thin crust and I was very pleased.  On the menu you will see the deep dish choices and the thin crust choices, but they are happy to mix it up and make a deep dish choice thin or vice versa.  The bar service is fast and efficient, which is good because every time I've been to this place there has been at least a twenty minute wait.  Definitely a favorite and will visit again soon.
author: Beenish K.

description: This pizza makes my mouth water just thinking about it. The regular pie is pretty dang good, but of course their deep dish is where it's at. Tried it since it was on the big eats list and have been back time and again for more. The little star was the one on the list, and although pretty good, i love the classic. The atmosphere is great, good wine, decent service and even if there's a really long wait it goes by pretty quick if you hang out at the bar. they've got the ordering situation down so you don't have to wait at the table for a long time. Once you're seated your food comes right out.
author: Audrey V.

description:
Wow! Thats how i am going to start this. It is most likely how i am going to end it as well. 
I came here tonight for the first time. I got the classic deep dish. It was the BEST pizza I have ever had. The BEST!  Go here and you will not be disappointed. Wow.
author: Wes P.

description:
Best Pizza in sf hands down.  better than the proclaimed best deep dish pizzas in Chicago, "Gino's" and "Giordano's".  HANDS DOWN.

The "Little Star", add sausage is my personal fav.

ALWAYS worth the wait.
author: Sean K.

description:
$30 dollah for a pizza pie? Whatsa matta you? 
I keep coming in and ordering the same thing(brass monkey-spinach and sausage on thick crust pizza) because I cannot get past the thought of gooey cheese with spinach and tomatoes with chunks of sausage on a crispy, thick, cornbread crust!
FOOD COMA Time!  This makes me delirious!  
This is my ultimate comfort food that throws me back to the days when Marco Polo discovered spaghetti noodles in China!  Yep, like the Greek guy in My Big Fat Wedding, whenever I come across something that is great,  I attribute the origins to my ancient culture that must have invented everything at one point in time.
The Chinese people invented "ketchup, noodles and maybe even pizza" and other tomato dishes but it sure seems that Little star is really close to Perfecting the Perfect Pizza!
author: Curtis L.

description:
This place is dark and small, and come early or you will be waiting for a bit. Much better than the other location because this one has coupons. 

The wings were pretty tasty though a bit small. I didn't eat much because I wanted to wait for the pizzas. 

Come here to give yourself a little chicago v. ny pizza test because both are absolutely delicious. I got the little star deep dish and the italian thin crust. In the end, the deep dish slightly was better than the thin crust only because I love my pizza packed with toppings. The thin crust was crunchy and the pepperoncinis were my favorite. The deep dish needed more spinach though, all I tasted was the tomatoes (not saying it's a bad thing). 

Best Part: Leftover Lunch
author: Steve N.

description: Awesome stuff.  A uniquely terrific pizza, and the atsmosphere has always been terrific - a great mix of hipsters old and  young, stylish san francisco families etc. Really just a great time for all.  It gets busy, but worth the wait and fun to hang out on old overstuffed furniture while drinking a giant pint of Boont.
author: Eddie V.

description:
I always order Little Star to go. Today, I ordered 4 pies.  The Little Star, Chicken, the vegetarian, and the classic.  They were all amazing.  I heard today that they are opening a shop near Zachary's Pizza in Berkeley.  The guy at the counter said, "It should be some good competition".

I think not.
author: Jay S.

description: Amazing deep dish pizza. The garlic bread was also amazing and super cheesy. Would definitely go again. Only complaint was that its a bit noisy.
author: Kyle J.

description:
Dang good deep dish!  Not sure why people come here to order thin crust, but more power to them.  Personally I can't get enough of the crust here, so much more tasty than Zachary's even though I think the inner portion of the pie might be better quality at Zachary's.

Downside is that it always takes a while to make the pizza (30 min if memory serves) and there is usually a wait.  The restaurant is small so get there early to beat the rush, you don't want to be standing around waiting for people to order and then wait for their pizza to be made!

If only I could find a place with Zachary's quality ingredients with Little Star crust then I would have a 5 star place.
author: Stephen H.

description: I can tell that if you like deep-dish pizza, this is the place for you. I enjoyed the atmosphere, and the staff were very obliging on this unseasonably hot day with multiple pitchers of water.
author: Jamie S.

description:
huh?  how did i overlook this review?  my goodness...i ate here a few months ago and i can still remember every bite of my brass monkey pizza.

best damn deep dish pizza on the west coast...beats zachary's by a mile!  the brass monkey is not on the menu...it's pretty much the little star plus sausage.  don't underestimate a small pizza...one slice or maybe even 2 will be more than enough to fill you up!
author: Jen W.

description:
Heaven in your mouth! 

This place, IMO, has the best deep dish pizza in the world. I am not exaggerating! My reference points are Lou Malnati's and Pizzeria Uno in Chicago - they are arguably the best deep dish joints there.

I normally write more, but Little Star does not need to be talked up anymore - just go and enjoy, you won't be disappointed!

Tips: 
1. You can split your pizza e.g. Half "Little Star" half "Classic!"  
2. 1 large deep dish is good for 3 people without leftovers.
3. Don't bother with the thin crust, it's good, but just go for the deep dish.
author: Leo C.

description:
I prefer the location in Valencia better but the pizza is still delicious here. I feel like this location is smaller than the one on Valencia so the wait tends to be longer. I've been here multiple times and have had to wait over an hour each time. But the last time I came really early (at like 6) and there was no wait, so I was pleased, but then again I came on a Wednesday night. I brought my parents and they loved the pizza but they didn't like the dim lighting in the restaurant...

Anyways, on the recommendation of a friend, on Sunday, boyfriend's brother's girlfriend brought home the my favorite, the Little Star, but this time with sausage (deep dish of course) and it was AMAZING! I didn't think the Little Star could get any better but it did!
author: Jess H.

description:
It took me a while to actually try this place even though I just live like 3 blocks away. I was told by several people that it was pretty expensive so I just decided to stick with Escape from New York. One night though, a friend of mine was in the mood for good pizza and we wound up walking over to LSP. 
Fortunately, the wait was only about 5-10 minutes and the hostess was pleasant and helpful. We ended up getting a thin-crust customized pizza with mushrooms, onions and artichokes. I was really happy when they brought our pizza out and saw they hadn't skimped on the toppings like other places can do. The music was great, albeit a little loud and I realized I had to semi-yell at my friend across the table for him to hear me. In the end though, I'd definitely come back. The prices were NOT expensive, really. There was a good crowd, which is always indicative of a place that's intending to stick around.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Great pizza for the size and quality.  I wish they offer some bread while waiting for the pizza to bake.  My wife likes it alot.  

Will be back again.
author: David O.

description: The deep dish, Chicago-style pizza draws me here, the bar keeps me.  Order the classic to get a sense of the pie and get whatever IPA they have.  That's a Tuesday night in the can.
author: Jeff P.

description: This place has awesome pizza and the staff was really nice when I went there. We got a deep dish pizza with pepperoni, sausage, mushroom, and spinach and it was really good. The crust was crispy, but still a little doughy in the middle. I think there are a couple in the city, and if they are as good as this location, don't pass it by.
author: Brandon R.

description: Absolutely adore. A little noisy and sometimes the wait can be a little daunting, but great people and awesome pizza. We go about every other week (my boyfriend seems to have a serious love affair with their pizza)!
author: Sarah A.

description:
I had a thin crust pesto pizza and a salad. Both were yummy! The thin crust pizza does not have delicious crust, but the pizza itself was great. A small pizza easily serves two.

Very close to the Independent.
Nice for a first date.
Great cocktails.
Neighborhood is a little rough.
author: Kem K.

description:
Solid 3.5. Dark and cozy pizzeria on Divisadero Street. Good for dining in and serves great selection of wine/beer/light champagne cocktails. I would recommend for date night, but it is a little too cheesy for a first date. 

The order was: 

* Spicy Chicken Wings - Pound of wings served with baby carrots and blue cheese dressing $10.50 (4 of 5) Good flavors and spicy. Had spicy heat but it was not overwhelming. Tasty. And delicious with beer. I totally recommend this. 

* Half and half 9 inch thick crust (3 of 5) 
** Half Mediterranean Chicken - Chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bells, green olives, onions, feta $19.50/2 
** Half Classic - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells $19.25/2

So the 9 inch was a good size three people. There are six slices and it takes about 25 minutes to come to the table. Mind your timing. The dough was very different. The dough is probably the thinnest thick crust I ever tried. And the sides were very light, airy, and crunchy. Similiar texture to a biscotti, but with much more finer pores in the dough. The sauce was chunky with lots of tomatoes. And I though this chunky sauce perfectly complimented its crunchy crust. It reminded me of how well the Tostito Scoop works with a scoop of thick salsa. It just holds the fillings perfectly. It was amazing dough and sauce. But the pizza fillings weren't strong enough for me. I ordered half and half, but I could barely taste the difference since both sides were heavy filled with the chunky tomato sauce. It looked like they lined the pizza with the cheese, then the fillings, and then topped it with the chunky tomato sauce. When it is presented on the table, you just saw a lot of tomato sauce. No doubt, it was good crust and sauce, but I don't feel like I tasted any  sausage or chicken.  

On another note, there was lots of cheese on the bottom layer of the pizza and I find myself twirling the cheese 3 to 5 times before I was able to break it off. This pizza is definitely a fork and knife kind of meal.

This was a darling fun place and if you are a fan of thick crust and lots of tomato, I  definitely recommend trying this place.
author: Janice T.

description:
As a (close enough to) Chicago native, I had my taste buds tantalized by the REAL DEAL Chicago deep dish at an early age and pretty consitently until I moved to California.  So when I tried Zachary's and loved it, and then people told me I *had* to try Little Star, I was sure I was going to be in for some out of this world pie.  High expectations... they get me every time.

We ordered take out, and the 30 minute wait was very reasonable for our three pizzas.  If I had eaten these sumptuous-smelling beauties right away, I'd probably be singing a different tune in this review.  Instead we had to wait about 40 minutes to get to someone's house before chowing down.  By that time, the crusts were a little soggy, the pies weren't as hot, and I just wasn't feeling them.  

The flavors were really good though... we got a Little Star, Brass Monkey (just LS w/ sausage), and Vegetarian (all deep dish - HELLO).  The tomatoes had a smokier, roasted flavor than most other deep dish sauces I've had, and I loved the ricotta-feta mix on the LS pies.  The roasted zucchini was excellent on the Veggie.

In all my years of eating pizza I've realized that pizza is just better when it's fresh, or when it's a day old and you eat some out of the fridge for breakfast.  Anything in between is just a gray area.  If you're getting take out, then TAKE it OUT of the box right away.  Eat on the street if you have to.  Better yet, suck it up and wait for a table - that's what I'll be doing from now on.
author: Laura B.

description:
2 hour wait was worth every bite of their deep dish pizzas! 

You are in for a treat because you'll leave this restaurant 10 times happier before you stepped foot inside this busy place. :D

I took a quick nap on their comfy chair while my friends  awaited for our pizza adventure.   They kept mumbling, "Their pizza better be worth the wait!" 

Before we were seated, we asked the friendly hostess on how much food to order.  She recommended to get a salad and 2 small deep dish pizzas.  We thought to ourselves, "We can totally eat more than that!"  

So, my friends and I got greedy and ambitious with their portions.  We thought that we can finish a salad and 3 small deep dish pizzas. Guess what?  

We were dying of happiness because we were so full after eating 2 and 1/2 slices.  We ended our thought process by saying, "The hostess knows what she is talking about. We'll listen to her next time." 

So...
All the waiting is definitely worth it! 
And...
I recommend to bring a book/magazine, play games on your iPhone, walk around Divisadero with your buddies and just enjoy every bite you take on that delicious pizza from Little Star! 

For a place called Little Star Pizza, they deserve a 5-star review for their excellent taste of pizza and service! 

Happy Yelping!
author: Deborah C.

description: Updating my review from before. Why, because after two years i have only grown to love this place more and more. The food never ever fails, the staff, hey owners how do you find all these killer employees? i own a business so i know how hard that can be. I swear every person we have ever met that works here is so nice, so accomadating. They do an amzaing job of setting expectations and just seem to love working here. Everytime they tell us 30 min, it ends up being 15. a good deal of the time we just order to go and walk home but we also enjoy kicking back and catching the show. Loud, yes, still kinda loud but its a small festive place and its a really good loud. But thats just because its so dam good and everyone is so happy to be here.
author: Dennis K.

description:
Let's be clear. I hate pizza sauce. I despise "saucy" things. I deplore red sauce. Ok, that was a bit dramatic, but seriously, I could forgo sauce on a pizza all together, I really could.

I came here with a friend after she wouldn't shut up about it and I got hungry listening to her. The wait was expected but was minimal. Our waitress was a doll. She didn't hover (I hate that), but was attentive. We ordered the wings and the Little Star deep dish (we added pepperoni to it as well). The wings weren't spicy at all to me, however, I tend to be a bit of a spicy snob. They were good though, and I would get them again.

The pizza was made of unicorn laughs and glitter. Oh my gawd, the sauce didn't bother me in the least bit. It worked. It just freakin' worked. And all that cheese.

I love cheese.

Anyways.. THIS PLACE IS AMAZEBALLS. I will gladly be back. Time and time again. And I agree with everyone saying it's still completely delicious the next day out of the fridge or reheated.
author: D. V. P.

description:
First off, THESE DEEP DISH PIZZAS ARE CAKES

alright now that that's out of the way. We did have to wait 45 minutes for 5 people. I guess that's a little excessive for some places, but this place had minimal large tables so that's understandable. 

For five people we ordered wings, a small thin crust pizza and a large deep dish. The mediterranean chicken deep dish was outrageously loaded with flavors and goodness. The thin crust was just as good as well, just not as stuffing which was good because we ended up not finished in the end since there were three light-weight eaters. The hot wings were very good also.

The ambience of the place is very sociable and small. I like it that way, although there's only one shared bathroom for both men and women, so I feel sorry for the ladies. But I tried my best to keep it clean :)

Great pizza here, and their bar menu looked abundant but didn't order anything from there.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Aww! I just read the tues/wed night half off pizza with an appetizer deal! Dayam... Ah well, this place was worth every penny, but a pizza for $9??!! Woulda been amazing... 
Service was awesome, very nice, laid-back guys who look like they all ride fixies to and from work, welcomed me and my friend in and seated us right away. We ordered the spicy chicken wings (plentiful and YUM) and the small veggie pizza. I kinda regret not getting a meat pizza, but the veggie was absolutely DELISH. You know how you eat pizza and there's always the crusts on everyone's plate afterwards? Not with these pizzas! Cornmeal crust = completely devoured.  
Only downside was that it's very dark and LOUD inside, but it's so nice and chill, food is great, it's not deserving of less-than-five rating.
author: Christine Y.

description:
omg the wings are to die for!  (like crack the bone good) smokey and spicy, and creeps up on ya.  which i like.  cleaned them wings like i was back in the motherland.  

and i've never had pizza made of cornbread (cornmeal, whateves) before, which was a neat new experience. :)  
it was yummy good.  apparently i'm a fan of deep dish.  


they were out of garlic bread (i know, right!?!  smh). 
had the "classic" which was heavy on red sauce (blame my nona's) and didn't have a parmigiana/spices add on option.    but still a great meal.  walked out with leftovers, which are not the greatest the next day.  hot or cold.

that is my mark of good pizza.  whether or not they hold up to the hangover test.  





would love to try their more creative dishes, and probably will.  
i will be back for dessert.  both the cheesecake and the spumoni. (yes together!  what of it!?!)
author: Molly Razor S.

description: New favorite Pizza place in San Francisco!   Thin crust pizza excellent, I'm not personally a fan of deep dish but the other 3 in our party ordered it and raved about it. I also loved the cheesy garlic bread! (shocker!) I heard they don't serve this at the other SF location.
author: A S.

description:
Hungry?

this is the place to be. Little Star. 

Don't matter which pizza you order, each will be good. So good, you will order all of them to just to try it out. Love the deep dish. 

Took it to go a bunch of times and each time, the pizza is hot and right out of the oven.

A+ Thanks!
author: David L.

description: We ordered the little star pizza.  It was delicious, I hadn't tried a Chicago style pizza with a cornmeal crust before but I did enjoy it.  The tomatoes and topping were fresh and the service was very good.  I wouldn't hesitate to come back.
author: Joel W.

description:
I walked in expecting deep dish pizza on par with what I'm used to at Chicago Fire in the Sacramento area.  But when I took that first bite I realized what I had been missing all this time -- flavor.

The pizza at Little Star is has really good ingredients.  All of the ingredients in the pizza tasted fresh and flavorful; the sauce, the sausage, cheese.... 

Contrary to what many have said, Little Star does take credit cards.  Parking is a problem here, but we parked on Turk and walked a few blocks which wasn't a big deal.  

I would definitely stop by Little Star again when I'm in the area.
author: M K.

description:
Hopefully you get a seat, but don't worry, you can get it to go. If you are planning to get a deep dish and you might have to wait for your seating you can put your order in ahead of time so you don't have to wait the full 30 mins for your pizza. 

The seating is pretty close together, but again, don't worry you can handle it. The glasses that they give you for water, they look like they are the bottom halves of wine bottles. Pretty neat. The reason I noticed, I was thinking, why would water need to have the bubble at the bottom of the glass?

On to the pizza. It was pretty good. It's pretty similar to Zachary's both in quality and in price (I think). The large deep dish is $23.50. We also had the caprese salad which was about 6 slices of mozzarella cheese and a tomato sliced up accompanied with olives and the oil/vinegar mix ($9.50?). And to round out the meal, we had the garlic bread which was roasted garlic that you spread over the toasted bread ($4.50). 

There is a selection of alcoholic beverages that we didn't partake in, but they looked good. 

Will go back to this place at some point.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
This pizza.. this pizza ry hurr...
Ok.. so this past weekend I went up to the city with some friends to visit another friend whom is quite the food connoisseur in the city.. perhaps the ultimate "San Franciscan" ha ha. Pizza was on the menu and Little Star was the joint. 

We walked a few blocks into a darkly dimmed restaurant. Amazing art work on the walls great decor and friendly hostess. First good impression. The San Franciscan ordered for us which I had no complaints about, We went with the Deep Dish Little star I do not recall the other pizza & the Caprese Salad. I LOVE cheese so I knew I was in for a treat. When the food came , presentation was lovely and I couldnt wait to dig in. 

I am not the greatest of eaters in fact I waste a shitload of food. I tried my best to tackle this deep dish but I couldn't. Overall this place had some great pizza and caprese and I would love to come back here. Give it a go broooo
author: Valerie G.

description:
Best deep dish pizza, EVER!! Try the brass monkey it's not on the menu, but it's the little star with sausage added and it's quite delicious! 

Fun Tip: This place is cash only, but the fee on their ATM is only 25 cents!! How awesome is that?
author: Nathan J.

description: Top notch pizza. Quick service and delivery is a great option. Fresh ingredients, and the crust is perfect!
author: Linds P.

description:
Oh man, do I ever miss this place.

When I moved to LA I mourned the loss of Little Star. I can count on one hand the times I actually got a table there -- the fact that they don't take reservations really needs to change, 'cause standing around waiting for hours (literally, sometimes) for a table is ridiculous -- but you just get around that by calling in your order and walking there to pick it up if you live in the neighborhood. And then you can take it back home and watch a movie while you eat your Little Star deep dish, spicy chicken wings, or whatever else you decide to imbibe on that evening.

The chunks of tomatoes they throw on there for the sauce and the layers of cheese and garlic embedded in the toppings made me change my mind forever about my previous preference for thin pies. I had moved to San Francisco from New York, where pizza is praised for its foldable, gargantuan slices. I wasn't ready for the greatness of  a Little Star deep dish. I had to be persuaded, and it only took a few bites before I was convinced. 

Be forewarned, you will be THIRSTY after consuming those salty (delicious) tomatoes and that buttery crust. But that's not necessarily a bad thing, and it's a small price to pay for damn good pizza.
author: Tommy C.

description:
I'm not so into deep dish pizza but Little Star happens to be an exception.   Their pizza is DELICIOUS. I forgot what I had ordered but I know it was the vegetarian one, haha. The crust was soooo good and it was filled with veggies! They didn't put too much cheese or too little which was perfect. What I also really liked about this place is their garlic bread. The concept is really cool, they give you these pieces of bread on a plate and  this little garlic thing on the side. Then you spread as much garlic as you want. It's really awesome because then you won't end up with too much or too little.  Their salads are also really good. 

Another thing I absolutely love about this place, is the atmosphere. OHMYGOD, The artwork on the wall is amazing. I can't get enough of their paintings on the wall and the staff is really friendly and nice. I really do recommend that you go here. :D
author: Susie N.

description:
Gino's East and other Chicago Establishments... Come to Little Star to see how it's done!  Chicago pizzas put way too much butter in the crust.  It's like having dinner and dessert at the same time.  I even prefer Little Star over Zachary's for the simple reason that you can have more than one piece at Little Star..  All this said...

The thin crust blows doors off the deep dish.  Try both yourself and tell me I'm wrong.   Regardless, great place, incredible pizza, mellow vibe, very friendly staff.
author: Mike M.

description:
I swear, they should just start calling this area of Western Addition 'Little Star.' I know some call it 'NOPA' because of the restaurant down the way, but I'm gonna write a petition to the city! Every time I tell someone the coordinates of my new apartment, within about 3 seconds, I'll hear, "Awesome! You're right by Little Star Pizza!" Indeed, I am. Great for my tongue, awful for my waistline. I'm pretty sure I'm going to be 300 pounds by Halloween, but it's all good.

If you look up the definition of 'hype' in the dictionary, I'm pretty sure you'll see the Little Star logo as the image. Usually, that's a bad thing for me, as it's pretty rare that anything (food, movies, fast women) lives up to the hype before I end up trying it out. Lucky for me, Little Star didn't disappoint at all! Fantastic Chicago-style pizza, a cool vibe, friendly service, fun champagne drinks, good enough beer selection, and a pretty unique jukebox. Whoever put that play list together could rival John Cusak's role in High Fidelity. I chuckled to myself looking at the different EPs, imports and rarities. It's clear someone put a LOT of time into making it the most indie/emo pay-for-play machine in the city. It's also pretty clear that the curator is a huge fan of Blake Schwarzenbach, as every Jawbreaker and Jets To Brazil record was represented in that bad boy. Very good taste there, if I might say!

The wait was pretty long, but it's to be expected. I wish there were more room to enjoy a beer while waiting for your table to open without feeling like you're in someones way, but I guess there's not much to resolve that small issue.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
maybe our expectations were too high, the deep dish pizza was certainly good, but it didn't blow us away.

we got half little star and half cheese with meat. and the spicy chicken wings.

everything was delicious, and reasonably priced, but just wouldn't say it is the best pizza ever just yet.
author: Danielle A.

description: Spinach and ricotta pizza to go. I'm so happy to have friends that make these sorts of decisions for me.
author: Amy W.

description:
Alright, seriously, why is the pizza so good? 

I've been a Zachary's fan for quite some time. I was convinced that no other pizza could rival the flavor, fullness, and baked crust of the chicago style pizza Zachary's consistently provides. To put it simply, I've renounced my loyalty to Zach's and claimed LSP as the new rightful heir to the top chicago-style pizza in my heart. 

The feeling I experienced after leaving LSP could almost be equated to a conservative young man's eye-opening sexual experience from a freaky girl. You never really could have imagined something so great until it sneaks up and rubs you just the right way. And you're left with W =O W! (I apologize for the vulgarity, but its true!) On top of the really good toppings/sauce/cheese, its really the crust that did the sneaking up on me. It's crunchy and crispyness that really left me speechlessly anxious to taste it again. 

The service was great (kept our water carafe topped off at a moments notice), the price is a little cheaper than Zachery's (~$24 for a large deep dish special), and the vibe is chill and hip.

Just go. I can ramble on and on, but really you just need to go.

Thanks LSP for opening my eyes to heaven.
author: Dale C.

description:
Normally a thin crust pizza fan, but was in the mood for something with more substance. Having already tried (and enjoyed) Paxti's deep dish, decided to give Little Star a try. Overall, a quality and very tasty pizza. Went with the classic deep dish. My favorite part was the tomato layer on top. So fresh tasting with nice chunks of tomatoes. The cheesy sausage-y filling was also very tasty. Giving it 4 stars instead of 5 because of the cornmeal crust... Sounds like it should be delicious, but it was disappointingly dry, hard, and flavorless. The crust is normally my favorite part of the pizza, but this one actually got left behind on my plate. 

Take-out from the Divis location was mostly convenient -- had to call a couple of times to get past the busy signal. Ordering was quick and was told it'd be ready in 30 minutes. Mildly annoying wait in line behind 3 other take-out pick-ups. 

Overall, happy with this place. If only could substitute the Paxti's crust, we'd really have a winner.
author: Melinda H.

description:
Imagine what a pain in the ass it must have been going out in the 70s and 80s.

All the crap you had to bring.

- Roll of dimes for the payphone
- Stack of 8-tracks or tapes to listen to
- Thomas Guides and maps
- Book of checks (for bail, just in case)
- Stack of cash

Now look, today, it's much easier

- Dimes?  Umm, cell phone
- iPod
- GPS
- What's a check?
- Credit & ATM cards baby

The need to carry around all that nonsense has been replaced by technology.

So, when I come across an establishment that only takes cash, I can only assume they are just plain lazy or have a need to keep things off the books.

Luckily for me, Little Star has an ATM machine in the place so I wasn't totally hosed.  

That being said, the pizza was pretty good.  The place was packed so we got it to go and just trekked back to the house.

I'll be back (with stupid cash in hand) to try the deep dish because that looked pretty deadly.  

In a good way.

Liquidity.
author: Archie R.

description:
Never was a fan of deep dish pizza until I tried Little Star's.  Cheesey, saucy, with the trademark cakey, crunchy deep dish crust, it's a messy decadence of pizza goodness.  It's one of the few times that you can be excused for eating pizza with a knife and fork.  The crust is what makes it a standout.  It's full of flavor and not too dry and not too greasy like the chain deep dish places such as Uno's.

Great wine and beer selection to pair with your pizza.  Good selection of pies for both canivores and vegetarians alike.
author: Mike B.

description: BEST DEEP DISH PIZZA I HAVE EVER HAD**We had the Mediterranean Chicken and I will be back for more!!! Great atmosphere and super friendly workers!!!
author: Jan G.

description:
I grew up on Zachary's, but Little Star is a different animal. Make me choose between slices and I'll take Zachary's. But will I turn down Little Star? No way.

The distinctive spin on Little Star's pies is the crust. Their toppings aren't really the strong point, unlike Zachary's, whose flat sausage should be sold at corner stores worldwide. It's funny because Zachary's "weakness" (crust) is Litte Star's strength, which makes both at home in the Bay Area.

My favorite part is where the melty cheese bonds with the sinfully crisp crust at the base of the pie- WHOA! Joey Lawrence moment. 

It's a must try.

******************************************

In hindsight, I also wanted to add that I do NOT recommend their thin crust pizza. Little Star excels at thick crust, but disappoints with thin. Thin crusted pizza must be on the menu to satiate the 10% of people who don't like Chicago style and are being dragged to Little Star by their friends.

Also, when it comes to toppings, less is better. If you add things that release water as they cook (like mushrooms), your crust will likely be more soggy. I wouldn't rule out a "Brass Monkey" (Little Star with sausage), just know that your pizza will be wetter than a pepperoni and cheese. 

Last pointer: don't get chicken on your pizza. I've tried it in the deep dish and it ruined the whole pie. It tasted very game-y and out of place.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Jukebox
 More upscale pizza joint
 Garlic cloves 

Back tracking 20 miles when leaving San Francisco to find this goodness...was well worth it. 
I couldn't decide on thin crust and the beau couldn't decide on deep dish. Leaving us no other choice we decided to get both. I wanted mine with pepperoni and was not let down. Little star had the best crust that I have tasted. Little star needs to come to Los Angeles!!!! I didn't want to finish it my food, just so when my trip was over and I finally got home at 2 in the morning I could dive into this masterpiece that was called pizza. Happy campers we were the whole way home:)
author: Amanda G.

description: Order the little star pizza and be amazed. This is some seriously good deep dish and I'm a NY style lover myself. We tried the thin crush and the deep dish and the deep dish blew it out of the water- the little star is my fave.
author: Caroline D.

description:
Saucey, cheesy, mushroom, sausage, pepperoni, deep dish pizza with crust that is flakey. The good kind of flakey though, not the type where your date blows you off. (Although that could be enjoyable in a different context.)

Do yourself a favor and stop whatever you're doing. Head over to Little Star's right now, it will probably be the best decision of your life. If not that, at least your day.
author: Jordann G.

description:
I love the deep dish pizza. For four people, we got:

* appetizer: buffalo wings (~$8) pretty standard. Not spicy at all. 
* one large deep dish: 1/2 classic and 1/2 little star (I think the lg deep dish pizza is ~$23 which isn't too expensive for a deep dish pizza)

The pizza is amazing!!! I also love that they let you do half / half.. 
I'm getting myself confused, but one of them is more meaty with sausage bits, while the other is more vegetarian (eg. spinach / ricotta cheese, mushrooms, etc). I liked both.. but if you have guy friends in your party, may want to consider the meaty one of the two! 

On a side note - they also have DELICIOUS pear cider for $4 / glass.

Con:
1) Parking here is a NIGHTMARE! There are no garages, very hill-y, and street parking only!

2) They don't take reservations OR call-ins.. meaning, you HAVE to show up and wait around.. we arrived at 8pm on Saturday night and ended up waiting about 50 minutes! :(
author: Sarah C.

description:
Just like when a movie gets a lot of hype the expectations go up and I leave feeling shorted.  I'd basically put the expectations in your back pocket when going here.  It's a decent pizza, but not the greatest.

The crust is very "corn mealy."  The deep dish is good, on par with Zachary's.  Overall I think Escape from New York is a better tasting pizza 

Also, the service I've had at Little Star was a little rude.  Not horrible, but noticeable.
author: Bobby B.

description: Arrived early to get a pizza cooking while we waited. The place is small and the atmosphere is fun, but don't expect much privacy. We had a cheese deep dish pizza and a thin crust white pizza, both were delicious, but the deep dish had too much sauce on it for my taste. It looks like they put a thick layer on top of the deep dish pies. I slid a little bit off the top onto my plate and I was good to go. tasty crust too. Arrogant Bastard on draft.
author: J D.

description: REALLY good pizza.  Their vegetarian deep dish is absolutely delicious!  I'd probably go all the time if parking wasn't such a headache in that area, but maybe that's a good thing lol.
author: Nick K.

description:
FINALLY made it to Little Star!

We love deep dish pizza and Little Star does a great job.

Ordered the garlic bread (yum!), the thin crust pizza special with prosciutto and other stuff (yum!!!), and the Little Star deep dish (yum!). I'd definitely recommend all three, with an emphasis on the thin crust special. 

Glad we made it! We'll definitely come back to try the chicken wings and grub on another of the thin crust pizzas. The deep dish was good but we still prefer Zachary's and Patxi's...sorry!
author: Tysen C.

description:
I've had Little Star take out before, but last night I had it for the first time on site.  We had the The Classic and The Mediterranean. One interesting thing about Little Star's Chicago style pizza is that it does not fill you up leaving you in a food coma like other places.  

I'm a bigger fan of Patxi's in Hayes Valley, but Little Star isn't bad if you're in the Mission looking for some good deep dish.
author: Peter W.

description: Not generous in the amount of toppings. The garlic bread is very good. I was expecting thin crust pizza to be much crunchier. For the price I would recommend Victor's Pizza on Polk St or even Uncle Vito's Pizza on the corner of  Powell St and Bush St.
author: Andrew M.

description: So I tried this place out because I was in the area and read some of the reviews on this place.......and boy am I glad that I did cause quite honestly this is the best pizza place that I have come across and eaten at in my time in California!!!!!........I thought that I would be forced to live a life without pizza since all of the places that I went to have really sucked and couldnt compare to back home in Jersey but alas I will be able to eat pizza again.......unfortunately its a 5 1/2 hr trip from Burbank but definitely worth the trip........and although they added that crunchy flaky stuff on the pizza which I have tried and hated before on this pizza it actually works and add a crunch which I surprisingly enjoyed......but yea great sauce, great cheese, and just and all around a great pie!!!!!!........I freakin love this place.......and recommended it to anyone who wants good pizza......oh the only thing that irked me about this place is that there was an influx of ppl eatin their pizza with forks and knives.....like really people?!?!......well ok I am done here.....lol
author: Mardoqueo L.

description:
Excellent pizza, both thin and thick, and a great selection of beers on tap.  It's a real neighborhood institution - perhaps more with families than with the hipsters that are moving into nopa in a big way.

A bit noisy, and sometimes the wait for a table can be a bit long, but very pleasant.
author: Nick C.

description: Excellent deep dish pizza with interesting combos.  Fresh garlic with the garlic bread.  They have cheap PBRs too.  We came right after work on a weeknight, so there was plenty of space.  Will try again!
author: Kim K.

description:
Deep dish or thin crust? Why not, both? I love Little Star on Divis. This place melts my socks. If and when in doubt and whenever you're in the East Bay, Zachary's would be the victor, as well. But my heart belongs to Little Star in SF. 

I love the chicken pesto thin crust. 
Chicago style pizza..ahhhh, I can only eat if not one, but two slices and I'm done. I personallly love the Mediterranean Chicken or the Combination.

Cornmeal crust all the way, baby!

Just be sure to bring cash with you, be diligent when looking for parking and make sure your appetite is ready and willing!
author: Mika D.

description: With 1,800 reviews what else really needs to be said? Personally, this is the best pizza I've ever had. EVER. All other pizza joints take note. I'd scream it from the rooftop if you asked me to. Word.
author: Teresa R.

description:
I went here with my bestfriend after a good six months apart.  It was the perfect atmosphere to just sit back and catch up.  

Truth be told, on this particular Friday night, the line was loooooooooong.  We ended up waiting about 45-60 minutes after the host told us that it would be more like 20 minutes;  as an "i'm sorry," the manager bought us a round of beers.  This kept us happy until our table opened up.

When we ate, the pizza was out of this world.  The crust was made of corn bread (I know!) and the cheese was savory unlike most other Pizza joints.  It was definitely memorable.
author: Bryan H.

description: Patxis used to be my favorite pizza place, but they stopped making the cornmeal crust. HOWEVER, Little Star did not! Delicious. Get there early though because the wait can be incredible. Well worth it.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
For my SF pizza fix, I'm definitely going out of my way to come here. 
I love this place, the pizza and the style. It tastes a lot like home, which isn't the East Coast or Italy, so it must be Chicago style - which is delicious. 
Great selection of off-the-wall toppings, so you don't get bored with sausage, cheese and pepperoni. (Although I do love their sausage).

I highly recommend the classic and the veggie with the feta and spinach. :)
author: Candice T.

description: This place is really good, but beware the pizza is definitely exotic, the parking is hard to come by and the place will be constantly crowded.
author: Seth G.

description:
My family and I really liked this place! 

I've never had this type of Pizza before, but it was delish!

Service/Establishment: Give it a two thumbs up.  It is very clean and the sevice is great!  The joint is dark and that gives it a relaxed mood. 

The Pizza: we had a pepperoni & basil and that was awesome.  The sauce has the right tangyness for my taste and the cheese was great too.

We will definitely will be coming back to this Pizzeria!
author: Johanna L.

description:
Maybe we were lucky.  I had envisioned dining on divis, on a Friday @ peak dinner time, to be a nightmare! Like I said we were lucky.  Parking: right in front.  Seating: waited maybe 2 minutes.  Lucky indeed!

My party of three started with 2 appetizers (which, for me, aren't necessary because I want to fill up on delicious pizza!), the salad with gorgonzola and walnuts, and garlic bread.  The garlic bread is a bit deconstructed.  You are given a roasted head of garlic, warm bread and a butter/olive oil concoction.  Little Star's version of garlic bread was great.  The roasted garlic that you spread on the bread really makes this a stand out.  
  
As for the pizza, we ordered the thin crust special (garlic, mozzerella, heirloom tomatoes, basil, prosciutto di parma) and the classic deep dish.  The classic deep dish is always consistently delicious! But the special, OH MAN! I almost didn't want to order it cause my fav is the deep dish, but it was outstanding.  The ingredients are so simple but they each add something to the pizza.  If it's a special next time, I will definitely order again.

Service was quick and friendly.  Leftovers are still delicious the next day!
author: Lesliegh H.

description:
Mangia! Mangia! Mangia!
I would come here IF:
You love carbs
You are wearing your fat pants
You are willing to wait 40 minutes for your pizza.  It takes about 5 minutes to order, 30 minutes for it to cook and another 5 for it to be delivered/cool down and enter your mouth.

Its a great place to come with a small group and definitely a place to go if you are close friends.  Sometimes the wait can be pretty long and with new friends you might have to deal with an awkward silence that can only remedied with alcohol...which isn't a bad thing.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Sure, the wait was long and the service took a while, but that's pretty standard with any restaurant with 4+ stars on yelp.  A bonus was that they put the order in for our pizza while we waited, so our wait once seated wasn't nearly as long!

The food was really good - tasty deep-dish (and no extra charge for splitting toppings - half no meat!), delicious garlic bread (basically a mini pizza, and creative drinks.
author: Alyxandra D.

description: Went there with a birthday party....table for 9.  They set us all around a table meant for 4.  :( We proceeded to spend hundreds of  dollars.  Yes, hundreds!  Then the server asked us if we could hurry up & leave because they had a big group coming in.  Huh? Thought we were a big group grouped around a tiny table.....  I don't care how good the pizza might be....the service was disheartening!
author: Darby P.

description:
We had to wait 15-30 minutes, but the nice thing with them is if you order their Deep Dish, they'll pre-order it while you're waiting and when you finally get a seat, you'll get your deep dish pretty quickly after sitting. Great Idea Little Star.

As far as the food goes, I got their Little Star Deep Dish LARGE, it was really good, the tomatoes on the pizza were tangy, but what made the pizza was the crust. Definitely a winner here. It's one of the best that I have. I would say that their crust is better than Zachary's over in Berkley.
author: Eric A.

description:
Little Star is great. I've only been to this location, but the pizza is really delicious. I don't really "prefer" deep dish pizza, but I don't mind it as much here and I like their thin crust a lot. 

If you're feeling especially hungry, the garlic bread is really good (they roast the garlic whole and you spread it on the bread yourself),. I like their cheese salad (aka caprese) too. 

Cash only, but I think they do have an ATM in the restaurant, and on a hoppin' night, you could be waiting for a really long time. I've gone with two people and had to wait an hour or so after 9pm, but I've gone with one other person and we were seated immediately.
author: Abbey S.

description: Delicious! There was no wait at 5:30pm, and the service was fast. Started with a mixed greens salad, had the Little Star Deep Dish and was stuffed after two slices. The atmosphere was relaxed - lighting is dim - though it is noisy. Quality beer selection.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
This place is CRAZY. a large deep dish weighs in at 5 lbs. i recommend you come here with an appetite.  

we started with hot wings (super delicious with just the right amount of spice, think peppered chicken wings not.. hot saucy wings) and got a large brass monkey (a little star with sausage).  yum yum yum :)

good stuff.. i recommend it!
author: Elaine G.

description: Cute location, yummy deep dish pizza that tastes fresh and not super greasy, great salads... if you're in the mood for deep dish, this is the spot.
author: Richa A.

description:
I found myself just chilling in San Fran, and I was able to stop by with a group of about five people.  We didn't have an appointment for any and we were pretty loud.  However, we ended up with an amazing hostess (she had big glasses) and she really made the whole experience for us.

The food was also exceptionally well-made!  

The next time I'm in San Fran, I am point it a point to return here!  5-stars!
author: Austin W.

description:
Let me just put this out there right up front.  YES, IT'S BETTER THAN ZACHARY's.  Waaaaay better.  In fact, Little Star pretty much turns Zachary's around, bends him over and has his way with him.  And I live in the East Bay... sadface.

I still prefer the ol' thin crusted 2D slices of heaven that make up a good NY pizza, but for deep dish, it doesn't get better than this.  I am spoiled.  I can never look at that over-sauced, tomato-y mess that is Zachary's ever again.  It's all in Little Star's crust - that dry but buttery, crispy crust.  It has the perfect cornmeal texture and that ooey gooey cheese is the perfect foil to just the right amount of crunch when you bite into it.  It's popular so be prepared to wait.  At least they have cheap booze.
author: Virginia L.

description:
The cheese and tomato sauce in the deep dish pizza tasted good, but the crust resembled that of a pan crust pizza in appearance and texture, and really wasn't that deep compared to what you would get at Patxi's.  I would go back to try their thin crust pizzas and other appetizers (the mixed salad was light and tasty), but think I will stick with Zachary's or Patxi's for deep dish pizzas.

Service was attentive and efficient.  We were also seated sooner than expected (party of two) on a busy Friday night.
author: Jenn C.

description: What a great little treasure to find.  I was surprised by how delicious this place was.  It tucked away so you really wouldn't notice passing by, but I'm glad I found it.  The pizza is amazing!!  You will love how the crust taste and the cheese is so yum.  The customer service was excellent!
author: James P.

description:
A great spot for pizza that is a little different than a normal pizza place. It's ambiance in the restaurant is awesome and the service is great. The wait can be lengthy though, so plan ahead. 

The thin crust is delicious and they have a lot of great flavors as well as the usual pizza toppings. While I didn't try the deep dish, it looks amazing sitting at the table next to us. I've never seen such a thing!
author: Danica N.

description: Best deep dish pizza I've ever had!! Loved the crust!!
author: Christie S.

description:
It isn't until you break out of your rut that you realize you were in one the whole time. Just as we know (now) we don't live in a geocentric solar system, phrenology is hogwash, and brunettes are hotter than blonds, so too can pizza be served up inside out, made of strange new ingredients, and is still absolutely fantastic.

I suppose to clarify, I have never had an "authentic" Chicago style deep dish pizza before. (My assumption was that elusive beasts were only found in the frozen wastes of the windy city) Hence I never bothered searching one out. If you've read my previous reviews, they characterize me as a pizzian (is that a word?) neophyte, used to chewy crusts, pasty sauce, and copious amounts of cheese.

I was intrigued by Little Star from the get-go. No lunch hour (opens 17:00), cash only, just two sizes of pie (sm and lg), no delivery, and where some parlors will put anything on as a topping - they've relativly few(although good).  As every girl knows, restrictions, scarcity, and mystery are all that more a turn-on. Why all limitations, yet no shortage of people willing to sell their first born for a LS pie? hmmm.

So, a beer and a pizza later, I have my answers. They do the cute Chicago thing, with the toppings under the cheese, under the sauce, all in crust that's kinda like a dense cornbread, fried up all crispy from being done in a pan/deep-dish.  I have to say, I like pizza as a knife and fork kinda food (hey, I could go on a date here!) and you really have to, with the pulpy sauce now unbound by cheese, it can get messy. It was a unique pie, for me anyway, I really liked having all the gooey cheese and toppings contrasted with the crunchy crusty. 

As for everything else: the wait for the food was rather lengthy, but that's normal with pizzas done like this I suppose. It'd be a good time to have a chat with someone(s) over a drink or two.  The service friendly and astute, among a ambiance resembling a cross between Pizza Hut (those red glass table candles) and a hipster coffee house (mixed media/found materials artwork all over the walls). 

As a specialty pizza place, I was impressed and will return.
author: Sarah M.

description:
they have a great selection on pizzas and other things. 

we started with their caprese salad which was nicely prepared and toothsome, I couldn't help it but wanted more bread with it!

pizzas:

special meatball thin crust pizza: I'm not a huge fan of meatballs but they did a very nice job finding the mid-point; it still had the moist meat without being too heavy.

the highlight of the evening was their Mediterranean chicken deep crust pizza.
everything about it was just delicious, had a nice texture and even the temperature was perfect.

I would surely visit again for more.
author: Sung C.

description:
Can an East bay kid fall in love with Little Star? 

I had dinner here this past weekend with the siblings, and because I had heard so much about it, I was pretty intrigued. However, my deep dish heart was already taken years ago by Zachary's.

It's easy to miss on Divisadero, so keep your eye out, but parking wasn't too bad. If you stay patient in the neighborhood behind LS, you'll be just fine.

My sister had a hankering for some wings, so we invited a plate of them to the table and they were delicious. Not your traditional wings dunked in a bath of lava, but more with a nice spice rub on them. The blue cheese dipping sauce gave it a nice bite, but I have to say a wings plate without celery sticks is a bit odd...

Moving onto the pie. We ordered a large 'Classic' ( Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells ) and it was fantastic. You never saw anything become extinct so fast.

What makes the pizzas here different than Zachary's is the crust. The cornmeal crust is simply amazing. Great crunch, a slight hint of flavor, but keeps the heavy pie in its place.

BUT, I still have to give it to Zachary's! 

The filling at Zachary's is much more rich, heavy, and off course I'm grading on a slightly biased scale. However, Little Star is a hit. There's always room for pizza in my life, especially great pizza, and Little Star can claim the title of best deep dish IN San Francisco.

Not the bay...
author: Mike K.

description: We went to Little Star (Mission) on our first night and decided to end our vacation with Little Star again but at this location. The pizza is amazing. The sauce is robust, juicy, and aromatic. I would say the food here is better than the other location. However, the service felt a bit sub par. It could be because there were too many servers and hosts by the front booth for too little people on a Tuesday night. Felt like a high school cafeteria with the cool kids just chillin' and everyone else trying to eat. That said, if we were in the NOPA/Wester Addition 'hood, we'd totally come here. One of the best pizzas we've ever had, and this is coming from a New Yorker.
author: Fede O.

description:
Saw the little star on 7x7, came here to eat it, was exactly what I expected: damn fine pizza. I'm no pizza expert and even more, my preference is with the New Yorkers, but this was good enough for me to convert at least once every couple months. Try the little star, you wont regret it.

A little dark in there for my taste, what are they hiding in there?  But seriously, this place was darker than a nightclub... If it takes my eyes more than 5 minutes to adjust to your mood lighting, its too dark.
author: Phil C.

description:
Pizza. On Divisadero. We're on! 

Little Star Pizza's rocking some delicious pizza in their oven! Lots of cheeses and spices that make their pizzas a memorable one! 

It took about a 15 minute wait before my friend and I were seated. But the waiting area was cool, with comfortable seats so it was fine. The lighting is on the dim side, but overall a mellow and trendy restaurant. 

We ordered their special Mediterranean pizza with LOTS of feta cheese, LOTS of tomato sauce, herbs, chicken and LOTS of garlic! Perfecto!! The pizza was also a dish deep style, so taking a bite into the pizza was just great, great stuff!  

I rocked the pizza with a Cock and Bull brand Ginger Beer: a good drink with a lot of depth. Our server was also a cool guy with those earrings that make their earlobes hang. Awesome!
author: Melinda L.

description: Went to visit my best friend in San Francisco and this is the first place she took me, after picking me up at the airport.  The deep dish pizza with the cornmeal crust is like nothing I've ever had...now I crave it all of the time and it drives me crazy that I can't have it.  Why can't they make something like this in Texas??
author: Ivy E.

description: The review is long overdue. Boyfriend decided to surprise visit me this past Valentine's Day and picked up Little Star Pizza for our dinner on his trek to SF. Everything about it was super yummy. A little pricey but super filling. My boyfriend and I together ate 3 slices and he ordered the larger size. We had enough for leftovers the next day. Surprisingly, it still tasted great reheated.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Cute pizza parlor meets wrong order

It sucks that you can't have it all...always some good parts out of a whole...like 2 out of 3, 3 out of 5....you get the picture 

First time around and I wasn't too impressed with the pizzas here but since I'm seeing 5 star reviews I must've missed something?

It was a girls' night out with my fabulous 5. We ordered the Classic Deep Dish pizza with sausage, onions, mushrooms and it was delicious. However, having acclimated myself to deep dish pizza in Chi-town as a former chi-town homegirl and chomped on fabulous deep dishes in every corner...you develop a tongue for the finest 

However, I won't dismiss the fact that the pizza was pleasing because of it's juicy chunks of sausage, tomatoes. The aroma of the herbs surrounded your nose & the crust (my fave part of the pizza)....flaky & buttery.

Not so bad...let's just say another visit wouldn't be out of the question
author: Charmian D.

description:
I am loving this place. I got the white pie with garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, and feta. 

YUM. So freakin good! It was seriously one of the best pizzas I have had so far besides pizza in NY of course! We had to wait in line for quite a while since it was a Friday night, which we didnt really mind. It was well worth it.

Four stars for taste, price, and overall presentation and setting. However one star off for only accepting cash. But they have an ATM available in their restaurant.
author: Carissa E.

description:
To die for crusts and the tomatoes on the pizza have the perfect balance of acidity and sweetness. Yum yum! It's first come first serve and we luckily scored rock star parking in front of little star...and when we got to the door, our table for 10 was just about seated - talk about timing!! I could only eat one slice of the large deep dish (got the special with chicken sausage and garlic). The guys ate 3 slices - that's how large they are. Little Star is defn my fave deep dish in SF.  

P.S. bring cash since they don't take cards.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I am a fan of the pizza, and most of the waitresses there, but the little bearded manager is a little rude fucker! He has no concept of class, and customer service. 

When two people spend $80 dollars on a pizza,salad and wine for that little joint in this economy you would think he would have sense enough to be appreciative! Sure he offered to buy us a round of drinks not thinking that after a bottle between two could be enough if we were driving! But it was enough for him to turn a table I suppose. Love the pizza, not that guy!
author: Miguelito C.

description: Little Star Pizza is awesome.  I love their deep dish and thin crust.  I was so appreciative when they opened in my neighborhood and probably order take out pizza there once/week!  My 2.5 year old gets a full serving of veggies from the tomato on each deep dish slice. The "Little Star" deep dish is our go-to choice!
author: Nina K.

description: Deep dish pizza is on point.  The thin crust is good too!  I thought I would be able to eat more than one slice of deep dish but it ended up just being 1.5 and 1 of the thin crust.  The Little Star deep dish pizza had so much flavor and fresh ingredients.  Loved it.  It is very loud in there so if you want to have conversation you'll either have to yell or sit right next to the person you want to talk to.  Fortunately, I was with my roommates and we were already together the whole day so all we wanted to do was eat not talk.
author: Grace P.

description: Hands down best deep dish EVER!!! Must try the Brass Monkey and Mediterranean Chicken!!
author: Herb H.

description:
You've GOT to be kidding me. Little Star is President Obama's favorite pizza? 

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/mbauer/detail?entry_id=39245

Has the President tried Zachary's (Berkeley, CA), Patxi's (SF, CA) or even Giordano's in Chicago??? I'm sure he's tried the latter, but Little Star shouldn't be his favorite.

I guess my experiences with Little Star have not been the same as Obama's...sigh!
author: Heidi C.

description:
I listened to the advise of fellow yelpers and headed over to Little Star Pizza after catching the matinée showing of Wicked. There was a special going on at the time (buy an appetizer and get 1/2 off on your pizza) between 5-6PM. We walked in at exactly 6:00PM and the manager was kind enough to still give us the discount! 

We ordered the hot wings and the classic deep dish pizza. The wings weren't really to my liking - it was more of a dry rub instead of the saucy wings that I prefer. First off - let me just state that I am not usually a fan of deep dish, but this pizza was oh so delicious! The pizza was super cheesy and the sauce was soooo good. I've had pizza in NY and even their pizza sauce wasn't as delicious :)
author: Tej K.

description:
The first I'd heard of Little Star was from my sister, who is living in St. Louis (where we both grew up). A friend of a friend of hers had been out to San Francisco and loved Little Star so much that he wanted to start his own version of it back in STL. A little while after opening, Barack Obama happened to stop by while he was in town and made the place an instant hit when he named it his favorite pizza. I was very intrigued by this and decided to head down to Divisidero and try out the original.

The pizza is great! It's been a while since I've been there so I don't recall which one I tried. I do remember liking it a lot. It's not your typical hole-in-the-wall greasy pizza joint. They've put a lot of thought into their recipes and turn out a really high quality pie. The restaurant itself is really cute, dimly lit, and nicely decorated.
author: Aaron H.

description: Yummy!!!! and the service was great on Sunday afternoon!!!
author: Slone F.

description: I am visiting SF and I always try and check out a top rated pizza place while in town. After reading all the reviews I was pretty excited to check out Little Star, but I left extremely disappointed. Got the thick crust pizza. There was nothing wrong with the way the pizza was cooked. I just did not care for it. The sauce was a little marinara for my style. Only overall negative was that it felt like I was sitting in my neighbor tables lap. This place is tiny, but it seems this is a SF thing.
author: Randy W.

description:
I can't believe we stumbled onto this place.  It was a good suprise when we were tired and hungry.  Good pizza, good beer, good wine, and good service.  

The atmosphere is dark and lit by candles.  The water is served from a decanter into cups that look like (or are?) the bottom of a wine glass.  

There caprese looked beautiful, so we got it.  Of course it was good.  

It's a small place and when we arrived there was already a small wait.  We were seated quickly though, because we were only 2 people.  

I can't wait to go there again...
author: cyndi t.

description:
I hate pizza. Generally. But I ordered a dozen Little Star pizzas for my wedding.

This shit is for real. I don't know how authentic it is, but it's so tasty. Worth the wait--better for it. You want to be hungry.

The garlic appetizer is great.
author: Miranda E.

description:
I liked the thin crust pizza better than the stuffed;  that's a bad thing for a place that is trying to recreate Chicago-style pizza.  The crust on Little Star's deep dish is gritty and tastes very much like corn bread.  The crust on the thin crust was very good, however.  Overall, a decent pizza, but it only aspires to true Chicago pizza.

Sorry Little Star, but when it comes to deep dish pizza in the bay area, Zachary's puts the smack down on your ass.
author: Mark K.

description:
Best pizza ever.

I came here randomly before a concert at the Independant, only because a girl on the street told us it was the best pizza ever. 

She was right.

Man, this place is so good. My now-boyfriend and I got seated pretty quickly, and then 5 minutes later there was a huge wait. We got lucky. It must have been destiny.

We spilt the Vegetarian, because at the time he was. I, on the other hand, am a lover of meat. However, this pizza was bombtastic. Bombalicious, if you will. Their cornmeal crust is so good. Usually, I don't like deep dish pizzas but this one wasn't heavy at all. The crust was crispy, almost like a nice cracker. They put the toppings under the sauce and the cheese under the sauce. So it's kind of upside down. Which made the toppings warm even to the last slice. Nothing tasted dried out like other places. 

I need to come back here soon. Neeeeed to.
author: Melissa T.

description:
There is nothing little about "Little Star Pizza".  I'm giving it FIVE BIG stars!!  Why?  Because this eatery converted me from a thin-crust pizza lover to a deep-dish pizza fan (but ONLY for this place).  No exaggeration!  I have NEVER been a deep dish pizza fan.  All of my previous experiences have led me to "stereotype" deep dish as: Heavy, doughy, soggy and overly saucy with the overly-tangy-powering-tomato-sauce-marring-all-the rest- of-the-ingredients".  

In fact, every pizza place that I would go with family or friends, if they'd order deep dish, I'd always order a thin-crust for myself. But after seeing the high rating and reading the amazing reviews on Yelp about Little Star, I decided to "risk" it, and join my friends in eating the pizza they had ordered: the Classic deep dish.

Little Star tears down my "stereotypical walls" of deep dish pizza: the crust is deliciously crispy and thin at the bottom but crunchy enough to hold all of the savory concoction of sausage, mushrooms, bell peppers, and onions, altogether topped by a lightly sweet and tangy chunky tomato sauce.  Now that I am converted, my mission is to share with other "deep dish" unbelievers "Litte Star Pizza" and have them join me in a crusade.
author: Nadine M.

description:
Um, amazing... 

We waited an hour drinking blue star wheat and boont ale at the entrance of the tiny restaurant. We walked in at 7:30pm and man, was this place crackin!!!  No rush, this place is warm and cozy, perfect on a chilly November night. We had a group of 9 and the reservationist was really accurate in her timing. And no, they do not take reservations. Not even for big parties. 

An hour later we were seated, a group of 9 at a four top. We didn't care. The food looked too amazing for us to wait any longer.

We ordered two orders of the chicken wings, the classic pizza, and the pesto chicken thin crust pizza (both large) to share. EVERYTHING WAS PERFECTION. Deep dish pizza FTW... the tomatoes were ON TOP of the pizza so it wasn't super cheesy or overly greasy. The chicken wings were HOT and a must when you're having a beer. 

DEEP DISH PIZZA FTW! (I said that already, but it's important to emphasize it again!) GO NOW!!!
author: Lynn C.

description: This place is BOMB!!!!! Without a doubt favorite pizza place. Ever. Before moving to the city, I absolutely had to go to Little Star every time I came to visit. I am a deep dish fan, while the rest of my family like thin crust. We all get something we love here. Sometimes the wait can be a little long, but that's just a testament to how good their pizza is!
author: Matt M.

description:
I think i'm starting to salivate just thinking about this place. 

I'm not really a deep-dish pizza kind of person, so the first time my friend's ordered from this place I requested the thin crust. It was a whole other story once the pizza came. the sauce is cooked on top of the pizza, making it look and smell completely irrisistible.
