I skipped over the thin crust and gobbled down two slies of the deep dish, of course feeling bad that i was partially responsible for the leftover thin crust slices..but not that bad because seriously, this pizzaz is so good. I've had pepperoni, and sausage. Boring, i know. but it didn't lack at all in taste.

The only downside is that they don't deliver. So I only get to eat it if i'm in the neighborhood. BUT it's definitely worth it.
author: Natalie J.

description: The Food was amazing! The only reason it got 4 and not 5 stars is because their delivery charge was $6 and I had to use a third party delivery service. Everything else about the experience was amazing! I mean yes, it's very very expensive for what you get Pizza Size wise, but it is well worth it. Splurge a little and get Little Star, you won't be sorry.
author: Jason M.

description:
It is a seriously good deep dish pizza

I stopped in here on the way to see a show at the Independent and is one of the best options in the area. On the recommendation of the server my friend and I had the Little Star pizza. This was a delicious soft yet crispy crust and tomatoes that tasted like real, honest to god, grown on a vine tomatoes... I know, crazy right?

I only wish this place had better beer options. The options were not terrible but just a little boring for the quality of the food and the service.

Our server was a lot of fun to talk too and had a lot of great suggestions for us. This was over-all a very good experience and I will come here any time I see a show at the independent for sure.
author: Eric G.

description:
As the 1315th review, it'll be tough to be original. So, i'll glaze over how good the pizza was (get one thin crust, one deep dish), and instead share a story....

Towards the end of the meal, as we were sorting out the bill and waiting for the waiter to box the leftovers, a couple came and stood by our table. As I was sitting with my back facing them, I paid little attention. The other four members of my party were all getting a little weirded out about how close they were standing (probably three feet away). I suggested they were checking out the art hanging above the table, so we stopped paying attention. A few minutes later the waiter collected the bill and we left. Standing outside, waiting for a friend to use the bathroom, we noticed that same couple had claimed our table. When my friend returned from peeing he said that he overheard the couple saying, 
"See. I told you it would work. Just hover around the table and they'll stop talking and clear out." 

 I thought about going back in and correcting the guy, but I didn't. I went home, fell asleep, then bitched about it on Yelp. 

Such is the life of a 5'6" Jewish guy.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Maybe this isn't a fair review because I'm not a deep dish fanatic but I thought Little Star was good but not great. It was nice because my party was sat (and FOUR of us!) right when we walked in and everyone was telling me to brace myself for the wait. 

From what I remember, the drinks were good and large. 

Pizza was good; I liked the cornmeal crust. Toppings were definitely generous, it's just that I'm more of a bare bones pizza gal. Also, I was eating with a vegetarian so we only had veggies on our pizza (insert slightly sad face). 

Service was good. 

Again, everything was good but not great.
author: Alli J.

description:
I came here last night hoping to take a companion out for his birthday dinner.  Unfortunately, or shall I say fortunately (just kidding), I was unaware that the restaurant is *cash only.*  So I tried to go and run to the ATM, but luckily, my date had a stack of cash. 

I really wanted to try the deep dish as this is what Little Star brags, right?!  But we shared a small and you can't share a pizza with two different types of crust, so we went with the thin crust, since it was his birthday and that's what the b'day boy wanted.  

I was able to finally get another item off the 7x7 list.  #60 Brass Monkey Pizza.  It's listed on the menu as "Little Star Pizza," but the Brass Monkey comes with sausage. MMMMMM. It consists of spinach mixed with feta and ricotta cheeses topped with garlic, onions, and sausage.  So yummy.  

The only complaints I have is the noise level (I swear we were yelling at each other across the table) and the prices.  I mean $18 is a little high for a small, 12 in pizza.  

If I could, I would give it 3.5 stars, but I guess I'm going to have to go with 3.  I think it's too hyped up for what it really is.
author: Jenny W.

description: I've been to Little Star twice now and both times all I had to say was one thing... "Wow". Their deep dish pizza is so good it ought to be a crime. It has all of the arteriolar clogging life shortening goodness that comes to mind when one imagines Chicago style deep dish pizza. I've had the classic: sausage, onions, green bell pepper, mushrooms, and the little star: spinach, ricotta, mushroom, garlic, onion and both were fantastic. They have good beers on tap: California Anchor, Blue Star Wheat, Arrogant Bastard,  and a few others and a larger selection of bottled beers. Had the California Anchor on tap and it was good, tried the bottled organic Eel River Organic Porter which was fantastic. I'd say a large pizza feeds 3 - 4, or 2 with plenty of leftovers. One of the best pizza places I've been too and definitely on par with Zachary's of Berkley/Oakland. Just a heads up deep dish takes 30 min to bake after you order.
author: Tomas K.

description:
I found this place using Yelp and I am so glad that I did.  We arrived at around 7:30pm on a Thursday.  The place was pretty busy, but waiting wasn't a big deal, as it was only about 10-15 minutes.  They allowed us to pre-order our pizza while we waited.  When we got seated, we ordered a beer and the pizza was served five minutes later.  We ordered the 9" veggie for two people.  The ingredients were fresh and the crust was out of this world.  I'm not even a crust person!  The pizza was the perfect size for two people.

We also ordered their homemade cheesecake.  It was heaven on earth.  I don't even like sweets too much, but I do love cheesecake.  The cake was creamy, not too sweet, and best of all did not have crust on the "back" of the cake, which I loved.

9" pizza, two beers on tap, and a slice of cheesecake for $34.  Service was fast, friendly, and attentive.  I fully recommend this place.  However, as a caveat, it can get rather loud inside.
author: Matthew S.

description:
I despise businesses that only accept cash.  Especially when I place an order for pick up and realize five minutes prior to pick up time that I don't have enough cash to cover it, necessitating a sprint to the bank so I don't incur some ridiculous ATM fee and so my pizza isn't sitting around getting cold.  

That being said, the cake-like pizza I picked up was worth it.  I won't expound upon its many virtues because, let's face it, it's been done.  Over 1300 times.  But it's still getting a minus one star for depriving me of credit card points.
author: Jenny R.

description: What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said?! It's a great date spot and the food is consistently delicious. The staff is always friendly and accommodating and the service is always great! They have great beer on tap as well!
author: Liz B.

description:
Absolutely the best pizza I've ever had!  I would move to SF just to get this pizza on the regular :)

I'm a vegetarian so the Little Star, their speciality was perfect for me.  Left my tummy so happy that the little box of left overs we got was eaten before we made it home.

Perfect, would recommend it to anyone.  They also have some yummy drinks and beers to match that pizza.
author: Zoo I.

description:
I love pizza. I eat a lot of pizza. This pizza is fantastic. 

Though perhaps not a classic Chicago style, it is the best Chicago-style pizza I've ever had. The crust is both chewy and crispy like a shortbread cookie and their toppings are fresh and delicious, not to mention that their sauce is really good. They also have a couple nice salad options and cheap tasty wine by the glass.

The wait can be long, but you can leave your number, head down the street to Fly Bar for a drink, and return when they call you.
author: Sara W.

description:
Yay, they finally take credit cards... In fairness, they have for awhile now, but I am just getting around to updating my review to give them credit where credit is due (pun totally intended).

I should also mention that if you can squeeze it in, their cheesecake dessert is, for no apparent reason, amazing.
author: Aaron L.

description:
I love Little Star. We ventured over there last night (I got clipped in the arm by a cab on the way - SCARY!) and upon walking in loved that it was a cozy, dark atmosphere. I also love that they provide seating, other than the bar, for those who are waiting (I wish Starbelly had that). Regardless, we skipped the wait and sat at the bar. We ordered a $20 bottle of Sangiovese (all of the wines were very reasonable) and it was pretty good. 

For an appetizer we shared the wings. They were really tasty, especially for baked wings and had a nice amount of heat. I also like that they weren't buffalo style. I love buffalo wings but it's nice to have something different. 
For our pizza we chose to create our own - a sausage, mushroom and roasted garlic 12" deep dish. Deep dish is the specialty here and I hadn't had it in years. It was absolutely delicious. The crust was nice and crispy and  the toppings plentiful. The only problem was that we could only eat half! We realized when we picked up the box of leftovers why - the thing was SO heavy. It's definitely loaded with cheese - under the sauce, of course. 

Everything was great but I think next time, for a party of 2, we'll order a salad and a 9".
author: Natalie G.

description:
Well, I've been looking for deep dish pizza forever down in LA, ever since visiting my friend in Chicago a number of years ago and trying Giordano's.   My favorite place in LA is Masa of Echo Park.  But the last time I went there I was disappointed at the thickness of the crust (a 2" pie was prob 1 1/2" crust with some topping... NO)

Sadly I had to come to SF to get some good stuff.  

Went on a Saturday Night at maybe 8 and we got a seat immediately (lucked out)  Ambiance was cool, it had that laid back rocker vibe, but whatever.  I was there to eat. 

A friend and I ordered a large Classic (a lot, I know), and after nursing a Racer 5 pint for 20-30 minutes or so, we got the beast.  I loved it, definitely above anything in LA, much closer to the tasty toppingness of chi-town.  The crust was nice(~1/2 inch) and it's outside had a the nice cornmeal crispyness to it.  The tomatoes and cheese were also both excellent (tomatoes were juicy,  cheese was tasty and chewy)   We somehow ate the whole thing... that was probably not a good idea; I probably needed to run across town to burn that sucker off.  I wish I could have tried the Little Star (spinach pie with different cheeses) pizza... but to get that , well, we probably needed to bring like 4 other people.

Value is good;  you aren't really ordering much besides the pizza.  

Yeah... I would go there again.  5/5
author: Neil Y.

description:
I love Chicago style deep dish pizza and this ain't it.

Is it bad?  No, it's fine if you are into this sort of thing.  To me it's deep dish pizza by and for hipsters.  I guess I'm just not cool enough to understand. 

And yes, I have eaten real Chi-town pies, while in the windy city no less and if you want that taste in SF go to Patxi's.  It's just that simple.
author: J K.

description:
I hate to rip on this place.... BUT.... I thought this place was alright... wait time 45+ minutes to get seated... seating time to wait for food... 30 minutes... eat time 30 minutes... 

We ordered half and half of the Classic and the Little Star, I had the pom-pagne drink (pomegranate soda, sugar cubes, champagne), my friends had the apricot beer (not bad, smells yummy, taste is average). 

I don't think I like chicago-style pizza because it was too tomato-ey and not cheesy enough.. I liked the Classic more than the Little Star, more flavor. The crust is good, cornmeal is a plus! Crunchy crust is good to me. 

Maybe I'm more of a thin crust, cheezy pizza type of gal. :) But I'm happy I finally got to try this place. Prob won't come again considering how long the wait is... for both getting seated and getting the pizza.. Wish I could love it.. 

I'll stick to Seniore's on Taraval and Blondies on Powell.. cheezy goodness
author: Kristina L.

description:
I've heard about Little Star through word of mouth and then saw it on Check Please. After I watched it on Check Please I got a huge hankering for pizza so we decided to give it a go. We go there at 830 on Sat. night and boy was the wait long! The lady taking names said it could be 1.5 hours for a table... so unfortunately we had to leave because I was starving and would pass out...fast forward a week... 

Came back to Little Star on a Weds at 6pm - no wait!!! Yay! We were promptly seated and our server came by and gave us the special for the day. We ordered the caprese salad and a small brass monkey. Caprese salad was okay, nothing spectacular ... and finally after waiting and waiting our pizza came out! The small had 6 pieces... definitely enough for 2 people. It was soo good!!! I'm so glad I followed fellow yelpers advice and ordered this! The sausage was yummy as well as the other toppings. I loved the crust and it did not get soggy like other deep dish pizzas I've had in the past. The flavors worked well together and left me craving more after eating 2 slices. I was good though and took the rest home. Our meal was about $40 for two people..a little pricey but definitely worth it. 

If there is a long line, there's a takeout line off to the side you can order from. Also this place is cash only! They do have an ATM machine inside if you don't have cash on you.
author: Julie F.

description:
Well, I live a few blocks from this place and quite a few people have said that I HAD to try this place. The short story was that it was okay. It wasn't bad, it wasn't great. I had a thin crust Greek pizza, some "garlic" bread, and cheese cake. This might be splitting hairs, but the pizza was barely even cut! It was a game of trying to pull a slice off without all of the toppings coming off. The garlic bread, wow that was kind of a let down. A small loaf of bread (that again was barely sliced), with a huge chunk of garlic on the side. Granted it was homemade and fresh, but it was just okay. 
The other end of things...I didn't eat in, I had take out so I can't speak to that experience, but the staff was friendly and the transaction was very fast. As I have read in other reviews, the prices are redonkulous. Nearly $20 for a SMALL, THIN CRUST??? $5 for garlic bread? The cheese cake was really good, but I don't think that it's $6 a slice good, especially considering the size of the slice.
author: Josh S.

description:
This is one of my favorite pizza places in the city. They have great deep dish pizza. I have eaten there and done take out as well. Every time the pizza has been awesome. 

It's a small place and usually pretty crowded on the weekends. But be patient, it's worth the wait. 

Minus one star because they only take cash... They do have an ATM inside, but still its 2010....
author: Katie I.

description:
It's good... real good. The masses do not lie. If I were a pizza fanatic, this place might  flirt with 5-star status...

A group of five of us split two pizza's, one deep dish, one thin crust (more than enough food). I thought both we're delicious. The Classic deep dish wasn't too doughy, it had a nice crisp to it. The thin crust was uber cheesy, but in a good way. All the toppings were combined perfectly. 

Be prepared, we waited about an hour, which was to be expected on Saturday night at prime time. There are a couple bars near by to help with the wait.

Def a place everyone should try, and although they are know for deep dish... make sure to throw a thin crust in the mix, you will not regret it.
author: Blake W.

description: Let me preface this review by stating that I wasn't aware that I am not a fan of deep dish pizza. With that being said, everything else was delicious! We arrived for dinner on a Thursday night and waited about an hour. I was shocked at how busy they were on a weeknight! We decided to order while we were waiting in hopes of saving some time. Even if you don't want to order beforehand, take a look at the menu so you have some kind of idea of what you want. We ordered a large Little Star deep dish, a large thin crust pesto chicken (NOM!), chicken wings (NOM!), and a mixed salad (NOM!). The thin crust pesto chicken was the bomb! The thin cornmeal crust was a perfect vehicle for the fresh pesto, thinly sliced onions, moist pieces of chicken breast, and ooey gooey cheese. I don't care if Little Star is known for their deep dish pizzas, I'd solely come back for their thin crust varieties. No shame, no shame. Honestly, their deep dish isn't inedible by any means; I'm just not a fan! Will be back for thin crust pizza and chicken wings!
author: Audrey T.

description:
YUM, YUM, YUM!!!  I think I would go back to SF just to eat at this place again.  We went around 7pm on a Wednesday night and still had to wait about 30 minutes for a table.  So worth it though.  

We loved the garlic bread...they roast a whole bulb of garlic and you remove the soft cloves and spread them on the bread...so tasty!!  We actually had the thin crust pizza as my husband isn't a huge fan of deep dish and it was fantastic.  Would love to try the deep dish sometime.

I was amazed at the number of people that came in during our 30 minute wait to get their pizza to go.  On a Wednesday!

Service was great, food was great...if ever in SF again, this will be a must stop!
author: Melanie R.

description: I facef^&$ed the heck out of this pizza, if I could make love with food, I think I would need to be in a room alone with this pizza..
author: Heath L.

description: Met a friend at Little Star in January; it was a weeknight and we didn't wait very long. Thin-crust Classic, garlic bread, beer. The service was great! We were seated all the way in the back, it was cozy in a good way. A bit too dark, but I know some people like that. I'll return if I'm nearby and craving good pizza!
author: Amelia N.

description: Best Chicago style deep pizza in SF!
author: Helga S.

description:
I'm having a difficult time just writing this review b/c I'm starting to salivate. SERIOUSLY.  I'm dreaming about the melted cheese and mouth-wateringly delicious cornmeal deep-dish crust.  (nom nom).  It's the perfect base for whatever topping(s) you choose. 

Since we had bread and roasted garlic to start (yummy), my friend and I shared a small pizza that was half Brass Monkey and half Italian Combo.  It was the perfect amount of food for two people who also "had" to have beers to boot. 

I like the "Brass Monkey" despite the confusion about its name.  Are they paying homage to the Beastie Boys?  Or is it this the house's version of a liquid cocktail to which the song refers?  I'm a person who needs ANSWERS.  But I guess that still won't prevent me from ordering it again.  It's their "Little Star" (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic) plus sausage.  I'm not sure why SF has all these secret menus.  Why all these mysteries, Little Star? 

Back to the pizza - the Italian Combo was nothing special, but still very good.

The only downside of this place is the price, but you definitely feel full even after having one slice so I guess you get what you pay for. 

I will get the caprese salad next time. Okay, I'm hungry now.  @#$%^%^
author: S K.

description: This is easily one of my favorite restaurants on Divisadero. It's impossible to go wrong with the Chicago-style options, and the thin crust Greek is one of my favorite pizzas ever. Don't forget to check the specials!
author: Torsten L.

description: Yes yes yes! Soooooooooo good! Awesome atmosphere and service.
author: Danny M.

description: Screw calories! If you are on a diet, don't even bother coming here. I came here with 3 friends and split the Little Star (spinach, garlic, onions, feta, and love). Generally I am a thin crust lover, but the deep dish style here has converted me. The food is super flavorful and filling (the small size fed 4 of us). They also have a few beers on tap to wash down your pizza. So, so good. Because everyone else is privy to the deliciousness of the pizza here, there will most likely be a wait. At 6 on a Saturday we endured a 30 minute wait, but totally worth every minute.
author: Kim S.

description:
This is my daughters' new favorite spot. Although very small and dim, this place can hold its own. The Pizza is amazing, especially the deep dish. The salads are fresh and great and the wines are good, too.
This is a place where you cannot go wrong with anything you order. And by the way, they will not burn your pizza, unlike other pizza joints we have been to. Try it out, you will not regret it
author: Danny C.

description:
All time favorite pizza joints:

1. Little Star (SF)
2. Grimaldi's (NYC)
3. Gino's East (Chi town)

X-factor.......Little Star has world class deep dish and thin crust!
author: Ash and Alex J.

description: I don't like Chicago style pizza...except for this one.  It was amazing.  Not too doughy with a good amount of sauce and cheese.  I've had a lot of Chicago style and nothing comes close to this!
author: Mike F.

description:
Best deep dish in SF!  I haven't been to Zachery's in a while but Littel Star is amazing.  The corn meal crust has the best texture and flavor for a pizza crust.  I recommend the veggie and the Mediterranean special pizza's.  Be sure to order at least 30 mins before you want to eat because it takes a while to bake. 

If there is a down side it is that this place is so popular that getting a table is a hassle, so I usually order out.
author: Justin F.

description: Best pizza ever, hands down. Kicks ass. The cornmeal crust will blow your mind. Doesn't matter which pizza you order, it will be fantastic. Because it is no secret that this is the best pizza money can buy, the wait is usually an hour plus. We happened to snag a bar seat and got served immediately.
author: Rachael R.

description:
These people are serving delicious pizza.

I got to experience little star last night with a friend who was visiting the Bay Area for the first time. We were craving pizza, and who can say no to a place with 1000+ reviews and 4.5 stars?

Things went really well from the beginning. We were told we were going to have to wait 30-40 minutes, but were seated in less than 20.

We had a Large Classic Deep Dish pizza with pepperoni added. For an appetizer we had garlic bread.

I had never been served garlic bread like this and I was pretty impressed. They serve you sliced bread, a portion of butter and some perfectly roasted garlic. The bread and butter were great on their own, but that roasted garlic did not fuck around. I have a friend who is a garlic lover and puts hella garlic on everything. This roasted garlic brought me closer to understanding how she can be that way. 

The pizza was pretty incredible. Unlike Zachary's, Little Star's deep dish has a slight crunch to it. it's perfect. And unlike Zachary's, we didn't wait an eternity for it. 

Food wise, this place got 4 stars really. Little Star earned that extra star thanks to the waitress that served us. I've never had a more attentive and pleasant waitress or waiter in my life. She was like one of those moms that makes you feel terrible cause she's doing so much for you and you really don't want her to.

Although small, the beer selection is pretty good.
author: Brian S.

description: Our whole family agrees that this is some of THE BEST pizza we have ever had.The deep dish and the thin crust both are stellar.The thin crust was both a liitle crispy and a little chewy.HEAVENLY.The deep dish crust was an A+.It melted in your mouth.We ordered the thin crust and recieved thick.Glad we got to have them both.They were very nice and brought us another thin pizza also.Very accomodative.This is an extremely buisy sot so expect to wait.Not a bad idea to order in advance.Can't wait for our next round!
author: Lu L.

description:
Divisidero is a fun street to hangout on.  Lots of different venues and a whole lot of randomness.  

Stopped in for a quick bite after playing a round of golf.  The thin crust pizza is crunchy, sauce is well seasoned and the ingredients are fresh.

I'll have to try the chicken wings next time.
author: HY L.

description:
Too many hipsters! Look, the place is good but I have had MUCH better. Across the bay, Zachary's kills this place in the deep dish department and does it without all the coolness and trendiness that Little Star has. I can name 5 spots in downtown Chicago that would destroy Little Star (Edwardo's, Giordano's, Lou's, Uno's, Gino's). It's good for San Francisco standards, where everybody can pat themselves on their back and relish in how cool and unique this place is. But in my opinion, the deep dish is average, I just don't like their spaghetti sauce, err tomato sauce, that  they use for their pies. 

I will say that their thin crust is much better and tastier. The crust is very crispy and it has a good balance of cheese, sauce, and toppings. In fact, I would even say that it is in the top 4 for thin crust with Gialina, Pizzetta 211, Delfina, and A-16 battling for top spots. I would give the thin crust 5 stars and the deep dish 2.5. But I still can't get over the fact that one has to have the secret password, look at my cool tattoo on my wrist mentality. It is a fucking pizza parlor! Get over yourselves already...
author: Nick H.

description:
It seems for the past few years or so, there has been an epidemic amoung my close friends. It can only be described as a "quarter-life" crisis. The way many of us have been attempting to steal back a portion of our youth, has been by celebrating our birthday's the way we did when we were in elementary school. A few months back, a dear friend had an actual sleep-over where we wore jammies, played truth or dare and crank called boys. And for those of you drooling, yes, there was in fact a pillow fight.

All explanations aside, we decided to continue this regression with a pizza party birthday for our girl Allie last night at Little Star. First, here's the good...

--Super friendly and accomodating staff. Their corkage is only $10 so we brought about 6 bottles of our own and they had no problem opening up the champagne for us to enjoy in the lobby while waiting for our table. 

--Delicious Caprese salad. I make this at home about 3 or 4 times a week, so I know my stuff. 

--I dig the loud yet cozy ambiance.

--Portions were large and priced moderately.

Reading all of that, you might be asking yourself "Why the 3 stars Lynsey?" Well here it is, the bad...

--Cash only!! Come on people, this is the generation of speed and efficiency. This is a huge issue for me, as I've written before.

--Not sure I'm a huge deep dish fan. Not sure what it is...I liked it and definately ate every last bite...but there's something missing. Some sort of herb or spice. I found myself dumping hot pepper flakes all over it, which I usually do with original style pizza...but it just...needed something. Ya know?

--They would not seat us or even take our party number until everyone was there. Do they think I'm going to show up solo and claim to be a party of 6?? This doesn't make sense, and probably lost them some revenue. If myself and the other early people had been able to sit while we waited, we may have ordered an appetizer or even bought one of their bottles of wine.

All in all, it was a great night with the ladies reminiscing on our childhood, the food was good (not mind blowing) and we took major advantage of the small corkage. I'll probably check it out again down the road...
author: Lynsey C.

description:
There is just SOMETHING about a serious crust, deep dish, hearty pizza - paired with super cheap PBR that I like.  I think it's a genetic thing.

It's not New York, it's not Europe, it's just damned good.  and it takes a while.  and you can't order in advance.  but they have salads to bide the time.  and PBR.

It's really good the next day, the crust could hold up the world. in a good way.
author: Nate P.

description:
Went here on a Friday night and I must say one of the best pizza's I've eaten in awhile.  Ordered a large classic pizza which was absolutely delicious... figured out that the cheese is on the bottom and the sauce and stuff was on the top which left the crust nice and crunchy while leaving the toppings cheesy and warm.  

No point in saying what everybody else said on how good it was so here's some cons:

-HARD TO PARK, drove for like 25 minutes till hitting the jackpot.  
-TOO LOUD, not really a place to go and have conversation.  I could barely here myself think in there.  I felt like i was at a bar instead of a restaurant.  Go earlier in the day I suppose to avoid this.  
-NO DIVERSITY, as far as the workers and patrons. I was the only brown person there. LOL.

well the pizza was damn good.
author: roe n.

description: Best deep dish pizza I have ever had. The cornmeal crust is amazing. I LOVE this place. Highly recommend.
author: Brooke T.

description:
This little hipster haven was quite delicious.  Got the basic "classic" deep dish, so good!  Who knew that a corn meal crust could make me so happy?  
Plus the hostess was pleasant and our server had neat glasses.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
Pretty decent pie by SF standards.
The deep dish monsters in Chicago puts Little Star to shame though.

Do yourself a favor and take out.
Deep dish pizza takes a long time to cook and you'll make no friends sitting in their dining room or waiting in line to eat.

Once you get that hot little pizza box in your hands, step on the gas and run every red light to get home as soon as possible.  If some idiot grandma or a cripple in a wheelchair gets in your way, I suggest you mow 'em down without mercy.

Deep dish pizza gets soggy if not consumed immediately.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description: Favorite deep dish pizza in the bay area, and maybe better than the deep dish in Chicago (although I haven't had them close enough to each other to really compare).  The cornmeal crust is the star of the pizza, although I'm a HUGE fan of the sausage that they put on their pizza. The place has a good vibe, and they usually have good beers on tap.  Love it!
author: Pilan C.

description:
NOM NOM NOM! 

Came Tuesday around 5:30 and was seated right away. My friends and I were afraid we wouldn't get seated and that we'd miss the special. But we made it, ordered a Caprese Salad, a White Pie thin crust pizza and a classic deep dish pizza.

The thin crust was AMAZING! There was so much cheese on it! I love it when you have to keep pulling at the cheese. The crust was the best part. It was crispy but it wasn't burnt! It was almost like a cracker. The pizza also wasn't super oily. Definitely the best thin crust pizza I've ever had.

The deep dish was also good but I feel like it's not that different than Zachary's in Oakland.

Customer service was great. Our jar of water was timely filled. The people who work there were all young and hip and really nice. Also, during happy hour (5-6 or 6:30) all alcoholic drinks are $1 off.
author: Lucy D.

description: After a long, hard, workout I'm sitting here day dreaming about slices of Little Star Pizza.  I swear, they are dancing right before my eyes as I write this review.  It's a good thing (I guess) that I don't live in the area, but man, it's only matter of time till I'm back to tame that nasty deep-dish-devil that resides in my belly.  Till then, I'm gonna go head and pretend everything I'm biting into today is pizza.
author: Addie X.

description: OMG the mediterranean chicken deep dish is to die for! I think about it even 6 months after I leave lol. The ingredients are simply amazing! Oh yeah the chicken wings are bomb too! :) We visit each time we go to SF.
author: Debbie J.

description:
CASH ONLY!

6:30PM on a Saturday eve, whew, just beat the rush!

Trendy ambiance: dim lighting to set the mood (the mood to eat foo!), interesting paintings to line the walls, and intimate table spacing. 

Was seated in a min, noticing the hipster staff. Love being in the Bay for this reason: can express one's style while providing good service without being forced in a pretentious suite n' demeanor. 

Grubbed on:
1. Mixed salad
     +I normally stay away from gorgonzola but it was soft and was 
     balanced with the dressing
     +Fresh, fresh, fresh...especially the tomatoes!
2. Deep dish special (small): house-made meatballs, spinach, ricotta
     +Some sort of cornmeal formed the crust and dish: crispy good!
     +Meatballs retained unique flavor while mixed with the tomato sauce
     +Spinach provided a minor, bitter zing
     +Ricotta spotted on the top of each slice, provided some solids to 
     the deep dish sauce

Final Call:
Place is awesome for dates or for groups. Come early though, otherwise you'll be waiting like the rest of the folks that came after 7:30PM. Can't wait to try another deep dish!
author: Chuck N.

description:
Perhaps it was because of my high expectations, perhaps it was because the pizza wasn't as hot as i was used to, perhaps it was because it was really busy I am not entirely sure but it didn't meet my expectations.

What I do know is they have good pizza but it didn't receive the 5 stars I so badly wanted to award this place.

I had the deep dish with artichoke hearts, sausage, spinach, and feta. The sauce was awesome, the crust even better but the cheese wasn't as gooey and melty as I was used to.

4 Stars because it is close to another deep dish pizza place I enjoy (Patxi). Definitely a place to try out.
author: Jackson P.

description:
I gotta tell you, I've always been one of those people who thinks Pizza is Pizza: when its good its great, and when its bad, its still pretty good. 

But Little Star pretty much nailed it. Not only was the Mediterranean Pizza the cat's pajamas, but the place had a great atmosphere about it. 

Better ingredients, better Pizza, Papa John sucks.
author: bm b.

description:
First Review on Yelp... and I had to think hard about who I would review, and thought about the restaurant that I had to recommend to anyone visiting Northern California.

I wanted to give this place 5 stars ever since I visited this place, and probably been here about 7-10 times before this review, but I also wanted to wait to compare it to all the Chicago's pizzas. I had Giordanos and Uno under my belt, but I wasn't sure it would be enough, but now after trying Lou Malnati's I can give it a well deserved review. 

Locally, it's pretty close to Zachary's, however, the main difference is the type of ingredients they use and the Crust. OMG, the crust is to die for. The first time my friend and I ate here, we ate the pizza just to get to the crust. It's a cornmeal based crust, with enough butter to satisfy anyone's taste buds. The pizza here uses large chunks of tomatoes which is great. 

The Pizza (all deep dish):
**The Classic - Huge chunks of sausage, flavorful, peppery, and well balanced. Everything comes well together. It's my second favorite here. 
**Little Star - Spinach, Cheese, Garlic. Out of this world. I would recommend this over anything they have on the menu. If you're a vegetarian, this is great, even for a carnivore like me. 

I would defintely recommend getting half/half the first time there, but everyone who's gone with me has liked the little star over the classic. 

Little Star also has 2 other stores, this place is still the best. It's not that much different, but it is definitely noticeable. Ambiance, food, and everything overall just comes together.

The wait can be at least 45 minutes, but they'll make you order ahead of time so your pizza will be ready by the time you sit. I HIGHLY recommend  you visiting this place if you're in the City.
author: Samuel L.

description:
1) Rainy Friday evening.  Still debating whether to go out for the night or not, but I really, really wanted some pizza.
2) Drove and picked up my girls.  Karma was in my corner.  Rock star parking right outside!
3) Yes, we snagged the last open table.  Karma is still working with us here.  10 minutes later and we would have had to wait.

Started with a thin crust - pesto chicken.  I'm not a big pesto fan, and the chicken was a bit dry, but I thought the crust was really good.

And end with a bang.  The Brass Monkey (Little Star + Sausage) was everything I had hoped for and more.  Tomatoes.  Sausage.  Spinach.  Cheese.  Mushroom.  Garlic.  Onions.

Taking off a star because service was a bit slow in between the pizzas.  To the point where we thought they forgot to put in for another pizza and we were sitting there wondering if the bill or the pizza was going to come.
author: Jenny L.

description: A must!! Wings are great, and pizza has not failed us once!  Deep dish you've got to try!
author: Seidi W.

description:
After hearing all the hype over Little Star, just had to check it out with my buddy R who is also a deep dish fan. We drove around for 30 minutes on a weeknight looking for parking before finally finding a spot. I also discovered my buddy's awful parallel parking skills. Eight attempts later into which I could have fit an SUV into, we finally manage to park. 

We were hungry and upon arriving were informed of a 35 to 45 minute wait, on a WEEKNIGHT. We waited around and just took a seat at the bar 20 minutes later rather than waiting for a table. We ordered the salad, mediocre. It was a Gorgonzola salad with not a lot of Gorgonzola. 

The pizza, a large with chicken and roasted garlic. It was good, deep dish. However, it was not what I expected. I was expecting true chicago style deep dish with soft doughy crust. However, the crust here was hard and not doughy. It was also not as deep as real chicago style. 

It was good, a change, but just not on the great side. For the city it is really good pizza. But when compared to Uno's or Lou's in Chicago, it does not even compare. Zachary's is better if ordered right (ie. without the spinach and with extra cheese). 

I recommend it. It would be worthy of 4 stars if it was not for the long wait, unfriendly service at the bar, and horrible parking. However, if you are looking for real chicago pizza, try it in chicago or order Lou's online. Will probably not return here. However, people who have not had real deep dish actually really like this place and I can see why.
author: Ahmed S.

description:
Yummmm!!!!!!!!
It's still so damn gooood.
Thin crust plain cheese still the best, add fresh tomatoes, side of small mixed greens...... well, on second thought, skip the greens and save the money for more pizza the next day.   Damn damn fine.
author: Today Y.

description:
I love getting take out here.  It never ceases to astonish me when I go to pick up the pizza box and I see its diminutive size and think "why don't I ever get the large?" and then pick up the box, which weighs roughly the equivalent of a newborn orca and remember that even with the small, my boyfriend and I always have leftovers.

When I have been fancy and actually eaten in the restaurant I've always had amazing service.  Including the time I brought a bottle of slightly warm champagne and the really sweet waitress had to dig through the kitchen to come up with some sort of container for me to try to ice the bottle in, and when I got impatient and tried to fill up the container with water so the champagne would get cooler faster and the container overflowed and spilled everywhere and all over the floor and the waitress was STILL super cute about it.  

Shine on indeed, little star.
author: fraggle l.

description:
This is my favorite pizza place of all time- I LOVE the classic deep dish. The crust is amazing and the tomatoes add so much flavor. It is always mega packed whenever we head there but is well worth the wait. Grab a glass of wine or beer at the bar and the time flies!

Only thing I don't totally love is the dessert.. nothing too special about it. Otherwise, everything is awesome!
author: Seema M.

description:
YUM YUM.

I was totally craving deep dish pizza and recently been introduced to "The Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Try Before You Die"  where Little Star was #60... so I figured why not kill two birds with one stone. Having gone to college at UC Berkeley, I was weary of a restaurant that rivals Zachary's (Berkeley staple!!!!) but was willing to give Little Star a try. 

Having read Yelp reviews of crazy waits, we decided to go right when it opened at 5pm on a Saturday. Even at that time, we were surprised by the number of customers already there... good sign about the food there. I loved the black decor... it made it dressy but casual at the same time if that makes any sense. 

Anyway on to the food!!! We ordered the small mixed salad and a small deep dish Brass Monkey pizza (secret menu! Little Star + sausage) to share and it was the perfect amount of food. The salad was tasty.. the right amount of dressing with cherry tomatoes and walnuts. Mmm. And the pizza - I loved the cornbread buttery crust!!! Though a bit hard at the bottom especially when trying to cut with knife and fork.. still really good. The tomatoes were perfectly tart and spinach and cheese and sausage all tasted fresh and yummy!!!! All this paired with a nice glass of Barbera = perfect meal. 

Service was great and I really like how they leave the water at the table. Plates were changed at the right time and food served appropriately. Overall great experience and definitely will be back!!!!

As for deciding between Zachary's and Little Star? I can't say!!! Both are different and yummy. 

Mmmm.
author: Sandy K.

description: The pizza is pretty good. Not as great as Chicago-style pizza could be. But, given the options in SF for pizza, we almost always go with Little Star. It is a little expensive and the wait time is usually pretty log.
author: Jenny J.

description:
The thin crust pizza is great!  I know everyone likes deep dish, but get the thin crust because it's not drenched in sauce and the pizza is larger in circumference, which means more of the yummy cornmeal crust.  I am usually a leave-the-crust-on-the-plate kind of pizza eater, but I always eat my Little Star crusts.  Mmm.  I crave the Classic Thin Crust on a weekly basis.

Only one thing - it would be nice if they had delivery!
author: Allison Y.

description:
The pizza was great. Service was fast and polite.

Deep dish classic was our favorite!
author: Ben B.

description:
Best deep dish pizza, probably anywhere I've lived (I've lived in Chicago and trust me, it's up there).  If I go to a place over and over, it's good, simple as that.  This is one of the go to places when we have any guests in town.  Simply put: the deep dish will blow you away.  

It's busy, no reservations, but doesn't matter.  Make a night out of it.  Both locations have the same quality, and the staff is always friendly (I don't care about staff treatment, but I know some of you do).  Appetizers are OK, but don't waste your time...get some beers (fat tire belgian abbey or the pyramid apricot ale are my faves) and pizza and enjoy!
author: A A.

description:
This place is amazing.  We started with garlic bread and spicy chicken wings, which were both yummy, and then ordered two pizzas:

DEEP DISH: Classic - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells

THIN CRUST: White Pie - Garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta

The white pie was one of the best pizzas I've ever tasted!  We had ordered a large but they brought out a small (plus the large deep dish - which ended up being more than enough for 4 adults.  Because of the screw up they ended up comp'ing our large deep dish which was not necessary).  

Even if they hadn't comp'd one of the pizzas, I would have still given the service 5 stars.

I'll definately be going back here more frequently!
author: Dana D.

description: Ordered the classic deepdish pizza, it was very good but overpriced, $19. Had the wings and they were ok. Waitress was very attentive. Will try again
author: Graham A.

description: The first time I had deep dish pizza I was in chicago and I was in heaven, it was my new true love!  While visiting San Fran I was debating between a few pizza places and my husband and I ended up here.  First impression was, wow this place is dark!  We were seated right away and ordered our pizza.  Service was fine, nothing special.  Pizza was wonderful!  A small is good for two people, deep dish is unbelievably filling!  True deep dish pizza, although I really enjoyed it, its still more fun to eat deep dish in Chicago.
author: Mallori S.

description: I don't think I can say anything about this place that hasn't been said already. Cornmeal crust was superb. Layers of cheese and delectable sauce. Mind=blown.
author: Rubun D.

description:
Little Star Review #968.  

Take a Chicago transplant here for a first date and expect a call back sooner than the standard 3 Day Rule.
author: Kerry D.

description: Crust is a little bitter, but nice texture and great tasting cheese and sauce. A stand-up Chicago deep dish.
author: Eric M.

description: I live down the street from this place, you cant go wrong with anything on the menu and they have beer on tap.  Great for carry out as well.  Will definitely be going back soon!
author: David K.

description:
After a year of culinary straying, last night completed my second visit to the Little Star family.  This location serves up equally delicious food to the Valencia one (http://www.yelp.com/biz/little-star-pizza-san-francisco-2#hrid:OoMs1qCM23FswwkZOKbTEw) and was where it all started as I understand.  

The decor in here is all Divis, with a little East Village vibe for good measure.  Graphic art on the dark walls gives an edgy feel.  Complete it with lots of young urbanites eating before a show at the Independent.  Service was downright sweet, and our salad came almost immediately.

The spicy sauce and cornmeal, almost-cookie-like crust make this not just any pizza, and not even just any deep dish pizza.  Also give their salads a try - they're much fresher and more intriguing than you'd expect from a pizza parlor.

Get in by 6:15 to avoid the wait, and maybe even find parking.  Bring cash, since they don't take cards - but if not, they have an ATM machine in-house that boasts an old-fashioned 25-cent transaction fee.  The last ATM I used in the city gauged me $3.50.  And didn't give me any cash.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
It's a crowded restaurant in a hungry neighborhood, so you certainly need to plan if you don't like waiting for food. (I am allergic to waiting for food. Some things, like roller coasters, I can wait for, but food is not one of these things.)

But, the service is very good, all the food is excellent, the drinks are reasonably priced, and the pizza... ohhh, the pizza. If you like deep dish you will love this place, and if you don't like deep dish, you might just get converted. I need not say more.
author: Colin T.

description: Wait kinda sucks and the pizzas takes 30 mins to cook... but so worth it. we got the little star its seriously good. Deep dish, crispy, and cheezzzy.. We also got the caprese salad also very good. =)
author: Gina H.

description: Not Zacharry's  but very good. Start with roasted chicken wings
author: nick g.

description:
Great deep dish pizza! But prepare to wait at least an hour for a table though!

We decided to go on a Saturday night. First off, parking is ridiculous, but then again, around that area, it was expected. Take a cab if you can! We got there, and the wait was over an hour, which was fine. You could give them your cell number and go to a nearby bar and they'll call you when the table's ready.

We ordered the classic and the Little Star deep dish. They took our order while our table was being set up since it takes a while for it to cook. We finished the pizzas with no problem!

Only thing is that place have only ONE restroom for both sexes so be prepared to wait in a LONG time or go somewhere else to use the restroom.
author: Jenny T.

description: Little star is the real deal.  Their deep dish pizza is some of the best I have ever had.  Simply amazing.  I have been here a couple of times and have never been disappointed.  I recommend the vegetarian deep dish.  So good!!! Their salads are also really awesome as well.  The ambiance of this place is pretty sweet and getting a drink at the bar is a must before you are seated.  Their beer selection on tap showcases mostly local california brew. The service is great even though this place is busy at all times.  The hosts and the servers really try to take care of you.  I recommend going on weekdays if you don't want to wait.  Honestly, just go anytime!!!
author: Vinh N.

description:
I really wanted to enjoy this place, especially since I had been meaning to try it for a while. Unfortunately the food was only average to me.

Our deep dish 'Little Star' pizza was on the bland side. The sausage didn't pop enough to override the tomato flavor, and the crust was dry to the point of almost hurting to eat. 

However, I did enjoy the service and the atmosphere for sure! It was like walking into a dark lounge which smelled like pizza. Can't do much better than that!

Hopefully my next pie is tastier.
author: Ryan V.

description:
I will begin by saying that while Chicago-style pizza is NOT my thing, and I don't especcially like my pizza with 5 toppings, Little Star is a damn tasty meal!

You might laugh (or cringe or smack me), but I really think of their pies as quiche more so than pizza.  Buttery, crunchy shell of a crust-- we're not talking 4 inches of puffy bread with crap on top, this is a like a pie shell-- with delicious ingredients stacked to the top, smothered in a top-notch red sauce.

Both locations are great, and have the same idiosyncracies:  no reservations, PBR in a can for $2, night time crowds, and a desire to turn tables.  It's a great place to grab a bite with a few friends, but save yourself the frustration of trying to bring a party of 10... you'll be waiting a while.
author: Laura F.

description: Of all the cities I've lived in, this is the absolute closest thing to Chicago pizza that I grew up with.  The food here is amazing but I also go here when I'm homesick and it really feels like Chicago! Thank you Little Star!
author: Marisa C.

description: Had the think crust meat pizza. It was pretty good; not a true think crust. Crust was crunchy and had good flavor. overall, it's overpriced. They don't offer many variations on the deepdish and it's too pricey to order a cheese and add toppings.
author: Sara S.

description:
Dear Yelp,

For a long effing time I've heard about how great Little Star is, mostly from people who have never been to Chicago nor had Chicago style pizza.  The kids certainly seem to like it though, as the place has been packed every time I've ever walked by it.  So I decided to finally get down with the Star, see if it lives up to the hype.

As expected, the wait was pretty long, but they let us put an order in before we were seated, as is customary in such places (the pizza takes a darn long time to cook after all).  We ordered the Classic, which is the quintessential Chicago style pizza (sausage, mushrooms, onions, bell peppers).  You can't go wrong.

Or maybe you can.  There are certain things you'll never taste if you're eating a true Chicago style deep dish pizza, and one of those things my friends is fucking cornmeal.  Lou Malnati must be spinning in his grave right now.  To be fair, it isn't necessarily a bad pizza, but it sure as heck isn't authentic Chicago style.

If I wasn't such a purist, I probably would have enjoyed Little Star more.  However, I ams what I ams, and Little Star is what it is (ie: not authentic Chicago).  When I'm in the mood for some of that tasty pizza, I go for Patxi's: the crowd is better, the Pabst is only a dollar, and the pizza is far superior.  Recognize.

I give Little Star Pizza a fantastic score of 2 out of 5 stars.

Love,
James
author: Cheryll M.

description:
Food: 1 large brass monkey (see other yelpers raving, this is good stuff).
Service:  2.5 hours before we got our pizza.  Is this supposed to be a french restaurant?
Ambiance: too hip for you pizza joint.  A bit loud b/c of the music. Kinda had to shout to be heard.

A series of mishaps or something, b/c we got there at 8pm, was told the wait was 45 min for a table, ok. So then 45 minutes in, realizing we're still waiting, we put our order in for a large brass monkey (not on the menu, but thanks to yelp it's the pizza w/tons of fatty juicy flavorful sausage). Sat down at 9:45pm *finally*.  Are told that oops, the kitchen messed up, so our order wasn't put in.  I almost fell over, i was so hungry.  The worst is the servers kept coming over and saying: "Five more minutes!" "Your pizza is up!" And ten minutes, 15, 20, 30 minutes would go by!   Stop it already and just be honest! 

So by the time we got the pizza, I am sure anything would have tasted amazing.  Last insult of the night is they offered to comp us half the pizza for the wait.  I dunno, something about comping for half was felt a bit half-assed, like c'mon, make it all or nothing!  What's w/the half pizza comp!!?! Man up!
author: Caroline I.

description: Update: The owner of Little Star addressed my concern in the most professional manner possible. Thanks Brian..
author: Tim E.

description:
Dont call me an asshole, but I really did not enjoy the pizza here! I was actually super excited to try this place after all the raving reviews from Yelp, but it turned out to be a huge disappointment. We ordered the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish pizza that had big blobs of cheese on it, hardly any red peppers, green olives or chicken.

The chicken wings here were awesome and I really enjoyed it. It was super packed here and our waitress was very attentive- she was excellent!
author: M W.

description: This place is a little on the pricey side, but so worth it, make sure that you order to go because this place is always packed! And make sure you have healthy appitite, you're going to need it.
author: Timothy H.

description:
I lived in Chicago for years - in fact I served food in the luxury boxes at Wrigley Field - where I once had pizza with Tommy Lasorda.

This is good pizza.

We ordered take out twice in 3 days (my wife was in the nearby hospital).  The first time I ordered on the phone and it was a lousy ordering experience - the person on the phone did not care that I existed in ANY sort of way.  The next time I went in and ordered - the people were lovely and considerate both on my ordering and pick-up.

Great pizza - seriously, I liked it more than most Chicago-style pizza I've had in Chicago.  It was light and heavy in all the right places.  It was so cheesy, but not SO cheesy.  Tasty tomato sauce.  Buttery crust perfection. And a "small" that is the absolute right size for 2 people!
author: Cameron M.

description:
Wow... THE best deep dish of this style I've had.  Zachary's has nothin on this place!  I've been to Zachary's twice and had some overnight pizza from here once and ate here once and even the overnight reheated pizza was so good and better than Zacharys!  

So I guess I should let you in on a little on a little secret.  Okay you can't tell anyone!  It's from their secret menu.  The best thing to order is called the brass monkey.  Okay now that you know you can go order it and try it out.  I wont tell you what it is so you can be surprised.  However, it's really not that big of a secret and don't order it if you're a vegetarian.  But I have to say it is one of the best pizzas I've ever had.
author: Wilson C.

description: Small place and very crowded but food and service was great!  Had the classic and Italian deep dish pizzas!
author: Wailun Eugene W.

description:
I didn't think pizza could really be that much better than other places. Little Star proved me completely wrong. Their crust and dough was unbelievably good and I'm getting hungry again just thinking about it.

The price of a small pizza may seem a little steep but they are thick pies and are worth it.
author: Alvin B.

description:
I'm surprised I haven't reviewed this place yet....

Deep dish pizza is good.  Add some pear cider, then it's extra good.  

However, after both dining in and getting take out, I recommend take out.  Dining in isn't bad, it's just a long long wait, and given how small the place is, it's going to be a long and crowded wait.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
There are just times when going about every aspect of a restaurant and it's food would only delay one's decision whether or not to come to a place. With no need to say any more:

*Little Star Pizza DOES PIZZA RIGHT*

Must-try suggestion: Little Star Deep Dish
(To not try it while being there is unthoughtful) 

Enjoy
author: Leevan R.

description:
To start off: THE FOOD WAS DELICIOUS!

I was here for a private party last month and I was extremely caught off guard. We barely found the place since the sign was so small. But it was a great relief to find such good pizza!

We had the deep dish veggie and meat pizzas. I've had bad experiences before with deep dish pizza, so I basically stay away. But these pies were the holy redeemer of deep dish on the west coast. The crust was nice and crisp, but not doughy. I heard that its a cornmeal type deal. That might explain the deliciousness.

Only downside: parking. We were there for lunch and no parking in sight. We ended up finding street parking in a near by neighborhood, but if you're planning to eat here, leave your self a lot of time to cruise. It'll be worth it!
author: Danielle D.

description:
5 BIG stars for Little Star!  
I actually asked where the name came from and unfortunately the server didn't have a clue.  However my bf had a pretty good guess...trust me it's pretty funny but I'm not at liberty to divulge this info with just anyone.

But I digress...the ingredients, ambiance and satisfaction all play an important role in creating the feeling you get after eating a thin or Chicago style deep dish pie here.  I swear it'll make you skip in delight all the way home.  (not a bad idea after a few slices) 

Let's not forget the service...this may also give you a warm and fuzzy feeling in addition to their alcohol selection.  :)  The place gets packed so plan on spending a little time at the bar before you get seated.

Side note - my hilarious bf happens to be from Chicago and surprisingly he has yet to find a place that trumps Little Star.  Looks like we'll just have to keep the search going.

To be continued...
author: Danielle V.

description:
My sister wanted to try this for her birthday, and as my family are adventurous when it comes to dining adventures- we decided to make a go out of this. We decided to go at 5 (opening) on a Thursday so we wouldn't have to contend with the parking issue associated with parking in the city.

The wait staff was friendly enough- although our waitress didn't tell us the specials. One of the staff came in with an infant and they were more interested in their own than chatting the new customers- even though we said it was a special occasion and that we had come from Hayward.  They only have cans of soda and this was a serious problem with me as I think if you can have beer on tap you can (SHOULD) have soda on tap, especially if you are going to serve people a large amount of spicy food.

The garlic bread is win if you love garlic (I do)...the garlic was roasted perfectly.

If you like Goldie then their jukebox is the bomb but God help you if you like another type of music or band.

The pizza: don't get me wrong it was good- but it wasn't the BEST PIZZA EVER. Their crust is an interesting mix of cornmeal and sourdough. I didn't like that the tomato sauce covers all of their pizza and makes them indistinguishable from one another (the pictures of the artistic spinach pizzas are LIES). I have left overs but I doubt I will make an effort to go back.

For 60.00 for 2 pizzas and 3 cans of soda...I just really wasn't that impressed.
****************************************************************************
4/9/2010- Just received a nice email from Brian (co-owner of little star) explaining that he brought his daughter in and it was the first time many of the employees met her. He said that it was probably too distracting in hindsight. That was a very nice and classy touch and it is appreciated.
author: Hanna C.

description:
After trying many pizza places in SF, I have been dying to try this one. 
Waiting outside on a Friday afternoon around 4:55pm, I couldn't wait any longer for Little Star to open its doors. 
Super surprised that as we sat down, we saw plenty of To-Go orders already waiting to be picked up and the amount of tables that were being filled in only 1/2 hour. This pizza better be good.
David and I ordered 2 pizzas, a beer, and a glass of wine. Happy hour between 5pm-6:30pm. How lovely!
I had the regular cheese pizza w/ mushrooms. (Sometimes you can't tell the real goodness of a great pizza with too many toppings)
David had the "special" pizza with slivers of bacon, broccolini, and garlic. The crust was amazingly crispy and well seasoned.
Very good meal, but a bit pricey. 2 pizzas, 2 drinks, + tip = $50.00
CASH only!
author: DayDay D.

description: Love this deep dish-style pizza. Great for date night!
author: Malak M.

description:
Ok, yes repeating what the other reviewers have said - great pizza (almost more like a pie!), wonderful flavors bursting open in your mouth with every bite, but why I take the time to write the review...

My dad and I ate here - we split a pie half and half - him ordering Mediterranean chicken and me ordering vegetarian. Being a veggie, I kindly asked the waitress if she could reference not to have any chicken spill over on my side of the pie. If it did, I wouldn't throw a fit, but if it didn't that would be super nice. Not only was she more than kind about my request, but she said the kitchen was very good about that and THEY WERE! NO CHICKEN ON MY SIDE! What a friendly and thoughtful establishment :) I love you, Little Star.
author: Elise H.

description: I had a slice of the deep-dish Mediterranean Chicken pizza. What's in a Mediterranean Chicken you say? Chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bells, green olives, onions, & feta. Crust was crunchy and thick, I'm not sure if I prefer it that thick. You can definitely taste & see the garlic, there was a lot of it, which I liked.
author: Kylie L.

description: Fantastic pizza.  I try to watch my diet carefully and only eat pizza once in a while as a special treat.  But when I do treat myself, it is usually to a deep dish pizza from Little Star.  All the pizzas I have tried have been fantastic. 5+ stars!
author: J J.

description:
first off - pizza here = too tasty. used to live across the street from this place. that was a whole lot of trouble.

2ndly - got my pie for 50% off last night with the Viv Special. awesome. granted I'm a little biased, but the place was rocking and people seemed stoked (though who wouldn't be at 50% off). can get more info on future Viv Specials at www.DoYouViv.com

lastly - don't underestimate the thin crust white pie. it's a sleeper / slayer,
author: Dinesh T.

description: It hard to find good pizza and I like my pizza with a thick crust at this place you could get a very good pizza with thick crust. The best thing is to get carry out and you could enjoy a delicious pizza.
author: Thomas T.

description:
Hub and I (and sons) are pizzaterians. From the time our sons were young, Friday night was pizza night.  Our preference swings from thin crust to deep dish. We fell head over heels for Vicolo's corn meal crust when it was in Hayes Valley (still buy the crust), We are devotees of Zackery's pride and joy.  And have fond memories of some amazing  home made pizza dough (too much work). 

Bonanza!!!! We have found all of our favs rolled into one delicious pizza. Deep corn meal crust, layers of spinach, mushrooms, cheeses and chopped tomatoes. Yes that is right, the wonderful people at Little Star Pizza have made the perfect pizza for we people who are committed to our Friday night pizza ritual. Of course our boys have outgrown our routine but we are trying to lure them back with a "little star". 

One Friday, there was an overload of onions in the pizza but that seemed like an off night.  Check out the other reviews for noise etc.  The staff are pleasant and engaging- very nice, professional guy at the bar.  Price is very good.  

Get there at 5 (Divisadero) and there is no waiting.  Would be nice if they were open at lunch.
author: Barbara W.

description:
i love Little Star, no doubt about that. 
this little gem is the best pizza in SF hands down. 
DEEP DISH FTW. 
MUST HAVE: Garlic Bread!
author: Chelsea B.

description:
The atmosphere: loud, bustling, and filled with a very random crowd - from men in business suits, to old ladies with too large of hair, to heavily tattooed 20 somethings. There was a 30 minute wait on a Tuesday night at 7 PM, so I'm sure it is even more crazy on weekends.

The food: my date and I went for a small deep dish Mediterranean chicken pizza, which was absolutely delicious and very fresh. One was perfect for the two of us - I left stuffed.

The service: our waitress wasn't hovering over us all night, but was very nice when I asked her to switch my Racer 5 IPA (which tasted like dirt - don't know if it was a bad batch or what) for something else. 

The verdict? Loved it and would go back in a heartbeat...the crust on the deep dish was so rich, almost like a quiche crust..mmm...
author: Kara A.

description: We visited Little Star for the first time today, and it's was a solid OK but not great or excellent.  Starting out we had a salad which was nice and then went with the original/classic (sausage, mushrooms, onion, peppers) but it just didn't have the flavor we expected, so it was lacking in that area, but otherwise good.
author: Brian H.

description: Very satisfying! Loved the deep dish! Great drink selections and good ambience. I'll be back.
author: Pareesa R.

description: the food amazing . but the service sucks!!! i asked for deep baked pizza it was almost like asking for given back the holy land!!! make sure they hear you when you say 'Deep" word. they hate you any way
author: B H.

description:
... more and more i am becoming a bigger fan of chicago style pizza 
...not to say that i prefer it over new york style, but it is turning into a head to head competition 

i would probably call this chi-cali-go style because it seems much more "prettier" than the other chicago styles ive had... not a bad thing 
what really got me was the wonderful crust... and i usually dont like eating crusts.. its a waste of space... 

i will be going back again to try the apps and thin crusts... 
little star is now definitely up there with one of my fave pizza joints... oooh and plus they keep it real with the $2 PBR's in a can...im sold
author: Nic M.

description: I'd give 4 1/2 if I could....1/2 star off for noise. I'm fine with some mood music, but not so loud I can't hold a conversation with my family. Food was excellent...best caprese salad I've ever had. 2 deep dish pizzas were soooo good. Definitely coming back for more!
author: nikki b.

description:
Other people have said it, but I'll say it too. Thank you Little Star. You removed the need to cross that pesky bridge to go to Zachary's. 

If you haven't been here yet, you should make plans soon. The pizza is delicious, better than Zachary's in my opinion...though I understand that is really a religious debate more than anything.

The only downside is the wait (45 mins is common). Oh, and you have to like chicago style pizza. But if you don't, that's fine with me, just means I'll get seated quicker.
author: Pavan T.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here a couple of months ago when it was pouring outside and still had to wait an hour to get a table, but fortunately were able to sit in the waiting area and enjoy a beer in the meantime.  

Deep dish pizza was really, REALLY, good (the Mediterranean Chicken I think) - so addicting - and I'm normally more of a thin crust kind of person.  The atmosphere was really cool and the service was great. 

Will definitely be back!
author: Natasha T.

description:
Little star!  If you're looking for a deep dish pizza with all the tomato sauce, cheese, meat, and jalapenos - This is the place to go.

You won't be disappointed, just go give it a try.!

You might have a wait depending on the time of day, but you all know how these types of places are.  It's worth the wait.
author: Bill Z.

description:
I'm going to keep this short and sweet:

- Their pizza is delicious
- Their wings are flavorful
- The staff is friendly and attentive
- They're always busy -- be prepared for a 20-40 minute wait. If you live close by, I would definitely recommend going the take-out route instead.

Now stop reading and go eat!
author: Lillian C.

description: Their classic deep dish really was cholesterol busting delicious. I particularly liked how generous there were with the ingredients while keeping the amount of sauce on the low side with the deep dish pizza. We also tried the pesto chicken and a mushroom thin crust. These were okay although in my opinion they were not nearly as good as the thin crust at Cafe Bao Necci or Tony's, but at the same time it seems unfair to compare their thin crust with other places since they seem to place a high emphasis on a deep dish which is definitely worth a return trip.
author: Procter F.

description:
So late one night, my roommate, bf and I had a craving for deep dish pizza and were ecstatic to find out that Little Star was nearby.  Too bad it took 5 minutes to get there, but 20 minutes to find parking!

We got a deep dish large pizza to share, with half Little Star and half Classic.  I really enjoyed the Little Star, which has ricotta, spinach, mushroom, garlic and onions.  

I would have to say Zacharys and Little Star are definitely on par with each other when it comes to deep dish pizzas, but I like Little Star's ambiance more.  It's dim, laid-back, and kind of hippie with the staff's unique sense of fashion.  

I also tried the pear cider, which was really good on its own, but not so much with pizza.
author: Jen Y.

description: One of the best pizza establishments I have ever visited. Their deep dish pie is to die for.  Love the food! Had excellent service.  Cornmeal crust is a new one for me but worth the minor wait for a pie.  Get there early as they are often too packed to be seated.  Very alternative looking staff and decorations which added to the appeal for my wife and me.  The lighting is very dark so don't mistakenly take a platonic friend or they might get the wrong idea.
author: Dustin R.

description: The Little Star special is our favorite. Delicious cornmeal crust. Spicy chicken wings are quite good as well.
author: Mara B.

description:
here we have a pizza joint which is stuck between a restruant and a pizza joint.  I think that is usually a good thing, but when it comes to good pizza, you really need to focus.

I mean the pizza is good, but i find it a bit fancy and a bit over priced.

If you like pizza and not the fancy pizza with the high cost, then i would recommend Patxis in Hayes Valley.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/patxis-chicago-pizza-san-francisco
author: Jai D.

description:
Our friend Josh aka DJ Angst, just moved into the neighborhood and he invited us out to Little Star on a random Tuesday night.

It was packed. We had to wait 15 minutes, so we grabbed a few beers and my wife had one of their special drinks. Not bad. We are discussing my departure from the local top 40 scene and all the drama attached to it. Hella people in the building, so it must be good pizza. We finally get a table. My wife and Josh order some Deep Dish concoction, I order a regular pepperoni pizza. 

MY LORD. This pizza is extremely yummy. Super flavorful, non greasy and just a delight to the tummy. CASH ONLY tho, so bring $$$
author: Alex M.

description:
White Pie! Do it.
I think I must order it at least once a month.
But if you want something a little more filling, 
their namesake deep dish is completely amazing!

I wish they were open for lunch too.
And since I'm dreaming, picture this..pizza by the slice to go!
I would eat it everyday.
author: Linz H.

description: Having just moved into the NoPa area, I had to get into Little Star as soon as possible. Needless to say, I was not disappointed. We ordered the Little Star deep-dish (added sausage) as well as the chicken wings. Both dishes we're very well prepared and delicious. The chicken wings are rather petite - which makes them a bit easier to eat. Anddddd the Little Star deep dish was incredible. I've had Chicago deep dish and NY deep dish, and this was right up there with them. The crust was infused with butter and garlic, toasted perfectly and melted in your mouth. The pizza did not come out scolding hot and was ready to eat right away. Then, to top it off since we couldnt finsish the deep dish, we wrapped it to go and brought it for lunch the next day... and it was just as good. I'll definitely be going back.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I used to think Patxi's was No.1, then this place came along. Where it succeeds is having a combination of both good deep dishes and thin crusts. I like the beer selection and the quirky waiting staff. 

The Garlic bread appetizer is basic yet very good, as are the blue cheese wings (love blue cheese!)

Never tried the dessert...always too full.

The Mediterranean deep dish is my goto.
author: Alexei S.

description:
My sister's swimming teammates took us to Little Star Pizza. I am quite the pizza lover, so I was excited to hear of a Chicago Style pizzeria in SF.

This place has the BEST Chicago Style pizza in the SF Bay Area!!  Definitely better than Zachary's...in my opinion. OVERALL in the bay area, Little Star is #2 behind Rainbow Pizza.  (Overall Grade:  A)

We ordered a large "Classic" (combo) pizza. I've been to 3 pizzerias in Chicago and Little Star seems authentic. It was definitely deeeeeeep dish and had a great crust. It had a pretty good amount of toppings. The sauce was pretty good, but not nearly as good as Rainbow Pizza's. The sauce also had some tomatoes that I picked off. (I know, some of you like tomatoes.)

If you like or love pizza, then I recommend you try Little Star Pizza in San Francisco!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Being a native, I am a little ashamed and embarrassed that I never knew about this DELICIOUS establishment before a few months ago. 

Last night, I was able to experience Little Star, and now there is no going back. The food is awesome. The five of us shared two large mixed salads, a small deep dish Little Star, and a small pesto chicken. Killer. And it was only $15/person! 

The only downside is the wait and that it's cash only. We were able to enjoy a beer at the bar though, and place our order with the host so that our food would be ready when we were seated. Awesome! I think I will opt for takeout next time.
author: Misha F.

description: Delicious Pizza. 4 stars because it is expensive for what you get size wise regardless if it is deep dish. But its a great tasting pie.
author: Yaniv H.

description:
Ok, so I've been to Little Star a few more times than I had when I initially wrote my review.  It is good, but it's not Zachary's.  In fact, to me, Little Star deep-dish is better in lesser quantities.  Yes, it still tends to be extremely generous with the toppings, but the flavor equilibriums are off, the mixture isn't quite zen, the cheese tends towards the sharp.  All in all, with more outings, I may even now be leaning towards the thin crust over the stuffed, and for this East Bay Zachophile, that's just blasphemy.

For those of you out there unfamiliar with the brilliance that is Zachary's, just go.  I hestitate to oversell Zachary's because then people may have unrealistic expectations, unsure of what to imagine near-perfect pizza should taste like.  Zachary's is always extremely good; quite often, it's unreal.  Zachary's simply gets better with time.  I've converted several people to Zachary's deep dish, including my father and my girlfriend -- and for those of you who appreciate that one cannot be a prophet in his own land, you know how good Zachary's must be.

I write this review to counterbalance my first review questioning whether LS or Zachary's was a better pizza.  To this critic, there is no comparison:  Zachary's wins any day of the week.  Zachary's is like Usain Bolt:  who cares who else is in the race?  Certainly, if I lived in SF and near Little Star, I would frequent more often.  I don't.  It's a luxury to be relatively near the original Zachary's outpost in Oakland.  I encourage everyone to try it when they're out in the East Bay.  It's a destination and worth the effort..
author: SalsaBoy S.

description:
Little Star is a great neighborhood joint that people gladly travel to from outside of the neighborhood.  There's a good reason for this: even if you never eat at the restaurant and only get take out, and even if you never order anything other than a basic deep dish pie, you are going to have an incredible meal.

But if you do decide to branch out, you'll find their various pizza selections to be very rewarding.  The thin crust is almost as good as the deep dish.  And they have some incredible combinations.

And should you decide to dine *in* - you are in for a treat.  I've come to Little Star on many an occasion by myself or with one friend to sit at the bar, drink a beer and destroy a pizza or two.  The ambiance is dark and fun, the beer is good and the bartenders are friendly.

And should you get stuck waiting for a seat - I highly recommend Minibar across the street for a bloody mary or some other concoction.
author: Oliver N.

description:
"We don't sing and dance or any of that crap."

That was what the hostess told me after I asked her if they did anything special for birthdays.  Which, which by the way, is perfect considering who on earth would WANT them to do that stuff?

They did, however, bring out a Gorgeous Slice of Cheesecake swirled with chocolate sauce and topped with a candle.

The cheesecake, however, did not overshadow their pizza.  So deep you can swim in it, delicious to the core, made with fresh ingredients.  There is the perfect balance of tomato sauce to cheese.  Truly Delicious.

I'll leave this review with two final notes:
1. If you're wondering if it beats Zach's, it does.
2. If I they could bake a larger pizza and I could travel in time, I would gladly travel back in time and lose my virginity atop one of of Little Star's creations.
author: Nick A.

description: I guess deep dish pizza isn't my thing, because I wasn't blown away or anything. We also tried the garlic bread, but it was weird.
