It does come with a whole clove of garlic, but be careful to only use the middle of the clove. If you put the edges of the clove on the bread, it can get a little choke-y. With the garlic bread you also get a big cup of melted butter. The deep dish is super filling though, and was enough for the three of us.
author: Kimmie M.

description:
Well kids, it was bound to happen. My no-good asshole fuckface douchebag Ex who cheated on me FINALLY came by my apartment to pick up the last of his shit -- over a YEAR after moving out.

That's right.  I know you're surprised to hear I didn't give his belongings to a homeless person/have my Santeria priestess curse them/hock them for drug money, but the truth is we're friends. Also, I'm not a vindictive bitch like one of his former boyfriends who, after an argument, actually CALLED AND EMAILED all of his friends with the vicious lie that he had every STD known to man, and while I can appreciate how BATSHIT FUCKING CRAZY that was, I also know it's cruel and patently false because The Ex may be a lot of things but he's definitely NOT some hooker saddled with STDs, he's just impotent.***

So anyway he came by to collect his 20 bottles of shitty wine atop the kitchen cabinets, his massage chair, his Viagra ***, and a few other personal belongings, then decided to CLEAR OUT MY FUCKING KITCHEN since, as he put it, he PAID FOR THIS BOX OF PASTA.

WHAT THE FUCK?!? JIGGA WHAAA? 

Yeah, he wanted to play THAT game. Besides, you don't cook anyway, right Darin? Oh and while I'm here let's take a look in the fridge. Yeah, I bought this bottle of Scharffenberger liqueur, lemme pocket that. Who bought this almondine eau de vie? You gonna use this brown rice? Does brown rice go bad? I'll take it anyway. Hey, what about this miso mix? Where's the cd/dvd cleaner -- I think I paid for that. Oh yeah, these shot glasses are mine. These champagne flutes -- mine. Mine. Mine. Mine mine MINE!

I finally said:

OH FUCKING HELL WHY DON'T YOU JUST TAKE THE FORKS, TOO? I MEAN, NOT LIKE I NEED TO EAT, RIGHT? HEY, WHY NOT TOSS IN THE SPOONS AND KNIVES AND MAKE A COMPLETE SET? ASSHOLE.

Well, I just figured that since you don't cook I could take the pasta. There's no need to get bitchy.

BITCHY? WHO'S BITCHY?!? NOT ME. OH NO. I JUST WANT YOU TO HAVE WHAT'S *RIGHTFULLY* YOURS! HEY, WHY DON'T YOU TAKE THE BOY BUTTER TOO, DEAR?!? NOT LIKE I'VE FUCKED ANYONE OR WHACKED OFF SINCE I KICKED YOUR PATHETIC ASS OUT FOR TRYING TO SUCK DICK IN ATLANTA!!

I guess I should pick up my old sneakers too.

OH PLEASE! YES! I THREW THEM UNDER THE BED SINCE I DIDN'T KNOW IF YOU STILL WANTED THEM, THOUGH NOW I REGRET NOT SMEARING MY SHIT ALL OVER YOUR PUMAS.

Look, I don't want to make this difficult.

NO SIR, NOT DIFFICULT AT ALL. I WANTED YOU TO EMPTY ALL MY CABINETS. EAT ME, ASSWIPE!

Why don't we grab some food.

GO FUCK YOURSELF!

No, seriously, let me cook for you.

COOK WHAT? THE MOTHERFUCKING PASTA YOU JUST BAGGED?!? AND LET YOU POISON ME? FUCK YOU.

I'm not gonna poison you, I need to keep you alive so you can cat-sit Tillie when I'm on vacation!

OH RIGHT. Ok, fuck it, you know what, let's go to Little Star. I haven't had their deep dish pizza in a while.

We called in our order since we figured the place would be packed at 9pm on Saturday. To our surprise, it was rather empty -- definitely a change from the last time I ate here when the place resembled a camel toe convention or sexless hipster orgy, wait that doesn't make sense, everyone knows hipsters don't FUCK to reproduce, they just strike an emo pose, in other words meiotically. 

Our large Classic deep-dish pizza was phenomenal as always. The cornmeal dusted crust was hardy and hearty, and held firm against the substantial weight of the sausage chunks, juicy tomatoes, mushrooms, and cheese. One bite and I forgot about the machinations of The Ex and any misgivings I held because of them. All that ran through my mind like a ticker tape was the opening line in Bellow's paean to Chicago The Adventures of Augie March "I am an American, Chicago born -- Chicago, that somber city -- and go at things as I have taught myself, free style, and will make the record in my own way," and while this makes for questionable politics (VOTE EARLY AND VOTE OFTEN!) and an idealism easily bruised, it's a GREAT FUCKING RECIPE for pie: these folks have perfected their deep-dish and elevated it to both a science and a peerless ideal. 

The deep dish pie at Little Star can paper over and heal long simmering resentments -- is that some powerful shit or WHAT?!? I downed my four pieces, and in the process swallowed some of my pride as well. 

Beautiful.

And towards the end of dinner, we had the following exchange.

Ex: Hey, are you still on that site?

Me: What site? Gay.com? Yes. Are you still picking up sluts at Badlands?

Ex: Very funny. No, no, I meant that review site.

Me: You mean Yelp? Yeah, still on it. Why?

Ex: Oh just asking...So have you reviewed this place?

Me: Why no, now that you mention it, I HAVEN'T reviewed Little Star. Yet.



***TOTALLY kidding. He is not impotent. He has a small dick. WHAT?!?
author: d s.

description:
You know you have to be good if you're a pizza place that doesn't deliver, is cash only, isn't open on Monday, and isn't in a super high foot-traffic location.  But they are just that good and its for that reason we are willing to jump on a scooter and try to balance the pizza all the way home as opposed to having someone else deliver.

The deep dish is just phenomenal.  Growing up in Chicago, where deep dish is a staple, my standards are high and are met by Little Star.  We've had them with veggies, meat, but really you don't need more than just cheese.  The tomatoes are sweet, the cheese salty and chewy, and the cornmeal crust always crunchy.  This last time we ordered wings and a salad as well, both of which were well received by our guests.  We accidentally received the wrong pizza one time (which of course we realized once we were home) and after a phone call, they threw a new one in the oven and gave us certificate for half off our next pizza which was cool.  Big, big fan.
author: Erin H.

description:
Jennifer Aniston reportedly made Brad Pitt wait six months before putting out.  And I waited the same amount of time before returning to Little Star.  Coincidence?  I think not. 

My first visit to Little Star in January was forgettable - either because we ordered the thin crust or because the lawyer I was dating had the personality of a turnip.

This time, however, the tasty food and upbeat atmosphere blew my experience through the roof.  Deep Dish "Little Star" Pizza with no onions or douchebag date = 5 Stars from Janney B.    

Busier than other pizza establishments? Yes.  Sexier than other pizza establishments?  Double yes.  Note:  How nice is it to dine in at a pizza place and not feel pressured to hide your love of utensils or your affinity for four-syllable words?

I wish that I had given this place another chance a few months ago.  Just like how Jen may have second-guessed her decision to wait when Brad ended up running off to Africa with the philanthropic philandering hussy who people seem to forget french-kissed her own brother on television
author: Janney B.

description: Love this place! I can never turn down an invitation to eat here. I like the beer, casual vibe, and the OMG good ass pizza! Prices are cheap too. :)
author: Emy s.

description:
411-1118, busy*busy*busy*411-1118, busy*busy*busy*411-1118, busy*busy*busy*411-1118, busy*busy*busy* WHAT THE HELL! They can't be that buszz, oh, I'm dialing the wrong number.

I get the deep dish veggie. It is just delicious. NOTE: when you call in for pick up and they tell you your pizza will be ready in 30 minutes, always add at least another 15 minutes to this, because it will really take 45 minutes for your pizza. If you believe them  and show up after 30 minutes you will have to wait at the bar and drunk people will bump into you.
author: Mitsi M.

description:
Little Star, Little Star
I will travel far
For your sweet sauce,
cornmeal crust,
Champagne cocktails are a must,
I dream of you when I'm not there,
Zachary's in Oakland doesn't compare,
The aroma makes my mouth water,
Too bad they only take dollars,
Can't beat their $1 PBR,
Awaiting my nex trip to Little Star..
author: anne m.

description:
Amazing. This stuff transcends "pizza." If you ask me, it's the perfecters of Chicago Style Deep Dish who deserve fancy awards like the Nobel Peace Prize, not the scientists who invented nuclear power. Not sure how the atomic bomb ever promoted harmony...meanwhile, yummy pizza does! (Granted, I don't blame the scientists--most were pacifists)

We ordered a small deep dish Little Star Pizza, Little Star Style with added chicken, because protein rocks.

Hot, gooey layers of feta and ricotta cheese were filled with fresh mushrooms, spinach, onion, and tender chicken. This plus juicy (and I mean JUICY) tomatoes and yummilicious sauce on crunchy, flavorful crust made my tastebuds very very happy. 

The pizza wasn't even greasy, and miraculously, managed to stay together despite my sloppy eating skillz!!

Some tips for newbies:

-CASH ONLY

-If you're planning to get take-out, bring your own utensils. They do not have plastic utensils or paper plates.

-Baking time for deep dish pizza is 30 minutes. For efficient and wait-free eating, call ahead and order. You will likely spend thirty minutes trying to find a parking space if you would like to park near the restaurant. Even better: call in your order 30 minutes before arriving and have your friend pick up the pizza while you drive around for 5 minutes.

-If you and your friend are hungry, order a Large instead of a Small. (No Mediums). I don't typically eat that much pizza and our Small was decently satisfying for us, but we really could have used more! (It's *supposed* to feed two...) More more more!!

And then THE question: Zachary's or Little Star?

I plead the fifth on this one.
author: K W.

description:
Twinkle, twinkle, little star...
How I love you, but you're so far....

I barely BARELY ever go to NOPA, but for Little Star, I'm going to have to come more often.

Friday night--no wait (that's not a typo).
Food, delicioso.
Cheap beer, even better.

Cash only--eh, whatever.

(Just don't plan on coming here for dessert.)
author: Maureen B.

description:
Holy shit, this is good pizza!  Best I've ever had.  The thin crust isn't all that special...go for the deep dish.  You'll be glad you did.  The little star is my favorite.  The ingredients taste super fresh, and the crust is so cornmeally, buttery, and flaky.  The last time I ate there, I had a big, stupid grin on my face the whole time I was eating.  I couldn't stop smiling--it's that good.  

I prefer Little Star to Zachary's.  The sauce on Zachary's pies is too salty for my taste, and the Little Star crust puts it over the top.  I've been missing this place since I've moved from SF.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Ain't no thing but a chicken wing!

I love wings. I mean I loooooooooooooooooooove wings and am pretty much willing to toss aside whatever eating plan I am on to sloppily devour a pile of them at any time or hour of the day or night. Am I proud of this weakness? Hell yeah I am, a girl who can eat is a girl you wanna know.

SO last night while throwing back glass upon glass of vino at Bar 821, the ol' belly boasted about being starving. "Feed me!!!" Yeah, yeah, in a minute, I'm in the middle of being attacked by Yelp haters. 

My friend then suggested Little Star and my belly and I were very happy at the idea of some pizza. The bartender then tossed us the menu and as we were looking at the pizza choices my eyes automatically drifted up toward Chicken Wings. Hell yeah!!

The guy sitting next to us at the bar said they were pretty phenomenal and seeing as how I have yet to really find wings that make me sing here in SF, I figured what the hell, let's give them a go. When they arrived, they smelled divine. Definitely on the garlicky side which i would normally steer away from, but last night was girl's night, so who cares, hehe.

As for the taste, holy cow! Or chicken I guess in this case. These wings are bomb! Not a typical "hot wing" or buffalo wing, but just a perfectly cooked and deliciously seasoned masterpiece for the mouth. YUM! I will definitely be getting them again and you should too!
author: Stephy S.

description:
Alright, I love pizza.  I really do.  And I never have had a Chicago Deep Dish pizza, and the food was surprisingly good.  After eating my dinner and boxing it up and taking home it was still good.  Put me into an early food coma which I cant complain about.  

But here is what I can complain about Little Star Pizza:

Driving from a museum the restaurant was sandwiched tightly between two businesses.  (I of course had directions).  After getting lost (on the street it was supposed to be on) I called them and asked where they were.  After being told it was on the same block down the street I continued to remain on the phone with them, but they however obviously got kinda impatient and hung up on me.  HUNG UP ON ME!  Without so much as a "Well ma'am your not talking anymore so I guess you are either dead or being quiet but I have a job to do and I hope you find your way to the establishment.  Goodbye"  What is the deal with that?  Usually there are tricks to getting a customer to hang up without seeming like a royal douche. 

Then I found it!

When I went in, I was first greeted by the beautiful and kinda artsy surrounding.  The hostess was very pleasant and showed us to our table.  My family and I ensued in very pleasant dinner conversation when low and behold I spotted a Juke Box!  Wow a Juke Box!  How long had it been since I have seen one of those!?  Eagerly I jumped out of my chair, rushed over to it, searched the deepest part of my pockets for some spare change, but right as i was about to slide my money into the juke box.  The worst tragedy I ever beheld seemed to have fallen on the poor Juke Box.  It was all music by Blondie or a bunch of musicians I have never heard of.  Now don't get me wrong I love Rock but seriously!?  I thought every Juke Box by law was supposed to have at least something good.   Hence the -one star so far.  Now lets continue onto why It doesn't have four stars.

When I got back to my table and sat down, the waitress came up and asked us what we wanted to drink.  I had spent all my day in the city and had worked up a thirst.  My throat was parched and I needed something a little extra besides water.  Looking up, I asked her, "Do you have refills on Coke?"
"No they come in a can"
"Do you have refills on iced tea?"
"No it comes in a glass"
Bewildered I looked and saw that they had a whole bar with tons of beer on tap.  Now here is where I tell you that I am not a fan of alcohol.  But i thought to myself, don't all pizzerias have some sort of refillable beverage on hand besides WATER?!  With a sigh, I said I would order a coke.

Alright so when I eat I love to have a calm atmosphere.  When I was eating, however, a man kept on walking by snapping his fingers as if he were thinking if he left his oven on at home.  Then when I said something to my family he quickly abandoned snapping, for the time being, and started whistling.  Honestly guy, its called decaf!

Now the pizza was extremely good.  I could only eat two slices and that was great.  We ordered the Little Star and the Classic Deep dish.  I loved the pizza and the surroundings but I don't think I will go back again.  But this is definitely a good place if your in the city and need some good Chicago style pizza!
author: josie c.

description:
Thank God for Little Star.  You see, I LOVE Zachary's pizza in Oakland.  But I'm a city boy and Little Star is just as good as Zachary's if not arguably better AND in the city, saving me a drive.  

The pizza here is just like Zachary's, but with a more buttery crust.  True Chicago style deep dish (from what I understand; never been to Chicago, and will not pretend to have been or be an expert on Chicago style deep dish).  The chunky tomato sauce was great, the toppings inside the pizza excellent.  The garlic bread was interesting.  We had to make it.  The spoiled me had a split second knee-jerk reaction along the lines of 'WTF is this $h!t??'. Then as I looked at the fresh, hot bread with the side of butter and a fresh roasted garlic right next to it, I thought this could be fun, and tasty.  And yes, it was both.  Delicious, even.  The garlic was easy to spread and the end result was so good.  The sodas and if I remember right the beers as well, had a nice variety of local and or obscure brands I had never heard of.  Ended up drinking a very, very delicious Black Cherry soda made with real sugar.    

The ambiance was very chill when I went in, (a hot Saturday between noon and 2ish if I remember correctly) and the staff friendly.  Parking was pretty easy.  I really can't emphasize enough how tasty the pizza here was.  Give 'em a try!
author: Sean V.

description: Ok... Here is the skinny - The cornmeal crust is delicious...BUT the filling and toppings just o.k.; not bad, not good...just - ok! For the money, I'm still in love with Zachary's!!!!   Sorry little star:(
author: Sasha T.

description:
I don't know why I hadn't been in here before. I think it was their sign outside; maybe I thought it was just a socialist meeting house or something? But anyway, now I know better. Not like I even need to review it. But I'll be the 1,567th person to give Little Star five stars, because it's wonderful.

I was very surprised by the size of the dining room. I expected smaller I guess. But it's deceiving from the street - you really can't see inside. Which is probably why I thought it was a secret society of some kind. And when I first walked in, I expected to feel like the least attractive, least hip person in the room (as I often do at places like this) but I was pleasantly surprised at the diversity. I even saw some blue collar folk. Fancy that. 

The interior is seductive. Dark, design-y, neutral. And yet artsy. Which I dig. The wall art was painted on window panes (and if you know me you know about my fenestration fetish) so I took it as an omen (because I'm nuts) and decided that this might be my new favorite restaurant. 

But actually, it might qualify in more substantial categories, too. Like the service. Our waiter was probably the best I've ever had, and that includes fancy downtown places. I don't know what his name was. I thought of asking him ("Excuse me, sir, could I get your name to post on the internet?") but decided against it. Anyway, you'll know him if you get him. Because he is AWESOME. 

Speaking of awesome, they have Henry Weinhard's root beer, which pairs itself nicely with their fantastic pizza. It's deep and crispy in the right places and filled with everything you could possibly want and I'll be here twice a week for eternity, k thx. Also, I grew up eating Zachary's and I think this is better. Just to throw my hat into that ring, which will probably come back to haunt me and be a huge pain in my ass, but yes, I think Little Star is better than Zachary's. 

But, we should not have gotten a large. Seriously, get a small for two people. I may never eat again. And I'm pretty good at eating.
author: Megan W.

description:
Have only had this for take out... but I had to ask my friend 3 times what the name of the place was because I was too busy eating the sausage/I forget what else was on it slice and couldn't remember what he had said.....I didn't realize it was this place that everyone raves about. I might have to betray my Berkeley loyalties and say I LOVE it more than Zachary's... Yeah I'm not afraid to say it......ahhh the flavors are just that good....It's kind of like in Ratatouille when the fireworks go off behind him as he's eating in pure bliss....

Just go here.....
author: Kelley N.

description:
I am usually faithful to my New York style pizza, but while in the neighborhood, I thought I might as well try the namesake's deep dish Little Star. 

While I'm still not a convert for the deeper side of the dish, I was very happy to indulge in generous helpings of tomato and garlic piled high over greens and ricotta and mozzarella. It was a meal that kept on giving the next day, and was just as good the second time around.
author: Julia G.

description: still the best pie in the city. nuff said
author: Lenny K.

description:
I'm usually an experience-seeker.  When I go places I like to soak up everything and try my hardest to file my feelings at that moment into my memory.  I am leaving in a week for Germany to visit a friend and I have no plans - I am going there and I KNOW I will see historic ruins and museums, but I don't have an itinerary.  I usually like it that way.

That said, Yelp has made me an information-seeker.  I go places now and find myself dorking out in the corner being like "no she DIDN'T just roll her eyes when I asked about the nightly specials!!"  I'm constantly noting things that may or may not go in my reviews on Yelp.  Collecting factoids, if you will.  Point in case, my experience at Little Star Pizza.

I've heard from friends that Little Star made awesome pizza, and then I Yelped it.  It might just be the #1 yelped about spot in SF. . .there's an overwhelming yay response to the place.  Another friend of mine has said in (hers and others' opinion) that yelp in general is pretty hard on restaurant and bar reviews.  I kind of agree, it ain't hard to get three stars, but it's damn near impossible to get an overall 4.5 stars as an establishment.  Usually, when a place on yelp has a solid 4 stars or above, I just KNOW I'm gonna have a great meal/time.

However, my overall experience at Little Star felt like a field trip. 

"Here I am, FINALLY made it to Little Star. . . now what makes this place so special. . ."

The food is wonderful of course, but I have to say it lacked that great pizza place atmosphere.  It's pizza, I just think it's one food that even if you are in San Francisco the place should be more comfy and homestyle, yo.  There's enough restaurants in SF that try uber-hipster or super she-she.  I wanted there to be maybe one TV, and great domestic beers served in red plastic cups for 4.5 yelpstars, I guess.

:shrug/sigh:
author: Kelly H.

description:
**Update**
The thin crust is the shizzle! Yes, I said shizzle, move on. Although it tasted like pixies dancing on my tongue, that greasy fucker left a stain on the passenger seat of me new car. WAK LS! No fifth start for you.

***************************
The fact that I'm only giving Little Star 3 (and a 1/2) stars may make some of you question my qualifications as an official foodie, but my first experience didn't wow the pants off me. And believe me...I wanted to be standing there in my Gap boyshort underpants blushing like a drunken pirate.

Driving down Divis with boyfriend in a hungry and semi-inebriated state after a heated game of kickball, my eyes fixed on the dainty and modern pie sign dangling outside Little Star. Now, I was in no mood for pizza. Actually I was envisioning myself licking the tahini off a falafel or caressing a damn fine burrito. Boyfriend says to me:

"how about pizza"

"Ick, no! I sooooo don't want piz... Holy shit there's Little Star! I've never been. We're going"

I said this as I sharply turned the corner going 50 mph. It was like a high speed chase in one of the "Fast and Furious" movies but without Vin Diesel and his massive guns and cone-shaped dome. Thank god!

When we arrived, we gave the tiny pixie working the hostess stand our names and were told the wait would be 20 minutes. But fortunately the party of two on the list before us bailed, so we got seated pretty much immediately. Thanks Lisa, Party of 2! I owe you one girl!

We ordered a deep dish pizza. Half Little Star for moi and half salami, garlic and olive for the carnivorous man I call my own.

We started off splitting a small garden salad, which was a perfect size for two and was fresh, light and delicious. I probably would have given the salad one big "meh" if it hadn't been for the two pounds of Gorgonzola they dumped on top. They know me so well...it brings a tear to my eye. I'm all choked up.

The pizza was good. It was really good. The sauce was delicious and just the right amount of spice to leave my lips burning, in that good kind of lip burning way. The crust was corny and mealy and yummy. Ok, so now getting to the three and a half stars *ducks.* The cheese yo! Where is the mother truckin cheese? I need my cheese. Bring out the oxygen tanks cause I can't live without a massive amount of cheese on my pizza! I mean damn yo! I thought you guys knew me. I feel so betrayed.

The toppings were good, but I must admit, I kept looking at the couple with the thin crust pizza next to us with envy. Plus that dumb bitch with the fugly white flats kept eaves dropping on our conversation, which isn't such a nice thing to do when you're bickering with your significant other and hitting his elbows with your knife just to piss him off. Smooches lover!

The pizza was great....but my heart wasn't into giving it the full five stars yet. I mean how is it possible that the best pizza I've ever had is in Chico? I mean when there's nothing better to do in a small college town than drink massive amounts of booze, play Frisbee golf and watch the cows grow, I guess you'd have that time to perfect pizza. But come on! San Francisco is a culinary mecca and I've yet to find pizza the can even compare to my precious (yes I stroke each slice like the ring that ruled them all) Celestinos. I'll come back to Little Star again and again until I can give it the full amount of stars it deserves. But it does need to try a little harder with me. They need to woo me. Court me. Show me they care. And then, after I try each and every concoction they can come up with, will I upgrade my review.
author: Sammy S.

description:
Biased New Yorker here.  But I was willing to try Chicago-Style.  I met my Midwestern friends and prepared for a new food experience.  My verdict?   YAWN.

So THIS is the best Chicago-Style pizza in town?  Please!  Someone take on the challenge and bring yummy, hot, fresh Chicago-Style to SF!  I wanna be converted, really I do....

Little Star was too dark, too loud, too crowded, and way too phony "Urban Hipster" for my tastes.  Luckily I had on a black tee-shirt  - but I was lacking the obligatory tattoo sleeves, black-rimmed glasses, and mussed up hair.  

They have a good beer selection (I learned that PBR is the hip way of ordering Pabst Blue Ribbon).  But I was looking to be blown away by the food.  Our two pies were OK in a tasteless sort of way.  The crust was good but without something yummy to put in it, so what?

SO, perhaps my expectations were set a bit too high, but at these prices for pizza - it better be amazing - not just so so.
author: Jim S.

description:
After your first time here, you'll find yourself CRAVING Little Star pizza. It's all about the deep dish crust at this joint. Golden, with the "just right" crispy on the outside, soft on the inside CORN BREAD CRUST. Yes..I said CORN BREAD! 

You won't be sorry.....next time you think "pizza", Little Star is definitely worth the trip. =D
author: Kat M.

description:
Holy shizzle fizzle ma nizzle!! Shatangi had a good pie here!! The greeting was warm and sincere and our order taken promptly. Had the little star special and it was delivered earlier than promised. the sauce was chunky and well balanced, the cheese melty and not overdone and the other toppings melded harmoniously. However... the crust was king!! I can only compare it to a savory version of a Beard Papa shell. Buttery and crisp with just the right amount of give. By far the best Chi style pie I've had in the BA. I'll ding them a star for the server that seemed less than impressed with our order and add one star for the rest of the staff that made up for her apathy by treating us well.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
Best Pizza? Sorta, but very good and different than other places. After a very, very long bike race on Saturday where I was able to ride more than ever before. I was starving, and the only thing that could quite our stomachs was lots of carbs, sauce, cheese, meat and vegetables. Where do we get all that wonderful goodness in one place? Simple. Pizza.

After the routine brainstorming of pizza places, we decided on Little Star. It took some arm twisiting. Since it was all the way over there, parking is hard and the wait would be super long. A call to Nizario's would have been a good solution, but I won the arguement. Parking was easy, drive was quick but the wait was long.

When you go to Little Star on a week night be prepared to wait 45 minutes to an hour. Luckily there is plenty of seating and a bar. The beer selection is excellent. $4 for a Racer 5 IPA, that alone is worth 3-stars in my book. Three Racer 5 IPAs. four PBRs and two Samuel Adams later we were seated. Since we already decided what to order, it was placed even before we sat down. 

Our two pizzas. A deep dish with tomatoes, sausage, green bell peppers, and mushrooms and thin crust Chicken pesto were a welcome sight. The waiter was impressed we could devour the pizza so fast. We were hungry, and the beer acts as a pizza lubricant.

Sadly they ran out of garlic bread, don't restaurants usually run out of specials not appetizers? Must be some really good garlic bread.

Our deep dish was awesome, never had the real Chicago thing, so this will suffice until a trip takes me out there. Stay away from the Chicken Pesto, it lacked pesto! Almost tasted dry and the chicken was the only noticeable flavor.

Next time, we will place an order for pick up. And enjoy the food at home, where I can promptly fall into my food coma.
author: Ryan G.

description: It's WORTH THE WAIT. I don't care how many people are in front of me, I'll start with a drink at the bar, and wait for my table. I'm still in disbelief I hadn't heard of Little Star Pizza until now. Their deep-dish pizza is a must-try. Unlike other pizza joints, Little Star is a bit more classy. Great vibe, great wine selection, and perfect for intimate groups.
author: Linda T.

description:
When I first moved to the west coast i SWORE that there was no such thing as good pizza (for a reasonable price) in San Francisco.

I have since changed my statement...sorta.

The deep dish at little star is not the best, however. . . the thin crust is pretty darn good. No they're not experts at dough, but the flavor is amazing. 

But the real reason that i love little star? the ambience.

 On the east coast, pizza shops are like dive bars (minus the yelling, beer spilling and ultimate puking). . .  they're hole in the wall spots, where your sole agenda is to :  go in, pick it up, take it out.  Or if you're really smashed and in Manhattan you eat it at the counter at 5 a.m with grease dripping down onto your jeans.  But most of the time, you have the pizza people deliver it right to your door.

On the East Coast, it's tough to find a cutesy  little neighborhood spot where you can cozy up to your hot foreign boyfriend over a beer and admire eachother in the dim lighting while stuffing your face full of pie. (pizza pie!)


Which is why Little Star is a big shining star in my starry pizza pie eyes.
author: JERK STORE ..

description:
Well, I guess my little 5 star review amongst the PLETHORA of 5 star reviews of Little Star isn't really groundbreaking, but what the hey.

After having just suffered food poisoning from pizza (expect scathing yelp review soon) the day before I came here, I was understandably a bit timid and repulsed by the idea of eating pizza again.  

THIS MOTHER F*ING SH*T IS THE BEST PIZZA I'VE EVER HAD.  Holy f*ck, this place has been literally 3 blocks away from where I live and I'm just NOW discovering it??  Damn, I must be oblivious.  We ordered the thin crust pepperoni, and even after vomiting up marinara and mozzarella for the entire previous day, I was all about this glorious pizza.  Perfect balance of cheese, sauce and crustiness.  Laid back atmosphere, fun soundtrack; friendly service.

I WILL be back.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Your taste buds are a curious thing. They're moody and finicky. They get all weird if you're sick, or pissed or drunk. Very interesting little guys, those taste buds are. Well,  my buds were rocking it on Saturday, they were in a pretty good mood and more than ready for some cornmeal crust, spinach and feta smothered in tomato sauce. I have devoured the pizza at this particular Little Star multiple times before its rise to Yelp fame, but like I said it seemed more delicious than usual this weekend.

Maybe it was because of the most random crowd I've witnessed in a restaurant in a while... A group of hip hop sounding kids, a crew of dudes with popped collars and crooked sunglasses (is this a new db trend?) mixed in with what looked like your average suburban family. Or maybe it was because i was absorbed in our conversation bouncing around and I was completely entertained. So, I blathered on in my usual style while my taste buds ignored my rambling and focused on the 'za. I was happy to be here again, it fits my style perfectly, dark, warm with pizza, beer and art.

So, needless to say, my taste buds and I had a fantastic time, and they let me know that they were thoroughly enjoying themselves and everything really does taste way better that way.
author: Michael E.

description: Why does Little Star Pizza need another review? Just to say, hey, people, nice work! Keep it up. Thank you for the best sausage and tomato left-over goodness my refrigerator has to offer.
author: Eloy T.

description:
I finally had the chance to taste what the hype was all about.  I must say their pizza is excellent!  I had the real deal in Chicago last year & this is very close.  You need to time your arrival since they don't take reservations & cash only too!  

P.S.
Parking is a bi*%# around this neighborhood.  Were you surprised?
author: Jo B.

description:
admit facts....digging deep dish...pizza pie...toppings thick hearty....over inch thickness...fine little star deep dish, little small, little pricy....twelve-inch large at $twenty-two....although repeat...fine deep dish pie...one of best had....

second choice standard thin-crust pizza pie....standard sizing sixteen-inch large for same/similar pricing.....standard thin being unworthy of praise...in fact below standard, subpar....
author: Hen A.

description: Seriously this place is SO good. Great beverage selection, amazing appetizers, and most of all perfect deep dish pizza. The service was fast and friendly, the food was clearly fresh and delicious, and very filling! This is a place you definitely want to eat at. I will be back!
author: Jena W.

description:
What else can I say that hasn't been said in the other 450+ reviews?

We had a fun evening with our friend and his dad who was visiting from out of town: Hawai'i to be exact (RIP Don Ho). I enjoyed my creamscile champagne cocktail. Caprese salad, one little star pizza, one chicken pizza. Got in at 6pm to miss the crazy crowd. Sevice was nice. Heated up our leftover pizzas the next day, held up pretty well, but do it in the oven, I don't think Little Star pizzas stand up well to the microwave.
 
Cheap night out! $70 for Caprese salad, 2 small deep dish, 2 cheesecakes, 3 sodas. 
Drinks: $10 for 1 champagne cocktail and a pear cider (I think we caught their happy hour)
author: Caroline C.

description:
Wow....this place was definitely worth the wait, like an hour wait...on a Tuesday night.  It's been a while since I've had some deep dish pizza and I always think that I don't really like it that much, but then I eat it and I fall in love all over again.  

Our party of 9 tried the Little Star, the Classic and the Mediterranean Chicken Pizzas...all large...and it was plenty of food, we even had 1.5 pieces to spare at the end of the night.  I tried all 3 pizzas and they were all fantastic!  My favorite though was the Classic...you can never go wrong with sausage.  I like that the pizzas aren't overly stuffed with toppings and the crust, oh man, it was like a little slice of heaven, all buttery, crispy and delicious.

We even went a little crazy and ordered some chicken wings.  Before we ordered them I consulted the waiter:  "on a scale of 1 to 10 how would you rate the chicken wings?"  to which her replied:  "10."  I was like, seriously 10?  Bring it on.  These chicken wings were good, but trust me, I know chicken wings and they were not a 10, they're a 7 at best.  

After dinner as we were waiting for our friend in the restroom a waiter came over to us and offered to buy us a round of drinks if we would leave our table and go stand at the bar and wait.  Of course we happily obliged and got some free PBRs out of it.  Thanks Little Star, not only for the great pizza, but the stellar service and free PBRs...in the words of the Terminator: "I'll be back."
author: Katherine C.

description:
Excellent thin crust pizza.

Arinell's is still my favorite but those lazy stoners often quit working early and you can't really count on them.  Little Star is an actual restaurant run like a serious business.

Anyway, Little Star has very tasty thin crust pizza.  I really love the sauce.  And the crust is so good I actual eat every bite (that is a big deal, I usually end up with a  plate full of crust stubs after eating pizza)
author: lisa g.

description:
How modest to be named Little Star, when I would have named this place 5 Big Fat Lip-Smacking Stars!

We had high expectations for this restaurant given all of the glowing reviews, and it lived up to all of them.  Because it was our first time, we wanted to try a variety of pies to get the full experience.  

Classic Deep Dish - oh my my, it's absolutely perfect!!  (and I am an uber-critical Chicago girl)  Exactly the right ratio of sauce:  cheese:  crust.  Nice distro of sausage as well.  Deeply satisfying but somehow not too heavy.  Wonderful cornmeal crust that is neither too doughy nor too fluffy.  Fresh chunky tomato sauce which has a great flavor, and is not too acidic or runny.  #1 for me.

BBQ Chicken Pizza - (special of the night) mmmmm, just the right amount of sauce so as not to be overpowering, chunks of chicken, green apple, red onion and cheddar cheese.  Thin, crispy crust.  Beautiful & yummy.

White Pizza - this is much lighter pizza, and works well as a 3rd choice if you have 2 much more boldly flavored pizzas.  Cheese, tomato, zucchini.  I might have added something for a little zing, like arugula, but that's just me.  The others in my party found it perfectly fine as is.

Dessert - cheesecake - good flavor, a bit dry.  Next time I would skip dessert and opt for the garlic bread or a salad instead.

The atmosphere is cool, from the dark walls to the low lights, to the retro couches in the waiting area.  Clientele matches the decor - casual hipsters, all ages.  GREAT juke box, which is key for me - because I usually like to eat pizza at home, so having your favorite music on rotation is the second best thing.  The place is packed, and the noise level is somewhat high, but you'll forget that once you sink your teeth into the delicious food. 

CASH ONLY.

Surprisingly, I think this place will make me eat pizza in SF in an entirely different way - as a true destination dining experience.

(Update 7/19:  Takeout is a viable option here.  Please try to restrain yourself and don't eat while driving.  It will be tough, but you can do it.)

Important tip:  save at least one piece to take home for breakfast the next day.  We did not, and as I write this, I am experiencing a longing for a warm piece of the Classic Deep Dish that is making me sad to my very core.  It's THAT good.
author: Liz S.

description:
2 blocks from my house.  Awesome.
When i first saw that they opened one in the Mission too, i was stoked for this place.  Its so f-n good that they deserve more than one location.
"White pie" is delicious.  Its the thin crust, and i know that most people enjoy their famous deep dish, but mmmmmm....sooo good.  "The Little Star" deep dish is also my fav.  
They reside in this area of the Western Addition where none of the bars/restaurants can sell booze.  Fly bar, Abir, 821, etc....so they dont.  They have beer and wine and i highly recommend the champagne cocktails.  They have one that tastes just like a 50/50 bar.
Another reason im stoked they opened another location....maybe some of the people will go there instead, allowing my wait to be shorter.That would be sweet.
author: Lauren F.

description:
At the risk of losing some friends or fans, I want to state firmly and unequivocally that in the NY vs. Chicago pizza cold war, I am a staunch NY partisan. I like pizza crust, and I think it should have a more significant role in a pie than a container for a mess of sauce and cheese and toppings.

That said, I'm into Little Star. I'm indifferent to the fact that it's not an 'authentic' Chicago deep dish pizza; I like the crisp cornmeal crust and the integrity of the slice; not soggy and messy when you eat it by hand, the way pizza was meant to be eaten. The combinations they offer are sensible as well; None of this California style curry chicken, brussel spouts, and passionfruit nonsense, though they'll probably make it for you if you bring your own sprouts.

It's a pleasant space to be in; Not cluttered, not too bright, not too crowded.

Yes, it takes a while, around 35 minutes from when you place your order, but they're upfront about it. I recommend that you place a to go order, then head over to Bar 821 across the street. You can pick it up when it's ready and take it back to 821 and consume it in front of all the jealous neighborhood drinkers. You'll make lots of friends that way.
author: matthew r.

description:
There are two kinds of pizza in America: Noo Yawk and Chichcago.  Everything else is a pale imitation of one of the two.  There is no such thing as California pizza.  CPK is not pizza.  (It's hog feed.  Wait, that's not fair to hog feed.)  Pizzerias in California that admit defeat and just try to imitate one of the two styles are much better off than those that think they are on to some culinary delight.  

Little Star, like Zachary's, has decided to imitate Chicago pizza.  It does not rise to the level of great Chicago pizza, but it does a good enough job.  Little Star could be a five star establishment if it put a little extra effort into their pizzas.  The crust is awesome, but not as dense as true Chicago pizza.  The fillings are also awesome, but they do not put in enough cheese and let everything just mix together.  The pizzas here are built like Chicago pizzas, but assembled like a New York pizza.  (That means that the toppings are carefully laid out on top of the cheese.  A great Chicago pizza goes for broke and throws everything into a huge mish mash.)  

Little Star has also become a victim of its own success.  Every time I go here, the wait is interminable.  They take reservations now, so avail yourself of this service otherwise you'll be drooling on yourself for an hour as you wait for a coveted table.  Parking around here sucks, so give yourself a lot of extra time.  

Little Star is not true Chicago pizza, but thankfully it is not California pizza either.
author: Chris I.

description:
I am utterly shocked at the high reviews for this place
I swear 90% of the reviewers were either drunk or have no idea what Chicago deep dish is all about

Growing up in Chicago, I am always skeptical trying deep dish places outside the windy city..now having tried Zachary's, Patxi's and now Little Star, I am sorely reminded why, cause they all suck in comparison

none would last a month in Chicago

And I can understand why, Chicago style pizza is really just too heavy for the west coast pallette, cornmeal crust that is flaky and buttery cooked in lard is the only way to go

want specifics:
the crust is stale and hard : 1 star
toppings /cheese : actually no real complaints here but nothing special: 3 stars
sauce: 1 star: too overpowering and tangy, and way too much ratio of sauce when compared to chicago style, which is usually more mellow and spicy

if I had to choose the best deep dish in the bay area would be Zachary's, not chicago style, but still the pizza taste good at least

Good riddance, I am done tyring deep dish here
Bay area has so many good options for pizza in general
author: Peter L.

description:
I gotta say, I'm pretty disappointed with you Little Star Pizza. 

Actually, It's not you... It's me. I just hyped you up so much. Plus, all the glowing reviews and a 4 and a 1/2 star rating on yelp shot my expectations to the moon.

I'm putting you more at 3 and a 1/2 stars for now because I did enjoy the classic deep dish pizza. But the thin crust Italian Combo was way too salty.

Perhaps you guys should start delivering? I wouldn't mind trying some more of your pizzas at home. Plus, it might alleviate some wait time for your customers. But that might take away part of the mystique.
author: Sam T.

description:
LIKED IT.

The pizza crust had the light butteriness of real Chicago pizza -- not the doughiness of Zachary's.  The tomatoes also seemed fresher (i.e., less canned), and the sausage was real and fennel-riffic.  

I suppose I dock it a star because the pizza isn't very saucy or cheesy -- it's quite staid and California-esque.  But still, a good one.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I have to start this review by giving props to Troy McClure SF, extrordinaire....who saw my rant about the pizza here in the bay and pointed me in the direction of this place. 

It is not quite the same as you would get in Chicago but seeing as a pizza night in Chicago will run me $400 in airfare plus the pie I am willing to get the SF version. It is pretty damn close, and a whole lot cheaper!!
author: Drue C.

description:
DAM!  One slice and your stuffed.  That's why I had TWO! + Wings + Cake* + Brownies*.  (*The last two were not a Little Star delight.)

There deep dish is amazing.  The crust is buttery good, crunchy good, and it can hold all the topping without collapsing, whoa!

The wings were good, but very oily.  The celery that came with it was very fresh.  Hot dam, this place is on par if not slightly edging out Zackery's because of location, location, location, and flavor.
author: Po L.

description:
You could easily miss this place on Divis unless someone told you where it was. Once you walk inside its a trendy little spot with TONS and TONS of people waiting to get their hands on some of the best deep dish pizza this city has ever seen. I think what makes these pies so special is their cornmeal crust that is flaky, crispy and delicious. I think I could just eat the crust and dip it in marinara and be happy. 

The Classic is my favorite (sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions) but you couldn't go wrong with the Little Star either (Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions and garlic). Perhaps that one works for your inner vegeterian.   

I've never tried the thin crust but I've heard good things. Bonus for having PRB in a can too. 

Don't forget your Benjamins because they sure don't take American Express....or Visa or Mastercard or any other plastic you have. Cash only yo'.
author: Morgan H.

description:
This is very hard for me to be hard on little star. I love the fact that their pizza is fresh in ingredients, and their chicken wings are greasy, but I am a pac northwest girl and I love my pizza greasy, and just the most unhealthiest thing ever!! so I can't say I don't like little star, but it's just not my flavor of choice. But I would recommend it to my friends that like cornmeal crust and not the doughy greasy stuff I am used to.

so zachery's is still my ALL TIME FAVORITE! sorry guys!!! oakland here I come for some damn good deep dish pizza!!!
author: Nina M.

description:
Why do I love Little Star?
- Because the classic deep dish pizza is perfectly proportioned with cheese to sauce to meat
- Because the melt in your mouth goodness leaves you wanting for more
- Because the chicken wings are BAKED not FRIED and not overly sour nor saucy
- Because the garlic bread comes with an entire cloak of baked garlic which you spread on the toasty bread
- Because even though the average wait is 30min - 1hour, the aroma of deep dish pizza being served is enough to keep you distracted
author: Sue L.

description:
I should be working right now. But all I can think about is my lunch I brought today. mmmm 2 fat slices of leftover Little Star deep dish Mediterranean Chicken pizza. YUM!

This pizza was great - a huge mix of all the promised ingredients and the deep dish large looks small but weighs a ton and is very filling. Can't wait to try a thin crust next!

Minus one star for no deliveries and cash only but thank god they are so close to my sisters house!
author: Jessica L.

description:
After all the hype on yelp, my husband and I went to check out Little Star.  I had prepared myself for a 30 minute wait - at least, but we got seated immediately.  I think being a small party helped.  Great pizza!  GREAT pizza!  We ate every bite.

2nd visit:  A two hour wait from the time we walked into the door to the time the pie arrived.  Whoa, Nelly!
author: T-Bone L.

description:
Dear Little Star Divis,

I haven't been to you in awhile, but we used to hang together a lot. Now I go to the mission location because it's closer, but I feel you're more intimate, and sometimes I wonder if your pizza is better too.

In any case, I miss you!

Remember me and my regular order of your signature pizza.
author: Alexandra M.

description: I took my boyfriend here for lunch on his birthday a few weeks ago :) We ordered the roasted garlic bread and small Little Star deep dish, which was more than enough for the two of us. The pizza was delicious with tons of filling - ricotta cheese, spinach, mushrooms, and chunky tomatoes. The only thing about the pizza that I wished was different was the crust. I was expecting it to be doughy and soft, but it was actually pretty crunchy and hard. Other than that, we thoroughly enjoyed our experience here :)
author: Krizia M.

description:
As a long time fan of Zachary's pizza I was looking forward to trying this place out, and it didn't disappoint!

In my opinion, there are two big differences in the pizza served up by Little Star and Zachary's...Little Star's pizza is less cheesy and has a cornmeal crust. Based on the mood you're in when you step into the restaurant, this could be a good thing or a bad thing. I perceived it as a good thing because it represented a change, and change don't hurt.

The restaurant's atmosphere is pretty dark and it gets quite loud in there (partly because of their fantastic jukebox)...as a result I had to struggle to hear the person sitting across the small table from me.

The host and staff were terrific, and the food and drink were excellent. We had the mixed salad and the classic deep dish pizza. The nice thing about less cheese is that I didn't feel that oh-so-popular 'post-Zachary's bloat' that we all get when we go one slice too deep...

It took me a while to make it here, but I'll be back!
author: Art D.

description:
Sure, you come inside to what looks like a socialist joint with a restaurant logo that looks reminiscent of the former communist Soviet Union's sickle.  The pretentious crowd might look like hipster too cool for school, but the deep dish pizza is damn good and it somehow works.  Also, you can't go wrong with a place that has the Stones on the jukebox with stuff like Stevie Wonder, Elliott Smith, Arcade Fire, and more.

As for the pizza, I was initially torn between Zachary's and Little Star having grown up on Zack's during my tenure at Cal!  But what seals the deal for me is the fact that Little Star's cornmeal crust is what makes this a winner.  It's a crust that's unlike any other.  The crust of the deep dish pizza at Zack's just doesn't compare, it's bland in comparison.  Definitely the best pizza in SF, and the Bay for that matter!
author: Colbert T.

description:
Reading all of the reviews on how people like Zachary's better, I didnt expect this place to be that great. But to my surprise, I thought the pizza was amazing and even better than the deep dish pizza at Zachary's!! I had the vegetarian pizza and I would recommend it anyone! 

The only downside to this place would be that parking is impossible. It took us a good 30 minutes to find parking and when we got into the place, the wait time was an hour and a half. But I guess there is a wait for a reason!
author: Linh F.

description:
I waited until I tried Zachary's in Berkeley before deeming Little Star Pizza the best I've EVER had. 

Zachary's cardboardy, Dominoes-style deep dish crust isn't in the same league with Little Star's buttery cornmeal crust. 

Proof that it was amazing: Being the old ladies that we are, Rebecca P. and I both got ridiculously sick afterward from all the greasy, cheesy yumminess, and we'd STILL go back, order the same thing, and endure all of the gastrointestinal distress all over again. We might bring a bucket full of Pepto and Pepcid next time, though.

Rebecca's ingenious pizza combination: deep dish with mushrooms, red bell peppers, and feta. 

Oh, and the cheesecake! I dream of it still....
author: Kelly S.

description: I love the little star deep dish. I have been coming here for years and I never deviate from the little star pizza and caprese salad. My son loves the jukebox and picking out songs for us to listen to. You may have a wait if you come in past 7:00 pm, but you can always order ahead for take out.
author: Susan G.

description:
I came here a few months ago with the bf and remember being a bit overwhelmed by the pizza.  Not that I didn't like it, I just felt that it was a serious meal for which one needs to fast for days to adequately enjoy.

Well I returned last night with some girlfriends and had a totally different feeling when leaving.  We ordered two small pizzas for 4 girls (one deep dish vegetarian and one thin crust white pie) and it was the perfect amount of food.  No one felt like they were going to combust upon completion of their meal and the variety was satisfying!  

Another good note was that 2 small pizzas, a bottle of wine, and a 20% tip came out to $17/person.  Not bad!

I will not hesitate next time my extremely handsome bf says "how about little star tonight."
author: Meagan C.

description:
Don't know about eat-in but take-out is pretty damn handy.  

Though I have a loyalty to Zachary's in the East Bay, I have to say that this is pretty damn good. The chicken wings are deliciously seasoned and the deep dish pizza is very flavorful and succulent (succulent is such a weird word...sounds kinda dirty doesn't it?)

Anyway...if you happen to be happy houring on Divis (and you should) give Little Star a call and go pick up a pizza or some wings for dinner. Maybe if you're lucky the bar will let you bring it back to eat with your beer.  

Minus one star for the deafening levels of noise in that place.
author: Jay H.

description:
My mom is from New York.
My dad is from Chicago.

Little Star trumps that shit. 

Thank's - it's tough being a little bay area baby & repping for more than dim sum, but I've found my thin crust & my deep dish (very conveniently around the corner from my apartment). 

Service & Ambiance is very SF - The servers are young, hip, amicable & attentive. Some of them are pretty cute, not gonna lie. That's some missed connections shit right there. The actual restaurant is quite small - expect to wait some time for a table - but very chic with whimsical art & dim lighting. Best juke box ever, the 6ths? yes please. I like this as a dating spot, although garlic is kind of a no-no for the first few dates & what the hell is pizza without garlic? & really...who in SF dates the same person long enough to reach that comfort level? uh, no one.

Order the Garlic Bread! Warm Semifreddi's Sour Batard with a roasted glove of garlic & a olive oil / butter spread. I've made a dinner of it. 

I like the Vegetarian Deep Dish ordered as a thin crust (yes, they will make it) sans olives. 

New favourite is the Classic Deep Dish - since I decided that animals are really fucking tasty & should occasionally be consumed, this is one of my most extreme "F you's" to veganism/vegetarianism. Go hard or go home. Cornmeal crust = really nice, although a little bit under-salted.

I'm always too full to try the homemade cheesecake, but it's on my to do list. 

Nice bar, wish it was roomier & I would come here more often for just a beer.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description: Little Star is some of he best pizza I have ever had. There is nothing I can say here that hasan't been said a 100 times in other reviews. Can't go wrong here, even as a date spot for pizza the ambiance is really nice too. I really like their cornmeal pizza crust
author: Michael C.

description:
Stopped in here impromptu on a Sunday evening for dinner with a group of friends. They quickly and politely accommodated our group of 7. We didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes before being sat.

I didn't think good pizza existed in California, until I had Little Star's. The deep dish here is unbelievable. The crust was good and crunchy despite the generous portions of cheese and veggies. The sauce was perfect - tangy and slightly spicy.

The waitress was superb at making sure we were amply supplied with water and anything else we needed.

I will definitely be returning for more when I'm in the area.
author: Falyn J.

description:
UPDATE:  Sometime last week of October. . .I had dinner at Little Star with my fabulous friend Mary.  We arrived at 6pm on Wednesday and had the pick of tables.  Service was perfect, food was tasty, we left happy.  Oh yeah, they have a good wine list but I'm on the wagon of course. . .wink

DISCLAIMER:  I think this might be the most boring review I've written. 

This is a TAKE AWAY review only however, picking up the pizza, the interior of this place is cute with nice ambiance. . .I will gladly add another star after I eat in the restaurant if the service is up to par.  

I was not interested in this pizza at all.  I'm a thin crust pizza lover.  I had Zachary's pizza and the food coma I had from that experience was so bad, it pretty much turned me off the deep dish pizza for good I thought.  I'm not a fan of feeling painfully full after eating a meal.  Then, my date suggested Little Star, and because I'm normally the one who makes plans (I'm a default planner take charge type of person), I agreed, happy to let someone else be in charge of the plans.  I would not have chosen Little Star Pizza if it were up to me. 

I'm glad I tried Little Star.  We ordered the salad which was super fresh.  I would even order the salad to go in the future without pizza.   We also ordered two pizza's, one deep dish and one thin crust.  Both were really good.  The deep dish was perfect.  I like the crust and the sauce.  I like my pizza crust crispy, and both thin and deep crusts were crispy (but not burnt).  The pizza's were NOT oily or overly cheesy which I also liked.  

I'm one of those people who wouldn't choose to eat pizza unless it's sort of fancy and a gourmet-like experience (caveat being I'm drunk, when it becomes a medicinal type thing).  That said, Little Star Pizza was way above good pizza in my opinion.  They use fresh high quality ingredients which you can taste with each bite.  

When it comes to thin crust, I'll probably stick to other places in the city known for their thin crust pizza but if I want deep dish pizza, I'll come back to Little Star for sure.

Viva Little Star Pizza!
author: James M.

description:
Review for anyone from the East Coast - go in with low expectations or just skip it altogether.  

Deep dish and (relatively) thin crust are available.  They use cornmeal crust (similar to NYC's Two Boots) that has nice crunch but is a poor substitute to real crust.  The cheese and sauce have no soul or magic to it - this is the type of pizza that requires toppings to be satisfying.

If you come by and this place has its typical 30+ minute wait, just skip it.  If you're really jonesing for toppings-dependent pizza, you can go to Extreme Pizza on Fillmore.
author: Scott R.

description:
Firstly, I believe NY and Chicago style pizzas to be two completely different foods and it is entirely impossible and illogical to compare them.

Secondly, Little Star is freakishly amazing!  "Do you want to go to Little Star" is actually a rhetorical question as far as I'm concerned.
I go to Little Star for the deep dish.  I've never had the thin.  I'm too obsessed with the deep.

This is the only place in the Bay area that can compare to Zachary's.  Honestly I could toss a coin between the two.
author: Joe M.

description:
Not since Gino's East in Chicago have I had such amazing deep dish pizza!  Being a new resident of the Western Addition/NOPA area, I had heard from several people about Little Star.  They did not disappoint!  Deliciously filling pizza, lovely mixed green salad, garlic bread with REAL roasted garlic (YUM).  I couldn't ask for a better meal!  

Only negatives are a)the size (tiny!) and b)their times....they don't open until 5:00 pm so don't expect to go there for lunch!

Looking forward to trying different types of pizza there...love that it's within walking distance!
author: Melanie N.

description:
Here's why 2 points can equal 5 stars:

1. Yes, better than Zachary's (and I have mad love for Oakland that might usually color my rating; not this time).
2. I can't get that Little Star special deep dish off my mind. I think I will add that pizza to my list of polygamous options. Don't worry, grilled cheese-- I still love ya, baby.
author: Michie L.

description:
This place is pretty good. In my opinion this is not as good as Zachary's pizza. But since I don't live in the east bay anymore Zachary's is not an option. However if my hubby was writing the review he would give this place 5 stars. he loves the crust. The cornmeal crust is pretty good. 

parking is a biotch but is probably manageable. I usually call in my order before I leave work and it's ready by the time I get there more or less.
author: Leena C.

description: I've only tried the deep dish pizza, but I know this is a great place if you want pizza, and a lot of it.  I'm normally a heavy eater, and normally can eat an entire Costco pizza, but the deep dish here got me - no matter how good it was, I just couldn't finish a whole pie.  Great if you're going with a group of friends though!
author: Josh Q.

description:
Ok yelpers, you guys are totally right on this one! I've done take out here twice now and I've totally fallen for this pizza. And thanks for the garlic bread suggestion -- yum, my mouth is just watering thinking about it. I'm totally psyched to come here and eat in person sometime.

I've lived in Chicago and have had the real deal. Is Little Star a true "chicago style pizza"? I don't know and I don't care. Its awesome pizza regardless!
author: Neil K.

description:
Have you ever wondered about the term "pizza pie"? Because I have. Most pizzas are definitively NOT pie-like. Fascinating, I know.

Well go to Little Star and be prepared to eat some fucking PIZZA PIE. It's a cornbread crust pie. For serious. And I mean that in the best possible way. Our pie had in it delicious tomato mess, spinach mixed with fresh ricotta and probably crack. 

You are going to like it. You are going to like it so much that you will eat until you feel like you want to die. But you won't die -- you will just vomit. And then you can eat some more.
author: Beah B.

description:
The pizza is fine, but why is it so freaking DARK in here? 

Not New York-style, but good.
author: Karsten P.

description: If you are patient you'll be rewarded with some quality deep dish pizza, but watch out for the health tax!
author: Murphy O.

description:
Continuing my pizza quest, we tried a large deep dish pizza and a small thin crust. The breakdown is as follows:

Bad sign number one: the people eating here all looked like people I don't like.

two: they "ran out of large thin pizzas." Uhhh....?

which means they three: freeze their pizza dough or get it from somewhere else

resulting in four: crust that tastes like Freschetta (straight from your local Safeway!)

five: all my friends agreed that it tasted like Freschetta

and six: Zachary's is better, from the crust to the flavor of the sauce and ingredients. 

My bottom line: It just isn't that great.
author: Brian K.

description:
WOW. I mean....WOW. This pizza was oh so good...finger lickin good...so good I (a little Asian girl) ate twice as many slices than each of the 6 other guys and 3 girls I came with!

This pizza really was amazing. Really, how could the crust still be crispy under the layers and layers of sauce and cheese and toppings? I don't know! But it IS! According to my Chicago-born friend, this place is as good as any pizza place in Chicago. Of course, this means that it's BIG slices. For the 10 of us, we got three large pizzas, a few beers and such...and we each paid like 10 bucks. Christine was def a happy camper.

Alright so why is it so good. We got the classic, which has big chunks of sausage on it (mighty tasty sausage I must say), mushrooms, and bell peppers. I have to admit that I don't like bell peppers, so I picked out the big pieces and I couldn't taste the rest. The sauce on top is really tasty, as are the toppings. But what really gets me is the crust. I love crispy crust and it is crispy! Eat fast though, it gets cold and loses its crispness as time passes (duh.). 

The place itself is small, cramped, and talk about CROWDed. But boy. worth the wait. Just do it.

This was the ultimate pizza-gasm for me. The end.
author: Christine L.

description:
I don't know what is the deal w/ all the other 4 & 5 star ratings. I can only say satisfactory over all. I had better deep dish pizza else where although I am not a pizza aficionado. I don't like the crust so much, not with cornmeal. Also, i would prefer a bit more cheese. The sauce is not too bad; so, for the pizza. I would say 2 stars. 

The salad was simple and good, but the chicken wings were just standard. Plus the modest interior but not the usual Italian cliche, I give an overall 3 stars.

I will have another try of the thin pizza. I hope that's what I am missing. 

Last thing, it's very hard to find it at night. I drove by three times not seeing it. It's sign was dark and small. Maybe I was expecting the usual cliche for the sign like white, green, and red stripe awning says" Little Star Pizzeria," but, no. It is at the end of the strip and doesn't seem to have any more business, you know.  Should the management pay some attention to this ^_^, I don't know. 

Anyway, you need to have its address to find it. It's at the conner of an unlikely place.
author: MJ W.

description:
Worth. The. Hype.

Like some of the other reviewers, I'm from the Midwest and have some street cred when it comes to deep dish pizza.

This is the best pizza I've had since I moved out West.  And the fact that its very very close to my new place is just plain fan-f*&^ing-tastic.  

And I thought throwing that old lady down the stairs was going to HURT my karma. Not so my friends. Not so.
author: Matthew R.

description: The best Deep Dish in the bay area hands down and Zachay's knows it.
author: Chris D.

description: The ambience of this place definitely adds to mystique of Little Star. It's dark and music is always being played so it's not your typical pizza parlor. It's true there's a long wait but it's worth it. Try to get one of their great pomegranate drinks to make the time pass while you wait for your seat or for your pizza. I've tried both the regular and deep dish pizzas and both are good but the deep dish is worth the extra few minutes! Definitely one of the best places in the city for pizza.
author: Nina R.

description:
OMG OMG OMG YESSSSSSSSSSSSSS yessssssssssss yesssssssssss yesssssssssss!!!

l ... i ... t ... t... l ... e ... 
s... t ... a ... r ... 
p ... i ... z ... z ... a ...

Oh yeahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh!  Baybee!

~smokes cigarette~
author: Gwen P.

description:
For expediency/laziness, I want to point you to my review of Little Star on Valencia, but there are a few key differences.

Little Star Divisadero is smaller, but it doesn't seem to affect the wait time. There are a couple nearby bars/cafes to while away the time, unlike the island LSV, which to my knowledge has only Four Barrel in its proximity (review to come).

Same menu, same delicious salads and pizzas, similar hard-working/hipster staff, same decent bar with decent prices. Same level of crowdedness, thus your dinner-conversation volume will need to rise precipitously in order to be heard.

But (and this is the key), I've been to Little Star too many times to count, and not once have I had anything less than a great night out. That says a lot.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Delicious Deep Dish pizza (did you catch that?  thats a triple "D").  

don't forget to put money in the juke box
author: Astrid T.

description:
LITTLE Star gets FIVE stars in this reviewer's opinion.  My wit knows no bounds.

I think telling you a story about a recent experience I had at SFO will give you an idea about this pizza.  Or maybe not, and I just like hearing my own stories.  You be the judge-

My girlfriend/domestic partner and I are departing for a multi-stop, 9-hour, cheap,  red-eye to Boston via Cinncinasty.  Little Star is conveniently located .3 miles away.  We order a "Little Star" pizza, which is an actual pizza choice on the menu.  And it's so damn good.  I'm from the east coast, and if you're looking for that kind of pie, don't come here.  But this deep dish is amazing.  The little star is downright addicting.  So we grab a large to go.  This is enough for 2 for airport dinner and some on-plane munching.  

So we're at the airport, hunkered down, sitting on the floor, $6 airport brand bottled water at the ready, and the box is opened.  The smell permeates.  All eyes seem to be focused on us.  A series of comments ensues-



Tourist kid- "Hey Dad, let's get one of those"
Tourist Dad- "Did you get that here?"
Us- "No"
Tourist kid- "I want one"
Impressed Guy- "That's from Little Star isn't it?  "
Us- "Yeh"
Random Guy- "they obviously don't have that here?"
Us- "No"
Impressed Guy- "Wow guys...wow, that's amazing"
Bitter Hipster- (eyes averted and under his breath) "Cool, screw you guys" (then proceeds to walk by and give us a bitter hipster thumbs up behind his back).  

As we proceed across this great country everyone within a 3 foot distance makes a pizza comment.  This was clearly no piece of crap Wolfgang Puck airport pizza we had in our possession.  Someone had brought in pizza from the outside, and it's the best damn pizza one could bring.


5 Senses summary-
 
See-  People get borderline violent at the site of your pizza enjoyment
Hear-  The Postal Service or Prince on the jukebox
Taste- Lots of Garlic...this is good.
Touch-  The menu next to where it says "little star" and tell your server "I would like this one"
Smell-  Lots of Garlic...this is good.

PROTIP-  $2 PBR all the time and $1 Happy hours = leave the house and get drunk for once!
author: Steven S.

description: This place was great. The deep dish classic pizza was amazing. Don't miss the garlic bread. We'll be back soon to sample more of their menu.
author: Kirk W.

description:
Best pizza in town?  Not quite, but it's very, very good.  I rank it #4.

Go to Little Star if you're into the scene or headed to a show at the Independent, but for the best try: 

#1 Pauline's Pizza
#2 Delfina Pizzeria
#3 Zante's, if you're looking for something unique -- Indian pizza.  

(Take your Zante's home -- no reason to eat in the restaurant, unless you also want some tikka massala or sag paneer with your 'za.)
author: Daniel S.

description: I've tried pies from three of the most popular pizzerias in Chicago and hated.every.one.  But Little Star is in a class all its own.  The crust is just so crunchy and chewy and filled with corn-tastiness.  I had it for the first time a couple of years ago, then again last night.  It was every bit as good as I remembered.  Chicago should be embarrassed that San Francisco makes better Chicago-style pizza than it does.  The leftovers are waiting for me in the office fridge...lunchtime can't get here fast enough.
author: Valeria R.

description:
3.5 Stars 

I am a huge critic when it comes to pizza. I am not one to give praise unless I feel it's something truly noteworthy. My family would travel back east often and my father made sure we had only the very best pizza at our fingertips. Places like Round Table were just not in our vocabulary.

With that being said, my three star rating is twofold - one whole star was taken due to some pretty lousy service. Our pizza took over 30 minutes to get to us - pies kept coming out, none of which were ours and were being served to patrons who had arrived much later than us. Our server, while friendly enough, didn't check on us once during that time.

The other half star is due to the fact that the deep dish pizza, while amazing, is still not quite as good as the deep dish I've experienced in Chicago.

Overall, I would definitely go back and would encourage people to try it. I just hope that in the future the service is up to par, especially when I'm spending $18 on a SMALL pizza.
author: Julia N.

description:
Let's get technical:  really I think Little Star is about a 3.8, but it's Friday and I'm in a good mood.  4 it is.

Poor Little Star.... it's true Chicago-style pizza obsessives like me who walk into their artsy and hip establishment with an automatic chip on my shoulder and a skeptical glimmer in my eye.  "This may be 4-5 Yelp stars, but it will never, and I mean *never*, compare to my beloved Lou Malnati's in Chicago, IL."  Of course this was never uttered out loud but anyone paying close attention could read the holier-than-this-"pizza" smirk all over my face.  I hate people like me sometimes.  That whole "my pizza vs. your pizza" dichotomy is never going to win me any friends.  I digress...

In all actuality, I gave Little Star a fighting chance and you know what?  They didn't really let me down.  Coming into it, knowing what I know and tasting what I've tasted, I wasn't expecting much.  But most of the key features were deftly delivered.  Stringy, thick cheese:  yes.   A top surface slathered with fresh, tangy diced tomatoes:  yes (maybe even a wee bit too many).  Thick crust: yes, but here's what they missed out on and how they inevitably redeemed my shoulder chip - their crust was too grainy and too hard.  Not enough butter, maybe?  It was like taking out a batch of cookies and going, "Crap, that 1.5 extra minutes really makes a difference."  I want to be able to lick up every last ounce of my deep dish, and here I couldn't get the fork to slice through the fortress of crust edge.  

It was good pizza.  But not so good that I get that guilty cheating on Lou Malnati's vibe.  *Whew.
author: Kate M.

description:
Delish deep dish pizza with a surprise ingredient in the crust -- cornmeal!  Makes it interestingly good.  Heard the thin crust isn't too shabby either.  No wait for a table on a weekday night.  Poor honey had a hard time finding parking though.  Our caprese salad had been on the table for a good 10 min. before he came inside after dropping us off.

There was a lil drama between some workers in the kitchen and a guy at the bar.  People were being held back, words were exchanged, etc.  Kinda distracting.  I'm like DAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAANG, can a girl eat her pizza??!?!??!  Wish they handled their bizness in the back or just asked the guy to leave as opposed to putting him back on his bar stool to drink more.  Homefry came back for a 2nd go around while I was ordering dessert.  Minus 1 star.

One thing I noticed was the pizza didn't come out piping hot like Zachary's.  Ingredients wise, not sure if it's better than Zachary's.  They're different, but equally good.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Awesome Chicago Deep Dish Pizza. One small is good for two people and the large is good for 3 people. I tried the one with spinach, ricotta and feta. GREAT!!! The crust was so delicious that I could have cut out the entire center and just ate the crust like a giant donut. That would have made me perfectly happy.

A nice thing about the restaurant was that the menu wasn't crazily overwhelming with choices. There were about 6 deep dish pizzas to choose from the you can create your own.

The thin pizza looked great (from what I saw of other diner's orders). The crust looked to be cracker thin which is just how I like the thin crust. I'll have to go back to try it for myself. 

Go early so you can get a table. Otherwise, the wait at 8pm is about 45 minutes. You can preorder your pizza when you put your name on the wait list so that your pizza will come out maybe 10 minutes after you sit down.

If you don't want alcohol, order the ginger beer. It's sweet and spicy. It's not as good as Bundaberg, but it's still tasty.
author: Rex D.

description:
Hearty.  Dark.  Gratifying.

The fact that you have to wait an hour for this pizza is testament that you'll always have a fresh, burning hot pizza.  I'm more of a thin crust gal, but if I'm craving a taste of Chicago, Little Star is the place to go! 

This pizzeria is hidden, small, and dark - as I recall, candlelit only. The bf and I were seated in a hidden corner table, transforming this last minute decision pizzeria into a romantic getaway!  Entertainment was provided by the jukebox and the crazy, drunk lady adjacent to our table.  Her date seemed something short of terrified and our server had good humor to laugh about it with us.

Careful when you get your pizza!  It's fresh from the oven and will burn your tongue!  But let it cool and allow yourself to sink your teeth (if you can manage) into this beautiful entity of sensual pleasures!  The crust, unlike many deep dish pizzas, remains miraculously crunchy and has a delicious grilled flavor.

Two slices had me stuffed.  Tastes great the next day cold OR hot!

Know Before You Go:
1. Hour wait for deep dish pizza pies
2. Average 15-20 minute parking search during evening hours.
author: Jane L.

description:
This place is delightful. The pizza was rad. The wings were good and the mozz and tomato contraption was luscious. 

This is the best pizza I've had on the west coast thus far. I have no idea why I have been living in this city for 8 months and this is the first time I've eaten here. It is hard not to blame my roommate for this. If you are reading this O, you should know I hid no less than 4 scorpions in your room. In addition, remember how you had a cat? Now, not so much. He has been replaced by a badger. The cat was delicious. I hope you enjoy your badger.
author: N S.

description:
This pizza sucked.  We ordered the Little Star Special and it looked like an accident- chunks of red (tomato) and globs of green (spinach) was delivered to our table and it seriously looked like vomit.  The cheese was on the bottom, with diced garlic (no lie- diced garlic) and who the hell wants to eat cornbread pizza anyway?
