1980's pseudo-gothic atmosphere- weird.

No stars.
author: yvette l.

description: Thank you Little Star, for elevating the pizza experience. Picture their joint like Goat Hill Pizza, but dim the lights, toss the red and white checked tablecloth, throw some cool art on the walls, add a jukebox, your own waiter, deeelicious corn meal crust and deep dish, nice wine list, fresher than fresh salads, mix in some West Add hipsters and lose the families and babies. Kids, this is the sexy pizza parlor of our imagination. Bravo I say. Brav-freakin-o.
author: Genevieve R.

description:
A better pizza than Zachary's, but I had to take a star away from little star because I didn't like the way the waiter took off with our money and never returned with change.  The service had been good, but not THAT good--still, I'd go back. (Bringing lots of SMALL BILLS to leave the 20% tip that I normally leave when service is good, not 35 or 40%)

Ah, also--this is a CASH ONLY operation...we were lucky we had cash on us to cover the bill (and an enormous tip.)

There's a non-denominational ATM on site, but it probably gives itself a huge tip, too, so watch out.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Went here for dinner before a concert at the Independent. Got here at around 730 and less than ten minutes later, we got a table. Looked like we got there right before the dinner rush since the place filled up by the time we started eating. Great service, super nice waiters and host. Complimentary deep-fried artichoke heart with oregano was delicious. Shared a bottle of Tiziano Chianti with my friend. Started off with the roasted garlic bread, which was tasty but nothing special. Split a thin crust classic pizza (sausage, mushroom, bell peppers and onion). Didn't think I would be so full, but it would definitely come back for more tasty food. 

Cash only! Although they do have an atm at the restaurant. Pretty hard to find street parking. Seating is made up of small tables, which I'm sure they could combine, but would probably have to wait longer for groups larger than 4. Also, no reservations.
author: Joyce C.

description:
We've been trying to go to Little Star since before Christmas when I'd noticed it had a great Yelp rating. We tried to go early in the afternoon after church but discovered that one location opens at 3 PM. and the other at 5 PM. - we were at the 5 PM. one. So we left for awhile, went to Green Apple Books and spent some money there... then came back about 5:05 for dinner. We were able to be seated immediately but it was the last table available and the line began to form immediately after we were seated. 

It is a small place, maybe 25 tables. Nice atmosphere, interesting wines and cocktails on the reader board but we ordered diet coke. Our dinner was a large thin crust pepperoni pizza and it was very good. The staff is colorful and friendly - we ate and left as quickly as we could to make room for other people to be seated and have their Valentine dinner too. 

We'll go back again some day - but right now we're trying to try 40 new restaurants this year in honor of my husband's 40th birthday today.
author: Bridget M.

description:
We were a party of 16, with reservations, and sat as soon as we got there, because we made sure everyone was there at precisely 8pm.  Since we were a large party we made it very simple for the waitstaff and one person ordered all the food.  Salads could've used a little more dressing, but the pizzas definetly made up for it.  WOW!!!   We had the thin crusted chicken pesto, UMMMMM.  And OH, the deep dish...OOH, OOH, OOH...I could eat the cheese pizza myself (well, not really, if I could, I would.)  Service was great, very friendly and accomodating.   We all left there very happy!!!
For large parties, have everyone meet at BAR 821, across the street an hour before dinner, a great way to gather the troups to ensure your large party will be seated as soon as you arrive. 
Happy eating!!
author: Gemma P.

description:
When I moved to San Francisco, my friends introduced this place to me, and it has since become the standard at which I now measure all pizzas.

I can't say enough good things about this place. When you go, expect to wait 10-20 minutes to get a table. Before thinking twice, i'll tell you now, its WORTH THE WAIT!

They have a nice bar there, where you can order some beer or wine to drink while you wait. The music and atmosphere there is great. They don't spend a lot on the decor of the place, but, whatever they have done seems to work really well. Low light, lots of people, good drinks, almost makes you forget that you actually came to this place to eat pizza. So, the wait flies by.

The pizza - wow. Deep dish, and thin crust. I recommend the white pizza veggie thin crust, and the meat deep dish. Unreal. Something about their crust is different, and tastes really really good.

I haven't been in over a month, and I can't stop thinking about it!


Update:
---------

Just went. Holy crap! Tried the deep dish with spinach and garlic, etc.. and had an out of body experience.

One other note - BRING CASH - they don't accept plastic.
author: Lee M.

description:
I LOVE LITTLE STAR!!!! Screw Zachary's! They ain't got nothin' on Little Star. The tomatoes in the the sauce are like little pieces of heaven. And the garlic bread is perfection. Oh, and the juke box f-ing rocks. My favorite pizza is the Little Star deep dish with chicken. You will NOT be dissapointed. My husband and I always get that pizza with a couple appetizers and 1-2 drinks each and I don't think our tab has ever been over 60 bucks. That's awesome!

My only bone to pick is that they used to accept cards and now its cash only. There is an ATM in the restaurant though. Happy dining!!
author: Kandace K.

description: Not many places do deep dish well especially on the west coast. Well congrats to Little Star as they really do a great job of it. Staff just gets it, great vibe. Will come back again and again.
author: Douglas C.

description:
Excellent deep dish pizza with fresh ingredients and decent service.  Little Star easily measures up with the best Chicago-style pizza establishments in the bay area.  If there is a wait upon your arrival, simply stroll on over to the bar, purchase a cheap PBR, and enjoy the music.  

There are a few things that are missing here that you would find at say.....Zachary's.
1.  Little Star does not accept credit cards.  Seriously?  Zachary's made the adjustment, maybe Little Star can follow suit?
2.  The servers do not plate your first slice of pizza.  According to my Chicago friends, this is a must in order to stay true to the concept of Chicago-style pizza pie.
3.  Closed for lunch
author: David A.

description: I really enjoy Little Star's deep dish, but both Zachary's and Patxi's are better.  That's not to say that it's not delicious, I'd definitely nosh on Little Star's pizza before a lot of things in the world.  Their unique twist on deep dish is the addition of cornmeal to the crust.  It tastes good, but there is something too crispy-crunchy about it for my taste.
author: Juan R.

description: Yummy! I live out of town and make it a point to come here every time I am in town.  The deep dish is a good combination of good old fashioned greasy food with very fresh ingredients that balance it out.  It is a must!
author: Meaghan H.

description:
OMG I'M REVIEW #100.

sweet. 

blah blah yummy blah blah zachary's blah blah pizza snobbery from east of the rockies blah blah blah you've heard it all before.
author: Tom H.

description:
Oh you are good.  I dare say as good as any pizza I ever had in Chicago, let alone in San Francisco.  The fact that at a year old you have such a following and have mounted an assault on Zachary's decades' old title of best Bay Area pizza is a true testament to how good you are.  I especially enjoy the deep dish Classic: the sausage helps notch up the spice to a nice level that I found slightly lacking in the Little Star.  

As for the Zachary's-Little Star debate, well now, that's not really fair.  I've opined elsewhere that Zachary's is the best pizza in the Universe, and I stand by that assessment.  But I am certainly glad to have Little Star close by.  An instant San Francisco classic.
author: Bob H.

description:
This location is a little different from the Valencia spot. This one feels more like a dark lounge with vampire lurking and instead of blood they're sucking tomato juice from the deep dish pizzas. 

The menu is basically the same; deep dish (classic w/  meats, veggie and chicken) and thin crust (pesto, Italian, and garlic w/ mozzarella) pizzas with sides of buffalo wings, salads and garlic bread. Little Star is still close to my Chicago deep dish west of the Mississippi.

Bar tables are scattered around and ATM is in the corner (cash only).
author: Lola L.

description:
This was my last meal when moving out of San Francisco - the thin crust pizza is something I still think about now that I've moved home to the pizza free pacific NW. 

Last week I tried the deep dish and couldn't believe how much food they gave us. It was like they piled 6 thin crust pizzas on top of one another. If I were to be ordering based on value I would get the deep dish, but since they marinara sauce is piled high on the outside of the deep dish I think I'll stick with my delicious thin crust for all future visits. 

And there will be future visits.
author: Michelle B.

description:
3 1/2 stars

ok this is the only spot that I have tried that comes close to true chicago style pizza that is located in the bay area, I dont like pizza so i am real critical.. 

built like chicago style some flavor does not have that bread consistency of chicago bread it is just not there..kudos for trying though haha

food ***
price $$
service ***
author: Clarence A.

description:
I'm so sorry I originally gave 4 stars. I didn't have the cheesecake last time. It was... THE BEST CHEESECAKE OF MY LIFE!

I love you Little Star.
author: Tash T.

description:
"Them there's some good pizza, Jethro."

Our waiter was the most personable guy I might have ever been served by, and the pizza was delicious. Can't get much better than that!
author: K. C.

description: This place is packed out the doors sometimes. Phone in your order and take that pizza to go, pick it up and its just as yummy at home!
author: Joe M.

description:
Is there something about SF and its love of overly crispy crusts?? Is that the mark of greatness in regards to pies?

It seems that everytime i check out a supposedly can't-miss pizza joint in SF (e.g. Pauline's and Little Star), I am met by lackluster bland crust and a feeling of disappointment. I tried the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish here, which on paper sounds quite good (olives, chicken, feta). Don't get me wrong, the ingredients, even though I'm not a big fan of chicken, were quite good, but the crust just didn't cut it. It was bland and a bit too crispy and corn meal-laden.

Perhaps I've been spoiled by Zachary's, but any deep dish pizza in the bay will inevitably be compared with Zachary's, and Little Star doesn't even come close.

Add to that, our waitress was borderline rude, and practically scoffed at us for no apparent reason on several occasions. All in all, I'm giving Little Star a reluctant 3 stars, although it's more like 2.67 stars. I didn't really like the service, I thought the pizza was okay, but at the same time, I think there's enough promise that I'd like to try it once more (though doubtful it will be the deep dish).
author: Bernie L.

description:
I agree with everyone else.

Better. Than. Zachary's.

I lived in Berkeley for four years and subsisted on a diet comprised mainly of pizza (and the occasional salad to moderate the expansion of my waistline), sooo you can trust me because I'm pretty much an expert that knows what I'm talking about. And I'm modest too.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
First off I don't like chicken or cooked tomato slices so I can't say much about the pizza except that the thin crust was pretty good.  I imagine with toppings I like it would be great.  The caprese was good though.  

As for ambiance, Little Star is pretty typical Divis.  It is a shoebox shaped space with a little unused kind of bar on one side and some tables with a bus station in back.  Its got some old cushy van seat kind of things in front to sit on for your super long wait if there is space.  Other than that its just a hollow space with local art on the wall.  BTW is painting on windows a class at Academy of Art college cause those things are everywhere?  Overall its just plain.

The service is really snappy and attentive.  They seem to be the masters of movin people through without actually rushing you.  

Bottom line this place is semi affordable, not fancy at all and will get you out fast after your 45 min wait.  Nothin special about it.
author: Ian M.

description:
So don't shoot me but I found this place to be only slightly above average. 

The line at this place on an early Sunday evening was ridiculous. I was already bitter from having a bad day and bitter over this Obama "Bittergate." (Why shouldn't the country, let alone small towners be bitter? Your country is falling apart.) But I guess that a different story.

Needless to say I probably couldn't be made too happy. My companion and I couldn't get a seat and they said it would take 45+ minutes for take out. I was hungry and this made be more bitter. 

We went to Fly down the street to wait, couldn't find a seat again. WTF? 7pm on a Sunday evening. People should have been done with afternoon drinking or not yet starting evening festivities. My only thought is its all over flow from Little Star. MORE BITTERNESS.

I was saved only by the fact that my dining companion only lives half a block from either Little Star or fly.

As for the food.... both the this crust and deep dish crust was good. But I found the topping selection minimal. I also found the Italian Combo to lack enough pepercicinis.

This city has a hard time doing pizza, but not as hard a Japanese food (see Godzila Sushi review).
author: Sara K.

description:
Little Star, I've been longing to eat your pizza for the past year. And I must say that my recent experience was just good. Hmph. 

Two of us came here on a Tuesday night and were promptly seated. I must say that the service at Little Star was wonderful. The hostess was friendly, the bartender, Claire, was very sweet, and our waitress was attentive. I loved the decor of the restaurant- funky paintings hung all over and very dim lighting. 

We started out with the caprese salad, which was tasty. The cheese was very fresh; it was a huge portion- enough for 3 or so people to share as an appetizer. We ordered the Classic Deep Dish pizza to share- 6 pieces. (Plenty for 2 people....with 1 or 2 slices leftover). Maybe it was an off night in the kitchen...but the pizza lacked flavor. I love how they make the crust with cornmeal, but it lacked seasoning.....I felt it should have been a bit saltier. And the tomatoes totally overpowered the pizza, in fact, it was all I could taste. I would have preferred more sausage, onions, and cheese....so I'm hoping it was an off night. 

I really enjoyed the ambiance of Little Star so I will be back and perhaps next time the food will impress me as much as the service.
author: Laura D.

description:
Yummy!
I wanted to give a try to Little Star Pizza for a long time and since I live around the corner, I just waited for the perfect day not to have to wait an hour long to get a table..

we went there 2 weeks ago and we loved it.
the ambiance is bobo but not too much, the music selection from the jukebox is amazingly good and the service is nice even the place gets really packed.

we had the Thin Crust Italian Combo Pizza which is a blast!! a long time since I got to eat a pizza made exactly like in Italy. Heavenly crispy and full of flavour. A must have.
we also had the Deep Dish Mediteranean Chicken which was also nice but was a bit more like a thick quiche rather than a pizza to me.

So a good experience there especially with the very high expectations i had. And even if it can get pretty noisy, the Thin Crust PIzza is just so good that we'll come back or will become at least frequent to-go clients.
author: lucy b.

description: This pizza is unlike any other pizza. Their deep dish is too good for words. Crispy, yet soft crust, layers of cheese, sausage, peppers and onions covered in sauce. Trust me when I say you wont' be able to eat more than 2 pieces (normally) so the small is plenty for 2 people. We ordered the Classic deep dish and the Caprese Salad on a rainy night and it was the best night ever. I've also had their regular pizza (non-deep dish) and it was pretty tasty as well.
author: Shanna T.

description:
Just plain good pizza. Everything just works. Not overly greasy, flavorful... I can't remember what I had but it wasn't anything standard or normal like pepperoni- will have to do that next time. One tip: Don't go during high-traffic hours if possible.

-1 star for cash only. Wtf is that?
author: Panda B.

description: It is tough to go against the grain, but I have to say I'm no big fan of LSP. I tried it this weekend for the first time and I don't think it lives up to the hype. I don' t know about you, but I feel like there is something wrong about having deep dish pizza in an swank bar-like ambiance. This is not to say I'm against swank bar-like ambiance, it just that pizza and "local art" don't really go together. Like Bud Light and Dom Perignon. Also the pizza itself wasn't that hot, the sauce and crust are a ways off of Zachary's. All that said, I'd go back - but you better be buying.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
The Stones or The Beatles
Bon Scott or Brian Johnson?
Prince or MJ?
Tupac or Biggie?
Britney or Christina?
Backstreet Boys or nsync?...

New York or Chicago Style?

These questions define relationships, and sometimes end them.

I'm from the east coast, and we tend to get pretty uppity about our pizza. And bagels. And... well... everything really. I don't know how you put up with us.

Generally I side with my tribe, but I'm just gonna go ahead and admit that I love the deep dish pizza at Little Star.

Nuff said.

Oh, and also...

Stones
Bon Scott
Prince
Biggie
Christina
nsync
author: Shawn S.

description:
Good deep dish pizza (try their namesake Little Star pizza...spinach + feta + ricotta + onions & garlic = yum), interesting diverse crowd.  I like that it's a little dark in there.  And the noise level wasn't so bad when I went.  

I almost knocked off one star due to their Cash Only policy.  I don't like Cash Only places, mainly because I rarely have more than $2 on me, and I am slavishly devoted to both my United miles Visa and that new "Keep the Change" thing that B of A has going on.
author: DD B.

description:
Mmmmm... deep dish Chicago-style pizza with a thick cornmeal crust.  Why hasn't anyone else thought of this?  

Some may say that the crown for the best deep dish pizza in the Bay Area is held by Zachary's out in Berkeley.  I beg to differ.  Little Star is by far the best Chicago-style pizza you'll find in the Bay.  Period.

Not only are the ingredients uber-fresh and flavorful, but the jukebox at L.S., which features a plethora of great indie tunes, is one that cannot be passed over.  You'll find the lights turned down low at night, but candles burn soft and romantically at each table.  Great kitschy art pieces can be found strewn on the walls, making the general ambiance neighborhood-y, comfortable, and hip [but not so hip that a new patron would feel out of place].

Something else noteworthy: The garlic bread is AHH-MAY-ZING.  We're talking a whole bulb of garlic oven-roasted and brought fresh to your table next to thick slices of sourdough bread.  Yee-uhmmmm.
author: Katie C.

description:
Hipster, pricey.

A came here with a few friends after hearing good things from random people.

It was WAY crowded, so I was hoping for good things. 
We ordered an appetizer and a couple pizzas, and all of us were not impressed. The sauce was not very good and it had more than was needed which over powered the other ingredients.

Maybe I just don't enjoy their style, we'll leave it for all the rave reviewers =/
author: Angel L.

description: I am not a deep dish connoisseur, nor have i eaten much deep dish, but personally I wasn't crazy about the crust. It was too thick and kinda muted the delicious toppings. It seems to have a nice ambiance inside.
author: William H.

description:
If I had to try to come up with something negative to say about Little Star, it would have to be that my crust-anticipation can at times detract from my enjoyment of the rest of the pizza. It tastes so damn good that I find myself rushing through the toppings-covered parts just to get to the pure, unadulterated crust.

Toppings-wise they match deliciousness with Zachary's, but Little Star's crust utterly dominates their Berkeley nemesis. 

Take note Zachary's, and do whatever you can to copy Little Star's crust style!

And oh yeah, I wouldn't even bother with the thin-crust here - this is a Chicago style pizza place, and they just can't hang in the thin department.
author: Nick H.

description:
Alright so we were cruising around SF when sharp pains of hunger started to attack us. so watcha gonna do? bust out your i-phizzy and yelp that shit up son. we were looking for pizza places and and you know what shows up? little star...and with 1,000+ reviews and a 4.5 star rating I was blown away. 

So we hopped over to Divisidero and hung out at the bar across the street until these guys opened up at 5. We got in around 5:10 and by 5:30 there was already a decent line (this was on a Saturday). Anyways with such high reviews maybe I was expecting too much but this place was quite average. 

I liked how they made the pizza super fresh after you order but there was nothing extraordinary about it. The appetizer was bomb, fresh bread and they provide the garlic cloves so you can spread it yourself. However the deep dish pizza itself was a lil disappointing for me. Way too much tomato sauce to taste any of the other toppings.

Also, I believe its 2009 - I don't understand how some establishments are still cash only. Service was friendly, for two the bill was around $24. I heard they make good thin crust too but have not tried it myself - I prefer pizza antica in san jose for  that!
author: Vamsee K.

description:
My 100th review! And it's not about the heavenly cupcake, but something that is almost as near & dear to my heart - amazing pizza.....

The FOOD: Deep Dish Little Star Pizza was FANTASTIC! Incredibly flavorful fresh tomato sauce with perfect blend of ricotta, spinach, garlic and onion, wonderful cornmeal crust..... I was surprised when they said it would take 30 minutes to get our pizza, but WOW it was totally worth it.

Drinks: Great wines by the glass, and lovely selection of champagne mixed drinks.  I had the "Movie Star" - champagne + ginger....YUM

Ambiance: I love the invitingly dim and dare I say romantic (?) atmosphere.  It definitely doesn't scream "hello I'm a pizza joint with bright fluorescent lights trying to run you out the door".

What a GREAT find.  I can't wait to try the Mission location as well.
author: Jane A.

description:
****Best Crust Evar!!!!****

The construction of food is something that gets overlooked so often.  Perhaps its because people don't usually tend to care about the small details in life.  A well planned day.  A perfect golf swing.  A perfectly timed joke.  

This pizza was probably the most well constructed piece of food I've eaten in a long time.  One gripe about most pizza is how it breaks apart when its picked up.  This pizza had none of those careless characteristics.  

Probably the best part of the pizza was that it was right before our kickball game and their was no crowd when we got there at 5.  We had the classic Deep which consisted of Sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions.  The tomato sauce was also on top, which was a change of pace, but the toppings....um...middlings were fresh.  

Again if you are a person who likes the well constructed things in life, then this is the place for pizza.
author: patrick o.

description: Little Star Pizza is by far the second best pizza i have ever laid my taste buds on. I came here yesterday with the in-laws and could not wait to get my grub on! Unfortunately, i really had to wait. I endured 30 mins of bickering from the two, until the pie was ready. But oh my $%%^&*(lgjvsdsd[ae. Sorry my tongue fell on my keyboard. Was it worth the wait! We ordered one large special which i believe was meat balls, spinach, peppers and cheese, as well as chicken pesto. They were equally delicious! What makes Little Star different from the "other guys" is their rich and almost maybe home made tomato sauce, as well as their pie crust! The crust is NOT doughy!  Its not dry, tasteless, or overwhelming. It has sort of a flaky, buttery, melt in your mouth, kinda nom nom nom nom to it! Definately a place I would wander back to ! (without the bickering of course =)
author: Karen A.

description:
OK for deep dish.. hands down the best I've ever had. The "Little Star" is the best. It was my first San Francisco meal when I moved here. The spinach salad is also scrumptious. The garlic bread is unique - roasted garlic gloves on top of bread! The beer choice is fantastic and root beer is off the hook - goes so well with pizza.

BEWARE of the long wait ahead of you... also don't take anyone who HAS TROUBLE HEARING... WHAT?   WWHHAATT??? It is very very loud in there. AND take cash... no credit accepted.

This place is the shi+. Go. Now.
author: Aaron W.

description:
pretty good pizza, but  it's pretty pricey. $18 for a small pizza, but I think it's worth it if you've never tried Little Star Pizza. 

We ordered half Little Star and half Classic, and although the Little Star was pretty good, I prefer the Classic. The Classic seemed to have more punch in flavor. 

the management was super courteous, fast service, and the wait was only 20 min. on a sunday night.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Eddo was right. The pizza God exists! (and lives on Divisadero, go figure!)
That cornmeal crust can stuff my face any day.
My only concern is their Large(st) size. 
Two hungry homos had no problem going thru' this puppy all by themselves.
So if you're calling in and have a big party at your place, remember: Order a bit more than usual. Definitely not Mid-West size!

and what's up with no being open for lunch? or taking plastic cards?
I'd take a Little Star (tm) off, but this sh*t is too good to complain. 

a big Mahalo to all of u who recommended!
~T
author: Tomas V.

description: Masterpiece!! Will the owner contact me for starting a franchise in Scottsdale, Az??
author: Jacob S.

description:
I once had the idea to start a band called "Little Star," but then feared that anyone who came to our shows would know I was a glutton for their amazing pizza.  I didn't end up going through with it though, so my dark secret remains hidden away from the world.

Oh, wait...

Also, to my old friend Zachery who helped me through four years of Berkeley and to whom I introduced all my out of town friends - Little Star is the reason we no longer see each other. I'm not sorry.
author: Roberto M.

description:
Delicious crust...thin, crispy, corn meal (or is it corn bread?)...probably the best pizza crust I've had in a while. 

I ordered the prosciutto topping special...again delicious. It especially went well with the beer I drank it with. 

Arrived around 6:15 on a Friday evening...already there was a wait for the tables. So I sat and ate at the bar. By 7:00 even the bar was full. So arrive early if you don't want to wait.
author: Renato L.

description: I finally got a chance to try Little Star.  Because it was crowded and loud we ordered two thin crust pizzas for take out instead, and the pizzas were very good.  We had a Pesto Chicken minus the onions with spinach and sundried tomatoes added on.  For my taste this was the better of the two with fresh ingredients and great taste.  The White Pie was super garlicky and good too, but I prefer a little meat on my pie.  I didn't really notice anything special about the crust, but next time we'll try the deep dish.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
PROS - 
Excellent pizza flavor
Good beer and wine selection

CONS - 
Pizza crust is more like Pizza Hut now - used to taste more like a buttery pie crust
Too much cheese - not sure this was possible, but there was so much mozzarella that the cheese was coagulating into hunks as we were eating it
Tiny tables with water carafe included
Pouring my own water - despite our server walking back and forth empty handed
author: Monica S.

description:
we eat here embarrassingly regularly.  

the deep dish pizzas are really excellent.  they are always cooked perfectly, and they hold up very well when taken home or delivered.  that's right, via caviar they deliver all over the city.  gotta love that when you are busy.
author: eshwar k.

description: Yes, we finally found some damn good pizza on this side of the Bay!!! It's as good as Zachary's if you like Chicago style deep dish and live on the East side. I'm with a thin crust man, so we don't splurge much on the deep dish even though the sweet couple dining next to us highly recommended it. The thin was outstanding though!!! So we made a deal. Next time we go, it's deep dish all the way so then we can compare. Yeah, Little Star, that's some real freakin' good pizzita!!!!
author: Christina N.

description: Delicious pizza made with top notch ingredients.  The cornmeal crust isn't my thing, but it's still pretty damn good.  Happy hour beer prices are a nice touch also.  The ambiance is awesome, but it does get awfully crowded as the night goes on.  I suggest getting here for an early dinner.
author: Bill K.

description:
Oh. Man. Sooo good. Bring some friends and some time and if you have to wait for a table, order your deep dish already cause it takes a while to bake. 
But when it comes.... ooooooooohhhhh man........
author: Alexandra D.

description:
You're probably reading this review because you just read my review on Zachary's in Berkeley.  Well, here we go . . . strap on your seat belts and hold tight.

LITTLE STAR IS THE SHIZNIT!  

They use this great corn meal crust which is sooo crunchy and delicious.  The pizza variety is wonderful and the service is immaculate.  The venue could be a little bigger and brighter, but I guess that's the ambiance they are going for.  If you want to get a seat, be ready to wait at least one hour on any given night.  Yes, this is how popular they are.  

They have a good wine list and delicious deep dish pizzas.  Try them all!  Keep in mind that one slice is probably equivalent to one pound.  I'm not joking!  They are hefty pizzas and they are very tasty.  

My gripes?  Well, the wait is always long and parking is very difficult.  Let me warn you that they are in a bad neighborhood so be careful on where you park.  If you take a cab there, even better.  If you are in the mood for a great deep dish Chicago style pizza, check out Little Star.  You will then realize why I prefer Little Star over Zachary's.  There is no comparison in my eyes.  

Can I get an "AMEN?!"
author: Manton R.

description: Went here March 31st to celebrate my birthday with a few friends. They do not take reservations over the phone and once we got there it was about a 30 minute wait. What was great though was that we were able to place our order before we were seated. They informed us that deep dish takes over 30 minutes to cook so we could order now and then have the pizza soon after we got a table. Pizza was amazing! The deep dish is a must. I will definetly go back again. Only reason i gave it 4 stars was because they were out of garlic bread which I was dying to try. Oh well.. next time!
author: Jus K.

description:
I absolutely loooooooooooove pizza...and this is in my top 3 of favorite pizza places in the whole entire world!!!!! If you are in San Francisco and craving some Chicago style pizza and want to enjoy it at a nice sit down place...here's your spot...you'll pretty much fall out of your chair when you take that first bite...
(make sure you get the fresh mozzarella on yours...)
author: Marla V.

description:
Good pizza.  The 'deep dish' or whatever is taste-y.  If you want Zachary's but don't get to Oakland, this will satisfy your cravings.

I like the decor, but I don't like how loud they play the jukebox.  I felt like I needed earplugs and it killed conversation.

It's a bit pricey as well, so I won't be eating here all the time.

Oh and expect a WAAAAIT.
author: Alice S.

description:
I lived in Chicago for 4 years. So, this part of the review may only make sense to anyone from the Illinois/Wisconsin/Indiana area...

Little Star is closer to Gino's East. The crust is very similar in that sort of crispier and more buttery way. If you're looking for a more Giordano's crust (more sturdy, less buttery), Zachary's in the East Bay is more similar to that.

And that said, Little Star is close to Gino's East. So, yes, it's "real" Chicago-style pizza. You will not be disappointed.

For those who have no idea what I'm referring to, the deep dish here is very authentic to what you'd get in Chicago. If you're not used to deep dish pizza, it is a very filling pizza. If you're able to polish off a medium sized thin crust pizza on your own, you may be able to handle 2 and half slices of deep dish. If you don't  like a lot of sauce on your pizza or a lot of crust, this may not be for you. If you do like a lot of sauce, Little Star's sauce is really good.  The crust is crispy on the outside, but flaky and buttery. It's good stuff.

I've also had both the caprese and mixed salads. They are good.  (The mixed salad is excellent.) They also have organic beer.  It's a noisy place to eat, but the jukebox has some really cool stuff on it. The staff is nice. Get there early if you don't want to wait.
author: Allyson V.

description:
Worth the wait. We ordered 2 pizzas and a large salad for 2 of us. Might have been a bit overkill, but after being on a waitlist for 45 minutes, our eyes grew much larger than our stomachs. 

The pizzas were very tasty, and Little Star has a pretty broad choice of beers and wine. Definitely give this place 2 thumbs up!
author: Sean S.

description:
I love Little Star.  That cornmeal crust and chunky tomatoe sause...mMMMMM.  And the best thing is, the place is around the corner from my house.  The place has the best juke box too!  
The downers are it's always crowded.  I was waiting for a while and the estimated time took longer than they estimated and I was shocked to hear them tell the people who's table we were waing for to leave. Of course I wanted to eat but that is bad business practice to tell your customers to get the heck out cause other are waiting.  If that happened to me I'd be pissed.  Also, as much as I love their juke box, it plays so loud.  When I got out of dinner, my voice was gone trying to carry a conversation over dinner.
Either way the pizza is great, and there is always the option to take a pizza to go.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I've been here twice and have been happy both times.  I guess you could call this high end pizza as the speciality pizza prices are $19 for a small and $21 for a large, but I've never been reluctant to pay the premium prices....because the quality is truly worth it.  

Anyways, the 5 star rating comes because I ordered three pizzas and some appetizers for a movie night this week and the order was ready at 6:45pm like I requested and everything was piping hot and properly labeled.  I only had to wait 5 minutes or so for them to accumulate and double check my order.  I was very much impressed.

The pesto chicken is quite tasty and the sausage/ pepperoni/ mushroom is my favorite.  The mushrooms are thinly sliced and flavorful...not big and chunky which I detest.  I plan to try the deep dish next time since it was gobbled up before I could get to it...but from the feedback i received from my movie night guests, the LIttle Star deep dish pizza is "comparable" to Zachary's but not better.   I haven't tried Zacahary's yet so we'll see...
author: LaSha G.

description:
I enjoyed my dinner here the other night! It was my first experience with Little Star, and I will definitely go back.

We had trouble finding it though because it's really non-descript and has darkened windows.  The only way you can distinguish is if you catch the little sign in the front.  It's across the street from the tattoo parlor.  

I'm not that big on pizza, so I'm probably not the best person to review a pizza place, but I liked it!  Of course, I also think Dominoes and Pizza Hut are good too.  Sorry... I am a plebian when it comes to pizza.  :( 

But the highlight of the restaurant was the peculiar but friendly waiter.  He had me laughing all night with his eccentric antics! When I asked him for a few extra chairs, he said, "NO!" then started laughing.  Then when we had to move to make room for the extra chairs, he picked up my buddy in his chair and moved him himself.  He had the best facial expressions, and a really good attitude.
author: James C.

description: Amazing deep dish pizza, Italian and Little Star were sooo good.
author: Mike B.

description:
07/06/08 (Sunday):

My family from SoCal came to SF for the 4th of July weekend, so I decided to take them to Little Star yesterday (Saturday) to try the best pizza ever.

Sadly, they were not as crazy about it as I've been.

We ordered one thin-crust Pesto Chicken (large), one medium Little-Star deep-dish (of course!) and chicken wings.  My little brother and sister-in-law really liked the Pesto Chicken, but nobody went ga-ga over the Little Star.  I don't care what they say...it's still the best.

BTW, I think they fixed the air-conditioning and service continues to be very welcoming.
author: Ben W.

description:
Deep, deep dish deliciousness. 
Red, red wine loveliness.  
Kick me, pinch me, I died and went to Little Star.
author: Daniella B.

description:
What really can one say about the food here, besides the crust on their deep dish is better than seeing two bums fighting over a sandwich only to have a third bum sneak up on the scene and steal the sandwich right out from under them. 

Unfortunately like all good things you're gonna have to wait for it. Oh and on Saturday night you're really gonna wait for it.  Sometimes this is harder to cope with than other times, like when you're drunk and you just got a tattoo on your wrist that you are starting to freak out about.  It's ok get some more booze and settle in. Eventually you will get seated and then a girl in half finished mittens that she traded some granola for at Burning Man will stand near your table and you and your friends can make fun of her for the 30 minutes that she has to wait for her table. Everyone wins.
author: Melissa H.

description:
I know a woman who often says "Mommy-Like!"  When she is quite pleased with something.  This is mostly received with disgust. She doesn't care, this is the same woman who, when in a bar and is low on drink, yells for the 'nurse' and expects the bartender to come a-running.  They ususally do.

Although I always gag when she spots a pair of shoes or is sipping a new concoction and says "Mommy Like!", I have found myself quoting it-but only in my head and only when I really, really like something.  

Little Star Pizza made me say "Mommy Like!" OUT LOUD and WITH CONVICTION.  I should have been embarrassed but the pizza was so damn good I didn't care.  Also, they have nice lighting. I looked hot when i said "Mommy Like!"
author: Meg W.

description:
I wish I could give more than 5 stars. Their deep dish is easily the best pizza in San Francisco. Loaded with sauce and toppings that stay perfectly on the delicious crust.

The thin crust is decent but can't hold a candle to the deep dish. Chicken wings are tasty but not spicy at all.
author: Bruce D.

description: Suuuuch good pizza. I don't normally like deep dish, but this deep dish isn't too deep. It has a crispy yummy crust, never soggy, great sauce and the garlic bread is amazing!
author: Kortni S.

description:
The best deep dish pizza I've had on the West Coast.

We got 1/2 Little Star, 1/2 Veggie. Wish we went full Little Star. It's delicious. I love that the cornmeal crust gives it a hint of sweetness. The only thing that kept me from giving 5 stars is that its a personal preference of mine to have a "doughier" crust. Meaning, I like crust that has soft in the middle and crispy on the outside. 

Serving is awesome here. Great place to take a date. Reasonable prices for the quality of food. The small size is perfect for 2 people. We also split a slice of the cheesecake which was good, but not amazing. I appreciated that it was fluffy and not dense, since the pizza itself is pretty filling.
author: Ben S.

description:
Who took the stars out of the sky and put them in this pizza!  We ordered from this place that has been raved about around town.  Yum.  While I am not a deep dish person, I have to give some props to this place.  The cornmeal crust is incredible.  The pizza is very saucy if you like sauce.  We had a pepperoni and artichoke pizza which sounds weird, but it was actually good.

The pizza is a layer of crust, a layer of cheese, and lots of sauce.  The toppings are pretty spare.  If this is your style of pizza, this place is for you.  The crust is five stars.
author: apple r.

description:
4 Stars because I have only been there once.

Deep dish. Delish. I am not normally a fan of it, but the flavor of the crust and the intensity of the sauce have made me a believer.

The scene, mostly early to mid 20's indie hipsters. Not my "scene", but once the pizza arrived, the crowd and the buzz dissapeared. It was me, a lightly sweet and perfectly soft yet crunchy on the outside crust with what I thought was going to be a covering of dissapointing tomato sauce. Needless to say, I was wrong. I can't remember the last time someone got the seasoning for pizza sauce just right. 

The cost for three people with one glass of wine each, a large salad and  a large deep dish was $20 (each). The cost of the partially eaten week old slice that I hoovered down today for lunch. Priceless. 

notes: fun atmosphere, cute little wine bar to sip while you wait, nice list of affordable, yet interesting wines by the glass, perfectly dressed and very fresh mixed green salad. Pizza: Classic - Sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions.

NEW NOTE: went recently and the bitchy, "i am cool cus I wear head bands on the wrong part of my head"- hipster hostess made me wonder if I would return again.
author: Claudia O.

description:
Just looking at the pictures of Little Star's pizzas makes my mouth water.  I have to admit, when I went to the restuarant I wasn't all that hungry so round one was just mediocre, but the next day I had the leftovers and it was amazing!  The pizza is thick with toppings and has a pie like crust that is absolutely delicious.  

Go when you are hungry, have time to wait, and make sure you have cash.  Friday and Saturday are always going to be a long wait, so opt for a weekday.
author: Carly W.

description:
Absolutely loved the Pizza!  Absolutely hated the service.  Man, they sat there like their shit don't stink.  IT STANK!!!  

Don't get me wrong.. Little Star Pizza she's the prettiest lil thang I've seen in a loooonnggg time!!!  But her personality sucks!  I went from wanting a relationship to just needing a booty call here and there.  Straight hit and run.  Get the goods and be out!

Suggestion:  Order to go.
author: Jamal G.

description:
Came here the other night for take out pizza and I'm in love! I had the pesto chicken, mushroom thin crust pizza and it was SO good. I LOVE mushrooms! It was the perfect combination! Now after reading all the reviews, I'm kicking myself for not ordering the deep dish pizza! Well.. more the reason to go back!

Update: Came here for dinner last night and the classic deep dish pizza was DELICIOUS!! Oh my gosh! It was perfect! Loved the cornmeal, buttery crust. The sausage, mushroom, and pepper filling was SO good. Much better than the thin crust.
author: Denise L.

description:
4.5/5.0

The wait took forever, but the deep dish vegetarian pizza was very tasty (less heavy than Zachary's).  They also have an excellent but limited Kermit Lynch wine list (all except for two of their wines are from Kermit Lynch, and I know that at least one of the other two is a good wine), but I was a little disappointed with my glass of sancerre.
author: Grace W.

description:
Zoinks.

Having heard of this place for so long, it ran the risk of being over touted and hyped. Thankfully Little Star did not disappoint, but it wasn't amazing.

We ordered the Little Star deep dish and the chicken pesto thin crust. Actually thought the thin crust was better - but not because the deep dish was bad. The chicken was just sinful. Light and crunchy on the bottom with the right balance of chicken, cheese, and sauce.

There's not much more to say...sadly. It was really dimly lit, but we came at 6 PM so there was plenty of daylight...which didn't illuminate our table since we were in the back. Service was good, and though a bit pricey, it was solid pizza.
author: Aaron F.

description:
I gotta start this one off with a.. BABY BABY!

Before coming to Little Star, I would have always taken a really good slice of NY style pizza over Chicago. Don't get me wrong - I still would BUT Little Star would make me hesitate.

Little Star has a really quaint yet hip vibe inside. Everything is low lit. They have a bar and the tables are a mix of high tops and standard.

On to the good stuff:
Pizza - We ordered a Brass Monkey - not even on the menu but our bartender put us up on the "not so secret, secret menu". The pizza was delicious!! Just the right amount of cheese to topping ratio. The dough wasn't too think but wasn't think like a cracker. All of the toppings tasted fresh. Awesome!

Beer - I only had the Amber Boont. There was no need to try anything else. Double Awesome! Too bad the wine selection was lacking.

Word of advise to all my east bay people out there... Skip Zachary's and just keep driving to Little Star. Its better!
author: Nick B.

description: There are a lot of pizza options in SF and this is one of the best. Forget just options in SF, this is one of the best pizza places I have been to anywhere. I live a few blocks away and eat Little Star at least a few times a month. Their deep dish is insane! The crust is buttery and delicious. Their thin crust is amazing as well. I prefer thin crust pizza in general but both thin and deep are awesome here. Def. go here on your next pizza outing.
author: Drew H.

description: Tasty pizza! Friendly service, good for a late night snack.
author: Adam M.

description: Came to this place on a friday at around 6pm and we were lucky enough to get seated immediately, but once we sat it started to get crazy busy in there. It's a little dark in there but I kinda liked that. We started off with the garlic bread which was solid they give you a whole bulb of garlic and you spread it on the bread along with the butter, so if you're feeling lazy don't get it.  Before I talk about the pizza I will say I usually don't like deep dish pizza and when I went to Zachary's in berkeley I was not impressed.  We ordered the brass monkey pizza and it was pretty fantastic, the thing that sticks out in my mind is how wonderful the cornmeal crust is it didn't get soggy at anytime, the last bite was as crisp and light as the first bite. The only thing you have to worry about coming here is the parking.
author: Greg T.

description: There is no better pizza in SF or anywhere else in the Bay Area.  Little Star Pizza is the place most people haven't heard of, but one they go they never forget it.  Its a great place for dinner with friends or your family.   Zachary's in Oakland and Berkeley is overhyped and has become too commercialized.  Little Star takes the cake for pizza.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Ash S.

description: Great Chicago style pizza. Best I've had in the city. But I think Zachery's in Oakland beats it on freshness of ingredients.
author: T S.

description:
My wife and I were in town for a show and someone had recommended Little Star because it was right around the corner from where we were staying.  We decided to get a deep dish and a thin crust just to check it out and both were amazing.  

Seriously heavenly flavor.  Perfection.  Some of the best pizza we've ever had... I grew up in NYC and this rivals Rosa's Pizza which I swear to be the best pizza on the planet.  

Give yourself a little love-in and have a little little star.
author: Jai Gopal S.

description:
Best Pizza in the City eh!!!  I heard this from one of my roommates who loves pizza.  

I've taken a break from pizza since college (I use to be that cool guy tossing pizza in the air at Seattle's best Pagliacci's).  So inherently I will always be skeptical when somebody makes the claim as best pizza in the city.

Salad = Average.
Drinks = Always a plus.
Pizza = The little Star with sausage, "Extremely satisfying and filling."

The pizza is 5 stars but I don't think its gods gift from heaven.
author: Justin C.

description: Damn this was amazing pizza.  I love Zachary's in Berkeley/Albany/San Ramon and all other pizzas around can not even hold a candle to their pies.  Except Little Star.  We ordered a Sausage, Pepperoni and Mushroom deep dish pizza and it was pure heaven.  The cornmeal crust was crunchy and the dough was flavorful.  The pizza was this good and I brought it home, I can only imagine how good it is right out of the oven!
author: Curtis C.

description:
I'm kind of depressed to have to give Little Star a 5-star review.  I mean, it's cash only, which I hate, and we had tried to go on three separate occasions and given up each time before we finally came really early and actually got a table.  It's filled with hipsters.  Technically, it's overflowing with hipsters.

But.

Hot damn, that is some tasty pizza.  I have no idea if the deep dish is "authentic" or not.  I hate deep dish.  I tried my boyfriend's and I did enjoy it, which is saying something, because as noted above, I hate deep dish.

*I* had a thin crust with double mushrooms and green peppers, and as ALWAYS when different pizzas are ordered in a group, my pizza was CLEARLY the superior pizza.  Friends of mine, get it through your heads-- just get the same pizza as I do, or you will end up not liking yours as much and stealing mine, and then our friendship will be just a little less than it was before.  

Anyway, the pizza was perfect... crunchy yet not hard or flaky crust, perfectly saturated with oil yet not greasy, tender, melty cheese and savory sauce in perfect proportions, and generous, lightly toasted fresh toppings.  Seriously, next time I go (and like, actually get a table), I'm ordering two large pizzas... for myself.  And I'm not sharing (see above).  The cheap champagne cocktails served in huge glasses are a nice plus, and the blue cheese salad was delicious too.  

So, Little Star, the victory is yours.  I will TOTALLY stand awkwardly for an hour in your cramped, cold, noisy, uncomfortable waiting area to eat that pizza again.  At least I can order my pizza while I wait.
author: Marie K.

description: I have to say I prefer this over Zachary's, but I'm not going to say it's better or worse; just that I prefer it. The crust is amaaaazing! (For something similar, check out the cornmeal crust pizzas in the refrigerated section at Trader Joe's). Also, you have to get the mixed salad (organic greens, ripe cherry tomatoes, red bell peppers, red onions, gorgonzola cheese, and chopped walnuts, tossed with a housemade vinaigrette dressing) to start, it's one of the best I've tasted! The tables are small and a little crowded together, and it's pretty dark in there, but it all adds to the experience. Oh and the fact that it took 30 minutes to find parking in the nabe adds to the experience too, I guess....
author: Clara K.

description: We ordered 3 large pies to go. We got one deep dish with meat, one deep dish veggie and the chicken pesto. Each pie was about 20 bucks. I am a big fan of the deep dish pizzas (tastes very similar to Zachary's if you've ever been). The chicken pesto was average.
author: Debbie C.

description:
dude. [yes, it warrants a "dude".] Pret-ty stankin good pizza. Had the classic deep dish and I think I actually like it better than Zachary's. Er. Yeah..I do think so. They have this amazing cornmeal crust which is crunchier, so that might not be to your preference. Its definitely my pref. :)

*Get the chicken wings...they're VERY good. I was skeptical at first too (I mean..can't get any better than some ghetto Church's Chkn right?!) but its good. Its spicy and has tons of flavor and comes out with bleu cheese (YUM) and carrots (YUCK). 

There'll most likely be a wait. There's some seating inside and you can grab a beer at the bar, but there was also a line for the bar when I was there. (granted, it was Friday night at 7:30...) If you'd rather not wait inside, there's a fabulous little dive across the street (Bar 821).
author: Grace G.

description:
The food was ok, good to try once but not go back. There was a long wait, very crowded.

Ordered small cheese thin crust, tasted alright.
Ordered large vegetarian, good but too much garlic. 

Don't like that it's cash only!!!
author: Daddy F.

description:
My new favorite pizza place in San Francisco. I'm in the thick pizza camp, and the little star deep dish (with artichoke hearts substituted for the mushrooms) was divine. I don't like cheesecake, but my date reported that his birthday slice was excellent. We will definitely be back.
My only complaint is that they don't deliver. Even though we're only a 10 minute walk away, sometimes you just want to sit on your ass and wait for pizza to be brought to your pajama-clad self. Ah well, they're encouraging exercise, right?
Okay, I lied, that isn't my only complaint. My other one is that they only take cash. It makes them look hokey and cheap in my eyes, plus it's just inconvenient. 
I would deduct a star for the two above issues, but the pizza was too tasty for that.
author: Rachel J.

description:
I love love love little star pizza...unfortunately so does everyone else, therefor the wiat is usual an hour or so during peak dinner hours and especially on the weekends....although...I went there a couple of weeks ago on a friday and was the first ones seatted and beat the rush completely. So if ya wanna aboid the crowds... go at 5pm
reasonably priced, good service, GREAT music, nice art! Good Stuff!
author: Kelle K.

description:
Leave it to SF to make even a pizza place trendy. Gosh, I love it here. =)

PROS:
-Amazing Caprese Salad (feeds at least 2!) 
-Yummy thin-crust pizza (get it w/ sun-dried tomatoes)
-Quality drink selection
-Jukebox. Need I say more?
-Stellar artwork
-Coolest pizza logo around
-Great place to hang out, very Mission-y.

CON:
-Cash only. Boooo!


I heart you Little Star!!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I just had a pie from Little Star last night...We ordered late, and got through on the first try (unbelievable, right?) They said it would be ready in 15 minutes, (and it was.)

They don't deliver so they're kind of a pain in the ass, but that's not why I'm holding back the fifth star.

Leave it in the oven 5 minutes longer and I'll hook you up.
author: Jason R.

description:
There is no repectable Chicago-style pizza joint that can provide a deep dish pizza in under an hour. I ordered Little Star to go on Friday and when they said my pizza would be done in 30-35 minutes, I was like umm huh?

The crust is quite tasty, but there are way too many tomatoes on the top. And, the cheese should be so melted that when you pull a piece from the pie, it stretches until you cut it! 

Not to mention it's cash only. Annoy-ing. 

All in all I was pretty disappointed with what is considered SF's BEST pizza. I'll keep searching on my own.
author: Carson H.

description:
Considering how popular this place is, we were ready to wait quite a while when we arrived around 7 on a Friday night, surprisingly, we were seated pretty fast. It was dark and very loud; was a bit difficult to converse. Our waiter was nice and helpful; checked up on us a few times while running back and forth. 

I love the crunchy cornmeal crust, but other than that, there was nothing special about the pizza. We had the Mediterranean Chicken because that sounded tasty, unfortunately it was lacking in flavor.. If I did a blind tasting, I would have never guessed the pizza contained chicken. However, the pizza was far from bad, just not as good as I was hoping. I'd return to try a different kind and to have more of the yummy crust.
author: Kim V.

description:
Procrastinating at work, I realize I've never said a word about Little Star, where we eat more than anywhere in SF.  Not that they need more accolades...

The deep dish pizza is the best pizza I've ever had.  Anywhere in the world.  (Zachary's doesn't come close...)
author: Dennis T.

description:
This place is gooo-oood. Love that I live nearby. Loved the garlic bread served with a clove of fresh amazing roasted garlic. Loved that the pizza was so amazing that we were talking about how sickly full we were between last bites. Loved the hip, dark interior because honestly, people shouldn't even be able to see each other when pigging out this hard. Loved that the check came to about 20 bucks.

Just ridiculously good and worthy of the hype. However, unless you want to be uncomfortably warm and surrounded by dorks and crappy indie rock, get it to go.
author: jessica s.

description:
My favorite pizza place in the Bay Area!  A semi hole in the wall with fantastic food at very affordable prices.

If you're here for the first time, try the Classic thin crust.  Absolutely tasty!  The garlic bread is very unique and makes a nice starter along with the small mixed-green salad.  In terms of portion size, a small thin crust should be enough for two people if you get salad.  

Little Star also has very affordable bar drinks and beers.  $2 PBR cans!  Finally, remember to bring cash and come early.  No credit cards and no reservations!
author: Hui C.

description:
Their deep dish pizza is everything it's rumored to be and more. So so so delicious.  

I highly recommend getting it to go though. The place smells very B.O. meets patchouli oil meets day old marijuana smoke. Plus, pizza makes the best leftovers. I don't feel so bad paying $20 for a small pizza when it's more than enough for 3+ meals.
author: Lauren B.

description:
LSP resides in the grunge capitol of SF: Divisadero/W. Addition. By grunge, I'm talkin' punker wannabes, 5-o-clock shadow appreciation day winners, hippy chicks, Sha-bay Chiquesteristas, and the occasional pit bull walker or two. But you go in and will be pleased by the aura of the place's dark interior, PBS sensible crowd, Pixies jammin' on the ghetto blaster, and the overpowering scent of damn good Za: 

I'm talkin' Deep Dish,
Texas T-slice,
BIG FUN stuff to eat. 

LSP's also got some flat board workin'. Tastes just as 
good. As many have said: East Bay.... you can keep your 
Zacharies!  We got LSP servin' us right!!
author: Johnny C.

description:
I was so sick of hearing about this place, I had to try it for myself. I will say that all of the talk is warranted. After going to school in SB, I never thought someone could replace my love for Wood Stock's. 

Little Star you have done it! I went in on a Tuesday night and this place was packed. Cute and cozy. Dim lighting and a bar in the back make this place laid back and charming. Even though others were waiting, we were seated right away. We had the house salad while we waited and it was a nice, tasty starter. Good dressing and lots of flavor. The large is perfect to share amongst three or four. Ok, enough, let's get to the goods.

The pizza...we ordered the Little Star and it was ridic! The small (6 slices) was perfect to share amongst 3 girls. The large would have been way too much food. We got the deep dish (of course) and it was so beyond good. The cornmeal crust is topped with melted mozzarella and ricotta and then layered with spinach, garlic and tomato sauce. The brilliant thing is the sauce is layered last (on top of everything else) so that the crust stays nice and crispy. I can't remember the last time I enjoyed a pizza this much. I can't wait to go back!
author: Jenny S.

description:
Dear Little Star Pizza, 
Your deep dish crust deserves 5 stars alone. Everything else we ate was really good but not mind blowing/spectacular. Yay, I am a fan, but a 4.5 star fan. :)
much love,
Shannon
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Get the White Pie, get the White Pie, get the White Pie :)

If you like margherita pizza, you'll LOVE the White Pie. 

I would've gave it 5 stars but the joint was madd crowded, yo. Had to order the White Pie and eat elsewhere.
author: Maricel B.

description:
Wow...um where do I start. Hell, let's start at the beginning. We started with the garlic bread. The garlic was served on the side to bread and a small dish or butter.  This worked as a proper lead in to the buffalo wings. The wings might have been worth the trip alone. There were several pizza choices including a weekly special but we opted for the Little Star signature pizza instead. This was very good. The pizza had plenty flava and somehow didn't fill you up. I finished up with the cheesecake which is about as good as I've ever had. As for drinks, I had a Boont Beer which had a crisp taste; this went great with the meal. 

The service was on point. The recommendations did not disappoint. The server (who was a bit on the burly side) made it clear, "I don't know a lot but I do know food". Point taken.  Oh did I mention that the check came back awful light.?

If there is a con, parking in this area always sucks. So do as I did and go early on Sunday. You wont regret it.
author: Brian A.

description:
I really really really like pizza. Hubby really really really loves pizza. We'll basically eat the crappy pizza from the cafeteria where I work (USF) if need be. But- thanks to Little Star, that won't be necessary.

I love both the deep dish and the thin crust varieties here.  I've eaten in, as well as taken out. I'd eat here every day if it weren't for Weight Watchers (note: you can eat whatever you want on WW, just not as much as I'd like!).
Also, the garlic bread is awesome. Bread, butter, and a roasted clove of garlic. Yum!!
author: Kayla N.

description:
the deep dish pizza is good, but not something i'd crave.  i prefer zachary's, lou malnati's, or prizzi's piazza.  
the crust just didn't do it for me.  it was decent but didn't have enough flavor.  everything else on it was great though.  
we also shared a tasty mixed green salad which had chopped walnuts, gorgonzola, red bell peppers, red onions, cherry tomatoes, and a mild vinaigrette.
wine and beers on tap and in the bottle complete a fine dining experience....
author: Randy D.

description:
As a former Chicagoan, all I gotta say is WOW!!  The deep-dish pizza here is spectacular, and made me homesick.  But it's got the nice, trendy young-people bar feel.

Sure, you could go to Zachary's for the touristy Chicago-style glitch, but when you just want your pizza at a nice neighborhood restaurant, Little Pizza is the place to be!!
author: Paul H.

description: Tried the mediterranean deep dish a small between me and my friend (6 Slices $20.00) We were FULL!! The beer was great! Atmosphere - HIP Parking can be tricky (metered but free after 6pm) I came here just because of the reviews and I tried to get there early since it was said that the wait can be long (We were seated immediately exactly at 6pm) but it quickly filled up was I glad we got there early. A bit noisy but that was part of the experience. The waiter staff was very attentive. two thumbs up!
author: Mark G.

description: I would highly recommend! The garlic bread was awesome, the chicken pesto pizza was incredible, and the service was great as well.
author: Philip S.

description: Hit up little star on Valencia, visited zachery's, then back to this location. this one wins! awesome staff, more space, and great food =)
author: Tiff W.

description:
Horrendous?  Pretentious?  Yes.

Both a little shocking however this is what this joint is.  They seem to be focused on the money making philosophy of a restaurant, rather than feeding people in order make money...

They greet you, seat you, feed you, then boot you.  All pretty fast like they have quota to fulfill that evening...if you must go to this place, I would order to go to avoid the staff.

Also not very consistent - salty sometimes and dry other times.

You want good?  Go to Pauline's if you are in the Mission, and try Stelladoro's stand in the Western Addition...

Avoid this place like the plague...
author: Michael C.

description:
Bomb. 
Why Little Star is better than Zachary's: the crust.
Little Star's crust is crunchier and the corn meal flavor adds a crisp taste to the pie.
My favorite is the cheese blend (I think it has feta, ricotta, and mozzarella.)
It is a bit pricey, but when you are in the mood something else besides a ninja-turtle style slice, Little Star is your spot.
author: Phil P.

description:
This is one of the best pizza places in SF.

The only downside is that the pizzas are not that big. For example, if you want a medium size pizza you should get the large because that's approximately the size of the medium.

But the staff is very friendly and I highly recommend it.
author: Miguel T.

description:
wings.......up there

Pizza...........
wow, cornmeal crust just became its own galaxy...
author: Kennan M.

description:
Coming from Chicago, I never understood why people liked Zachary's so much (glorified Giordanos in my book).  When I heard the hype about this place I thought the same thing.  Well, Little Star has earned its "stars".  Great Chicago Style pizza, not the best ever, but the best I've had in the Bay Area.  

I would definitely recommend eating at the restaurant to experience the crust properly.  If you order takeout the bottom of the pizza gets soggy and unless you have a pizza stone at home you are SOL with the crust.  Be prepared to wait though, the place is tiny.
author: Bill L.

description:
Update: After this review, the owners contacted us and comped us a pizza. I've got to give credit to owners who pay attention to their customers. And yes, the pizza was still great.
_______________________________________

The pizza was delicious. However.

As consummate "locavores," my girlfriend and I are always rooting for our neighborhood hot spots. Little Star has long been one of our favorite take-out locations. Tonight, we decided to dine in, and we frankly could not have had a worse experience.

Prior to leaving the house, we called to see how long of a wait we should anticipate. A fairly snippy voice on the other end of the line informed us that she had no way of knowing the duration of the wait, as she was in the back making pizzas. Then she hung up on us. Despite this unsavory beginning of our evening, we headed out the door and queued up at Little Star. We were told that it would be a 45 minute wait, and we settled into one of the chairs in the waiting area. 

An hour and a half later, we were finally ushered to our table. We ordered almost immediately, and 20 minutes later were graced with... the wrong pizza. We flagged down our (admittedly contrite) waiter, who corrected the order and told us it would be another 10 minutes. As we waited, a couple with whom we'd been chatting during our extensive wait walked by our table, having finished their dinner. They looked at us in shock.

"You haven't eaten yet?"

No, no we hadn't.

Needless to say, we will never dine in again. Take-out is highly recommended, but almost three hours for pizza? PIZZA? Seriously??? No, thanks.
author: david j.

description:
Along with A16 I think Little Star makes the best pizza in the city. That said, I don't think San Francisco is a very solid pizza city. It's always great, but not the write-home tastiness of pizza's I've had other places. I usually get it for take out, but have eaten in a few times. Service is always fine, and for a packed environment the food is timely and the beers cold. 

Take out is always in it's thirty minute time frame and I love the Blanco. Though I can't figure out how to eat the garlic bread (it's just bread and cloves) that's not the restaurants fault that I'm apparently garlic bread illiterate . The 'buffalo' wings are also good and I will continue to make this my pizza choice when I'm not too lazy to walk the four blocks to Little Star. Yes folks, I am too lazy to make that walk sometimes, and sadly, Round Table is the best delivery in this city.
author: brant f.

description:
UPDATE: 5/5/07
THE OWNER WAS KIND ENOUGH TO WRITE BACK AND APOLOGIZE. I WILL GIVE IT ANOTHER TRY. MAYBE IT WAS AN OFF NIGHT? I HAVE ALSO CHANGED MY STAR RATING TO 3- FOR THE APOLOGY/GOOD FOOD.

Well Little star you sure live up to your name. (Little Star) After checking all the wonderful reviews- I decided to try this joint.

Well the 1hr and 10 min wait was no fun, but I was willing to wait.

The cash only policy stunk, but they did have an atm in the place that charged a lot to pull out cash.

The ambiance was surprising for a Pizza joint, I liked the art work. But did not like the Hipster attitude Service.  OK you guys are only a Pizza place.

Yet again, we were forgotten about on the list, and yet again another couple that came in 45 min after got a table before us. After confronting the hostess that we were next. We Still had to wait for another table for 35 min longer. She was a bit apologetic, but it was all a front.

We were hoping we would get better service once we arrived to our table.... nope did not happen. We were not greeted for another 15 min.  
mind you we started our night starving it was getting close to 11:30- and we had not had dinner yet. The waitress did not make any suggestions- or asked us how we were doing- so we ordered.

The food was delicious, We know NY style pizza- it was really good.
Our caprese salad was fresh, my strange champagne cocktail came in a large glass with ice. not so much Champagne though.

The waitress took along time and never asked us how we were doing.

I think I will be back but only for take out. The food great, Service BAAAAAAD.

What does it take get seated in a fair manor in this city. If you read my Alamo Square grill review it happen there to.
I guess we are just invisible human beings to Servers.

Wait don't Servers work for tips? Um Helllllo.....
author: a g.

description:
Good pizza (especially the deep dish).

Bad atmosphere (especially after 7 PM). The din is almost unbearable. If you come for a late dinner on a weekend, bring your earplugs or just order takeout.

Warning: cash only! Fortunately, they have a generic ATM on the premises that charges only $.25 to your bank for a withdrawal.
author: Al Y.

description: So Little Star Pizza...hands down one of the BEST Deep Dish Pizza's in town. It is a busy place, but so worth the wait. Grab a beer, chill out and await awesomeness in pizza form. I have been to both the shop on Divis. and on Mission - Both are fantastic!!
author: Jamie K.

description:
So I've only been here twice and both times were extremely busy.  There's a good vibe, and bars to hang out at nearby when waiting for your table. I don't know if the person working the bar/to go orders was new but she didn't give me a receipt and being the slightly inebriated moron that I was just assumed since I watched her type my name into the computer that she would get in my order. She also refused to do the substitution on the pizza that I asked for insisting it couldn't be done even after I explained it had been done for me recently.  I came back to the girl that not only didn't recognize me from 30 min ago (understandable in a busy place) but also lost my order and insisted I never talked to her (after I paid).  It eventually all worked out and I got a pizza a while later.  

So bascially my point is, you should probably a) get a receipt and b) not necessarily believe the girl behind the counter.  Or you could just order by phone or not be impatient like me and just wait for a table.
author: Jackie A.

description: Excellent pizza and customer service the best pizza in sf ! I will def return I would highly recommend this pizza place! It would be even better if it was brick oven I'm not as easy person to please so that should tell you they earned this review
author: John D.

description:
Finally, really good deep dish pizza in the city. I've been going to Zachary's in Berkeley for many years and it will always be my #1 spot, especially if you plan on ordering the chicken special. It is so f*ing amazing. But if you're in the Mission and have a craving for pizza, Little Star Pizza is the place to go. I don't recommend getting the thin crust as it's not what they are known for. They have good veggie and meat combos and the crust is made from wheat and cornmeal.

They don't take reservations but wait for a party of 2-4 is usually under 30 minutes. Yes, even for a Saturday night. I saw some reviews that said the venue was swank. Hardly, unless you think of swank as a hipster bar with old wooden tables and handmade resin artwork. It's right off of 15th street so it's best to cab there rather than try to find parking. You can head out to a bar on 16th street afterwards since LIL* only serves beer and wine.
author: Kimmie N.

description:
We arrived at Little Star last Friday a little after 7:30 pm and were told that our party of 2 would have to wait 20 mins.  Fortunately, there weren't too many people ahead of us, and surprisingly, we really did get seated after 20 mins!  But as we sat down, a whole throng of people--pairs and groups alike--came through the door and waited to have their names jotted down, while the hostess intermittently tried to solve her sudoku puzzle.

I would definitely describe this place as totally hip and totally loud.  I loved the interior decor of the restaurant, but I really could not get over the ear-aching volume of noise in the room.  Not only did I have to scream across the table to speak, but I also found myself screaming "What?!" back at my SO far too many times during our meal.

However, I must vouch for their delicious pizza.  I can't say I can compare Little Star to many other Chicago deep dish pizzas (as I've only had UNO's), but I really enjoyed my Classic Deep Dish here.  The crust was very cornmealy and crunchy (although I do kinda like the buttery and somewhat chewy crust that UNO makes), the sausage was tasty, the chunky tomato sauce was flavorful, and the cheese wasn't piled on too high.  

Much to my surprise, though,the pizza was EVEN better the next day!  I popped a slice into my toaster oven at 300 degrees for about 20 mins, and it was even tastier than I had imagined!!  The pizza juices had more time to soak in, and the crust softened up a bit overnight: THE PERFECT combo for leftover pizza.

I'd come here again, but I'd probably order my pizza to go, like I saw a lot of people do.
author: Diane L.

description:
I have waited here for 90 minutes to get a table and it still gets 5 stars.

Usually end up at the one in the Mission though since it is oh so accessible by BART.

parking is a bitch.
author: Christine K.

description:
As several others have said, when you want Zachary's but don't want to drive across the bridge, Little Star is a good choice. I think their food has improved since they first opened, and the vibe is hip, yet unpretentious (a rare combination).

One suggestion -- they should have Ranch dressing so my ghetto-ass doesn't have to dip my crusts in bleu cheese.
author: Vandana M.

description:
I think it was a Wednesday right after work. We walked over. I'd heard the rumors of this incredible deep dish place out in what people used to call the Western Addition. City folk tried to compare it to Zachary's Pizza. While I had faith that it was good, I didn't realize how good.

The walk was nice. From Pac Heights to there is a little sketchy. Not unsafe so much as keep your eyes open and be aware of your surroundings at all times...OK, that's a gross exaggeration. The neighborhood appears it's going through the gentrification pains.

Walking into the dark space that is Little Star immediately differentiated it from any other pizza place I'd been to. I'd expected lines out the door based on the mythology that surrounds this place. Our wait was self-imposed as we tried out several different tables before making our selection.

Started with a salad that was full of good stuff. I like a good salad. And, this was a great salad. The pizza came hot from the oven. From start to finish, each bite proved to me this was worthy of the hype.

The service was great. The waiter looked like he'd escaped the tattoo parlor a little too late to avoid illustration. He looked like he could rumble. But he was a very kind and generous person.

So I've been once...We'll be going back...It's just a matter of time.
author: Dave B.

description: We got lucky! They normally have two hour waits, but we only had to wait about a half hour, granted we did come on a weekday. Pizza was delish :-) I'm a bigger fan of their regular pizzas than their deep dishes. We got the original deep dish (w/ sausage, red peppers, mushrooms, etc.) and the regular chicken pesto one. It's definitely worth a try, but go early!!
author: Sharon G.

description:
It's good. Damn good. I can't say if it's better or worse than Zachary's or Patxi's, but it's good. Interestingly different from the others with a corn meal crust. The only downsides were that the wine by the glass we picked wasn't all that great, and it was REALLY LOUD, but that may have simply been due to the presence of a large party.
Read my full review here: http://sibilous.blogspot.com/2005/01/little-star-pizza.html
author: Don H.

description:
Oh my God.
FINALLY.  
Real pizza west of the Mississippi.

Being from St. Louis, I have a very high standard when it comes to thin crust pizza, Chicago style pizza (a.k.a. deep dish), calzones...you name it. As far as I'm concerned St. Louis, Chicago and New York set the bar for good pizza.  
Little Star just put the West Coast on the map.

This pizza is perfection.  More specifically the deep dish, which usually isn't my favorite style of pie.  Melts in your mouth kinda good.  The amount of cheese is perfect.  It's not too doughy, has plenty of toppings, but isn't overflowing with them. 
Add a beautiful amber beer to the mix and I'm in heaven.

Is there a Yelp Elite event in the works that somehow involves this pizza??  If not, hook it up Nish!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Wow! Wow! Wow! 

Is all that i have to say. Wow doesn't even do Little Star Justice. I'm still beating myself for not having tried Little Star earlier. 

You could be from Italy or could have invented pizza, but still if you think this isn't the best Pizza you've had ever, you just need to go get your taste buds bronzed because nothing you eat, will satisfy you ever again.
