I'm a fan of their cornmeal crust. In addition, their Garlic Bread is the best I've had in the city. They serve you warm, moist bread with whipped salted butter and a whole roasted garlic, which is meant to be smeared onto the bread. 

I may never try a NY style Pizza again. Deep Dish Chicago style owns NY Pizza!. Nuff' said. 

Do try the Caprese Salad. Its pretty rad!
author: Tushar V.

description:
What to say that hasn't already been said? Not much I guess. This place could be the most perfect restaurant on Earth. Here we go: close to my place, deep dish pizza AS GOOD as any in Chicago, cool ambience, great bar with fun drinks for the females, robust wine list, AND... what would detract from Little Star, the long wait that you sometimes have to endure, turns into a blessing as you can stroll down to Fly Bar for a pint while you wait for your table! Or, grab a drink at Little Star's bar.

Call me boring but I always order the Classic deep dish, and am NEVER disappointed. And now I'm hungry. I love you Little Star.
author: Drew S.

description:
This location was even better than the Valencia street location. The staff was great, the decor is a bit more cozy...I love the toys everywhere.  Parking is an issue but it is well worth it.  
Seriously this is the best pizza in San Francisco...hell in the whole Bay Area, yes I said it. 
Just go to the gym twice on the day you go because it is hard to resist eating more than one piece!
author: Nilu r.

description:
Better than Zachary's.  Yes, I said it.  

Come here for your deep dish pizza.  When you walk in, it seems more like a high-class lounge than a pizzarrrrria.  You certainly pay for it.  Great beer selection.  

For you ranch dippers, THEY DO NOT HAVE RANCH DRESSING.  One time I asked for it, they said no.  I said OMG, pretended I had to take a call on my cell phone and took it outside, I ran out to the street, looked around, and ran to the grocery store at the corner, picked up a bottle of ranch, and made it back before the pizza arrived at our table.  Saweet.  

-1 star for no ranch.  Can you believe they asked me if bleu cheese was an acceptable substitute?  WTF.  Oh well good pizza.  I can only eat like 1 slice.  It's like a meal in a slice.
author: Dong T.

description:
OOooo, Mama likes this place!!

You get full with just 1-2 slices of their deep dish.  Makes you all full of cheesy, pepperoni, saucy goodness.  Their salads are good and enough to split with another.  Oh my goodness I need me to get me some of this soon.  I love their corn bread crust.

I only wish they would deliver, but I'm sure they're banking anyway with their limited hours and take out.

A must for pizza lovers!!
author: imelda j.

description:
If you are having a pizza craving and you have a large group and you want options, this is going to work.

You are going to have options from deep dish to thin crust, and from every topping I think that you can imagine.  They also have other food too for those that don't even like pizza so don't worry about that.  But if you are looking to have a pizza party for adults, this could very well be your place.

It is pretty good, and I don't know anyone that has ever had a bad experience here.  I prefer super thin NY style pizza so this isn't totally my fav, but I also know that I have always walked out of here totally stuffed too so that speaks for itself.
author: Denise B.

description: Regular crust and deep dish are excellent.  Highly recommend.
author: Keith B.

description:
Deep dish is my childhood. Ginos, Lou Malnati's, what have you. I crave deep dish pizza so much that I've ordered it express delivery from Chicago that comes packed in dry ice. I've crossed the bridge to go to Zach's.  But Little Star gets it right and it's in San Francisco. The tomato sauce is mouth watering and the sausage is king. What more can I say.

What's with the jukebox? There's some good stuff in there actually.
author: Michael S.

description:
Little Star is one of the best pizzeria in the city.  I did not know that the second restaurant in Mission opened until I read about it here a minute ago, but I'm pretty happy with this one.
In my opinion, LSP has much tastier sauce (more fresh spice?)and crust (has yummy + crunchy cornmeal) than Zachary does.
author: Ryoko M.

description:
If Little Star would institute an "order while you wait" policy, I would give them four-stars. Nothing sucks worse than waiting for a half hour for a table, and then waiting another half hour AT your table anxiously anticipating your meal.

As for the pizza itself, my initial reaction was to craft an on the spot Yelp review. The review went something like this, "Blah blah blah, over-hyped." I shared my sentiments with my party, and I realized that I was in the minority amongst my four other friends. So I shut up, and continued eating.

I think what I initially balked at was the diminutive size of the pizza we ordered. Being a fan of Zachary's and Patxi's, I understand that it does not take a lot of deep-dish pizza to fill you up, yet, on principle, I bristled at the idea of paying $20 for a pizza as small as the one that was delivered to our table. However, by the end of the meal, I was full and satisfied.

I'd gladly return to Little Star, but not before trying to convince my friends to go to Patxi's.
author: Alex C.

description:
It was a Friday night and I had gotten off work an hour early in the Financial District.  By the time we arrived at Little Star Pizza it was almost 9, I was drunk...probably, given the social setting, too drunk to be eating in Little Star Pizza; a sit down restaurant. 

It wasn't my fault.  We were at the Page throwing back IPA's and playing Foosball when my friends suggested we go eat at this jewel of a pizzeria.

Friend: Little Star, now.
Me: What's that?
Friend: Pizza.
Me: *finishing IPA and reaching for coat*

In my inebriated state I imagined a hole-in-the-wall pizza joint with slices sitting in a carousel o' heat.  I was surprised, and struggling to find any type of sobriety, when we came upon a nice dimly lit establsihment with a full bar and a crowded dining floor.

The wait was 30 minutes.  We went and got more drinks, came back, I played with a dog tied to a tree outside, we were seated.  We got more drinks, we ate.

I don't remember where we sat, or what our waiter looked like, or what kind of beer I got...but I remember the moment our cornmeal-crust deep-dish pizza w/pepperoni and sausage was put down on our table.  It was like someone laid out the Holy Grail and said "eat it."  

My drunk and stumbling hands couldn't move fast enough to suffice my ridiculous appetite.  I managed to slap a couple of slices on to my plate and dug in....twas amazing.

Come here, eat, drink, be merry.  They encourage that type of thing.
author: Josh T.

description:
Years ago I lived in the area and I never knew about Little Star. You *gasp,* I'm sure.   But in hindsight, it was probably best since I couldn't have afforded it during my college days and would have walked around aimlessly mouthing the sweet words .. Little Star ... Little Star ... Little Star ...

It's a whole 'nother story now.  

I love all pizza but generally prefer thin crust ... unless it comes to Little Star.  The way the crust, cheese, toppings and sauce all meld together is quite magical.  Every bite makes you ponder the construction of such a well built food machine. 

Oh, and don't be too mesmerized by the pizza that you forget the wings.  They're not heavily sauced like buffalo wings but instead have a nice, spicy (but not overly spicy) rub.  

It was damn worth the four year wait.
author: Nada b.

description:
When I was little, my dad used to work at Little Ceasar's Pizza. We were dirt poor and being a pizza cook was only one of three jobs that he did. Every night when he came home he would bring home an extra large pizza overloaded with every single topping that ever existed on the face of the planet. This was pretty exciting for me as a kid the first month or so, but then the novelty wore off and I started hating pizza. It eventually got to the point where just looking at a pizza made me want to barf. So as a teen and in college, pizza would always be my last choice in food when dining.  

fast forward to my adulthood and my boyfriend wants to go to Little Star. I tell him how much I hate pizza and rant on about my story.  He insists that it's delicious and I try to be a good sport and have a slice. We have a slice of the classic italian and it's delicious. We had the thin crust and it's super crispy, just enough cheese, not overflowing with grease. Now I live half a block away and I eat here all the time. Thanks to Little Star, I  am a fan of pizza again!
author: Jade L.

description:
FINALLY tried this place. Was deterred the first time I stopped by because of the 40 min. wait, but my advice is to head there for an early dinner before it gets crowded (we went there around 6pm, were seated right away). With all the hype in the reviews on Yelp, I was expecting a large-ish space, but it was pretty small, so I don't really recommend bringing a large group here.

We started out first with their garlic bread. Was a bit disappointed because it consisted of sourdough bread, butter, and a cut whole garlic. Really? I skipped the smooshing of the garlic into the bread and ate just the bread and butter.

The pizza was great. We ordered one pie, one half was the thin crust Classic (sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers) and the other half was their special that night (thin crust, prosciutto, green bell peppers, arugula). Don't know if this indicates a high level of quality in the pizza, but the day-old leftovers tasted really good too the next day!

Also, there's no full bar. I was a total ditz, tired from work, didn't even notice, and asked the waiter for a Safe Sex on the Beach.

Waiter: "I used to be a bartender, and I've never heard of it."
Me: "Um, well it exists, it's a virgin sex on the beach."
Waiter: "Well I don't want to serve you a VIRGIN sex on the beach, hahahaha."
Me (mumbling): "Um okay. Sorry."

I later ordered a San Pellegrino Aranciata. Yeeeaaahhhh...
author: Catherine H.

description:
I need to clarify that this 5-star review is for Little Star's deep dish pizza ONLY. Their thin-crust gets 2 stars. 

I have been to Little Star 3 times since it opened. The first two times, I ate their thin-crust pizza. Their thin crust is mediocre at best. Honestly, you're better going off 3 doors down to Stelladoro's if you're looking for thin crust. It's both cheaper and tastier. Moving on.

What I'd really like to talk about is how my life changed when the boyfriend and I decided to give Little Star's deep dish a try last night.
Oh.My.God. A revelation.
This is possibly the most delicious pizza I have ever had in my mouth. I am not a crust girl, but this crust is amazing. It is somehow both thick AND flaky. The sauce is unbelievably delicious, with chunks of tomatoes and herbs. And cheese. Oh the cheese. Yum. This pizza even reheats well. Pizza never reheats well. 

It's cash only. So what? After eating a slice of this pizza, you won't care.
author: Steffany F.

description:
A little taste of Chicago style pizza (my home) right here in our neighborhood. 

A regular ole deep dish cheese pizza and a few champagne cocktails, I'm good to go.

Just be prepared to pay cash- no credit cards accepted. Although, there is an ATM inside that charges only $.25 to take out cash. That rules.
author: Kelly F.

description:
"For 2, name's Keika."
"Just letting you know, it's going to be at least a half hour wait."
"THAT'S FINE WITH ME!" I said with a big-ass smile.

And WHY do you ask was I willing to wait 30 minutes for a pizza pie?  Because of all the hype I heard from friends and Yelpers about how f'in good this place is AND I drove out there on a weeknite to avoid the weekend crowd!  They don't take reservations AND it's cash only...but I didn't give a hoo-ha.  We ordered the Spicy Chicken Wings and a small deep dish Classic Pizza and were stuffed and happy by thte time we left.  Friendly, fast service as well (excluding the wait)!
author: Keika L.

description:
At best it is a good imitation of Zachary's in the East Bay.  

The staff and the service are less then thrilling and the wait times are ridiculous.  By the time we were seated (30 minutes after our quoted wait time) we still had to place our order. At least at Zachary's you can order while you're waiting to be seated, which cuts down on the wait time significantly.  The Little Star people have yet to figure this clever idea out.  

I would rather spend my money at Zachary's and besides you probably eat faster even having to make the trek to Oakland.
author: Chris G.

description:
I was overwhelmed when I walked in (I felt like I could eat the smell).  I had only heard good things about the place, but had no idea it was actually a sit-down restaurant.  Regardless, the place was absolutely packed and the wait to sit down was quite ridiculous, and for good reason...the pizza is awesome.

Minus one star due to cash only policy (bastards).  

I keep reading reviews that knock this place for it's rude service, but why the hell would you want someone sitting at a table eating pizza and smelling their own farts in an empty wine glass (god help you if you don't watch South Park) for an hour when you've got a line of 20 people waiting to sit down???  Sometimes I forget I'm living in San Francisco, the land of the hybrid and home of the smug.
author: I AM SOFA KING WE TODD DI D.

description:
Oh Little Star, you could be so much more to me, if only it weren't so friggin difficult to deal with you.  I'm terribly impatient and never have anyone who is willing to wait it out for the right to partake in your wares.  You're always crowded with super shabby wannabe chic hipsters who just fell down the Divisadero hill and ended up in your sultry, tiny, dining room or draping themselves over your teeny bar.  

I'll forgive you though, because I love your Little Star spinach pie.  And I have to say that I am not a wing person.  I hate bones and tendons - they scare the bejeezus out of me, but your wings are simply delicious and I will gladly let tendons slap me in the face for the privilege.  Well that and the Little Star spinach pie.  and maybe if I'm good a Blue Moon draft.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Little Star Pizza is way above average.

Mostly because the ingredients seem very fresh and the preparation is skillfull.

Both their thin and deep dish are very good.  I recommend the deep dish vegetarian.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I have to say this maybe the most overrated place I've experienced using yelp so far. This purely based taste wise on their thick crust pizzas. 

One problem I have with it is how overpowering the sauce is. I would say the sauce is about 80% of the taste of the pizza no matter the topping (meat or vegetables). All three of our pizzas tasted roughly the same because of this. While I am more than in agreement with the the fact they use fresh ingredients that you can immediately taste, it is not enough to account for a "good" pizza. 

The second is I really disliked the corn meal crust texture . It reminded me of eating a crumbly cookie which was not at all appetizing to me while having pizza. 

Admittedly I am more a fan of artisan pizzas. However I've had pizzas with fresh ingredients and sauce that had a taste profile unique enough that I was amazed how I have never tasted anything like it even though it was just a simple pizza. All I got here was the taste of sauce, yipee. 

I just don't see this pizza being a real benchmark of any kind. I feel kind of sorry for people that have experienced this pizza as the best they've had, just know that there is much more variety and craftsmanship of pizza out there.
author: Andy C.

description:
the thing is they just are really tasty!
one million days ago i lived up the street from here on mcallister and i was so stoked on this place, specially when hunged over
author: Jessy M.

description:
I am so lucky to have this gem of a pizza place just a few blocks from me. I really enjoy making my own pizza. I typically get the Small Cheese pizza with chicken & roasted garlic. YUM YUM, & more YUM. I recommend this place to everyone. It has such a great casual laid back atmosphere, the wait staff is very nice, and take-out is easy as can be.

My only complaint is the cash only factor. I have to plan in advance to get cash to avoid the $2 fee at the ATM in the restaurant. If they would just accept my debit card, I'd give it 5 stars!
author: James E.

description: I liked this place, too bad me and my date we're the only minorities there. Overall good service, a bit crowded, and the cornmill pizza is very tasty! And i'm a damn pizza connoisseur!!!!!!!! I know what's good!!!!!!!! I think I got mediteranian.
author: Joseph C.

description:
I've only been here once, but that one visit was enough for me to know that the pizza here is awesome. It's as good as it gets. It's just sad that they don't have a joint here in Cupertino, but then again I'd be willing to drive to SF from time to time just to enjoy their pizza.
The time I went there, the restaurant was bursting with people. We had to wait for at least half an hour or even more, can't really recall. But let me tell you, it was worth the wait.
We had the deep dish pizza, the thin crust pizza, the chicken wings and as we plow through the first round of pizzas, we realize that we want more, so there goes the second round. Another round of the deep dish spinach-feta cheese-mushroom pizza and other yummy stuff, we were good to go.
I highly recommend the spinach-cheese-mushroom deep dish pizza. 
I would definitely come back and try their other pizzas. 
Aaaaahhhhh who's down to go grab some little star pizzas with me right now!!! haha four thumbs up (including my two toes hahaha) That's how good this place is! Oh and make sure you go with the right company - that will make the experience a golden one =D
author: Melissa S.

description:
I'll give the pizza 3.5 stars, guess I should have rounded up.  I have been to the Divis Little Star a couple of times now.  Both times the place was packed and the wait was 40+ minutes.  I knew that going into it both times and that is cool.  I just don't think this place is worth a 45 minute wait. I don't think many places are worth a 45 minute wait. Yes, they have beers, but the bar and surrounding gap between it and the tables is small.  Not a perfect scenario. 

On to the pizza and the food.  I have had the tomato and basil salad (aka caprese salad) and my faithful wife and friends the garden salad (huge, complete with Walnuts that I am highly allergic to) and they are great.  I have also sampled the thin and deep dish multiple times. They are also both good.  Not knock your socks off good, but solid.  Speaking of solid, maybe they could make the edge on the thin crust a little thinner because it is bordering on being capable of busting a tooth.  Still, I think I like the thin crust better. Sorry, I am from New York.

Verdict.  Go on a week night when you find that once in a lifetime parking space right in front.  Good tap beers and food. Just not worth a 45 minute wait...10 to 15 maybe.
author: Jason G.

description: This place was a total find. I had been looking for a good deep dish pizza and had heard about this place. My wife and I made a stop last week and were pleasantly surprised by how good it was. We had a veggie deep dish - loaded with spinach and cheese and a mouth-wateringly good tomato sauce. The portions are good sized too - we split a small pizza and salad and were both stuffed.  The waitstaff was friendly and service was OK.  I have heard Zacharys is the best- but I haven't tried it and  I can't be bothered to make the trek to the East Bay. I WILL be returning to Little Star though - the pizza was all that and more.
author: David Z.

description:
By far the best Deep Dish Pizza in the bay area!! Period. 

We went there on a Sunday and had a tough time trying to find parking. Once we got in, we were immediately seated near the bar. 

Our first order was for Garlic Bread. The offering was different in that they had given warm bread with butter and half a roasted garlic. Definitely interesting and surely tasty!

We ordered the Vegetarian Deep Dish Pizza. The crust was nice, juicy, fresh and crispy. The toppings were good and the sauce was excellent!! We don't like a lot of cheese and were pleasantly surprised by the cheese on this. The quantity was perfect!

Overall an excellent meal, and beats Pizz'a Chicago in the South bay and I think I prefer this over Zacchary's

Its going to be a regular hangout whenever I visit the city!
author: Manish P.

description:
"I love Little Star".  Blah, blah, blah.  That's all I've ever heard from anyone who's ever been within whiffing range of this place.  But I shall now join their leagues, as I have finally realized what all the fuss is about.

First of all, what pie to get?  Combo or veggie?  (deep dish, of course.)  We decided to ro sham bo, and I took the combo side and won.  Now sausage isn't one of my favorite foods, but what they did with it was amazing.  I think I was still drooling when we walked out it was so tasty.  And the sauce -- don't even get me going on the sauce.  Everything that should ever be in a sauce and nothing that shouldn't.  Wrapped up with love and a bow on top.

Who gets to take home the leftovers?  Again, my ro sham bo skills rocked the casbah and I can't wait for dinner tonight.  Or whatever, I'll eat it anytime!
author: Karen C.

description: It's all about the deep dish veggie. Staff can be snooty and the ambiance quite loud, But if you like great pizza this is the spot.
author: E B.

description:
Native Chicagoan and Deep-Dish Pizza Fanatic here. Little Star is, in my opinion, a more faithful rendition of true Chicago deep-dish than Zachary's or Patxi's. (They're all delish nonetheless!)

I still miss the super-buttery crusts on actual Chicago deep dish, but Little Star is the closest. I tried the Mediterranean Chicken recently, and it was exactly what you'd imagine if you took a Chicago deep-dish pizza and put some spinach, feta, and chicken inside instead of the usual toppings.

They take CASH ONLY, so don't forget to stop by the ATM before coming here. Their "garlic bread" is unusual: you get a plate of roasted garlic cloves smothered in olive oil and a loaf of bread. It's really dimly lit inside, giving it a loungy atmosphere without all the smoke or stink of a nightclub.
author: Richie K.

description:
Many people in the Bay Area like to compare Little Star and Zachary's but there is no comparison. They are two different types of deep dish pizza. Zachary's is more of a family style restaurant where Little Star is a cozier neighborhood restaurant eatery. Plus their crusts are different. Zachary's is more traditional deep dish where Little Star has the corn meal crust (which I prefer). However, Zachary's has more selection in their specialty pizzas. 

Why do I love Little Star? Besides being the best pizza in the city they have really yummy chicken wings and garlic bread with actual roasted cloves of garlic used to spread over your bread. Plus, they're only three blocks from my house. 

Be warned it gets very very busy and usually a good 45-1 hour wait on the weekends so put your name on the list and go stop by the Fly and grab yourself a beer or two.

Service is nothing to complain or rave about. 

I suggest getting the Classic or the Little Star. Enjoy!
author: David C.

description:
Tried the Divis location of Little Star for the first time and it is just as good as the one in the Mission.  We got a cheese pizza and added pesto as our topping and man that was good stuff.  I love pesto in general and this is a great version.

The pizza is filling, deceptively so.  It was just the right thing to munch on while watching the presidential debate.

I ordered it to go and it was ready when they promised.  The line to pick up the take out order was longer than I was expecting, but thats just a testament to their popularity, and regardless it was only 5 minutes.
author: Aaron T.

description:
I have been here a few times now so I am re-writing my 1st review that was so bland.

Speaking of bland, little star is just the opposite.

On a recent visit with two friends we were seated fairly promptly on a Sunday night at the table that we wanted by the window.  The service was fast and friendly... and while they didn't have the garlic bread that made me come the last time I ate it* the wings were pretty darn tasty if a bit on the not spicy side.

This time around it was the 'little star' and the 'classic' deep dish pizzas that we feasted on.  By god, I think that these were BETTER than the last ones.  How do they do that?  Extra crack in that crust?  It is just stupid how freaking great the pizza is here. Buttery like any decent deep dish but with that corn meal in there.... oh fuck.  ahhhh..... mmmm. It is that good.

If you haven't been, please go.

Also, watch out for the new little star pizza opening in the mission in a month or two.


*exaggeration
author: Thadd L.

description:
Okay, let's play a game of Pluses & Minuses here:
+: The jukebox is awesome!
-: It's so loud you can't hear yourself talk.
+: They leave a jug of water at your table.
-: There's no pineapple on the menu!!!

I like Little Star & from time to time I crave it, but my husband would eat it 24 hours a day for the rest of his life if given the chance! sheesh.
author: Melisser E.

description:
I dig the deep dish/ cornbread-style crust.  It is good as it gets in SF.

There WILL BE a wait.

Cash only.
author: Ryan W.

description:
Little star, so tasty in so many ways no so little ways (mostly because i'm about 10 pounds heavier after I eat there....umm, that just mean there's that much more of me to love...right?).

The crust is cornmeal, so its a little....cornmealier than your usual pizza (almost cornbready). The sauce is super tomato chunkity and yummie, and they're  presto is delishiosticly mouthwatering (yes, I did say delishiosticly). Just watch out for the lines here- they can be killer on weekends. 

Speaking of which, its not every day you can say a pizza joint is a nice date spot, but damn, this one's pretty close. Dark lights? Check. Hipster endorsed jukebox? Check. Ironic and cheap cans of PBR? Check. Tasty healthy-ish appetizers? Check.  

So next time you've got the hottie hipster date, saddle up to the 'star, grab that can of PBR, let that slow song of death cab for cutie set the mood, and hope that glimmer in her eye isn't just the reflection off the PBR can.....
author: Tim V.

description:
I've now been to Little Star 3 times and I think its time to review it.

Deep dish pizza at its best in SF.

There will be a wait. Sometimes that wait will be a long wait. But all will be forgotten once they drop that delicious deep dish pizza on the table. The pizza might look smaller then usual but after 2 slices you will be completely full or nearing it and have plenty of leftovers. One of the best things about this pizza is that it reheats the next day and tastes as good as it did fresh out of the oven.

Little Star is always busy so expect it to be crowded but it has a nice pizza eating atmosphere. If you have not tried it yet it's well worth the trip and your taste buds will thank you for it.
author: Patrick B.

description: Great Pizza. I am thin crust guy but this place has super deep dish (along with thin crust)...I go for the deep!
author: Sean H.

description:
Having recently been subjected to Little Star under protest... again...  I have to now go on record and say:  I do not understand the people that say that Little Star is "almost as good as Zachary's".  Have these people been to Zachary's?  In my estimation, Patxi's is much closer to a Zachary's pizza than Little Star.  

The corn meal crust is delicious, for sure, but the sauce is just ... meh.  And for me, it's all about the sauce.   My friends are all a twitter over this deep dish pizza and I keep thinking I'll see the light eventually but so far for me, this pizza is just OK.
author: LeSLiE W.

description: I entered pizza in Frisco on Yelp to and this was the first place to pop up. I'm glad I tried it.  Small restaurant with either dine in or take out.  They won't seat you until your whole party arrives so make sure everyone arrives promptly.  Had garlic bread and caprese salad for starters.  Then tried the 'classic' deep dish which was the payoff.  tasty pizza with a buttery corn meal type crust.  Never had Chicago deep dish but I'm hoping it tastes as good as Little Star!!!!!
author: Leo C.

description:
dare I say...better than ZACHERY'S?

Yum- yumma-yum-yumma-yum-yum-yum!
author: Sarah D.

description:
I've only been here once so this review will probably change.

We had their Italian combo thin crust pizza and it was pretty darned good!  I can't say it was THE best I've had, but it met all the criteria for good thin crust: crispy crust, plenty of sauce but not soggy, the toppings stick to the pie, and there is enough cheese to melt into stringy bits but not too much that you can't taste the other toppings.  We devoured half of it in the blink of an eye---it was good!

We also sampled their chicken wings, and we asked for it to be made ass-kicking hot.  And it had a bite to it!

The restaurant itself is fairly spacious and I think that's because they didn't jam-pack it with tables---you can comfortably move around in it.  There is only a single restroom so you may have a wait.  And they are CASH ONLY.  Pizzas come in Small (avg. $17) and Large (avg. $21) sizes.  To be save, everyone bring a $20 and you should be fine if you split the food among everyone.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Totally deeeeelish. Love the fact that the crust is both deep/thick AND crispy. I usually go for thin crust because I love the crunch, and this gives me that texture plus all the benefits of deep dish pizza.

Was also happy to learn of their awesome happy hour deal which results in $1 cans of PBR - hell yea!
author: Beth T.

description:
Not only did our pizzas look the same but they tasted similiar as well.  We split two small deep dish pizzas, and although both pizzas had completely different toppings, the pizzas tasted almost identical.  The fresh tomatoes, though flavorful, overpowered the toppings and cheese of the pizza.  The crust was too bland for my taste.  The pizza is certainly not bad but it's not great either.  

I would recommend skipping the toppings and just ordering a deep dish tomato and cheese pizza, or if you have to have good toppings when you order pizza, I would recommend skipping this place all together.
author: Josh K.

description:
Having lived in Chicago before and eaten deep dish pizza every Monday night (see my Giordano's review), I was very skeptical coming here. Being the only Chicago style pizza I hear people rave about in SF (Zachary's doesn't count because it's not in the city) I had to try it. Got a small with olives because that's what I always got at Giordano's and I had to compare them fairly. I must say, Little Star is very very good pizza.... BUT I do have a couple of qualms. #1 it's just not cheesy enough. I want the cheese to come off in strings when I pull it up from the box. This cheese was such a thin layer that I could barely find it when I went to eat a slice layer by layer (my fave part about deep dish). #2 Crust was a little too burnt for my taste. Nice buttery flavor but I like my crust a bit more doughy.

Anywho - I  give you 4 stars for trying, Little Star. Nothing will compare to my Giordanos though.
author: Sarah P.

description:
Now I've had deep dish pizza before - in Chicago.  So I didn't really think that anything here in SF could live up to that... but after reading the rave reviews I decided to check this place out.

I didn't expect the interior to be as nice as it was... candlelight, dark walls - the ambiance was definitely brought to the table.  The deep dish was pretty lovely and my only comment would be that it could have had one less ladle of sauce.  Otherwise tasty and perfect for a foggy SF evening.  My dining companion and I agreed that we'd be back again sometime soon.
author: Rashmi N.

description:
Very good pizza, I only have came here for the deep dish Chicago style pizza, actually I was here last night. And had the left overs for breakfast and it was still yummy! I must admit Zachary's in Berkley is a bit better, although I am going to have to go back to Zachary's for a taste test mission....

The wait is a bit long sometimes, parking is terrible for the NOPA location, the cool thing is there are some cool spots around so you can grab a drink or dessert at Cany Bar or a show at the Independent.  I wish they would deliver or have a spot you can pull up to grab take out, if they had all the things I really wished for I would for sure give them a 5 star :-)
author: Bobby B.

description:
Y-U-M. This pizza is so good it's dangerous. And by dangerous I mean that my boyfriend is willing to get himself dressed (yeah, he has a nasty habit of working from home in his boxers), lose his parking spot, and huff it 20 mins from our place just to get some. They don't deliver but we're willing to travel for this treat.

We've only ever ordered the deep dish - but from what I understand the thin crust is delish too. I personally recommend the Classic or the Little Star, but I can't imagine you'd go wrong with anything coming out of that oven.

Prices are reasonable (for something so good) but I'd skip the salad and make your own if you have the time/energy.

I implore Waiters on Wheels (or a similar service) to add Little Star to your lineup. We'd probably indulge more than once a week.

Yum!!!!
author: Carrie S.

description: Everything at this Little Star is solid gold. The garlic bread with the full bulb of roasted garlic is absolutely fantastic. Staff is friendly, wait is never too long even on the weekends and straight up they have some of the best deep dish I have ever had in my life.
author: Stephen B.

description:
I've always been under the assumption that Zachary's was the reining Bay Area deep dish king...until now. 

Little Star turns out some exception deep dish. The crust is what makes it so special for me. It is crunchy and flaky, almost pastry-like in texture. It's not overly cheesy which makes me happy and the tomato sauce has a nice spiciness (but not overly) to it. 

The atmosphere screams hipster; complete with $2 cans of PBR. 

They only accept cash, which is a bummer for someone like me who rarely carries cash. The nice thing is Little Star has a conveniently located ATM by the front door and surprisingly, I was only charged a .25 cent service charge rather than the regular $2+ for using a machine that's not your own bank.
author: Lee H.

description:
Despite my well-worn and deep-seated feelings about east coast, nyc-style pizza, I do love this place.  Having never been exposed to Chicago-style pizza outside of Pizzeria Uno's and Pizza Hut, I had always, incorrectly, assumed deep-dish pizza to be vastly inferior, and had, regrettably, quietly judged those who had vigorously argued its virtues.

But after being back there with a large group last night for the half-dozenth time, I was reminded of my love for this pizza, and I'm willing to concede that this is f'n good pizza, even if a slice is meal in and of itself.

But no review of Little Star should go without mentioning The Jukebox.

It isn't much of a secret that I'm a jukebox junkie, and there aren't many left in this city that haven't seen a few of my dollars pass through the reader. This jukebox is possibly my favorite in the city, and it isn't one of those newfangledInternet jukeboxes that let you download and inflict Journey's Greatest Hits on the entire bar.  This is an old-school, hand-selected jukebox, and it, quite simply, warms my heart.

Yes, the Stones are well represented.  So is Bowie (and not just Greatest Hits).  And, thank god, there isn't any sign of anything by The Eagles.  But more importantly: Pavement? Modest Mouse? A Beck album that isn't Odelay? The Walkmen!? The Soft Bulletin!??

Someone at Little Star is after my heart.
author: james s.

description:
The pizza here is pretty good. I've always been more partial to new york pizza, but here it was different. The cornmeal crust was crispy and buttery and different from typical pizza crust which made it soo much better. The crust is usually what turns me off from deep dish, compared to new york styles thin crispy crust. The new york style pizza wasnt very memorable. When I come next time, I won't be eating in but getting take out, because the deep dish takes half hour to make, and I tend to be very hungry by the time I find parking. 
Oh yea, remember to bring cash, because this place doesn't take cards. There's an atm machine there also though. But, you prob have to pay a fee. Oh yea, parking here = to pain in the butt! It took us over half hour to find parking that was 4 blocks away from this place. Sacramento has spoiled me with parking thats on the same block.
author: dI c.

description:
Having been raised by Polish parents from Chicago, I can thoroughly assure Yelpers of my Chicago-style deep dish pizza knowledge. Be it Giordano's, Lou Malnati's, or Gino's, I've tasted the best.

Little Star gets props for being in the Mission and having a clever logo (points before I walk in the door). Whenever I go there, I'm always waiting for friends to arrive or find parking, so I tend to grab a drink at the bar, conveniently located immediately at the entrance (where you can also pick up your pizza to go). 

I've gone there with parties large and small and the staff is always excellent. 

As far as the pizza goes, I always get the Classic. I'm happy to see that Little Star didn't try to cater too much to the fanciful palettes of Californians (no CPK tofu pizza). Their pizza is quite good. It's a little light (that's the first test: slice weight) and lacking cornmeal on the underside, but it's less greasy than a typical Chicago deep dish. The slices hold up well (nothing falls off or slides around) and makes for a tasty snack in the AM. It certainly rivals Zachary's. 

The only downside to the whole experience: CASH ONLY. (I think they're fixing it soon).
author: Tim B.

description:
My roommates and I were having our usual dilemma about where to eat, but it was especially difficult this time because we had some friends visiting from southern California. Even bigger dilemma: our friend does not like ethnic foods, pretty picky. It's always important to show your guests a good time in the bay, but we just could not think of a place to go in SF!

Here is where Yelp came to the rescue! My roommate came across a pizza spot called Little Star with a ton of reviews raving about their thick crust pizza (brilliant because this friend of ours adores Zachary's). Based on the reviews of fellow Yelpers we decided to check this place out...

...And the pizza was delicious. I'll even venture to say the thick crust at Little Star is better than at Zachary's!! It was a hit with our SoCal buddy as well. However, four stars for the extremely long wait and difficult parking. Other than that the food, service, and atmosphere is wonderful. Thanks Yelp!
author: Priscilla M.

description:
OK, having lived in Chicago and having had plenty of Gino's East and Giordano's, and having visited Zachary's (Zax) almost religiously over the years, not having to got to Chicago or to cross the bridge AND finding something just as excellent in San Francisco, was HUGE!

I really like this place.  But if one thing bothers me it is that both locations (Divisadero & Valencia) are extremely loud.  And the loud music makes it really difficult to hear or talk to anyone not immediately adjacent to you.

So take in - good, take out - great!
author: K G.

description:
OK, the world awaits another Yelp from me, so here goes.

Tried Little Star for the second time last night. First time was over a year ago. I wanted to see what all the hype was about. 

I don't think it's nice to name out a competitor and declare it superior, so I won't name the place that I think is better (also if I did it might result in more crowds there - not cool). So, simply put, I think Little Star is good, but not great. It's almost the same thing as the other place (Chicago deep dish), but with a few limitations. 

The most positive aspect of the deep dish pie here is the crust. It is crunchy, corn meal style and good. The cheese is good, but there is not enough sauce. The pies taste a bit dry as a result. "The other place" has a zesty tomato sauce that explodes with flavor in each bite. I didn't have nearly the same sensation at Little Star. 

In summary, Little Star will do in a pinch, but I'm glad my other favorite is around, and in case you're wondering, it isn't Zachary's.
author: Matt H.

description: I always enjoy little star. One of my fav deep dish pizza in the city.
author: Shivani S.

description: It's good pizza for sure, but not the best and on the overpriced side.  It's not anywhere near NYC's greatness, but it still deserves some attention.  What I like about it, is that Little Star does have a distinct taste and both the thin crust and thick crust are equally as good.   The ingredients are fresh and the sauce is tasty, but it just doesn't knock my socks off.
author: Jessica B.

description:
I haven't had a very wide exposure to deep dish pizza. I tried Zachary's - it's alright. However, the Little Star Deep Dish Classic, (sub Spinach for Peppers), is, in a word - Heaven! Ohhhhh, that cornmeal crust! Ohhhhh that thick, zesty tomato sauce! If you don't cream your pants when you bite into this pizza, you probably have the anatomy of a Barbie Doll.

Note: on occasion it's been so noisy that I couldn't shout loud enough to talk. Which tends to make me really grumpy. That's where they lose a star. I hear they've turned down their way overrated juke box.
author: Griffin L.

description:
My favorite place to be on a Sunday night! And don't worry -- it's nice and dark in the dining room, so no one will see the cheese dripping from your chin when you pack in that extra piece ;o)

I'm an honorary Chicago native, and Little Star might just have the best Chicago-style deep dish I've had outside Illinois. For that matter, it might be better than any I've had in Illinois, too. The pizza sauce is amazing... I'd pay good money for a sneaky peek at the recipe.
author: Heather L.

description:
I'm not really into pizza. Yeah, I know! Weird, right? 

So when I like a pizza place, it's kind of big deal.

My chief complaints with a lot of pizza are as follows:
Bland sauce.
Chewy inedible crust.
Too much cheese.

Oh Little Star, how you have shown me the way. I came here and had a deep dish pizza and I have never liked deep dish pizza in the history of deep dish pizzas. I loved it. Best of was the yummy, just right crust. One bite and I was a convert. 

Plus the jukebox is a mirror image of my CD collection. The Walkmen, Band of Horses, Elliott Smith?! YES!
author: Jackie I.

description:
Simply the best pizza ever.

Pizza is my favorite food (burritos are number 2), and normally I love thin crust pizza (the reason I studied abroad in Florence, Italy) but I die for the thick, cornmeal, deliciousness of Little Star! I love the Divis local, super cozy, non cheesy, slightly elegant and a good crowd. 

My favorite to order is the salad (with cheese! and nuts! awesome), then the Little Star special. I took my parents here when they came to visit. They both claimed they didn't like spinach, so I ordered it for myself. They both tried a piece and fell in love. They also have great wines, and if I go with friends, splitting all that food makes for a very reasonable dinner out. I would definitely pay twice as much!
author: Whitney F.

description:
- food: delicious
- atmosphere: loud / cramped but fun
- price: who cares
- staff: hipster / friendly

additional info:
- amazing jukebox
author: J. B.

description:
"I would walk 500 miles, and I would walk 500 more..."

Worth the wait for amazing deep dish concotions, and the Divis location is very cosy and a great date place.

thank you for existing.
author: Serene M.

description:
Sigh.Sigh.Sigh.Sigh....pizza, yummmm

Little Star Pizza was a-m-a-z-i-n-g. My mouth is watery just from thinking about pizza at this place. Pizza at this place is something else. All their pizzas are rich in flavor, and made according to your choice of toppings. Don't let the size of the pizza fool you either...it will fill you up. 

It's absolutely the BEST pizza. If you're the type that normally leaves pizza crust behind on your plate, you definately won't do that here!
author: Rosa D.

description:
If you like deep dish pizza, then I highly recommend Little Star.  Personally, I think it's better than Zachary's or Patxi's.  Little Star's deep dish pizza is made with a cornmeal crust, giving it a very unique texture and flavor.  My personal favorite is the 'Little Star'.  

Personally, I find the tomatoes on most deep dish pizzas to be overpowering.  This is not the case with Little Star.

I've been to Little Star several times and service has always been acceptable.  

In addition to excellent pizza, Little Star has very reasonably priced beers and a badass jukebox.

While their deep dish pizzas are phenomenal, there are a few areas where they fall short:

1.  The thin crust pizza is nothing special.  I would skip it.
2.  Appetizers and salads miss the mark.  For example, their garlic bread is made with sourdough bread and is served with a side of butter and a slow roasted bulb of garlic.  
3.  No credit cards.  Cash only.
author: Dheeraj I.

description:
Hmmm. Nummy pizza.

Not sure how I feel about the depressing black curtains and shadowy interior. I sorta felt I was at a funeral. Of course, it might not be so bad eariler in the day.

Anyway, we had the deep dish little star and I think we could have ordered two without leaving leftovers. Definately the best pizza I've had in town, even if it's a bit more expensive than I'd normally spend.
author: Jere K.

description:
This place is good for sure.  Although, I was coming in here expecting the place to be better than Windy City in San Mateo - and I didn't think it was.  I ordered the garlic bread, and was unpleasantly surprised when it was actual baked cloves of garlic to spread on slices of bread.  Where is the grease?  I'm sorry, garlic bread should not taste healthy.  They should rename the garlic bread to be called "baked garlic cloves".

The pizza was very flavorful and the crust was nice and crispy.  I haven't had authentic Chicago style pizza, but I am now curious to try it to see for myself how this place stands up against it.

There was a long wait for a weekday night.  They said it'd be an hour wait, and it only took 30 minutes.  They've got a small bar that you can get some beers while you wait though, so it wasn't that bad.  They also have take-out, so that is an option.
author: Russell R.

description:
Even if sprecks of grizzled pepperoni wax played hooky from my roommates half to my off limits quadrant, the heaping veggie commando fired back in flavor, gusto, size and overall presentation. The vegan precinct was not held back by a goddamn thing, the absentee dairy digestive inhibitor would have actually prevented elation emancipation. 

I sway you not in vain: anyone get the veggie, minus cheese plus spinach and you there is such a notion that you will experience asymptomatic recognizance for at least 25 minutes. That sauce, that crust, garlic infused foliage............ this some smack ya momma grub, straight up. Less hours in a hospital bed never appeared so feasible!

p.s. The bill ain't gonna lower though, thats where the last star is hiding. No matter the star size, the shit's a splurge trouffe. Take your helping, shut up, and save up for the next brilliant installment.
author: Christopher J.

description:
I really don't understand the bad reviews. Sure, maybe you caught one of the employees on a bad day or mom didn't make you Mickey Mouse shaped pancakes this morning so your day was off to a terrible start but I can't think of one thing wrong with this place. Well, it felt slightly cramped but, it's in San Francisco-- what do you expect?

The pizza here is awesome, plain and simple. I'm not one of those "pizza experts" from Chicago, or New York or whatever who claims that a pizza joint isn't as good as that hole in the wall Greasy Eddie's on the corner of 5th and Pretentious in some slum on the east coast. All I know is this pizza is good. Really good. 

I, of course, went with the deep-dish style because after I tried that, I never thought of thin crust again. The deep-dish crust is probably the best part of the pizza. I had a veggie pizza with spinach, garlic, and mushrooms--- perfect. The sauce, while it could stand a few more spices thrown in, was also perfect. I used to be a die-hard Patxi's fan but that might be changing...

The garlic bread-- what can I say about this garlic bread... they give you a sourdough roll sliced. In a separate container you get butter and olive oil whipped together and then a whole BULB of roasted garlic. You spread it all on the bread yourself and it is glorious. I think I liked it even more than the pizza to be honest. 

The beer is a little overpriced but, beer and pizza is like PB and J so, I had to go for it anyway. 

The atmosphere and service were awesome. We hardly waited at all for anything to come out after we ordered it and we were seated within 2 minutes. Granted, it was a Thursday evening so I don't know what the weekends are like but, still impressive. 

The dark and velvety atmosphere is perfect. Although you are fairly exposed and close to everyone else, it doesn't really feel like it. It is both communal and intimate. 

As for parking... again, it's San Francisco. Take the bus or walk.
.
author: Matt L.

description:
Always good, but never blown away. 

It's funny, we as Californians are just so damned spoiled... my classic story is being in Chicago for a week and going to a different deep dish pizza place every day, from a list compiled by natives and long-time deep-dish freaks... I was never wowed. Don't get me wrong, it's deep dish and as Stephen Baldwin said, "Even when it's bad, it's still pretty good."

But those delightful pies were still missing something, even on their hometurf. When you have "Chicago-style deep dish" at Little Star or Zachary's, for example, the ingredients taste fresher, the pie is less oily, and the whole experience is just overall... tastier.

Now, to touch upon the Zachary's vs Little Star face-off. Not necessary. They're two different styles of deep dish, and although inherently stem from the same wonderful Chicago origin, they're tough to compare, much less compete. Little Star is much more like its Chicago roots than Zachary's -- it's a little more shallow and has flattened the ingredients internally -- some purists actually prefer that, as they think Zachary's is "too jumbly in there," allowing the extra ingredients to hop around too much.

The real difference, however, is the crust. Little Star has that cornmeal crust... that's really what it comes down to. If you prefer that, you're a Little Star fan 'til the end. But if you prefer a more traditional wheat crust while still prefering the "Chicago-style" to ACTUAL Chicago, then Zachary's is the place for you.

LONG story short, Little Star is delish, just not my preference. Can't we all just get along?
author: D. R.

description:
Little Star's pizza is freaking delicious!  I especially like the signature Little Star deep dish; their regular crusts are aiiight, but, if you ask me, deep dish is the way to go here.  The sauce they use is something heavenly and their pizza tastes great the next day for breakfast!

The service is great too.  Great place to come with no more than 4 people, please!  That's my one gripe about the place: there is ALWAYS a wait.  It is well worth it though.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
This pizza place is one of the best in the city!

The place was a little dark but the people who work there are friendly and down to earth.
author: Isabella V.

description:
One word : YUM! 
Try their specials, usually pretty damn good.
author: Valerie O.

description:
Honestly, I didn't want to like this place.  Ratings this high for a pizza joint in San Francisco?  Unheard of.  Really.  Is it because we don't have good pizza in this city???  No.  I can appreciate quality pizza just as much as the next person.  Is it because we have have a bunch of pizza snobs (I like to call them PS's) amongst us?  More likely, eh.  I'm not going to lie.  I really wanted to give this place a scathing review just to knock some PS's on their asses.  But ... I can't, dammit.  Instead, this pizza knocked ME on MY ass.  I'm not even a huge fan of deep dish, and the pizza here was ... hmmm... delectable.  It's a good thing that Little Star is a nice, longish walk from my house.  Walk it off, baby, walk it off :)

The inside of the place is fun too ... good jukebox, kinda dark.
author: Jenni A.

description:
This is a loaded review. I'm from Illinois, and I've eaten a little bit of Chicago pizza here and there.  I have friends that have eaten a little bit of Chicago pizza here and there. They have strong opinions about Chicago pizza, and if I'm going to quantify an assessment of Chicago pizza I'd better be able to defend it.

Um. I'm not good under pressure.  I like the pizza. What else? We'll start with comparisons, since this seems to be the norm.  I like Little Star less than I like Patxi's and more than I like Zachary's. I like it less than I like Papa Del's in Champaign, IL, but more than I like Giordano's in Chicago.  The latter might be sort of sacrilegious, but I guess I'm in good company if Little Star is President Obama's fave. 

As far as "authenticity", here's where I risk a heated multi-hour debate.  The crust is nice and crunchy, but there's not enough cheese. The quantity of sauce is good, as is the consistency/viscosity.  However, I do agree with Carson H. that an alleged Chicago-style pie that comes out of the oven in 25 minutes is suspect.  45 minutes is a respectable amount of time to wait; an hour is more like it.  Additionally, the California twist is unmistakable in the add-on selections. Artichoke hearts? "Garlic olive oil base"? Wtf. Gelato for dessert? Ha.

However, I guess "style" allows a bit of wiggle room, and I'd say Little Star has successfully re-interpreted the concept of deep-dish Chicago pizza.  If you're looking for a carbon copy of the fare at a classic Chitown joint, prepare to be disappointed. If you're OK with roasted zucchini on your pie, though, I'd definitely recommend LS.
author: Janna M.

description:
This is pizza ya'll. mama mia it's good. If you want great pizza, I mean if you really want aweasome pizza, fuck the rest, this is the best. Seriously! Oh boy so saucy! 
What makes a good pizza anyway???
1) Crust son - crunchy outside, chewy inside, tasty
2) Sauce - you can pour this shit on anything
3) Toppings - I say simple is best but whatever you like you can get
 
Here's tip! order a box just for fun - you'll be happy you did (breakfast, lunch, snack for the next day. You'll thank me.
author: Glen G.

description:
Um, it's Little Star.  Like my arm is my arm.

You go, you wait forever, and you eat like it's your last meal on Earth.  And you'd be OK with that.  Because it's Little Star and you have a glass of champagne.
author: Amanda C.

description: Great god damn pizza.  Can't make up my mind which is better... this or Zachary's.  Fuck thin-crust pizza.
author: Rocco D.

description:
YEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEES! 
PIZZA PIZZA PIZZA!  

Needless to say me likey little star.  Great pizza, great garlic bread, nice servers, cute interior.  I'm sure their thin crust pizza is good but when the guys next to you order it you feel like slapping 'em and saying WHAT? The deep dish is amaze.
author: luke b.

description: I REALLY miss Chicago pizza and this is the closest I've gotten to Giordano's stuffed spinach pizza in the city.  The corn meal crust is different but yummy.  I've actually never eaten in - always call ahead for pick up.  They offer delivery now (through a third party that brings your pizza via bike) but a large pizza ends up being $40 with delivery charge and tip.
author: barbara b.

description: Growing up in Illinois to the likes of Lou Malnati, Pizzeria Uno and Due, Bacino's, and Gino's East, it was a welcome surprise to find authentic deep dish in the Bay Area.  The place gets crowded, but the small, but well-chosen beer selection at the bar helped pass the time (bring cash - no credit cards).  They have both a thin and thick crust version, and we had the thick crust.  We started off with a pound of wings, which were well done as a baked version.   The crust had a nice buttery touch like in Chicago.  The next layer of cheese and meat was then topped with a zesty, chunky tomato sauce.  The pie didn't have as much meat as the ones from Chicago, but my arteries appreciated that.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Peter L.

description: the pizza taste good.. but the crust is way better at Paxti's.  The crust over here is tough and dry.
author: E F.

description:
BEST PIZZA IN MY LIFE! 

My mouth is watering just as I write this review. Ive been coming here for over a year and it is hands down the best pizza ever! I order take out for the most part and always order their staple: Little Star Pizza which is deep dish.  I had never been a fan of deep dish until I had this one because its the first one that doesnt over-use the tomato sauce. It's just right with all of the ingredients. A friend recently told me to add roasted garlic and I cant wait to try that next.

Their cheesecake is also to die for. It's homemade and the best way to end the meal.  I'm really grateful this place is in my hood. If it wasnt, I would definitely travel across town to get it.

p.s. cash only!
author: Veronica P.

description:
Got here around 6:45pm with my cousin and a girlfriend last night and the place was packed.  We waited for about 45 minutes before we were seated but it was so worth it.  We ordered a small Little Star, a small Classic and a large Mixed Salad.  The salad was a good starter ~ loved that they cut up the onions and peppers in the salad.  Any salad with gorgonzola is a good salad in my book.

I didn't try the Classic since I'm still a vegetarian for the next few days.  From what I was told, there was way too much marinara and not enough sausage.  To quote my cousin, "It was like eating spaghetti sauce on top of a pizza crust."  However, the Little Star did live up to all the hype on Yelp ~ definitely recommended!

FYI ~ the pizza is super filling.  We were all stuffed after eating two slices each!
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Yum yum yum yum...  Take Zachary's out of Berkeley, bring it to SF, swap out the Cal students for hipsters and add $2 PBRs. Love it.
I once made the mistake of showing up with a big group on a Friday night - total rookie move. Groups of 4 or less are the way to go for sure. And sitting at the bar while you wait for your table isn't half bad since they'll keep the beers flowing for you.

PS -- BOOOO They no longer accept credit cards. Bring cash!
author: Heather C.

description:
What can I say about Little Star that hasn't been said before?   People.  Stop your bitching.  They have an ATM right beside their front door, so you really don't need to have a shit-fit about the cash only policy.  You're having Little Star pizza.  Isn't it worth the two buck surcharge?

Something that you often face when consuming deep-dish pizza is a richness so overwhelming that it can distress one's bowels.  Such is NOT the case here.

The thick cornmeal crust has a delicious butter-free crunch and bulky texture strong enough to support the weight of the selected toppings.  The fresh vegetable and meat toppings are well-measured and topped with the perfect amount of mozzarella cheese... not too much to make the pizza soggy, yet enough to act as nature's greatest (and tastiest) adhesive.  The zingy tomato sauce has a consistency and flavor of perfectly stewed and reduced tomatoes.  YUMMERS!!

If you want to have the PERFECT experience at Little Star, order a large deep-dish Classic pizza and substitute pepperoni for the onions.  Get the Caprese salad for its fresh basil and ripe tomatoes (or the Mixed Salad for its generous portion) while you wait.  Don't forget to order a can of PBR or Movie Star (champagne cocktail) to wash down all the goodness.

By the way... Little Star is a GREAT choice for take-out if you don't have the time to wait in line for a table.  Oh YEAH!  If you don't want to wait too long, just go with ONE other person.  Tables for two free up pretty regularly.
author: Jenny K.

description:
What's this?  Pizza down the street from me?  I hope it's good.

Just kidding.  I had been meaning to try this place for a while, and then I moved in a block away.  I love this pizza.  I love it thick, I love it thin, I love to take it out, or to eat it in.  A good selection of red wine or beer, oh and "garlic bread" means here's a loaf of bread.  And a roasted head of garlic.  Eat it.
author: Mick B.

description:
When we arrived the place was packed.  From what I could tell from a glance at the wait list, there must have been at least 25 people ahead of us. Luckily a good amount of the seating here can't accommodate more than two people, so we were seated less than 10 minutes after arriving.  

The service was surprisingly good.  We ordered our drinks just minutes after arriving.  I had the Creamsicle, a champagne cocktail that tasted like a grown up orange soda.  Plus it was huge!  Very yummy.  

For food we started with the caprese which was excellent and came with a little side of olives.  For pizza we went with a small deep dish Little Star with sausage added on.  My boy and I are spinach fiends so we were both in love with this pizza.  The tomato sauce was perfect and seemed very fresh.

Our only complaints were the prices (expensive for pizza) and the noise level.
author: Katie S.

description:
The sauce!  The sauce!  It reminds me of Al's back home!  I swear it's the same secret....

Deep dish is where it's at, baby.  Just make sure you're in good company because you could be waiting for your table for a looooong time and it can be excrutiating if your comrades are pesky.  In the non-cute way.

DEEP DISH!
author: Jessica M.

description:
To date, Little Star is my standard for pizza.

Biases.  For me, it's all about the crust.  Little Star does one of the best cornmeal crusts around.  Others may disagree and say it's all about the toppings.  Anyone can change the toppings, but for me, that crust takes a little more time and effort to perfect.  So ask yourself, are you about toppings or crust?  Are you a top or a bottom?  LOL

Parking on a Friday night.  Forget it.  This is SF and it'll take you some time to find street parking.  We were able to find street parking 2 to 3 blocks away.

Waited and waited.  Adapt to the wait time.  It'll take up to 1 1/2 hours to get your food.  Upon our arrival, we were told it was a 35 minute wait to be seated and that mandatory 1/2 hour wait required for deep dish pizza.  Okay, no problem.  Wading through the standing room only waiting crowd, we made our way to the bar.  We ended up ordering a pint each of an ale that had the name "Racer 5" in it.  We were buzzing after a few sips.  Hmmmm.  I later found out that it had 7+% alcohol in it.  The buzz, the decent crowd and the conversation made time fly.  I want more Racer 5.

The halogen track lighting highlit spots at various tables.  The wait staff was energetic and easy to reach when flagging them down.  Even with the smart and polite crowd about the restaurant, I'm not sure I'd recommend this place to kids.  It was more of a bar room intimate dim inside.  Hmmmm.  Maybe bring the kids on a weekend afternoon?

The main event.  We ordered 1/2 the Little Star and 1/2 the Classic.  We were impressed with both.  Again, it's that crust that had me at hello.  I'll definitely be returning to Little Star, but my search for other good pizza continues, and the journey may be long.  Again, if you're a crust fan, Little Star is a must have.
author: D. A.

description:
The pizza is fantastic - better than Zachary's, in my opinion.  The corn meal crust really sets it apart, and it doesn't taste greasy at all.  They have a small, but good beer selection as well.  The salad is ginormous, so only order that if you are in a group of at least 4 people.

I would have given it 5 stars if it wasn't for these issues:
-lack of parking
-no reservations
-cash only!
author: Jen M.

description:
My roommates told me I hadn't lived until I had Little Star.  I think I have to disagree.  I have in fact lived and could have gone on living having not gone to Little Star.  

This place is so hipster I want to cry for the poor pinched ankles in skinny jeans that I see all over the place and the PBR that people proudly drink from cans.  Honey, it's no longer ironic to drink white trash beer while wearing Sevens.  Irony happens when you DON'T expect it.  And since that style is so insanely popular and this is the land of "nothing surprises me", you're going to have to try a little harder.  How about dressing in clothes that don't fit and drinking Remy Martin?  Oh wait....

This would be a 3.5 rating but I'm giving it 4 since I have yet to try the thin crust which is my preference when it comes to pizza.  I will hand it to Little Star for it's deep dish.  All toppings, no super thick crust.  If I can find a Chicago style I like, they must be doing something right.

This is a total date place.  Mood lighting and all.  If I went here by myself I'd feel like a total loser.  Also it cash only which I find infuriating.  Especially when I've lost my ATM card and B of A can't seem to get me a new one until 7 days after the fact.  A place this busy should take credit cards or ATM.  But no one else seems to think it's a problem and I probably wouldn't either if B of A didn't suck and I had my head screwed on straight.

Overall the place is cool.  I'll come back for the New York style to see if it is up to par.  Then I can tell you how it is.  But please PLEASE let the hipster thing die out before I come back.  Or at least tone down.  I'm having a hard time finding jeans that don't make my ass look huge.
author: Alexis B.

description:
their wings + some vegetarian chicago style scrumptious pizza + a diet coke with a fresh lime = the most perfect meal on earth.

This place is a consistent hit and delivers complete satisfaction everytime!
author: Aaliya Y.

description:
I've got one word to describe Little Star- AMAZING.

Actually, my dinner at Little Star with my boyfriend,  "Herbert Stencil" on Saturday night was the end of a year- old saga, the start of which can be found in one of his reviews: http://tinyurl.com/bx44u.

We got there just before 5PM, when the restaraunt opens.  We were greeted by attractive male waiters, which is always a plus.  Truth be told, our own waiter was just cute, but the other guy was quite attractive.  When we walked in, Weezer was playing over the sound system, which we were both fairly indifferent to.  However, a trip over to the jukebox revealed a great music collection.  There had to be around 100 albums, by artists such as Death Cab for Cutie, Iron & Wine, The Postal Service, The Shins, The Pixies, Franz Ferdinand, Pearl Jam, David Bowie, and many others.

The atmosphere was quite nice- we got there when it was still rather quiet, but it started getting more interesting as the night went on.  There was a definite buzz in Little Star.  The decorations were a nice mix of modern, elegant, and classic.  The lighting was on the dark side, but for the atmosphere and furnishings, it definitely worked, and did not commit the oft-commited crime of overdone, hindering, mood-dampering darkness.

To start out, we ordered the garlic bread.  The waiter came out with warm, fresh sourdough bread, a lot of butter with a tad bit of olive oil mixed it, and a large roasted garlic bulb cut in half so that we could get at the sweet, delicious roasted garlic insides.   It was absolutely brilliant, and worked perfectly.

The pizza wasn't so shabby, either, to say the least.  We ordered the "Little Star."  Deep dish with a savory pie-like crust, it really "hit the spot."  On top of the crust was the cheese (just strong enough, but not too strong...perfect pizza cheese) and sauce and toppings over that.  I  been avoiding the cliche Zachary's/Little Star comparison (funny that after only about a year there's already a cliche), but here I must interject- they definitely copied Zachary's, but it's so good, who could object?  The sauce was a nice strong tomatoe sauce that I cannot say enough about.  The toppings were great- feta, ricotta, spinach, mushrooms, onion, and garlic.

Go on a casual date, go with lots of friends, go on your own and sit at the bar- you're sure to at least have great food, an attractive waiter,a dn hopefully a great time.
author: Alyssa O.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed the deep dish pizza at Little Star, as well as the funky, dark and romantic atmosphere. The pizza crust was buttery and crispy enough but I would have liked more cheese, the toppings made up for it though as they were all high quality, as well as the tasty champagne cocktail I sampled. 
I have yet to try deep dish anywhere else in the city so the only comparison I can make is to the stuff I enjoyed in Chicago which I believe it reaches but does not surpass. Be forewarned, parking is particularly horrible and they only take cash but there is a small atm inside the restaurant.
author: Meg L.

description:
Been a Zachary's devotee for yeeaaars and couldn't wait to try what others deem its equivalent, or (gasp).....better!

Ordered both thin crust and deep dish and the lowdown is that yes, it's really good but different than Zachary's in that their thin crust is regular dough and deep dish is cornmeal (exact opposite of Z's).  

I loved how thin the thin crust was and that it had plenty of sauce that goes almost to the edge.  Z's thin can be lacking on sauce sometimes and rarely ever goes to the edge.  But!  Taste-wise Z's has the upperhand IMHO.

LSP's deep dish (known as "Stuffed" at Z's) is really tasty and the crust held up great so you can pick the little monster up.  The only part I didn't love was that the crust reminded me of Pizza Hut's greasy crusts.  That didn't take away from the fact that this is a tasty top-rate pizza -- I just love Z's more -- I now want to leave work to make the trek across the bridge to get some.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Overrated... 
Don't get me wrong, I eat like a pig whenever someone is willing to pick up some little star and bring it to a house party, and it's always a big hit. But, it's really not that great. Every pie has too much of that thick out of the can tomato paste sauce on it, not enough cheese and the crust is practically dripping with butter. Maybe some people dig that maybe I dig that but maybe not. 

Honestly I think DiGiorno's is better.
author: matt l.

description:
Little Star vs Zachary's........

That is the Age Old Question....  

Well, for me I think Little Star is pretty damn good and I know for sure I will go back many times but I still would put Zachary's on a higher pedestal.  Little Star's crust was buttery good, the sauce and toppings were really tasty but..................

it just seemed like they didn't pile on the toppings like Zachary's did.  At least when I went.  It was a pretty noticeable difference.  Enough where my eating companion noticed it too.  We were able to do a half-half so that was nice.  We ended up doing the Classic and Mediterrean Chicken.      

We went early so we didn't have to wait for a table.  About 5:45pm on a Friday early evening and I had heard that they had a Happy Hour too so cool!!!  They started filling up around 6:45pm though and that's when people had to start waiting for tables so be sure to get there early if you don't want to wait.....

HAPPY HOUR DEETS:
$1 off beers 5pm - 6:30pm; After 10pm
author: Mark W.

description:
OK. I've had better deep-dish pizza, but not in San Francisco.  I'll keep looking, but in the meantime, I'll probably stick with Little Star.  I don't really understand why it's so difficult to find real deep dish in San Francisco.  It's not all that complicated to make.  It's not like the pizza shops in Chicago or even Detroit have some special magic.  

On a side note, I HATE HATE HATE places that are cash only.  I'd almost give this place 3 stars for that fact alone.  Come one.  Who carries cash anymore?  Get a credit card machine already.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Not as good as Zachary's.  The pizza was tasty, and the staff is really nice.  The crust was different than I am used to on a deep dish, it was a bit thicker than I am used to.  Little Star is a fine substitute when I do not want to drive to the East Bay for Zachary's.  

Oh, they are cash only too.
author: Dana H.

description: Best deep dish in San Francisco. Not a close competition.
author: Amjad S.

description:
Pretty long wait, pretty high prices, pretty good pizza.

Parking's a bit tricky as expected with the area. Might take a few laps around the block until someone leaves and you can swoop in.
author: Joel J.

description: This place is awesome, even when they're kicking you out for being too drunk and falling on the floor!
author: Craig E.

description: If you ever land a spot here, try the Italian sausage Pizza, thick crust , very good pizza, not a regular pizza you are use to eat.
author: Rafael G.

description: Best pizza spot in the area. I recommend Classic deep dish. On the weekends it is very busy, so wait times are long, and not always accurate. Although we waited a while longer than expected, the service following our wait time more than made up for it. Very sweet staff!
author: Jenna L.

description:
so it's final.  i decided this year, being the snobby foodie NYer i am, that I am not spending any more money or calories on crap pizza in Cali.  it's pains me. pains me to eat cheese on sauce on dough that tastes less than each ingredient on its own.  Why, SF and LA, can't you make it like any place in NY!? 
ok, so Little Star is deep dish but the ONLY place I'll pay for pizza.  I've given SF a fair shot at pleasing my palate with pizza but pah-too-ey & yuck is all i have to say. 
ordering for takeout is the way to go (it actually doesn't get soggy once you get home) but if you decide to wait there, it has taken us an hour before but def worth it with a fun grp of friends. Without that, order a drink play "countdown from 4000."
author: Emm C.

description:
I like how both of the locations are barely visible and are easily missed if you are just passing through. I don't like having to wait for a table, wait for my pizza, only to have the pizza be totally run of the mill. The nice service and good draft beer selection did a little to ease this, but I really can't see myself going back on my own accord.

Paxis Chicago Pizza knocks this place out of the water for deep dish!
author: Alex D.

description: Darn it! I was very excited to come here, was willing to wait for a table, and it was worth the wait, but the pizza was still not dramatically great. It was good, A-OK...the service was wonderful and the people were sooooo nice. But for the price and the expectation, I was let down. I had the Little Star, which is one of their menu options. I also had a champagne cocktail, ginger to be exact. It was good. The beer selection is limited but each beer is a really good one. The bar has 5 seats. Ugh...Zachary's, I'm sorry I cheated on you since someone said Little Star was better. The grass was not greener. Please take me back. I promise it will never happen again, until the next time.
author: Maybe Milan B.

description:
Mmmm....tasty.....

Came here on a Friday evening a little after 8pm with a friend.  For a table for two the wait was expected to be about 30 minutes.  I was really hungry so I was disappointed but my friend and I had a lot of catching up to do so it wasn't a big deal.

Service: The host allows people to order before getting a table so that the pizza can be ready by the time you get a table. Genius!  We didn't actually have to do this, but the girls waiting next to us got that option (we got a table soon after we saw this happen).

Once we sat down, we ordered and basically the waitress didn't really stop by after that.  It wasn't really a problem, but I suppose it would have been nice if she asked if I wanted another drink.  She was a very pleasant waitress, just a little more attention to our table would have been nice.

Food: Yummy!  There's not much else to say.  The 2 of us ordered 1 large Little Star pizza since she's a vegetarian.  We both had 2 slices and were stuffed full, leaving us 4 slices total to take home. woohoo!

I'll def. stop by again to try different types of their pizza.
author: Naoko M.

description: It was great!! I went with two other people and the each order a different small pizza so we could try some different stuff. We got the chicken mediteranian, and classic Italian both on thin crust and the deep dish little star (suggest pizza). My favorite was the classic italian. I prefer thin crust usually, but the deep dish was great too....there wasn't that much crust it was all toppings. Yummy! The crust and the fresh ingredents have this pizza special. You'll have to add it to your list of places to try next time you are in SF.
author: Tracy B.

description:
Guess I'll get on the bandwagon.  I sort of had it in for these guys before I got to try it this week ... terrible lines and awful parking had thwarted numerous attempts to try this place and the hype was starting to get to me.  

But the stars were aligned this night:  parking RIGHT out front as we happened to be driving by and immediate seating (note to self:  go on a Monday night again).  

Ok, so they're kinda doing the pizza thing that is all the rage and they've clearly been influenced by the hip/tough/goodlooking waitstaff vibe of Delfina, but it's all GOOD as the pizza is indeed fantastic (I didn't even have the deep dish and I didn't even have tomato sauce!!).  The wines were well priced and the salad was one of the best I've had in a long long time.  Perfectly clean, crisp and fresh greens, wonderfuly ripe tomatoes, and no skimping on the quantity.  

Finally, they can't seem to do wrong with their jukebox selection.
author: Jenn S.

description:
Pizza has got to be my favorite food in the world. I like Thai, Pho, and Japanese, but pizza I think I can eat everyday. Since I last went to Chicago in 2001 and ate a REAL deep dish pizza, I've been looking for something comparable outside of the city. Most deep dish pizzas are not Chicago style, which consists of high wall crusts, thick bottoms, and SAUCE ON TOP of the cheese and toppings. Pizza Hut tried to put out a Chicago style deep dish and let me say, it was probably the worst pizza I've ever tasted.
