But they did put the sauce on top (well actually, they brought you a bowl of sauce you had to put on your pizza yourself for some reason). 

Finally, a place outside of Chicago that sells deep dish pizza! Almost as good as the real thing, the bottom part isn't as thick as it should be. I don't know why anyone would get thin crust here since you can get that anywhere in the city. The pizza was really really really good.

I would have given Little Star Pizza five stars, but when me and jess l. ate there, we ordered garlic bread, but what we got was a loaf of bread, a small tub of butter and a roasted garlic. We were very perplexed. It was a do it yourself garlic bread loaf, and for $4, I expect that it should not have been.

It's also way too dark in there with all this red lighting that makes me feel kinda gross since it's not like I was on some romantic evening out. It also made my eyes hurt to try and read the menu in such bad light. I think next time we're taking out. Though they have a pretty good jukebox.
author: Aaron M.

description:
There's very little to say about this place that hasn't already been said, but to add to the fire... The deep dish pizza is fantastic - I recommend the mediterranean, minus green olives (no one likes olives).

The atomsphere is cool/dark/mysterious/tragic-sexy, the jukebox has a nice collection (including some Springsteen) and the waiting couches are noteably uncomfortable - which is, somehow, quite awesome. 

Last time I was there, I was unquestionably the least hip person in a 100 ft radius. Everybody surrounding me had at a minimum 4 factorial  more tattoes and piercings than myself. The hostess had to look up from the Lord of the Flies in hardcover to seat us. Awesome. Additionally, this is one of the few hipster joints I've found where people don't seem to judge you negatively simply because you weren't at the last Critical Mass bicycle rally or Scissor Sister's CD release party.
author: Tom C.

description:
So we had to wait 30 minutes on a Sunday night.  It was well worth it.  It's not cheap either, but again, well worth it.

We started with the garlic bread appetizer - i Love do-it-yourself food! grilled sourdough bread, smooth buttery mix, and fresh roasted garlic cloves to spread.

then we ordered the Mediterranean chicken pizza and a pepperoni and mushroom pizza.  Both were SO good.  the chicken one was my personal favorite but both were tasty.

hot, smothered in cheese and sauce, the crust is to die for.

worth the parking nightmare, the wait, and the price...
author: Lauren V.

description:
Ok so the wait is long, but for fantastic deep dish pizza at great prices, why wouldn't it be. They don't do reservations so we waited about an hour for a table of 9 on a Saturday night. 

The pizza's were excellent! The hit with our table was the thin crust White Pie pizza (Garlic olive oil, mozzarella, zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta). I really enjoyed the Classic Deep Dish (Sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions).

The service was fantastic!! It was a little odd when we got there because there was no host for about a solid 3 minutes. Which when you get to a place you feel slightly odd just standing there wondering what to do. Once the host got there, he was nothing but polite and real about our wait time (I hate when they say 20 minutes and it's more like 45)! Our waiter was great and very helpful with helping us decide on some of the different beers they have on tap. 

All in all a great place!! I will definitely venture back here!

P.s. If you're reading this and wanted to grab a deep dish pizza in the East Bay check out Zachery's in Berkeley. They've got AMAZING deep dish's as well.
author: Rana A.

description:
I've been subjected to going to Zachary's for a a while now since I live in the East bay. Co-workers told me about this place, and simply put, Little Star beats Zachary's hands down. Took a while to get a table, but once we did, it was great. Polite servers, energetic atmosphere, and amazing pizza. I rarely use that word, but this is one time that warrants it. 

For those complaining about wait times for pizza...get used to it, that's the way Chicago-style pizzas are, unless you want a chunk of gooey dough on your plate. Not nearly as insane inside as Zachary's in Berkeley, and the menu has tons of opportunities to be creative. To me, it's all about the tomato sauce, and this place has it down, no doubt about it. Don't change it on me!!

garlic bread was incredible too...a must-have appetizer if you can stomach all that bread forthcoming.

Had no idea there were two of them...good to know, in case I'm in that neck of the woods. Definitely a go-to spot, and I will absolutely be going back.

Only downside to the place is the cash-only policy...not a big fan of that, but I'm not docking stars like Star Search for it, because there's an ATM with a mere 25-cent service fee inside!
author: Jory M.

description:
I do believe that Little Star has done an about face and has gone Delfina on us. Often times when a little known spot gains popularity and is highly acclaimed it goes straight to their head. This in my opinion happened with Delfina and appears that Little Star has followed along down the same road.

The pizza is still above average, but the staff makes one feel like you are "lucky to just be eating here".  Which is how I am made to feel every time I have dinner at Delfina. 

Well anyway, enough about Delfina and lets stick to Little Star. To me the service can make or break your experience and in the past Little Star performed well. But my past few visits, I am greeted with a surly attitude and made to feel like I am simply not too cool enough to enter the place. 

I know this is not any fault of the restaurant nor can they control it either, but the couple making out while I was trying to make my way through our deep-dish did not help matters.

Was last night my last visit to Little Star? Despite the lovely couple making happy and ignoring their pie probably will not keep me away. I just will no longer be excited about my future visits.
author: Anne J.

description:
I would give this place 4.5 stars. 

Usually if I'm feeling like pizza in the city, I would head to Seniores Pizza. However, a friend of mine took me to Little Star this past weekend and WOW! I didn't know pizza could taste so good! We had the usual pepperoni, sausage, and mushroom deep dish pizza. I think our eyes were bigger than our stomachs cuz we ordered a large and ended only finishing about a quarter of it.

The only compliant I had about the place is that its very dark, otherwise great atmosphere for a place to chill after work and get some food.

P.S
The pizza still tastes great the next day!
author: Andrew C.

description: Great deep dish pizza that has the sauce on top and uses a corn meal blend for their bread
author: Danny C.

description:
In the end, pizza is always going to be good. The cononation from 1,000 plus reviews with a 4.5 star rating is that Little Star walks on water and will eventually lead its people to the promise land after 40 days and 40 nights in the desert (yeah, I know I just  mixed Jesus and Moses, sorry about that). I'm not sure I agree with that notion, but I will admit Little Star is a pretty good pizza.

There was a wait when we went, but the line moves very quickly. A 40 minute wait lasted maybe 15 minutes tops. In the end, most people got fed up and just ate at the bar, and tables opened up in bunches.

You can really taste that the place uses fresh, high quality ingredients. The garlic bread appetizer was earth moving, and you've got to love the fact that instead of putting garlic on bread they bring out a head of roasted garlic with bread and butter. Our entrees were a deep dish Little Star and a thin crust chicken with pepper pizza. Two mediums fed four people with left overs. The pizzas were good, but it kind of reminded me of a later Pearl Jam album in that it was trying a little too hard for perfection. A great pizza is more about how the taste of the ingredients meld together into one unt, though (I can't believe I'm waxing philosophical about pizza).

There's a lot of debate over who has the best deep dish in the Bay Area--Zachary's or Little Star. For my money, it's none of the above (Old Chicago Pizza in Petaluma still holds the title, IMHO). But if I'm in the City, and I want pizza, Little Star will probably be my choice.
author: Joey J.

description:
It's pretty easy to miss this little place. We actually drove by 3 times looking for parking and were still unable to locate where little star was. That was until I actually spotted a "little star" and I got a little peek inside the restaurant. Place seemed a bit like those shady night clubs where they open a little slit and ask you for a password before you come in. Just my opinion. 

We found parking a lot easier than we were anticipating which was good because SF street parking could be a little B. We got in, the restaurant seemed to be lit only by natural sunlight haha. Not super crowded on a Thursday evening. We were promptly seated and then ordered of course the deep dish pizza and an order of spicy chicken wings. The deep dish was a bit disappointing...I guess that's what happens when things are hyped up. I was expecting some sort of fiesta in my mouth but it never came. The chicken wings were actually pretty good. Pizza on the otherhand, could have been better. I think the sauce was a bit too tart for my taste and needed more of a marinara zing to it. The pie itself did look very appetizing. Maybe a different combination would have made a difference? Prices aren't to die for either. Pretty reasonable. I don't think the pizza is good enough for me to crave in the future though.

3.5 stars
author: Stine H.

description:
If you don't know bout Little Star, you should.  Best deep dish Pizza in the city.  Worth any wait, worth any bus, worth any burns you might sustain from eating too fast.  

They've got a cornmeal crust that beats out Zachary's in Berkeley any day.  I know, dem fightin' words, but have you tried Little Star?  Then shut up.

Also, hot tip for locals not in the know: $0.25 charge on ATM withdraws.  Finally an establishment that's not trying to scam you by accessing your own money.
author: Alex P.

description: As a lifelong deep dish fan this is the best there is. My fiancé has been Zachary's fan for years and this converted him. I love the signature pizza with spinach, but what makes it trump all is the cornmeal crust. I've had the best Chicago deep dish in Chicago and I mean no offense, but San Francisco and Little Star show chi-town how it's done.
author: Jessica H.

description:
great pizza, good service, and a cozy atmosphere. Great for a first/second date. We had the Italian Combo thin crust - muy delicious. Regardless of the warning from our server about long cooking times, the pizza arrived promptly. 

Pretty reasonable as well considering we had beer and a salad with our meal, about $15/head. A quick tip - one salad is definitely enough for two if you are ordering pizza as well.
author: Nikhil B.

description:
Only four stars because of the wait, and the dim lighting. 
I mean, don't get me wrong, I love the whole romantic lighting thing, but if you can't tell whether there is tomoto sauce in your date's teeth, then that is just way too dim.
Okay, on to the yummy pizza and beer: dig in, because it is super delicious and quite affordable. In a weird zone on divis. but close to other good areas, including my neighborhood, so I'll definitily be back. P.S. good salads with nuts on top.
author: Kyla L.

description:
Mmmm... Little Star. Their pizza is top notch. As an East Bay gal, I'd always gone to Zachary's, but since I started dating someone who lives a half a block from Little Star, I figured I should give it a go. After all, my friends had all been raving about how it's *better* than Zachary's. ("Sacrelige!") But, lo, it is better than Zachary's. Not by a huge amount, but man, something about that crust. It's so buttery and cornmeal-y and crunchy and delcious. Zachary's crust ain't got nothin' on it. And hey, my boyfriend who is a recent ex-Chicagoan says that it comes close to being as good as the real thing--that's saying something, right?

As for the non-pizza items: Their salads are really tasty. Loaded with blue cheese, tomatoes, onions, mixed greens, and a delicious dressing. Got the garlic bread once--it's not for the lazy. They just give you a head of roasted garlic, a loaf of bread, and a container of butter. Yummy I guess, but not really the same thing as "garlic bread". We didn't eat most of it, because it took too much effort and we were ready to get crackin' on the pizza.

Can't say much about the service or the ambiance. Since it's so close by, we just call in an order to go and pick it up a 40 minutes later. It's always really crowded when we go to pick it up--I can't imagine having to wait for a table.
author: Heather H.

description:
To date, Little Star is the best pizza that I have found in SF.  I tend to be pretty picky about my pizza, and this place stacks up with the best of them.  With good quality toppings, mounds of cheese and sauce, and a flaky, corn-meal crust, these pizzas are excellent.  I tend to agree with everybody that the restaurant is pretty noisy and the service is just OK, but the pizza is just as good if you get take-out.  I'm anxious to try Zachary's now, having read so many good reviews.  

Oh and they do a nightly happy hour with $1 PBR's.  I forget exactly what time though....sorry.
author: matt c.

description:
Ingredients so fresh, so simple.
And cornbread crust on a pizza? WTF it's so good!
author: Yeeman N.

description:
I was craving deep dish pizza after seeing it on Food Network. I've never actually had Chicago style pizza before, so I wanted to find a place that people raved about. After a few searches on google, I wanted to try this place. 

It's hard trying to find parking and the wait is ridiculously long. I put my name on the list for three people and the wait was an hour. It's super dark and hot inside. So we decided to just take it to go. It was a better alternative than standing outside for an hour. 

As for food, the pizza was better than I expected. I ordered a Classic Deep Dish and it was SooOooOo good. I also ordered some chickens. Not the best chicken wings I've ever had, but pretty good still. I wish I would've gotten an order of the homemade cheesecake, but it was too much for me. 

Very friendly staff, but the place is too small. I would still recommend it.
author: Joy D.

description: For some strange reason they put a lot of cheese on the pizza last night. Disappointing..
author: Wailin L.

description:
I waited an hour to be seated here at Little Star. My first thought after sitting down: "this better be damn good pizza for me to wait that long." In fact, I don't think I've ever waited an hour for any restaurant no matter how good. 

Result: it was good but still not worth the wait. I strongly suggest take-out because the food is heavenly but the waiting game is not worth it. The decor and atmosphere don't warrent waiting.
author: R K.

description:
Kicks the crap out of Zachary's.  It actually bothers me how much people rave about Zachary's.  I'll admit I'm not a Chicago style pizza connoisseur, but I just don't think Zach's is that great.  The crust is way too dry, etc. etc...

Since this is about Little Star, let me go on.  The pizza is amazing and so are the chicken wings.  That's all I've had - I get the same thing everytime!  When my brother visits from out of town he insists we go to two restaurants - Little Star and Burma Superstar... I'm happy to oblige.  

Parking sucks and there's always a line.  But its worth it.
author: Marc L.

description:
I went in expecting great pizza, thanks to my fellow yelpers' helpful reviews, and I was not disappointed.  The Little Star deep dish did not disappoint!

What I didn't expect was how much I'd love the mixed green salad.  It was the perfect complement.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Damn good Chicago-style deep-dish pizza!

Minus one star for not doing half-baked takeouts.
author: Stephen B.

description:
I've never been a big pizza person, but there is something to be said about a pizza that is substantial enough to be an entire meal in one slice.  The only deep dish I'd had up till now is that oil-soaked monstrosity that one would get from Pizza Hut.  Well, slap me silly and call me crazy, but Little Star's pizza makes any other pizza I've had look miserable and underfed in comparison.  

DELICIOUS.
author: Max B.

description:
Well, my rave review is pretty redundant at this point, especially given that my in-house Chicago pizza expert already weighed in. But damn, this was good pizza. We had sausage, mushroom and olive deep dish. The crust had a great texture, light crunch with some bready heft behind it, the sauce was tasty, the sausage flavor kept coming back to me (in a pleasant way!) for the next few days and making me want more pizza.
The price was pretty much the same as I've seen at other places too for far inferior pizzas.
We played it smart, showed up early, didn't even have to wait-- but it filled up right behind us and there was a line by the time we were done eating. Possibly worth the wait, people.
author: Sara G.

description:
I tried Little Star Pizza for the first time tonight, and I may be a little biased, because we went there after biking for 6 hours in chilling grey fog, and all I could think about was how much I wanted deep dish pizza like Zachary's! I was also starving, so to me, even the sourdough (which you have to pay $4.50 for, but it comes with butter sauce and a whole roasted garlic) was like the best thing I ever tasted. And just earlier I was ranting about how I'm so sick of having sourdough at every SF restaurant.

So instead of just writing a review of Little Star, I'm presenting you with a play-by-play of how Zachary's and Little Star compare -- since the subject consumed a good part of my husband's and my dinner conversation! Now I KNOW some of you say that there's no point comparing Zachary's to Little Star, but you have to admit, it's pretty much inevitable -- and they really aren't THAT different pizza-wise, except for the crust! They LOOK identical and are priced VERY similarly!

We got Little Star's parallel to our Zachary's favorite -- Spinach and Mushroom -- so it was pretty easy to start drawing comparisons!

So here goes...

WAITING:
(wait times were comparable -- close to an hour during peak time)
LS - Had a nice couch and a bar where you can order drinks and appetizers while you wait. For a 45-minute wait, didn't feel very crowded.
ZP - People stand in line inside and out and crowd around the counter. You can go for a walk around Rockridge though which is nice.

PRICE:
LS - $18/9" and $23/12" -- small is still more than enough for 2! That's about 3, 1.5"-thick slices a person!
ZP - $18/10" and $23/12" plus they have 14"

SAUCE/TOMATOES:
Both are very similar and perfect in my opinion. Little Star maybe tastes a little more savory -- almost roasted. The mozzerella was chewy and delicious and comparable as well.

FILLINGS:
LS - More generous with the spinach and mushrooms. But we paid $1.50 to add sun-dried tomatoes, and there was seriously about 1 sun-dried tomato per slice. Sad, because they were good... and sad, cause we paid for them!
ZP - More generous with the tomatoes -- and maybe they go a little overboard. It's more like tomato pizza than spinach/mushroom pizza. The toppings are more mixed, which may affect my perceptions.

CRUST: (THE BIG DIFFERENCE)
LS - Buttery, cornbread crust -- like a pan pizza. Crispy and porous, not doughy or chewy. Delicious flavor and crunchy cornbread texture. Nothing like typical pizzas or Zachary's. Apparently this is more like "real Chicago pizza."
ZP - Chewy crust that's more like traditional pizza crust but kind of flaky/layered like baklava or pie. When it's fresh, it's almost too crispy on the bottom and hurts my sensitive teeth, but when it's leftover and a little chewier, it's PERFECT and JUST like crust I had in Italy. Features BONUS soggy (in a good way) crust layer between the toppings and tomatoes. This is my favorite part about Zachary's, so I missed that at Little Star.

ATMOSPHERE:
LS - Featured 100% San Francisco hipsters. The loud, hip atmosphere and dim mood lighting aligned perfectly with the crowd. Our first reaction was, man, it's dark in here. It felt like a club.
ZP - A bit more "Berkeley" -- earthy and artsy and diverse. Not overly-polished or slick. Features pizza-shaped art. More bright and sunny.

OVERALL:
If you're craving deep-dish pizza, it's good to know that satisfaction awaits, regardless of which side of the Bay you're on! Both are a bit expensive for pizza, but both are totally worth it.
author: Alexa A.

description:
This place has excellent deep dish pizza which is very corn breaddy in texture.  The walls are painted dark blue and purple, and the tabletops are black, giving the restaurant a trendy, clean vibe.  We came on a Wednesday night at around 6:15 and it was relatively empty.  However, after about 45 min, the place was pretty packed, especially for a weeknight.

We had the classic deep dish pizza (large) and the mixed green salad (small) which was more than enough for two people.  Yaay-- leftovers!!!

p.s. our server had pretty gangstaaa tats and stretchy earrings like Siddhartha

P.S. CASH ONLY YA'LL
author: Peter L.

description: Sorry to say but this place is hype! Maybe we ordered the wrong pizzas but I think I've had better frozen pizza :(
author: Monkey T.

description:
only the best damn deep dish this side of the mississippi.
their thin crust could use some work, but that's what defina is for.  and the fact that the beer selection and staff are great is a complete plus.
cheers.
author: kristopher y.

description:
OK Pizza, great drink selection, decent service, but they can't seem to wait to hustle you out the door. Their 'turn-and-burn' model is one of the reasons it doesn't take 45 minutes (or $30) to get a deep-dish pizza. Couldn't much tell the difference between the thin crust pizza and the deep-dish, except for the rim of extra crust and the pool of salty, warm tomato sauce on top of the deep-dish. 

You'll like it if:
You like to wait to be hurried.
author: Jabe N.

description: Delish! The deep dish is to die for. It's like corn bread and crust had a baby then put a yummy combination of goodies on top. The thin crust was really good as well.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Best pizza in the city.  I've had the deep-dish classic a few times, it can't be beat.  The crust is a-MAH-zing!  I don't know what's in it, but the crust has a great crumbly texture, kind of like graham or cornbread or something special.  The sauce has a lovely consistency that I just can't describe and the toppings are not too overwhelming but not skimped on either. 

Best to go at certain "off" times, like before 7PM or after 10PM or so.  When I arrived before 7 there were plenty of empty tables (weeknights) but by the time I left around 8:30 the place was packed and the line was about to overflow outside. I've had to wait an hour for a table in the past. It's best to keep this in mind and strategize your visit to maximize your experience; don't let the long wait and the crowds discourage you.
author: Christy I.

description: Mmmm.  I have never deep dish until now!! The deep dish is incredible! The line was out the door but we had called ours in, so, we just walked right in and picked it up.
author: Alicia V.

description: I love their salad and crust... especially the texture. deliciousness baked in an oven. Awesome date place also and great service. could get super busy so call in or reserve early.
author: A L.

description: I went with a group of 8 people on Sat at 6 pm and got seated pretty quickly.  We JUST beat the dinner rush.  We ordered salad and chicken wing appetizers and pesto thin crust and Mediterranean chicken deep dish pizzas.  This was the perfect amount of food for us.  Pizzas were great all around and I thought the slightly spicy wings were delicious.  I'm mostly writing about the ginger/champagne cocktail.  It was so good - it was very tasty and gave me a pretty good buzz before I even realized it.  The seating was bit tight and it's little loud, but great service and atmosphere.
author: CM P.

description: Because I would give Zachary's in Oakland/San Ramon 5 stars based on their superiority to even native Chicago Deep Dish (I've done the analysis folks) it makes it so that I can give this a 4 star rating because I would come back...but it is maybe closer to a 3.5 but since I'm bullish on Zachary's...no reason to be stingy.  It's a cool spot but a little off the beaten path but I happened upon this place only once so far and hope to be back.
author: Steven G.

description:
love it here.  pizza is exactly how my friends talked it up to be.  i was genuinely surprised that the reverse topping thing (sauce on top, cheese and other stuff underneath) was a pretty neat way to eat it.  don't get me wrong - i'm not super naive when it comes to food, but i wasn't huge on pizza growing up.

our server was good - a bit distracted but definitely worked it out for our table of six on a friday night.

i'll have to check out the one by my new digs - apparently they have one in the east bay!!

good stuff little star!
author: Lily G.

description:
My girlfriend said to me, "you haven't tried Little Stars yet!!?? It's so much better than Zachery's!!" So the next time we went out for dinner...Little Stars is where we headed.
The wait was about 40 minutes, so worth it by the way! Half way during our wait they let us order so that by the time we sat down...here comes our food. We ordered the Mix Salad, good. Garlic bread, even better!!! Who on earth would serve a head of roasted garlic, melted butter with warm sour dough bread, all aranged on a plate for you to make your own piece??!!! Little Stars does!! 
OMG!! I LOVE their pizza, we got the deep dish CLASSIC. All I have to say is, whenever I'm in the mood for pizza this is where I request for dinner. You have to try it, if you're a fan of Zachery's, you'll love Little Stars even more!!
author: Vi N.

description:
Little Star Pizza was one of the shining stars of my hubster's B-day weekend in SF!  

I salivate as I remember the crispy cornmeal crust and melt in your mouth cheesy spinach center covered in fresh crushed tomato marinara goodness.   We had the Chicago Style and it was truly an amazing pie!

We picked this up and it was the base to an incredibly fun evening in celebrating with friends and helped to soak up the many bottles of wine we drank that lead to a strobe light coming out and our own private rave!
author: Nicki W.

description: 5 Stars. I'm a Chicagoan. 'Nuff said. (This is my fave Chicago Pizza in SF. Specifically, they got the crust right, the cheese is stringily delish, the sauce is perfecto)
author: Phillip O.

description: Take my Chicago card but I must say I'm digging Little Star's Brass Monkey pizza!  Thanks LSP for giving a Chicago transplant a go to place when I need my real pizza fix.
author: Ritchey R.

description:
Little Star pizza serves great deep dish pizza in a great location. The room is dark, with local artwork on the walls. Our server was friendly and knowledgeable. When she saw us panting at the pizza being delivered to another table, she assured us that our pie was next. Haven't heard anyone mention how great the house salad tastes: greens, nice vinaigrette, gorgonzola, walnuts, red peppers. It was the perfect appetizer. We ordered their Little Star combination and added pepperoni. The jukebox had a varied selection of indie and classic rock. Their wine and beer list is varied and reasonable. There was a Marina guy outside in a suit on his cellphone, but if you're going to let that keep you from enjoying pizza, then you should bring that sort of thing up with your therapist.

n.b.: I've just been informed that the guy in a suit on his cellphone is not a Marina guy, but a fellow yelp member. Duly noted.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I'm a pizza snob and this is my absolute favorite pizza joint. You can't go wrong with either the classic deep dish or the italian combo (on thin crust), depending on your mood. Service can be better though. Also, they only take cash, but they have an ATM machine that charges (if I remember correctly) $.25 per transaction.

BEST. PIZZA. EVER.
author: Joy L.

description: We visited the outlet in NOPA, which was packed on a Sunday night.  Despite the mob, the service was great and we ended up sitting at the bar.  We got the small standard deep dish.  It was good, but almost too much for us -- it's heavy.  I think I prefer the thin crust-style. That being said, I think it's a fun, cool place for SF pizza.
author: Andrew G.

description: Ordered the nine inch DeepDish classic. Perfect lunch for two. Delicious, and really satisfied my craving for deep dish. I'll be coming back soon.
author: Steve O.

description:
Our favorite pizza place in the city. It also helps when its just down the street too. I actually prefer getting their pizza to go....its just a great....and you get it way faster than if you were to sit down and wait for it to be made, even if there was no line.

My only complaint is that their tables are too small for the pizzas....they SERIOUSLY need to invest in those pizza hot pad trays like at Pizza Chicago where the pizza sits elevated off the table so there is table space.
author: K B.

description:
Extremely delicious pizza. Both the deep dish and the thin crust are great. Definitely rather expensive as far as pizza goes, but worth it in my opinion for sure. I can't legitimately comment on the atmosphere, as I've actually only carried out.

Minus 1 star for being cash only. I'm already pretty irritated with this strange cash only bar trend, but a cash only *restaurant*? To me, that is nothing short of ridiculous. And stupid. It's easy to spend a lot of money here, and I don't carry enough cash for that. More importantly, I don't want to have to carry that much cash. You're a real restaurant, with a bar, and you're not cheap. Suck it up and get a merchant account already.
author: Derek S.

description:
...i can't say that this is the best pizza around...but...if you've never had corn bread pizza, this is the place to go!

Pros:
-pizza still tastes good re-heated...i actually think it tastes better re-heated!
-cornbread crust...where else can you get this?!
-$0.25 ATM machine
-interesting decor

Cons:
-the wait
-hours of operation...they don't open until 5pm!
-and...the wait...maybe next time we'll do pick-up?
author: Nancy T.

description:
YUM YUM YUM! My favorite pizza in the city. Who knew pizza could be so good? :) 

Must try. Great pre-concert place because it's right by the Independent, has good (affordable) food, and a cool bar.
author: Han C.

description:
Little Star, Delfina, Golden Boy, Pizza Orgasmica...there are many pizza places in the city that word has it 'do not suck', because let's be honest, West Coast pizza sucks. That's right, I said it, and you should have known this already. Golden Boy is my favorite so far but after trying Little Star it's going to be my local favorite (the schlop on Lower Haight is only good for drunk eating).

Ambiance (4): Standard issue hipster-ish interior with low lights, mixture of wood and metal, and some art on the wall. Not complaining, it's good to go, just not what I expect of a pizza joint. 

Food (4): They are known for their deep dish but after going to Chicago a few times, I have sworn off deep dish pizza. It's just too much...too much! We had a thin crust with pancetta, goat cheese, chicken, and I don't remember what else (it had me at pancetta). It was pretty tasty and the crust was good and crisp. We ordered the smaller size since we were having wings too and it was just the right size. The chicken wings were not bad, but I haven't had a chicken wing that doesn't remind me of microwaveable buffalo wings since Sports Grill (new English rule: double negative bad, triple negative good). This might be related to the wings not being grilled, which is my preferred wing preparation method. In terms of drinks, I appreciate that they have tempranillo and malbec in stock in addition to the usual suspects, so if you like red wine, they are bound to have something that appeals to your tastes. Of course they have beer and white wine too. Also the 10 dollar corkage fee is appreciated.

Service (4): Great, friendly service. The timing of the dishes arriving was perfect and I don't know if it's coincidence or the server putting in the order in a certain way or us eating at just the right rate. Anyway, I felt welcomed and being taken care of without the incessant and forced niceties of some fancy restaurants (I am looking at you Gary Danko). There always seems to be a wait to get a table though, but what can you do when the place has good foodie cred?

Value (4): The prices of all menu items seemed just right. That includes the cost of drinks and I already mentioned the corkage fee.

Overall: I liked this place but did not love it like I do Golden Boy. The quality is good and the flavors were good but just not amazing. However, this the best option in my area, so next time take out will be the way to go to avoid the wait. Oh and if you have a deep dish craving, this is one of the few places in the city that I have spotted it so far.
author: Alvaro H.

description:
Keep your pants on. It's just pizza. And I love pizza as much as anyone. It's the only reason I'm not a vegan. Yes the pizza is good, but I just don't understand the hype.
The crust is definately better at Zachary's, and if I didn't have to cross a bridge to get there I'd never eat at Little Star.
Pluses include good pizza, maybe the best jukebox selection in the City.
Minuses include the wait for pizza and the wait for a table and the possibility that if you drive it will take an hour to find parking.
author: Jason D.

description:
Their deep dish pizza is good, but certainly not the best.  I enjoyed their corn bread crust.  I liked how it crumbled and melted in my mouth.  But, having been to a place like Zachary's Pizza--there is NO WAY Little Star gets my vote as the best deep dish pizza.   The pizza itself is good, but I don't think I'll be returning to the restaurant.  

The service is horrible and the ambiance of the place...well, sucks.   The staff is rude and don't really care if you get your food, drinks or silverware.  The place has horrible lighting.  The restaurant begs to be cool, and unfortunately, most of the people there (at least the night we went) were begging to be cool as well.  Too bad neither were succeeding. 

I would expect a place like this in the middle of Melrose, but in the middle of San Francisco?!   I'd rather BART to Berkeley and enjoy my deep dish pizza in the middle of my old college town.

The best word to descibe the place:  pretentious.
author: Jaymee C.

description: Very nice experience. We got the garlic bread and caprice salad as an appetizer to start and they were delicious. Our main course was a cheese pizza that we added some toppings to and it was amazing. The service was great and the atmosphere was really nice.
author: Joe B.

description:
I dreamt last night I was a little star pizza. Everybody loved me. They looked at me and they began to drool. I was yummy to them. I felt powerful, just like a little star - like the Sun's little brother.

Of course i had a little Star Pizza a week ago and it has owned me ever since.
author: BirminghamBill S.

description:
Good but not amazing.  Had the thin crust veggie and deep dish Mediterranean Chicken and while both were yummy, I didn't think they merited all the praise that people heap on LSP.  In my opinion, the thin crust wasn't really thin crust - I was expecting Neapolitan-thin, which this wasn't.  And maybe I'm a Chicago deep dish traditionalist, but I didn't think the corn bread crust was so great.

But it's still good, of course.  Misaligned expectations strike again.  It's super loud inside, parking sucks, and the wait can get really long ... good thing there are decently priced glasses of wine at the bar while you wait.  :)
author: Melinda C.

description: Best Combo at Little Star: 1/2 brass monkey, 1/2 Mediterranean chicken.  If you don't think this is the best deep dish pizza EVER, I will fight you.
author: William S.

description: I'm too full to write much. Very good pizza. Not the best Chicago style I've ever had, but far from the worst. I prefer the to-die-for flaky, buttery crust that is more commonplace in Chicago, but would definitely not turn down an invite to go here again. Okay, I need to go lie down now.
author: Laurie A.

description: This is different than deep-dish pizza in Chicago.  Having slogged through three years of pizza in the Windy City, I can say that's a good thing.  At Little Star, it's a VERY good thing.  Amazing pizza with superb sauce, veggies, meat, and somehow it avoids being overly greasy or heavy.  So excited to have this down the street from us.  We'll have to try the thin crust one of these days, if we can bring ourselves to skip the deep-dish...
author: Brendan K.

description: Okay... so everyone yelps about the magnificent deep dish pizza here... but what about the thin crust pizza? Delicious! I do want to add that a bottle of wine here is pretty dirt cheap and the selection is not bad at all. They have a Washington Cab and a decent Tempranillo on their list of wines along with other varietals. There's no reservations here... so on busier nights like Thurs-Sun... be prepared to wait.
author: Sarina U.

description:
Word.  What a find.  I am a pizza whore and quite frankly I have little willpower when I come face to face with the saucy seductress known as the pizza pie.

Even when I have the one night stands with the coyote ugly pizzas I don't have really any remorse.  Sure, I'd like to be picky in theory...but really, a bad pizza is still good to me.  I could easily eat it every meal.  However, when I come across a good pizza I become absolutely smitten.

Ahhh, Little Star.  You have damn good pizzas...thank you.  You have damn good apps...thank you.  You have damn good cheesecake...thank you.  You even have a decent little beer selection as well as $10 corkage....thanks again.  You are only 10 minutes away by foot....how sweet of you.

You're pretty busy I know but to get some personal time with you I'll wait...you're worth it.

I'll see you soon Little Star.
author: Chris D.

description:
Had the Caprese salad and the Vegetarian Deep Dish.  Salad doesn't factor into my score because this is a pizza joint. The salad was good (the olives and tomatoes were good but the mozzarella was nothing special so I probably wouldn't order it again).

I can't understand how anyone could review this place after having just their thin crust.  It's pretty obvious that they specialize in deep dish and I am surprised by the people who review this place with utter conviction without talking about the deep dish. That being said, I'm more of a fan of Italian style pizza--no, not quite NY, I like it rustic, fresh, simple, and crisp.

If you like deep dish you will probably like the zza here. It's got a great crust--can't really describe it. It is cornmealy but it's not like cornbread. It's buttery but it's not like pie crust. It's the kind of crust that I wouldn't like for anything but deep-dish pizza.

The fillings are also good--fresh veggies and springy cheese topped with a hearty and acidic tomato sauce. So it's the best deep dish I've had and the price was reasonable.

The only reason I can't give it 5 stars is because I still don't get deep-dish.
author: Shawn T.

description: Excellent pizza, period. Long waits at times but worth it.
author: Kathleen A.

description:
168 reviews or not, it ain't New York pizza.  It ain't worth waiting in line for.  And it's not just because THEY LEFT OUT THE MUSHROOMS.  

On second thought, it is.
author: ed y.

description:
In the tradition of damn-fine-pizza, Little Star delivers.
If you like Pauline's, you will certainly like this place.  Definitely go for the deep dish for your first time to experience the tasty tomato goodness.

One thing, the jukebox has a little bit too much music made for and/or by white people... but if you bring a few extra bucks for it you can pick the songs you like for the whole evening.
author: Chris M.

description:
First off, don't order a large for 2 people.  We had 2 1/2 slices between us before we threw up the white flag!  The other slices fed a family of 3 and a cousin.  

The ingredients were fresh and this is a deep dish that isn't baked in oil.  They also do a great caprese salad.    My only disappointment was the sausage tasted like meatloaf and need more flavor.  

Little Star is almost always crowded, but they do to go and remember CASH ONLY!
author: Jason A.

description:
Weds night: 6/14/06 -- Longest. Wait. Ever. 1 hour and 45 minutes! But I'm giving Little Star 4 stars anywhere for having the nicest staff and the tastiest Chicago-style pizza on this side of the Bay.   

Haven't quite decided whether it's better than Zach's but I definitely prefer the atmosphere, droolworthy deep-dish crust & salads over Patxi's.
author: Claudine C.

description:
Asking me to choose between Little Star and Zachary's is like asking a mother to choose between her two children.  While both of them have their similarities, they each have distinct differences that make me love both of them equally.

Similarities:
1)They both serve wonderfully delicious deep dish pizza. (Obviously).

2)Both restaurants are CASH only operations.  Be sure to make an ATM stop before going to either.
UPDATE: Zachary's now takes plastic.

3)No reservations are taken at either place, so be prepared for a wait.

Differences:
1)  The crust-Little Star's crust is corn meal based which is more traditional with Chicago-style pizza.  The crust is crisper than Zachary's layered crust.  

2)Accessibility-Zachary's is more accessible to the public as the Rockridge location is a short walk from BART.  Also free parking (after 6pm) is available at the BART station.  Parking can be difficult in the Western Addition.  Plus, no pay-lots are nearby.

3)Ambiance-Zachary's is well lit and family friendly.  Little Star reminds me of a bar with its dimly lit dining room, jukebox, and echoing din of the crowd in the dining room.

4)Leftovers-Zachary's holds up better the next day than Little Star.  Trust me.  I did a side by side taste test.  I heated both in the oven and Zachary's pie tasted just as fresh as the night before.  The same cannot be said for Little Star.
author: mandy f.

description: I was a bit tempted to give 2-stars but will keep it at 3 for now and give the joint another go ... For a Wednesday, the place was surprisingly busy so we decided to get 2 pizzas to go.  I don't eat red meat and the fellas I was out with are all good sports so we got 2 thin crust basil & olives.  The sauce was good and the toppings were fine but the crust was like eating a pizza on flatbread.  It might just be I'm used to a bit doughier crust but after all the talk, I was kind of underwhelmed.  The chicken wings we got as a starter were fine, cooked well but no zip to them (although that might have just been because my friend ordered them that way).  On a positive note, the guy at the front counter (checking diners in) was great as was the gal handling the money.  I'd be willing to give the place another shot ...
author: Jessica G.

description: I don't know how to say this, but another year goes by and Little Star still manages to be a transcendent experience. The best pizza - deep dish or otherwise - I've had on this coast.
author: Brandon B.

description:
First let me say that I have always been a fan of little star and have eaten there many times. I actually prefer it to Zachary's, Giordano's, and other deep dish styles I have tried in Chicago. But I had the funniest experience last time at Little Star that I have to share...

So not a busy night so there appears to be one or two servers covering the dining room. I just want to charge my bill to my card and my waiter appears busy so I signal the hostess who is walking by. She actually looks straight forward and pushes my hand out of the way. 

Okay fine so I see there is someone behind the bar next to the cash register so I ask if he can just charge my card. He responds that he is manning the takeout station so I'll have to wait for my waiter.

Ten minutes go by and my waiter hasn't come to my table. But I notice that the guy behind the bar and the hostess are both sitting around doing nothing. So I stare at the guy behind the bar. He nervously notices I am watching him. He moves side to side. He takes one step to the side, lifts up the fold down section of the bar. Hides behind it so my view is obscured. Looks over to see that I'm still staring at him, and moves back so I can't see him. Still doing nothing. Not helping any customers. Not cleaning the bar. Not pouring any drinks. Just looking too cool for school and not wanting to be helpful in any way, or even signal my waiter.

Waiter comes 10 minutes later. I tip him generously because he was busy and helpful. Too bad the staff probably pools the tips so it went to the useless hostess and cashier too.

I am not from this country so it still shocks me that staff in many American restaurants refuse to help customers at other tables that they are not serving directly.
author: Lorenzo C.

description:
the crust, the crust, the crust is buttery cornalicious. The sauce is very good but zachs has them on the sauce. Over all I would say Little star and Zachs a tie for food.

For service Little star rocks. I was treated like a rock star by the friendly staff of Little Star. 

BTW no wait the evening i went
author: Ellis D.

description:
I don't think it's better than Zachary's ... but it's way closer. I think I do prefer the crust on little star ... mmm corn meal.

Thank god for the jukebox ... it's a nice addition to the place. Not really a fan of the dim lighting ... I prefer to see my food when I eat it.
author: Alex C.

description:
Huh?  Wha?  Why is this place reviewed so highly?  The pizza here tastes like cardboard!!  It's worse than supermarket pizza.  I can't understand why this place is sooo packed.  I waited about an hour to get a table figuring it must be damn good if it's this packed.  WRONG!

What the HELL are people thinking?  We ordered the thin crust pizza with a few toppings and it was tastless and disgusting.  YUCK.  The wings weren't good either.

God, I miss NY pizza!!!  I've tried a couple of different places now in SF and NOTHING compares to even an ok random pizza place in NYC.
author: C A.

description: WOW, this place is good.  Ordered the deep dish Mediterranean Chicken and the thin crust Italian Combo.  There was 5 of us and it filled us up perfectly!  Not a piece left over.  It was so good, they didn't even need to clean the pizza tray as my friend Larry Chu cleaned it off to a shine!  In the words of the Terminator...I WILL BE BACK!
author: Joseph C.

description: I'll keep it short since I already wrote a review for Little Star in Mission. Made a second trip to this Little Star, ordered the same thing as before: The Little Star w/added sausage, but made some adjustments this time. In my first review I'd noted that the sauce drowned out the rest of the flavors in the pizza, so this time around I asked for less tomato sauce and substituted the feta cheese for gorgonzola cheese...mm that's more like it, stretchy cheesy goodness and ingredients you could actually taste besides just tomato chunks!!
author: Mahsa K.

description:
Pizza review #2...

We shared a caprese salad which I thought needed more basil and a lot less oil and balsamic.  It was fresh and the tomatoes and fresh mozz were delicious.  

We had a small thin crust pizza with sausage, onion, and tomato.  Very tasty and a perfect size for two with the salad.  

The food was delicious and even better that we didn't have to wait for a table.  This place is uber popular right now and my only real complaint was feeling a bit rushed out and the initial slow service.  Once the wine did come out (11 minutes after ordering) everything was smooth.  Would probably take out next time.  Ambiance was fine, just don't need tablecloth / turn the table service when I'm out for pizza.

Visit #2 - Until this visit I hadn't eaten a deep dish pizza I'd order over any thin crust version.  Now, I DREAM about a deep dish Little Star.  Amazing.  The crust, the sauce, the toppings were incredible!  Trying to get a table however is a nightmare, borderline insulting.  If I get reminded that, "You need your ENTIRE party to be here, inside the door to be seated" I just may bypass their pizza altogether.........maybe not.  Come on!  Where in SF that is popular can you get seated without your entire party?  I don't really need the visible reminder nor the insulting barking from the hostess.  She actually threatened to not seat our party of 8 unless we made the 9:40 check-in time with our entire party.  Just a little TOO much.  For this, I take it down from 4 to 3 stars.  As if this really matters, the pizza kicks ass!
author: J P.

description:
Yum. The little star deep dish is my dream..but then again, so is the sausage and mushroom thin crust.

feed me seymore.
author: Amy J.

description:
Deep dish draws deep divisions among foodies -- especially those who have lived in or visited Chicago.  So, I put Little Star to the ultimate test: taking my Chicago native fiancee in for dinner with a couple of friends visiting from the Midwest.  Verdict?  It stood up favorably against Chicago strongholds like Giordano's.  

I think it's the cornmeal crust ... this nice, crispy but crumbly bottom layer that meshes beautifully with the melted cheese and sauce and toppings.  I'm a big fan of the classic dish (sausage, bell peppers, tomato), but really: everything is good.  Also, the garlic bread is worth killing for: half a loaf of sliced sourdough served with a dish of butter and several gooey roasted garlic cloves.  

There's usually a wait here, so plan accordingly. Thankfully, the bar has Racer 5 IPA on tap and a better-than-average wine selection to take the sting out (try the Malbec if you're into reds!) -- not to mention a killer jukebox.  Essentially, classic SF dive bar booze and music enthusiasm mixed with Italian bistro atmosphere.  Bonus: it's a block-and-a-half from The Independent, and so works great as a pre-show eatery.
author: Sean F.

description: Love it. The pizza is some of the best I've had and the prices are right on. It can be a little loud though.
author: Calvin W.

description: The buffalo wings are fantastic.  NON-FRIED, just enough spice, garlicky but won't give you garlic breath fantastic wings.
author: Wakako U.

description:
A yummy pizza joint with a very dark yuppy atmosphere.  You have to love the deep dish pizza, but to make it even yummier... get it to go!

A few of us agree that the pizza is worth waiting for, especially if you call in for a large "Little Star", pick it up 15 minutes later, and take it home with a bottle of red wine (you choose the wine).  Enjoy the company of your closest friends, favorite bottle, and the delicious pizza in a place where you can hear the conversation and see the food you are eating... at home.
author: Krankee C.

description:
I'm not gonna bore you with a long overly-endulged story where I go off on a tagent about my crazy experience at this pizzeria. 

One word: YUM
author: Morty P.

description:
It was a rainy and windy Sat. night yet all a girl could dream of was eating chicken wings! After countless attempts to eat at a few other joints (because little star had a 30 min wait), we ended up eating here anyway.  The wings,which all you yelpers claimed were very good, turned out to be unmemorable. I prefered by bf's deep dish pizza over the wings. Service was good and the dark lit interior was ideal for the stormy Sat night.

I would pay a visit again for the pizza only. The thin crust actually looked really good...
author: Julia V.

description:
OH MAH GAWD.

I waited AN HOUR AND A HALF for a two top on a Wednesday night.  there was a nice NOPA hipster parade going on, which is different than the standard Mission hipster parade - HOORAY for different thrift shops and koi tattoos instead of dragons.  As a city, are we really so divided that we have MICROCLIMATES as well as MICROCULTURE?  Can't we all just get along? 

Anyway, I wasn't that hungry when I walked in but after that long wait, I was ready for some killer pizza.  I had the Little Star deep dish and the house salad.  We got a large for 2 people and had four slices left over.  Delicious crust and ingredients.  Oh, and then we also ordered the homemade cheesecake because nothing tops off deep dish pizza better than deep dish cheesecake.  So effing good. 

The food absolutely rescued this dining experience.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
This is how I decide where I'm going to eat, or what I'm going to eat - I watch the Food Network.

I watched Top Chef and they had a Deep Dish challenge and suddenly I find myself looking for a place to get a deep dish pie.....gosh, I'm so impressionable. :)

I got the deep dish, and strangely it had the marinara sauce on top - how strange. It was good, but I didn't love it. I know so many people who absolutely love this place - I guess I just have different taste buds.

I went back this weekend and ordered the thin crust, and although it was good the crust is a little too thin and it soaks up all the liquid - maybe I'm being too hard on them because I have never heard of anything shy of a great review from them, but they just don't make my heart flutter.
author: Laura G.

description:
Deep dish = delicious. I grew up in Chicago and I wouldn't compare this to Chicago style deep dish. The crush - corn bread - is different but fantastic. Get the little star - when they name it after the restaurant, there's a reason, it's GOOD.

You can only pay in cash, though - that is kinda a bummer - it's also slightly more on the pricey end for pizza, but it's worth it.
author: linda t.

description: If you're in the NOPA district of San Francisco, there is no better place for pizza and a place to have fun with friends. If you're carb-free and fat-free foodie, you can't eat a whole slice because it's so filling, but yummmmm and SO worth the cheat! The wait is hours on some nights, but worth it and you can drink while you wait. It's within walking distance, or a few minute drive from most of the Victorian's in the NOPA vicinity. This place is also great for kids in the afternoon and early evening. My kids would eat breakfast here if they were open!
author: Esther P.

description:
Tonight, it is raining. Raining might be an understatement. It is blowing water sideways. And Little Star doesn't deliver. But my order will be ready in 30 minutes. And why, you ask, am I writing my review now when I haven't gotten my order? I guess it was one of those things that I meant to do. And I keep using Yelp as my personal phone book, so when I looked it up tonight to call in a phone order, I decided to finally write a review.

I love this place. They are worth walking in the rain for to retrieve dinner. Perfect crust and yummy sauce. Even a simple cheese pizza tastes like heaven on a pan.

A tip: Want to be the cool kid who orders something by name that is not on the menu? Order a brass monkey. It's the little star specialty pizza plus sausage, and it's the most popular pizza they serve.
author: cynthia c.

description:
The best deep dish pizza in the city that i can find. 

Very nice people work there as well. 

If thick pizza is what you crave, then this place will suit your fancy.
author: Jack C.

description:
What could I possibly say about Little Star that hasn't already been said? This place has won Best of the Bay- Pizza for at least the last 3 straight years. I went for my first time recently and was beyond impressed by everything except the décor. The place opens at 5pm, but since there was a big party that day, they had their door open at 4:30pm. As the party was walking in, I walked in and was seated immediately. None of this, "We aren't officially open, so you'll have to wait," crap you'd get at pretty much any other restaurant. I was very impressed by this.

The rest of the lunch/dinner went great. Even though there were at least 20 people in the big party, another table with 2 people, and then my 2 top, we were treated just the same as we would be if we were the only people in the restaurant. I think they only had 2 servers at the time, so again, impressive. I got the Little Star pizza because it's good to order the dish named after the restaurant and I'm not big on meat (spinach, feta, ricotta, mushrooms, onions, garlic). It was amazing. The crust was great and the tomatoes on top were so unbelievably fresh. I've been to Uno's in Chicago and I like Little Star better. Yeah, I said it. One thing I read in the comments was that the crust was buttery- I disagree. I thought the pizza crust was going to be like eating a croissant, but it wasn't. Just the cornmealy goodness you would expect. By the way, the pizza heats up great, too.

The only MINOR issue with the place is that black curtains cover the windows and walls. The bar looks good, but maybe something else can be done. In the evening, the sun shines right into the windows, so maybe the curtains are really necessary. Who cares. They have the best deep dish anywhere.
author: Jess H.

description:
Recently went here with family and was very happy with service and especially the food. We ordered the deep dish and 3 diff kinds and enjoyed every slice :).
The parking was the issue but thats a norm in this area.

I will definitely be back to Little Star soon :)
author: Jeffery S.

description:
LOVE, love, love this place. The deep dish pizzza (originally known as Chicago style dish) is so yummy with its corn based crust that i can never have enough of it. It's so good that I have to have it at least 1 or 2 a month to get my pizza fix.

Definately 5 stars!!!
author: Unique t.

description:
First off all let me start off by saying that the hype surrounding this place is well, and I mean well deserved.  Like other reviewers I too was a tad skeptical about some of the glowing reviews but my wife and I loved every bit of our experience.  

THE ATMOSPHERE:
The ambiance in Little Star is truly awesome as the staff is very down to earth and chill complete with hipster ear rings and tattoos.  The table we sat at was clean and overall the place was very well kept.

THE FOOD OOOOH THE FOOD
My wife and I had the 9" deep dish classic, the garlic bread, and roasted wings.  The first thing to arrive of course was the garlic bread and oh my what a sight it was to see.  I was happily surprised to see that the bread was soft and hot, as most places serve rather cold, crusty bread sharp enough to cut diamond.  Along with the bread was a side of pillow soft butter and a bulb, a mutha FRACKIN BULB MANG, of yummy roasted garlic that spread on the bread with absolute ease.  The hot hottie bread was followed up by hot, perfectly seasoned wings that had a tad bit of spice on them tempered by what tasted a like a creamy cool blue cream cheese ranch deep and cold crunchy carrots. The pièce de résistance of this visit by far was the deep dish.  The deep dish is simply a delight to eat with it's stringy gooey cheese, zesty tomato sauce and fresh and I mean FRESH veggies.  Every savory, hot and juicy bite made me want to eat more.  

OVERALL RECOMMENDATIONS:
Sanfranciscan and tourist alike should all try this place.  The prices are reasonable, the atmosphere is awesome and the food will make you do a happy dance.  Please keep in mind that we went early, like when they opened early so we had no trouble getting a table and got our food very fast, but should you go later in the evening this place is known for getting packed fast so if your starving get there at a reasonable time.
author: JiujitsuGrinds X.

description: If you are a New Yorker this pizza will suffice.  However you are better off going to Arinells if you really want the best slice.
author: Tom L.

description:
I ordered the classic deep dish pizza. Yes, its really good. Thick and crispy. But really take a while to get to pizza. I wait about 25mins.

Do go there when you r really hungry. otherwise you can order the thin crust~
author: Shenn L.

description:
Growing up in the east bay, I loved going to Zachary's pizza to get a nice deep-dish pie.  So after moving away, I felt a pizza-shaped void in my heart and belly - that is until my friend introduced me to a little pizza place around the block from my pad called Little Star.

Basically all you need do for this place is get a group of 4 friends and get one thin-crust and one deep-dish.  The thin and crispy slices go hand-in-hand with the thick and crunchy deep-dish pies.  My two favorites are the deep-dish "little star" and the thin-crust "white pie".  I'm not a vegetarian; however these pies are and the toppings on these pies complement each other perfectly as well as the particular crust they're on top of.

One drawback to this place, however, is that there is always a really, really long wait, so give your name to the host/hostess and get a brewski (or more) @ many of the bars on Divisadero.  Another thing that you could always do is to jump over to the Little Star in the Mission and get seated in half the time.
author: Denny H.

description:
Had a craving for deep dish pizza tonight and was looking for something as good as Viccolo. Went online and saw Little Star on 15th was nearby my friend's place so we went there. From the outside, it looked closed, like no one was there because the windows were darkly smoked. Luckily, we parked and went to the door as it was open. There was no wait and we got seated immediately.

We started with a mixed salad. This was probably one of the best mixed salads we'd ever eaten. I think we downed it in 5 minutes. The combination of dressing, feta cheese, and crushed nuts made it a really hearty salad.

We ordered a large Mediterranean Chicken Pizza which was actually too big for us to eat, but it was DELICIOUS! I luckily got to bring home the leftover pieces.

Total dinner: $35.26

Definitely will go back! Thanks Little Star!
author: JAMIE A.

description:
Guess who *doesn't* need another five-star review?

Little Star!

But I'm doing it anyway.

When people heard I'd never eaten at Little Star they seemed SHOCKED AND HORRIFIED that I could live in SF and *not* have eaten there. Well lemme tell ya -- it only occurs to me after spending some quality time at one of the bars across the street and those aren't the times when I'm willing to wait an hour for a table...especially when that crappy pizza place down the block will sell me a slice in five minutes.

So THAT'S why I'd never eaten at Little Star.

But then last week by homies and I were feeling peckish and they suggested we go across the street to Little Star. I was like KNOCK YOURSELVES OUT! I'm not leaving this bar stool just to go stand around and wait in a hot pizza joint for an hour.

But THEN I remembered that something at Little Star called the Brass Monkey is on 7x7's list of 100 things to eat in SF before you die:

http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

And I like crossing things off lists more than I like sitting at bars so we headed across the street, put our name on the list and spent the next hour trying to stand at the bar while also not annoying the crap out of the servers who were trying to work.

Our wait ended up being longer than expected, but everyone there was SO DARN NICE that it didn't matter. I had a lovely conversation with the bartender, Jessica, about getting her Ph.D and about how disappointed I was that none of the male patrons were hot and about snow globes from Austin.

The upside to waiting for a table is that you can pre-order your pizza with the hostess so that when you DO sit down, you don't have to wait too long. So we sat down, ordered some garlic bread (that was actually a loaf of bread served with a head of roasted garlic and a thing of butter) and ate our pizza.

My homies were a-okay with ordering the Brass Monkey so I could check it off my list and BOY HOWDY, we weren't disappointed. It turns out, the Brass Monkey isn't even on the menu (how In-n-Out of you, Little Star!), but if a sausage, spinach and feta pizza sounds like it would even remotely float your boat, I highly recommend it.

It's definitely knife-and-fork pizza -- not something you'd order to eat while watching the big game -- and I know that there's a big pizza debate raging on in the pizza world and that if you can't fold it up and eat it standing up, it's not real pizza, but whatever. It's damn fine.

The big downside: No seat covers or paper towels in the bathroom. I know that makes for a cleaner bathroom and all, but if I'm gonna eat, I want to wash my hands and NOT have to open the bathroom door without a protective layer of paper towel (or seat cover, if necessary) between me and the the germy door knob. 

Food for thought, Little Star.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Looking for a great Deep Dish pizza? Look no further.
author: Gonzalo M.

description:
I love their SF spin on the classic Chicago deep dish pizza. I came home from a Vegas trip and was in desperate need of hearty food. Ordered the Classic, added roasted garlic...grabbed it to go and enjoyed it with a nice sangiovese. The pizza crust was outstanding, seemed to have a bit o cornmeal throughout - loved that! The tomato and filling was delic. Cheese was spot on, but I should have asked for even more...just to add to the gluttony of it all. 
The staff were super friendly....and I need to go back for a happy hour session. 
Cash only.
author: Austin W.

description:
Pizza was mediocre.  The crust was good, and I enjoyed the corn meal on it.  The sauce was not so great and a little too chunky for my taste.  

The worst part about little start is the crowd and the service.  The people in the place were loud and really annoying.  The servers pants were so tight , there is no wonder why he was grumpy and unfriendly!   Get over yourself Litte Star, your pizza isnt that good, and your servers thnk they are too cool for school.
author: Vinny M.

description:
it's not chicago.
it's not zachary's.
though it's not that bad. i would definitely come back for some if i was in the hood & mood for deep dish pizza. 
once again, it's neither of the first 2 though it'll do for san francisco.
author: Madhu D.

description:
we decided to come here on a tuesday night. the wait was 15-20 minutes for a table so we opted to sit at the bar.  sometimes sitting at the bar is not bad at all.  you have one dedicated waiter right in front of you all the time!  haha ... he was super attentive.  kept asking us about water and drinks etc etc.

they actually offer thin crust pizzas as well but we just opted for the special of the day deep dish which was a meatball, red pepper, ricotta, spinach pizza.  it was good.  i havent had deep dish in a while and im no connoisseur by any means.  but it wasnt too heavy.  there was just the right amount of cheese, crust, sauce and topping.
author: claudia y.

description:
I love Little Star, I just wish they'd love me back by actually letting me eat there!

First off, the pizza is fabulous.  Though I get that some folks don't like deep dish, that's basically the whole reason for this pizza.  Unlike Zachery's it's not stuffed -- it's a more or less traditional Chicago style deep dish with a cornmeal crust.  In addition, the service is generally good and the atmosphere is pleasing, unlike a traditional pizza parlor.   

That said, it's long past time for Little Star to start taking reservations.  Their wait times at both restaurants regularly run more than an hour and there is very little room to wait.  On a recent Tuesday at 8:30 PM, we were told the wait time would be 1 and 1/2 hours.  That would have had us eating more than 2 hours later.  

It's actually painful to write this, since I've been a fan from the very start, I've been going there less and less.  Given the wait times and lack of waiting space, their unwillingness to take reservations shows a level of disregard for their customers that I find off-putting and rude.   

Little Star, I want to keep loving you, but my patience is running out.
author: Rose H.

description:
I generally go to the Valencia location, but I have recently come to the conclusion that Divis is better! The following things are all better than Valencia:

The pizza. Deep dish is way better here.

The service is quicker and less tudey.

The wait is shorter.

The noise level is much quieter. No exposed brick. 

The decor is cooler.

Other than that, parking is about the same. The price is the same. The menu and beer selection is the same. etc. For dine in Little Star, this is the spot.
author: Zac H.

description:
The pizza is very good, but you have to try the hot wings. They are not spicy as much as amazing. These lil things are marinated (very rare for hot wings), not vinegary, and accompanied by some great blue cheese sauce. 

due to the fact that little star is usually packed and deep dish, by nature, takes a while to bake, hot wings are a great appetizer for any hungry individual or group. 

I do agree that Zachery's has a slightly better deep dish, but you will get a better overall meal experience at little star, and not feel like you have 45 lb of whole milk mozzarella in your belly when you leave.
author: Jonah B.

description:
The first time you come here, you will be disappointed
with yourself
because it took you so damn long to come here.
author: A W.

description: Brilliant deep dish pizza.  The key is the cornmeal crust, which is firm and sweet.  It mixes well with many of their combinations.  Beware that 1-2 pieces will satiate the average person.
author: p w.

description: Five stars for the pizza!  Yum!!!  Could I deduct stars for the loud and unattractive ambiance? - Sure, but the pizza makes up for it!  I came in on a week day early evening and had no wait.  Will definitely be back!
author: Phoebe M.

description: It's been about 2 years since I've been to Zachary's so I can't actually remember whether I like Little Star or Zachary's better. That is a good thing. Unlike Zach's, the atmosphere is dim and intimate, so it would be a good setting for a casual date. If you want deep dish pizza in SF, this is the place to go...just make sure you bring cash.
author: Lainy C.

description: Once I discovered Little Star, there was 1 less reason to trek to east bay to visit friends.  No longer spend time, gas & bridge toll to eat at Zachary's with Little Star in SF.  Glad there are now 2 locations.  Take out makes it even easier & faster to enjoy.  Love the deep dish pizza with chunks of tomatoes.
author: Kim S.

description: If it were NY thin crusted pizza, it would get 5 stars.  Even though it's 1 star shy from perfection, Little Star shines the most with its deep dish pizza with rich and flavorful sauce.  All the Zachary fans on the peninsula don't have to drive to the outskirts of Berkeley anymore for Cihcago style pizza.  Patxi's is another chain that is up there above BJs and Chicago.  Twinkle twinkle little star, you beat Zachary's deep dish pzza by far!
author: Jenny L.

description: 5-star pizza with 3-star wine and 2-star logistics. Still, if you don't care about all the rest, this place makes excellent deep dish. Our veggie pizza was eye opening. We got the small and even got to take a piece home for breakie the next day. Will go again 4-sure.
author: Brian J.

description:
Pros: Fantastic deep-dish pizza, dark atmosphere, well priced

Cons: Slow service (but good enough for a pizza joint)
author: Jacob M.

description:
Service= very friendly and she was wicked cute

Food= having lived in new york and chicago i have been looking for a good pizza here in SF... i need look no further.

Atmosphere= average...tables are pretty close to eachother.

Homo factor= missionites.... a little bit of everything

Price= average

Hostess= friendly and happy considering it was crowded

Bathroom= clean but always a wait
author: Annmarie K.

description: Seriously some of the best pizza I've ever experienced anywhere. Ever. And we eat a lot of pizza. We had spent the day hiking at Muir Woods and were famished and were lured in by the positive reviews. Luckily we beat the rush and were seated quickly. There were four of us including two hungry teenagers. Our waiter was shocked by our Midwestern appetites and tried to talk us out of ordering two large pizzas. We went with one deep dish and one thin, both pepperoni and sausage. To our waiter's surprise we demolished every last bit. Deep dish pizza is one of my favorite things and this rivaled the best I've had in Chicago and outshone several of them. The crust was the perfect blend of crispy buttery-ness and pillow-y lightness. The sauce was well seasoned and complex without alienating the teenagers and the cheese was high quality and plentiful. This is high on our "must eat" list for our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Jessie S.

description: Long wait for mediocre pizza. SF has this weird duality obsession with both deep dish and thin crust. Very few places do either of them well. Lots of kids flailing about. Felt like Chuck-e-Cheese.
author: V. C.

description:
I'm not a big pizza fan but when I do have it and when it's good, I'm raving about it. 

Little Star Pizza is a little joint hidden from the street. You may walk right on by if you weren't looking for it. We came here on our 2nd night in town. Craving for some wholesome food, we found this place. 

It was a breezy night and we had given our names to the host. 1hr wait for a party of 6. Ouch! Well, we decide to wait outside, there wasn't much space inside for everyone, including other parties who were waiting. Yes, there's tons of people waiting to be seated here. Must be good huh?

Well, a little over an hour passes and we are finally seated. Whew! We immediately order a couple glasses of their house wine (red). Mmmmm! I love me a good buzz especially with Italian food. And we start off with some appetizers. We order (2) Garlic bread: warm sourdough bread, served with a blend of butter &amp; evoo and a bulb of roasted garlic ($4.50), (1) Caprese salad: fresh mozzarella served with slices of tomatoes, basil and drizzled with evoo and balsamic vinegar ($9.00) and (1) Mixed salad: mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, red bell peppers, red onions, gorgonzola cheese, chopped walnuts tossed with housemade vinegarette dressing ($6 small, $9 large). For our main dishes we decided on: (1) Large deep dish 12" Classic: sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions ($17 small, $22 large) and (1) Large deep dish 12" Little Star: spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions and garlic ($18 small, $23 large). The crust is made up of cornbread. You can taste the different layers of ingredients placed upon this badboy. From the crunchy crust, warm gooey cheese and the textured tomatoe which lay above it all. It was great! My overall experience with Little Star is one to be remembered and passed on. I'd recommend this place as long as you're ok to wait awhile. If not, call ahead and pick up for take-out.
author: Irma E.

description: Awesome gourmet little pizza place.  The ingredients were definitely high quality.  Highly recommend this place.  There is nothing else like it.
author: Laurin A.

description:
This is not Chicago-style pizza. This is not Chicago-style pizza. This is not Chicago-style pizza. 

I went to school in Chicago and the pizza here doesn't come close to Giordano's. 

It's fine and adequate and who knows, it may be the closest thing to Chicago style in San Francisco. But if you're hankering for true Chicago flavor you'll be disappointed. 

That said, I had great service at the bar and enjoyed talking to the bartender.

The no credit card policy is a pain, but to make up for it, they've got a bargain priced ATM - only a 25 cent surcharge.
author: Rocky A.

description:
Soooo delicious, but definitely get the deep dish.....the thin crust holds nothing vs. the deep dish delight.  

A bit noisy, but fun.  Eat at the bar if the wait is too long.  Also wish they had more variety of starter salads.  

At the end of the day a huge fan because the deep dish is SOOOOO good.  And I am not normally a deep dish fan.  It is just crack in a the shape of a circle....yum!
author: Caren H.

description:
Ordered three things. All three with their own brand of awesome.

Thing 1: Garlic bread.
I've eaten some serious garlic bread in my day, as my love handles will attest to, but nowhere have I seen a presentation like this one before. Warm sourdough (if my tastebuds don't deceive me) with a crispy crust sliced just thick enough, with a ridiculous amount of butter that you apply yourself, as with the garlic. The bread's good enough to eat alone. Just imagine what butter and garlic do. It's like the holy trinity of taste. Or so I'd think if I hadn't had...

Thing 2: Chicken wings.
While I've definitely had my fair share of both breads and pizzas, I have not once eaten chicken wings before. I don't know how. I don't know why. Mostly, I don't know how I survived without eating these particular wings. I'm salivating as I'm writing this. I'm wondering if they're still open right now so I can run blocks over there and get more. A bit of spice, plenty of sauce, cooked nice and soft so it comes off the bone... and onto mine.

Thing 3: Special of the day: deep dish barbecue chicken pizza
Here I think is where my opinion deviates from my gf's. I prefer thin crust. I'm not the world's biggest barbecue sauce fan. I won't rave about this pizza like I do Things 1 & 2, but despite the fact that the pizza wasn't what I'd design for myself (next time I'll get the thin crust Mediterranean chicken, which sounds quite my style), the quality was such that I will definitely return, even if I don't get my coveted wings. I can tell a good pizza, even without my favorite ingredients. The cornmeal crust was appropriately firm without any blackened areas or mushy bits, the ingredients were fresh and the cilantro nice and perky-- good combo with the barbecue sauce, I might add. I will say: I just told my gf what I wrote, and when I said I wasn't the pizza's biggest fan, she said in a meek voice, "I thought it was good." So there you have it. It was good, because she is always right (and I happily finished my leftovers about an hour ago).

Obviously I care about food more than anything else, but I'll also say, in case I haven't made this long enough yet, that the service was good, the decor was cool, I liked the art, and we didn't have to wait for a table for a late Sunday lunch.
author: Shaina 'Occasionally Rahn' K.

description: They have some of the best thin crust and Chicago style deep dish in the Bay Area.   Last time my wife and I went, we had the caprese salad, deconstructed garlic toast, and the large Little Star deep dish.
