Deconstructed garlic toast is toast, with butter on the side, and a whole roasted garlic that you can squeeze like toothpaste.  The caprese salad is just perfect - olive oil, balsamic vinegar, slices of tomatoes, slices of thickly cut mozzarella cheese, and black and green olives also.   I like the root beer, but they have plenty of beer beer.  The atmosphere is very homey, and everyone that works there is very nice.
author: John H.

description:
The best pizza I've had in the five plus years I've lived in San Francisco.  I've had Zachary's three times and I thought this was better than Zachary's.  Mostly because the crust on the Little Star pizza is GREAT!  They had a mint ice cream that was perfect.  It tasted like homemade mint ice cream... not like mint flavored ice cream.  And the cocktails are delicious - try to "koolaid" you won't regret it.  

I didn't realize until after dinner that it was "cash only," but they have an ATM in the restaurant that's only got a .25 charge for use.  So, it was no big deal!
author: Corey F.

description: delicious! im not usually a deep dish pizza fan, but after my friend told me it's a must try- i couldn't say no. we ordered and a friend thankfully picked it up for us. i got my deep dish pie with mushroom and pepperoni's. lots of sauce- check. gooey cheese- check. stuffed full of savory mushroom and meat- check. two slices filled me up. cornmeal crust is fantastic. overall, absolutely will have it again when im in the area :)
author: Abigail W.

description:
Not on the same scale as Lou Mulnati's, Gino's East, or Giordano's, but still the best Chicago style pizza I've had outside of Chicago. crust, cheese, then toppings, just like it should be.  
good:  crust was nice and buttery and crisp.  not too thick, not doughy at all.  Just like chicago style should be.  sauce was great, and plentiful.  They have a good selection of beers on tap and wines by the glass (including some nice ravenswoods), and service is decent.

bad:  NOT ENOUGH TOPPINGS!  Cheese was about 1/3 what true chicago style should be.  not enough of everything else either (as chicago style goes), but the toppings are plenty by california standards.  the wait has consistently gotten worse since my first visit, but I hear they have a new mission location.
author: Fong L.

description:
I should start out by saying that I am a thin crust girl, all the way.  That said, this was very good pizza.  Way yummy.  Better than anything I have had in Chicago (the supposed home of the deep dish pizza).  I've also had Zachary's, and this is much better.  The crust is  like a crispy, chewy bowl, holding all the saucy, cheesy, spicy, meaty goodness.  Also, not to be missed is their mixed green salad.  The combination of their wonderful vinaigrette with gorgonzola and walnuts, let alone all the tasty veggie parts, is the prefect starter to the meal.

** Update ** I tried the thin crust (months ago) and yep, it's just as tasty as I wanted it to be, and then some.  It will always be a toss-up now whether to get the deep dish or the thin crust.  Here's hoping to have a group of 6 or more and get one of each!
I can't wait to go back and try the thin crust.  If it's as good as the deep dish pie, I may have found my new favorite pizza place.
author: darla s.

description:
Way better than Zachary's (in Berkeley).---and it seems like I'm not the only one who feels like this!

LSP actually got me back to liking pizzas... PERIOD!   I am not a fan of the fare, but having LSP made me think twice about my previous biases.

I love their crust.. it is infused with garlic and has that cornmeal, grainy texture that I like (adds to the crisp/ness factor... not a soggy deep dish at all!)

My favorite is the vegetarian deep dish.

The pizzas are really good.
author: Grace M.

description:
Little Star Pizza is a pretty cool place.  The place is so tiny they separate the entrance area from some of the tables with a curtain. The girl who was at the hostess stand was in full 1980s Jane Fonda Aerobics  gear and looked like she had just stepped out of the video for Eric Prydz  "Call on Me"... except for the colorful full-sleeve work on her  arm. Neutral Milk Hotel in full effect on the juke. Very hip.

I'm not going to make any comparisons or throw superlatives about. I've never been to Zachary's or The Cheese Board (but believe me, I'm going). I will say that the crust is phenomenal and it tastes like they use about 22 gallons of olive oil per pie, which is almost enough. 

The place also smells fantastic, although on a weekend you might get a better whiff of your neighbor: it's pretty close seating.
author: Aiden B.

description:
This is a thin crust takeout review:

I also have been wanting to try Little Star ever since Check Please. I like  me a  thin crust pizza, finally decided to just do take-out since the wait has always been more than our stomachs can bear.   

I really enjoyed the white pizza , fresh tomato, zucchini , feta and mozz.  The crust was crispy but not as thin and delectable to my palate as some others.

The little star deep dish sounds pretty good as well, but that is for another visit.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I have to say I prefer the thin crust over the thick. I know that may sound blasphemous, but the corn meal crust just doesn't do it for me. You have to like a hard crusty bottom to like this style of thick crust. I prefer mine doughy/bready. 

However, the pizzas are still good. The thick crust does hold up the toppings and tomato sauce well. You really have to use your knife and fork (or not). We shared a Classic (sausage, mushrooms, green peppers) Thick Crust (large $22) and a small Pesto Chicken Thin Crust ($17). 

Tip: Since the thick crust takes 30 minutes to bake, order the thin as an appetizer (only 15 min).

Cash only.
Expect long waits, so drop by put your name down and check out places surrounding the restaurant.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I have been looking for something to satisfy my craving for Chicago's Giordano's Pizza. This is the closest I've come without a plane ticket, and for that, I'm giving it 5 stars.

Prices are decent, but more than regular pizza if you think that's what you're coming here for...
author: Paul B.

description:
After a long day walking the Haight and Golden Gate Park we decided on Pizza for dinner. We had not yet tried Little Star before but after reading about the positive reviews on Yelp we were all looking forward to giving this place a try. 

If you did not know the address the discrete storefront would have caused you to walk right on by. It did not appear to be your typical Pizza place. I suppose that is cool image the owners were trying to convey. 

The staff was very accommodating in quickly seating our table of five. 

After selecting a variety of drinks from the extensive, reasonable beer and wine list we were ready to order our pies. 

Thin crust vegetarian pizza is what we selected and when it soon arrived piping hot we were not at all disappointed. It hit the spot. 
The crust was delicious. The tomato sauce was fine with the veggies fresh and well prepared. The liberal amount of delicious cheese was just right. All in all it was quite tasty. For those who like to sprinkle garlic, beware of the shaker as it has a tendency to pour hard and fast. 

All of us recovering NYers debated whether this was comparable to NY Pizza and wondered what made the NY Pizza a singular taste experience. No Little Star was not NY Pizza but it had a quality of its own that made it some of the best we sampled on the west coast. 

We all agreed that we would definitely return again soon.
author: Danny A.

description: We really, really want to like Little Star, and have been going back every few months.  It's a way cool place, hip atmosphere, nice people, great reviews on Yelp.  But after four different visits, I'm not so sure I'm that sold on Little Star's thin crust pizza.  The last pie we ordered had a crust that was really noticeably oily, while at the same time being rather dry and cracker-y. The crust got even drier as we finished the pie. Now I understand that Little Star's Chicago-style pies are awesome -- but as sort of a NY pizza snob, I much prefer Neapolitan-style thin crust.  If your preferences are anything like mine -- and they certainly may not be -- there may be other pizza places that make a better thin crust.  This is still a great place, especially if you're a deep-dish fan.  As others have noted, it's not inexpensive, parking can be difficult (although it gets worse elsewhere in SF), and you may have a wait a bit before you're seated.
author: Richard A.

description:
Yum.  Yum F*(&*& Yum.  This place has been reviewed so many times that my review right now is gratuitous.   That being said, I had to weigh in.  And boy did I weigh in a little heavier after eating here.  This was a phenomenal meal.  Pizza (deep dish) was spot on, and we washed it down with some cheap beer and not-so-cheap-but-damn-fine zinfandel.  
The wait can be a bit much, but I am not going to let that hurt Little Star.  Better than Zachary's for sure.  Zach's is great, but can be a bit overboard on everything.  This was just more put together.  See for yourself.  Trust me.
author: Blake W.

description:
I've been dreaming of going back to Little Star for weeks now... 

First though -- like lots of other yelpers mention, it's cash only... they do have an ATM with a low surcharge inside the restaurant.  

Parking was a hassle... (thank goodness I wasn't driving!)
Although the restaurant wait was long (it's a pretty tiny place) the bar was quick with drinks and the company was great.

Pizza -- delicious. The cornmeal crust is a nice change of pace.
But honestly, the Caprese salad is what's haunting me now.  The tomatoes, mozzarella, and balsamic vinegar were each *perfect*  

I'm going back ASAP!
author: Katrina O.

description:
I give this place 3-1/2 stars.  The deep dish pizza is good, mind blowing...not.  The wait is always ridiculous and they only take cash.  The jukebox has pretty good jams and the beer selection isn't too shabby.  Too many fucking hipsters eat here, but what are you going to do?  Hipsters like pizza too.

P.S.  I will fight to the death and say Patxi's is better.  And Zachary's is better than both.
author: Christina S.

description:
Finally good pizza in San Francisco!

The thin crust is really good but the deep dish is so amazing that one should just keep their appetite for the latter.
The atmosphere is rather trendy, yet there are lots of families in the early evening.
Prices for drinks are very reasonable: beer is at $4, -$1 at happy hour (5pm-6:30pm and then after 10pm).

Parking is hellish though in this neighborhood... One should look on transversal streets and not on Divisadero to find a spot.
author: Elsa T.

description: I think Little Star is the best pizza in the city..their deep and thin crust are epic and their thin crust is even better.. Best local pizza in the business!!
author: SF M.

description: Great product, good prices, nice people. Complements the surrounding neighborhood in a big way! Can't ask for much more.
author: Rocky B.

description:
Food:
Very fresh, tons of options for toppings, mmm deep dish

Service:
The service itself is good but the pizza takes FOREVER to make, you can't order while you wait, and the wait can be an hour long

Overall:
Wish it was a bit bigger and allowed pre-ordering but I'd go back despite my complaining :)
author: Jared F.

description:
My friend took me here last week and I was a little hesitant since we're having deep dish and it's NOT at Zachary's.  But to my surprise, the pizza was damn good!!  I'm probably going to do a head to head Little Star vs. Zachary's taste test in the near future.

Another great surprise--the jukebox rocks!!  Almost too much.. it was like they took all the songs from my ipod and put it in the jukebox.  If you're a fan of Radiohead and Broken Social Scene, check out the tunes at Little Star.
author: Miranda S.

description:
I never even really liked deep dish pizza, until I had a little star classic.

'nuff said.
author: Gail O.

description:
I love you, Little Star.

When I moved to the West Coast last year I was bombarded with people telling me, "you'll NEVER find good pizza out west.  Never ever."  Clearly, these people have never tasted the perfection that is Little Star pizza.  

The thin crust style is very good and they use just the right amount of sauce (not too sloppy, not too dry).  The deep-dish pizza is made with an incredible cornmeal crust that makes me wanna curl up with it and snuggle.  Okay, maybe I should stop raving about it before I get all horny.  

It's worth the wait, though - and yeah, it's loud, but the jukebox is cool.
author: Sleuthy W.

description:
Edit: A year later, my heart has warmed significantly more to Little Star, and frankly, now that I simply call in an order, step over the masses, and walk out with my pizza nullifies most of my complaints.  Take off half a star if you don't live in the neighborhood.  Also, I'm not catching BART to Zachary's, even if I grew up eating their deep dish well before Little Star.  Eff that noise.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It's a wonderful feeling to have a restaurant that I can use as a landmark to tell people where I live.

It's an even more wonderful feeling to be able to walk out of my apartment, turn my head, see a traffic light turn green, and be able to sprint across the street and be right at Little Star.

I've never been masochistic enough to try to eat here on a Friday or Saturday night, but I know that Sundays can be a bit of a nightmare, with half-hour to forty-five minute waits.   

The jukebox leans toward hipster (as do some of the clientele), but has enough classic hip-hop gems to keep things interesting -- I seem to always put on some Digable Planets whenever I eat.  It's dark, but that's not necessarily a terrible thing.

Enough about the ambience, though; Little Star is all about the food.  Deep dish that rivals Zachary's for Best of the West.  Good appetizers, including excellent salads and wonderful garlic bread.  Champagne cocktails that work well with the food.

If I were single, I'd say that it's a great place for a first date, if you don't find yourself flirting with a waitress.  As a taken man, it's a wonderful spot to take your lady on a weeknight and enjoy great food and a dimly lit, intimate vibe.  Takeout is an option and works well with a nice bottle of red, but there's something about ordering a "Pom-pagne" with dinner that just works.

This is one of those times that a half-star addition on Yelp would be nice, but whatevs.  The long waits, above par (but nothing to call home about) thin crust, and the "being closed on Monday" thing are ding-worthy, even with hipster-magnetism aside.  No superlatives, no bullshit, there are few places in SF with better pizza than Little Star.
author: Sterling M.

description:
Yes, this is the 3rd time I've had pizza in the past 7 days.  Look at my profile - I LOVE Pizza!

Every bit as good as the Mission Little Star.  I had the Little Star Deep Dish this time.  Very very good, but EXTREMELY Garlicky.  Yum, but The Original is better.

The caprese salad is very good too.  I loved the balsamic vinegar they put on it.  It's large, so it's a good idea to share it and a small pizza.

It was actually harder to find parking at this Little Star and the wait was long - 45 min.  I haven't had to wait to sit at the Misson restaurant yet.  But, it was still worth the wait.
author: Angie C.

description:
I think this is a good place. I have been here twice and I am sure I will go back for more. Here is what I like about them ...

The pizzas are tasty and delicious. This place has good amount of variety in pizzas and with good flavours. Thus leaving me wanna come back for more. the staff was awesome, both the times. The girl who was managing the wait list .. was dealing with the customers with a fantastic attitude. Didnt some one say that a smile goes a long way. ~smile. U got to go back for more pizza here.
author: Amlan S.

description:
Yummy deep dish pizza.  I liked how they got the crust so crispy, but it wasn't burnt or undercooked at all.  Nicely done.
However, being an east-coaster, I just prefer thin crust, oily, and runny sauce and cheese that drips down your face.  Little Star's thin crust wasn't enough like my fantasy of pizza from home.  Nothing wrong with it, just not the pizza that haunts my dreams from home.  Someday I'll find that....
author: Jessica L.

description:
5 stars - PIZZA (deep dish veggie)
5 stars - mixed green salad
5 stars - walking distance from my house
5 stars - totally inexpensive dinner for 2
5 stars - interesting beers on tap

this review gets 3 stars for the moronic service I received last night.... I don't think the bartender had ever tended a bar in her life and the hostess just plain sucked. 20 minutes does not mean an hour ... and when we asked how much longer it might be, we got a curt "soon". Come on cranky pants... she really sucked.
author: Amelia L.

description:
Great deep dish pizza. Might be slightly saltier than Zachary's. I don't know Chicago pizza enough to know what's authentic. Definitely a good place to be. The atmosphere is intimate yet vibrant and the waiters/waitresses are nice.

Out of town people, be aware that the parking situation in the area is one of the worst. They also don't like to seat you until the whole party is there.
author: Ryo S.

description:
Dat's some freakin' tasty pizza over der.

Granted: I'm not a Chicagoan. Regardless, in my estimation, Little Star makes the best deep dish in the city. It blows Patxi's away. The cornmeal thin crust is pretty damn satisfying, too. 

Overall, they execute very well in the realm of American-style pizza. Their tomato sauce is especially tasty.

They make a mean salad as well.

They have a cool jukebox, too, and the servers are very nice.

There are some cons: There's almost always a wait, it's loud, and the beer selection isn't great... Blue Paddle is a nice option, though.
author: Angelo B.

description:
I had been here 4 or 5 times and always liked the deep dish (that's what everyone says is the best).  But I wasn't amazed like so many others.   Anyway, the deep dish is definitely good.  But my observations on the deep dish are a little too much sauce, not enough cheese and the crust could be crispier.  The point I'm trying to make is that there is better deep dish out there.  Lou Malnatti's in Chicago.  Now that's a good pie!  Just too far away.

What took me by complete surprise was the thin crust.  My friends and I ordered a small cheese thin crust as well as the deep dish and I couldn't keep my hands of it.  Man it was good!  Crust was crispy, perfect sauce/cheese ratio and the ingredients were were very high quality.  Probably the best thin crust pizza I've had in the bay area and there are only a handful that come in higher on the all-time best list.

I'm leaving one star off because I think there is some room for improvement on the deep dish.
author: Raymond F.

description:
From all of the rave reviews, I just had to try it.  Business is definitely good with the wait at over 40 minutes on a Wednesday night.  Sadly, the pizza and wings were just ok for me.  The crust is a bit unique but no wow factor in the filling.

There are actually several good pizzerias in town.  Little Star does not really rise above.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Little Star has pretty good deep dish (for California!) but when you've previously lived in Chicago for 4 years you get a little spoiled.  

It's also really dark inside - beyond ambient lighting.  I could barely read the menu.  

I like the way they serve their garlic bread, though, with a whole bulb of roasted garlic.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
"When I'm sad, she comes to me
With a thousand smiles, she gives to me free
Its alright she says its alright
Take anything you want from me, anything
Anything...

Fly on Little"... Star Pizza,
Yeah yeah, yeah, Little Star Pizza 

- Little Wing (kind of),  Jimi Hendrix

Okay, so these are not the actual lyrics, but had he eaten here this great song just may have been called "Little Star".

I just had the most euphoric pizza tonight, as though I was in the midst of hearing Jimi Hendrix's "Axis:Bold as Love" on vinyl as I devoured their thin crust Italian Combo. 

What should I order for side two?
author: Michael R.

description:
Transcendental pizza?  It's possible, folks, and you can find it right here.  My cousin and I split the Little Star deep dish last night, and I can tell you that eating that pie made the half-hour wait for a table and the additional half-hour wait for the pizza itself well worth it.  One bite and the world around you melts away.  The roar of the crowd dies down to a tolerable murmur and the intermittent wailing and flashing of cop cars on Divis are but mere twinkles in the ambience (you can hear a couple of violins too if you listen carefully).

Truly sublime.  Unlike anything I've tried before, and I live and breathe pizza (come on now, it's the perfect food).   I've been told that there's an ongoing battle for supremacy between Little Star and Zachary's, and until I make my way out to Berkeley, I'm rooting for the local hero.
author: Andrea U.

description:
This is one of the top pizza restaurants in the city. It's not one of my tops because I like thinner slices. But if you like deep dish, this is the place to be! I enjoyed it nonetheless. 

They don't take reservations at this location, so it's best if you come early (before 7pm). They also won't seat you until everyone in your party is present, so tell your usual late friends to stop lagging! The place is not that big and the tables are a little small as well. It'll be hard to fit a really big party in my opinion. It's also a little dark. 

We had the chicken wings for appetizer and sipped on the different array of beers they offered. For the pizzas, we had the classic deep dish and a pesto chicken thin crust. I guess I never had a real deep dish pizza before because the sauce was on top of the pizza...which was very interesting! It was all very good. 

I had a good time and will be back again.
author: Allan M.

description:
As I sat on the waiting area couch in Little Star the other night waiting for my friend to arrive, I realized that if I wasn't careful I was going to start drooling as I was practically daydreaming about the thick cornmeal crust I was about to eat.

In other words, damn I love this pizza. I usually get the classic deep dish but don't mind the occasional foray into thin crust territory, especially for the pesto chicken. And if I split a large with my friend I usually end up with two days worth of leftovers. And this pizza makes for some mighty fine leftovers, let me tell you.

The staff is usually pretty friendly. Always smiling, as far as I've seen, but they don't seem to be faking it. They're cash only, which isn't really a problem. There's an ATM right inside that has a measly fee of 25 cents.

I can't give Little Star 5 stars because I wish they took reservations and would seat you even if your whole party wasn't quite there. I understand the reasoning but it's still annoying.
author: Tara B.

description:
I LOVE Little Star. Just looked up their number to order and thought, what the heck, write a review. Pizza is like burritos. A lot of people have  an idea of what they think it the best  and everything else is crap.
LSP has a lot of garlicy, herby sauce over a crunchy (cornmeal?) crust with cheese baked in between, much like Zachary's in Berkeley. If that's what you like, this is incredible pizza. I love the thin crust too if done well but really the two types of pizza almost aren't even the same type of food.  If the above sounds good to you and you aren't a snob about what a pizza "has to be like", this place rocks.
author: carol k.

description:
im not a fan of crust but i sure as hell couldnt stop eating little stars crust!

meatball was ok
classic was yummy

id give it another star if the wait wants so long... 
tip: preorder pizza so when your table you arent ready to bite your arm off!!
author: M E.

description: Little Star Deep Dish pizza is solid. It's a good choice is you're craving deep dish pizza.
author: Jolie S.

description:
i love chicago-style pizza!!! and i love little star's cornmeal crusts ***drool***

came here for an early dinner (~5:45p on a Sat) = no wait + happy hour drink specials ($1 off all alcoholic drinks)
got the meatball special (bits of meatball chunks + spinach + melty cheese and tomato sauce) = absolutely delicious

fyi: leftovers taste just as good when reheated. we got the large (8 fatty slices) for 2 people, ate half and took the rest for home :)
author: Vy D.

description: After 5 years, Little Star is still great. Can't beat the cornmeal crust, perfect tomato sauce, and tasty deep dish pizzas. You absolutely can not go wrong with a large classic deep dish (you'll want leftovers in the morning) and a mixed green salad to start. The salads are generously portioned, a small is more than enough for 2-3 people plus the deep dish pizzas take a while to bake, so it's nice to have something to nosh on while you wait. A perennial favorite in the SF pizza scene.
author: Candice L.

description: My first deep dish experience and well, gotta say... LOVE IT! Have it every so often for dinner with my sister and her husband, and every time, it tastes as good as it gets. Its Delish. Tonight had the thin crust pepperoni as well as deep dish with pepperoni, artichoke hearts and sun-dried tomatoes... so good!
author: Rachel L.

description: I was starving when I came home to see this on my kitchen table.  When I first saw the pizza, I thought someone had brought Zachary's.  In comparison, the extra ricotta adds extra cheesiness and a creamier texture.  I love the chunky tomatoes on top, but I think the crust here is too thick, and it doesn't have that sweet doughiness that I like.  Still, this was really satisfying on a cold, rainy night.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
FINALLY...an AWESOME deep dish pizza joint...their crust was fabulous!!! And I want to know the secret on how it doesnt get soggy with all that yummy sauce!

There was the perfect amount of cheese on our veggie pizza...thats important!

I can't wait to go back...
author: Sarpreet G.

description: Best deep dish pizza. Great crust. Freshly made so be prepared to wait, but definitely worth it.
author: J C.

description:
Delicious pizza whether thin or thick crust...I prefer the thin.

The one on Diviz is loud...not sure about the other one.
author: Shawn H.

description:
The best pizza I've had at a restaurant in California (maybe the US).

Great food.
Filling portions
Friendly staff
Fun environment.

I highly recommend you visit Little Star Pizza. The waits may be log (we waited 1.5 hrs) but it is worth every minute.

I know where I'm eating the next time I want a delicious pizza!
author: Sachin T.

description: Best deep dish pizza aside from Zacharys in Oakland in the bay area.  Definitely the best in SF.  The sauce is very comparable to Zachary's, the crust has a slightly different texture.. but still very delicious.
author: Lili L.

description: Visiting from NYC where there is an abundance of good pizza, of course I had to find SF's best. Decided on Little Star after seeing it #1 on many Yelp lists and I was not disappointed. My friend and I went around 7pm on a Sunday night and were seated immediately, though maybe just by luck because when we left there looked to be a long wait. Everything on the menu looked great but in my opinion all the thin crust pizzas were priced $2-3 more than the usual "specialty" pizza restaurant in NYC (like Roberta's). We decided on thin crust Italian and deep dish vegetarian to share. Thin crust Italian came out first (and fast!) and it was actually way better than I expected.. something about the garlicky crust was unique to what I've had before. Trying not to make ourselves full we anxiously awaited the deep dish vegetarian. SO GOOD. We took home the leftovers and let me tell you.. they were just as good cold. Hipster servers (I live in Williamsburg so I can say that) were nice.. but I mean your usual hipster servers. Crowd was mixed.. definitely a good place to come with friends and share plates. I guess this is like the Roberta's of SF. Will definitely be back next trip.
author: Marta F.

description:
OMG...I LOVE their corncrust  deep dish pizza! It is CRAZY delicious.
Their Caprese salad is outta this world!
Love this place and the vibe and everything!
author: R B.

description: The deep dish pizza is so good I want to weep tears of joy.  I almost don't want to tell anybody about this spot so I don't have a wait each time I go.  If I ever settle down with a significant other, he had better be OK with eating Little Star once per week, minimum.  How else can I put this?  It's so good that sometimes I think about writing love poems about it.  The crust tastes like cornbread and rainbows.  The cheese tastes like... well, cheese... and happiness.  I love you always and forever Little Star.  xo.
author: Whitney S.

description:
I had never been here before, so arriving a bit after 9 p.m. this past Thursday, I was a bit surprised to see how busy this place was. My guest and I waited around 20 minutes for our table, but the time didn't seem that long since there were plenty of visuals around for me to occupy myself. I enjoyed to artwork hanging all around the restaurant and especially the free copies of The Onion :D

Also, it's always nice to be able to grab a beer at the bar while waiting for a seat in any restaurant. Brownie points for that.

I looked through the menu while waiting and decided on the Mediterranean. Another 20+ minutes later, it came out and didn't resemble anything Mediterranean...and didn't taste anything close to it either. I was hoping for some fresh flavors, but was just met with overwhelming tomato sauce. 

The bread itself was a little TOO crispy...possibly overbaked by a minute or so? My guest was eating it with a fork and knife (I KNOW RIGHT???) was having trouble cutting her pizza and had to use more force than I would have imagined. I had no trouble biting it, but again, the crust was a little too crispy for my taste.

Our server was okay I guess. Kinda slipped past us a few times when we wanted our to-go box and check, so I had to wave down another dude. The hostess didn't seem happy to be working there that night. She wasn't terrible, but certainly didn't look like she was enjoying her shift?

And those comparing it to Zachary's..eh. Zach's isn't that great to begin with, sooo...
author: Tinothy M.

description: the best pizza I have ever had the pleasure of trying. seriously, I will have to hit up the local del taco in Newark in order to satisfy my drunken desire for booze food since I live in the area. I have been to Chicago, had the deep dish there, and by far, little star takes the cake. I absolutely loved the corn bread crust; however, please increase the toppings as there wasn't enough ricotta or chicken on the pizza. as well, the garlic bread was cheesy goodness that didn't make me want to take a deuce in the bathroom shortly afterward (thank you pizza hut). the deep dish takes 30 min to make, so plan out your night accordingly. :)
author: Jasen S.

description:
I wanted a deep dish but my sister wanted a thin crust, so we decided on the Italian Combo. I was a bit wary of olives since I don't like them but it always seems like you can't taste the olives on a good pizza. We ordered the pizza to go since holy crap was there ever a large amount of people here. The price is pretty good, we had the large thin crust for three people which is about $8 per person.

The pizza smelled so good on the ride back to our hotel. The pizza tasted spectacular when we finally got to eat it. The crust was crispy and tasted great. The toppings were plentiful and we couldn't tasted the olives, awesome! The pizza was very filling and I wish I could try the deep dish now after seeing pictures of it!
author: Kevin K.

description: great great great deep dish pizza. One of the best I've ever had. Every bite was scrumptous, flavorful and everything I could ask for in a pizza. Will definitely be coming back here again whenever I have the chance. I hope this place never changes it's great style, great food and great service.
author: Penny S.

description: I LOVE when the pepperoni is under the cheese. This makes me so very happy. The crust is delicious. Their pizza converted me from a thin crust lover to a deep dish person.
author: Merrilee T.

description:
I've been wanting to go to this place forever but only just made it for the first time last week.   I LOVED it so much I went back again this week.  This is absolutely my favorite pizza place in the city.  

The deep dish pizza is like pizzaria uno on steroids.  Great, fresh toppings and amazing crust.  Loved it.

I'm also a big fan of the wings.  They aren't traditional buffalo wings but a great spicy dry rub, lots of meat and a great flavor.  The mozzarella and tomato salad was superb too!  Great fresh tomatoes and the cheese is great.

Can't say enough good things!
author: Clay G.

description: Staff was great - the hostess took our order while we waited on a table and our server kept us laughing every time she came by. I'm not into Chicago style deep dishes but the pizza here is just amazing. It wasn't a big sloppy, soggy mess. Instead, the bottom was crisp, forming a solid foundation making it very hand holdable. LOTS of cheese, which I like. The wings were spicy but good. Garlic bread is awesome here (see pics). We got stuck in the corner table by the window which made space a premium and it was quite dark in this section so it was hard to see the food.
author: O'Shea J.

description: 3 1/2 star.  Got thin crust pizza.  Didn't like their pizza selection.  I like the simple Italian toppings at Delfino.
author: Chloe H.

description:
pizza-joint lovin is like a throwing up gang affiliations here in the bay area.

TO ME, my homie is Little Star Pizza.
small joint (thankfully our tuesday dinners are early so we never get caught in a nasty wait, usually...), dark restaurant, with some high tables and some low ones, a pumped up mac plays ipod-alicious songs in the background.

their deep dish pizza is really amazing.  the sauce is so thick and is packed with flavor.  toppings are fresh and bountiful (srsly).  and the crust.  omy, i had no idea that pizza crust could taste like that!  i can't compare it to anything else, it opened up a new category on its own.

but its bourgie pizza!  so keep that in mind if you splurge and get a fat bill.
author: Angela Q.

description:
That buttery thin crust...I WANT MORE! I could have had the entire small all to myself, but had to be polite and share. The giant salad was also yummy.

The thick crust looked popular, but I doubt I'll stray from the thin. 

The service was fabulous and the waitress laughed when I said I'd be yelping about the experience. Pizza lovers must go here.

p.s. Zachary's is just okay and Zelda's in Sacramento is terrible...soggy, nasty thick crust. Maybe I just hate thick crust pizza though.
author: Whit P.

description:
No more wasting calories on less than superior pizza.   From here on out, it's Little Star Pizza, period.  Their deep dish pizza is simply fabulous. 
 
Save room for the cheesecake.
author: Ronnie T.

description:
Very good deep-dish pizza, no need to go to the East Bay anymore for that Zachary's fix!

The place is always busy, any day of the week, but you can call ahead and order for pickup and just jump out and grab your order.

Service is good, it is not inexpensive, (comparable to Zachary's) but think about the bridge tolls you are saving.  The space isn't exactly thrilling, but the food sure is good and served efficiently.

Parking is a tough.
author: Doug M.

description:
It's a bright spot on Divisadero, worth the trouble to find parking for

Need to wait for your seat? Go to the corner and have a drink at Fly Bar while you wait.

Then when you get back, enjoy what is now my top pick for deep dish. I would like more cheese on top and throughout [covered in tomatoes & sauce with cheese mixed in, not all over], but the great toppings and appetizers make it all worth it.
author: Charles C.

description:
I won't even take a star away for not taking credit cards I'll survive.
My husband tried to take our leftover Little Star deep dish Classic pizza for lunch. Oh, hell no! I admit, I could have hurt him had he tried.
I love Little Star. Yummy salad, oh the garlic bread, and the crust on their pizzas! My sister insisted that it was too buttery, but I don't know what the hell that means. 
The first time I finally made it to Little Star, I decided that it's official: Zachary's is dumb. Sorry.
author: tracy d.

description:
The deep dish pizza is fantastic. Sauce and crust are perfect. I've tried all the varieties at least once, and they're all great. It's also incredibly filling -- I can usually take out 3-4 slices of a regular pizza, but I can only handle 2 slices of Little Star's deep dish.

I've only gotten a thin crust a couple of times and didn't find it as exciting. Nothing bad about it, it's just that the deep dish is what they're really spectacular at, so why bother getting something else.

All the appetizers are excellent, especially the caprese salad. The wings aren't as spicy as I'd like, but they're nice and meaty.

I only live half a block away, so I usually do take-out to avoid the line, but the restaurant atmosphere is decent. The jukebox is excellent, but the noise level is a few decibels beyond my comfort zone.
author: Jessica J.

description:
Everyday I don't eat pizza from Little Star . . . I die a little bit.

In the vote for Little Star vs. Zach's  . . . I say give me another slice, they're both outstanding.

Little Star's much closer for me, and ALWAYS has EXCELLENT music.
author: M S.

description:
It's funny how life works.  We were resting in bed watching "Check, Please" on KQED and they covered The Little Star.  Two of the three customers really enjoyed it.  The third thought the place was too dark and too loud.  The two that liked it commented on the Juke Box.  We were kinda hungry so we headed out.  It was a toss up between Green Chile Kitchen and The Little Star... the parking was what was going to make the choice.  A long story short ... we found parking after an eternity and decided to go to Little Star because it was new.   We got in line ... and then went down to The Fly Bar and had a tasty drink while we waited for the line to die down.  The Mediterranean Chicken Pizza was flavorful and fresh.  We really enjoyed the cornbread crust.  It's a great place to go ... but it's still "pizza."

... oh .. and it really has a good Juke Box .. but if it's noisy don't waste your money .. cause you won't be able to hear the music.
author: Kevin-John B.

description: Honestly, one of the best pizza's in the city. The dough, sauce, cheese, and whatever topping you choose to add, then on top of that  even more tangy sauce, making this place worth checking out. On the flip-side of quality, there lies the reality in service. 2007 Zagat rated for food, definately!
author: Zee R.

description:
Good deep dish pizza.  Not the best.   But pretty decent.  The crust isn't as buttery as Uno's deep dish, but you can definitely taste and enjoy the consistency of the crust.

Choices are limited, but you can always make your own.  And no matter what you choose as toppings for your deep dish when you create your own, it will always come with chunky tomatoes.  Their caprese salad was amazing!
author: Tadd L.

description:
The deep dish "Little Star" pizza was super yum!  Verbatim from the menu it has spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic.  The crust was nice a crisp!  For those that are not much into beer, try the cider (the first one listed from lightest to darkest).

The service was pretty good and the facility is kept well.  I wouldn't recommend for big parties since the place isn't that big.
author: Lorace R.

description:
Little Star pizza...you taste so good...you made me look like a complete pig when I ate you...I hope you're happy.

But seriously, I'm always a pig when I eat so it's not like I was acting different or anything. But you know that already, don't you Little Star? Yeah...you do...

Now, while you are quite tasty, I don't think you are Zachary's. Zachary's is quite tasty. I love them. But since I don't have to get on the BART, you are my second favoritest, and therefore because of location, you get the same points as Zachary's.

You know...I think Little Star and Zachary's should have a wrestling match in a kiddie pool of lube. That'd be something I would definitely want to see...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Looks like this place has been reviewed to death, so I'll just add brief comments.

Cons: Always a long wait, a little too dark inside, sometimes service is a little slow.

Pros: Classic (sausage + stuff) and Little Star (spinach + stuff) are both great deep dish pizzas, I love the rich crust.  I prefer their pizza to Zachary's, though it's nothing compared to my favorite deep dish in Chicago - Gino's East sausage pizza YUM (mail order ftw!).  Garlic bread is incredible - great bread w/ delicious clove of garlic to spread.  DELICIOUS!
author: Deva H.

description:
I ordered the following thin crust combo:
chicken
artichokes
tomato
roasted garlic
mushroom

This combo was pretty unctuous to me even if it was a wee bit soggy in the middle. What really impressed me was the service. We were sat immediately and we didn't have to wait long for the server to come around after we'd made up our minds. I addition to the pizza hubby and I ordered a salad. Waited all of 3 min after the server took our order for the salad to come. After we were done with the salad our server came, whisked away the plates and placed the pizza on the table. Yummy!

If there is one thing I hate doing is waiting and I am happy to say that we did none of that here. Can't wait to come again!
author: Wendy L.

description:
734 reviews! Wow, that says it all!
Sinful, perfect pizza. I always get the pesto deep dish, and a movie star cocktail. The line says it all. 

Just wish they'd accept reservations, as the wait can be a real buzzkill.
author: Killing Me Softly ..

description:
Ever since we saw it featured on Check Please! last year, Hubby and I made some failed attempts to Little Star for lunch.    Eventually we got it and went there for dinner - we heart Little Star a lot.   Their pizza crust has a special crunch only good cornmeal can make.  The flavors are all great.   We've managed to come here each time with one additional friend and manage to finish their large deep dish and a large thin crust duly impressing our waitstaff with our capacity.  

I think they make both pizzas wonderful.  And its rare when we have leftovers.  

My only reason for taking off a star is that they only open for dinner, darn!
author: Regi K.

description:
1 star for not taking reservations.  I can't wait over an hour for dinner and then another 40 minutes for the food to come out.  My stomach will eat itself.  that, and by the time i get a table and the food comes, i'm drunk off of one glass of wine cuz i'm starving and maybe that's why i think the food is so great.... which leads to--

5 stars for taste, the mediterranean chicken deep dish is my favorite pizza in the city.  It's delicious and has all the right proportions of toppings and  chunky tomato sauce on top.  Even the leftovers the next day are great.  The classic is great too.  

Other minuses: Cash only, which is a pain in the butt.  What decent sit-down restaurant these days takes only cash?   Parking is impossible in the area if you are driving.  Unless you get lucky, plan on an additional 15-20 minutes circling.   Inside, it's small, cramped, and loud.  Some like this but if you are with one other person, it's hard to chat.   It's only open for dinner so it's not like you can come at a less crowded time.

Overall, I love the pizza and if I can plan ahead accordingly, I can avoid getting too irritated with the wait and the other minuses, because bottom line is, it's great deep dish pizza.
author: Kari L.

description:
This is a review of the Little Star Deep Dish pizza. Little Star has several Deep Dish offerings but I'm reviewing their eponymous pizza.

Easily the best pizza in the city and the best Deep Dish outside of Chicago. I know, superlatives are not incredibly helpful, the details: 

* the Spinach, Ricotta & Feta are perfectly balanced with Little Star's tomato sauce, which is always incredibly fresh
* their corn based crust is a perfect compliment
* for all you meat lovers & haters - this is a vegetarian pizza 

I've ordered take-out dozens of times from the Divisadero location (cash only) and Little Star has never let me down.
author: Risk D.

description:
To this day, I still don't understand the appeal of deep dish pizza places like Little Star or Zachary that are exploding with popularity.  Maybe I simply don't like deep dish pizza and therefore too biased to review a place like this.  But we all need someone to jump off the bandwagon once in a while, right?

The four of us went to Little Star on Divisadero first and found a waiting list of at least an hour.  So we wandered into Mission looking for Pauline's as a substitute and ended up finding another Little Star on Valencia!  This time we were extremely lucky that the four people who were next on the list were nowhere to be found.  So our wait time was zero minutes.

I like the decor of Valencia Little Star better than Divisadero Little Star.  Less dark, more modern.  It was a bit loud because of the exposed brick walls, but I have a deep fondness for exposed brick walls so I tell myself I can live with the loudness.  Seating is crowded but charming and still comfortable.  They have the cutest coasters that look like they were bought in a Museum store.  

I had a small mixed salad and it was fine.  Good amount of cheese and nuts to fill me up.  No overpowering dressing which is a good sign. 

I didn't try any pizza this time.  My dinner companions liked their pizza, although they did comment that the taste was a bit strong at first and pizza was kinda greasy.  Nevertheless, they liked it. 

The wait staff looked, um, ready to go home.  Our waitress was either super tired or totally uninterested in us.  She'd only nod or semi-nod to all of our questions with a dazed face.
author: Candice B.

description:
little star deep dish pizza. i am salivating thinking about it right now. 

however, this place needs to take reservations. takes forever to get seated. also, cash only (seriously?). **update, as of the first of this month, they now accept visa and mastercard** good deal. 

however, great food, great ambiance, and totally worth it. stick with the deep dish, the thin crust is nothing special.
author: Sarah A.

description:
i really dig the thin white pie and the pesto chicken (both with and sans chicken)...
and i checked tonight and they don't take credit cards now only their valencia location does.

try their wings. they are spicy, delicious, tasty creations.

little star. i love you.
author: lucy m.

description: Awesome Chicago style deep dish pizza - it was crowded, but well worth the wait.
author: Paul S.

description: Thanks Yelp! Gotta love when you can order off a secret menu at a restaurant you've never been to before.  That being said,we saddled up to the bar, ordered the Brass Monkey (Little Star deep dish with sausage) and devoured the whole thing.   It was a perfect meal before hitting up The Independent for a concert last night.
author: Kelly I.

description: Okay, so I love my pizza, awhile back when I've never had deep dish pizza, I flew to Chicago just to try it out.  Being a pie fan....Little Star, to me, was a bit disappointing...?  I was kind of hoping a 4.5 out of 5 star rating from Yelp would mean the food is orgasmically delicious in my mouth, but I didn't get that, I got a WTH and a jolt in my head.  I usually don't like to think about the food when I eat it; it's either good for bad.  Don't get me wrong, the pizza's good still, but I came in expecting too much.  My friends and I ordered a thin crust pizza with half pesto chicken and half classic.  To me, it was lacking a lot of flavors, and it was kind of bland; the only thing it had going for it is the fact that the thin crust is a crusty bottom.  Those are very hard to come by nowadays because most pizzeria have the soggy fold 'em up thin crust and I personally hate those.  Yeah, I don't have anything else to say about the pizza, it's OK.  Maybe the deep dish is a lot better, I'll save that for an update if I ever come back.
author: Victor N.

description: Definitely some of the best pizza I have had...love both the deep dish and thin crust.  The wings make a great addition!
author: Katelin H.

description:
It's hard to be hungry in my 'hood and not default here, as if by instinct.  To quote Of Montreal: "How you gonna check my style when I am so superior? How you gonna hate a thing when you are so inferior?"  After about a dozen visits, the novely of deep dish pizza in a thin crust town with crunchy buttery cornmeal crust and packed an inch and a half thick with stringy mozzarella, and superchunky, slightly-acidic tomato sauce has worn off and has been replaced with an abiding love for this the best pizza joint in SF.  There's nothing bad on the menu, and I would know, as I've tried all of it.  The specials are also spot-on, with the exception of the BBQ chicken pizza which was too jalapeno-laden for my liking.  Expect a long wait.  Enjoy with beer.  If it's out-of-control crowded, consider getting a pie to go and eating it across the sreet at Minibar, they're down with that.  More than once, after a particularly wearying day at work, I've called from the muni on my way home from the office.  The pizza has been waiting for me to pick up on the walk home from the bus stop, and I am happy again.

Finally, to the true test of a good pie: does it taste even better, cold, the next day for breakfast?  Yes, my goodness, does it ever.
author: Tee Jay R.

description:
I'm not a huge pizza fan especially thick crust but SUPER good ratings on yelp meant I still had to try..

Me and my friends got a large 1/2 classic, 1/2 Mediterranean.  Large pizza was a little small, but still fed 3 people..  I thoroughly love both, but prefer the classic.  And remember I said I hated thick crust..  well it isn't that thick considering it is a deep dish and most of all it does have the after effect of heavy dough in your stomach.

We had this for takeout, but when I picked up, the inside was very personal.  Smaller tables good for intimate 1on1 dates, not so good for groups.  Dark ambiance and it has a bar..

Highly recommended.. just found my favorite pizza in SF
author: Andrew K.

description:
Great pizza, horrifically bad service.

We don't expect to be seated quickly on a Saturday, not a problem. Wait was longer than estimated, again, no big deal.. Then, 15 minutes sitting at our table, no service, water, nothing.

Finally ordered at the bar. The bartender was awesome. He brought our drinks right out, our salad, and received our generous tip for his services.

Wait staff kept wandering by our table empty handed, refusing to make eye contact. We left, still wondering who exactly was supposed to be our server, but thankful for that bartender!

A shame, really, they do have fantastic pizza. We'll be ordering it to go in the future... like all the smart people who accidentally elbowed me in the back on the head on their way to pick up their food.
author: Table F.

description: Good spot if you like deep dish pizza. That being said I don't like deep dish but as far as deep dish goes some of the best I've tried. So if you like deep dish check into it
author: dan m.

description: Got a large little star thick crust pizza and it was great. Crust is made out of cornbread and is not as heavy as normal pizza crust which makes you enjoy the other ingredients more. Service was excellent.
author: Sri P.

description: We ate at Little Star Pizza a couple if times now, and this last time we dined there, i thought the pizza was terrible. It was a probably a isolated incident but our pizza tasted like it was half-a**ed. We ordered the Pesto chicken pizza and It was cold, toppings was bunched together, and it seemed like there was way to much pesto on it.  Service was good, but the food was bad enough for us to probably not come back.  I recommend Little Joe's Pizzeria on Mission and Italy.
author: Rio A.

description: Their deep dish pizza is the best I've ever had.  Fantastic cornmeal crust.  A+ for food and flavor. The place is small and cozy, can get a bit loud for dinner, but still worth it. Love this place.
author: Enrico C.

description: Thin crust and deep dish don't get better than this. period.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
OK. 

I don't know if the deep dish pizza constitutes as a pizza or what. It's more like a healthy quiche,  just as thick and scrumptious. I'm so happy to have experienced the tasty feast. I ordered a veggie plus sausage medium and I ate half by myself and couldn't help eat left overs in the morning. Yeah, this coming from a very conscious breakfast eater. It was just that darn good.
I'm coming back a lot. :)
author: River W.

description: Spectacular deep dish pizza with cornmeal crust. By far, my favorite deep dish pie in the Bay Area. I usually go for a mixed salad and the classic when sharing with a friend or two. It's plenty for 3-4 adults.  I've never tried the thin crust in several dozen outings to both SF locations. I'm afraid to skip the deep dish. My only complaint is that they are closed on Mondays, but I suppose they deserve a day off.
author: Juan S.

description: Little Star was great. I haven't had deep dish and like it that many times but this flipped the script. The house special was loaded. Took it home and ate it for breakfast the next morning.
author: Uri B.

description:
Hands down the worst pizza I've ever had.  I'm not sure why everyone raves about the crust.  It was grainy and tasteless and not at all enjoyable.  (It's their cornmeal crust, but should really be dubbed their sawdust crust.) We also waited over 2 hrs for our seat.  What made the wait even more aggravating was that the hostess told us to check back in an hour.  We checked back in less than an hour only to find they had already seated someone else who was behind us in line.  So we waited an extra 45 minutes for another table that seats 3 to open up.

Overall, the experience was totally not worth it.  I would have been better off spending my money at Round Table Pizza (tastes better without the high price or the aggravating wait).  After our meal, I also got violently ill.  I had to jump out of our car as I didn't think I was going to make it.   Seriously bad pizza.   Blech.  Stay away!
author: Mary L.

description: Me and my friend had come to visit San Francisco for a week. The apartment that we were staying in had a list of suggested place to eat and Little Star Pizza was on the list. We head to the restaurant about 8pm and man was it hoping with people. When we first got there, it was an hour wait for a seat in the restaurant part of the place. However the host suggested we sit in the bar. We head to the bar. We order an appetizers, Garlic Bread. I have to say, THAT WAS SOME DAMN GOOD GARLIC BREAD. After an appetizer, we order a deep dish pizza to split. My friend being a vegetarian, we ordered the Deep Dish Little Star. And man was it good! If I ever go back to San Francisco, I will be definitely going back.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Very good pizza, great atmosphere, solid service, but most importantly, EASILY the best jukebox in San Francisco. I've searched high-and-low for three years in this city to find a bar with a great jukebox; most are just over-the-top hipster crap, but Little Star actually has great records by artists including Beulah, Springsteen, Duran Duran, Elliott Smith, Wilco, The Wrens and many more. 

All the tedious (a/k/a terrible) hipster bars in the Mission should have a jukebox even half as good as the one in Little Star.

We'll be back soon.
author: K F.

description:
OH HOLY JEBUS - PIZZA LIVES IN SF!!!!!

Simply some of the best pizza I've ever had. It's not Lorenzo's at 3am, nor is it like any crap you'll ever order for delivery. It's better, it's the best. Go deep dish Classic and add pepperoni. 5+++ stars baby!!!
author: David R.

description:
Overall, Little star has good food, atmosphere, service, and restroom faciliates, but the only two problems I see are the composition of the food placement(not too sure how to exlplain any further) and the lighting, which is most likely done on purpose. The lighting is horrible in my opinion, the whole restaurant is dark and has a sense of emo-ness, but this I can see as a purpose of the restaurant. The advantage of having a dark room instead of a well-lit room is that when people take their dates here, they will not be able to see the horrific eating habits or the person's face at most. But that shouldnt stop you from coming here. Good deep dish pizzas at a fairly good price, around $10 per person.  Very good service topped with excellent deserts make this a must-go to place on the weekends, although my friends and I went on a Wednesday afternoon. 
 
                                                  Bong Ape Ee Tit
author: Jimmy K.

description:
I honestly walked in to LSP thinking it was just going to be another Pizza O type of place -- I was so happy to find out just how wrong I was.  For starters, LSP has atmosphere, ambiance, it is dark with votive candles on the tables, romantic even (yes, you can go on a date here).  Good jams feeding out of the jukebox the entire two hours we were there.  
Then, then there is the pizza!  The pizza is legit, it is the best deep dish pizza I have had in the City and I might even be so bold to say it is on the same level as New York and Chicago pizza.  The icing on the cake, or the deep dish pie as it turns out to be, the service is fantastic.  Fantastic not just for a pizza place, but fantastic for a top-notch restaurant.
author: Katie P.

description:
This might be the best pizza west of Chicago, but I'm chipping off a star from what would be a 5-star rating because of the chip on the shoulder worn by many of the people who work here.

And the ginger champagne drink is yummy, but otherwise you might prefer to carry it out and deal with the cozier attitutde in your own home.
author: elsa m.

description:
Hell yeah.  Chicago-style stuffed pizza with some great beer.  I feel like I'm back in the midwest.  I like it better than zachary's.  I think it's the sauce, or perhaps it's the atmosphere.

It's damn good.
author: cindy p.

description:
SO GREAT... We heard it was the best pizza in San Fran and I would have to agree!

Bad news Cash only... Good news ATM inside.  
Bad News LONG Wait...Good news Great carry out (and bar)
Bad News  2 small pies and a salad for 5 people... good news they had so much on them and the deep dish was so thick that it fed everyone...
author: Tricia M.

description:
I crave their freakin' pizza...deep dish cornmeal crust...my mouth is watering just thinking of it...parking can be a challenge and the wait at prime time can be freakin' long...but its worth it....their lychee sangria drink is pretty tasty also...
take out is the best...find an accomplist with a car or just walk your butt over there....their pizza is sooo damn good it's worth fighting for the last piece...
author: Jenniflava R.

description:
Love their pizza. Love their jukebox. Don't mind the wait when there's a seat at the bar. And now that the shine has worn off a bit, it's not as insanely crowded as it used to be.
Still trying to think of a reason to go B-East now that I can skip Zachs.
author: Jess S.

description:
So I'm going to admit that where I grew up, in Seattle, to my knowledge it is all but impossible to get deep dish pizza. Thus, the style was something that was only available at a chain like Pizza Hut when it was trendy a few years back. Needless to say I didn't try it out. I discovered this place by walking by while my girlfriend was in town (I just moved here a few months ago) on the way to Frankie's and we peeked and and thought that it looked cool and decided to check it out the night after. We ordered a half veggie/half classic deep dish and ate at the bar. Unlike what some people have said about this place, the staff was really friendly to us, the bartender especially. We had essentially no wait since we sat at the bar and we even went on a Saturday night. 

The pizza itself was delicious, the chunky sauce on top is killer! Let's just say that I've gone from never having any deep dish to being a complete convert (I can only imagine what the real Chicago stuff is like!). The crust has a great texture and the cornmeal adds a bit of something you won't find in most NY style places. A word to the wise: order the large and take about half of it home. Decent beer selection too.
author: Nicholas B.

description:
I want to give this place more stars but I can't. The pizza just wasn't that great, and the restaurant itself was more like a bar than a pizza place. And, on a sunny Sunday afternoon, the restaurant was so dark I could hardly see my boyfriend across the very small table. 

The service was pretty good. It was slow, but we're talking deep dish pizza here, so I'll wait the requisite 45 minutes. 

Back to the taste...the plain ole deep dish with mushrooms was just that...plain. There wasn't anything memorable about it. Zachary's is somewhat better, but I liked Pizzeria Uno the best for deep dish, though I think they changed names to Pizzeria SFO, and then maybe went out of business a couple years ago. Sigh. I guess I'll just stick with thin crust from Victor's or Gaspare's.
author: Lara L.

description:
Hands down the best pizza I've had in a very long time. I had heard all the hype and wasn't in a rush to try deep-dish pizza since I prefer thin-crust. That said, I must say that the cornmeal crust is crispy and delicious, not a thick mushy pile of dough below some toppings. 

The restaurant itself is also wonderful -- cozy without feeling crammed and lively but not too loud. Great place for a casual date or a small group of friends. 

Oh! Bring cash. We didn't realize it was cash only until we happened to see a sign on the wall at the end of our meal. Fortunately, we barely had enough cash to cover the bill and tip.
author: Mark V.

description:
2 bottles of French wine, a large deep dish pizza and huge salad feeding 4 for under $80?!

Uuuummm....Yes Please.

I was impressed with Little Star. A cozy restaurant with very friendly service and possibly one of the best jukeboxes in the neighborhood!

The waiter was raving about the Pumpkin Cheesecake. It must have been good because they ran out when it was time for dessert. No matters, everyone was already full.

Buttery, deep dish crust, topped with very fresh ingredients.

We will be back
author: Angela C.

description:
When~~~~  the moon hits your eyes
Like a big pizza pie
That's amore.~~

The piping hot pizza, what can I say? Well...  il pasto era molto squisito (the meal was delicious). 

It was very difficult hold myself back from eating and burning my tongue, my lips, and/or my face.

This place is a definite: "Must Try"
author: Cristoper C.

description:
The place is very nice and the pizza is great but remember to RESERVE, even on Wednesday we waited 40 minutes. 
Depending on your taste you may prefer the thick pizza or the thin one. I tried both and my bet is on the thin one, but as I said it's really personal : )
author: Steve E.

description:
We ordered the deep dish combination pizza which was very tasty and the crust is perfect.  Then pesto chicken pizza thin crust was ok, the chicken was dry.

However, there were a few weird things about Little Star that our group found odd.  First, the garlic bread came out "unprepared", so there were slices of toasted bread with a small tub of butter/fat and a roasted bulb of garlic that we had to make ourselves.  Frankly, I prefer my garlic bread to come out ready to eat already.  If I have to prep it, I might as well have stayed at home.  Second, the spicy buffalo wings weren't "buffalo style" at all.  It's like oven baked chicken wings with pepper and no hot sauce no ranch.  It was still good after a few dashes of tabasco, but just weird they say they are "buffalo wings".  The last thing is they don't offer pitchers of beer.  For a pizza joint, I guess that was all surprising to us.

The restaurant itself is very dark and it was hard to even see how much pepper flakes I was shaking onto my pizza.

Overall, the food was good and service was really good.  But unfortunately we won't make a trip all the way out from Daly City to the Western Addition just for Little Star Pizza.  Be advised that they take only cash....weird  Sorry folks, maybe it's just me.
author: Yun W.

description:
After reading all these great reviews of this place, I thought I had to try it out for myself. I called them a little after they opened on Saturday, I ordered the Little Star deep dish and a pepperoni deep dish for my kids. I ordered the pizza to go because I did not want to deal with the crowds or the difficult parking. I was told that it would take 30 min to bake, and when I got there in 35 min, the pizza was ready as promised. I was surprised that the place was not that crowded that night. Maybe because it was still only 5:30, and would get crowded later. Also, very disappointed that they do not accept credit cards!

When we got home and ate the pizza, I admit the pizza was good, but the sauce was very salty. The crust was excellent, but my wife and I really miss eating the deep dish from Pizzeria Uno. Our favorite there was the Spinoccoli pizza. We were a little disappointed with the pizzas, probably due to all the hype.

Next time, we will try Paxti's to compare.
author: Chester L.

description:
I sank my teeth last night in to one of the best pizzas I've ever eaten. So why not 5 stars?

I had to wait an hour for a table, and then for the pizza. Be prepared to wait. Also be prepared for the host to lie about wait times to keep you on the curb until a table opens up.

We had both a deep dish Mediterranean and a deep dish Little Star, both highly recommended.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Can't stop thinking about it, even though I ate there over 6 weeks ago! (just never got around to the review :)

Caveat- you may not be overwhelmed with lust for this place, I know one member of our dinner party wasnt, though he did say that it wasn't bad.

Otherwise this place is fantastic. There is something about their dough that I really like. That and the pizza tastest FANTASTIC!!!  nuff said!!

Other than the food, the staff does their job well, and the setting is dim and comfortable. The place isnt huge and was almost full when we went (Thursday night) so its definately possible you might have to wait sometimes.

Really I have nothing negative to say at all.
author: Josh S.

description:
The perfect food! Little star has great pizza, but also great salads and desserts.

I wish they were open before 5pm!

Deep dish is the best, semi-friendly staff, but hip, so that's ok!

Always hot and always fresh.
author: thrasher b.

description:
This place like...totally rocks.  The pizza is awe-inspiring.  It's like the Statute of David of deep dish pizzas.  It's like an idealistic, unreachable vision of what a pizza can be.  Except it acually exists and is super yummy.  Can you imagine if David was real?  Yeah.  That good.

Am I exaggerating?  Probably a little.  But it is really good and has earned its exalted five-star status.

The restaurant can get a little crowded but it's cozy and warm.  This gets three thumbs up!  (I'll borrow one from someone else to emphasize my point.)
author: Aron L.

description:
Look out Zack's! Little Star has a lip up on your crust.

First off my friend and Derm turned me on to this spot and his batting average is in the 800s, so my expectations were high and they were met.

I took my kids and their friend whom is a meat and cheese girl. She looked like she was going to cry when I told her what I had ordered. After all we just got off a few buses, walked several blocks and waited 1 hour. Why such a sad face? Mushrooms, fetta , onions and garlic were the cause. They don't have cheese pizza? 

Two bites into this pie and she was asking how many slices she was allotted.  

BTW - my boy has crowned this the best pie ever. L'Salyer's  review to come after his restriction is lifted.
author: John S.

description:
I have finally found it! The great pizza place within walking distance from my apartment (though a little farther than I would have liked). I came here with my mom and sister and we all loved it.

My sister's a vegetarian and they had a good selection of veggie specialty pizzas. We had the "Little Star" appropriately enough, which was delicious. The crust was great--crisp but not hard--and the toppings/cheese/crust ratio was just right.

If you eat in, there are a nice selection of beers on tap and wines by the glass. But the seating area is pretty limited, so you'll probably have to wait a bit for a table. Well worth the wait, though, but probably wouldn't be a bad idea to do take out if you can (and you're hungry).
author: jim o.

description:
I'd been hearing echoes of Little Star for months, maybe years, but couldn't bring myself across the bay for deep-dish what with Zachary's pizza just a few minutes away. 

Then I heard the rumors that President Obama liked Little Star pizza so much, he had it flown to the white house. [side note: this is not exactly true. According to Little Star staff, someone at Little Star gave their recipe to a restaurant in Louisiana, where the Prez ate it and had it it flown to DC from there, not SF]

Ok, so I finally ventured over to Little Star. I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, but I still think Zachary's spinach mushroom stuffed pizza is simply better than the comparable "Little Star." Here's why:

-The cornmeal crust is nice and crispy, but the texture just doesn't work for me.  The grit from the cormeal was strangely distracting and unappetizing. 

-Tomatoes: Zachary's are just more flavorful and juicy. These were fine, but didn't give me the flavorgasm that I always get at Zach's.

-Spinach: LS leaves the leaves rather intact, meaning you get the spiny bits that make for a chewy, messy eating experience and a much more pronounced spinach flavor. At Zachary's, they chop up the spinach and remove said spiny bits, so you know there's spinach but you're not overwhelmed by it. 

Also, I gotta say you get more bang for your buck at Zachary's. I'm usually stuffed silly by two slices there. At Little Star, I ate four and was still hungry. However, Little Star's mixed salad is f-ing amazing and put's Zachary's attempts at salad to shame. And I don't even like salads. Get one. 

I also appreciate the fine selection of beverages at Little Star (cocktails AND beer AND wine) and the fabulous jukebox , so I gotta say for a dine-in experience Little Star beats Zachary's, but on pizza merit alone, Zachary's is and always will be the champ.
author: Reina G.

description: Nice place, with a refreshing old-fashioned jukebox. But the deep dish pizza is just OK: bland crust that's a little too thick, bland tomato sauce (but w/ a good chunky texture), and too thin a layer of cheese. I like Patxi's much better.
author: George F.

description: I've never been a fan of pizza and when my bf's sister wanted to take the family out to dinner, I couldn't complain. We started off with a salad which was pretty good. We also ordered the chicken wings and those were super tasty! It had a hint of curry. We ordered 2 pizzas. A deep dish chicken pizza and a veggie pizza. Both were delish. The crust was probably the best part! I've never been a crust girl but seriously, you need to try it to understand what I'm talking about. Oh, the veggie pizza was soo hearty that I didn't even miss the fact that there was no meat in it. 4 stars for the pizza and chicken wangs! And 1 extra star for the fact that this is President Obamas favorite pizza joint whenever he comes over to this side of town!! Loves it!
author: Esther M.

description: This place was sooo yummy.  It was our 1st stop for a 4 day trip to SF - and what a great way to start it!  We stayed in Union Square and took one of the buses to this great neighborhood.  We walked right in and ordered a large deep dish, cheese and a large salad to share.  I loved, loved the salad. REAL greens with yummy gorgonzola and walnuts - delish!  The place was packed with everything from families to retired folks - if you have a larger party - be prepared to cram yourselves into a small round table.  There is also a small bar.  The place is small and noisy - so not the best place for conversation....
author: H G.

description:
It's not Chicago deep dish but it's damn close!  I love all of its chewy goodness, tangy tomato sauce, and yummy toppings.  The garlic bread is incredible.  So is the spinach salad.  And unfortunately for me, I can never seem to get out of this place without ordering all of the above.

If you are watching your figure, stay away from this place.  It's dangerous to your wardrobe.
author: H B.

description: Little Star deep dish was mediocre. The flavors of the pizza were good but the crust was ok.  I've had pizza from Gino's East and Lou Minalti's and Little Star doesn't even come close.  The best local deep dish I've had is still Zachary's.
author: L C.

description:
I feel a little bad giving Little Star "only" four stars because they didn't do anything wrong.  Their signature 'little star' deep dish was excellent: substantial without feeling heavy, not burying the spinach taste in garlic and cheese but also not coming off like a bowl of roasted vegetables dumped on a pizza crust.  It was ready on time and hot.  Two things keep it from being five stars for me:
1)They don't deliver.  This is probably a completely unrealistic thing to expect of them, but it's nevertheless inconvenient if one doesn't have a car handy.  It happens that I'm lucky enough to have a parking space and a car, but I think a car-based business (even partially/inadvertently) doesn't quite earn the 5th star.
2)They're also just expensive enough to require a (again, probably unrealistic) level of stand-out taste.  I think they're great, probably the best I've had in the Bay Area, but they didn't change the way I think about pizza or anything, so I can't quite give them the fifth star for this on a taste basis either.

Obviously, I'll be back, and maybe I'll  re-rate higher, but right now I'm just not quite ready to give all five.
author: Nathan P.

description:
I'm very specific about pizza.  To simplify things, I mostly tell people I don't care for it much, but that's not true.  I like drippy NY thin crust with cheeze folded into a sandwich.  Other than that, pizza must be grease free and have a crispy crust.  This leaves top tier pizzetta and the very best deep dish.

Little Star is consistently unbelieveable.  We are in the area, and eat there pieriodically, but more often do take out.  The food is always great - fresh, delicious well combined ingredients that are succulent without being greasy, and most critically the crust is outstanding.  Thin crust is really good as well.  Salads are consistently excellent as well.

The staff is friendly, helpful and spot on for scheduling, which I really appreciate when I walk over to get my pie and don't get stuck with a soggy pie or waiting for 15 minutes.  This is tricky to get right, and I really appreciate it.
author: Stefan A.

description: Delicious! Great deep dish pizza.
author: Brad W.

description:
very good pizza. better than zacharys! both their deep dish and thin crust are crispy! chicago style pizza in SF!

they have such a great variety so try all of them!
author: J G.

description: Get the classic deep dish pizza and garlic bread..dont eat anything several hours before because this pizza will give you serious food coma.
author: Wesley M.

description: Pizza here is amazing. Got a surprise bday party here and couldn't have been happier. The spicy chicken wings are amazing as well. Nice selection of beer. Love the atmosphere. Kinda easy to miss if you're just driving by, but if you find it you'll be in love! The Classic was amazing so was the pesto and the mediteranean.
author: David Y.

description:
i've now officially tried all 3 deep-dish spots in the bay area(little star, patxi's, zachary's). little star had its good points and its bad points. pizza-wise, i'd rank it last place among the three. i just wasn't that impressed. patxi's was so much better to me. it was greasier(again, a good thing), cheesier, and the sauce wasn't too chunky. prices and wait-time are about the same. our pizza was a little too small, but that's our fault for not getting the large. i wish they had a medium, though...

drink-wise, i'd rank them 2nd. patxi's, again, comes in #1 because of their $1 pbr's. it's only $2.25 here, which isn't bad, and all alcoholic drinks are a dollar off during happy hour. they also have mixed drinks here, which is a nice touch. 

little star dominates the other 2 in terms of appetizers in deserts. the other two only have salad for apps, little star has hot wings and garlic bread. the hot wings were amazing! big, juicy, spicy, and it had a smokey/different flavor to it. i loved it more than the pizza. it is convenient, considering all deep-dish pizza's take 30+ minutes to make. for desert, we had the chocolate chip/cookie dough gelato. it was also fantastic. the other two places don't have desert at all. 

lastly, i'll compare convenience/service. i'd rank them dead-last. the crowd was very douchey and annoying. this is a restaurant, not a frat party, you dumbasses. our waiter was very nice, no complaints there. patxi's wins because they deliver and they serve by the slice(so does zachary's, but only during certain hours).

overall, it was a cool experience. i think i'd actually come back here for the wings and gelato, and maybe try the thin crust. but if i'm craving deep-dish, it's patxi's all the way.
author: Andrew T.

description: Wonderful beer on tap. It's a busy place so arrive early if you want to get a seat or, like me, order it for pickup. The service is always nice and they have great pizza pies. My favorite is the classic deep dish. No one in the city does it like Little Star!! Seriously, I've tasted them all. I love their bread, always fresh and crispy. Great quality of products on their pizza. The cheese and veggies and meat are all good things. This is a great place to go with a date or with a small group. They don't take reservations so again, come early or be prepared to wait. The pizza is worth it though!
author: Sari S.

description: Best Pizza I have ever had in Cali. The classic is my favorite, you can not go wrong with that one.
