It is always extremely busy, so just expect a long wait, but it is definitely worth it. I crave their pizza just about every week. I have had deep dish busy from many places, and the crust is unexplainably good. If you are looking for a great pizza  in SF, look no further.
author: Michael C.

description:
There pizza did make me sick.  The service was all right!  but I have never tried the thin crust but the other crust DEEP DISH, not worth it WHATSOEVER at all.  Of course, if you know pizza you will know that!
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
I went again last night and I must say the salad was awesome but there deep dish is not really all that, I think people in SF need to learn more about what a TRUE GOOD DEEP DISH IS.......because it is not valid here at all!
author: Tamara M.

description:
Flippin' AWSOME!!!!! Get the" KOOL-AID". You will know, just ask for it.
Say Word...Word!
author: Lou Z.

description:
I love this pizza. I have tried three different varieties and all were outstanding. The downside, the noise. I believe that too many places today feel that if it is not loud people are not having a good time. The establishment turns the music up, the cliental screams to have a conversation and all of sudden concert level noise becomes the norm for having a bite to eat. i couldnt wait to get out of here.
Don't bother to wait, order take out and enjoy your pie.
author: Cathy M.

description:
Love the lighting. Dark and scary.

Special pizza on the menu was Prociutto, Arugula, some other crap that I can't remember. It was truly remarkable.

Good Caprese, but not great. 

Service a bit slow. 

No Credit or Debit cards? What the crap? $0.25 ATM fee, so I guess it's excusable, but come on, nobody is cash only anymore.
author: Ryan P.

description:
The deep dish Little Star is tops.  
I'll actually crave this pizza.  It's the crust.  So butter. 
Little Star and a bottle of champagne.  Perfect!!!
author: M E.

description:
Rockin deep dish pizza, on par with Zachary's in East Bay and the original Uno's/Due's in Chicago (not the Uno's chain silliness Uno's you have at the airports...).  This place is more of a bar with great pizza and tables than a restaurant and is a bit dark.  Servers are friendly but it's a bit loud and not kid-friendly

It's cash only.
author: Jim M.

description:
I love Zachary's pizza in the East Bay.  I love even more Little Star.

PBRs in the can for $2...classic.  We had a large group of 7 people and it took a while to sit down, but it was worth the wait.  We got the garlic bread and 2 deep dish pizzas.  The pizza was really good and I am not sure if it was really good because I was starving, or it is just that good. I am sure it was both.

I can't wait to go back.
author: Dan D.

description:
I recently just found this place out from, yeah, yelp. I decided to give it a try and definitely not disappointed =) I was afraid the waiting would be a bitch, but apparently not. 

The pizza was GOOD and loved that crust! For some reason their pear cider was amazing. The place is small and intimate. A little bit loud but understandable. I was sitting next to a table full of blonde bitches. 

The price is a little high and definitely not something I would go for pizza all the time, but once in a while I think it's a great indulgence.
author: Perry S.

description:
ITS HERE! Finally, a pizza in California that is true to my Chgo born and bred taste buds.

All other Chicago style pizzerias beware - you are doomed. Little Star is the real deal so imposters take back your stale, dry crusts you claim to be authetic, cause Little Star will smoke you with their cornmeal crust that is crispy yet chewy, and strong enough to hold the motherload of toppings for your za.

The classic (minus the green peppers cause they kill my insides) is for me. And that side salad is the bomb, and cheap so don't make excuses and just order it.

Oh - and don't forget a side of anchovies, my favorite, yum yum! Ok, skip it if you are freaked out by now but get over there ASAP! Warning though -my cravings for pizza always come up first on Mondays, the day they are closed.

If you have a car, its worth the gas to call ahead and pick it up and gorge in the privacy of your home.

Live on Pabst Blue!
author: Sylvie L.

description:
If the pizza wasn't so completely amazing, I would have brought this place down to one star based on the wait alone. On a weekday evening (not a Thursday or a Friday, but I can't remember which day specifically), our party of 3 were told to come back in 45 minutes for our table. So we did. We waited for two and a half hours after that. No joke. No exaggeration.

Thankfully, the pizza was mouthwatering and completely satisfying. We had the deep dish classic and it worked out for 3 people. I recommend you go. I also recommend you bring a book.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Sweet Christ i love this place. 

The west coast answer to Giordano's and Gino's East in Chicago. the only problem is that i dont go here enough, and i live 4 blocks away. The signature Little Star deep dish is the most manly vegetarian meal you will ever eat. the salads are serious as a heart attack.

oh and another problem is that i'd weigh 700 lbs if i went here everytime i got the notion.
author: Matt H.

description:
Definitely will be back, to try a deep dish pizza.

We tried the thin crust pizza and were pretty impressed as it now replaces Amici's as our first alternate to more 'authentic' Italian pizzas like in North Beach...Always a great sign when your pizza comes out and it's not burnt or lacking in crispiness.

Interior looks like a great place to stick around and eat in although we got ours to go.

I read that the deep dish pizza is Zachary-esque so that will be next to try but it will be hard, IMHO, to dislodge Zacharys as king of deep dish in the Bay Area...Of course, they're off to a good start with their thin crust.

Good luck parking in the area, btw

Update:  Finally tried the deep dish...Excellent!
author: Barca F.

description:
Friendly, great service.  The drinks were good - nice selection of beer on tap and bottles, and the cocktails were good too.

The chicken wings were good - had a nice sauce.  I was disappointed with the pizza.  I felt it was smothered with tomato puree.  All I could taste was tomato puree and the crust.  The crust is really good.  Would've given it a 2 star (for the crust, service and drinks) except that the people I was with said it was subpar that day though it's usually better.  At the price I don't know if I'd bother going back.
author: S C.

description:
Best pizza this side of Chicago!

I used to travel to Oakland, Berkeley or San Ramon  to a Zachery's Pizza to get my Chicago-style pizza fix.  

Then we attended an election-eve party where we had our first Little Star pizza.  This is OMG pizza!  Perfect cornmeal crust and a tomato sauce with just the right sweet-bitter balance.  We'll be regulars from now on!

Cash only!  But there's an ATM in the lobby that charges a consumer-friendly $0.25 service fee.

Call ahead and pick up if you want to save some time and avoid the crowds.  Sorry, no delivery.
author: Dave C.

description:
First time visit last night and we got lucky w/ immediate seating since it was only about 6pm. Our server was super nice and very attentive. 

Had a large mixed green salad w/ vinaigrette, tomatoes, chopped walnuts, gorgonzola cheese and red bell peppers. Normally I hate walnuts, but together w/ the cheese it was awesome and there was no bitterness to the nuts. 

My friend and I had a small deep dish cheese pizza to which we added an assortment of our own toppings. 

WOW---I LOVE THIS CRUST. When I told my Zachary's Pizza-loving friend that I think it's better than Zachary's, he paused, hemmed, hawed, and wanted to debate me. But he only persuaded me to agree that it's equally good, just different. I think the cornmeal in the crust gives it an extra boost of flavor and crunchiness that Zachary's is missing. Zach's crust is just too thick, tough and filling sometimes.

Anyway---to top off a perfect meal, the freaking music on the jukebox was the best I've heard from a jukebox in a long time. Depeche Mode and The Smiths, for real? YAY!  Yes yes yes, I know, someone had to pay to pick those songs and they deserve some of the credit, but props to Little Star for even having those bands as an option in the machine!

AND finally-they have one of the best logos in the City.
author: C G.

description: Definitely the best pizza in San Francisco.  It's not as good as Zachary's in Berkeley, but I live in San Francisco, so I guess Little Star is my new go to joint (except not really because I don't live in the neighborhood, and you know how San Franciscans are, if it's more than an 8 block walk away, it's kiiind of farrrrr) .... I would totally get fat from pizza if I lived within 8 blocks though, delicious.
author: Greg J.

description:
Little Star should be the face of San Francisco pizza!! It's Chicago style pizza meets San Francisco. Light, deep-dish...if that makes sense. 

Great wines, inexpensive beer, and impeccable service!! 

This is one of my "Top 10" places to eat in San Francisco.
author: Scott C.

description: Not a fan of Deep Dish Pizza? You will be... Not a fan of Vegetarian Pizza? Eat the "Little Star" and You will be...Corn bread crust is insanely delicious. Everything else is too with the combo of the freshest tomato sauce, spinach, feta, mushrooms and other wonderful ingredients. This is a pizza you can't stop eating even after your full! Classic sausage jus as good. So fun to dine in or do take out. My cousins and I had the best time here last night! Super festive* With already a billion rave reviews, all I can say is this place is a must do~
author: Sandi P.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and had to wait about 25 minutes for a party of 4.

I admit, I liked the thin crust pizza better than the Chicago deep dish pizza. I was never really a fan of lots of dough/carbs, even when I lived in Chicago. Thin crust pizza is definitely one of my favorites. We got the thin crust classic (mushrooms, sausage, onion, and green peppers) and the Mediterranean deep dish. Two small pizzas definitely fed all 4 of us pretty well, and there were still two slices leftover in the end.

There honestly isn't anything not to love about pizza. There are some pretty amazing pizza places in NYC, but I can't complain about Little Star.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I have only done take-out from Little Star, as I live down the street and my boyfriend and I like to dine with a flick. Their pizza is fantastic. The cornmeal crust is delicious, and their ingredients are fresh, tasty, and well-made. Look for the nightly special, as it's not on the menu, and usually awesome. As I understand and have seen, they have great beers on tap and a nice wine selection. Their house salad is super good as well, great dressing and not-too-simple, as many house salads can be at italian joints. 

One downside is that they're cash only, which I often forget. Bring cash!
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Deep dish pizza, you are a hawt mess. One look and I go crazy for that tangy tomato sauce, falling off sideways but just enough to get caught by the cheese, oh cheese, oh creamy ricotta, peeking from layers of ooey gooey mozzaralla and succulent vegetables. Buttery mushrooms send a wave of warmth down my back and onions, ever so blackened and sweet, push me over the edge. I start to sweat a little, pant a little, beg a little. And then I remember - it's just pizza. Crazy OMFG sexy pizza! Mmmmm.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I went to Little Star pizza one rainy night in February to see what all the hype was about (I had seen it plugged on Diggnation). It's a pretty small place, easy to miss unless you looking for (especially at night).

I ordered the classic, and deep dish. It was delicious. The crust has a wonderful texture: crispy on the bottom and soft in the middle. The toppings were very top notch, none of the disgusting stuff you see at most pizza chains. The bartender was very nice, and kept my drinks coming. Altogether, the taste of the pizza was superb. Everything mixed together so well: the texture of the crust, the flavor of the toppings If the taste of the cheese, and the amount of sauce.

It does have a very long wait list, so if you go on a weekend be prepared for that. The interior is small, but charming, being decorated with all sorts of interesting trinkets. It's worth a visit if you're anywhere in the Western division and hungry for some pizza. Heck, it's worth a visit if you're in the city, and in the mood for pizza.
author: Anthony G.

description: Oh, Little Star Pizza.... how I missed my slice of Pi. Since I was a bit spoiled in Chicago and Saint Louis with their deep dish pizza, I feel that I know what it takes in the deep dish realm. I really enjoyed the Brass Monkey pizza we ordered from here.  We gobbled our slices up like that and had tons left over for the week ahead. It was sort of pricey for pizza, but this definitely one of the better places for the dish in SF. The crust is one of the best parts for sure!
author: Nichole P.

description: This ain't Lou Malnati's.  Nope, not even close.
author: Hannah H.

description:
"Brass Monkey! That Funky Monkey, Brass Monkey-Junkie! That funky Monkey!"

We ordered the Little Star Pizza and the Brass Monkey. This is a huge pizza pie! It was heavy and full of great fresh ingredients. We enjoyed our cornmeal crust.
author: Amy M.

description: Been here a couple times since my last review...our waiter was awesome (guy with a beard, fedora hat, has a novel tattoo'ed on his arm). The pizza was great as always...best pizza ever in fact.
author: Chris S.

description:
Very good pizza. That's the point no?
But it has also very good music, and pretty unique. I couldn't tell until I came there with a friend of mine, completely crazy about David Bowie. And that's when the place played a rare song from David Bowie, apparently almost impossible to find on records.
Still I gave them only 4 stars because the music was too loud, even if it was good. ;-)
author: Jean T.

description: I just love this place!  When I say I want pizza in this is what I mean.  The wait can be terrible.  The staff is kinda surly and they want you in and out.  So what.  It's awesome there.
author: Reni W.

description: Great pizzer. Fantastic thick biscuit-ey crust, just what you need to hold yummy lasagna soup. Garlic bread was really good with mozz and fresh basil. Broccoli not listed as a topping choice... usually a good option for deep dish (with spinach, ricotta, etc). Pizza was heavy... (heavier than Patxi's)... no room for dessert although the cheesecake looked appetizing.
author: Tom H.

description:
After several more visits I have to give LS the fifth star.  Just wonderful pies.  We tend to do a lot of take out due to the long table waits.

Really great!  Reminds me of Chicago.  The pizza is deep dish and delicious.  The restaurant is dark and relaxing.  Admittedly Zachary's does have better Chicago style pizza comparable to the institutions in Chicago but it is located in the East Bay.  

I also recall good beer and music.
author: John S.

description:
I know, this is so last year, but sometimes you are not in the right place when the pizza whim strikes, or too-hungry to wait .  So when I was out Friday with a friend, we stopped in to see if we could get a table before Sunday Brunch.  We could and we did.  If there is a platonic ideal for thin-crust pizza, Little Star's is the one. Thin to the point of Kate Moss anorexia, crisp to the point of erudite and graced with a perfect, tangy sauce, this pizza is amazing.  Seriously, the best thin-crust in the City.  Get there early, since it gets way beyond-crowded around 7:30/8 pm.

Next go round, deep dish (and I don't mean Rosie and Star Jones gossip)....
author: philip c.

description:
A good deep dish pizza, if you like that sort of thing.  I don't think it's any better than Zachary's, except that the wait for a table isn't as long.  That's offset by the increased difficulty to find parking in the area (if, as I was last night, you're foolish enough to drive.)  The crust is a little better than Zach's, but not that much so.

The jukebox is excellent -- a broad, eclectic selection of music.
author: Eric W.

description:
Being a self-proclaimed pizza connoisseur , to get a perfect score is a tough thing to come by. But,  this place has it all... great deep dish pizza (thin crust is tasty as well), fantastic happy hour specials ($1 PBR), lovely staff, and its a 5 minute walk from my doorstep.

Pending on when you go, there may be a line, but well worth the wait. Some argue that the prices are high, but I think its well worth every penny. Plus, you end up having left overs, so its like 2 meals for the price of one!

When I moved here from the midwest, everyone preached to me about Zachary's in the East Bay. Finally I tried it, and I have no hesitation stating that Little Star is FAR BETTER than Zachary's.

Overall, 2 thumbs up....4.5 stars...molto bene...
Why are you still reading this.... go eat some pizza!!
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
Cheap beer on tap, pretty good.
Long wait for a table, hated it.
Weird clientele, ignore them.
Chicken wings and pizza, yum.
author: BrYan W.

description:
I used to work at the place that made deep dish pizza.
True deep dish pizza is hard to get right. I mean we would know when we f'd up the dough batch.
Little Star I love your cornmeal crust with lots of butter/shortening.
This crust is of the Gods... and I have gone too many times to count and it always tastes great. They never f- up the dough.
Great wine list- Great beers. I wish that this place would have taken over a larger space- but i guess that's what the mission Little Star is. 
I hope to try the thin crust soon, but it seems a waste not to get the deep dish. It's so rich and made so well.
Hats off to you Little Star- from one deep dish pizza maker to another.
Well Played.
author: shannon t.

description:
Deep dish pizza pie just like papa used to make it in Chicago. Too bad there were no mandolin players or limonchello. But, Little Star does have Blue Paddle Pilsner and very tasty wines. Don't miss the Classic pizza pie.
Cash only so be prepared. The ATM in the joint only charged me 25 cents.
author: Brett D.

description:
This is one of my favorite pizzaria in SF!  Both NY Style and Chicago are awesome with just the right crust and filling for the Chicago and perfectly thin crust for the NY style.

Another good thing to order here and to die for is the 1 pound chicken wings!  So good!  It has a resemblance of Jamaican Jerk Chicken, but slightly different and very good!!

If you haven't tried their pizza or the chicken wings, I would highly recommend you try it soon!
author: Rico d.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this place. Delicious food. Good service. Simple yet elegant decor. Down-to-earth owner. I'm from Chicago, and I think Little Star has the best deep dish pizza ever.

A little tip: bring the leftovers home. Letting the ingredients and seasonings marinate in the fridge overnight makes for a yummier pizza the next day.
author: Hanh P.

description:
They know how to layer that deep dish. The crust embodies perfection, its texture tricks my senses into thinking I'm eating thick, firm pie crust, the texture and butteriness is akin to that of cheese cake graham cracker crust . The quantity of cheese however, is not overwhelming. The marinara is perfectly seasoned with thick chunks of fresh tomato. The sausage is divine. I must admit ignorance to all of their other dishes, this is enough for me, The Classic Deep Dish. 

In all honesty I've never eaten in. I attempted the sit down two weeks ago and the wait was so long that I just phoned in my order from outside and took it to the park but really, I don't care, just give me plenty of napkins and a classic deep dish, it would get me through the worst time share presentation or accounting seminar, its that good.

Drivers: BEWARE of the boundaries of that handicap parking spot outside.
author: eric m.

description:
i love pizza but chicago style has never been my thing. maybe its my miami roots and the fact that deep dish isnt very popular down south.
ive been to chicago and wasnt too impressed since i thought the pizzas were too saucy and heavy.

so needless to say i was a little hesitant about little star especially when we got there and they told us they were out of thin crust.
so we settled on a deep dish cheese and a little star. both were amazing!!! omg that crust is divine!!!

we got a cheesecake to share for the table and it was devoured in less than a minute. it was so soft and smooth it almost felt like ice cream!!

i wish little star existed in miami (hint, hint) i think it would be a huge hit!!
author: jen r.

description: Yes, the wait can be long and the parking can be terrible, but it's worth it!  Going here requires a team effort.  The driver drops off the passenger(s) and they go in to get your name on the list.  The waiting party can order in advance as the other person parks; this will limit your wait time tremendously.  Go for the DEEP DISH.  The first time I went here, I had thin crust and was not impressed at all.  I wasn't going to ever come back, but someone invited us for a group party, so we gave it a second chance.  DEEP DISH ALL THE WAY!!!  The Little Star was good and so was the Mediterranean Chicken (we actually ordered the Brass Monkey, but they gave us Little Star instead).  The 2 large deep dish pizzas fed 6 of us surprisingly.  I read another yelper say 1 pizza can feed 3 people - so true.  Glad we didn't over-order...  The pizza is tasty without sauce running everywhere.
author: Jennie L.

description: I've been to the Little Star in the Mission and this location tasted better to me. It's all about the crust! Vegetarian pizza with the garden salad, a couple beers and a glass of sauvignon blanc, wonderful evening! I love the ambiance of the Little Star Pizza restaurants. Great neighborhood too. Don't expect to park anywhere close though.
author: Eva B.

description: We ordered to go...part of our 7x7 list, we were close by, and had to come here.  All the ingredients were fresh and the crust of the pizza was buttery x chewy...and damn good.  Not only were the ingredients some of the freshest that I've ever had on a pizza, it was the mozzarella cheese that stole the show.   Order anything on the menu, it's all good!!
author: Bryan L.

description: Yum! My favorite! This is exactly what good pizza should taste like. There is usually a wait, especially on weekend nights, but it's worth it.
author: Jade C.

description: Get in my belly!!!!! You delicious pizza. Thank you for being conveniently located next to my Casa cause I don't know what my stomach would do without you. Thin crust pizza that's actually crispy and just the perfect consistency and taste explosion in your mouth. I can't figure what could ever beat this beautiful creation that little star pizza has concocted. A slice of little star thin crust  and a black cherry soda and this will be one happy little lady.
author: Elisa M.

description: Came with JF after we were denied at NOPA (no reservation... :( we did make it back after an adventure during opera in the park...). After a long day of biking around SF, we were famished. Little Star reminds me of Zachary's in Berkeley: super deep dish pizza topped with way too much tomato sauce. The crust was super yummy though. Just not sure I would voluntarily return (I already go to Zachary's quite begrudgingly since my Cal friends adore the place)
author: Susanna W.

description: Place is amazing....I go everytime I'm in SF! Must have! Great for friend to get around a slice of deep dish and some beers.
author: Hovik N.

description: Not sure how missed reviewing this one, been here at least 7 times.  It's a must eat while in San Francisco. I'm moving to Hawaii and it was one of my lasts meals. My favs are deep dish Little Star, thin crust White Pie.
author: Kelli G.

description: Le bf took me here and we ordered the classic with additional toppings: corn, olives, and roasted garlic.  I must say it's one of the best deep dish pizzas I've ever had.  The service was also great and I would def. return.
author: Jane P.

description: I'm a big fan of the deep dish pizzas. I love the crispy corn meal crust and Little Star also makes a mean salad. Love this place!
author: Sweet D.

description: I brought my parents here (who are visiting from the east coast).  They loved this pizza so much, they couldn't stop talking about it.  We ordered the deep dish- I've always thought the sauce was a little strong, but there is a light sauce option= perfection.  My mom thought the cute blonde hostess was incredibly cheerful and on-point, there was a crowd of people waiting for tables, well worth the wait.  Minus one point for the loud music.  We love Little Star Pizza!
author: Liz Y.

description: I love, love, loove this place! My friend and I go here almost once a week and practically always order the same thing. There's always a wait, but it's totally worth it. Mixed salad and their deep dish name sake, The Little Star. Spinach, onions, garlic!, tomatoes, mounds of cheese and a cornmeal crust--it doesn't get any better.
author: Marie H.

description:
Probably the best pizza joint in the city. It's got a laid back atmosphere (people are talking, jukebox is playing), but it's still nice inside. The first thing you'll notice when you walk in is that it smells amazing in there!

The pizza lives up to the hype. The deep dish is loaded with toppings but surprisingly isn't very heavy. We had the 'Classic' and had no regrets. The garlic bread was also a bright spot worth mentioning--an impressive loaf of bread served with butter and a bulb of roasted garlic :)

The service was great too--everybody from the hostess to the servers were nice, helpful and funny.

Trust me--go here.
author: Rishi M.

description: I've been here 10+ times and never had less than a stellar experience. Mixed Green Salad and Classic pizza are amazing!
author: Matt O.

description: Although I prefer thinner pizza (Antica in SJ is by far my best), the deep dish pizza here was amazing.    The only down side is that they didn't have any coffee to finish off the meal!
author: Durif M.

description: The delivery system is complicated and pricey, but probably worth it because the restaurant seems small and slightly sketchy.  However, the pizza was totally worth it!  We got half classic and half mediterranean.  Really fast service and the medium deep dish was enough for 3 people with medium appetites plus some.
author: C X.

description: I heard that Little Star is the SF version of Zachary's and is the best Chicago pizza in the city unfortunately it was good but not even in the same league as Zachary's.
author: John R.

description: I've been going to this spot since it first opened and still dream about it and go back on a regular basis. The valencia location is closer to home, but I still prefer the nopa spot. I really, really, really wish they had delivery. Is that bad?
author: Roxanne L.

description:
Little Star offers some good pizza. I had the classic, thin crust with a bottle of their house white wine. It was a tasty meal. I would have liked to try their champagne cocktails, but that's for next time! 

If you don't know where you are going, it's a little hard to find, but their sign looks like Pacman. The interior is loungey and fantastic.
author: Lawren B.

description:
The best deep dish SF has to offer.  The moist cornbread crust rules. The Mediterranean Chicken my fav. 

Wishlist: more deepdish recipes/choices on the menu. Little Star's currently the best, but years ago it was Vicolo (behind the Hayes Valley Bar & Grill) that had no rival, offering an awesome veggie, four cheeses, pancetta, and an ever-changing variety of choices.

Hence Little Star, there's still room to surpass!
author: Ted W.

description: I love Little Star. I've been there many times for many different occasions and until this most recent visit, I'd always ordered the signature pizza "The Little Star". It was simply perfection and why mess with it? This time, I actually broadened my horizons and ordered the Mediterranean Chicken pizza. It was still delicious. The Western Addition location is far superior to the Mission location even though it is smaller. The jukebox is fantastic and the waiters are actually very friendly for San Francisco waiters. Almost every time I'm in the city, I end up here. It's my old standby and I love it.
author: Randi Y.

description:
Not only do they have fabulous pizza, they also have champagne cocktails! 
yum. 

The staff is great as well. We walked in 15 min before closing and they didn't make us feel guilty. Jessica, Our waitress was very sweet and attentive. We stayed late to finish our drinks and chatted with Jessica and the bartender. Great time, Great people, Great decor, GREAT pizza. 

Five stars for sure.

We ordered the Italian Combo (Pepperoni, salami, onions, green bells, black olives, pepperoncini) and added on feta and artichokes. Amazing. I can't wait to try the Little Star  (Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic)....deep dish style. mmmmm.
author: Summer C.

description: Hole-in-the-wall chicago style pizza joint.  I loved it.  Small place so seating is limited.  My friend and I got there at about 7:45PM on a tuesday night and got seated right away.. others who rolled in after us had to wait for a table.  I've also had Paxti's and I'd say I prefer that pizza over this, but it's still very good pizza.  I also recommend the hey kool-aid (champagne cocktail with black cherry soda)
author: Shaila L.

description:
While not quite as impressed as some of my friends, this place is still pretty good. I didn't get a chance at the meat, as I was dining with vegitarians, but what they did have was pretty good, especially the garlic bread.

But the price is just too high for pizza, ever.
author: Reverend D.

description:
The deep dish is decent.
I am shocked by the high ratings
I don' t think it's as good as zachary's, but I haven't tried since they first opened.
author: jeff k.

description:
I simply don't get it.  We're in the neighborhood and have eaten here three times, wishing it would be a great pizza place.  But it isn't.  Pizza not very good, overly salty.  

But we have also TRIED to eat here on two other occasions and called  to ask how long the wait was.  No reason to hoof it on down there if the wait was too long.  Both times the pipsqueaky girl who answered the phone told me that, since the phone was in the BACK of the restaurant, there was no way she could answer that question.  Her tone suggested that I was a pain in her butt, and that she could not be put out.  The first time she refused to peek out and check, and the second time I somehow convinced her that it was a reasonable idea and she did, um, check on the wait.  But what do you wanna bet she just set the phone down for a second and went back to twirling her hair before making up an answer for me?  Yeah, I think you're right.
author: Matilda S.

description:
Little Star was a lot more fancy than I would expect for a pizza place.  I believe it is the swankiest pizza place I've ever been to.  The champagne cocktails were interesting and rather tasty and came in way larger glasses than I would have expected.

The pizza was quite good.  The crust was very crunchy, not soggy or oily at all, which was good because there was a lot of cheese in that pizza.  The sauce was really delicious as well.  Overall, pretty good pizza.  It's up there with some of the best deep dish I've had.  

The wait was quite long, but service was fine once we were seated.  Luckily the pizza was worth it and the salad we had was decent too.  Prices were a bit high.  You're paying for ambiance a lot more than quality, I'd say.  Still though.. good pizza.
author: Matthew S.

description:
This place is nice to go early in the evening. At night it gets really crowded and on friday nights it is unreasonable. Beware!

The pizza is fine. It isn't spectacular but I do like the cornmeal crusts. it's nice to have something different on a pizza from time to time. Servers were nice but the hostess needs to learn how to estimate times better.

It's a fine place to go early if you want pizza but there are so many other better pizza places out there.
author: Josh J.

description:
I'll go back again and again. Their Deep Dish Pizza is surprising at first, but so delicious! Probably the best pizza I ever had.

It's most of the time crowded (average of 30min to 60min waiting time) but it's worth it. Oh, yeah, don't forget to bring cash, they are cash only :(
author: Matt T.

description:
Just good pizza! If you're a fan of deep dish,  you  need to eat here.  Fill's up rather quickly,  so get here early.  Good beer on tap as well.

Service: funny and friendly staff
Decor: Dark but cosy
Price: just right
Location: Western Addition
My Favorite: Little star w/ sausage...delicious!
author: M M.

description:
My daughter loves the thin crust pesto chicken. My wife and I love the deep dish little star - spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. Yumm, my mouth is watering as I am writing. 

We order take out from Little Star about once a week.
author: Oz B.

description:
I SIGNED UP FOR YELP SO I COULD TELL YOU HOW GOOD THIS PIZZA IS.

Seriously.  That should be enough right there.  It's better than Zachary's, hands down.

The baked actual garlic to spread on the bread was a nice touch too.
author: Justin G.

description: amazing! Thick and thin crust, these guys know and love pizza and both varieties scrumptious!
author: John B.

description:
the best: little star deep dish, thin crust white pizza, the salads, the garlic bread.  really nice selection of beer and wine at both locations.  

long line?  order to go...the pizza will be (almost) as delicious.
author: Melissa C.

description: I've lived in Chicago and had my share of deep dish pizza.  This is by far the best I've had in a while. Definitely a must try.  I had the original and the crust was perfectly crispy without being oily.
author: Sun M.

description: Fresh ingredients, not too cheesy, flakey crust; I am a fan!
author: Douglas R.

description:
We were recommended Little Star by a few friends that knew my love for a good pizza. Having never tried it I was excited to taste the deep dish pizza. 
The overall space is way too crowded to sit and have an enjoyable dinner without having to hear about your neighbors problems of the day. 
After we were cramped into our table the next shocker was opening the menu. I am used to high prices but this was over the TOP!! Really? Its only pizza!! The prices were enough to make me walk.
Finally, after ordering the pizza arrived. On a scale of 1-10 I give it a 5. it was tasty but I felt like I just ate a rock. Straight to my gut and stayed there all night. 
Overall I will not be going here again nor will I recommend it to friends.
Little Star is a 2 star in my book!
author: Gail T.

description: Ehh....came back to try the classic. meh....had one slice and was sick of it. Guess I gotta stick with the little star...that one was delicious
author: Betty N.

description: First time I had corn beard as the pizza dough.  It turned out to be a good idea.  Had some wine with my gourmet pizza.  Its a rather unique place.  You gotta try it.
author: S F.

description:
What else can I say that someone hasn't already? IT'S FUCKING DELICIOUS. 

Tried the cheese with onions (thin sliced) and their famous deep dish. Deep dish was much better, but don't get me wrong- the cheese and onions is not bad. 

They're super busy all the time so they try to get you to leave ASAP, in subtle ways like "accidentally" dropping the check by your table when you're only half way through your first slice.
author: Anthony J. C.

description: This place makes me quiver and jump for joy because it's so delicious.  Every part of the deep dish pizza is amazing from the tomatoes to the toppings to the delicious crust.  It's even amazing the next day.  It gets really crowded, very loud and I always have to wait.   Nearby parking sucks and it's a cash only... all of which I don't care -the pizza's that good.
author: Carmen S.

description: A greater percentage of San Franciscans like Little Star pizza than voted for Obama!
author: Luke M.

description: I love Little Star so much I want to take it behind the middle school and get it pregnant. Deep dish to die for.
author: Alex H.

description:
Deliciousness.  Cornmealy deep dish banished my abiding love of those memories from Pizzeria Uno in the mall back in the day when I was 10.  This is some serious crust, folks.  They must oil the heck out of the pans to get the crisp, but not greasy, edges while maintaining a tender inner crust.  We had the Classic, w/o peppers on my half, which was fully of chunky tomato sauce, onions, mushrooms and sausage.  The large was enough for dinner for two and heft leftovers.  I want to go back and try more.

It was busy on a weeknight, but not so much that we two had to wait long.  Service was friendly and attentive.
author: Jess Z.

description:
I'm from the east bay and around those parts it's all about zachary's spinach and mushroom deep dish.
A few weeks ago some friends mentioned Little Star and said it was very similar to Zach's
They were right, and that is a very very good thing

The signature "Little Star" deep dish pizza is a slice of tomatoey heaven with a crunchy cornmeal crust.
A large feeds four people perfectly (2 slices each.)

I also love the way they serve their garlic bread do-it-yourself style with a head of roasted garlic, a cup of creamy butter, and slices of toasted bread all ready to assemble and enjoy.
author: Sean R.

description: Really great deep dish pizza, but still not sure if it's worth the epic wait. Luckily, there's a bunch of cool art bars on Divis to distract you while you wait.
author: Lara C.

description: AMAZING deep dish pizza. Love the Little Star. A small pizza is enough for two people. Great for takeout! The pizza is layered 'inside out' which creates a scrumptious bite. Highly recommend trying at least once.
author: Christina G.

description: Pizza is really good, but it's pretty expensive in my opinion.  It also gets really crowded, which tells you its good, but it's annoying if you wanna eat there.  I also wish they delivered, that would be awesome.
author: christopher h.

description:
MMMMMMMMMM!!!!!!

I love thin crust Pizza, but was willing to try a stuffed one. It was delicious. but Lo and behold I realized they also have one of the best thin crusts in the city. YIPPEEE
author: butters m.

description:
Update: the owner wrote me a nice, personal email and encouraged me to try a little earlier for better seating (less cold, brrrr) and less noise.  ...maybe after a drink at your too small bar.  But surliness aside, I'm upgrading to 4 stars.  SF isn't by nature a pizza town, but these guys come pretty close to getting it right.  Takeout all the way: 4 stars!

***
Two things served here: pizza and salad (plus drinks).

The pizza is definitely out of this world (sit-down or take-out), but the cash-only business burns from time to time (like hot cheese on the roof of my mouth), especially when you've just come from tea time at Cafe Abir (another Divis haunt).

Tried eating here with my hot date and found it extra crowded, though the pie made it well worth the wait.  Service was par, not sub and definitely not above.  Salads were good, albeit too heavy on the cheese (when the only other choice on the menu is pizza, duh, go light on the cheese!).  ...it's the kind of place to bring four friends, then have mini, scream-in-his/her-ear chats on the side.  Plus, there's a LOT of pizza to share.  ...makes for great leftovers!

Favorite pie: thin crust with artichoke hearts, tomatoes & garlic...haven't tried the meat pies, but sure they're good, too!  Deep dish pies almost feel like Chicago, but with less grease.  The deepest, please!

S'more drawbacks:
(1) the front door never stays shut, so if you're sitting or waiting to sit near the door at night, bring layers.  Brrrr!
(2) the music is definitely awesome (contemporary indie hits mixed with 80s & 90s classics), but everytime I've been inside (3 now), it's always way TOO loud!  I'm used to yelling at a bar, but when I go out to dinner, it's nice to eat AND socialize, not just stuff my face and constantly cup my ear, like "What?!"

Solution: Get take-out (way better than Stelladoro's just down the street) or maybe try for a night when the speakers are blown.

...Great food ruined by too much noise!
author: Carrot C.

description:
Lovely deep dish cornmeal pizza. I can't say I loved their flour crust as much as their cornmeal pizza. My favorite is definitely the mediterranean pizza (chicken, veg, cornmeal crust). Definitely the pizza for those who love it very saucy. 

It's a place for the trendy and young. Small tables, minimal lighting. Nice wine list and fun champagne cocktails. A place to go for an exceptional, hip pizza experience. 

But I love my Za pizza better!
author: Bubbles L.

description:
I love the pizza, salad, chicken wings and the cheesecake.  This place is excellent.  Because it is so incredible, you can almost always find a huge crowd at this place.  I have never eaten there, I always order and pick it up because its too packed.  

They offer deep dish or thin crust pizza, both are excellent depending on what you feel like.  The Mediterranean chicken deep dish is one of my favorites.  If you aren't in the mood for pizza, the chicken wings are some of the best.  Don't forget about the cheesecake!
author: Molly A.

description: LOVE,love, love this place.   Dangerously close to my house, though.  The Little Star deep dish pizza is absolutely divine.  I dream about this pizza! mmmmmm.  Great service and cozy place with a great jukebox.  Suggestion:  please expand your wine list!
author: Jamie R.

description: Good pizza, not great. A little too heavy for me, with a thick cornmeal crust.  Four stars for food, - 1 star for long lines and sometimes not answering phone for takeout orders.
author: Julie W.

description: Like everyone else who has been here ever, I cannot sing the praises of this spot enough. I am damn near obsessed with the deep dish Little Star pie as well as the thin crust White Pie. Their mixed salad is to die for - perfect balsamic, gorgonzola, veggie mix. It's a treat of a salad and one I often find myself calling in for pick up. About that - what a delightful, friendly and professional staff! Yummy wine list, delicious desserts - seriously, I know it's tough, but leave room for the cheesecake. You won't regret it. Cozy atmosphere, intriguing artwork, there's really nothing not to love about Little Star! Come one, come all.
author: Maya B.

description: Wow just wow ' this place is amazing it totally is the best deep dish in the city ! Special BBQ chic pizza but sub the chikn for mushrooms totally awesome!!!!  Iyar warn you the red pepper has cayene pepper in it and it'll mess u up!
author: Gurvinderpal S.

description: Dude, the pizza...AWESOME...that is if you enjoy the deep dish Chicago style where one slice makes you super full!  We had wings to begin with which I wouldn't order again, a salad makes more sense with that much pizza.  They are pretty much always busy, and they only take cash, so bring plenty.  I think we waited for a table for 3 for around 45 min on a Thursday night.  Also, it's very small, and so are the tables.  Once you get a pizza on there you don't have room for anything else.  You also get to know your table mates and people around you very well.
author: Tina D.

description: Brian, the owner of Little Star contacted me about my review and explained the situation that they had on Saturday and apologized for his host. It makes me feel better to know that this is an establishment where the owner takes the time to read the yelp reviews and respond to any unpleasant experiences. Go Brian! I'll give them a second chance
author: Kristen M.

description: We went there for dinner on sat. Night. About a 30 min. Wait to get seated. Not bad. We got the little star deep dish with pepperoni instead of onion and it was great. Had the garlic bread appetizer and that was interesting as well. Overall a good experience with great service. A bit pricey but you get what you pay for. You also pay for health insurance $1 per person that dines there. Interesting!
author: Genaro R.

description:
my friend said this was obama's favorite pizza joint... that's saying a lot since he's from the birthplace of deep dish. but even so... i was still pessimistic on whether it was an authentic chicago style pizza since i've never had one outside of chitown. 

it's the real deal folks. i wouldn't go as far as to say it's my favorite or the best i've ever had but it sure took me back. it was 10:30 when we ordered so we only had a large classic deep dish (sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers). 

my knock on this place is the pies are a little small. the large is the size of a medium (at least from what i'm used to) but hey... it's california... people actually care about how their body looks. also the pizza wasn't THAT hot when we got served... maybe it was precooked and they just heated it up?? 

regardless... i enjoyed my meal. instead of driving 2000 miles for some deep dish... i only have to drive 400.
author: John L.

description: Best corn meal crust ever! Double espresso gelato?? Muito buono. We heard about this from the 100 things to eat before you die list. The crust blows the water out of other deep dish joints in town. Only good rival is Zachary's in the east bay. Get the veggie deep dish and the White Out thin crust. Follow in down with some of their dark lager on tap for $3.25 during HH and you will NEVER look back.
author: Scott D.

description: My love affair with pizza goes way back.  Shakey's pizza was a staple of our family gatherings growing up in Angeles City (Philippines) and ever since then I've always been on a search for great pizza.  I've also drifted between being a fan of Chicago style pizza vs New York style pizza.  I'm back in my Chicago style pizza phase hence my review of Little Star.  The pizza here is comparable to Zachary's.  I also love the fact that I don't have to drive all the way to Berkeley for a good deep dish pizza.
author: Brian A.

description: Best Chicago Pizza that I have found in San Francisco! It was affordable and lived up to expectations! I wish they had delivery but they were pretty accurate on when the pizza would be ready so it was super easy for pick up! I would drive again from the marina to get this pizza!
author: Kimberly M.

description: Their cornmeal crust rocks.  I usually order the classic, with a caprese salad and sometimes the spicy chicken wings.  I feel lucky to have this spot in my hood.
author: jane d.

description:
Best deep dish pizza in the city by far!  I love the fact that they don't drown the pizza in cheese, that tomatoes are the star of the pizza.  Delicious and redonkulously filling.  Oh, and how can you not love a place that has PBR on the menu???  

The wait is a pain in the ass and their "bar" is, well, really not, so head across the street to Mini Bar after you put your name in.  Little Star will give you a time estimate.  Then just check in while you relax in a booth at Mini Bar.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
well, i was talking to fellow YELPer alvin x. over drinks at absinthe (always  5 stars in my heart) about the stunning lack of truly good gourmet pizza in this otherwise culinarily blessed burgh.  you see, i am from chicago, a stalwart in lovingly crafted, but by no means gourmet pizza, and when i moved out here for journalism school i was all like "yo, where's the pizza?"  Luckily good old al, (also five stars in my heart), had an answer for me: "yo, man, like, the pizza i$ at little star on divishnizzledero and fult-spot."  i, being the gourmand greyhound that i am, raced over at full speed  and, to my gullet's dismay, was stopped by a massive queue.  I gave me and alvin's name to the mystical native american princess at the front (which i thought was a rather interesting touch, but meshed well with the decor) and waited........

being from chicago i know that deep dish takes a long time, so I tried to pre-order for us from the hostess, she politely informed me that this was impossible, so i cried into my beer for 45 minutes waiting for a table.  seated...we ordered the little star special from an enchanting little puffy haired star-child and told him to keep the beers coming.  over talk of Plato's concept of gustatory virtue alvin and i whiled away the intervening time and began to (in the words of the talking heads) stop making sense.  whatever.  the food came and it was quite good.  the crust was not quite the toothsome corn-meal that I had grown up with, but as approximations of deep-dish pizza go, this was one of the closest.  wayy better than that old california pizza kitchen.  the sauce, superb. and i could drink that boont amber till the big one comes.

4-stars

-1 for the crust.
author: zac m.

description:
Holy crap, I love this place. Whenever I have guests in town I always take them here because we are guaranteed great service, its a really fun atmosphere, affordable and the wine list is awesome. 

Oh, and of course the Pizza is great! Thin crust or deep dish, you can't go wrong.
author: Delilah S.

description:
Litlle Star gets 5 Big stars, yes I am a dork, but I don't care. I love this pizza. I love it so much that I recently had to move to Los Gatos from SF due to work, yet I was just telling my husband.... "tomorrow night we are heading up to the city, and we are eating at Little Star....okay?"

I am a pizza snob at heart and I know good pizza. 

I get the thin crust, mushrooms, extra sauce.   

oh and a can of Pabst beer of course.

yum!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
bomb
thats all i can say 
it was so good 
service was cool
atmosphere was cool
jukebox 

pizza was unreal
author: Trent D.

description:
The fact that this place has a 4.5 star average scares me as I'm beginning to realize what I may be in for now that I live in California. 

Saturday afternoon, for whatever reason around 4pm I suddenly had a craving for deep dish pizza. Not sure why, i generally never get cravings for it, but none the less, I had a craving and it wasn't going away. I hopped on yelp and after reading briefly it didn't seem like a hard choice: Little Star was the place to go for deep dish pizza in San Francisco. 
To add to my later disappointment, my girlfriend wasn't at all in the mood for it, but I did one hell of a job convincing her how good it would be so she hopped on board. 

We peeped the menu on-line and ordered the 'classic' and 'little star' 9" deep dish pizza's. The garlic bread also got a nice review so we added that to the mix. The nice gentlemen on the phone confirmed my order, gave me my total and informed me that it was cash only. I liked that he did this because I've been to multiple places that haven't and it really sucks when you show up with just a credit card. 

So, parking wasn't easy but since I knew I'd be quick i blocked the parking structure next door, ran in and grabbed my food. The place was packed and actually looked like it would be a fun place to grab a beer and pizza. My food was ready and they had me out of there in just a minute. So far so good. 
I get home and I can already taste the food. we open up both boxes, dig in, and I just give my girlfriend a look. She can tell, and she starts laughing(a sympathetic laugh) because she knew how much i was looking forward to this. 
The pizza certainly wasn't terrible. It just wasn't really that good. The crust is very different. I believe its cornmeal which seems to be why some people love it, but not this guy. The peppers and mushrooms on mine weren't flavorful and the texture was very bad. All in all just not good. 
My girlfriend was pretty blah with her description as well but I generally don't like spinach pizza so i didn't try. The sausage chunks were large which was nice, and tasty, but the pizza just didn't do anything for me. 
About 10 minutes after my first bite we realized we ordered the garlic bread and got excited again because we thought that may salvage a little bit of dinner. Well, we opened the bag, found a loaf wrapped in foil with a plastic container that had butter inside. I opened the foil and didn't smell any garlic. They just gave us bread and f'in butter. At this point I nearly hit myself in the face with a beer bottle. I may have given the place 3 stars initially(since they don't have 2.5), but not after this. 
One of the 5 star reviews I read below actually said they consider this better than the deep dish they have in Chicago. I have never been to downtown Chicago, but I've been to the outskirts. I've also had deep dish all over the northeast and I don't know what the hell this person is talking about. Generally i consider Pizzeria Uno to be 'airport/mall' food, but I guarantee if I lined up the 'Chicago classic' from uno against the 'classic' from little star, I think people who love little star would fall over from how good the Chicago classic is. I just really can't believe that this is considered awesome deep dish pizza. 

I'm going home for Christmas very soon, and there are a ton of great places to eat high end food. I won't be going to any of those places however. They have those here in the Bay. No, when i land back east, it's gonna be all about chicken wings, pizza and deli sandwiches. Hmmmm, I can't wait!
author: Ryan M.

description: I dream about this pizza.  I've never had such great tasting pizza anywhere else!  My stomach is growling just thinking about it....mmmm
author: Ben N.

description: Smells great when you walk in. Intimate interior as well. Pizza was brilliant, deep dish style. Would give the crust a 7/10 tho for deep dish. Definitely would rank somewhere on my top 25 Greatest Pizzas of All Time List. If you dig pizza, you've gotta hit up this spot.
author: Kevin S.

description: This place is a little jem i love pizza and i love Little star..nice crispy base...yum..
author: Ronan M.

description: Most the reviews are of the Deep Dish- I ordered the thin crust, which may have been a mistake.  The pizza isn't bad, but the thin crust tastes similar to Mama Celeste frozen pizza.  That being said, the toppings were all fresh and flavorful.  The balance between the cheese and the sauce was very good.  Next time I will try the deep dish and possibly adjust my rating...
author: Chris C.

description: This location has visually interesting decorations and art, plus the bar is great for a good beer. We didnt have time to sit for a deep dish, so instead tried the thin crust garlic and chicken pizza. I gotta say it was verrry salty. So much that it ruined the enjoyment of the pizza. We ate it all cuz we were hungry but i dont think ill be having this again. Perhaps I need to try the deep dish to really review the place right.
author: ella a.

description: Went to Little Star on a Saturday afternoon, and there was nobody there. I took this as a bad sign, having never heard of the place. After my first bite, I was shocked. This pizza was amazing. The cornmeal crust is really excellent. The sauce is sweet, but not too sweet. They go light on the cheese (which I love). The DIY garlic bread is good, but kind of annoying.
author: Ben R.

description: This place has the best deep dish pizza in the bay!  Yes I've been to Zachary's in Berkeley.  Yes this is better.  The cornmeal crust just makes this culinary masterpiece!  I always go with the signature Little Star although I've tried almost everything on the menu here and would highly recommend you start there.  Added kicker of goodness is the quality beers they keep on tap at good prices.  Great place to take a date for cheap great food.
author: Chris G.

description: I'm not a huge fan of chicago pizza.  See, I enjoy the best of all foods, thus NY style is where it's at.  Even though I hate NY...well not the city or ALL the people..just some of the people. Go Sox!
author: Sir Paul L.

description:
went here on a tuesday a couple of weeks ago. let me tell you the pizza is amazing! the crust is made to perfection. i got the special chicken one with artichoke hearts. the people in the kitchen know their stuff! cute decor. cozy place. great music. 
only reason for 4 instead of 5 stars, the host was a bit too phony. older guy with a dark beard. i am not sure if he knew what he was doing b/c there were a couple empty tables open while we were waiting. 
whatever the case, nice joint and heavenly food. i am telling all my buddies about it!
author: Katie C.

description: Oh, Jebus! That was so damn good. The crust, the crust, the crust. Come hungry and patient. We got the Little Star large deep dish. I want to marry the pizza if it was possible and socially acceptable. Go!
author: Ramin R.

description:
Went here with 2 of my friends. We decided to sit at the bar for happy hour drinks, appetizers and pizza. The food and service was very good.
The bartender was ready to help us with a good attitude. 
There isn't a big selection of drink besides beer, wine and champagne cocktails. But the Champagne drinks were very good especially the black cherry. We also ordered the ginger drink and orange creamsicle. 
My friend ordered the buffalo wings which were not your typical saucy wings but instead breaded with spicy seasoning. I highly recommend this appetizer! it was so good. 
I've had the deep dish pizzas here which are really good, so we decided to get the thin crust special with broccoli, sausage, mozzarella and black olives. 
the portions are very large, the small pizza was filling for 3 girls. 

this is one of the best pizza places i have been to in San Francisco. !
not only is the food amazing but the service is even better!
i would definitely go here again!
author: Yasmina Z.

description: we tried the mediterranean chicken deep dish pizza and it was delicious!!! the crust was really good and the pizza was extrememly thick, definately a knife and fork type of pizza. their garlic bread was strangely tasteful, the bread was like any other sour dough i've had but it came with butter and a grilled garlic, we had to spread our own garlic. overall the pizza is extremely filling and worth the price. i would recommend getting the small deep dish if you want to feed 4 people, the large pizza will feed about 6 people.
author: Hanh D.

description: In the continual search for what to eat, pizza is inevitably suggested.  With this my wife usually groans, as she is the health conscious person in our family. To stem the conversation from spiraling out of control and focusing on my lack of a nutritious diet, I then suggest Little Star.  The groan turns to an ooooh, as the prospect of eating the best pizza in town swirls in her head.  5 stars for letting my wife, and more importantly me, eat great pizza without having to discuss the pros and cons of everything I shove in my face.
author: Alaric F.

description: It has a cornmeal crust.  A very obviously, very cornmeally crust.  If you think your Chicago pizza should have this then you'll like it.   I don't want my deep dish to be overpowered by crust; especially cornmeal.  For the best Chicago deep dish... hands down, it's Zachary's.  And I hate crossing that darn bridge.  But if I'm going to commit to the calories, I'd rather go there.
author: Laura T.

description:
Little Star has always had a reputation for being one of the best pizza joints around town...and for good reason.  The pizza here is top notch and very tasty.  However, the ridiculously long wait times, plus the snottiness and rudeness of the host here takes away from the charm of the place and knocked it down to 3 stars instead of 4 for me.  

The host had given us an estimated wait time of 1 hour...an hour and 20 minutes later, we watched as he sat another large party who came in after us..I went up to ask him why he was seating them before us, and he snapped back at me that they were on the list before us.  If that's true, fine..but it seemed like he knew these people & were giving them the table because of that.  When i gently pointed out to him that we had been waiting a long period over the time he had given us, he decided it was good customer service to tell me that I hadn't been waiting an hour and 20...but an hour and 10 minutes instead.  And he didn't say it nicely either.  He was outright rude, and a flat out ASSHOLE.  Very unnecessary and uncalled for, and if the manager of Little Star is reading this...he's the shorter, thin mustached/bearded host with long hair pulled back into a ponytail.  This was Saturday Jan 17th. RUDE RUDE RUDE.  He should NOT be in the service industry if he doesn't know what it means to treat customers with kindness. 

We were finally seated about 20 minutes after that..and the food was very good.  We started with appetizer of :

Spicy Chicken Wings - pound of wings served with baby carrots and blue cheese dressing $9 - these were delicious. VERY good. spicy & not overly sauced.  

Classic Deep Dish pizza - sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers & onions $22 (for large) - the deep dish pizzas are definitely the way to go. TONS of toppings, piping hot and cheesy, for crust lovers (like me!) the crust is a deliciously crunchy buttery indulgence. 

Thin Crust Chicken Pesto - pesto sauce, roasted chicken, mushrooms & onions -$17 (for small) - also very good, but in deep dish i think it would have been even better! 

FYI:  the large/small sizes did not seem to differ much at all.  it was right in front of me, and I couldn't tell the difference.
author: Lulu C.

description:
*beeeeep*   *beeeeep*   *beeeeep*   *beeeeep*   *beeeeep* 

This is a Public Service Announcement: Little Star Pizza is the best deep dish pizza in the Bay Area!  Dare I say...better than in Chicago *GASP!*

I am from Chicago (well, if you want to get technical - Buffalo Grove - but I still say "pop" and "maaahm" instead of "soda" and "mom.") so I am very picky about my deep dish. When a restaurant claims to be Chicago-style, I get really easily annoyed about the tendency in SF to "Californify" all the wonderful, artery-clogging specialties of other regions. Little Star, however, has managed to hit the ball out of Wrigley with their rendition of deep-dish pizza.

I applaud Little Star for striking a great balance between fresh tasting ingredients and stick-to-your-ribs satisfaction. The Classic, which has toppings of tasty sausage (I am super picky about my sausage), mushrooms, green bell peppers, and onions. The Vegetarian pizza's toppings (mushrooms, onions, black olives, red bell peppers, garlic, zucchini) were even hearty enough to satisfy this discerning meatlover. I was also impressed with the sauce, a crushed tomato variety with good body and flavor - not too chunky, watery, or sour.  Then there is the clutch of any good deep-dish pizza - the CRUST! Little Star's style is most closely related to Gino's East in Chicago, with a crispy cornmeal crust that makes for a slightly sweet, grainy savory treat after you're done eating the rest of the slice. I appreciate that their crust is not too heavy or doughy because eating the crust is supposed to be part of the experience - not meant to be left on the plate as an afterthought. 

Some other Californication observations (I just pictured School House Rock meets Red Hot Chili Peppers): There are a few pizza selections (Mediterranean Chicken, Pesto Chicken) that are not exactly authentically Chicagoan, but it's nice to have different options. You would also be hard pressed in Chicago to find garlic bread made from sourdough which you flavor AT YOUR TABLE with olive oil and freshly roasted garlic (!!!).  This is *AMAZING.* Their caprese and mixed greens salads (cherry tomatoes, red onion, gorgonzola, walnuts, and vinaigrette) are two great ways to start the meal - delicious, fresh, and large enough to share with a few friends. Little Star also features a great array of beers and offers up an eclectic, but contemporary selection on their jukebox. My favorite pizzerias in Chicago have some good pizza, but they really lack all the other things that make for a fun, satisfying dining experience.

And that's why Little Star deserves mad props. They successfully execute a Chicago classic, giving it a California twist. They do it WELL and without bastardizing the experience. 5 stars.
author: Steph P.

description: Recommend the deep dish - delicious, high quality
author: Neil B.

description: Dearest little star, I'd give you ten stars if I could.  The deep dish is incredible, the servers friendly, and the ambiance is very chill.  When my friends want to get together to eat, this is one of the first places I mention... Thank you, and please keep making more pizza:)
author: Karen K.

description: This is my favorite pizza ever! :)  I love the trendy romantic ambiance.  The staff is very friendly and theres a juke box where you can select songs to be played if you are so inclined.  Theres candles on the tables and its very dimly lit inside, so even though it has a tendency to be very loud, my husband and I enjoy going there on a date night.  It can sometimes be a little bit of a wait, but well worth it!  I love the deep dish veggie pizza, we always get the garlic bread and the spring mix salad.  I like things salty so their food is always a little underseasoned for me, but if you ask for salt they will gladly bring some for you and then the food is just homey, awesome, comforting - great.  If you were to eat it without the salt, the flavors dont really pop to me.  The garlic bread is so interesting, it comes with a whole head of roasted garlic, butter and sourdough.  It is wonderful; if you're really broke, go for that and a coke and you'll be a happy camper.  You can tell all the ingredients are fresh and organic, it tastes like you went outside and picked everything from your garden.  The deep dish pizza is not doughey it has a lot of cornmeal in the crust so it makes it a new interesting take on pizza.  Its an experience for me, not just the same old boring pizza. :) Highly recommended.  Only one con is that I have noticed a little inconsistency here; sometimes out of this world and sometimes just good. :( Still high on my list of favs. Pretty tight inside, so I wouldn't bring a group larger that five.
author: Guapa A.

description:
what more can be said about little star? 952 reviews worth feels like enough. not sure why i haven't written mine sooner, but i've been a fan of this place for a long time now. their deep dish pizza is a seriously delicious meal, and what's left tastes just as good (and maybe better?) for lunch the next day. the thin crust is not too bad either. it's all about the cornmeal crust and chunky tomatoes in the sauce.

get there early to get a table. no reservations, cash only but the atm inside charges a very nominal fee. happy hour till 6:30. several decent wines and beers to compliment your meal or to be had at the bar. deep dish pizza takes a while to cook, so order right away of you're hungry. or just call ahead and get take-out. mmmmmmmhm. you're a star.
author: Isabel C.

description:
Food is 5 stars - works are 0 stars... so, here we go...
Never try to call in a pizza there - why?  

Because they will confuse "I would like to call in a pizza to go that I will pick up and not eat there because I am taking it home to eat so please put it in a box so that when I show up there to get my pizza it's in a box ready to walk out the door with me so I won't have to eat there because I'm on my way home." 

This was confused with "no thanks, I'm just calling to see if you make a Hawaiian pizza to go and I'll be there in 30 minutes to pick it up but trust me, I don't want it even though I am going to be there in 30 minutes requesting the pizza I'm telling you I want.  You're smart enough to know I'm kidding and don't really want the pizza."

Also, bring a calendar if you want to time how long it takes them to bring your drink, once ordered.  Also, expect to be made to feel like a moron when the pizza you called in is not ready because who ever took the order thought you were kidding about ordering a pizza to take away.

"Um, are you sure you called this Little Star?  I know you are telling me you did, and the number you gave me is for this location and you're now showing me the call on your cell phone, but are you sure you called and spoke to someone here?"

Remember about 38 minutes ago, when I ordered an iced tea?  Any chance I could get that?  I hate to be a pest, but after you've forgotten my ordered and insulted me, I'm thirsty.

The pizza was good - but there are other good pizza joints around.  Frankly, I don't see what the big deal is.  

Would I go back?  Probably not to this location...
author: J B.

description: The best deep dish in the city! Neighborhood place that draws a crowd from all over the city. The "Little Star" is my favorite. Be sure to bring bills as they are cash only!
author: Patrick R.

description:
i don't like pizza. 

what i really mean is that i don't like pizza in general. too much bread, too much waxy cheese, too little sauce (and too little seasoning in said sauce!), too much meat with nitrite. blech.

my boyfriend lives in the east bay, and has only experienced zachary's deep dishes. honestly, i can't remember my last experience there except for the insanely long line of people spilling out onto college ave. 

however, at little star, we walked in and were almost immediately seated even though there were about 6 tables ahead of us who were all, unfortunately for them, not deuces. i picked the house chianti (meh) and he had the boont amber (yum). 

all of the staff were cool and really attentive. 

our server, a plugged/inked/pierced/all-around-nice-guy, told us the special, let us mull over the menu for a few minutes while he took care of some other tables, and then came back when we were firm on the caprese salad and mediterranean chicken pizza. 

the caprese was lovely. fresh buffalo mozz with plum tomatoes and shaved basil sitting in a pool of aged balsamic and extra virgin olive oil. two pieces of sourdough toasts accompanied the dish and we did not regret pouncing on it like lions to freshly slaughtered prey. this is the kind of caprese salad i like to make with good balsamic and fresh mozz. the only thing i would have done differently, would have been to add heirlooms instead of plum tomatoes for sweetness.

what can i say about the pizza that countless of other people haven't said before? honestly, i hate pizza dough, but this is the best cornmeal-flour dough combo i've ever tasted. it held up well against the filling and had a great crunchy crust. the sauce was decent, and the chicken/artichoke/green olive/feta filling was very tasty.

warning:

cash only, but kinda expensive. there's an atm onsite that only charges $0.25 so i guess that's a plus. also, the two slices i inhaled made me feel like i ate an entire pie by myself. the small size is more than enough for 2 people. no delivery, but plenty of take-out.
author: May T.

description: Nice to see a great pizzareia join the ranks of Delfina.  But I'm still in favor of Delfina.
author: Kurt F.

description:
The addition of Little Star Pizza last fall has made my favorite neighborhood even more enjoyable. I can't think of a better location for this place. It's comfortable hip vibe is home to many locals. The familiar background music (all jukebox) , along with the vivid, punchy artwork, set the tone for a light & happy evening with friends.   The lengthy wine, beer and cocktail list aid in creating ample leisure time!
--THE FOOD: I have never met a pizza I didnt like...but I REALLY enjoy the variety of pies available. The option of thick or thin is just the beginning. The trademark "Little Star" thick crust pizza, is by far their showboat. The ricotta cheese and fresh chunky sauce blanket the pie. Though the cornmeal crust is a unique delicacy, the flavors atop the pie create a meal on their own.  I'm also quite impressed with the vegetarian, and non red-meat options. The thin crust Chicken Pesto is also a favorite of mine. --DESSERT: It is nearly impossible to not gorge myself when visiting LSP, but on the slim chance that I'm still hungry (or feel like splurging) I take full advantage of LSP's dessert menu. All desserts are made on the premise by a specialized dessert chef. Perhaps the most popular, is the Cheesecake. Words can't describe how light, fluffy & dream-like it is. I also recommend the gelato. Various flavor are available, depending on the availability each night. It, too, is dreamy and parallels the Italian wonder! --OVERALL: Overall, I'm so very impressed with my local pizza joint. LSP is a place where people know youre name (or learn it quickly). It's the perfect Sunday  night dinner with friends, or a place to kick off an evening of bars or music.   Once a Divisadero secret, Little Star Pizza has become not only a place of great eats & relaxation, but a warm gathering place for locals.
p.s. my friend owns the place!  :)
author: Nicole L.

description:
This place is great if you love to overpay for your pizza. 

Someone who has worked in the pizza industry for over twenty years told me that deep dish is a great cash cow because it is as cheap to make as regular pizza, but people will pay WAAAAY more for it as it "feels" more substantial. e.g., the extra dough you're shelling out is, literally, for extra dough.

I grant that the sauce is good, and the dough is good, and the atmosphere is great. But seriously, this is another example of randomized herdist worship of mediocre pizza in a city that woefully lacks any pizza decent enough to eat.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Uh ya, I think i love you little star. The pizza here is so good I was in heaven. I ordered the special which was like a percuitto, artichoke thin crust. Yuummeh!! I also has a Ginger champagne cocktail, which was in a generous glass and was ab-delish. I am not usually a champagne fan but it was so good, dry, not sugary, and didn't give me a headache an hour later. The service was great, our waitress was super cute and friendly and answered all of our questions patiently. It's dark in there, which i like a lot, and there is really cool art on the walls. One of my favorite things about this place is the jukebox in the middle of the restaurant. I put in a buck and played some TRex to eat my pizza too. All in all, one of my Favorite spots for pizza in CA. Oh, and Sarah the bartender is super adorable.
author: Chris T.

description: Great atmosphere and fabulous bartender! The deep dish is quite tasty. In comparison to Patxi's- less greasy, able to eat more than one piece, and different offerings as far as toppings. Great jukebox and beer selections.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I was late for a large party. Mt fault. They didn't seat half our party, understandable. they finally sat the rest of us at another table, no problem. They threatened to kick us out for not ordering anything despite our other table ordering for us too, unreasonable.
author: Kelvin S.

description: I prefer Patxi's over Little Star for Chicago style pizza
author: Carlos L.

description: Zachary's? Dead to me. I would eat the crust alone with skim milk for breakfast and consider myself a lucky man.
author: patrick g.

description: It was love at first bite and I've been craving it ever since.  Reminds me of Gino's East, only better and fresher.  It wasn't greasy and heavy the way some "chicago-style" pizza chains are.  So good I ate all of the leftovers cold for breakfast.  And don't even get me started on the cheesecake, light, fluffy, melt-in-your-mouth.
author: Kristen N.

description:
Not too bad.
  But the thin crust is always hard as a rock.  4 out of 5 times it has been like a thick cracker.  Everyone seems to like Little Star Pizza so much!  Maybe I should order a different crust in the future?
author: Bernadette G.

description:
I would have to agree with some other reviews on here-- Little Star Pizza puts way too much tomato sauce on the Chicago Style Pizza to the point where the taste of the pizza is literally gone. This style of Pizza is supposed to have the sauce on top, but it's not supposed to be drenched in it, jesus! I had to scrap off half of the sauce and some of the tomato chunks as well to enjoy it. 

If you are going to do Chicago Style, I would recommend Patxi's Chicago Pizza on Hayes and Octavia--it's much better and has a great selection of beers on tap if you decide to eat in.
author: Alexandra O.

description:
Mmmmm...I have indeed found my newest way to get as fat as I wanna be. The recipe for this pie may as well be the recipe for common crack because god help me, I can't get enough and just thinking about it makes me all shakey and erratic.
PartyBot and I love love loved that Little Star Pizza in the Mission so much that we decided to do take out from the Western Addition branch. This has turned out to be a good and a bad thing. We have had Little Star twice in the last week and this is no light pizza.
I don't like the crust quite as well from this store but Party mentioned that this could be a result of transporting the pizza in a closed container as opposed to eating it at the shop. I think he's probably right.
A few days ago we tried the veggie and that was out of this world. Not as cheesy as the regular Little Star Pie, this was chock-full of fresh veggie goodness and kind of earthy. In a good way.
Tonight we had the mediterranean chicken and that's the best by far. Succulent chicken breast (yes, I just described pizza-topping chicken as succulent), crisp red peppers, juicy onions, warm green olives, tangy feta cheese, and that ridiculous tomato sauce make for one delicious mess. Knife and fork are recommended.
Start assembling the Yelp intervention team asap- I think we're going to be prime candidates for professional help soon. I can see where this is going...and it's beautiful.
**Also! Their mixed green salad comes with gorgonzola, walnuts, tomatos, and outrageously delicious dressing.
author: Autumn K.

description: great spot. great customer service. great food. nuff sed!
author: Johnny S.

description: This is the best Chicago-style pizza that I've tried in the Bay Area. If your standard is Zachary's, you've wasted a lot of time. The sooner you get over to LS, the sooner you'll get back on track. Seriously, if Little Star is a 4, Zachary's is a 2. I've tried the Classic, the Little Star, and the Mediterranean Chicken. The MC is my favorite, but the LS is pretty good too.
author: Bib G.

description: This is great pizza; I think the deep-dish is better than Zachary's. The tomato sauce on top is sweet and rich, just how I like it, and the crust is dense and delicous. I haven't tried to thin-crust yet but am looking forward to doing so.  Walking in and observing the clientele, even at the relatively early hour of 6:30 p.m., I was reminded of an old ABC song called "So Hip, It Hurts" -- lots of wannabe hipsters.
