But it's a cool space, laid-back and mellow, even family-friendly. Our server seemed pretty bored with her job, but the service was okay, not stellar, not terrible.  I'll definitely go back. Good pizza is so rare in this town.
author: Tara M.

description:
from a new yorker, deep dish pizza doesn't get any better than this.  i'm used to eating sicilian pizza back home and i think this is as close as you get to Gino's in the windy city.  if you think the pizza is phenomenal, wait til you try the caprese salad.  the tomatoes, fresh mozzarella cheese, and basil with a healthy serving of balsamic vinegar and olive oil is absolutely astounding.  i would just come here for that but that alone itself isn't enough.  

come early or the aroma from the wait will make you even hungrier.  =)
author: Alexander H.

description:
My Big Fat Greek Wedding.  Stay with me, I promise I have a point (and one that related to Little Star).  When My Big Fat Greek Wedding came out in the theatres, everybody was like, "ooh la la, you have to see it, big fat blah blah blah."  I made a point not to see it.  Then, it came out on DVD, and a friend basically abducted me to make me watch it with her.  That's how important it was to her that I watch this damn movie.  And then we watch the movie and she is looking at me every other minute while laughing maniacally because at this point she's memorized the entire thing and I was like, "meh.  It's okay."

So I read all the Little Star reviews and I expect this pizza not only to be fantastic, but to do my taxes and tell me I'm a fairy princess, because that is sort of the curse of being talked up and having your reputation precede you.  And the first time I had Little Star I was like, "meh.  It's okay."  But the next morning I thought, I wonder if there's some of that tasty pizza left.  And on subsequent pizza cravings, there was no doubt which neighborhood pizza I wanted, cash only and long wait be damned (helpful hint: ordering over the phone usually cuts down on the wait frustration).  Yes, I've had the real deep dish slim shady in Chicago, and yes, it's not the same.  But that doesn't mean that Little Star's cornmeal deep dish, with its delicious sauce and fresh ingredients (artichokes, holla) isn't, in fact, amazingly good.  Wow, that was a lot of negatives in that sentence.  Little Star is amazingly good, that's what I'm trying to say.

And you know what?  I caught My Big Fat Greek Wedding on tv some time after I was forced to watch it, and I actually liked it.  Sure, it was cutesy, but it was also pretty funny.  So, when you have Little Star for the first time, bear in mind: it's not going to braid your hair and sit on your bed until you fall asleep and make you cinnamon toast in the morning.  Just be ready to have a good meal that might become an addiction.
author: Tanya N.

description: Believe the hype. Little Star Pizza will own you. It certainly owns me.
author: Maria D.

description:
I have had the pizza before, and it is very good. however, this time around, I didn't get to the pizza, I stopped short of eating here because the host was really rude. I worked for 3 yrs as a hostess in a crowded, high volume restaurant w/ no real waiting area. I understand the difficulties of trying to manuever... The elderly couple I was w/ had unintentionally stepped in the hostess' path, and instead of politely asking them to move, or saying ANYTHING, she just rolled her eyes at them and shot a dirty look. I told her not to do it again, I was probably more bitchy than necessary, but I am very protective of my grandparents, and having worked in her job for as long as I have, I found her attitude disrespectful, immature, and unprofessional.
UPDATE; the management followed up w/ me and asked about the experience, so that they may improve their service - I have gone from 2 stars to 3. If I go back the next time, and the service is good, it will be a 4.
author: suzanne g.

description: Best chicago style pizza ever.  And i've been to a couple good ones in chicago, too.  Mostly i get it to go, but its nice little dive restaurant, as well.  They got cool 80s on the jukebox, a bar with some tasty beers on tap, and decent salads.  Did i mention their pizza is the best ever? I think i've had all the deep dish combos.  Their thin pizza is good, too, but i've had better in NYC.
author: chad n.

description: Does this place even need to be reviewed anymore? Seriously!!! It has well over 1,000 reviews with over 90% 4 or 5 stars. Okay then, I'll keep it simple. The deep dish is AWESOME any way you order it...veggies, meat, any of the speciality pizzas, it's all good. One thing that doesn't get talked about that's really good here is the garlic bread!!! It's not the typical garlic bread with olive oil, basil and garlic. Instead, it's just plain baked bread that comes with cloves of garlic on the side that have been baked separately. It's soft and you spread it on the bread yourself. It's deliciousness!!! I know the wait can sometimes suck, but hey that's what the bar's for...right? Another option is to order your pizza, garlic bread, and wings (also yummy here) to go, head on over to 821 across the street for a beer, wait 20-25 min, head back to get your food, and then bring it back to 821 because they let you bring in Little Star!!!
author: George A.

description:
bottom line: pizza is decent, but order it to go...unless you have vacation hours to burn, the wait is not worth the trouble to sit and eat inside.

as someone from the midwest, i was never at a loss for decent pizza when the craving calls. however here in SF, that seems some sort of luxury compared to the weak offerings all over town. after reading the glowing reviews of Little Star Pizza, i was willing to give the place a chance.

unfortunately that chance was not only ripped asunder, but scattered on the sidewalk and doused by birds passing by. the biggest downside for this place has to be the grossly inefficient use of the staff's time and the utter contempt for customers by not offering even the most rudimentary form of reservations or even honouring the sanctity of their wait list, which is the only way in unless you know someone on staff. at a place this popular, reservations are a must, and it's an unforgivable oversight for a business not to offer them.

after waiting over an hour watching people further down the list than our meagre party of two and friends of the staff being promptly seated, we were shown to a bar table--not a real table--which was neither comfortable nor particularly favourable being right next to the unisex restroom. to further our delight, the waitress who had been schmoozing with her friends on the couches in the waiting lounge for ten minutes saw us waiting patiently at our table and actually asked in a condescendingly surprised tone, "did someone seat you?!"

one of the themes that seemed to resonate with this place is that you're on your own. don't bother planning ahead, because you can't. just show up, wait until you're in need of a shave, and hope for the best. someone quickly dropped off a giant carafe of water so we could go about serving ourselves...nobody asked for our beverage order. we ordered an appetiser to quell the gnashing hunger in our stomachs--garlic bread in this case--and got a plate with the ingredients: bread, plain butter, and whole garlic cloves...i'm quite glad my extensive culinary skills preparing toast each morning at home also prepared me for fixing my own food here.

what i can be thankful for is after an hour and a half of audible hunger, our "vegetarian" pizza came quickly and abruptly; literally dumped off at the table without so much as a word from the deliverer. the only upside to all the nonsense and headache of the evening was that the pizza was in fact very good. not chicago deep-dish good, but excellent by west coast standards. in fact it's the only thing that earns them above the minimum of one little star; the restaurant's name is oddly similar to my rating of it.

so if you're craving some pizza, definitely consider this joint, but in line with the rest of the 'do it yourself' theme, do yourself the favour and order your food to go.
author: Aaron H.

description: Love the pizza but they lose a star because they are now cash only.  Why would a restaurant initially accept credit cards and then stop?  Oh well, the pizza and cute waitresses will keep me coming back.  With cash, of course.
author: phil h.

description: 840 Reviews??? What a bummer for those who dont live in the city. May be a reason to visit... Damn good, and now the last cornmeal crust pizza in SF since Vicolo and Panhandle are gone.
author: Adam X.

description: I prefer thin crust but for deep dish, this is as good as it gets. It's even good cold. One of a kind crust.
author: Marla Y.

description:
The only reason that I'm not giving it a 5 star rating today is that I've only tried it once. The Deep Dish tastes a lot like Pizano's in Chicago. A flaky, light but crispy crust with a good helping of cheese and toppings.

I had the special for the night. Meatballs, Pepperoni, Ricotta and Spinach. Well, the special was with Mushrooms instead of Pepperoni but they were more than happy to modify it for us. The pizza took the typical 25 minutes to come out. We arrived right as the opened so there was no wait. By the time we left though there was a line out the door.

The best part of the pizza was the meatballs. If they've got them the night you go, you owe it to yourself to order them. They are a bit spicy, but not too spicy.

We ordered a small pizza (9") for two people. It was the exact right size for the two of us. We didn't order an appetizer. If there are three of you, get a small and an app and you'll be fully satiated.

Yum Yum!
author: H B.

description:
places like this make me regret being vegan.

i devoured the pizza nonetheless and consequently underwent a painful tummy ache. WORTH IT.
author: Jamie C.

description: best pizza in sf by far! the deep dish is killer, although I've never had it in Chicago. been here twice and it's defiantly our go to place for a pie!
author: Elise B.

description:
I don't like deep dish pizza - usually gooey and yucky. Zachary's wasn't good either, but this place, man oh man! It was so good! Everything seemed to be reasonably priced and nice selection of wine, beer.

I love their pizza and the thin crust cheese pizza was outstanding as well.
author: Lucy D.

description:
Went there with little expectations, came out with awesome food.  

The service was great and friendly.  Beer was served in frosty mugs (nice touch) and could definitely be a regular place of mine.  

FYI, the pizza is just as good on the second day.
author: Austin S.

description: Little Star has really good pizza. They make an awesome thin crust which is my favorite (i LOVE their white pizza). I was finally convinced to try their deep crust which I normally don't like but I love it here. It is just SO good. And people who work here are always nice and always give you a correct quote on how long it will take to be seated or to pick up your pizza.
author: Emily R.

description: I had a horrible experience at this restaurant.  A group of myself and three friends went to Little Star to celebrate a friend's 30th birthday.  We ordered everything from appetizers to pizza to dessert.  Between the four of us we ordered two bottles of wine.  While finishing our wine, the rude and greedy owner asked us to leave because "we had been eating for too long and there was a waiting list"  On our way out he approached us again and accused us of conspiring against him.  I have worked in the restaurant industry for five years, and I have NEVER seen any of my managers or owners ask a table to leave in order to accomodate the waiting list.  THIS RESTAURANT SUCKS.
author: Megna M.

description: Omgahh. I went here a month ago on a Sunday night with a few of my friends. We got here around 5:50 pm, the wait was 50 mins. So we just went around the corner to Alamo Square. While we were there, we pre-ordered our pizza. Around 5:30, I got a text that our table was ready. The seating was really packed. We were so close to the diners next to us that I literally just turned my head to my right and was able to look over the shoulder of the person at the next table. A little awkward, but that doesn't keep me from wanting to try the deep dish pizza! It took about another 10 mins for our pizza to come out so my friends and I ordered the garlic bread and chicken wing appetizers. I could've done without the garlic bread, but I liked the chicken wings. They were simple and not over sauced. Then our pizza came out and it looked soo good! We ordered a large Little Star and added pepperoni and sausage. Best deep dish pizza I've ever had. There was a good amount of cheese, it was stringy but not too chewy. I like the tomato sauce. The pepperoni and sausage went well with it. The crust was nice and crunchy but not greasy. I had only one slice, a piece of garlic bread, and three chicken wings. That was enough to fill me up. In my group of 6, each of us had one slice. And there were two slices left over, so our pizza was 8 slices. All of my friends agreed that what we ordered filled us up. All of that and we only paid about $10 each, that was including tip. This place is good to come with friends or even on a date. I wouldn't recommend it for people with children who would need to get up and run around because the place is tight. It took us 15 minutes to find parking, but we found free parking a couple blocks away. Our waiter, Patrick, was very attentive and checked on us a couple times. Have patience with the wait to get a table. The pizza will be well worth the wait!
author: Kayla V.

description: Hands down, the best pizza in SF. And it was literally two blocks from my apartment when I lived there. Just a regular pepperoni pizza with roasted garlic. The best!. The crust is uber-tasty with the cornmeal.
author: Chelsi S.

description: Little Star is the best pizza that I have had in San Francisco, and the second best in California.  The crust is deep dish and not for the thin lovers.  Be ready to indulge.  The only annoyance was that they only have bottled beverages.  $3 for an iced tea was too expensive.
author: Chris M.

description:
They don't take reservations so prepare to wait for over an hour. For a pizza place the lighting is too dark, you couldn't see the food or the stuff on the pizza.
The noise level was so bad the person beside me couldn't hear me never mind screaming across the table. If you can lip read this place is not that bad.
The wings was nothing to write home about. Boiled wings sprinkled in spices, if you like your chicken well done you will not like this.
The pizza was too salty ( as mentioned in another review) If you like that, the pizza sauce is bland with salty toppings. I think people give this place too much credit. I guess this is the only place in that area that is good because there is not much to choose from. I have no desire to go back.
One restroom for the whole restaurant???? 
1 star... edible.
What restaurant these days do not accept Credit cards? I can understand if your entrees are under $5.95 but that is crazy!
author: Alison W.

description: OMG GOOD!!!! This place definitely lives up to its many reviews. Had the deep dish pizza with chicken and it is DE-LICIOUS!!!! Not too saucy, crust was very crunchy and crust wasn't drenched in grease whatsoever, small place, great service, worth the wait and the $20 for a pizza. Wanted to visit again just the other day since I was in the area, but they don't open till 5:00pm!! :(
author: Doris L.

description:
ick.  There's only so much salt and cheese you can pile on top of a bland slice of pizza before giving up and going home to make your own.

I'll admit I was seduced by the packaging, but the food was terrible and the attitide of the service turned me off immediately.  Has everyone see that note on their menus that basically says hurry and eat so you can get the fuck out so we can seat more people and charge them ridiculous amounts of money for bland food?

Give me Pauline's anyday over the pseudo-pizza at little star.  I'll even haul my lazy self over to Eat Bay for Zachary's before going back to Little Star.

one star for packaging.
author: melanie t.

description:
Little Star, I've eaten at Zachary's. I know Zachary's. Zachary's is a friend of mine. Little Star, you are no Zachary's. 

Its okay for deep dish, but anyone in SF who claims this is better than Zachary's is straight trippin. The best bay girls, AND the best bay deep dish pizzas, come straight outta Oakland.
author: J S.

description: I think this is the best pizza in the Bay Area.  Period.  If you don't like Little Star Pizza: fuck you.
author: Matthew H.

description: This place has really good deep dish pizzas. Although I am inclined to favor this place over Patxi's just because Patxi's is a bigger chain, I don't. The atmosphere is kind of cramped and really dark (granted I came for dinner). I would really give this place a 3.5 if I could, but I'll round up because the food IS pretty delicious. Service was ok, nothing amazing. I live close by so the best option for me is getting it to go - that way I get good food and can get away from the so-so atmosphere/service! :)
author: Janie Y.

description: Great pizza.  I love the chicken wings too.  The place gets a little crowded around 7 PM on weekends.  I rate this above Zachery's, but below Patxi's.
author: Paul L.

description: Here visiting friends in San Francisco, they told me this place was the best pizza in town. We ordered a thin crust pesto chicken pizza and a deep dish vegetable pizza. Both of them were fantastic! The thin crust was crispy and light and had the perfect amont of cheese and toppings.  The deep dish was not greasy like some deep dishes, and the toppings were plentiful and delicious.  The crust was very tasty as well.  Four stars instead of five because the waiter was not very attentive. Also, after excitedly putting money in the jukebox and selecting 3 of my favorite songs, the music was so quiet I couldn't even hear it!!!!
author: Julie R.

description: Ignore all that shit I was talking about Little Star back in 2007. My initial gut reaction against a new establishment opening up along my beloved Divis Corridor is usually suspect, but under the weight of time & experience, Little Star is TRUE BLUE West Add elite. I've come to be a fan of deep dish pizza because of their Classic pie, & for no other reason. Yeah, the thin crust isn't the best pizza in the world, but it's much better than passable. Forgive me, Little Star. Pals?
author: Pete J.

description:
um, SUPER YUM!! 

everyone's commented on how delish the deep dish is...and it TRULY is.  the tomatoes and the cheese are PERFECT and really, that's what makes a great pizza.  

for your appetizer, GO WITH THE CAPRESE SALAD.  the cheese is SO fresh...it's hard to recreate at home!!  

a note about timing:  get there when they open their doors for dinner.  this place gets PACKED FAST and standing there, waiting in an aroma filled room is nooo fun at all.

enjoy!! i know you will. :)
author: Yvonne P.

description: OMG - Best pizza I've ever had, EVER! The cheese was so yummy and fresh tasting. I can't wait to go back. I've never had deep dish pizza before and I'm not sure how Chi town does theirs but this is the best pizza I've had in SF. Definitely go there if you like fresh ingredients, thick crust, and supporting another awesome local business.
author: Laura C.

description: Hey, this isn't a nightclub, stop yelling at each other at the top of your lungs because you can't hear above the music with the empty pizza tray ordering drink after drink. There are plenty of good bars in the neighborhood to get your heat on and digest your cheese baby. Tasty tasty pies and friendly great service and of course PBR. Unnerving atmosphere with loud music and scenesters yelling about facebook at each other makes it a bit hard to enjoy the food. Great for take out or to be seen, I guess.
author: William R.

description: I had the good fortune of trying deep dish pizza for the first time at Little Star, and wow their pizza pies are delicious!!! They have great options, the service is friendly, and they also have really good appetizers such as the garlic bread! I hope not offend anyone by comparing, but I think that Patxi's deep dish pizza is just slightly better because they have better combinations. However, this place is still worth visiting.
author: Luis O.

description: Great pizza and a nice place to go all around.  Again, great pizza!  I wish they had just a couple of non-pizza options for the folks that don't want to have pizza with the rest of the table.  But, perhaps that is the point.  They are a pizza place after all and a fantastic one at that!
author: Ila L.

description: I'm totally down with everyone who gives Little Star pizza a 4 or 5 stars because this place is awesome! Thin crust is my favorite kind of crust and you can't go wrong with the white pie. Good as it gets! I also tried the garlic bread. That was only ok because it was just thick bread served with a roasted whole garlic on the side so you can spread it yourself. I also like that it has a juke box to set the mood any way that you want. Little star pizza is the way to go if you're in the city.
author: Daphne N.

description: I order the Deep Dish Brass Monkey- (Not on the menu for some reason) AMAZING. Almost like lasagna. The chicken wings are BOMB!I wish I could figure out the spices -the recipe for it. I would make them at home. Instead I spend all my money at Little star, but that's okay.
author: Tara M.

description: I've been 3 times, and each time, come away unimpressed. On the last occasion, our pizza came out burnt not once but twice, and the toppings were over salted and insipid. The deep dish we tried tasted just like hot canned tomatoes, and not very good ones at that. I like the wine list, and that they try, but you'll never find me waiting to eat there.
author: Stellah D.

description: I'm so excited that they've opened up a new location in the Mission, where I live. I've been to this location and it is definitely the best pizza  I've had in the city, and the Mission was seriously lacking in quality pizza. The davisadero location has  phenomenal cheesecake too. I would take a date here if you were looking for something casual and fun.
author: Cyrelle D.

description: Another Yelp-recommended first for me.  Yes, this pizza is quite tasty; light, flaky crust, tasty toppings, but not ready to get my panties in a bunch over it.  I enjoy a heartier, more substantial pizza with more toppings, and I really felt it was overpriced for what you get.  Also, although I can't really comment on the service or ambiance because I took mine to go, I think some people are getting a bit carried away in their excitement over there now being a cool, trendy pizza option in a City full of cool and trendy everything else.  Although quite good, not sure if I can join the hip-hype-holiday on this one.
author: Rick H.

description:
the first time i went to little star, i was pretty sure i would never return.  at about 6:00 on a wednesday evening i went in with a girlfriend to get on the hipper than thou list for a table.  i was snobbily and righteously informed, by a little annoying art school attendee in a server's apron which SHOULD require her to behave gregariously, that the wait was 45 mins.  my first mistake, apparently, was to reply to this with a genuinely surprised "on a wednesday?!"

despite the fact that the bitchy little hostess was in converse and 6 inches shorter than me, she managed to look down her nose and say "we ALWAYS have a wait past 5pm, SEVEN DAYS A WEEK"  incidentally, THEY OPEN AT 5PM.

i turned around and walked out, and ate at a less than glamorous but very tasty place (stelladoro, owned by a great vietnamese couple), rolling my eyes the entire time at snarkyass san francisco.  YOU ARE ON DIVASADERO, LITTLE STAR.  YOU SERVE PIZZA.  WHAT IS YOUR PROBLEM?


that said, i was convinced to return again about two months later.  much to my chagrin, the pizza is actually very good.  the only thing that would have made me happy was if the food sucked and i found a fly in my champagne cocktail (which was also delicious).  i didn't.

god damnit.
author: calamity d.

description: This place is great-- it's like Zachary's only in the city, without the long wait time to order and tastes better due largely to the delicately sweet cornmeal crust. I would order the Little Star deep dish pizza. Yum!
author: lindsey l.

description: BBBBBBBBBBBEST pizza in SF, hands down! We had the classic and it was a perfect deep dish pie.
author: Hazel B.

description: Best deep dish I've ever had. Personally, anyone I know will tell you the same thing. There's usually a long wait to get in and I've only had it to go. Call ahead to order-- the parking is abysmal so it's a two man operation--one drives around the block while the other picks up the pizza. There's no delivery. I've given gift certificates--how to make friends and influence people.
author: william b.

description:
when i was opening up my shop i wanted to name it little star, but little star had just opened, so i couldnt use it. (brilliant minds think alike)?
then i wanted to name it little orbit. but the orbit room was too close, so i couldnt use that...i have a thing about the night sky, i really wanted to incorporate it into my name. but oh well. they win. so then i did come up with a name, and then someone took my name and used it....moral? i dont know. life is unfair? 

what is fair? pizza. 

little star good name
good take out.
author: coffeecake j.

description: MMMMM mmmmmm MMMMMM.  I love Chicago deep dish Pizza, and little star brought back those memories that make your mouth water.  This deep dish, however, felt healthier since it was less greasy than most usually are.  Little star..I'll be back!  Don't mess up my service though, cause that's a No-No.
author: Jin B.

description: This place is literally a slice of heaven! I'm quite appalled that it took five years for me to visit. I can't believe what I was missing! The Little Star cornmeal crust with spinach and garlic is as good as it gets. Minus one star since they didn't have any of their much talked about garlic bread appetizer. And it was only 8pm. How does that happen?
author: a p.

description: One of the best Pizza places in the city.  Deepdish and tasty.
author: Justine E.

description: So my first time here, I came with two international students as a English partner for a conversation small group. I thought oh whatever! how good can pizza be any way? But I decided to go here because I heard some good things, and I wanted to show them what food was like outside of the cafeteria. Let's just say I am hard to please, a person that criticises everything and people say I'm overly harsh and blunt and I find things to Brumbaugh and criticise about just because I can I debate and challenge everybody that I can, and enjoy holding an opposing view just because I can . I could not find anything to debate about at this place I could not complain about a single thing this is not easy to do, and while my two conversation partners had everything bad to say about the place, I thoroughly enjoyed our dinner I admit I never had deep dish before, but I pigged out that night and had a little bit too much to eat I went back to other times, and all three times I still could not find a single thing to grumble about just because I can. I looked  through the reviews a bit and all the lower ratings seemed a little nasty even though some would say I can be a bit nasty i think that they were a little off
author: Rachel N.

description: Not a huge fan of corn, nor am I big on thick crust pizza, but Lil * does something that works well and I love their pizzas! It can be hard to get a table right away, they only accept cash, and I think they are closed on Mondays if Im not mistaken. Those are the things to watch out for, other than that its GREAT!
author: Vivek N.

description: The Pom-Pagne is huge and delightful.
author: Stephanie C.

description: The Little Star classic:  best cure for Chicago homesickness.  I'm pretty sure it made me sick once but I'm still giving it five stars (that good).
author: Neha N.

description: Good pizza...great service, but way too long a wait for pizza.  I thought deep dish would be deeper and the crust left more to be desired...but I loved the pesto thin crust.
author: Joni S.

description:
**Update: packed or not, hands down best pizza in the bay area (that I can attest to).  5 stars

I'm giving this place 4 stars only because it's so damn packed it's difficult to get even a take out order, let alone an actual table.  If you can bear the moderate waits, the pizza is fantastic.  beware though, this isn't deep dish int he truest sense.  it is a touch lighter than zachary's or chicago style, but i think it's significantly better this way.  at zach's you're full of 1 or 2 slices of pizza, barely scratching the behemoth pie.  at little star you can comfortably eat 3 slices without getting into food coma.  the pie is mad good and you will most assuredly enjoy it, no matter your pizza discriminations.
author: Jerry T.

description: Mmm- Very tasty and perfect ! "The Little Star" thin crust was better than most pizza I have had. We also had a garden salad that was the perfect size for 2 of us to share. Our waiter was very cool, too. Good stuff.
author: Amy J.

description: It's worth the wait!!! I mean what is in the damn sauce?!??! It is so good! I've never been a big fan of deep dish, but this place does it for me. The chicken wings are also spectacular. Also, if you want to skip the wait you can always call in ahead of time for pizza pick-up.
author: Samira S.

description:
expensive pizza for the yuppies of the western addition/nopa area.
came here one night with my friends cuz a guy at work said it was fabulous. it was full of people sitting in low couches drinking wine with the lights off. 
why do yuppies love the trifecta of wine, dim lighting, and sitting low to the ground on uncomfortable seating? i just dont understand.
anyways, of course we left after the dude said 45-60min wait or something. came back next week and got a pizza to go. 
got Mediterranean something. overrated pizza. not big enough of a place- but thats why the yuppies love it, it always looks full and you'll have time to drink that wine while you wait.
author: just k.

description:
Seven of my coworkers went to Little Star. We were surprised when we got a table immediately (as soon as our entire party was there) without reservations. 
To get the lips moving, everyone ordered drinks. The "Pompagne", don't get me started on that drink. For seven bucks, I would have enjoyed freshly squeezed juice instead. Watered down does not begin to describe it. I was so thirsty after finishing the drink, I had to grab my friend's beer.
The eight of us orderred one deep dish and two thin crusts. I liked the thin crust the best, Mediterrean the most of all. Some of my coworkers like the pesto chicken the best but I thought the bird was a bit dry. The deep dish is also good but I prefer Zachary's. 
After the pies arrived, the inconsiderate wait staff starting showing their skill. (Big parties beware: this restuarant hates you.) Our waitress kept asking us if she could take our plates away. I had a freaking slice of pizza on my plate and she has the nerve to ask me if I was done. I fended her off but she was able to pick off some of my friends. 2 seconds after throwing my napkin on my plate, she whisked it off while saying "napkin on plated definitely means you are done." WTF?!? I get charged 18% gratuity just so I can feel that I need to leave as soon as possible?!? Sure there were people waiting but we ate $200 bucks worth of food. Let me digest a bit. 
Now, because my friends are pretty cash poor, it took some effort to pay the with Benjamins. That, though, is a different complaint.
author: Lams L.

description: Ahhh deep dish! Little Star has brought the deep dish from Chicago and somehow made it better!!! I love the roasted garlic bread, spreads like butter! The veggie comes with the roasted garlic and zucchini, amazing! I love a saucy pizza with plenty of crust and garlic, little star makes my day :)
author: Ashley F.

description:
This email rant  while discussing the merrits of LDP is tongue -in -cheek but it gets the point across.  They all enjoyed it so much that they said I needed to put it in Yelp.  Little Star Pizza shouldn't call itself Chicago Style.  

"AAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH....
 
TASTE IS NOT THE ISSUE HERE
 
  It may be the best f*ckin pizza every made by a mortal..It may be god damn elvin bread that can sustain you on a trek to mordor...but don't f*ckin call it Chicago style pizza when it is NOT, NOT  Chicago style pizza.  It's like going to a sushi restaurant and all you see on the menu is fried catfish.  Sure as hell catfish is good, but it is not Sushi.  This is not semantics, this is a fundamental issue of false advertising. 
 
I will repeat rules to those who do not know.  When describing Chicago style pizza...
 
1) It must contain at least 2 inches of cheese
 
2) Sausage must be large in size and layered on top of the cheese.  Every single bite must contain sausage.
 
3) Eating more than 2 pieces in one sitting results in severe stomach pain that can only be cured by watching 6-8 hours of some sort of sporting event or action movie interrupted by numerous naps and trips to the bathroom where you pray to god the evil cheese will find a way to exit your *ss. 
 
 
AAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHH  
 
I am so pissed off right now. God damn bunch of bull sh*t liars at Little Star Pizza.  What the f*ck is a Little Star anyway.  Fuck*n reprobates all of them.
 
SERENITY NOW
author: Christopher C.

description:
best pizza i've ever had. service was pretty terrible, but it's easy to overlook when you're crying tears of joy.
wait was about 20-30 min, but we placed our order with the hostess so that we only had to wait about 5-10 min for our pizza after we were sat.
author: Lia A.

description: Went there last night with my teenage boys and it was simply the best deep dish pizza I've had in San Francisco the 20 years I have been here I think. Only one in the Bay that can compare has got to be Zachary on the east bay.  We had the Little Star Vegetarian Pizza with spinach, mushrooms, feta, etc and it was delicious!!!!!! We also had garlic bread with roasted garlic pulps, the boys had root beer in frosted mugs and I had a great pilsner on tap. Wonderfull casual place to come on a Friday night.  It was a nice ambiance as well, candles on the tables, art work, specialty drinks and our waitress was the best. So nice and accomodating.  There were many families with kids when we were there, I personally would not bring little kids to this restaurant, but that is just me I guess. My teenage boys and I will be back, next time perpahs we'll try the classic.  My son who thinks vegetarian is boring loved our vegetarian pizza, it was simply so flavorfull you did not notice the meat was "missing".  Great place and wish we had gone there before sicne we have lived in this area for a long time.
author: Beth P.

description: If you've ever craved deep dish pizza while flipping through a West Elm catalog, and who among us hasn't, you must go here!
author: L W.

description: Little Star is pretty much perfect pizza as far as I'm concerned. Had some take out with friends last night as we curled up for a lazy hungover Saturday evening hanging out on the couch. Great deep dish, still need to try the shallow dish.
author: Phil M.

description:
I am a former Chicagoan and their deep dish at LSP is phenomanal!
Though no one can ever beat Lou Malnati's for deep dish.
author: Sara K.

description: I would vote for McCain for a free Little Star pie. OK, no I wouldn't, I should be banned for even just joking about that. But the things I would do for Little Star... mmmmmmmmmm. Best deep dish I have ever had. If you like tomatoes, you'll be happy, they give them to you chunky here. Hey, the salads are good too.
author: Lee M.

description: While pricey this place has its charm.  The tasty small pizzas hover around $16 and feed one to one and a half with larger starting at $20.  This is certainly the second best deep dish in the Bay and The best I've had in SF.    I'd recommend this place as more of a date spot than a regular eating joint.  The atmosphere is dark and bar-esque and the wait staff is cordial.  Last night (10:00 -11:30) provides patrons with second happy hour offering half off drinks which brings a can of Pabst down to a buck.  Don't want to pay $16 for a pizza to get the cheap beers?    Little Star has a small bar seating maybe five.  Sidle up and get loaded on the cheap.  Maybe then you'll be willing to spring for one of their delicious deep dish pizzas.
author: Ian H.

description: Like they need anyone else to write them a stellar review...Ok here's one more- The best deep dish pizza in town-period.  The perfect sweet tangy combo tomato base used with both the meat and veggie pies sets the mood for orgasmic satisfaction with every bite. Beer and Wine are nicely pared and the ambiance is subtley hip with no pants hangin below the crotch.  I want to marry you Little Star and tell Bert in the back he's the bomb!!!
author: John C.

description: Order the thin crust chicken pesto...the wings are also a good call. The best pie in the city! yummie!
author: Lena D.

description:
Having eaten a lot of Chicago deep dish pizza, I'll admit I'm a little spoiled.  However, Little Star definitely does Chicago style right.

At this location it always takes awhile to be seated.  Fortunately, there is a well-stocked bar with a number of decent microbrews, which helps pass the time.  Although I don't mix wine and pizza (Oh the horror!) the wine list seemed fairly good.

On to the grub.  The one time I had anything other than pizza, my partner and I had a caprese salad.  It was decent, although forgettable.  The pizza, on the other hand, was very good.  Cornmeal crust is not an innovation, nor are occult ingredients like spinach and artichoke, but the pizzas were put together intelligently, and the taste was dead on.  Every time I have a hunger for deep dish I pick up a pie from Little Star.

I originally was going to give Little Star 4/5, but I came to my senses and realized that this was certainly the best Chicago deep dish pizza one would find in San Francisco; furthermore, the restaurant is fun and the service is great.
author: John B.

description: Little Star is my new favorite pizza in SF (and perhaps the world, hehe).  Their simple deep dish cheese pizza is a work of art.
author: Jared E.

description:
This place ROCKS! (with an ALL CAPS people!) - kick ass rocking good pizza! kick ass rocking good Caprese salad (my favorite!). I mean seriously, the ingredients in this joint are so incredibly fresh, it's the freshest I have ever tasted and that is what makes this place superior to even Zachary's over in Bezerkely, which is the only other good Chicago style pizza in the area. And what is most unique about Little Star is their crust, I believe they use corn meal, I've never asked, but that is my guess. All this yummyness (freshest ingredients, corn meal crust) makes this Chicago-style pizza joint EVEN BETTER than Chicago pizza! And to add to all that yummy goodness, they have a killer kick ass alternative jukebox (makes me want to go home, plug in my iPod and rock my tunes even louder!) My only gripe about their beer selection is that they don't have Chimay. Being that I am such a lush when it comes to beer I am going to have to start asking them "Hey, can you carry some Chimay please?!"

So one of my girlfriends told me recently that they opened up another Little Star on Valencia. Honestly I did not believe her. "Are you sure, it's a Little Star?" I asked, "Yes! I'm sure, we ate there the other day, it's right by my house!" she said. Still, I was in disbelief. So on a sunny weekend afternoon, the old man and I took a stroll in the area to sniff out the inventory on some furniture stores and so I told him that there's a Little Star in our neighborhood, so as we were walking down Valencia to look for it he asked, "Are you sure?" even he was in disbelief that our favourite pizza joint could be even closer to home now (we live in the Lower Haight). The man was the one who spotted it first and in the distance I could see the star, it was like if you were walking through the desert, dying of dehydration and you spot an oasis far in the distance, marked by a a few palm trees growing around the perimeter --- that was my joy! I seriously jumped up and down like I was Tom Cruise on Oprah's couch! No kidding!

So I've yet to make plans to check out the Valencia spot, but I have no doubt in my mind it is just as fabulous as the spot on divis.. The only problem I will have now is which spot should I go to now?

If only I could give this place 10 stars...
author: NirvAnna M.

description:
This is some seriously delicious pizza. I grew up eating Zachary's deep dish (over yonder in the E. Bay), but I would say that Little Star beats Zachary's on the deep dish pizza...maybe it has to do with the tasty corn meal crust or topping combos. I love the hip, vibe,  ambiance (relative to typical pizza joints) and the fact that they offer some good salads, as in, salads I actually want to eat- no flavorless iceberg with Italian dressing here. 

I've been to this location a few times with friends, once on a date myself and have recommended it to friends as a good date spot. I will warn that the wait can be long for a chance to eat at my beloved little star so be prepared. And by prepared, I mean do not go to little star when you are starving to death, about to pass out. Go put your name on the list when you're starting to get hungry, then head either across the street to 821 (or to another nearby bar), grab a beer, relax and anticipate the yummy pizza in your near future.
author: Jennifer E.

description:
a haiku for u:

deep dish little star
oh it's so gooey and yum
sorry paxtis nope
author: Melanie C.

description:
i tried to call in a pizza ahead of time for dine-in so i wouldn't have to wait 40 minutes for it to bake.  it turns out that you can only call in for take out.  fine.  i go little star pizza and got onto the waiting list.  i asked if i can order the pizza so it will be baking while i'm waiting for my seat.  again, the answer was no.  you can only order a pizza when you are seated.  which i find outrageous.  (i've always called in my pizzas at zacharys).  

i had my bf drop me off at the place so i can sign up for a table as he went to find a parking spot.  (parking is pretty difficult in this area).  buttttttttt, you cannot be seated until your whole party is there.  so a table opened up in the 15 minutes that he was trying to find parking, and i was not seated because he wasn't there!  even thought he came in like 30 seconds after the table opened because they seated the people after me.  so we waited another 30 minutes before another table opened.

this place gets 2 stars for how inconvenient the service is.  it gets one more star because the crust was really good.  oh, also, they serve sodas in cans.  so a can of soda costs 2$ without refills?  

if i had to go get a deep dish pizza in san francisco, i'd go to patxi's, which, i admit, is not as good, but at least you get seated immediately and the service wasn't frustrating.
author: H. L.

description: Tried this for the first time the other night...limited menu so make sure you're in the mood for pizza - great deep dish (looking forward to trying something other than sausage - the people I was with aren't the most adventurous sort), really nice service, cute place.  Would definitely go back.  (one heads up... they only take cash)
author: Kristin D.

description: Solid 4 stars....my 5 star experience would have to be in Italy, but that's neither here nor there.  This place was delish!  Nice thin crust perfectly dusted with cornmeal.  I hadn't heard of Little Star until this week and from the other reviews I guess I missed out on the deep dish.  That will have to be my next trip.
author: Brye L.

description: Not sure what all the hype was about with Yelpers, it's just an OK place and the pizza was just OK.  I only tried this place out because of the rave reviews on Yelp and I don't agree that it's that good.  I went to Paxti's during the same week and throught they made a better pizza.
author: Kmaintl L.

description:
Hey dudes, I'm not just being contrary to be contrary, on the contrary, I'm just trying to be honest.  

(OK, skip this first paragraph, it's shite!)

I think that saying you love one pizza and hate the next is an almost useless exercise.  Pizza is just one of those things that is done so many different ways, that one persons favorite method is the next persons death.  I don't know you, you may be my inverted pizza doppleganger.  Do you like Pizza Hut, Chuck E. Cheese, Escape from NY Pizza, Pizzeria Delfina, Patxi's, Orgasmica, etc...  I'm sure if I had the time, and patience I could go on and on about crust styles, cooking styles, toppings, sauces, etc.  but I don't and won't.  Having said that Pizza made with crap is gonna taste crap, and pizza made with quality ingredients, has a chance.  If we cut our pizza teeth together, compared pizza notes together, sat down and philosophized about pizza, if I knew where you were coming from, then I could take your advice.  Hey wait, I could read your other pizza reviews, but I'm just too lazy for that and prefer to rant a little.

Anyway, I digress.  I can't say I'm a fan of Little Star pizza.  The first time I went there, I got one of their deep dishes and one thinny to share.  It was long ago, but the one things I remember was there was no balance to the toppings on the deep dish, i wish i could remember which one it was, but I do remember it coming out too salty, needing something to contrast the salt to bring it all together.  There was something mediocre about the thinny too, but I forget.  The second time I went to LS, whatever.  I had another pizza there tonight and was disappointed once again.  This time just a plain cheese thin one; this is like the blank canvas of pizzas, upon which a great pizza can be built, but also could and should be great in it's plainness.  So, in addition to the crust being burnt (this should NEVER happen), I found the crust too chewy to be enjoyable and wasn't too jazzed about its flavor when I got to the end.  I wasn't crazy about the sauce and even the cheese was not that great, I think too thick for a thin crust, but that's just my opinion, take it or leave it.  So, i don't like their pizza, you do, I think we can still be friends.

I do like the ambiance here, the dark dining room, quite music, I remember the bartenders being friendly, comfy couches to wait the two hours it can take to get a table.  Even the ATM has a pretty cheap service charge, which is great since this place doesn't take plastic (wtf).

P.S. PBR = VOMIT  (maybe we can't be friends)
author: Adrian L.

description: Pretty good, and I like that they have both thin and thick pizzas.  But their thin pizza is not as good as Cheeseboard and their thick pizza is not as good as Zachary's.  We also felt that we were rushed out when we were almost finished.
author: Min L.

description: Chicago-style pizza fans REJOICE!  Having moved to SF from Chicago, I've had Lou Malnati's shipped here just to savor the tomato-smothered, cheesy, goodness. No more now that I have Little Star.  Order the "Classic" deep-dish.  I've had it my last four visits and cannot seem to move on to a new order as the "Classic" is soooo damn good.
author: Katie S.

description:
I'm a Chicagoan . . . who likes pizza, big, thick, put you in misery by the time you're done pizza. I've been to all the biggies, Gino's, Lou's, Giordano's, as well as the neighborhood's greatest. Needless to say, moving to SF has left wanting for authentic Chicago Style Pizza, so I've tried the most talked about places in town. I tried Paxti's and it was OK, a very nice meal-I'd even go back--but a touch underwhelming, especially for the price. Little Star really lived up to the hype. It is true Chicago style in most every way save for the overall size--in SF "deep dish" isn't all that deep. The sauce and ingredients were tasty, and I loved the crust, in some ways, even better than the big Chicago places like Lou Malnatti's. There was a bit less crust and it was sweeter and crunchier. So while you definitely get more pizza for the price back home, Little Star is definitely the reigning SF champ, at least so far. 

Alas, my true favorite Chicago pizza is stuffed pizza, like they specialize in at Giordano's back home. It's a cheesier pizza overall, whereas crust and sauce dominated deep dish, and that doesn't seem to exist out here. Nevertheless, Little Star should be able to get me by until by next visit to Chicago.
author: Michael M.

description: Word!  I just read the negative reviews of this place and was relieved to know that I am not the only one who thinks this place is WAY over-rated! The whole " bridge and tunnel trying to be hip " and the "marina sluts slumming"  (my personal favorite) are great descriptions of this poor crowd. Ditto with the service! Some of the worst in the city!
author: sockanooni s.

description: I went to Little Star last weekend. By far the best pizza I have had in a long time! Deep dish is my favorite! It had a local vibe and the service was great. Everyone must go!!!
author: Gabriella R.

description:
Wow! The pizza is amazing! I have never liked deep dish pizza, but I'm new to town and some friends suggested this place. The restaurant itself is alright, although very loud. The salad was a great deal, and the 'Little Star' pizza with chicken was an entirely new experience in pizza. It was like lasagna in a delicious pizza shell. What's even better? Leftovers! Leftovers are guaranteed since it's impossible to eat more than 2 pieces of pizza at once. 
Great for takeout, but only if you call it in, as it takes ~1/2 hour to prepare the pizza.
author: Michelle N.

description: Indeed, this is damn good deep dish. I haven't been to the Windy City, but according to Chicago natives, Little Star rivals some of Chi-town's best.
author: Deanna T.

description: Over one thousand two hundred reviews.  There are no words left to speak.  Except yum yum and triple yum. Just get there early and hungry.
author: Ash A.

description: Thinking of Little Star's deep dish pizza makes me want to do leaps and turns across the dance floor. I usually get pepperoni and mushroom. It takes a while for the pizza (perhaps 30 minutes?) to arrive but the wait is absolutely worth it. :)
author: Ileana H.

description: Yes this place is great. I have been here a handful of times and have always been impressed with the pizza.  The deep dish pizza is so good. It took me awhile to get used to them not putting a lot of ingredients but I understand thats not the style. I usually order the deep dish pizza with olives and mushrooms. I highly recommend this place and its by far the best pizza I have had in San Francisco.
author: Marissa Z.

description: Twinkle twinkle. Whenever I think of deep dish pizza, I imagine an abominable amount of grease gushing out every orifice... but I was pleasantly surprised that Little Star's pizza turned out to be very fresh and not over the top. Try it with the cornmeal crust. Mammamia!
author: I Love Beef C.

description: Delicious deep dish pizza--close to Chicago style. Corn meal crust is incredible--better than Zachary's pizza. I do think, however, that the pizza topping mixture is slightly better at Zachary's. Good service, both in person and over the phone.
author: Holly M.

description: Excellent stuff - started with the garlic bread, which was spreadable roasted garlic cloves and toasted bread - quite nice - and then moved on to the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish, sans green olives, and it was super. Nothing left on any plate in sight.
author: Anders P.

description: By far the best pizza I've eaten in the Bay Area (although I've yet to make it to Zachary's...), not to mention they actually have real Chicago deep dish pizza, not the cheap imitation stuff offered up at most other places that can only claim to know how to do it.  Now only if they could cook me up a real stuffed pizza I'd be in pizza heaven :)
author: Nick B.

description: I might be in the minority, but I'm not that into Little Star.  I always seem to end up waiting for a table for 30+ minutes, then dealing with waiters that obviously missed the "Be nice to customers" lesson on the first day of Service Industry School.  And to top it off, I don't think the pizza is all that great.
author: Jess T.

description: Yum!  We went to the Mission location but for some reason it was closed, so we decided to come over to this location because we were craving deep dish pizza!  We got here 30 min before closing, but didn't feel rushed.  We ordered the Little Star Deep Dish which has feta, tomatoes, mozzarella, mushrooms and spinach and we added in sausage for some meat.  The waitress told us it takes 30 minutes and asked if we wanted an appetizer so we ordered the garlic bread.  The garlic bread is not what you probably think it is.  Its sour dough bread served with a roasted garlic and butter and you basically make it yourself by spreading it on.  The pizza was yummy but I don't know if it's better than Zachary's it sure comes close... I think the toppings at Zachary's tastes better but the cornbread crust here is definitely amazing and tasty.
author: Kymberli C.

description: Today was my first time going to this place sober. It was funny coming inside and actually seeing light. I did not remember going into this place at all. I just remember being wasted and waiting for pizza. Regardless, going there for happy hour between 5 and 630 is probably your best bet. It's not too crowded then and they have $1 off beer. So a pint of good beer for $3.50 is a good deal to me. I have not had the Thin crust pizza yet but I have had the Deep Dish. The deep dish I don't think is as good as chicago pizza but I do like their tomatoe sauce and I think the crust takes great. Next time it's on for the thin crust pizza.
author: Nir B.

description:
Best Deep dish for sure. 

Little star and classic are the best...also the cheese cake might be the best suprise!
author: Preston Y.

description:
try the mediterranean chicken or the never-miss sausage and mushroom combination.

it's so difficult to explain what the closest thing to a perfect pizza consists of, but spotting it is much like sexual harrassment: you know it when you experience it.

too many words for such a great pie.
the shit sells itself.
try it, fraidy cat!
 
okay, bottom line:
 this is the pizza place i go to when i'm sober.


that says a whole lot.
now go. be in the know.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
i was hopeful not that many people knew about this hole-in-the-wall pizza place on divis . . . unfortunately it looks like i'm wrong.

i adore Little Star Pizza.  i love chicago-style deep dish pizza.  my friends from chicago even admit it's the best around.  

maybe i should give it one star so people will avoid it?!
author: kristen h.

description:
i grew up in chicago.  i like little star over zachary's.

it makes me foodgasm a little.
author: Michael M.

description: I'm from the East Coast, so I'm very particular about my pizza.  Little Star does not disappoint.  I have learned my lesson not to go there completely starving, because you're gonna have to wait a while to eat, but it's definitely worth it.  They have a cute bar where you can sit and sip delicious champagne cocktails while waiting for your table.  Also, best jukebox in the city, hands down.  They are cash only, but have a convenient ATM right by the front door and the charge is only 25 cents!
author: Michelle L.

description: This is by far the best deep dish pizza I have found in the city.  Almost as good as the real deal deep dish from Chicago. Little Star has a great atmosphere and a good selection of music on the jukebox.  What I didn't like was the extremely long wait to get your food.  Don't wait till your starving to go here.  You may pass out of hunger before you get your pizza.
author: Vanessa A.

description:
little star is my heaven.
the little star pizza itself is the best pizza i have ever had!!!!
the mediterranean one is pretty good too.
even their salad made my mouth water.
they offer pbr in a can. now tell me where else i can get that and an awesome slice of pizza.

if i could i would go to little star every day but unfortunately i cant.

best deep dish pizza i have ever had. BJ's is shit compared to this.
author: A. V.

description: what can I say.  Can't wait for the new one to open in the Mission.  All other pizza spots in the hood are hearby served notice.
author: Eagan I.

description: I would always see this place when I go to the Independent, but would never really have the time to stop by.  Luckily, earlier this month, I finally had a chance.  Their deep dish is brilliant.  I had the pepperoni and cheese, pretty basic, but it's what I like.  I'd say this place beets Zachary's, but for deep dish pizza, Paxti's is my favorite.  Little Star is a very close second though.  It's very nice inside.  I imagine if we needed a table we would've needed to wait because the place was packed.  We ate sitting on the sidewalk in front of the Independent, which went great actually, I really enjoyed it.  I'm sure I'll be coming back for the full dining experience.
author: Todd V.

description: I love me a deep dish little star pizza from little star!  Yes, both the the particular pie I'm speaking of and the name of the establishment in which it is baked is called little star.  Their thin crust is good too, but the deep dish..... fahgeddaboutit.  I've eaten in at little star once and I'm hip to it's vibe-age.  You'll love it too if you're in to darkness and candlelight.  While joining me to pick up a pizza my father referred to it as "sketchy" :)  Sure enough he enjoyed several slices!
author: Michael R.

description: The place was nice and the service was good. The staff was friendly and did a good job of giving our privacy while making sure our glasses were full and food was on time. We decided to go w the deep dish .. we both are from chicago and the reviews said it matches up. it doesnt. The pizza actually isnt all that bad but I think next time I will go for the thin crust. Overall the service was good, pizza was ok, good draft beers but I feel it is not worthy for the four and half stars it received. Written with a little chicago bias.
author: Tony M.

description: This place is A-MAZING. Pizza so good you'll think you're in Chicago! Only drawback is their cash-only policy. But the pizza's good enough to merit a stop at the atm -- oh, and the $2 PBRs are worth it, too.. make sure you ask for a glass to pour it in (they'll give you a frosty one straight from the freezer).
author: C'est La V.

description:
Cheese pizza as good or better than cheeseboard.

Have to go back for the deep dish to compare to Zach's
author: Karthik K.

description:
Giving this place 3.5 stars for my first visit... 

Chose to go here last Friday for dinner because I couldn't eat meat. So I figured pizza would be a good option. I've actually been in search for some really good pizza spots and this place has stellar reviews on Yelp. 

We originally tried to go to the Valencia location because it is closer to our house but after driving around looking for parking for 15 minutes we decided to try the Divisadero location instead. So, we head over to that location and what do you know....we find a parking sport just around the corner. =) Place is smaller that the Valencia spot but I like the cozy feel to it. Tables are small and not an ideal place for large parties...although there was probably a group of 8-10 people towards the back of the restaurant. There was a slight wait (only 15 minutes) so the host advised us to take a look at the menu and place our order anyway because it would take 30 minutes for them to have it ready. There are a decent number of vegetarian options that all sounded absolutely delicious. We opted for the vegetarian deep dish. It was just me and the hubby that night but we ordered the 12". By this time we were so hungry that the 9" seemed too small since that was the only thing we were ordering. After being seated we realized that this place is cash only. Thankfully, there is an ATM right in the front of the restaurant and only charges you an extra $0.25 (not including your bank's fee of course). About 20 minutes later our pizza comes out and it looks sooooo yummy! Definitely a good pizza! Not great but still very good. I think it was the crust that threw me off. I think it would be better if it wasn't so crunchy...maybe like a bit crunchy on the out side but softer or more doughy on the inside? I don't know....it just couldve been better.Warning - a 12" deep dish pizza is too big for 2 people. I only ate 2 slices and the hubby ate 2 1/2. We ended up taking a lil more than 3 slices home. And when I picked up the to-go box it felt like it weighed 5 lbs.! That's some heavy stuff! Anyway, still a good pizza place and I definitely want to come back to try their thin crust pizzas.
author: BrElla4eva H.

description:
I met a friend here after work & I liked that it was casual, but not too casual.  The pies are also fairly priced.

We ordered the Vegetarian Deep Dish & I was madly in love with it.  If you love deep dish pizza, then this this is your spot.  I really do believe that pizza preference is very personal, but Little Star is one of MY faves!  All of the ingredients are very fresh tasting & the crust is thick & cracker- like.  Yum!
author: Cryssy R.

description: Try these: the "little star" (deep dish) and the white pie (thin crust).
author: Luca C.

description:
So I've heard a lot about this Little Star place, and it's been on my bookmark list for a while.  Yesterday my friend and I were driving down Divis and thought..."why not?"  I was impressed when we first walked in, it was a hip funky little spot, jukebox music playing, fun art displayed, nice little bar and I started getting excited.  We decided to share a garden salad which was very delicious and ordered the Little Star deep dish.  As it was being delivered to our table my mouth started watering...boy o boy the long wait is finally over!  Was it all the hype!? or have people who rave about this place not ever tried deep dish before?  I was disappointed to discover while the pizza is good, it's nothing out of the ordinary and my friend completely agreed. I'm reminded often by my Sconi boy that San Francisco  just doesn't know how to do pub food, Chicago dogs, and pizza like they do in the Mid West so I'm not accustomed to what true deep dish is like, but I'm hoping it's more memorable than the one I had last night.

The service was fantastic though...our waiter was super attentive however our friends who we ran into (table of 5 guys) said the same waiter was a jerk to them.  One friend's exact words were "The waiter hates us, I've gotten more attention from him just standing 5 minutes here with you girls. Go figure"
author: Tanger T.

description: Little Star was just okay for me.  Sure, the pizza was better than a pizza at Domino's, but it was just okay.  Hue L. and I stopped by on our way to Matcha at the Asian Art Museum this past Thursday.  It was about 6pm and there was no wait.  We got a nice tall table for 2 more toward the rear of the restaurant.  It is very DARK back there.  I like the whole dimly lit romantic vibe, but I wasn't on a romantic outing and I could hardly read the menu.  We ended up splitting a small deep dish 1/2 Classic and 1/2 Mediterranean Chicken.  (I also had a Pom-pagne, which was good!)  Maybe we just chose wrong, but I'd be willing to go back and try some of their other selections - like maybe their namesake pizza!
author: Kris L.

description:
i took a newly transplanted east coaster to little star last night.  his review: definitely above average thin crust pizza and great to find a place to go when he starts feeling homesick for new york.  i think that's a good endorsement for little star - if a pure-bred east coaster finds it above par, the rest of us should be satisfied.  

personally, i thought that the thin crusts were delicious.  the simple cheese pizza was practically perfect.  the pesto chicken, which is usually my favorite pizza combo, was not salty enough, so it almost seemed bland.  dressed up with crushed red pepper and parmesan, it was acceptable but not the best i have had.  

we went late and were able to get in immediately, which was nice since i was worried about waiting forever on an empty stomach at 10pm.  the service was ok.  the waitress screwed up one of our orders and did immediately fix the mistake, but she made us feel that the error had been our fault, which was a little weird.  

all in all, i was not disappointed, even after reading amazing reviews like liz's.  that's definitely a good thing and worth a return visit.
author: Kirsten F.

description: Some thick bomb azz pizza. Love the Lil Star combo pizza, fresh, veggies and great sauce. thick, filling. ReallyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyYUM
author: SForiginal T.

description:
the deep dish here is DELICIOUS.

try the secret "brass monkey" pizza (not on the menu) that is basically the "little star" w/added sausage.

love the cornmeal crust and the hearty portions.
author: Wendell M.

description: Yum, yum, yum.  Classic deep dish pizza -- I dream about it.  Always a wait, but sometimes you can get a seat at the bar immediately; enjoy a beer or glass of wine; and munch on roasted garlic with bread and butter.  This pizza is terrific, and the cornmeal crust is to die for.  Cash Only.
author: Christine S.

description: Totally BLAND.  I was expecting greatness.  I had heard it compared to Zachary's and I was looking forward to a great deep dish on this side of the Bay.  The atmosphere was dark (nothing special, just dark) and very loud (just from patrons talking) and the pizza (vegetarian) was completely bland.  All I could taste was the crust - which was interesting, but not particularly flavorful and not enough to carry the pie.  I'm giving it two stars since there will always be a redeeming quality to bread and cheese, but otherwise this place is an over-rated bust.
author: Sarah L.

description: Really, the only bad thing you can say about this place is that it's insanely difficult to get a table.  The thin crust is divine, the deep dish is out of this world, and if you have room, the cheesecake and gelato are a perfect finish!!  Go with an appetite and a lot of people so you can try a lot of things.  Or just get take out once a week and work your way through  the menu!
author: kerry l.

description:
the pizza will own you.
the beers will compliment.
the drink specials will titillate.
the aromas will seduce.
the service will accommodate with a smile. 
the jukebox will let you know you are not as indie as you think.
author: Gabby K.

description:
Getting good pizza in the Bay Area is a challenge, one I've spent years tackling.  Little Star is by far the best place for deep-dish.  I prefer it to Zachary's in the East Bay, which is also good stuff, for the fresher flavor, lighter crust, and heavier emphasis on sauce and seasonings.  Patxi's does not deserve to be mentioned in the same breath as the other two.

I'm not crazy about the noisy atmosphere or the Mission-trawling hipster douches the place attracts like flies on a Friday night, but that's why they have a to-go service.
author: Shaenon G.

description:
We went to this place at 6:30 pm Sunday, based on the reviews here and got immediate seating "because the person before you got a beer and then walked out."  (Note to self: take the hint next time.)

The place was packed.  Contrary to the reviews and the LSP website, the music is nothing special.  There was one Elliott Smith track, but for the most part it was standard top 40 radio: Sting, Radiohead, and R.E.M.   But played at ear-shattering volume.  I've been to quieter rock concerts.

It took close to an hour to get the pizza, at which point we got doggy bags and took the pizza to Cafe Azur because we just couldn't take it any more.  I was partially deaf, my 19 year old brother's ears were ringing, and his girlfriend had a headache for the next two hours.  

Great pizza, but you have to be drunk to find this appealing.  Either that, or you REALLY REALLY want to be cool.

Incidentally, I've tried posting this review on citysearch.com, and it just never shows up.  Makes me doubt citysearch's objectivity, to say the least.  As at least one other person did, I signed up on Yelp specifically to warn people off this place.
author: Will S.

description: Best pizza I've had in years.  The sauce is out of this world! The thin crust is amazing and the deep dish absolute perfection.  I like starting with the Mixed Greens Salad which is nicely balanced.  It's pretty loud and can fill up fast so go early.  Also, they don't deliver which really bums me out when the rain is coming down and I'm wishing I had a nice hot slice of comfort food. But, they are worth the trip. (note: cash ONLY for pick-up!)
author: Lisa A.

description: I'm not sure if i really have anything possitive to say about this place but everytime we go there, they screw up our order! Once the crust was burnt, another time they gave us the wrong order... so, I'm not so happy with this place right now. The pizza is not as great as everyones says....
author: Dhoris P.

description: Great salads, delish pizza -- my favorite pizza place in SF.  I miss it now that I'm in NY.  Definitely better than Zachary's -- something in the crust and sauce that's just tastier.  Yum.
author: Darlene L.

description: This little star will always hold a place in my heart.  The original location somehow captures a ghetto underground neighborhood vibe that the new mission location surprisingly can't master.  Go figure.  Who's hipster now, bitches?  The cramped quarters and candlelight make the heart grow fonder.  The tomatoes on that deep dish make me moan like Rachael Ray biting into one of her 30 minute meals.  This little star is an easy five star for me.
author: Dubs W.

description: Yum I'm drooling just thinking about it.  The tomato sauce is soooo perfectly spiced, and the crust just melts in your mouth.  Salads and other appetizers are super yummy too.  They are really busy most of the time, but don't be afraid to order take-out.  You'll bypass the trendies hanging out at the bar, and people will glare at you with envy as you leave with a hot, heavy pizza in your arms.
author: Leah P.

description: I'm from Chicago - this place measures up.  Don't tell my family - admitting to this is like putting ketchup on hot dogs.
author: Erin K.

description:
service 3.5
food 4.5
ambiance 4
the .5 thing made sense so the math would work out neatly.
sweet place to walk into. off the grind of divis and into a comfy little neighborhoody feeling, oh pizza joint perhaps. the look on the waitresses' face was priceless when i tried to order two medium sized pizzas for 2 peoples. she talked me down to two small deep dish, and after a salad we barely finished it. delicious. did not taste heavy and greasy, a little tomato action on top, fresh, and the cornbread dough is dope. 
"do you need any change on that" chaps my ass for some reason, so our sweet if inattentive server is getting docked. 
check this place out.
author: Jeremi M.

description: I heart Little Star.  That corn meal crust does it to me everytime...
author: Kiera E.

description: The pizza here is good chicago-style pizza... but it's not as good as Paxti's on Hayes.  If you are a fan of cornbread crust then you may think otherwise - I just found it to be "a-ok" rather than "great".  They also only accept cash which can be a pain.  They do have a good soda selection and the ambiance is very nice.
author: J D.

description: So I'm in love with the white pie, even thinking about it makes me salivate. Sorry maybe talk of my glands aren't the most appetizing, but seriously I'm drooling here. I really wish they delivered... sniffle. Take out works though! The atmosphere and fantastic choice of music makes me want to stay all night and I generally stay for hours. Great choice of beers, delicious garlic bread, delectable caprese salad and really a great staff with a wonderful sense of humor and finesse!
author: Jessie J.

description: I had a pretty good time here with my buddies.  We ordered the garlic bread, chicken wings,  chicken deep dish, gelato, and cheesecake.  The large pizza satisfied all us heartily.  A bit too hearty I might add(don't forget those antacids!)  The high point of the dinner was definitely the dessert.   Both the gelato and the cheesecake were very creamy.  This place is also a nice place to meet new people.  I realized I had met fellow yelper Jimmy K. here who also seemed to be having a good time.  Overall, great place to go to for pizza.
author: Doogie H.

description: Hey, where else are you going to get a decent Chicago-style deep dish pizza in the city?  If you are (un)fortunate enough to have ever had a Chicago-style deep dish pizza, then you, too, would know the cravings that one gets and you, too, would become a regular of this place.  =)  However, be ready for a commitment, because the typical wait is ~45 minutes long just to get a table and they don't take reservations in advance.
author: Kelvin K.

description:
After hearing great things and making several attempts to eat here, we finally made it.  The first time we tried, we wanted to get lunch on a weekend.  We made the trek over to Little Star only to find that it was closed.  Okay.  That sucks.  No lunch, even on weekends?  The second time we tried to go for dinner.  We made it over there, and... oops. They're closed on Mondays.  That also sucks.  Our third attempt was on a Sunday night, and we decided that if it didn't work out, we were giving up.  What's the point of a neighborhood pizza place that requires planning in advance?  And indeed, when we got there, we initially thought it was closed again.  We groaned, noticing the completely black exterior.  But we got closer and--wonder of wonders--it was open!  You wouldn't know it were it not for the lack of the usual iron bars in front of the door.  But it was definitely open, and we were seated immediately.  And overall, we had a great experience, owing entirely to the excellent pizza.

Our service was adequate, but barely.  We were seated for probably six or seven minutes before we got water, which was served in a medium-sized carafe.  That ran out shortly after we got our pizza, and it was never refilled until we were given our bill.  Nevertheless, the server was polite, and anyway, we weren't making any big effort to get his attention, so it didn't hurt our overall experience too badly.

My biggest complaint was how dark it was inside the restaurant.  We were seated in a nook on the side-front of the restaurant, with walls on two sides and an opaque curtain on the third.  The meager light from our candle really didn't do much.  With pizza that's this good, and this gorgeous, I'd prefer to be able to see my food.

The pizza was so good that it overcame any of those (relatively minor) complaints.  We had a thin crust pizza, with all sorts of toppings.  Everything was extremely fresh and high-quality, and it reminded me of the homemade pizzas that I often make (usually with less perfect results).

We went halfsies on the pizza, with my girlfriend getting her faves on her half, and me getting mine.  I had ordered black olives on my half, and it came out without any olives.  I brought this to the server's attention and told him it was still great without them, and he took the olives off the bill.

Anyway, we definitely plan on coming back.  But we'll be checking our calendars carefully first, and bringing our flashlights.
author: David B.

description:
We've eaten here a few times, I'm not really a deep dish (thick crust) pizza fan, but my wife really loves it.  When we do eat here, we try to come early right around the time they open.  We've never had a problem looking for parking or getting seated because of that.

The wait staff is very friendly and attentive.  We've tried both the thick and thin crusts here, and they were both pretty good.  I prefer the thin crust over the thick (just my preference).  I'm a pretty big eater and I usually start to feel full from either 3 1/2 slices of thin crust, or 2 slices of thick crust.  Great pizza place overall.
author: Cal H.

description: It's good pizza.  Expensive, non-delivery, cash only pretty good pizza.  The best deep dish I've had in the city.
author: Heidi P.

description: The only reason this pizza isn't as good as Gino's East in Chicago is the lack of a sausage patty option.  We're talking full sausage coverage here, people.  It seems unlikely that this option is available anywhere in California, so go to Little Star and enjoy the delicious pizza and semi-pretentious, semi-indie jukebox.
author: Sam P.

description: The pizza has been thoroughly described by others here.  It is good, and distinctly different from what you can get throughout the City.  But it is expensive, parking is bad, it's cash only, and for me the Number One reason Not to Eat at Little Star is the ambiance.  Concrete floors and loud scrapey chairs and loud music with nothing to dampen the noise makes me feel like I'm attending bingo in a church basement.  I only get take out.
author: David N.

description:
thick or thin? that is the question, my friends, think or thin. how about both? the best way to experience little star is in a big group (still fun for a romantic date though). that way, you can enjoy both the thin and thick crusts. 

The cornmeal crust on the deep dish serves as a nice foundation for the thick tomato sauce and cheese that tops it. i highly recommend the 'little star'- spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic. I'm usually a meat-on-my-pizza guy, but not in this case. Wow.

As for the thin crust, I gotta go for the classic-sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions. Wow, as well.

The ambiance is fantastic. Dimly lit with candles (great whether you're out with the group or the hottie), interesting local art, varied bar- everything from PBR to some fantastic wines. 

if you go, bring cash (all they accept) or there's an ATM in the front (only $0.25 surcharge- hell, i should get all my cash here!).

so, it's 4 big stars for little star.
author: Billy L.

description: Five stars for Little Star! I'm from the Midwest and have craved deep dish pizza ever since I left. I did a jig o' joy when this place opened in my neighborhood. Fresh ingredients, perfectly crispy crust, just perfect. I take my folks there when they're in town, I go with friends there when we just want to chill and have a great dinner, I even took my Italian friend there and he complimented the staff on the food.
