What more could I want? I haven't been to the one in the Mission, but I'm sure it's just as good. I'll go again and again.
author: Angela W.

description:
the best service i have ever had. the waiter was attentive but not all over us. he noticed everything but didn't hover. 
the place is almost always packed but the wait is not that bad because it's pizza. 
and the pizza is great, deep dish Chicago style. 
the crust like light crunchy, couldn't eat more than two pieces so much cheese and toppings.
author: Morgan G.

description: Fantastic pizza. Both the deep dish and thin crust were amazing. Love the $2 PBR's. Great atmosphere and friendly staff.
author: scott o.

description: Little Star, I blame you for being the one thing that's keeping me from being a true vegan. Damn you, delicous!
author: Stumbalina b.

description: This place rules. Awesome massive deep dish pizzas that require the use of a fork and knife. Small "hole in the wall" atmosphere and ironically a waiter who used to work at Hole in the Wall in Austin served us. Cheekiness aside, if you are looking for a quality pizza with interesting toppings, Little Star Pizza is your place. Enjoy.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Really enjoyed this place.  Nice space.  Very good pizza.  Wings were awesome too.  Very good beer selection.  Good deep dish pizza with an excellent sauce and not too filling.  Wait was lengthy.
author: Tim S.

description: Over Hyped, i got a deep dish that was watery and it almost came apart. very crowded, service not great.  parking sucks. would rather just get patxi's
author: Quailty P.

description: Who would've thought one of the best compliments I could pay to a pizza joint would be: damn good chicken wings! But that's only because it was the first thing to pass my lips (save for a few beers while we waited). The jukebox is chockfull of terrific indie rock and a few great hair metal bands -- take me down to the Paradise City indeed. But the pizza is front, center and primo. We shared both thin and deep dish versions and everything tasted delectable. I wish I lived nearby so I could do carry-out. Instead, I'll have to wait with the rabble to sample the taste explosion that hit my mouth last weekend.
author: Andrew S.

description:
i grew up in bakersfield, ca.....not an exciting town, but a town with Pizzaville, USA.  the finest pizza i know.  that is, until i was introduced to Little Star. 

i'm a thin crust girl - so i could care less about the thick crust.  the thin crust  was baked to a crisp, cracker-like perfection.  but not tooooo thin (like fancy pizzas can get).  i know a pizza is in a league of it's own when i eat the crust (and think of them as some of my favorite bites).  i usally discard that last part of the triangle as a doughy, inedible blob.

 the sauce was filled with loads of herbs - brilliant on the tongue.  and as a classic pizza lover - our only topping was good ol reliably tasty pepperoni.

bravo little star - my new favorite pizza place (sorry Pizzaville).

ps - the service was great  - esp since we were annoyingly late for a play - bu they got us settled on time and with a smile.
author: Kate F.

description:
Please check all that apply....

__ I like fresh ingredients
__ I like damn good pizza, deep dish or thin crust
__ I don't mind a bit of a wait

How did you do?  2 of 3?  Then Little Star Pizza is a "Must Try".
author: Ashley Q.

description: Yum. Fancy-pants pizza for a bit of $$. Four of us headed here on a Tuesday night and by the time we finished place was packed and people waiting to eat. Juke box GREAT! A little too dark but service fantastic. Since deep dish takes awhile to cook, we ordered a thin-crust to hold us over. They were great about making a vegan pizza (and for less $). Crust deeelish, and if you live it the 'hood, order take out! Plus, the cheesecake is tops.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night and there was a 40 minute wait for a seat. There are also options to get a bar seat, which is full service or order take out. We decided to just wait for a seat. As time past, more and more people showed up and put their name on a list. Not your average pizza joint with a waiting list. The staff here are very quick and super friendly. When we got our seat, we ordered their Spicy Chicken Wings. This comes with baby slices of carrots and blue cheese, they don't serve ranch here. The wings were a bit salty, but was very flavorful. We wanted to try out their garlic bread, but they ran out! I'm not sure if that's a good or bad thing. We had their large deep dish half vegetarian-mushrooms, onions, zucchini, black olives, bell peppers, garlic and half Classic- sausage, mushrooms, bell peppers, and onions. Both were very delish! How come I never thought about putting the sauce on the top to keep the bottom nice and crunchy?! The cheese was gooey, toppings were generous and sauce was perfect. If you love non-oily, crispy, flaky, hot, gooey pizza, this is one to try. 
Best time to come is during the weekdays between 5-7, an inside source had said. 
Cash only! ATM machine there only charges .25 for a transaction and whatever your bank charges you.
author: Annie D.

description: For a while, there seemed to be no stopping the number of small restaurants and bars popping up in this corner of the city. I love it because I can finally bar hop in my hood, and Little Star is one of my fave places to hang out. The food is great, and one of the owners waits on you while the other is in the kitchen working his magic. Neither of them are from New York or Chicago, but their pizzas have fooled many of my Chicago & New York friends.
author: Babs P.

description: Blue Jay, Tsunami, Little Star, Oh My!!!  A fantastic addition to the Divis food chain.  This little pizza joint rocks as hard as it's indie classic jukebox.  I never cared for deep dish pizza until I had the Little Star, and now I am hooked like the crackies down the street.  The second, maybe third time I went back by myself to grab a pizza to go, I noticed a hand written sign on the front door reading, "Closed we ran out of Pizza Dough, really!!!!--My first thought " You've gotta be sh#ttin me, it's 9pm." Brian the owner is a great guy, my hats off to him and his success of revamping  once middle eastern cafe/restaurant, into a neighborhood jewel.
author: jonathan b.

description:
Thank god I won't have to cross the bridge for a deep dish pie.  Great jukebox.  Super cool Champagne cocktails--love the Kool Aid one.

Meanwhile, be sure to try roasted garlic on the pie, it really ::burp::: made it perfect.

We cannot wait to come back and try the thin crust.  MMMMMMM.
author: Mel B.

description: Of the pizza I have had in the city so far, Little Star is easily one of the top in my list. (If only they delivered or were closer to me!) The deep dish is excellent, with a perfect crust, fresh sauce and great topping combinations. The thin crust is really tasty as well. I love the caprese salad as a perfect appetizer for one or two. They have a great selection of wines and beer. The atmosphere is casual, but classy and kind of fun. Service has been alternately really friendly and great, and bordering on rude and neglectful. Other than this, Little Star is an awesome pizza place.
author: Barbs J.

description:
My friends and I went here last Saturday after recommendations from a friend. Plus, I've been on a deep-dish pizza kick(thanks a lot Leanne, David, Lauren, and Jim!)
Parking: you're stuck with the street. Use mass transit if at all possible. Otherwise, you just have to circle around. I did find spots on a Saturday nite around Turk and Eddy.
Wait: you can't phone in reservations. For a Saturday nite, it actually wasn't too bad. A wait for table (for 3) ran roughly 35 minutes. However, the wait is shorter if you plan on eating around 7. Beyond 8, anywhere up to 45/60 minutes.
Appetizers: I highly recommend the garlic bread and mixed salad. Bread is very delicious. There's something about butter and roasted bulb of garlic to get the taste buds going. Definitely get appetizers as a deep dish pizza takes 30 minutes to bake.
The pizza: Right now, I'm slightly leaning towards deep dish as the best type of pizza around. Great menu with vegetarian, classic, and custom-topping pizzas. We ordered the classic with sausage, mushrooms, bell peppers, and onions. A large will feed about 3, so you can do the math for larger or smaller groups. Considering we were very hungry, we got our fill with about 2 slices per person. The fresh tomatoes were the deal maker for me and I loved the crust.
Service and environment: servers were very friendly. Nice couches and chairs in the waiting area. The main competitor for Little Star might be Zachary's. Zachary's is great, but has more of a college feel to it, and sometimes it feels a bit cramped inside. Little Star is better for buds or a group wanting great pizza before an evening in the city. More ambiance and it's easier to have a conversation while listening to the jukebox.
Overall: I was very pleased with the pizza and service here. More appetizers(including wings) give a slight edge over Zachary's. On the other hand, they don't take plastic so BRING CASH. But, there's an ATM inside for  your convenience. 
A great place to eat before bar-hopping in NOPA or a nite at the Independent. I highly recommend going to the Divisadero location and will go here again or order for takeout.
author: Neil N.

description: The classic deep dish is fantastic. The tomato sauce is tangy and really tasty. The cornbread crust is great. I really enjoyed my meal.
author: Steve S.

description: Best za I've had in my life, vegetarian is to die for.  Period.
author: Monica R.

description: This place features great deep dish Chicago style pies....mmmmm. Sink your teeth into these! The decor is hip unlike cheesy (pun intended) pizza joints.  I love the music they play there.  Go late and you'll find yourself waiting in a line.
author: Julia H.

description:
FEB 2006 Update: Had take-out deep dish from Zachary's on College (ALWAYS too insane to try to eat there), and I think Little Star beats it hands down -- their sauce and crust are way yummier!
JAN 2006: I got take-out deep dish (the "Little Star") and a salad: Still so yummy!
JAN 2005 Review : After driving around for 10 minutes trying to find a parking space, I was thinking this place better be really good - and it was! I hadn't had deep dish in a few years since last braving the crowds at Zachary's in Berkeley and after eating theirs it really made me regret that time lag. The crust was crispy and the tomato sauce was yummy -- perfectly spiced (we had the "Little Star"). We also had the green salad which was perfect. Good, friendly service. The jukebox was fun, too. I've had atke-out from there since then and the quality was just as good, though better to eat deep dish on the spot. m 1/2006 takeout deep dish (the "Little Star"): Still so yum!
Review from 1/2005: After driving around for 10 minutes trying to find a parking space, I was thinking this place better be really good - and it was! I hadn't had deep dish in a few years since last braving the crowds at Zachary's in Berkeley and after eating theirs it really made me regret that time lag. The crust was crispy and the tomato sauce was yummy -- perfectly spiced (we had the "Little Star"). We also had the green salad which was perfect. Good, friendly service. The jukebox was fun, too. I've had atke-out from there since then and the quality was just as good, though better to eat deep dish on the spot.
author: Dana B.

description: I  usually prefer NYC style but I loved their pizza! Their salads were also wonderful. I didn't indulge in the garlic bread that my friend ordered but the head of roasted garlic they brought for it looked like a lot of fun. I was not expecting the champagne cocktails to be as addictive as they were. A friend and I ate here two nights in a row before concerts at the Independant and it was just as good the second night as it was the first!
author: Melissa W.

description: Great deep dish pizza place! been here twice and i'm very satisfied with the food here, great setting, very low key, a little "emo" because it's dark, but I like it! I can't remember what we had, but I think it was called the Little star or something, but all I remember is how incredibly fresh the tomatoes tasted and pack with flavor! The garlic appetizer was tasty as well. yum yum, I want some now!
author: Kristine C.

description: Fantastic Chicago style za. Very cool atmosphere and tasty beers to go with your za. Only problem is that it has become such a trendy hit that the place has crowding issues - I get it to go and enjoy a beer while waiting.
author: Chris G.

description: I'm in love with the cornmeal crust. Crisp even after sitting in a box for 15 minutes. The toppings are also good, although the marina can't beat Zachary's.
author: Jane K.

description: Excellent pizza. Usually I am not into deep dish pizzas, but the vegetarian was absolutely amazing. It was a little dark, but it was a nice ambience. The size of the pizza was good for the price and the house salad was good for two people! I also thought it was strange that it was cash only. WIERD.
author: Mish M.

description: I love the pizza!  I worked for this place about two and a half years ago, and I never got sick of the stuff.  And I STILL get cravings for it.  Now if that doesn't make for good pizza, I don't know what does.  Sure, it gets crowded, but I think it's work the wait.  Ain't nothing like the Classic.  I could eat a whole one by myself.  Definitely at the top of my favorite pizza places list.
author: ashley w.

description: I think I just had an orgasm in my mouth. Oh, wait. I was just eating Little Star's deep dish pepperoni dipped in bleu cheese dressing. Oh. Oh. OOOOOOOOOOooooooh!
author: Ginny Z.

description: Good thin and thick slices. Up there with Zachary's...and don't have to pay the $3 toll to the East Bay.
author: Peter S.

description: I know this will upset some people (including my boyfriend) but I prefer Little Star to Zachary's! The cornmeal crust is so amazing and that's what gives it  one up on Zachary's. I've also had the thin crust which is really good. The waits here are really long and it's a small place so I would recomend take out.
author: Sarah H.

description:
oh man - this place is sooo yummy!
a deep-dish pizza place in san francisco. 
i actually think it's better than the oh so famous - zachary's in berkeley.

we ordered the wings - with a dry rub and served with carrots and a yummy blue cheese dressing dip. then for the deep dish pizza - a small with half little star and half sausage combo!

crowded place - worth the wait... but may just order them to-go next time! 
yummy! can't wait to have another slice!
author: kiko v.

description: Seriously. I have never considered myself a "pizza guy".  Little Star though.... (sits at keyboard with blank stare shaking head)... Little Star is synonymous with "holy s--t!"  or "out of f-----g control!".  In the most mind-blowing, tummy tempting sort of way imaginable.  Sometimes I want Chinese.  Sometimes I want Thai.  Sometimes I want Italian.  Sometimes I need Little Star.  The order never changes.  Mixed salad, Little Star with sausage, and a couple of Racer 5 IPAs.  Absolutely heavenly.  I need you, Little Star.  See you soon baby.
author: Barry A.

description:
The pizza is good but not exceptional, we found the tomato sauce way too overbearing. The service wasn't the greatest either, barely acceptable.

The worst part... no ATM/credit card!!! No mention of it at the front desk or on the outside of the restaurant. That's just ridiculous.

Sorry, this was a one time.
author: S. M.

description: After being cautiously skeptical (Chicago Pizza in SF?), I was pleasantly surprised by this place.  The large deep dish pie is more than enough for two people, and Classic was tasty, although the hunks of sausage could have been smaller.  The waiter warned us the deep dish takes thirty minutes to cook, so we ordered up the Caprese salad to start. It was a nice size, and good, although it would be better if they actually gave you some extra olive oil and balsamic along with it....the wait for two was short on a Wednesday, (15 min), the pitcher of water at the table was a bonus, and the art on the wall was a nice touch, I'll certainly be back.
author: Scott R.

description: The pizza here is very good, the atmosphere kind of reminds me of restaurants in NY how they have curtains at the door and its very dark inside.
author: Tony C.

description: Wow..simply wow!  The deep dish pizza is wonderful.  The crust is light, crispy and buttery.  We tried the "Little Star" a wonderful spinach and cheese pizza and the Mediteranean which is a chicken, artichoke,cheesey delight.  All their pizzas are covered with a scumptious fresh tomato sauce.  Next time we are in town we will definetly return to this outstanding pizza establishment.  I wish they would open one in Chico.
author: gary w.

description:
UPDATE: We got a second pizza from them and it was cooked great & tasty. The management and staff were very nice and attentive. We'll be back.

******
Old comment:

I got Little Star takeout for the first time today and the thin crust pie was undercooked- spongy crust, limpid pepperoni, and cheese that was still in its grated shape. After a stint in the oven it was OK, but not the same as properly cooked the first time.  I understand that pizza chefs on a saturday are overworked and underpaid so I'll give it a second chance.

PS- Little Star, if you had a real email address I would have sent it to you direct and not made it public.
author: Brian A.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and the wait was 45 minutes for a table for 2. I always wanted to try Little Star because people say its the best in San Francisco. While waiting for a table, I was told by the hostess that I can pre-order the pizza because it takes 25 minutes to bake a deep dish pizza.

The pizza was amazingly good. The corn crust was crunchy. The sauce on the pizza was perfect and the cheese was very delicious! 

I would go back anytime. Worth the 45 minute wait.
author: J L.

description:
the pizza here is sooooo good. a small is $20 and perfectly feeds two people. the crust is perfect and the pizza is nice and saucy. yum.
if you don't want deal with wating to be seated, call it in ahead of time and pick it up. bonus: it even tastes freakin' delicious the next day.
author: eve l.

description: Best Deep Dish Pizza in town!  Better than Zachary's!  If for no other reasons then it is in the city and it is a normal resturant where you can just sit down, order a meal and enjoy it.  The indy rock feeling is  very mellow and fits perfectly.  The bathrooms have really cool painting along the walls.
author: Pele N.

description:
This place is a joke. Chicago style pizza, while not my favorite or first choice can be very delicious. The ingredients taste suspiciously of Costco quality stuff and the service is so abominably bad, I can't even bring myself to give it another shot. 

I tried people, I have eaten there 6 times in the past year, and yet each time I am surprised I even went back. The last time was the last straw. First we waited 45 minutes for our pizza, which had been dropped off twenty minutes before at the table next to us. They ate our veggie pie, never once questioning why it had no chicken on it, which was what they had ordered. We got their chicken pie, which now I understand why they wouldn't have noticed if it had no chicken on it. I think I found one, no two pieces of chicken. Hard to tell when you just open up a cheap can of tasteless stewed tomatoes and dump it all over the pizza. The owner finally came over to tell us what had happened, our options were to eat this pizza or wait another 25 minutes for the one we had ordered.  I am a good sport about mix ups and mistakes, so we ate it, but it was not good and it ruined our meal. Plus the wench who served us never apologized for the mistake, even though she was the one who ran the wrong pizza to the wrong table. 

Too much attitude for one dark place that makes me feel like if the lights were turned up, I wouldn't want to be eating in there. Also, you know you are in a classy joint when they have security cameras aimed at the host station and the bartenders register.  If you have such a bad stealing problem with your staff that requires security cameras, kindly keep them hidden from customers view, or fire those lousy rats.

 I've had it with coffee shop service at restaurant prices. Take it seriously, be nice to your tables, and watch the tips roll in. I waited tables for over 10 years and I get sick of the cooler than you 18 year olds that places like Little Star and Farmer Brown hire to provide service to their customers. I can overlook a lot of things, but after awhile it is the  bad service that will make me never return to a place even if the food is really great. Which by the way, at Little Star, it ain't.
author: Ham and Eggs M.

description: By far the best pizza I've had in the city. Because it's always super noisy and crowded in there (the Western Addition location) we always order a pizza to go. While the deep dish is super tasty (and seems to be a favorite of others), I'm actually a fan of the thin crust. If you're looking for a wonderful cornmeal crust pizza for a reasonable price, I definitely recommend Little Star Pizza. If you don't like noise and crowds, I'd recommend phoning in a pick-up order. If crowds and noise adds to the overall dining experience for you, then eat at the restaurant.
author: Deidre E.

description: This place is a little on the pricey side, but so worth it, make sure that you order to go because this place is always packed! And make sure you have healthy appitite, you're going to need it.
author: timothy h.

description: This pizza is in a league of it's own. It's closest relative is Gino's East in Chicago, but the corn meal crust makes this pizza totally unique. You say pizza, I say Little Star!! The only down sides are that parking is difficult, they only take cash, and it gets crowded so the wait can be a little long and that crowd comes with noise. Totally worth it all though!
author: Kimberly M.

description: We tried out the wonderful deep dish pizza. Great flavor and we filled up nicely. I liked the atmosphere and experience. The cold air from outside seemed to rush into the small restaurant each time the door was opened, but overall a great dining time.
author: Travis M.

description:
I have to give this place a bad review despite the fact that I enjoyed the food. The service was despicable. On our way out of the restaurant my boyfriend overheard the hostess say "Thank god they're finally leaving!" Are you kidding me??? We had spent maybe 10 minutes talking after we paid the bill. No more than 10 minutes. And we had spent over $125. That's just plain rude.

If you like the pizza, I'd recommend going to the Little Star in the Mission- It doesn't have any of the problems that are so frequently mentioned in the reviews of this one (i.e.- too dark, too loud, crappy service, etc.).
author: Katie D.

description:
maybe i was just expecting something else, but this was definitely not a place i would go back to. i had some takeout with some people this past july and they totally hyped this place up. 

the atmosphere of the restaurant while waiting to pick up the food in the waiting area was good and the staff was really nice, but the pizza was definitely not my style.
author: Katherine F.

description: The corn meal crust is definitely unique to the place.  It has a twist compared to the other Chicago style pizza's I've had.  Right now its a toss up with Zachary's in Berkeley.  Definitely would recommend everyone to try it at least once and compare to the other Chicago style pizza places.
author: gareth l.

description: I think we ordered the wrong thing.  Thin-crust vegetarian pizza with sausage on half for take-out.  After going, I see a lot of people get the deep-dish.  The crust was not very good, the ingredients didn't seem crisp and fresh.  The area is seedy.  The clientèle was young 30's and somewhat hip.  Many people were getting take-out.  We ate ours in the car on the way back from the Bay and it was very disappointing.  Once again....the crust tastes different, I don't know if it is cornmeal or what, but it didn't have a great aftertaste.
author: Leila C.

description: Don't want to go all the way to the east bay for Zachary's?  Go to Little Star!  While I still think Zachary's has the best deep dish around, Little Star is a very close second.  To me, the deep dish should be all about the flaky crust and the flavorful fresh sauce and this place has both.  Plan ahead, the wait can be LONG and cash only!
author: SFFoodie F.

description: As close to Chicago as you will get without traveling to the Windy City.  Little Star's deep dish pizza is by far the best deep dish I've had outside of the Chicago city limits.  The crust, the sauce and the sausage (which they make at Little Star) goes unmatched in Bay Area deep dish pizzerias.  The portions and prices are well-balanced and always leave you feeling satisfied.  Can't say I've ever had a problem with the staff as some Yelpers have pointed out.  It does get busy, so try to go early.
author: DamnGringo X.

description:
Don't believe the hype - this place was just OK.  Not worth the 1+ hour wait.  With so many great restaurants in SF, I don't think anyone should have to wait more than 30 minutes for a table anywhere.  If it's a longer wait than that, I usually go somewhere else (which is what I did the last time someone wanted to eat at Little Star - while we were waiting over an hour for our table, I went down the street and got a snack).  Little Star also doesn't let you order ahead and then have your pizza when your table is ready.  This is is a very smart and nice service that Zachary's in Berkeley or Oakland lets you do (since it can take up to 45 minutes to get your pie - makes perfect sense to order ahead and then you're not waiting forever and taking up valuable table space!).  I was shocked that Little Star wouldn't allow this.  Very bad business sense.  First they make you wait over an hour for a table, then when you finally get a table and place your order, you have to wait another 45 minutes to get your deep dish pizza.  Not worth it!!!

The pizza - when it finally arrives - is OK, but not as good as Zachary's (dry crumbly crust, weak toppings).  After waiting almost 2 hours for it, it is definitely not worth it!!!  I've been to Little Star twice now and I've sworn never to back.  I definitely would rather risk traffic and drive over the bridge to Zachary's any day!  Note:  Little Star accepts cash only.
author: Tara B.

description: Second only to Zachary's for best pizza in the Bay Area (I'm obviously partial to deep dish pizza).  Little Star has a more romantic ambiance, same cash only, but its really all about the pizza
author: 'toph G.

description: Is LSP better than Zachary's? Dunno, but it is certainly closer. Truly amazing deep dish pizza, the place is a little dark inside, but it's easier to be more indulgent that way. The jukebox is choice, I will see you there!
author: John B.

description: Best deep dish pizza in the City.  Even better than Zachary's (which I love) so probably the best deep dish period.  Its the crust that makes the difference.  Crunchy, which is pretty amazing for a deep dish pizza.  And with a cornmeal flavor and texture.  Yum!
author: Kevin G.

description: I love this pizza, especially the deep dish. Now that they have two locations, the wait at the one on Divisidero is not nearly as long.  I also highly recommend their cocktails at the bar.  Remember cash only, but they have an ATM in the restaurant for your convenience.
author: Michelle E.

description:
This is the ultimate pizza in SF. It's everything you want from food; flavorful, textured, and enough to fill you and your friends up. And it's pretty comparably priced to any run-of-the-mill, unspectacular pizza joint. But this is by no means average pizza. The buttery, crisp cornmeal crust adds a texture and flavor that makes this place unique. All of their pizzas are topped with a fresh, extra chunky tomato sauce that really compliments the texture of the crust, and bursts with flavor on its own. Their self-titled signature pizza is a must, and probably one of the best foods around that I could actually share with or recommend for any of my vegetarian friends, one of my favorite foods in general, actually.

The atmosphere is great, too. I haven't actually done anything but sit at the bar, there, but it's pretty cozy, and a lot nicer than any other pizza place I've been in that offers take-out.

Give it a try. You will not be disappointed. With a large pizza, you and two other friends will be full for just over $20. Their hot wings are good too.

If you call in an order, they will remind you that they are cash only, but they have an ATM just inside the door that will only charge you TWENTY FIVE (25) CENTS. That's 1/10th of any other ATM I've seen in the neighborhood. I'd give them an extra 6th (little) star for that.
author: Cooper B.

description: This pizza was so good I almost peed my pants.  Too bad we had to wait for 45 minutes for a table.  Good for us that we didn't have anywhere to be that Friday night but on the couch at home later.  The take out option is rad here if you live close enough cause you can avoid the masses.  There is a reason it is crowded, it freakin ROCKS.  Try the "classic" deep dish and be prepared to swoon.
author: Claire C.

description:
it just keeps getting better and better.  top notch deep dish.  i've loved this place from day one. a fellow who works here used to use my garage space to store his scooter --  very impressed with what he's done with since then.

one caveat:  bring cash.  they don't accept credit/debit cards (although they added an atm machine).
author: Tim G.

description:
dear little star,
your pizza's are so yummy, and your prices are so low. 
i am convinced that you are running an illegal drug ring in the back, and sprinkle a little crack on your pizza's every now and then.
i have you figured out. i know why you only take cash.
but you know what? i think it's better that we keep your little secret on the DL.
i love you, your pizza, your garlic bread with roasted garlic that's all smooshy and yummy, and your cute curly haired waiters.
author: Parisa G.

description:
you know, the first time, i wasn't a huge fan of the cornmeal crust....

the second time, my ex was REALLY constipated (like over a week...how does one survive something like that?)...and she was hoping that little star would do the trick for her....it didn't...maybe something to do with the cheese?  duh!!!!

now, the third, the fourth, the fifth, the sixth, and in about 30 minutes...the seventh time......yum!  i'll never doubt you again, little star....
author: Miss P.

description:
I'm a fan of deep dish pizza and Little Star does it well.  I think the problem with this place is that it's so hyped that you go in with expectations that are hard to exceed.  I'd say this place met my expectations, and perhaps with less knowledge about how great everyone thinks it is, there would have been more "wow" factor.

Came here for dinner on a Tuesday night when they opened at 5:00 pm.  This was ideal because (1) street parking was relatively abundant and (2) we walked right in!  As we were the second people in the place, we were one of the first orders of the night... and so our pizza came out fresh and without much wait.  The happy hour drink specials are from 5:00 - 6:30 and the wine was very affordable (between $5 to $7 per glass).

Service was good... the only caveat (which we actually didn't know) was that this is a cash-only kind of place.  We came up several dollars short.  Oddly enough, I had a roll of quarters in my bag from the bank (think laundry money)... which was the missing $10 we needed!  Felt kind of funny to pay with a roll of quarters.  As we wandered out the door, we realized they had an ATM.
author: Lindsay M.

description: Their cornmeal crust is amazing.  It is a great date place because it has comfort food with cozy decor and a friendly crowd.  I was raised on Zachary's, but occasionally enjoy cheating with Little Star.
author: Jessica V.

description:
The pizza is orgasmic (deep dish classic), the salad (mixed green) is incredible, and they have sierra on tap!

Don't forget your white belt, Chuck Taylor's, and skinny jeans...this place is too cool for school!

Just to verify I own none of the above, I just live vicariously through the hipsters in this joint.

YUM!

5 big mothas for this one!
author: Kyle J.

description:
Damn good Chicago style pizza.  Third best in the bay area in my opinion.  Patxi's being best, and Zachary's coming in just slightly better than Little Star.

The Good:  The pizza is fantastic.  The atmosphere is nice.  Far more date appropriate than Patxi's or Zachary's.

The Bad:  I like my sauce smooth.  Little Star is a bit chunky.  The cornmeal crust is really good at first, but I get tired of it quickly.

The Ugly:  Long, long wait for a table.  I know the pizza takes a while, so predicting wait time is a challenge, but the hostesses are far less than helpful.  They probably need a signup list with phone numbers, so people can go hand out at one of the many cool local bars, and have them call when your table is ready.
author: Scott L.

description: The restaurant's namesake, Little Star deep dish pizza, was delicious.  Be prepared to wait a little.  Everything's made-to-order.  Parking's a challenge (what can I say... I'm from LA).
author: rochelle a.

description: Wow -- this pizza is delicious! So many veggie options and they really load up that veggie pizza.  I say this after ordering way too much takeout and I'm going on my third straight LSP meal. I'm still not tired of it!
author: Megan S.

description: I really enjoy Little Star. I love the fact that they also have Kermit Lynch's Bandol and Cab Franc on the list. The key to this place is to get there early or do take out. I love their juke. Pizza is excellent. Service can be spotty. Also, it is cash only. FYI there is an ATM on premise.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I *never* would have tried a refried beans pizza. But I was outvoted. And it was SO GOOD.  It was the Sunday night special with onions, tomatoes, avocado, mozzarella and queso fresca.  Who would come up with that??  It's pretty obvious that these people are pizza geniuses.
author: Kerrinski S.

description: The pizza here is good. I did not like the corn bread crust first but now I like it. I am giving only 3 stars because you can't get anything special done on your pizza. I have asked for extra olives several times but never got anything but a few. Also, I have asked the pizza to be NOT cut a couple of times and even though order taker clearly put the note on the order the kitchen either did not bother reading the note or ignored it.
author: Venkat N.

description: At least as good as Zachary's....  My friends and i argued over this for a while, so we did a heads up comparison of Little Star and Zachary's.  It was a tie.  Therefore the nod has to go to Little Star for being a much better place to eat in, and for those living in SF, you don't have to go over a bridge...  you really can't go wrong with any combination...
author: Robert R.

description: The first time I came here the jukebox blew me away.  Then the food came.
author: Rachel N.

description: Are you kidding me? This has got to be this neighborhood's brightest shining star. Raised in SoCal and exposed to Chicago style pizza only in recent years, I couldn't believe what was happening in my mouth when I ate this pizza. I can no longer even look at pizza crusts with no cornmeal in them. Dead to me!
author: Shannon V.

description: This place is worth the wait. I am from the Midwest and can say that it would give many pies back home a run for their money.
author: Charles H.

description: It was ok, but did not live up to all the hype. I got the classic which was recommended by the waiter, but was unimpressed. I will give it another try, but probably go for the thin crust.
author: Charles W.

description: I just tried this place out this passed weekend and It's darn good.  It's a bit loud, but other than that it's all good.  I would deffinitely go back.  Thanks for the pizza   =o)
author: Xiu L.

description: It may actually beat zachary's. Only because of the jukebox though. Pearl Jam, dammit.
author: Seiji C.

description: Real Chicago style deep dish in San Francisco. I actually ate two slices though one would have sufficed especially with the beers during dinner and after. As an added bonus, they have a great jukebox, not something I've seen a lot around the city. Want to go back and try a couple different toppings...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
blah blah blah chicago style pizza. blah blah blah cornmeal crust.  blah blah blah cash only.   blah blah blah Little Star is good, but Zachary's is better.     Did I miss anything?

oh, I like the decor- cool paintings of musical instruments on the wall.
All night, the jukebox was playing the story of my life: Joy Division's Love Will Tear Us Apart (Again)
author: Smruti S.

description: Damn , over 400 reviews. must be good right? Well it is..........yes you will wait awhile but they have a good beer and wine selection. When you finally get seated and order, things are truly flowing. Attentive staff (rebecca) and when the pizza arrives................worth the wait.
author: Jerry M.

description: I had heard the hype and then tried the pizza. Oh my god, it was better than I had even dreamed it could be. Rarely do I find that things live up to hype that that they generate, A.I., Tony Manderich, the 2004 Chicago Cubs, however, with Little Star it is everything and more. I also really liked the "no reservation" policy. Who besides me hates when it takes three to four weeks to get into Delfina? Or the Slanted Door? If I wanted to wait three to four weeks to get in somewhere I will call my primary care physician.
author: Miles T.

description: I'm not a big fan of deep dish pizza but this was actually pretty good except a little too much sauce for me.  I have to say definitely order the deep dish over the think crust.
author: Mary L.

description: Aw man...this place is the sheeit! The wings/garlic bread are pretty much 'must orders' every time we're in there...the wings are more fried chicken-esque than hot-wings style, and they're SO good when they come out of the kitchen. The garlic bread is pretty nutso too - you get to squeeze out the toasted cloves and spread 'em on the bread yourself...very tasty. I've had both deep dish and thin crust there, and you can't really miss with either one. We usually go with the Little Star deep dish, but check the nightly specials - they usually have some really good stuff they throw together with all kindsa good ingredients. It's a great spot for big birthday parties too...we had over 20 heads in there for my bday not too long ago, and with tip it came to just over 20$/person...we had tons of beer/salad/apps along with 4 pizzas - definately good bang for your buck.
author: Justin H.

description: Both the deep dish and the thin crust are great. The wine selection is decent and YES...any place that serves $2 PBR's is a winner in my book. My only complaint was that impossibly bland Caprese salad. I know tomatoes aren't always in season which means that unless you can get a decently sweet tomatoe I would suggest not even bothering. The wait staff is friendly and bartender is great. I was one of the first customers here. The bartender and I had a conversation about the neighborhood and I called it NOPA. She said I was full of shit and that the neighborhood name didn't exist. So Ms Bartender...guess what the name of the restaurant down the street is? NOPA sucka. Validation baby...v-a-l-i-d-a-t-i-o-n.
author: Steve H.

description: Very good pizza, definitely on par with Zachary's
author: Nicole S.

description: I've lived in NYC for a good portion of my life and this is the best pizza I've ever had.  There.  I said it.  Hope I don't end up in the Jersey swamps for this.
author: el r.

description: So everyone from NY always rips on California pizza joints.  I'm guilty of it too but to be honest I don't think the pizza in CA is as bad as New Yorkers make it out to be.  Little Star is a good example.  The pizza here was pretty good (even by NY standards)  and they had some really interesting tasty champagne cocktail drinks.  My only complaint is that the stools at the tables were crazy high and not very comfortable and they only took cash.
author: Herman S.

description: Of course Little Star gets five stars. This place is fast becoming a San Francisco institution. I prefer this location with its long wait and moody lighting because it is where I fell in love with the most perfect pizza on Earth.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Hands down, this is the best pizza ever.  I've only had the thin crust (personal choice for pizza) and it's perfection.  The pizza was thin and crispy and the toppings are very fresh.  It's worth the wait no matter how long the wait may be.  Another great thing about Little Star is even though they take cash only, they have an ATM in the restaurant that doesn't charge fees.  You don't find that many places in the city.  I've heard the deep dish is wonderful too but, I haven't gone there yet.  One downer is they do not deliver.
author: Carl C.

description: Best pizza I've had so far in SF!  I LOVE the deep dish crust and how saucy it is.  My favorite combo is a deep dish with chicken, artichoke and sundried tomatoes.  If only they would deliver or take reservations!!
author: Erica L.

description:
Disclaimer: as far as deep dish pizza goes, I'm a die-hard Zachary's fan.

That being said, I have to grudgingly admit that the crust here is actually better than Zachary's.

Other than that, it's good, filling deep-dish pizza.  I'll leave it at that; I'd feel disloyal to my 10-year favorite if I were to rave about this place too much!

The garlic bread is fantastic.  They serve bread with a roasted head of garlic, rather than oily, vaguely garlic-flavored toast.  I'm a huge garlic fan, so I very much appreciate the ability to make the garlic bread as garlicky as I want.  Yum!
author: Morgan M.

description: Ok I love pizza, deep dish? even better, but this was a dissapointment. I don't get what people are raving about. I gave this place a 2nd try and still eh. Why did they close down all the UNOS in the city???? I miss their deep dish BUTTERY crust. I think I was expecting that from Little Star. Extra Butter Please!
author: Karen T.

description: It took a long time for anyone to figure out good pizza here in the City.    Little Star is a winner. Sometimes gets pulled out of the oven a little early.
author: scott c.

description: Stopped by on a Weds night after circling for parking for a good 45 mins. Despite waiting another 1.5 hours for a table, I would say it was still worth the wait. We split the Little Star Pizza which was yummy considering it was vegetarian. We also ordered a plate of the wings, which had a great spicy kick and offered something different than your run-of-the-mill buffalo flavor. The service was great. I'd come back on a weekday again.
author: Jen S.

description: BY FAR the best deep dish pizza in California.  Zachary's is good, but Little Star is the best.
author: Roger G.

description:
PIZZA!!!

I ordered a large thin crust pepperoni for two. The crust was perfect and the sauce out of this world. Little star has turned me into a pizza fan.
author: Gina S.

description: I have high standards for pizza joints and Little Star did not dissapoint. Just the right mix of traditional and gourmet ingredients, unique selection of cold microbrews, and loud, dimly-lit atmosphere were ideal. Attentive service and plenty of leftovers. The pizza was just as good, cold, for breakfast the next day!
author: Matt S.

description: I love Little Star and I heart the deep dish.  Now, I can't say that I truly know the deep dish because i'm not from Chicago.  I am from Montana where english muffin pizzas were what I thought was the real pizza(you know the kind-slice of kraft cheese and prego marinara), but that's neither here nor there.  Back to little star....my favorite part is the PBR in a can...it would be even cooler though if they gave you small paper bags ( a girl can dream, can't she?).  The pizza is super filling, cheesey and delicioso.  Love it.
author: Aly E.

description:
OK went here last night, after an hour wait we were finally seated, and starving.  But what?  THEY HAVE NO APPETIZERS LEFT, NO GARLIC BREAD, NO WINGS (which are the only two appetizers that they offer).  After this disappointment, I order the only salad that they have on their menu (which I guess counts as an appetizer, but I ordered it as an entree) and my boyfriend got a pizza.  Asked if they could add chicken to the salad to make it a little more filling and the waiter (who was the best part about the experience) said that normally they are not allowed to do so.  What?  Not allowed to please the customers?  Whatever.
Then my salad comes out (without chicken) about three minutes later.  But no pizza for my boyfriend.  After about ten minutes, of my staring at my salad and not eating it, the waiter realized his mistake and took the salad back.  Finally, the salad and pizza were ready and they brought out our food (this time there was chicken on my salad) but then the kicker, NO RANCH!! Ranch is essential for pizza (so says my bf) and they do not serve it.  Horrible experience and the food was nothing to write home about!
author: Sarah A.

description:
"I'm from Chicago and pizza in California is wrong in most every way. Zachary's, from what I understand, is an exception, but I'm not down for the roadtrip. Finally Little Star opens a few blocks from my house and the pizza is ridiculously good. so good.

The service? Not good. To the waitresses and bartenders with the attitudes: It's pizza, get over yourself. Yes, it's a popular joint...like about 100 other joints in the city. But when all you do is toss the pizza on my tiny table and never come back...well, you're not tippable.

The place is so loud that you have scream to people just inches from your face. I've been there twice and decided that from now on, we order takeout so we don't pay extra to tip bitchy people for a decent pizza.
author: kari d.

description:
Some of the best pizza I've had on the planet. If you love deep dish you have to stop in here. 

i could go on and on about the place (and I do, to my friends) but there's really no need to belabor the point. If you are reading this and hungry then head over right now.
author: C R.

description: Yikes.  I'm not worthy.  This pizza kicks the ass of every other pizza in SF.  And I'm ONLY talking about the deep dish here (the thin crust is shockingly mediocre in my experience).  But the cornmeal crust on the deep dish turns this into a slice of heaven that even heaven can't possible complete with.  This is a genuine slice of what heaven must taste like on a good day.  And while I'm on the subject, the caprese salad is THE BEST in  San Francisco.  Don't miss this freshness.  I don't know how they do it.  But just DO IT!
author: Dann H.

description: ok, i've revised my little star estimate, since the new location on valencia is worlds-WORLDS better than the earlier experience i had on divis. Got to admit...the pizza is delicious and the service was much, much better. also recommend getting takeout. Worlds quicker.
author: heidi y.

description:
We will add this brief review to the ever-expanding file for this great pizza place. Our expert pizza team was first in line tonight at 4:50 p.m., in the door at 5, and by 5:37 three pies hit the table after we had just polished off decent tap brews and garlic bread (nicely presented warm bread with the roasted garlic on the side still in the hulls). The server was efficient and attentive. We agreed that this rivals and perhaps is better than Zachary's deep dish (we had the Classic - great sausage - and the veggie). The crust was jusr right. The night's special was thin crust white pizza which held its own. When can we go back???
NO CREDIT CARDS - an ATM is in-house...
If you don't arrive early, the line can be long. Order while you wait in line so you can eat by the time you sit. On the other hand, waiting 45 minutes on average for a deep dish ain't bad when there is decent beer on tap and a day's adventures to recap.
author: Thighmaster M.

description: Come hungry!! But not too hungry because you'll probably have to wait for at least 30 min to get seated. It's definately worth the wait!! The signature Little Star deep dish pizza rocks my world! I usually keep eating until I'm almost too full to walk. I also love that if the wait is long they'll start your pizza for you so that it's ready by the time you sit down. Amazing!
author: Angel P.

description:
Little Star makes good pizza, and their cornmeal crust is a nice alternative to Patxi's, along with a different selection of toppings than the former has to offer.

Their pizza deserves a silver star next to Patx's gold. I probably would visit Little Star more often if not for the mass of hipster clones whose skinny jeans and flannel congest the art-school curtained entrance.
author: Mike K.

description: Tasty quality Chicago- style deep dish pizza.  Even though I'm more of a NY pizza guy I enjoyed it very much.  The crust is very buttery though so I couldn't stomach it that much.  If ur a fat American you would like it, lawl.
author: Winton W.

description: Simply the best pizza in town.  I love the thick crust, I think it is cornmeal and the thin crust almost equally.  Friendly folk are there to help.  I usually get carry out, but nice inside if you are there earlish otherwise expect a wait.
author: Deborah T.

description: I have a theory about this place. You see, the deep dish is so amazingly, mind-alteringly good (especially the crust!!), but I'm starting to wonder if it's just due to the fact that by the time I get seated and get my food, my blood sugar is so low that by that point anything remotely edible will taste good to me.  Worth investigating? Maybe... Either way, I'll still go back to Little Star. It's so worth the wait. Mmm, cheesy goodness...
author: Jennifer H.

description: their deep dish pizza is amazing, good beer also
author: Michael E.

description:
For their 1002nd review..thought I'd contribute a little orange to the page. Sorry...didn't love it...but there are highlights. Got pizza to go (but I drove super fast in the rain so it was still smokin hot when we got home). Ordered a large thin crust classic (sausage, mushrooms, green pepper, onion), large little star thick crust (spinach, ricotta cheese, mushrooms, more cheese), and a salad. 

I agree that the crust is great....there's a great bite, doesn't get soggy, and even gave me a little roof of the mouth rawness (which is always sign of good bread). But the tomato sauce is too tart...not a fan. Plus the cheese wasn't gooey....no goo equals missing 2 stars.

I should have prefaced that I don't especially enjoy deep dish pizza. Even when I was in CHI-town (yikes....sorry lou and gino)...but I still delusionally believe there may be an elusive deep dish slice waiting to satisfy my picky buds. So...patxis next maybe?

Oh yeah...the salad was good...
author: Emily W.

description: best deep dish ever.  love the sauce.  love the crust.  large classic, hold the sausage, add pepperoni.
author: Patrick M.

description: Don't take the 3 stars in a bad way. it really was "A-OK", in fact, it was quite tasty. Nevertheless, it was just pizza. Good place to go for a pizza and some beer, but bring cash.
author: Ryan W.

description: Holy fuck it's good pizza. Came here at 8pm on a Friday night. My friend and I were hunger shakes/faints level starving, so we were in quite a neurotic state when we were forced to circle the block for at least 30 minutes trying to find parking. No luck. Gave up and decided to play ninja and just double park in front of the auto garage next to them. 20 minutes later we had a small thin crust pesto chicken in our hands. Had to play ninja again by parking in front of a fire hydrant so we could eat. I don't know if it was because of the hunger shakes or the adrenaline of playing parking ninja but freaking A that pizza was HEAVEN. We are 2 tiny girls, and we downed that entire 12" pizza in less than 15 minutes.  The chicken wasn't dry at all which is usually the case with most chicken toppings. Generous pesto sauce and gooey cheese completed its pizza perfection. It was SO worth all the hoopla. But next time I think I'm just going to phone in my order and pick it up lol.
author: Jen L.

description: You just gotta check out this place. Not only is it only is the pizza, salad, and beer a **love love**, but you get some style, funky people, and a lovely atmosphere for under $15 a meal. Great to walk on down and have a mid-week casual dinner.
author: miss lisa k.

description: awesome deep dish pizza! this place is great. get there early because it gets packed fairly quickly. they use a cornmeal crust which is different than your standard pizza crust, but it works well, and is delish. if you're a pizza lover, give this place a try, but go with the deep dish.
author: Bernie S.

description: Some of the best pizza I have had in SF. I am tough to a please x - bgirl. Living blocks from Grimaldi's will spoil anyone( if you don't know what that is get thee to Brooklyn NOW!)
author: kristen l.

description: Absolutely delicious. The Little Star deep dish was heaven on a plate. My addiction to ricotta cheese was fed quite nicely. Great jukebox too.
author: Noelle Q.

description: What else can I add?  I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza.  Despite this, I loved the Little Star special.  Superb. Salad was good.  Dark.  Good music.  Parking was a bitch.  4 stars is the highest rating I can give deep dish.  And the bill really sneaks up on you.  Watch out.  A couple salads, glasses of wine, some pizza and **WHAM*** 80 bones!!!  Punishing bill for pizza.
author: sarah k.

description: Absolutely LOVE it! Fun beer selection, great vibe, great jukebox, FANTASTIC chicken wings - and believe me, I'm a connoieseuer in this department!, and great pizza. If you like deep dish, it's great here, if you like thin crust, it's great here. Major brownie points - they found that the credit card fees weren't doable for them, so they switched to cash-only, which is usually my worst nightmare. But they so did it right. They brought in an ATM machine, and the fee? $0.25. Seriously. The minimum they have to charge. These are some seriously good people. Impossible parking and often a long wait, but for this place? It's worth it, everytime.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Dear littoe star,  
    I wanted to write my review before I even ate a slice of your pizza because I couldn't find parking to pick up your pizza and when I stopped next a fire hydrant the cops gave me dirty looks and I thought they were going to pull me over.  I was pretty pissed off.  But the manatee convinced me to eat before yelping so I ate.  The chicken wings are pretty good here.  The pizza is also pretty good.  Definitely better than Zacherys.  Everyone will have their own opinion and preference for the crust however.  Its a corn meal crust that is on the dry side.  But I like it dry (*snicker*).  So I felt it was good. The manatee was indifferent.  We had the littoe star special.  Everything was fresh and meatless (lame).  I am still on the fence as to whether or not I'd come back.  Parking here is the biggest bitch in the world.  So I would most likely pick it up instead of trying to eat there.
author: Fatty A.

description: My only regret is not coming here sooner.  Best pizza ever!  Little Star will change your life.
author: Charly G.

description: Maybe i'm not a huge fan of Chicago style pizza.  I'm not a big fan of Marinara sauce either unless its with fried calamari.  So maybe that's why i'm just giving this place 3 stars.  It's a bit over priced for pizza.  It was good but i'm not dying to come back. Honestly, I'd rather go Roundtable and order a thin crust Italian supreme and I'll be a happy camper.  It was just aight for me.
author: anette d.

description: The pizza is great - try the thin crust specials.  The deep dish is good because it holds a TON of toppings.  Be prepared to wait if you want to eat it.  Luckily they have 6 champagne cocktails you can sip!
author: Amme P.

description: If you order this for takeout or get there before 7 pm, the wait isn't a problem. I was *planning* to eat only a slice. Then I tasted the deep dish crust and the toppings (little star vegetarian special), and it was like an addiction... all finished! Friendly staff too :) I'm definitely going back.
author: Anika K.

description:
we got the classic deep dish and substituted the bell peppers for the artichoke hearts.  mmmmmmm what an awesome possum coolbean deep dish pizza!!!
i've found my favorite pizza place in the city!
that crust is soooo buttery and sweet and crispy and chewy and delicious...
and the toppings... just the right amount....
author: charlotte s.

description:
Better deep dish pizza is not to be found anywhere else in SF, the Grater Bay Area, or anywhere else (possibly baring Chicago, but i'm not convinced yet).  Parking is hell, waiting is hell, everything up until you get your table is hell.  Once you have a seat, the service is amazing, even on the most crowded of nights the wait staff always finds a way to single you out.  The fact that it seems every single waiter is unbeliveably attractive also helps.  If your lucky, and you get there early, you might be able to hear the jukebox, which has one of the best selection of music i have seen anywhere.  Unfortunatly the speakers are some of the worst i've seen, and shortly after Little Star opens, it gets to loud to hear the music. 
 The garlic bread is fantastic, even though it's just toasted sourdough, butter and a head of roasted garlic.  Simplicity has its advantages.  
The pizza is phenomenal, as long as you get the deep dish.  The thin crust is ok, but it doesn't have the same taste and texture.  It's simply not as good.  The sauce is nice and chunky, full of herbs and spices, with hunks of tomatoes floating around, bits of spinach and ricotta meld together into a pizza superbeing.  If you've never had good deep dish pizza, you must try this, it's one of those life changing foods.
author: Herbert S.

description: I finally ordered a deep dish pizza (w/sausage & mushrooms) from here last friday and it was totally worth the drive from DC. parking sucks, but if you know where to find it, it shouldn't take more than 10-15 mins. or you can just double-park (shhhhh). got there a bit late in the evening and the place was pretty crowded--luckily, i was there just to pick my pie up. the pizza was so good i actually saved a few slices to bring to work...and show off.
author: Chris C.

description: Good deep dish pizza, the thin crust is just alright. If you can't decide, definitely go for the deep dish. The atmosphere of cute lil' restaurant was nice. Very comfy feeling. A little on the pricey side though.
author: Danvin R.

description: I don't really like pizza in general.  It has to be really good for me to waste the calories, you see.  Little Star gets 5 stars because I love their pizza-not like, LOVE.  I'm glad they don't deliver.
author: M M.

description: The pizza is great, but the place is dark and cramped. It's very loud with all the people crammed in and music playing.  The waiters are less then enthusiastic and look more like someone you would see at a hip hop or punk club.  I don't think I would dine in again.
author: Jes S.

description: Excellent deep dish pizza- the crust has a nice crispiness and there's loads of tomatoes and oozy cheese on the pizza!!  I liked the sausage and veggie versions :)  The wine list is simple but good. The service was good.  The prices are a tad high, but the pizza's quality is top notch!!
author: Sarah W.

description:
I went in last night with a friend for dinner. We had such a great evening. After being in hospitality for so long, it is so rare to find both of us relaxed and enjoying a meal out. Not only was our server unintrusively attentive (right on time to pour wine, water, etc) but well informed. She was right in steering us to share a small salad. We also ordered a large Little Star so that we were sure to have plenty to go home with. I am salivating while writing this just thinking of my leftover piece in the fridge. 
They also have a fab juke box. I appreciated the songs from Dirty Dancing last night. RIP Patrick swayze.  
Little Star Pizza is a gem. I hope spreading the word will not ruin it!
author: N J.

description: The best Chicago style pizza in the Bay, even better than Zachary's in my book.  The cornmeal crust was already enough to swing my vote, but I also have a strong preference for their sauce.  It's not as overwhelmingly tomato-ey.  I wish they were open earlier on the weekends, and there can definitely be a wait, but the pizza is the best. I've been to this location and the one in the Mission, and much prefer this location even though it's further away, just has a better vibe and had a better service experience here.  The service is minimal, but they're cool peeps, and I don't need a ton of attention in a pizza joint.
author: Cliff B.

description: Love the cornmeal crust - as a Chicago pizza girl...this is my favorite deep dish out there.
author: E. P.

description: I love, love, LOVE Little Star's Deep Dish Pizza.  The food gets 5 stars, the ambience gets only 3 for being loud, crowded, and a little dark, which is why I get my pizzas to go.  Call in your order in advance and believe them when they say it will be 25 minutes.  Keep in mind they take cash only. Try the deep dish pizza with chicken, spinach and feta...YUM.
author: Brooke N.

description: Believe the hype!  Excellent deep dish and very affordable.  My only problem with it is that it's extremely dark if you're there at night but, as far as quality is concerned, this is the best pizza in San Francisco.  Also, they have a good juke box.  They had Pearl Jam (10)....
author: Steven M.

description: Best pizza spot in town without a doubt. Between the delicious cornmeal crust deep-dish pizza, the inventive & fun drinks, and the superb jukebox, this place rocks. Great for a date spot, and great for getting pizza with a group of friends. Go to Bar 821 or Fly Bar afterwards for more drinks if you enjoy being hungover at work the next day.
author: Chris B.

description: LSP is a great pizza place in the Western Addiiton. LSP specializes in Chicago style deep dish pizza. . The wait can be sometimes very long at this place but the pizza is realy good! They also make a thin crust pizza for people watching their carbs :)
author: Christian S.

description: Love it, love it, love it. The wings are great, my bosses took me there for a christmas dinner, but also b/c one of my co-workers thought one of the waiters was really cute. I didnt really know a good deep dish pizza place in the city, but this, was a great find. When I took my boyfriend there a month later we felt a little out of place cause we dont exactly look like hipsters, but had a great time and ate SO much.
author: Niki M.

description: Good atmosphere and pizza was tasty, however the place was a tad cramped and hot.
author: Andrew R.

description: It's Pizza after all, so I'll keep this simple:  Best Deep-Dish in the city.  Cool atmosphere with Beer & Wine.  I usually get the Veggie Deep-Dish and add Pepperoni.  I know, I know...but Pepperoni on my pizza is like Catcher In The Rye for assassins...I just have to do it and I don't know why.  The pizza is amazing and I would go here more often if they a) had a better parking situation...it's on Divisadero b) took plastic....nothing sucks more than making an extra stop or c) HAD DELIVERY.  Pizzas are not cheap here (in the grand scheme of Pizza) but they are filling.  I can hold my own when hungry and can barely make it through 2 1/2 slices here without feeling sick.
author: Ari G.

description: Ok, obviously the pizza rocks, you know that by now, but in this world of cash only institutions did you know Little Star has an ATM that only charges $.25!  I was at the Independent the other night and their machine rakes $3!  Blasphemy.  I shouldn't be so happy to get charged anything to pay someone but there you have it- 3 months and this city has warped and twisted my idea of happiness...oh- one other tidbit- deep dish takes 20 minutes to cook, thin crust only 15 for those getting hungry around 4:20pm or thereabouts...
author: Johnny G.

description: Not a 5 - can't compare to Zachary's. But, who wants to trek across the bay when you can stay home. No delivery :( Which means I have to walk there and wait for a LONG time. But - wow, havent found any pizza in the city as good as this. Really worth it. Heard great things about the new location. Only go for deep dish, otherwise there is no point in waiting.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Has the boys over at Zachary's met their match?  Can this be a new SF vs. East Bay rivalry?  I'm more the traditional NY-style (thin crust; minimal if any toppings) kinda guy.  But to keep me on top of my game, I venture into the deep(-dish) area and try the hearty stuff.  This particular trip to LSP was my first.  Went with a bunch of work colleagues for one's b-day feast.  So with a pack of 14, it was imperative that we get there early. 6pm to be exact.  The hostess quickly accomodated us although we had to squeeze a bit and the waitstaff was attentive to our big group the entire night (cute too!).  Being the big (that is, appetite-wise) pizza eater that I am, I was a bit curious about the sizing of the pizzas... a "large" was ONLY 12 inches wide.  So we ordered a combination of some thin crusts and deep dishes.  On the thin side, the vegetarian and chicken pesto.  On the DD side, the Little Star, Mediterrenean and Classic.  I claimed that I could consume a whole large pie by myself, and so was carefully watched the entire night by some colleagues who doubted my claim.  The pizzas themselves were incredible.  I'm never one to really eat veggie pies... but this one was so deelish.  That cornmeal crust is awesome, but quite filling.  So after eating my first slice, I knew that my "whole pizza" claim was going to be tested...

Then I went to the dark side... each slice of the different DD pies was so good, it reminded of my younger, "better metabolism" days in college when I was a lot of active and thus could inhale slices and slices of pie.  This night was not the case... after the 4th slice, I was reaching an immediate slow down point.  But the Pesto Chicken thin crusd was calling... 

Not to be missed... the Chicken Pesto offers a real clean taste... not-too-overly-done on the pesto, and the chicken wasn't dried out. This was a great slice of pie.

I finished the night having consumed 6 slices (4 DD's, 2 thin) and a pint of pilsner.  Although I was able to walk it off throughout the course of the night.. I knew that I would make my return to LSP many more times in the future, and probably go through the same ritual!!!!
author: Dale K.

description: Great. The line on a Friday night was 1:45 so we went out for a drink and then went in and sat at the bar and ended up ordering from there. Bartender was awesome and the bar seemed just as good as a table to me. Pizza was fantastic and I've eaten plenty a deep dish in the Windy City.
author: Andy D.

description: I'm partial to more tomato based sauce on my pizza vs extra cheese and Little Star's signature pizza deep dish delivered (figuratively).  Although it's veggie it sure tasted meat-like what with the shrooms and spinach and such.  The crust was great, they were practically bread sticks in and of themselves.  Me and two of my boys went on a Sunday night and the line was out the dough (damn, I'm good).  If it weren't for the company, people watching, and blue pedal pilsners, I might have quietly smoldered because of the 50 some odd minute wait to be seated (we were quoted 20).  I'll also have to remember to pass on the $9 microwave caliber chicken wings in lieu  of additional meat toppings on my pie.
author: Sam N.

description: Amazing deep dish pizza. It's gotta be the crust. Yes, the crust. The buttery, flaky, crust goodness. It is definitely one of my top 5 pizza places of all time.
author: Jan Z.

description: Worth the wait!  We waited for about an hour for a table on a Friday night.  It was packed in the entry, by the bar, in the waiting area . . . but when we finally got that deep dish pizza, I was soooo glad we waited!  Super fresh, high quality toppings and great sauce!  Also I love the garlic bread!  It's really just a head of roasted garlic that you can squish onto yummy warm bread with some soft butter . . . OMG, yum!
author: Amy C.

description: Damn good ass pizza. love the crust. There's usually a wait on the weekends but its worth it. Both thin crust and Deep Dish is off the hook. Real pizza pie!
author: Lynn T.

description:
mind you i eat pizza for every meal and never get sick of it.. EVER. with that said i dont just eat pizza at any pizza joint and walk away satisfied. my taste buds for pizza are on par with a sommelier and my professional opinion is that this place is DELISH! 

you have to be quite extraordinary for me to even order a deep dish pizza... and like it. so with the recommendation of the deep dish little star i said what the hell... why not?  we also got the thin crust white pie. i couldnt believe it. i actually preferred the DEEP DISH! im still in shock over that one. oh my god! i almost forgot the apps! caprice salad.... YUMMMM! and the garlic bread was UHHH MAZING!! theres something to be said about squeezing out fresh roasted garlic on your own bread. you can have a little or in my case ALOT and be totally satisfied. i wish i didnt let them clear the table before the pizza came cause the rest of the garlic wouldve been so good on the pizza!! well, @ least for me... 

seriously with over  800 positive reviews how can you go wrong?
author: Christine L.

description: I Love Little Star Pizza.  Every person I've ever brought there becomes a CONVERT.  I've been going there for years, but still, I find no reason to venture further into their menu than their signature pizza, the Little Star.  It's that good.  Just THINKING about going there gets me all in anticipation of having it.  That crust...  That sauce...  That Ricotta...  I want some NOW!!!  A word of advice:  If you're planning on going to Little Star in the evening, make room in your stomach, and EAT LIGHT during the day.  You WILL be full.  Diet food this aint.  Also, be prepared to wait.  A 45-minute wait is completely normal here, and is to be expected on just about any night.  In my humble opinion, this is the best Deep-Dish pizza in the city (perhaps the best, period).  Check it out!
author: Eric H.

description: Definitely one of the better pizza places in San Francisco. The two draw backs are price and cash only. The deep dish is way better than thin crust
author: John D.

description: Foggy night, I was craving some Little Star deep dish, but I didn't feel like making the 10 block trek.... OMG!!!! LITTLE STAR DELIVERS!!!! I had no idea life could be so good! I placed my order with Little Star and then dialed a delivery service called Center City to have them pick it up.... 40 minutes later my pizza arrived fresh and hot. Visit the Little Star website for ordering info. This is amazing! Thanks guys!
author: Lynsey P.

description:
I don't think there's much I could add to the glowing descriptions that people have already given except as to inform ya'll of Little Star's eco-friendliness. 

Not only are these guys members of the Viv network (www.doyouviv.com), but they're also eco-friendly beyond the standard call of duty. 

Their composting program is remarkable, and their recycling is throughly comprehensive. 

All of this is very suprising for such a popular spot, with such great food, and with such a following purely for pizza-sake- But nonetheless, little star gets 5 stars as a sustainable business.

...and as you can see- they get 5 for the food. (thats 10 stars!)

just go and eat there. its that simple. i would recommend it to anyone who visits SF.
author: Ryan O.

description:
Awesome deep dish pizza, appetizers, and beers on tap. Now I don't have to go to Oakland to get my deep dish fix in...

Only drawback is it gets super crowded and is not a big place. I usually go right around when they open (between 5 and 6) and usually never have a problem getting seated right away.

Good service too.
author: Josh M.

description:
yeah yeah, another 5 star review.  so what?  there's crack in everything here, and im talking about the good kind.

BRIAN (sp) at this location was a doll, and was able to accomodate my uber-last minute, party of 11 with no problem.

support your locally owned small businesses/crack dealers!
author: Kimby T.

description:
I liked this place. I came here after going to the Cal Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park.  Yes the parking is little funky and yes it's kinda a hole in the wall.  But the place is jammin with locals (of which I'm not, I came from the East Bay).

We had a cool server who refilled our water. The beer comes in bigger than normal pints. I think they are like 20oz.  And we got a great deal on the happy hour or early bird special.  

So onto the pizza. 
Deep Dish.  This deep dish I can really only compare to Zacharys.  I like Little Stars tomato sauce. It's not as vinegary.  The dough is not as crunchy/crusty as Zachary's but I thought it was good. The amount of stuffing was okay. Not over generous, but not skimpy.  Fair, but I would have preferred more.

We also got a chicken/pesto thin crust pizza.  This was okay.  It's not super greasy like a  thin new york pizza which I liked, but the downer was that the chicken was extremely dry.  Add that to a drier crust and it was not something you want to come back and order again.  Had I known the crush was more on the dry end, I would have said order a more "oilier" topping like sausage or more veggies.

Anyways--- the pizza was decent-- I wouldn't call it my favorite but I wouldn't tell you to avoid this place.  But the atmosphere and the service and personnel were fun so give it a try and try different pizzas. I'm sure if I do, I'll find something I like. 

We also got a salad. The dressing was perfectly ratioed to the greens.  But I would have preferred less onions.

Oh ! And this place is very decently priced for eating out!!!
author: A P.

description: We had both the deep dish and the thin crust pizza and both were fantastic!!  Not too heavy and tomatoes on the deep dish were fresh tasting and so yummy....very reasonably priced also....had to wait a bit, but well worth it
author: Carly P.

description: Just moved to SF from Chicago - so there is a clear bias when writing this review.  And I must say in the month and a half in being in SF and the quest for a good pizza, I have had some REALLY BAD pizza.  BUT!  Little Star quelled my frenzy.  The crust was a little too hard, but overall, this is the best deep dish pizza in SF.  Mad props to you, Little Star.
author: Melinda D.

description: We lucked out the other night and got seated right away...and the pizza was delicious as always! I used to live in the East Bay, so Zachary's was the place to go for deep-dish, but I think I've found a new favorite with Little Star...
author: Kitten W.

description: Amazing Deep dish pizzas at this joint.  We ordered one deep dish and one thin crust pie for 6 of us.  The deep dish was by far better and next time I would probably opt for only that.  Once you go deep dish you'll never go back.
author: jessica s.

description: Ambiance was fantastic, low lights, soft music...  We had the deep dish pizza and garlic bread. The toppings were generous and very fresh but that crust was off the hook! My girl and I ALMOST put away a large. Out waiter was very friendly and prompt for the most park, he could have come around to check on us a little more frequently but that would be my only complaint. This a great little intimate place for a first date.
author: Rocky B.

description: I came with a group of 10 a few weeks ago around 7:00pm and I was told the wait would be an hour.  The host was extremely accomodating and kept me updated about the table when I asked.  Friendly, unintrusive service.  I love Little Star even more now.  :)  I wouldn't recommend coming in with large groups, though.  We came in with a group of 10 and waited an hour, but the the large groups that came in after us had a MUCH longer wait.
author: Trinh N.

description: Best deep dish pizza in the City! I like to get the pepperoni - no frills. The veggie one with spinach tastes a little bit too much like lasagna. The garlic bread is good if you are going to eat in, but they are pretty stingy with the bread which is annoying. My only consistent complaint is that they routinely mess up my orders. Granted, this ends up getting me free pizzas, so this ultimately I guess I end up benefitting from it.
author: Jenica M.

description: I hadn't eaten here since before the Divisidero construction, so we decided we needed to go back.  We went at 7PM on a Saturday night and put our names in, half our party wasn't there. They couldn't sit an incomplete party, so we waited outside.  The hostess was completely attentive to us and made sure to get us as soon as a table opened up. A+ attention right there.  The place is filled with hipsters and non hipsters, but wasn't as tragically hip as I remembered (or expected) it to be. Like Goldilocks, the porridge was just right.  Service was great. We got a dude with tattoos and big gauged ears that was right on the ball. We ordered and our 4 individual 9" deep dish pizzas came. I did NOT remember the food being this good. The crust... perfect. Not greasy, a little crispy. The only thing that still turns me off a little is the chunks of tomatoes in the sauce.  But I ate it anyway so my wife wouldn't give me a look for picking them out. Fantastic place.
author: Vor H.

description: Little Star Pizza does NOT beat Zachary's-unless we're talking ambiance.  The jukebox makes for a very good evening, minus the toll and Bridge traffic.  The wings were respectable, the service, not so much.
author: Beth V.

description: Finally - some yummy deepdish in the city - and a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  Great pizza, good scene - usually crowded, but I've never had to wait too long for a 2 top.  Great place to people watch and find a new hair style - mohawks are back.
author: Aga N.

description: Don't let the candlelight and swank fool you: drink specials on PBR = hipster haven. That aside, it's about time we got some decent pizza in SF. I love it and it's great. During the wait, order the garlic bread, which comes as a whole bulb of roasted garlic with yummy bread.
author: Autumn W.
