description: Whether dining in or taking out, Little Star is stellar!  If you eat in, grab a pizza (or several) and a PBR and enjoy the surprisingly swank interior.  Great place to go if you are catching a show at the Independent down the street or if you are enjoying a movie at home.  Very lively environment and well worth the bit more you are used to paying for pizza.
author: Lucas M.

description: The best pizza ever.  The best juke box in the city.  It's a bit loud for conversation, and super dark, even when it's a sunny afternoon.  But otherwise, I can't get enough of their deep dish pizza.
author: Alisha A.

description:
Ah yes, yet another positive review of Little Star. When my friend told me about this place, I was like, "Corn meal does not belong in my pizza crust," but it turned out better than expected. Being that I'm from New York, and therefore a pizza snob, I can only say that the pizza was good, but didn't exactly meet my ideal. It wasn't bad, just different. Also, because I'm from New York, I have a very particular notion of what makes for a good chicken wing - and that is deep fried wings slathered in a sauce of butter and Frank's Red Hot. The Little Star wings were tasty, but not what I look for in a wing. We sat in the back and it was a lot darker than the pictures suggest. Our table was kind of tipsy, but after a few glasses of Racer 5, so were we, so it didn't matter. Our server was friendly, but not particularly attentive. By around 9:00, the place filled up with people hanging out around the bar and generally being more casual than us, which I think is the way to go at Little Star.

Update: Went again last night. The place seems to be much more popular now. The vegetarian deep dish we had was better than expected but I'm still ambivalent about the wings. 

And another thing: Enough with the comparisons to Zachary's. The crusts are completely different, people!
author: Brad L.

description: Thanks to our good friends at Yelp, we finally discovered a great pizza place in our neighborhood. The thin crust white pie with garlic olive oil, mozz, zucchini, feta and fresh tomatoes is better than any pizza we ever had in NY!
author: Julie B.

description: Delicious. The Little Star Special is definitely the best. After being a Zachary's fan for a long time, what makes Little Star possibly better is the delicious cornmeal crust, the fact that it's a little lighter than the greasiness of Zachary's. It's a "light-tasting" Chicago-style pizza, if that exists. I'm not a big fan of the ambiance at the restaurant, which is dark, and very loud. It's a good place for hipsters to hang out and have a drink. Have not tried the garlic bread, salads, or cheesecake (which I've heard good things about). If you don't want to drive across the bridge to Zachary's, definitley a good place to go.
author: Joyce G.

description: best deep dish in SF. NOT as good as Zachary's. probably better than Paxti's. I like NOT buttery crust.
author: Sophia Y.

description: YUMMY!  go!  immediately!   we shared  the salad with fresh mozerella which was very yummy.  and then had the deep dish.  a little too much cheese overload for me, but both were excellent!  tasty cocktails and beers.  and a great great jukebox!  this place is hip, fun and buzzin.  great place to take a date.
author: Caroline S.

description: Pretty much the best pizza ever. Ridonculously loud inside though. But you're probably eating too hard to talk anyway.
author: Josh K.

description: The pizza is ALWAYS so delicious.  Every time. Never fails. A bit of an attitude sometimes.. my boyfriend and I went in on A tuesday night at around 5. The hostess told us to sit anywhere so we chose a 4 top in the back, and then the waitress asked us to move to a tiny table in the front to save that one for big parties.  It was still nearly empty when we left.  But even though the staff can sometimes have a 'tude, the food makes up for it.
author: katie p.

description: Pizza that gives Zacharys a run for its money!  My friend and I split a small salad, garlic bread and then splurged and decided to get two small pizzas so we could try the deep dish and thin crust.  Left sassy happy and we each had leftovers for a couple more meals! I've passed by the spot before and from the outside it looks to be a more romantic setting --- au contraire! While I am sure one could have a lovely date here, it is a casual setting. I am glad they don't deliver; I would eat pizza too often!
author: Danielle R.

description: Little Star is amazing.  It's the longest you'll ever wait, door to mouth, for pizza and worth every minute.  I waited 105 minutes on a TUESDAY for Little Star Classic + pepperoni and came out feeling like I had won something.  Something magical about that; in a culture where we'll knock off a full yelp star if dining takes more than 25 minutes - Little Star rocks my house.
author: Matt S.

description: Good pizza is hard to come by in San Francisco but Little Star is definitely one of the best out there! It satisfies my pizza cravings. The cornmeal crust is delicious and the toppings are fresh. The tomato sauce is not too sweet and not too spicy. It can be tricky to get a table since it is a small place, so get there early or be prepared to wait. Great beer list too.
author: Jocelyn F.

description:
it was awwwwright.............disappointed that it wasn't a wow experience .....................

had the little star deep dish pizza (veggie pizza w/ spinach, feta, etc.), good sauce (on top of the whole pizza -- interesting), crisp cornmeal crust on the outside, good flavor...............but hub & i stil love milano's pizza on 9th & irving & my hub's pizza..........also had the garlic bread.......i prefer the regular ole garlic bread.......perhaps little star's bread needed to be warmer & a little more crisp & toast..........

we went there right when it opened on a friday & it started to fill up about 30 minutes after they opened................

bring cash & allow for about a 30 minute wait for the pizza

we're not completely giving up on little star.........we'll give 'em another chance & try their thin crust pizza next time.................
author: Cindi N.

description: Terrific pizza.  The thick crust is better than Zachary's...it's the sauce people, cleaner, less muddy than Z's.  For me, the thin crust is where it 's at.  Plain cheese thin, but I'm from that great City to the East and that's how we do it.   Worth the wait, decent wine by the glass, dimly lit for that Blanche duBois effect...
author: Nicole K.

description:
3 stars - blasphemy?!  no, i like the pizza here, but it's not the be-all-end-all everyone makes it out to be.  the atmosphere inside is nice - usually very lively and not the easiest place to carry a conversation, but definitely nice.  the pizza tastes fresh and well made.  i've had vegetarian and meat choices and i like their thin crust versions slightly better than the deep ones.  don't get me wrong, it's good pizza, but i've noticed the tomatoes tend to be a bit soggy usually.

fyi to first timers: cash only dude.
author: Ken L.

description: I ate Little Star's "Little Star Pizza" about 12 times before I realized that there isn't any meat in it.  That is awesome!  Go for happy hour, order yourself up a $1 off $2 PBR, that equals $1.  Make sure to get the frosty glass.  Watch out though, kid alert at the 15th & Valencia location if you go before 10:00.   Who are the losers who order thin crust here?  The thin crust is good, but why?
author: Mike K.

description: The crust is more corn meal than dough, which I am a HUGE fan of.  It's all really good, and definitely worth it.
author: Maureen S.

description:
like zachary's pizza in the east bay, but in a waaaaaayyyyyyy better city.  :)   super yummy.  one or two slices can fill up the average lady, or three if i'm feeling super greedy.  

be ready for a wait (-1 star).  it's a popular place, but popular for a reason!
author: jen b.

description: Waiters are bored with existence and jukebox stole my money but the pizza is great.
author: Marina N.

description: I love the pizza here.  It's a deep dish style, cornmeal crust, sauce on the top pie.  They also have thin crust now, but I just can't order it because I know I'll regret not having the deep dish. The little star (spinach, feta, mushrooms, garlic...) is my current favorite.  It has a good atmosphere and is also apparantly where all hipsters with children go out to eat.  I had no idea how many even had children before I started eating at Little Star.  If you going during prime time, be prepared to wait for about an hour.  Conversely, you can go geriatric style and have your choice of tables at 6:00 pm.  I usually choose the latter, but to each his/her own.
author: Zach J.

description: Oh, Little Star! How I love you! I love deep dish pizza and Little Star does a fantastic job. There's a long wait since deep dish pizzas take longer to make, but it's oh-so-worth-it. It's the perfect blend of thick sauce and cheese. The classic (sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions) is great but it's also nice to make your own. It's important to note that Little Star is cash only. They have an ATM inside for convenience if you forget, however. The restaurant itself is hard to miss if it's your first time. There's just a little sign above the door. Inside, the area is dimly-lit and it's a casual place so relax and enjoy!
author: Christine P.

description:
The pizza is so good at Little Star that I wish I had taken it to go. I haven't had much deep dish in my life, but I imagine that this is the way it's supposed to be. Heavy, tasty, fresh ingredients... what more could one want? The service was impeccable; very friendly, prompt and accurate. 
Everything else leaves something to be desired, hence the 4 stars. The parking can be tough, but they did put our names down on the waiting list while my brother parked. The garlic bread left much to be desired. It literally was a roasted garlic, a cup of butter and a sliced loaf of bread. I generally expect some preperation to go into food that i'm going to buy at a restaurant, and I also expect it to taste really good. Neither occurred with the garlic bread.
The last thing about this place is the noise. It is super loud inside. We were there on a Friday night, so maybe on other nights it would be less noisy, but we were literally yelling to hear each other. 
I highly recommend this place, but I doubt I'll ever stay here and eat again. I'll just get some take-out and savor the flavor of a wonderful pizza.
author: Erik S.

description: I'm in love with that cornmeal crust! I love the deep dish pizza here. Honestly, I've never eaten inside the restaurant before (usually takeout) but it was definitely worth the wait to sit inside. I had a lovely dinner and the pizza never disappoints.
author: Faye P.

description: I'm a bit biased because i'm not a fan of deep dish pizza.
author: j d.

description:
we order from here about once a week even tho it's not close to our house.

i get the thin crust cheese for the kids and thin crust classic for the grownups.

very delicious. highly recommend.
author: Fred C.

description:
Little Star has the best deep-dish pizza around.  Forget your Zachery's or Paxtis- Little Star leaves those guys in the dust.

The quality of their ingredients is great, their corn-meal crust is amazing and two slices is more than a full meal.

I'd advise you to call your order in and pick it up, waiting for a table takes forever and the place itself is a little lacking in atmosphere.

Only reasons they don't get 5 stars are:
-too noisy inside,
-long wait times,
-they only accept cash
-parking can be tough
-they don't open until 5pm
author: Steve d.

description: After hearing rave reviews from everyone, I had to finally try this spot.  The boy and I took a break from our Great North American Layabout weekend plans to venture outdoors for a little pizza acquisition adventure.  We called our order in and jumped on the bus for take-out.  We ordered a small deep-dish (sausage, pepperoni, mushrooms etc) and the caprese salad and both were intensely filling and delicious.  I was worried the small might not be enough for the 2 of us but when you get the box, you can feel how heavy and dense the pizza is - they are not kidding around!  I was in a bit of a food coma afterwards but it was totally worth it.  The restaurant itself was crowded with modern decor and had more hipsters loitering about than you could shake a stick at but maybe I'll give the sit-down a try sometime.
author: Suzanne V.

description: there are obvious reasons why little star pizza on divis has 4.5 stars with 1398 reviews to date. i don't think i even need to rave about this place as much as i want to. so all i have to say is mmmmm!!!
author: Kathy E.

description: We love this place. We both grew up on New York thin crusted pizza, and Little Star's is fine, but their thick crust version is in a class of its own. Corn meal crust, not soggy, not greasy. The cheese is under the incredible sauce. Then you can add things on top, including fresh mozzarella. Good salads too. We have eaten it there and taken out. While the cost for a pizza may seem steep at first, these go a long way, quite filling.
author: Dave C.

description: The pizzas here are so tasty that I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.  We were starving and had to wait over 30 minutes for a table, but it was well worth waiting for.  The deep dish and thin crust pizzas didn't disappoint.
author: Naomi N.

description: It is really good pizza. Almost as good as Zachary's actually. The crust is a little dry but I definitely enjoyed the pizza I ate. The problem with this thick crust pizza is that I can only eat one slice. So this place is perfect for those who have huge appetites.
author: Gina R.

description: Just about the most perfect salad of greens (assorted Californian arugula, frisee, etc) lightly dressed, last there in mid November and the tomatoes tasted of summer sunkist.  The pizza, classic for those meat eaters left in SF, is as good as it can get. Though, too many wannabe hipster for NOPA, it is still tolerable. GO During the week.
author: One P.

description: We live 4 blocks away but maybe getting old or something...always a line  and freaking loud.  But good pizza and a short walk home so order ahead, grab the dog and pick it up...hey 1000 review congrats little star
author: Aberdo G.

description: Still great deep dish. Now available in the mission and the east bay. Yum.
author: saru k.

description: So yummy. A pizza place with a full bar, fun drinks, good appetizers and, of course, very good pizza. I'v tried both the deep dish and regular and both are good. Everything tastes fresh, not too much of anything or bland. The tough part is the wait so go with people you can stand for more than 15 minutes. You can also get seating at the bar or get drinks while you wait.
author: Nisha A.

description: Good stuff indeed, but it doesn't come close to Zachary's.
author: MIchael R.

description: Better than mediocre sex. Go early and avoid the wait.
author: Venessa M.

description: The deep dish pizza here is great. I think the thin crust is average. I usually get the pizza to go, it takes 30 min, a small definately feeds 2 people. The classic is my favorite.
author: Samantha S.

description: It's not quite as good as some of the deep dish you can find in the midwest, but it's the best I've had on the west coast.  It's better than zachary's and the service is as good as the pizza.
author: Gucci M.

description: A much needed addition to the neighborhood. I don't know about being better then Zachary's, but it definitely felt healthier. The champagne cocktails were huge and the salad was enormous. Definitely  a nice casual spot to grab a delicious and affordable bite. You can count on there being a wait, this secret has been discovered.
author: Kai H.

description: After hearing so much about Little Star, I had to force myself to leave my favorite pizza place, Gaspare's, and try it out.  The hostess told me 45 minutes (luckily, it was only 15 minutes).  We were starving and got the thin crust chicken pesto pizza, which was definitely good.  Crust was crispy and chewy, the pizza was not oily.  But, this is definitely not NY-style pizza.  Gaspare's is closer to the real deal.  My friends love Patxi's on Hayes, so they weren't converted to Little Star.  I definitely liked their pizza and would go back, but I DON"T think it's the best pizza around.
author: Christina S.

description: This place is great.  As to the LSP and Zacharies debate, I'll have to say that Zacharies is still better, if not by a nose.  The crust is great and corn-bready and the place gives off a good vibe.  People should definitely try it out!  Try to go on an uncrowded night.
author: systems e.

description: Pizza that rivals Zachery's and an unparalleled jukebox.
author: Ken S.

description: It's not as good as Zachary's (IMO) but it's worth a taste.  The one complaint I do have about this place is the location - there's not much to do around here, so if you want to plan an evening around it you'll probably have to drive, hike, or commute by bus afterwords ...
author: Omar S.

description: According to sfgate.com 's Culture blog, a Little Star Pizza will be coming soon/soonish/not soon enough to 16th and Guerrero.
author: Emma Sophia M.

description: Great gourmet style pizza. Good atmosphere to go out with your friends, or go on a moderately priced date. If you're going after 7:00 allow around 20 min. waiting time because not a lot of seats are available. .
author: Joe G.

description: Damn good pizza! We had a half veggie, half meat pizza which was great (the only complaint is that it was hard to distinguish between the two...good thing the basic flavors were terrific). The place is super crowded all the time, for good reason, and can be a bit of a scene. But overall it gets my four stars...GO!
author: Pierre K.

description: This pizza joint rocks!! I've been going for a while now without it but I think I'm back. I've eaten there only twice and frankly it's a bit too loud and dark. I now live close by so takeout is much preferred. And make sure to call your order in-it takes up to half and hour for them to make it and  that crowded waiting area is torture. But never mind...the food!! Both thick and thin crust is the best-you can't go wrong. Depends how hungry you are. Little Star special is my favorite deep dish and the white pie is my favorite thin crust. The basic mixed salad is always dressed with the right amount of dressing and is so tasty. I say always get the large so you can have leftovers and it gets better the next day.
author: Karen C.

description: If only they had more tables... I'm no fan of deep-dish pizza but this place will convert any skeptic. A elegantly simple menu of a few appetizers, some draft beer and pizza. Poor Pauline's is down the block from their new location on Valencia and probably not too happy about such strong competition.
author: Selim N.

description: Amazing deep dish pizza that is worth the sometimes long wait.  Great atmosphere, and you can wait at the bar and have a drink.  Parking is a little difficult in the neighborhood.
author: Mike B.

description: Everyone told me that Zachary's Pizza was the premeir deep dish pizza, but now after tasting both, i think Little Star is better.  They wait staff si stylish and polite and the food is great.  Go.  You will not be disapointed.
author: Katie Sue A.

description: Great pizza and a good selection of wines for a pizza restaurant. The service was very accommodating as my date and I lingered over salad and a glass of wine, and the pizza came hot and crispy, just the way I like it. The atmosphere was good, a little bit loud and the hard surfaces everywhere made it echo but for such a popular place that's to be expected. It was also very warm, almost to the point of discomfort.
author: J.J. P.

description: This place is more awesomer than Zachary's (which I love BTW) because of its cool factor. Great sauce, great crust, great pizza, good beer, and just an all around hip atmosphere. Not that I don't love screaming kids in high chairs and pimply faced teenagers shooting spit wads but sometimes I just wanna chill with the movers and shakers. Sometimes we have had to wait a while to be seated but the place is small and it's popular. I can live with that. It was always worth the wait. And have you ever had leftover Little Star? Take some home and eat it the next day. It still rocks.
author: Hunter G.

description: I am allergic to tomatoes and to be honest, deep dish pizza usually does not agree with me or my weak stomach. Having said that, for Little Star Pizza, I have endured allergic outbreaks and a belly so full I had a hard time walking home after wards but, I've always gone to bed happy (and itchy). It is also a secret weapon for my entire household. No one can be in a bad mood or stay mad at anyone if you bring the possibility of Little Star into the mix. "Hay mom, sorry I shaved my head, got a tattoo of a slobbering bulldog on my neck, and backed your car into the creek. How bout we get some Little Star and put that all behind us?" "Mmmm Little Star! I'm starving -let's go! I love you honey!" "I love you too, mom." Hugs always follow Little Star.
author: Nuvia C.

description:
tried to go to the location in the mission district, but for whatever reason it was closed that night (night before the super bowl).  so we wound up at this location.

very good pizzas.  we had the classic and the little star with pepperoni added.  i liked the little star with pepperoni the most as the rest of our party did.

i felt their pizza was fairly comparable to zachary's .  though both places have some differences, i can't say a like one place over the other.

one of the differences, which i kinda liked, is little star seems to use some cornmeal in their crust.
author: R K.

description: Solid Chicago pizza, some will prefer Zachary's, some will prefer Patxi's (Palo Alto better than San Francisco), some will prefer Little Star. To me they are all in the same range, good Chicago Pizza. After having tried the three of them I wonder if there's space for something new, to me all the menus look kind of similar and some creative thinking would make the difference.
author: Alex A.

description: Exceptional deep dish pizza.  As Jim Roam of ESPN would say, "Fe-nah-menol!"  Deep dish little star is what I order...ALL THE TIME.  I tried the chicken and that was good too.  I've actually never eaten at the restaurant itself, but have picked up my order from them on numerous occasions.  I believe it's the crust.  I normally don't eat the crust of the pizza, but Little Star Pizza's crust = *points to lips w/both hands* "god, that's good.  It's so good once it hits your lips, it's so good!" (ala Frank the Tank in Old School)
author: Paolo E.

description:
Best take-out pizza in San Francisco, hands down.  I've never eaten in the establishment, but the vibe is always happenning and lively.

Where to start about the pizza.......the crust, tomato sauce with herbs, everything is awesome!  If there is perfection in a pizza, this is it.  I've only had one type (vegetarian), but hope to try some of the meat combinations one of these days.

I've had delivery from both North Beach Pizza and Pizza Orgasmica, which are so-so.  For the same price, Little Star is worth picking up.  If they were only a bit closer.........I guess that's too much to ask.
author: Andy S.

description: Sweet baby jesus, why did I wait so long to dine at this fine establishment? This pizza is simply devine! My roomate and I went there for dinner this evening, and let me tell you, it did not fall short of all the wonderful yelp reviews that it has received. The sauce was perfectly tangy with chunks of ripe, juicy, tomatoes while the cornmeal crust was crunchy and delicious. We ordered the "little star" pizza which was topped with some very tasty, fresh veggies. Might I also say that the ambiance is quite lovely inside and that the service was friendly and attentive. Overall, a pretty enjoyable first expererience. My little star cherry has been popped. I only take one star away for the pesky gnats that circled our table and my glass of chianti, but that is subject to change as I will be returning, hopefully soon. Stay tuned...
author: reina t.

description: They have the best Chicago style pizza in the City.  I was a convert of Zachery's but I've had a change of heart.  Amazing, just absolutely amazing.  I had the Veggie pizza recently and I couldn't stop myself from eating, it was troubling, but, somehow, I was able to get through it without gorging myself to death.
author: David O.

description: Yankees or Red Sox. Beatles or Stones. And Zachary's or Little Star. For me, it's Little Star and it's all about the crust. They use cornmeal and it just has way more flavor than Zachary's doughy crust. We usually go with the deep dish classic (sausage, green pepper, mushroom, onion) which wouldn't typically float my boat but it's awesome. And if you don't like deep dish, they have thin crust pizzas too which are great. We almost always take-out but it's also a cool joint with a hype atmosphere and a great little beer/wine bar with happy hour specials.
author: Bill R.

description: We ate here on a Saurday evening, arriving early because we heard the place would fill up quickly. That was true! IT quickly became too noisy to hear the jukebox that had some excellent indie rock on it. Being purists, we ordered the  9 inch cheese deep dish. The crust was amazing--if a little over cooked. We looked the butter-basted flavor.The tomato sauce was nothing like I have tasted before. We thought the cheese on top was a little sparse, but I didn't mind--the tomato sauce was just the best I have ever tasted. With six beers--4 PBR and two Racer 5s--the bill came to $22, minus tip. Just a great deal! Beer prices are one dollar off for early birds. Also try the Bean Bag Cafe for $1.75 draft microbrew beer after three pm--just down the street.
author: Carl M.

description: Great Pizza! Consistently good every time I go there or order take out. Thin crust or deep dish. They do a really good white pie too. And now they accept credit cards... even better.
author: John C.

description: Yum, yum, and YUM! I heart cornmeal crust! I have been to both locations and like them both. I like the deep dish and thin crust pizzas. Really nothing negative to say except that they don't deliver...but maybe that's a good thing, because if they did my butt would be much larger:)
author: Emily R.

description: Little star is dangerously close to my house. I'm in love with their pizza. The thin crust and deep dish are equally delicious. They make a great salad and have a nice selection of beer and champagne cocktails. The restaurant on Divis is always crowded but typically the wait is less then they predict. They're so close to my house that if it is super crowded I can order it to go and walk home so the crowds don't really bother me too much. I may feel otherwise if I didn't live so close.
author: Sierra d.

description: dining in romantic low lighting and deep dish pizza. i think i recall the food being ok but not amazing.
author: Helen L.

description: Not bad at all.  Deep dish pizza was almost as good as real Chicago pizza.  They had a few beers on tap, the IPA was not so good though.  Doesn't open til 5 pm.
author: Phil D.

description:
The best Pizza in the bay area. Period.

Oh yeah, its cheap and they have good brew on tap and solid a juke box.
author: Ryan P.

description: Best pizza I have ever had. Tried both the thick and the thin crust and though both were great, with much difficulty, I favored the thick. Be prepared for a different type of crust experience. Its more of like a cornmeal crust, loved it. Quality was excellent and tasted extremely fresh. I would recommend it to any San Francisco visitor that is unaware of how the city by the bay took the pizza and made it something better.
author: Mario H.

description: I love this place.  We always get the classic deep dish and the buffalo wings.  The salad is great.  I just love this place.  If I had to pick my last meal it would be a little start deep dish.  I also go to the little star on Mission and the food is just as good there.  I like the Mission location because there is more light and it is easier to park.
author: P S.

description: This is probably the best thing crust pizza in San Francisco. Topping are spaced perfectly and not overabundant. Very tasty gourment ingredients. Even thought I'm not a big fan of deep dish but the simple tomato was very, very tasty.  CASH ONLY! They have ATM inside for a low fee.
author: Samantha K.

description: Little Star has the best deep dish in the city.  Not only is the pizza fantastic, they serve barley wine.  Two pints and you'll be hammered.
author: Jon P.

description: Really good pizza, a little too much on the $$$ end maybe, given that we are talking pizza.  The too-cool-for-school/twenty-something attitude of the wait staff gets old really fast.  Otherwise, no complaints.  Damn good pizza, much better than Delfina Pizza's.
author: marie m.

description: Rolled in on a Sunday night and the place was packed - a half hour wait for the three of us. No bother, however, as the bartenders were exceptionally friendly and the jukebox was great. After sitting at the bar and having a drink, the three of us were offered the opportunity to eat at the bar by the hostess. We said we'd rather wait, but she didn't give up. She said it would be at least another half an hour - we looked at eachother, and she chimed in, "So, why don't you just eat at the bar" and then walked away. I thought this was a total breach of restaurant etiquette, but I guess that's what they can get away with when the food is that good. The bartenders were really friendly and awesome.
author: Dibital N.

description: Probably the best pizza in SF...I was so excited that I actually ate chicken for the first time there!
author: Paola W.

description: Well, I definitely think Little Star is better than Zachary's...I hadnt eaten at Zachary's in about 6 years and was so excited about it.  I was trying to be open but I realized right away that Little Star's crust is crispier and and more flavorful.  The toppings at Zachary's were undetectable and the sauce was just big clumps of tomatoes.  Little star's sauce tastes and feels like it has been simmering for hours.  I'm not happy to report this as I was looking forward to eating at Zachary's the other night .   But it's OK, let the east bay have their Zachary's and I will get mine at Little Star...
author: Ms. G.

description: Large take-out Little Star pizza, a bottle of champagne, my couch, good friends = perfect evening. The buttery golden crust holds the mountain of toppings securely without turning into a soggy mess (like Zachary's can). Almost better as leftovers the next day, when that champagne hangover sets in...
author: Beth W.

description:
im eating the left-overs right now. deelicious deep dish. crust is like, grainy, like corn meal and so good. 

ambiance inside is more than any other pizza joint, no, they are above a "joint," they are a restaurant. pizza restaurant. beer on tap is prime. small menu, my favorite, easy to choose from and you know they will make it well. 

the servers were a little too quick for my taste, taking empty  bottles from my hand and all, but good service all in all. will return.
author: Meegs P.

description:
Yum, yum, yum! I was told by a co-worker that I had to go here if I wanted some good deep dish pizza. Although this was only the second deep dish style pizza I've ever had, I must say, it was DAMN good.

Get there early because I had to wait for almost 2 hours. It's worth it, but if you're as impatient as I am, you might just end up leaving. Parking is a bit tough in this area, so if you can take public trans, I'd recommend that. I would also suggest going in a small group (2-4 people) because this place isn't that big. Very limited seating.
author: Linda I.

description: DE-LISH-OUS.  If you want Chicago style pizza and do not want a 4 hour plane ride then go to Little Star.  It is like bubble gum chewing cheese pizza.  YUM YUM! Calorie Free?  Who cares.  From the hostess who dressed like Cher to the very friendly wait staff, you cannot go wrong.  The pizza was hot, the toppings are diverse.  The beer is cold and the art work is interesting.  The interior is dimly lighted, yet oddly relaxing.  My water glass was always full.  Yes I will go back.  Want to join me?
author: Geoffrey B.

description: The bar for Chicago deep dish has been set sky high by this here establishment. That's right friends.....between my boy Ray Butler and I,.we have covered all the so called "classic" deep dish joints in Chicago such as Gino's and   Lou Malnati's. Know what? They cannot even compare to Little Star. Pass on the boring, lethargic flour crust and dive into this rendition made out of corn. Call it polenta....who freekin' cares?! The pie here, thin and deep-dish, is second to none. The sauce is pure heaven, as is everything else they put on the pie. Zachary's? What's that? Long live Little Star...........I applaud you. You've made San Francisco king of pizza.
author: Kenny G.

description: Some of the BEST pizza ever!! I've been a huge fan of Zachery's pizza for a long time but recent had Little Star and their deep dish is (dare I say) better! Thin crust is also great. Eat in or take out - quality is the same.
author: Kelly C.

description:
large deep dish mushroom and pepperoncini. tastes just like pepperoni but it's better for you!  it's the best.

rad juke box!
author: Heidi J.

description:
this is so not even pizza. it's like a dance of ectasy in your mouth.

deep dish = huge portions of filling. giant pizzas = group time and bonding, and leftovers afterwards. fresh ingredients = happy jenz.

and quit the bitching about the ATM/credit card deal; it's a little of a bummer, but when you consider the convenience charge is 50 cents and not 3 bucks like a lot of other cash points, it's a helluva deal.
author: Jenz y.

description: We always get the chicken Mediterranean deep dish pizza to-go.  It's very satisfying and our favorite pizza in the city.  I just wish they would add more green olives (please, we love them).
author: Amanda P.

description:
the little star deep dish was yummmmmm
the italian combo thin crust would be perfect if the crust were thinner, but it's still delicious.

overall, they're not as incredible as said here, maybe i was expecting too much. i'd rate it an A-.
author: Jam C.

description: I have been looking for THE pizza place in SF and I have finally found it, Little Star Pizza.  As soon as I walked in the door and got a whiff of the pies, I felt weak in the knees.  I highly recommend the veggie pizza with spinach and mozzarella (I think the name of the pizza is Little Star ), you will never miss the meat.  I also must mention the crust. It was light, buttery, with the right amount of crunch.  The only problem I have now is no other pizza will ever compare to Little Star.
author: Karly N.

description: Best pizza in SF by far! Not as perfect as Zachary's in Berkeley but sure is damn close. I ususally get the take out since it is so close to my place, (although double parking on Divis is always very frightening!) and its a cool sexy vibe inside if you want to wait a bit and mingle. Place is cash only...so come prepared. The Little Star varietal is my fave. Go there..you wont be disappointed!
author: A B.

description:
deee-lish-shush!

I don't know if we were really hungry but we ordered all the appetizers. Except for the green salad.  I must say - that I was in heaven eating their Caprese salad.  It was a flavor explosion in my mouth!  The chicken wish - eh was just a wing. The garlic bread (their version is roasted garlic that you spread over a pieace of bread), the garlic wasn't roasted enough and was pretty solid and I couldn't spread it really but it was good.  Now the pizza - wow... that was yum-o!  I can't even remember what we had.  I know it was deep dish, we had chicken, veggies, oh i can't remember. I remember I could only eat one slice because I had sooo much of the appetizers already.  And the cheesecake. I'm not normally a fan of cheesecake.  But I could eat there's all day!  And becuase I liked the Caprese salad so much I went home and bought my own fresh mozzarella and tomatoes and even bought a live basil plant thinking I could re-create the magic that is the Caprese salad from Little Star.  Sadly I was mistaken... no magic recreated.  Oh well - I'll have to go back to Little Star sometime soon then!

I could have also rated this restaurant so high because I was with a good group of friends. I could be biased there.  Food tends to always taste better when you're around good friends so who knows.
author: Judy T.

description:
TELL that hostess you can order while you wait!  And while your at it, start the training process over.  Yeah, it's great to watch set tables just sit there with groups of 2s, 3s, and 4s watching.  The server was fantastic, yet after hearing our hour plus no pizza order wait, no comp nada.  Shit comp the salad or a couple beers.  
So the pizza was finally decent.  I don't do the deep dish thing, so if you like crust and sauce this is for you.  i do like the cornmeal of the crust.  I do want to try the thin crust, heard it is really really good.  The salad had been tossed in the dressing bowl without dressing negative one star.  Useless hostess negtive 2 stars.
author: Carey C.

description:
First time having Little Star's yummy deep dish pizza!    A bunch of us got a veggie pizza to go and it was really good!   Little Star definately rivals Zachary's.  The main difference is that Little Star's pizza has a corn meal crust.  Zachary's pizza crust is more doughy.  But I think for a similar price point, Little Star's pizza might be a size smaller than Zachary's?

In any case, I definitely want to try the other pizzas on the Little Star menu!   They look really interesting.  

Mmmmm....I love pizza!
author: Y K.

description: Good pizza but not the best. I'd go there again if I'm nearby but Arizmendi, while only having 1 flavor per day, is FAR better. I'd like to see more veggie pies and a rotation in the menu.
author: Tim H.

description: A tasty place for pizza.  Always enjoy a pie from Little Star.
author: Rose D.

description: Good pizza, good service, moderate prices, good people however be aware they will not take reservations and their waiting area is not that big or comfortable.
author: M Y.

description: best deep dish i ever had since i had it in chicago! it just takes forever to get seated and they dont take reservations so get there early!! it also takes forever to get the pizza after you sit down and order it so if you're hungry, order some appetizers because you'll be waiting long! lol ... the place is tiny and cramped.. its a dark "romantic" place i guess but its so cramped and tiny that you're practically eating w/ the stranger next to you so dont go there with huge groups or else you'll be waiting DAYS to get seated.. its a cute place to go with just a date or a few people... but anyways .. the pizza- AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! any flavor no matter what.. even if it sounds gross... i guarantee you will LOVE it! like normally i dont like anchovies or onions or spinach on normal pizza.. but somehow, they know how to make these things taste better than cheesecake!! lol
author: Sofia M.

description:
great deep dish pizza.

i have usually never been disappointed with their special pizza either.

they also have hard cider to drink!
author: Kate R.

description: Best deep dish in the city! I've tried Zachary's deep dish in Berkeley and Patxi's in Hayes- Little Star has the best crust by far! Make sure to get the Classic pizza...yummm
author: Jessica W.

description:
I was a little disappointed -- the deep dish crust was pretty hard and difficult to bite into.  The toppings were good though.

The best thing was the Movie Star Champagne Cocktail.  Definitely worth a second try to get one of those!
author: Karen B.

description:
This is the best pizza I've had in years!!! Yummy!!! 

Love the ambiance. Yes there is usually a wait, but it's worth it! Friendly servers and did I mention that the pizza is great?!?!

You can also get your pizza to go &, bonus, they will do 1/2 and 1/2 so you can get two pizzas in one :)
author: Julie T.

description: Pizza is good.  They have both deep dish (nice) and thin crust (better).  Ambiance - brick wall and Mission crowd - makes it fun.  Only downside is that it is very very popular.  If you get there after 5:30 PM, expect to wait about 45+ minutes.
author: Nick K.

description: Recommend the Little Star, Classic, and the daily special. Good, casual vibe but can get really loud.
author: Michelle A.

description: One of my favorite pizza places ever! Although I don't go regularly, this is a big treat when I do go. My favorite is the Little Star special, wow!!! I so happy they are in my neighborhood!
author: Felix L.

description:
Only good wings i've had on the west-coast. Great gourmet pizza and good beer selection. Trendy interior low-light conditions. Hip place but expensive, it was really busy when i went, we were seated at the bar which turned out to be really fun.  The bartender spilled an almost full beer on me and was very apologetic, got me a new one and help dry me off, we made a good time out of it.  
This place tends to be busy, but don't pass it up. i recommend going at night.
author: Brad Y.

description: I went last sunday and it was pretty busy. They wouldn't seat us until our full party of 4 was there. Even after there was a half hour wait. Once we got inside we had a great waitress but we waited for what seemed like almost an hour for two pizzas. They were delicious though! They have a great vegetarian selection and stuff for meatlovers too. The beer they had on tap was also good. It's a great place to go with a nice atmosphere, but seeing how parking can also be atrocious (it took us 15 minutes to find a spot 5 blocks away), I'm not sure if I would go there on a regular basis.
author: Jes L.

description:
i recently visited some friends in SF and they suggested we come here for a casual, not-too-expensive meal and some delicious pizza.
i was so happy with this recommendation!!
the place was comfy & cute and the staff was wonderful- they seemed genuinely friendly and glad to help. 
their chicago-style deep dish pizza is amazing- we had the little star pie and it was SOOOO good. seriously, i live in chicago and i cannot think of a place that serves better deep dish here. it was so light and fresh tasting! i usually feel full and heavy after eating this kind of pizza, but i could have had 2 more slices of the little star!
if i was rich, i would actually fly out here to have this pizza. or can it be shipped?!!? i will SO be here on my next SF visit!
author: Jill H.

description:
best pizza in the bay..... okay maybe one of the best. the deep dish is scrumptious and the thin crust is just as good! 

huge fan of the wings, although they one come by the pound so be prepared to get your eat on!
author: Chris R.

description:
Craving pizza the first night of a business trip, my coworkers and I drove into San Fran, and after looking for parking for about 20 min, we managed to find something a few blocks away.  This place was BUSY BUSY BUSY, and we waited another 20 min for a table.  During that time, we saw a ton of carry out from this place, and it smelled so good in there, we were dying to try it.

We ordered a large Thin Crust and Large Deep Dish for 4 people.   At $20+ a pie, it's not cheap, but the pizza is pretty large.  Since we had multiple tastes, the restaurant was nice enough to let us split each pizza and have 2 separate flavors on each pie to accommodate everyone.  

Thin crust - the spinach and feta special (can't remember all of the toppings) but it was awesome.  The spinach was perfectly wilted without being too wet, and the flavors really popped your mouth perfectly.  The sauce is perfectly flavored and amazing. 

Deep Dish - sausage and mushrooms.  The crust is delicious and amazing.  One thing I didn't like was the sauce is put on top of the pie, and fills in the crust and toppings are underneath.  But there is so much sauce, I couldn't even tell what toppings were on the pizza.  Still, I could've done this as a deep dish cheese pizza and been more than happy with all of it.

Had a black cherry soda which was also a nice little addition to the meal.  

Service was awesome and I can see why this place had such a wait.  It's a good thing I don't live in San Fran, as i'd be carrying out regularly and be broke!  For a party of 4, I believe our meal came out to just over $50.  Totally reasonable and would go back in a heartbeat!
author: L F G.

description: For a deep dish lover in S.F., this is as good as it gets.  The salads are fantastic, atmosphere is enjoyable and unique, and the pizza is AMAZING.  Both the deep dish and the thin crust are the best I've had in the city.  This is a must have.
author: Jeff K.

description: Good pizza - I can't say it beats Zachary's in a taste test, though. The atmosphere is ok, if a little cold, and I've had mixed experiences with the staff.  They ran out of pizza one night so they closed early, but the manager saw us standing outside and offered us his last thin-crust pizza, which was really cool of him. But, later the same night they tried to charge me for 2 glasses of wine when I only had 1 and when I asked them to change it, the waitress/bartender was very rude about it. I'd probably go back to give it another try, though.
author: Katie K.

description: LORDY. Best real chicago-style deep dish pizza. You'll want to gorge on it. The crust is a perfect cornmeal that is nice and thin. The tomatoe of the Classic is perfectly tangy. The sausage is crumbled and not overbearing. Holy moley.... Spooge....
author: Mary R.

description: This is it......Little Star knows what they are doing. It all stars with the Deep dish and it's bold thick sauce all the way to the crispy full of flavor crust, hands down the best pie in the entire Bay Area (including Zachary's). The chapagne Cocktails are popular with the ladies and the handfull of beers they have on tap are a good selection. The only downfall is their lack of Cabs in house. The lighting and ambiance make the small restaurant seem lively and grand.
author: JC C.

description: So every body under the sun is saying that this is the best pizza in town.  It is good, I will give you that, but I think in a town full of  the best _______________ I've ever had, there has to be a better pizza place around.  I did like it, don't get me wrong there thin crust just wasn't thin enough for me, but the deep dish was nice, i just ate to much of it as a kid and have moved on to the thiner more textured style pizza's which i still can't find.
author: brian m.

description: I love this place. The atmosphere is very cool. The pizza is awesome. It saves a drive to Berkeley.  The overall experience is better than Zachary's, but I find the pizza falls just a tiny notch short in my book.
author: Val U.

description: What more can be said?  Amazing Chicago style deep dish with a crispy crust that tastes like butter.  It gets very busy though and they don't take reservations.
author: James B.

description: Am I a deep dish expert? No. Do I love their signature deep dish pizza? YES.  I have never actually eaten here so I can't really comment on the atmosphere or service.
author: b s.

description: I love tomatoes, therefore I also love deep dish.  For my birthday I had a sampler of three of the pizzas, the classic, the cheese and the veggie and they were all delish.  As most people have noted, the do it yourself garlic bread is awesome.  However, I don't think comparisons to Zachary's  should be made-the two taste very different to me, probably due to the crusts, since LSP is cornmeal.  The actual restaurant is supercool on the inside and it has a great jukebox selection that matches the neighborhood.
author: Cassandra E.

description: If you like deep dish, this is your spot.  Very well made cornmeal crust.
author: Chris D.

description: Great pizza. The thin crust was crispy, the sauce was strong but not dominating, and the toppings were fresh. Good atmosphere as well. It was a bit dark in there but I can overlook that. In the end, I'll be honest, the fact that they have Racer 5 on tap guaranteed them 5 stars :-)
author: Mike C.

description: Best pizza in SF without a doubt.  Bring cash - They don't take credit cards.
author: Matt B.

description: Some of the best Chicago style pizza pie this side of the Mississippi. You can even get a PBR in the can. This place is also a bargain. Oh, and great chicken wings too.
author: Deno M.

description: A long wait to be seated but after eating there, I can see why.  Good pizza. Great service.  The waiter even encouraged us not to order too much food.
author: Monkeyfaced E.

description: If they took credit cards, I'd give them 5 stars.  I love the thin crust pizzas.  They also have unique champagne cocktails.
author: Jody B.

description: Best pizza I have ever had! I have heard soo much about it and during a visit to SF this weekend I finally had a chance to try it. The place is on the small side but it was spaced out well inside. The sign is small so we drove by it a couple of times. We got the italian pizza but had it as a deep dish, it's normally a thin crust. I only have one beef with it and that is they only take cash, BUT their ATM is only a $0.25 fee. Every time I come back to the city I will have to come here.
author: Ryan M.

description: Best pizza in San Francisco, hands down. It's expensive, but in a city that is seriously lacking any suitable pizza options, I'll fork over the cash. And while I'm on that subject, it's a cash only place. Great for take out or dining in. Deep dish and thin crust are both legit options.
author: Shannon C.

description: If only Little Star would open up a third spot in the Inner Sunset ... I'd be there weekly. Yes, everybody loves this place, so I'm not alone there. I never thought I'd say that LS kicks Zachary's ass, but ... ahem ... I'm afraid it does. My standard lineup: mixed salad followed up by the Little Star deep dish, all washed down with a lovely glass (or two) of Cotes du Rhone. The cornmeal crust is to-die-for, the chunky tomatoes are addictive ... mmmm. I had it twice last week and was jonesing for s'more today ... a girl can keep on hoping, can't she?
author: lisa p.

description: The best deep dish I have ever had. Whenever I have craved pizza I thought that Pizza was the bomb, but I was wrong! So Little Star you havewon my heart! Any pizza is the best! You must try it! The only downer is that it is first come first serve. Not open on Mondays.
author: M C.

description: We went here to see what all the hype is about.  Unfortunately, we came here on Saturday night, bad mistake.  It was very, very crowded.  So, we ended up ordering out, which wasn't much faster.  When we finally got the pizza, it was piping hot.  The thin crust pizza was excellent, and very tasty.  I will have to try the deep dish next time.  I must say, the atmosphere is very interesting for a pizza joint, almost bar/club like.  The place is small, dark, and very loud.  Parking is very difficult, forget about it.  I will definitely try to dine in again on a weekday.
author: Crosby C.

description: Just so you know, Little Star now takes credit cards! Way to roll into the 20th century!
author: julie q.

description:
Great deep dish pizza!

Went with the "classic" which has sausage, tomatoes, olives, and about a foot deep in cheese/sauce.   Very good, and the essential crust was light, flaky, and a perfect compliment to the pie.
author: Cadillac X.

description: Excellent, excellent pizza.  Actually, one of the best I've had.  Also, last night when I went to get some caprese, William Baldwin with some unrecognizables.  I think the crust is made with cornmeal or the like - it has a sweetness to it that is not usually found in pizza, but it taste great.  The place has a cool, low-light atmosphere with a great juke box.
author: Nick D.

description: According to anyone I talked to in San Francisco, this was the place to eat a pizza. My new bff Bryce that I met at Toronado even recommended it. Little Star serves both thin crust and deep dish pizza. I think that is very diplomatic of them to offer both types of pizza. We ordered one of each. For the thin crust, we ordered a white pie, which was really good. Then the deep dish Mediterranean chicken pizza came out. It was unbelievable. So tasty and I do not normally like chicken. In addition to the pizza, we started out with a mixed salad. It was a nice mix of greens, gorgonzola and some veggies. We were all ridiculously full even though there were four of us sharing the 2 small pizzas. I noticed a home made cheesecake on the menu and asked the server if it was worth stuffing ourselves to the point of discontent. He said absolutely. We ordered one piece and four forks. Man I almost got myself a piece to go for the road. i highly recommend you do the same if you eat too much pizza and can simply not eat another bite.
author: Stephani S.

description: I love Little Star. They serve the best deep dish in the city hands-down. And I can now admit that I love Little Star more than any of my old favorites in Chicago.
author: Amy H.

description: the sausages are tastee and the crust felt just right. i loved the pizza..seems a lil pricey though but overall worth every bite
author: Brian K.

description:
I think its the best pizza in San Francisco -- and I've debated the point many times.   And I'm not usually a fan of the Chicago style pizzas.  Plus they have a great draft beer selection -- something sadly lacking in San Francisco overall.

The only drawback is the small size.  I love the pizza but wish I didn't have to wait 45 minutes to eat it every time.  But I do anyway, so more proof that its awesome.
author: Darin S.

description: Little Star is good...i think i like the deep dish better than the thin crust..This is one of the best pizza places in SF..the other is Gaspari's on geary and golden boy on green....i admit im one of those east coast people that scoff at california pizza..but little star is really great...get it to go, though..unless you like crowds.
author: lesley s.

description: I've only been here once but wow!  It really made an impression on me.  Not that the food wasn't great (LOVED the cornmeal crust on their pizza - very different!) but Little Star gets 5 stars from me since they really impressed me with their customer service.  After apologizing for accidentally giving our pizza away (and of course replacing it), they ended up comping our entire meal.  And yes, I definitely think this place is better than Zachary's (which I think is overrated).
author: Fran C.

description:
I LOVE pizza.  Seriously more than you can imagine.  After hearing positive reviews about LSP I had to give it a try.  I anticipated parking and the wait on a Friday night to be miserable but it wasn't bad -- we waited only 15 minutes for a table.  

It was def. a scene, but the overall service of the staff was amazing despite the place being packed.  We opted for the chicken wings, green salad and the deep dish pizza. The corn meal crust was unique and tasty.  Overall the food was excellent.  I don't think it's the best pizza I've ever had, but it was good.
author: Aimee L.

description: The best pizza in the city!  They have great deep fried Chicago style pizza.   They have good organic (?) salad too.  I like their veg deep fried pizza and spinach deep fried pizza called "little star".  It's very dark inside, so sometimes it's hard to see what you are eating, but everything taste good there.
author: moshi m.

description: Yum.  It is so hard to find good pizza in San Francisco.  They have it here.  Fun atmosphere, good jukebox, delicious pies.   This is the place to go if you want deep dish -- I understand they have thin crust too, but haven't tried it.  I keep threatening my friend from Chicago that I am gonna drag her here.   It might not be Lou Malnati's, but it is as close as San Francisco has gotten.
author: Jamie F.

description:
This pizza is amazing! As an 8-year veteran of Chicago pizzerias, i know from good za and this place was without equal. Not deep enough to really be "deep dish," I nevertheless spent most of my bites looking on and chewing in amazement. On the waitress's recommendation, I paired our Little Star special (veggie spinach, etc) with a local, mild IPA. Delish. Would go back again and again. And again.
And as Peter mentions below, it's cash only, but the in-house ATM charges only a symbolic 25 cents surcharge.
author: J S.

description: As someone from Chicago, I can say this is probably the most authentic Chicago style pizza in the city. When I crave a taste of home,  I usually hit up Zachary's in Oakland, which is reminiscent of Giordano's in Chi, but I'm slowly converting to Little Star.  I'd say this pizza is more like a Gino's given the style of the crust.  I usually get the combination pizza.  It goes well with a stella since we don't have any Goose Island here.
author: Larissa W.

description: Should I admit that their number is now in my cell phone? Deep dish all the way; why even try the thin crust? If it just wasn't so noisy (boy sounding old!) or take so long for a table..and if only they took credit vs. cash..! But for pick up on the way home, it's perfect.
author: Jill B.

description: Previously I was totally opposed to deep dish pizza. It was too cheesy and just...not good. Little Star has changed all that. The ratio of crust (amazing cornmealish crust) to cheese, chunky tomato sauce, and toppings is perfect. There is pretty much nothing else to say. Fabulous pizza.
author: Abigail R.

description: Food is spectacular, and delivery service from Shorty's is wonderful as well.  Unfortunately, it's not family friendly.  I have a toddler, and they refused to bring the pizza out to my car.  They expect you to park, get your toddler out, juggle the toddler and pizza, get your toddler buckled back in, and not drop the pizza.  So, I had to pay for delivery, which increases the cost substantially, which was the explanation for a 1 star deduction.
author: Vicky K.

description: Good but not worth the wait. The pizza was very similar to Zachary's in Berkeley but honestly, nothing spectacular. We had the Mediterranean deep dish. The crust was nice and crispy but the sauce and chicken lacked flavor. I didn't taste the feta cheese. Service was friendly and efficient. Parking was easy.
author: james i.

description: I'm from Chicago and I've had a good many deep dish pizzas in my time. I can say Little Star is top notch. it's consistently perfect  and authentic from the cornmeal crust to the oh so wonderfully spiced, rich tomato sauce. Little Star, you rock my world!!!
author: Mollie A.

description: Deep dish......wow! I avoided this place for years, what a dunce I was! Goodbye Pizza Orgasimica.Little Star has the best cornmeal pizza in San Francisco.
author: Joe R.

description:
More like 3.5 stars. The pizza was good, but nothing extra special.  We got a deep dish meatball, ricotta, red bell pepper, spinach, mushroom pizza (it was the special). Maybe we ordered too many toppings, but each bit only had one topping in it.  There was less cheese than I am used to deep dishes having (not necessarily a bad thing unless you like cheesy pizza). The sauce was good, with a nice fresh taste. Wasn't big on the crust. It was not a true cornmeal.

The atmosphere was...bar like.  It was dimly lit with a candle on the table, but was a open room with people having loud conversations. The menu was also half alcohol. I wasn't into the atmosphere.
author: Holly B.

description: This place is awesome, and has greattttttt pizza! Def the best I have eaten out in Frisco by far. The place is cool and chill and has a good ambiance. Staff is friendly and they provide great service. Def will go again! I'm salavating justing thinking about the Pizza! :)
author: Maria T.

description:
very decent deep dish for SF

watch out for the hipsters, though

the juke box cannot be beat
seriously

so it's a toss up,
i would say get the pizza para llevar
but the juke box 
makes you want to stay

it's also way too dark to have a normal conversation or 
see what you're eating
author: Eva S.

description:
Sorry - Just wasn't that impresses with Little Star!  I went on a very rainy Wednesday evening and was actually the first party there!  The staff was a bit too casual and we felt as if we were interupting their conversations at the bar.  
The pizza is very tasty, much like Zachary's, but wow was it skimpy!  The slice was aproximately the same size as a slice of pie - which I guess is the idea.  For nearly $20 I expect a SLICE baby! 
I guess I'll just marinate my own stewed tomatoes
author: K O.

description: I want to give this place 5 stars because the pizza smells incredible.  I've been in at least 10 times but walked off because the wait is just intolerable.  Why can't they take reservations? lame!  Plus the neo-hipster crowd is very loud and annoying, not the kind of people you want to be stuck standing around with for 60 minutes while waiting for a table.  Ah well.
author: Nick A.

description: Amazing spot. Great pizza (both deep dish and thin crust are outstanding), great beer, great atmosphere ... and affordable. Have a drink at the bar while you wait for a table.
author: Michael C.

description: I absolutelty love little star pizza. I had the deep dish with tomato chuncks and basil and the thin crust was tasty too! Service was good. Atmosphere was dim and great variety of beer. I had Zacharys and it was ok but Little star would be my place for pizza.
author: Lisa N.

description:
little star does great deep dish.  i grew up in the chicagoland area, and i love me some deep dish pizza.   definitely in the company of gino's east, pizzerias uno & due, and giordano's.  
the mediterranean deep dish is really fantastic.
thank you, little star, for reminding me of my childhood.
author: Eric L.

description: Let me begin by saying that I generally prefer thin crust over Chicago deep dish.  But when I am in the mood for deep dish, no other place comes close.  Eating a slice of pie from Little Star is a life changing experience.  And not only is the food great, I love the scene on the inside: low lights, cool juke box, and excellent beers on tap!
author: Robert G.

description: Duffman's favorite pizza in SF. The deep dish is delicious. A lame spot to dine in, but perfect to pick up if you are gonna spend  the night chilling in your humble abode. Take on a small deep dish and you will be glad you are on your couch. I guess it could be considered a touch pricey, but compared to the prices and quality of other pizza places Little Star is definitely worth it.   Tip: If you call in on a busy night, and they say your pizza will be ready in 40 minutes, it will really be ready in 50-55 minutes.
author: Duffman D.

description:
Great crust... its all about the deep dish at Little Star.

If Little Star is too crowded try sushi at Tsunami! If Tsunami is too expensive just go get a cheesesteak from Jays!
author: Ethan O.

description: I've never been a huge fan of deep dish pizza.  Until tonight, I thought all deep dish pizza was soupy... Little Star changed my mind.  The crust was flaky and crisp, there was just the right amount of delicious toppings that actually stayed on each slice while I ate.  I was prepared with a fork and knife and was glad to put them away clean when I was done eating.  I got take-out but it seemed like a nice place, next time I'll probably eat there... if there's not a line halfway around the block...
author: Amy L.

description: My first review on Yelp has to be about Little Star. I can't say enough about this place. If you like real Chicago-style deep dish pizza, this is the place to be! I've only had better in Chicago, and even that's debatable. It's casual yet funky; a great place to go if you want a night out without breaking the bank. Speaking of bank, make sure to stop at one before going in ... it's cash only, though they do have an ATM with a ridiculously low teller fee (only 25c). There's another location at 15th and Valencia, which is closer to me, but the vibe isn't quite there so I still make the trek here.
author: Warren F.

description: Great pizza and great atmosphere! My boyfriend wanted to get pizza, as usual, and I wanted to go to a sit down restaurant where we could order a decent bottle of wine.  Little Star is a total package! Get there early though because it is small and there may be a wait.
author: Aimee J.

description: We order take out here since the place is so tiny and dark inside. The cornmeal deep dish crust is the best! They are pretty good with the timing if you call ahead and place your order; too bad they don't offer delivery....
author: Heather I.

description: Absolutely incredible pizza.  The Classic deep dish pizza is really good and so is just the plain old cheese thin crust (probably one of the more under-rated pies in the city).  I know that everyone fiercely debates pizza quality or lack thereof in SF but Little Star is just good food, plain or simple, no matter what the category.  Will always recommend going to share a pie with friends and listen to their solid jukebox.
author: Ray G.

description: Lived in Chicago last year and tried as much deep dish as I could - Art of Pizza, Gino's, Lou Malnati's, Pizzaria Uno, Pi, Chicago Pizza & Oven Grinder to name a few - Little Star does pretty well against heavyweights. The ingredients were fresh, and I enjoyed the overall experience. But if you're expecting the depth of flavor and heartiness you find in a real Chicago deep dish, it's not quite there. Unless you're having deep dish deprived night sweats, it's not worth the wait.
author: Ben L.

description: I used to avoid Little Star simply for its price, but the longer I've been in the neighborhood the more I've come to appreciate this place. Their menu is limited, but what they make they make well. Yes, their prices are high, but you get a lot of food and can always count on it being absolutely delicious. Great vibe inside and also great for take out. They just started taking card, so now it's just too convenient not to have all the time!
author: Raquel P.

description: Little start pizza is the awesomest, yo! This place is fanastic. The decor is much nicer than your average pizza joint. Quite the Gem. only give it 4 stars cause I'll always be true to my Zachary roots and I had to ask for my beer twice.
author: kelly M.

description:
three words for little star: better than zachary's.

the namesake pizza, which we had was fantastic. also, the caprese salad was made from very fresh ingredients and was very tasty.
author: Jason S.

description: Great pizza, even the thin crust.  Plus it has a tremendous jukebox and cheap PBR.
author: Jake B.

description: Rocks!! Fantastic, only please make the place bigger ;-)
author: Brian C.

description: LOVE the pizza here.  easily my favorite in the city.  most people rave about the chicago deep dish, but i'm partial to the thin crust because their fresh ingredients shine a little more.  the crust is a true thin crust, spun thin and cooked to the right crispyness.  god damn, i want a slice now.  the service on the surface is hipster inspired indifference, but my experience is that everyone is actually really conscientious.  i drop this place a star 'cause the wait can be freaking horrendous.  just grab one of their microbrews on tap.
author: Kazuo L.

description: The deep dish classic pizza is everything they say. I am still dreaming about the pizza and I ate it 3 nights ago!  The restaurant on Divisadero is very dark and gets pretty noisy by 7:30pm, good thing my friend and I went early. The service is so so. Our waitress spilled some of the wine while she was pouring it and wasn't very attentive throughout our meal. But, I could care less. The pizza and wine were perfect. Salad is just so so.  Definitely over order, you'll want to take home leftovers.
author: Jenni L.

description: Originally from Chicago, I can say that this is the Best Deep Pizza in San Francisco!
author: josue p.

description: First off, don't forget to take cash if you don't want to pay the $3 fee to use the cash machine near the door. Little Star doesn't take cards or checks, which is the only thing mildly annoying about this place. The thin crust pizza is simply fabulous, and I love the dark, intimate atmosphere. Try the White Pie: Garlic, olive oil, mozzarella, zucchini, tomatoes and feta. What's different about this pizza is that while it contains fresh tomatoes, it is made without the tomato sauce usually smothered on every pizza we eat. You may remember this distinctive taste from pizzas eaten in other countries. But if you like it with tomato sauce the folks at Little Star will oblige. And it's still delicious.
author: Regina B.

description: I like the deep dish.  Although I did not dine-in.  My pick up pizza is good.
author: Corinne P.

description:
went tonight for a date.  NIce lighting. Fun decor, I had a nice pear cider to drink that was nice and light would make a great summer drink. We shared a mixed Green salad which was ok but not my fav kind of salad. The we had a large deep dish pizza. with Sauage and oinon. THe pizza was good lots of cheese and a ton of tomato sauce so you had better like that. The wait staff was pleasent. It was busy we got there at 6:30 and there was aline later. It got really loud in there so trying to have a conversation where we were seated was hard that is my biggest complanit 
I will go back to try some of the other pizzas
the meau is small I will say as well
author: Chris S.

description:
Man oh man. Don't believe the hype. 

The thin crust pizzas taste like pizza topping over month-old stale flour tortillas and the forgetabout the chicago-style pizzas. The corn meal crust are an improvement but gritty. 

At least the decor is cool and spartan.

Think Zachary's Chicago Pizza in the East Bay. Now go there instead. Too bad Pizzeria Uno is gone....remember the Seafood Delico.....yummy!
author: Rod A.

description:
This pizza rocks.  I was there one time. My girlfriend and I now refer to this place as "Little SIGN Pizza".  It is very hard to see. We went there once. A mutual boyfriend told us about the place. The only downside was that it was hard to find. 

The pizza is like my uncle's place in South Chicago. Thick Chicago-style. A small weighs over five pounds.   There is a bar on the right when you walk in. You can order, wait, and have a drink if you want take-out.  We took it home, fixed a salad and popped open a nice Cab. It was truly a memorable night.
author: Jaq B.

description: I was never much of a deep dish pizza fan, but Little Star managed to change that...so good and addicting.  I also love their garlic bread.  So much more tastier than Zachary's.
author: Jeanette B.

description:
i was here on a date and we got the little star. delicious! the leftovers also make a delicious breakfast and late night snack ;)

downside: we waited for an hour even though it was 9pm. 
two words: take out.
author: Kan L.

description: Best deep dish in SF with awesome cornmeal crust. Fresh ingredients, always consistent quality. For the few times we've dined in, their beer selection is perfect.
author: D S.

description: The best deep dish pizza I had in my life! You must try  their Little Star pizza!  If you go there, be ready to wait; but believe me, it is definitely be worth it.
author: P J.

description: Good pizza.  I prefer the thin crust, but even their deep dish is pretty decent.  Good beer selection too.  Huge positive is that when you're done eating, there are usually cabs in the neighborhood which is pretty clutch in SF.
author: Nate H.

description: After reading all the reviews, I finally decided to check out the place.  Their pizza is good, but I still like Zachary's better.  Zachary's pizza is more saucy.
author: Sunday R.

description: Wow!  I finally came across the best pizza in SF....  thick, crusty, rich and warm (just like me!, well, except rich)  ...
author: Eric H.

description: being from new jersey, i'm a true believer in the inherent superiority of northeastern thin-crust pizza. that being said, this place is deep-dish bliss. and the wings are amazing-- the best non-fried wings i've had in SF, if not anywhere.
author: Brett W.

description: every time someone comes to visit from out of town, we take them here.  why?  because i've never met someone who doesn't like their pie.  and it has a cool, hip atmosphere without being too full of itself.  i think the little star is quite possibly the best pizza i've ever had.  and the crust...jesus h. crust...it's so fing good.  they have the best juke box of any pizza joint i've been too.  and there are always leftovers...and the pizza is just as good cold the next day...the true test of a good pie.
author: Jessica W.

description:
the meal:
veggie pizza sub sausage & garlic for bell peppers & olives :)

the good:
the crust, the toppings, the sauce (the music is great & the wait staff is fun too!)

the bad:
the wait, cash only, the strict ordering rules (no pre ordering for dine in)!

the ugly:
my low carb diet after dinner at little star....buh-bye!
author: Bubba M.

description: The atmosphere is spartan, with blue and gray walls and a rust-colored cement floor, but nobody's coming here for the decor. Thick-crust, aka Chicago, pizza lovers are attracted by the deep-dish pies with their crunchy cornmeal crusts. The signature Little Star is stuffed with a mix of spinach, ricotta and feta cheeses, and mushrooms, then topped with a thick, zesty red sauce. The white pie is a bit of a misnomer, considering it combines mozzarella, feta, garlic, and olive oil with colorful zucchini and tomatoes. A selection of cracker-thin crust varieties are available as well. It's not likely you'll have room for the delicious housemade cheesecake, but gelato is known to aid with digestion, at least in Italian families. Always crowded, with a jukebox playing classics adding to the din. I'm glad I live around the corner, because parking's a major problem in this mostly residential neighborhood.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I am giving Little Star 4 out of 5 based on their service.  The pizza is REALLY good if you like deep dish...its perfect!  I went on a Friday night (really busy) and they said the wait would be 45 minutes.  That was fine with us, we saddled up to the bar.  But afte an hour and half, and four beers later, we were STARVING and really annoyed.  They should have just been honest about the wait from the jump.  After investing that wait, we just decided to stick it out.  Moral of the story- prepare yourself for a very long wait.  The ambiance is cool- very hipster, dark, rock-esque, but the waiters and waitresses are too cool for school.  Part of the motif I guess!    Overall- great pizza, bad service, long wait.
author: Erica S.

description: crust crust crust, sauce sauce sauce.  i don't care if you're vegan (skip the cheese), vegetarian (skip the meat) or omnivorous (go crazy), this is probably the best pizza i've ever had.  and it's all because the crust is so crunchy and the tomato sauce is so fresh and chunky.  it doesn't matter what toppings you get, you will absolutely fall in love.  sure, the place is tiny and cramped and loud.  maybe next time we'll try the carry-out.  it doesn't matter, whatever you have to do to get some little star, it is worth it.  also, get a black cherry soda because it's the perfect compliment.  skip the garlic bread, as it was cleverly served but nothing all that special.  still, it did take the edge off the 30-minute wait for the deep dish.
author: kate s.

description: hello there all, Mary here.  I wrote a week or so back about a problem I encountered here.  I think it's only fair that I report the resolution.  The owner, Brian, called me and apologized sincerely for my experience and put me on the credit list for a free pizza.  He called me as soon as I left him my number and he spent some time with me on the phone discussing the issue, and you know, I get the feeling he is a nice guy.  Thank you Brian for responding in a decent way.  That's good business.
author: Mary C.

description: Cailifornia, lets get something clear. Pizza state, you are not. I know that short of tongue service, im not gonna find a decent pizza in this city, so im done looking for good pizza, and resolved to look for "roundish pie looking things that have an Italian flair about them." We got the garlic bread, and im down with roasted garlic, and fresh bread like a nun is down with lead panties. We got a thin crust and deep dish. They were both ok. I liked the crust on both, but the zauze was really acidic, like, more acid than a Burning Man notebook. But what really singed the shorties was while we were finishing off our beers after they cleared our plate, one of the waitstaff, in the most feigned politeness since Diane Keaton saying "Im just tired, thats all", they asked us to "Please think about leaving because they had people waiting." Granted, we got there at about 530 to beat the rush, but it was 700pm! WTF? An hour and a half is too long? If i had a derby on, id have forecefully grabbed my brim and announced a "Good Day" to him, and with a twist of my waxed moustache, and a quick snatch of my cane, whisk off into the foggy streets of Cantlesbury to wage my chances against the Ripper. But i dont, so we pounded our beer and we complained amongst ourselves.
author: Mick F.

description:
more like a 4.3.  

i'm a ny pizza guy, but enjoy any pizza if it's good.  deep dish pizza that isn't pretentious.  we got a large half classic and half little star.  the little half was the shiznizzle and the classic was ok.  it really wasn't that expensive considering that we could have had 4 people share it easy.  we also got a small pizza and b/c we came early enough (thanks to you yelpers who made us paranoid about the wait), beers were a dollar off.  our total bill with tip was 40 bucks.  delicious and i will be back.
author: shar d.

description: so effin' good....it hurts!!! seriously, the next day my poor body kept craving some of that delicious pizza with all the fresh toppings: sauce that tasted like tomatoes, olives that tasted like kalamata, and the cheese...oh man, don't get me started on the cheese!! this place is highly addictive...be warned! good jukebox, drinks, food, and people...what more do you want? some people think the wait is a problem, but i say it shows how many people have good taste!
author: Parisa M.

description: Possibly the best pizza I've ever eaten, a decent beer selection, and acceptable service.
author: James d.

description: Hands down my favorite pizza place! In the world! The Little Star deep dish is the best. Very reasonably priced wine and generous glasses. Cool low key atmosphere and much higher quality ingredients than Zachary's without having to drive across a bridge.
author: alibee i.
