description: get here early. the hostess actually took our order before seating us because deep dish takes about 45 mins to bake. we ordered a large 1/2 classic 1/2 little star large pizza. the pizza didn't look super huge but it was enough to feed 4 hungry people. i liked how the pizza didn't fall apart. i hate it when deep dish slides into a pool of cheese and wet toppings after it's transfered to a plate. i didn't give little star 5 stars because the crust could have been more flavorful and the pizza didn't burn my mouf.
author: B Y.

description: This place has the most bomb-ass deep dish pizza around!  The ingredients are so fresh, you'll swear they just picked the tomatoes and slaughtered the cow to make your pizza.  Not a rush job, this place won't deliver and give them a minimum of 30 minutes to get your takeout order ready.  They don't make your pizza till you order it and their prices are beyond fair.  Their SMALL deep dish feeds my hog of a boyfriend and my big man appetite perfectly with 3 pieces each.  I can't even imagine the epic proportions of the large!  Best of all, you don't necessarily have to eat this with a knife and fork for the purists like myself that don't consider pizza authentic unless it's palm food.  Their dining room is really cozy and well decorated but always packed with locals and the wannabe locals so it can get noisy but that's okay cause conversation is overrated and it takes time away from filling your mouth with their yummy pizza.  I always stick with their classic deep dish but all their selections look great and I have NEVER had a bad pizza from them.
author: Jill D.

description: After a day of hiking in the Headlands, "The Little Star" and some beer was just about the perfect way to put an exclamation point on a beautiful day.  What really separates Little Star from other deep dish pizzas is the great combination of delicious sauce and unique crust.  While we recently moved across town we will still have to make our way back to the best deep dish pizza the city has to offer.
author: Leo S.

description: it's sunday night, which means my brain is fried and i have nothing funny to say. but heed my words, little star pizza is the best deep dish pizza in the city. in the state. in fact, the best anywhere up to the chicago city limits.
author: Bee H.

description: I have been versed on the zodiac, constellations and twinkle twinkle....but LITTLE STAR.......LITTLE STAR.....what's that?   Don't let the name fool you....this place is kind of a big deal.  From the outside you just see a black door with a sign of a tower with a star above it...but don't mistake it for a muslim bake shop....walk in and experience the chillness of this spot.  I did not sit and dine because I wasn't so fresh after a 2 hour workout at the gym but I did sit in there to wait for my thin crust classic pizza, little star Chicago style pizza, spicy wings, and cheesecake.  The place is just down to earth and chill....it relaxed me like I was in the Himalayan mountains in a secret spring behind the waterfalls having a bubble bath.  The thin crust pizza was very delicious, but the Chicago style pan pizza was insane in the membrane.....it's like having two meals in one.....first you have your pizza of choice (I got the little star...which has spinach and feta cheese on a cornbread crust) and then they put a mote of thick pizza sauce in the middle....very addicting.  I was on a strict diet for two weeks and I put it on pause for that day like I was playing Nintendo WII to use the bathroom and had 4 slices of the Chicago style, 3 slices of the thin crust, 5 spicy wings (which were just alright for me....not spicy at all), and a slice of some tasty homemade cheesecake.....oh snapples was that good!!!  That was like a month ago and I am still feining like a crack baby.....I know they be sprinkling some crack on the pizza....it just doesn't add up.  Oh yea!!! plus they have dranks (Ebonic definition - alcoholic beverages)...next boys night out we are going to hit this spot up.  Prices are more than other pizza joints but well worth it.
author: Te R.

description: The pizza here is so delicious that I ate so much of it over the course of a year that I got sick of it and haven't had it in months now. I've eaten here (well, mostly take out) dozens of times--I remember a time when I got pizza here once a week. Both the thin and deep dish pizzas are excellent--spicy, flavorful sauce and crispy, perfectly textured crusts in both cases. I think the deep dish here is a little better than Zachary's, but it's a close call. It's definitely better than the crap I just had in Chicago--totally due to my own bad decision in the place, I'm sure (or so I've been told...now I have to wait til next time damnit!!). But actually perhaps my favorite thing at Little Star (other than the fab jukebox) are the the chicken wings--so. good. This deep affinity could have something to do with my pizza burnout, but really I've always loved the wings....just more so lately. Cheap PBRs (normally like $2 a can I think?) are a plus, too. And the champagne cocktails are served in a huge glass--or at least they were, last time I ate inside. I knocked off a star because I was truly annoyed when this place switched to CASH ONLY! WTF? It's not like it's a cheap, divey joint AND in the beginning they did accept credit cards, which makes it all the more irritating. Ah well.
author: Jasmine F.

description: geez.. i've walked/driven by this place like a gazillion times... never really paying attn due to the dark entry of this place. finally, after a couple of ppl told me great things, we thought to try it out.. made an order to go, ready at the exact time (1/2hr) . classic, large, deep-delicious. crzy thing was it was still 5:30p and the place was already packed, every table taken.. parking around the area can be a PITA, but as Sam(uel Jackson) Adams says... "MMM MMMM GOOD.... "
author: Marcus W.

description: worst dining experience ever! after ordering over $100 in food and drink  the owner rudely pushed us out to door to make room for a new table after he thought we had been sitting long enough.  very unprofessional and quite rude! on top of that it's super loud...so loud that you can hardly even hear the painfully hip tunes in the back ground.  pizza was ok... certainly nothing to go nuts over.
author: emily y.

description: Ehh I had better. It's just a deep dish pizza loaded with cheese and sauce.  Nothing spectaclar.
author: C W.

description: the vegetarian "little star" deep dish pizza is a food orgasm. one of my favorite foods of all time. this isn't just pizza, its a pastry pie that melts in your mouth.
author: Liz S.

description:
i have a lot of a good memories surrounding Little Star Pizza. 

a sunny, summer day sharing pizza with a pretty girl while sitting underneath a shady tree (the tree outside the store, albeit, but a tree none the less). a crowded night at the restaurant itself with Kati, James and the rest of the work crew, for our "office holiday party" a couple years ago. 

the stand out, both times, was the "white pizza." cream sauce, pale veggies and a perfect not-too-thin crust. i need more Little Star in my life, if for nothing else than the sake of good memories.
author: chaz w.

description: Quite possibly the best pizza I have EVER had. If I didn't live as far from this place as I do, I would be obese, and it would be Little Star's fault.  Thank god gas prices are ridiculous.
author: Sarah Y.

description: I've been reading through the reviews and I agree with the comments about a long wait. But you know why there's a long wait? Because its the best pizza this side of the mississippi and everyone knows it. I literally tell people who are visiting "this will be the best pizza you ever taste" and they laugh me off, having thoughts of Little Cesars or even Round Table in their silly little pea brains. This isn't "pizza" folks, its PIZZA. The best damn pizza this mouth will ever sink its teeth into. Here's the secret: order 45 min ahead and pick it up and eat it in your cozy apartment. OR go between 5-6pm, no one is there and you'll be happy you came early. But yes, i'm a little peeved at the cash only rule like everyone else.
author: Holly S.

description: if you are a big fan of thick crust pizzas this is the place to be! mouth watering cornmeal pizzas.. ! yummy
author: Tess C.

description:
i grew up in berkeley. i grew up on zachary's. and yes it is good. but little star is AMAZING. that crust! it is so crispity buttery delicious. for anyone who thought they didn't like deep dish, give this one more try. i bet it will change your mind.

if only it weren't so noisy and crowded all the time. but at least you can drink champagne cocktails while you wait.

oh and i think nopa is the lamest name for a neighborhood ever. it's called western addition.
author: Mia M.

description: everyone likes to be a pizza snob.  finding a pizza place everyone can agree upon is harder than a Cialis induced four hour stiffy.  but i have yet to find someone who can complain about Little Star.  both the thin crust and deep dish are worth your while; seriously consider ordering both.  service is fast and friendly, but the place can get crowded during prime time - expect a 45 to an hour wait.  i would wait outside because with all that pizza around, you'll be salivating like a Somali eyeballing an U.N. food drop.
author: J M.

description: yeah.  its as good as everyone says it is.  service was friendly.  we got there at 6:15 and had no problem getting a table for six right away.  line was insanity by 7:30 however.  its one of those places that doesn't have a ton on the menu but everything on the menu they do absolutely right.
author: Jen H.

description: Awesome food awesome people. Well worth your time and money and calories. Ranks right up there with Zachary's and Chicago Fire.
author: Umair A.

description: First time getting food from here after hearing so many great raves from friends-Yep it's pretty good, par with Zachary's but it's on this side of the bay! Deep Dish is really flavorful, can't wait to try the thin crust. Why 4 stars? Their On-Line ordering system is kind of a major FAIL! Created an account, gave them all my info, placed an order, showed up when I was supposed to...and, no pizza. The system is new, they never got my order,etc etc etc. But then like magic my order came through the system 45 minutes late..."Do you still want the pizza?" "Well you've already charged me for it so yeah, I do" waited another 25 minutes past pickup time and they finally finished my order. Moral of the story? Skip the ONLINE ORDERING!!! Pick up your phone and call it in to another human....or if you do do an online order CALL to make sure they got it. This is for the Valencia location-other branches don't do online ordering. Also the front staff was great, knew someone screwed up and offered me a free drink-kudos to them for actually noticing...
author: andrew s.

description: Yes it's truly the best deep dish in the Bay Area.  Better than Zachary's.  If you have a freind who disagrees, I'd challenge her to a blind taste-test.  Honest tongues prefer Little Star.
author: Troy B.

description: ahhh, it was just what i wanted and expected.  got out of the john legend concert and was starving for some pizza.  ordered a pint of the blue star wheat.  delicious and shared the thin crust classic with a friend.  the service was fast and friendly.  the setting was great too.  dark with mod bulb lighting fixtures.  it was a down tempo feel for a pizza joint.  i'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Sharlene C.

description:
I don't want to pose as the World's Greatest Expert on Chicago-style deep dish pizza, but my credentials are pretty good. I'm in my early fifties, so I come from the era when you were either an Uno's family, a Due's family, or a Gino's/Giordano's family. We were Due's fans. Then Uno's sold out to corporate interests, Due's faded, and Lou Malnati opened up his place across the street from my house back in 1971. The Brian Piccolo Foundation fundraisers and the fairly constant stream of Bears and Cubs and Blackhawks (defenseman Eric Nesterenko was another neighbor) spurred the popularity of Malnati's, but it was the pizza that made it a legend. And the family - Lou and Jean and Marc and Rick are just good people. It was nice to be in their place, they made you feel welcome. 

So, like every Chicagoan, I get my jones for some of the Real Thing. I had been to Zachary's and Patxi's, and then I started hearing about Little Star, and reading all the praise here. I went there the other day and ordered the Chicago classic: sausage and onions and bell peppers and mushrooms, and, as is my habit, substituted black olives for mushrooms. 

There's no doubt that this is the genuine article. No prefab Uno's, no "what the hell is THIS" Pizz'a Chicago nonsense (and can we please punish the advertising mastermind who came up with that ridiculous spelling of "pizza"?) , this is a real Chicago-style deep-dish pizza. And it's a thuddingly average specimen. The crust has little too much cornmeal, it's more oily than buttery and flaky. Mine was perfectly done, but it seems like it would burn pretty easily in another minute, and that it would reheat much too tough. (It did toughen too much when reheated. Notable fail - one of the essential joys of the Real Thing is that it reheats well. I spent one summer hanging with friends, most of whom worked at Malnati's or at Gabby Hartnett's Bowling Alley across Lincoln Avenue. We'd bowl and close the alley, then go across to Lou's. Lou would give whoever was working a break to sit down with us; he'd often join us himself. We'd order whatever we wanted, and when the bill came, it would be for one medium cheese. And when Lou learned that I lived across the street, he'd always make sure I took home the leftovers. "What, you got somewhere else to go so fast you can't drop this off at home first?" I had leftover Malnati's for lunch at least twice a week all that summer. Rest in peace, Lou; you were a sweet man!) The cheese was very good and in the right proportion. The onions and bell peppers were UNDERCOOKED. Too much raw veg flavor, too much crunch. Only the crust and perhaps the edges of pepperoni slices are supposed to crunch in the Genuine Article, not the veggies. It's Comfort Food. 

The most important part is the sauce. There's gotta be a lotta sauce. I estimate the proper sauce-to-other ingredients ratio in the Real McCoy to be about six times the ratio in your average delivery thin pizza. It has to be rich and chunky, but it ISN'T just chopped tomatoes. It's a SAUCE - it has to be cooked. The Little Star sauce is so acid, so jarring with uncooked flavor, that I immediately took up knife and fork to probe and see if someone suffering from temporary insanity had put GREEN olives in my pizza instead of black. Whew - not the case. But a HUGE disappointment, after the accolades of Yelpers. 

They serve the Goods here. It will quiet your Jones. And while I'm sure that some of the complaints about service I read here have validity when the crowds are out the door, I showed up at 5 pm and I found the service to be very friendly, although the place is a little dark for my taste. But this deep-dish will not thrill you, it will not make you exclaim "My God! It's like I never ate pizza before I tasted this!" it will not excite that instant sense memory that is the essence of food nostalgia. Like Patxi's, it's good. Serviceable. More than acceptable. But it doesn't come within a mile of Zachary's, which could open up in Chicago any day and do a land-office business, even up against Malnati's.
author: Randy K.

description: It was worth the 1 hr wait.  We tried the thin crust pesto and the deep dish mediterrianian. i loved the corn meal crust on the deep dish.
author: rien d.

description: little star knows what it is doing:  deep dish to make any zachary's lover think twice, a bustling atmosphere in an intimate space... and a juke box.  aaahh.  you make friends, the husband, gregarious guests from the south bay and me happy.  grazie.
author: julia p.

description: yum!  if this place wasn't so crowded all the time, i'd definitely go more frequently.  i've tried both the thin and the thick crust pizzas, and both are delicious.  the service was a bit slow on my most recent visit and we had to wait a good hour for our table, but the food makes up for it!  definitely a great place to get a bite before heading to a show at the independent!
author: Amy K.

description: My favorite pizza in San Francisco. Deep dish with corn meal crust rocks. Great salads and beer too. Nice intimate, cozy atmosphere. Best for small groups.
author: Wendy A.

description: Expensive (over $100 for pizza and wine for two people, with tip), but the latest bone-headed idea is to suddenly stop taking any credit cards.  Cash only, and they've installed their own ATM machine so you can get the unexpected cash to pay the large bill.  Establishments who are this hostile to their customers shouldn't be patronized.  There's lots of great pizza in San Francisco--go elsewhere.
author: Robert G.

description: Just spent the weekend in Chicago and had Giordano's deep dish in Oak Park,  It was just fine, but does not hold a shred of parmesan to Little Star Pizza.  I am a Zachary's(East Bay hot spot) fan, but now I have a new favorite, Little Star Pizza.  It's a great date or group spot too.  The service is excellent.   Our salad was delicious and fresh as well.  Cannot wait for our next visit.  Suggest dinner at Little Star Pizza, entertainment at The Independent and dessert at Candy Bar on Fulton.  Yes to a night in NOPA!
author: Choosy M.

description: I'm a Chicago girl, and this pizza is the only I've had in California that comes close to pizza in the Windy City.  To top it off, they have PBR in the can. So outrageously satisfying, it's almost indecent!
author: Jayne A.

description: whoa. this shit is bomb. the best pizza in San Francisco right now.
author: Bobby P.

description: Im torn. Little Star: I found you first. Paxtis: I found you second. You both rocked my world. You both took me in and comforted me with your mouth-wateringly tasty pizza. I cant decide. Maybe we can all live together, as one of those alternative-to-the-traditional style relationships? You would each feed me, and I would love both of you equally.
author: amber d.

description: Came here famished on a Saturday night.  Circled the area for 15 minutes with my friend, until we finally realized that maybe I should at least put our names on the waitlist... did that, then circled the area for another 15 minutes looking for a spot. Parked. Went in and waited for another 20-25 minutes. The hostess was very nice, and came over to us to give us updates on our table every so often. We get seated finally - waitress brings over water, we put in our order for garlic bread and their special for the night - Large thin-crust pizza with pancetta, arugula, mozarella and fontina cheese. The bread came out fairly quickly, was OK - it's french bread (very soft, yum) served with a tiny bowl of butter and huge bunch of garlic cloves you spread on yourself. The pizza was good, but reeeally salty cos of the pancetta - so I ended up taking all the pancetta off.. but other than that, was pretty good... didn't like the crust very much, ended up not eating it. The waitress was very attentive and nice.  She even sliced the 3rd slice of pizza in half so we could split it evenly for our take-out boxes, haha.  With my glass of sauvignon blanc and my friend's ginger beer, the bill came out to be around $40 - so $20 per person, not too bad... I'm not sure if I'd come back here anytime soon cos of the long wait, and the pizza didn't blow my mind. Too harsh? Sorry..
author: Christine Y.

description: After trying out this pizza, I would have to say that this is the best pizza I ever had in my life. I liked the atmosphere and the art on the wall. If you're ever craving pizza in the city, skip blondies or fat slice, and have a real slice of pizza at Little Star Pizza!
author: P. L.

description: OH MY GOD their deep-dish pizza is amazing.  The crust is beyond fabulous: Crispy, crunchy, delicious.  The staff is friendly, and take-out orders are ready on-time.  Pizza is my favorite food, has been for decades, and Little Star is far and away the best pizza I've ever had. I wish there were more deep dish combos and specials for take-out, but otherwise I can't think of a single complaint.  Go Little Star!!
author: John M.

description: little star is soooooo good. it made me a deep dish convert, and the cornmeal crust was the best. the juke box is awesome too. i also love the chicken wings.
author: sarah C.

description: Well 500+ people can't be wrong.  Little Star is awesome!  It's absolutely delicious and I'm so glad I only live 4 blocks away from it!  I can't believe I waited so long to try it even with it's close proximity.  The deep dish crust is probably going to kill me but's it's so crunchy and tasty.  The thin crust is really good too if you're into that.  I also recommend the garlic bread because you get a whole roasted garlic bulb with a pot of butter so you can load that sucker up with as much as you like :)
author: Eliza C.

description: I blame this place for starting me on my Deep Dish Diet - not recommended. The food is amazingly delicious and always leaves me wanting more - again, not recommended. The only downside to this place is that it is not a hidden gem, and quite popular. Friday/Saturday night outings prove to be almost impossible. I wanted pizza here so bad one Saturday night I ended up waiting 2 hours (I know - it's ridiculous, I almost feel embarrassed admitting this). But, per usual, it was well worth the wait.
author: Heather H.

description: Based on the fact they have SO many reviews should be a sign.....this place is THE BEST PIZZA IN SAN FRANCISCO and maybe all of the Bay Area and maybe even all of California.  I hope they join some crazy Food Network Pizza challenge and kick butt!!!!
author: Erin M.

description: i have very exacting pizza standards - i was born and raised in new york, and i only like thin crust.  i wouldn't give any pizza in CA 5 stars.  that said, little star goes a solid thin crust pizza with the right ratios of sauce and cheese.  good wine selection.  too crowded most of the time, so i often do take out.
author: eeeee d.

description: i went here with some friends and had to wait nearly 2 hours to get seated. on a thursday??? wtf? the pizza was ok but not really worth a 2 hour wait. plus, it tasted HORRIBLE the next day.
author: stephanie z.

description: We went on a friday nite around 10 and it was really crowded so we got it to go.  The 30 minute wait for the deep dish to go was worth it!!  Despite walking down the street eating the deep dish w/ my drunk eyes half open, the pizza was amazing.  It wasn't too wet from the veggies the way that Zach's or Paxti's gets wet:( The crust was crispy, not too doughy, and sauce was really good.  Unfortunately it's not open for lunch on the weekends, but I'll be back again sober w/ my eyes fully open to fully enjoy this great pizza!
author: LT B.

description: deep dish little star and the white pie...don't forget a movie star cocktail! you can't have a better pizza dinner then this.
author: Deb B.

description: omg, thee best jukebox evar!!11!1!!
author: sam l.

description: Best and most likely most fattening pizza in town.  Their deep dish cheese w/ the sauce on top is amazing....oh so good.
author: E G.

description: Worst Pizza I have had in a long,long time....Chicken wings were disgusting!!!!!  I'd rather eat DiGiorno and buy crap from CostCo
author: Sean C.

description: Little star pizza is a great pizza place. There pizza are some of the best in SF. I have never had deep dish before until Little Star and it was great. The crust was nice and the sauce was delicious.
author: Olivia T.

description: Let me preface this review by stating that I am one of the millions of asians out there that have a wee bit of a dairy allergy. Translation: I am in no way a connessieur of pizza. However, I've been known to suffer the consequences now and then (or take some Lactaid pills) to enjoy a nice slice of pie. And I've heard such rave reviews of this place that I just had to put my food allergies aside and check it out. What I really appreciated was that they were more than happy to make my thin crust pesto-chicken pizza with minimal cheese so that I didn't leave the place with massive abdomonal pain and/or nausea = we could go out to bars after dinner. And I really appreciate that. I went to dinner with a couple of friends, and included in the trio is a vegetarian. So needless to say, when searching for dinner venues we're confined to those that accommodate vegetarians and the lactose-intolerant. And here, all three palates were happily fed. The pizza was delicious, the prices more than reasonable, and the service was superb. I'm definitely going back there again!
author: Marie M.

description: So me and sweetie pie Notorious H.I.Z. went to Little Star Pizza on Divisadero Street. We found this cozy space to be a treat. To eat, it only took us the time it takes to beat my meat. Gross! No really, tho....our salad came as fast as a Big Mac. Everybody talks about this pizza and how it may be the best in the city. In my opinion...it depends on if you are a huge fan of corn-meal crust and deep dish pizza. Yes the pizza was good. I ate it all. The crust was amazing....nothing left on the plate, but the pizza had all this crushed tomatoes slopped over the top. I guess that's how deep dish is done. It was good...don't get me wrong. I need to try the rest of the pizzas before I give it my ultimate judgement.  I think Little Star Pizza is one of the best "Different style" pizzas in the city.  My only negative comment: The menu seems limited lacking choices of toppings and stuff. I still think Paradise Pizza on West Portal is my favorite so far. Nobody knows about it and I hope it stays that way.
author: Glenn C.

description: Best pizza ever!!  Totally worth the 45 minute wait for a table.  We had the chicken pesto thin crust and the classic deep dish...both perfection in their own way.  I am still full from tonight and can not wait to go back.  Loving the fact that we live so close.  Good bye to all the crappy pizza chains as we will never be ordering from you again!!!!
author: Tammy S.

description: My friend I just had dinner at Little Star or at least attempted to.  We ordered the chicken pizza we took a couple of bites, but the chicken was reeeally dry. I typically will eat anything that is put in front of me. We told the waitress who graciously offered to make us another pizza. We decided to split it. I wanted something different, but my friend decided she would give the chicken another try. There we were chatting and patiently waiting for another pizza when a guy (who we later found out was the manager) came to our table. "Why would you order the chicken pizza again if you didn't like it the first time, you are going to get the same thing" he said somewhat accusingly. We were both really surprised... oh I don't know maybe you won't cook it until its bone dry for the second time. There was no apology from him nothing. It really did feel like we had made the mistake and he came to the table to chastise  us .We left money for the salad and wine and left.  This maybe the worse customer service ever... and he was the manager. The pizza it typically good, but not that good to put up with that attitude.
author: maureen G.

description: This is yet another hyped up pizza joint that made me wish I went to Papa John's instead. The texture and taste of the thin crust pizza here is different, different in a bad way. And they pile on too much cheese. It looks as bad as it tastes. The salad is good and the beers on tap are $4 instead of the usual ridiculous $5, and I would have given 2 stars based on those. But the people who pack this place are so unbelievably atrocious I would never come back here even if the pizza were good. The dining area is not large yet the shrill bitches (OMG!!1 aaaAAAAAHAHAHAAAAAAaaaaaaaa!!!!) and their dicked counterparts who seem to love being here somehow manage to raise the noise level to that of a block party. I'm pretty sure these are the same pigfuckers who pay to get into a show only to have shrieky and fascinating conversations with their friends while the band is playing.
author: keith s.

description: For all you east coast transplants struggling to find a good slice of pizza in SF, you're in luck. Little Star has top notch thin-crust, eastside style pizza that you've grown to love and miss so dearly. My three friends and I split two large pies, which was more than enough for us all to have our fill for the night, and also take home a few slices to enjoy the next day. My recommendation - The Italian Combo (pepperoni, salami, white onions, black olives, green peppers, and pepperoncini). Savory to the last bite.  For a cocktail, go ahead and order the Hey Koolaid - a light, delicious mix of champagne and cherry soda.    The place is small, so I wouldn't recommend parties over 4 people going there unless you're willing to wait around for 30+ minutes.   The waitstaff was attentive and scored points for turning down the music a tad, so that the four of us could enjoy a conversation while scarfing down the best pizza in SF.
author: Nishan K.

description: I am a big fan of deep dish pizza and the one here is really good. The crust on the night I got it was delicious, crisp, buttery, savory. We got the classic deep dish with sausages, tomatoes, mushrooms and cheese. Everything was good except for I felt the sauce on the pizza could have been cooked just a touch longer, it still had that slightly sour uncooked taste to the tomatoes. We also got a thin crust pizza which was okay but the crust was soggy and the onions were undercooked. Others in my party liked it a lot though. I was a little confused by the garlic bread as you have to to sort of put it together yourself, they give you a plate with bread, olive/oil butter spread and a roasted garlic bulb, which is fine except for they didn't roast the garlic long enough so it wasn't spreadable so basically we paid for some bread and butter. At least it was good. I'm going to give them an extra star because the host was so nice and even though we had a large group he was super accommodating.
author: Cathy T.

description: i am from the east coast where pizza is literally sold on every corner - and it's pretty darned good 95% of the time.  i gotta say, it's hard to find good pizza on the west coast.  i was thrilled when little star opened in my hood. while it's not exactly traditional east coast pizza, it's still really f-ing good.  i love it.  i love it for takeout, i love eating at the restaurant.  it's just plain ol good.
author: Mary C.

description:
what else can you say about this place?

killer jukebox
crispy thin crust pizzas (not a dish fan)
cheap happy hour beer (pacifico is $1.84!)

in that order.
author: jorge c.

description: deep dish Mediterranean chicken w/ a boont amber - that is all.
author: Zach D.

description: this is actually 3 1/2 stars....very friendly staff but super long wait. i don't dink the pizza here is that special. i am not a fan of deep dish, but the one i tried at little star was the best i had so far. there crust is really unique, but I had better pizza than this. the garlic bread is good...it comes out with warm white bread and u spread butter on roasted garlic on it ur self. very tasty. this is a small place, so it is best to come early.
author: Karen H.

description: this place has the best pizza in the Bay area,  the last time I was there the service was very fast and the food as always was delicious
author: brian a.

description: Seriously good pizza with a cornmeal crust.  Amusing 80s pop always on the stereo.
author: Emily D.

description: i love pizza. crappy frozen pizza to fancy restaurant pizza.  i worked at a pizza place in high school.  so i've eaten a lot of pizza over the years. little star is different and delicious.  even the leftovers the next day are so good.  for the deep dish pizza, the crust is buttery and flavorful, and the sauce is fresh, and the toppings are generous.  the wait is long and the parking difficult, but it is a good place for a date (cozy, kinda dark), or just order and pick up.
author: Ben D.

description: mmm...i love deep dish pizza, and if you can't get to zachary's in the e. bay, you should definitely come here!!  i love the cornmeal crust, b/c it's not too heavy, even tho it is very substantial.  the garlic bread here was interesting...they give you a loaf of sliced french bread w/ the butter and roasted garlic on the side, so you can put as little or as much butter and garlic as you'd like!
author: Helen T.

description: Wow - amazing pizza!  We went for the deep dish and it certainly lived up to the hype.
author: S P.

description: Long-ass wait for a table last Thursday, but KILLER cornmeal, deep-dish crust.  Where have you been all my SF-life?  I didn't have a pizza hang-over like when you eat deep-dish in Chi-town (my privilege for 4 years at Uni), that over-carb-ed, over-cheezed buzzy feeling.  It's deep-dish that has been Californ-ized with that NorCal water in the crust.  We had the Little Star and the thin-crust White Pizza (not that great, by the way).  I also have to say that "White Pizza" is called "white" according to some folks back in NY because NOT ONLY is the creamy base ricotta (and maybe some garlic) instead of RED sauce (See?  White!), but it also does not contain ANY red items.  A little basil chiffonade, some cracked black pepper I've seen, but not really chopped tomatoes.  That's missing the point, I believe.  Also, white pizza is not license to slap on the cheese- it's kindof a delicate balance.  So, thumbs up on the cornmeal crust, beer selection, champagne cocktails and the NOPA hipster code (i.e. black tees)  that's just shy of pretentious and thumbs down on the "white" pizza and the wait.  I heard the owners are young, so I guess there's  room for improvement.
author: E L.

description: not bad deep dish- not overly cheesy or greasy, but the crust was surprisingly dry and thin; pretty cornmealy.  most importantly, arrive EARLY- they fill up fast.  open at 5 on wkends.
author: Zoe L.

description: This truly is some unique and amazing pizza. Definitely more of a date restaurant than a pizza joint and the price reflects that. The deep dish is very deep (the two of us only managed to cram down half of a large pie), the corn bread style crust is revolutionary, and I love the sauce on top style. I also love the fact that the drink selection is cheap and reasonably priced. I HATE restaurants that overcharge for drinks, I go for the food not to pay $3 for a coke or $6 for a beer and Little Star understands that. My only complaints, which are by no means reasons not to go there, are that there could be a little more variety on their "specialty" pizzas, I would expect some more unique ingredients and combinations out of a place like this and the second would be that the sauce could use a little work. Maybe it was just the day that I was there but the sauce struck me as a little too tart, perhaps undercooked, and not salty sweet like I like my pizza sauce. But I'm getting into the nitty gritty here, a lot of which is personal preference. I will be back.
author: M L.

description: good, solid san francisco pizza place. best deep dish in the city for sure. it takes a while to get it but that's mostly because they're always slammed. the specialty pizzas are pretty good, though you can't go wrong with building your own. again, deep dish is the way to go. best to go ahead of dinner rush if you want any chance of getting a table
author: Sidney B.

description: damn, didn't realize this place had so many reviews! if you love deep dish style pizza, you'll definitely want to try this place out! parking isn't easy, and sometimes the wait can be long. but if you can, just grab a seat at the bar area...
author: Darren W.

description: Great Chicago style deep dish pizza. Parking is a challenge in the area and the all cash policy requires forethought before visiting. The food is exceptional and you'll quickly forget about the challenge finding parking or worrying about bringing cash. If only they delivered.
author: Jim G.

description: what can I say that hasn't been said 1096 times already? probably the best pizza in SF
author: Shaddie J.

description: I had high expectations of this place after reading raving reviews on yelp and was really disappointed. DON"T GO THERE UNLESS YOU HAVE PLENTY OF TIME ON YOUR HAND. Small place, limited seating, average service, average pizza, big price, and ridiculously long wait time.  It has a tiny sign which is hardly visible from the street. We drove right past it even though we had a map and the address. We went on a Saturday evening around 5:45pm, and the place was already pretty crowded.  We were seated right away, which turned out to be the only positive about this experience.  And since we knew what we wanted, the waiter had our order immediately.  When we saw a lot of people streaming in to line up at the cashier, we realized they were here for take-out orders, and at one time there were more people standing in line than those sitting down at the tables.  After waiting for about 20 minutes, I started to see a pattern.  Waiters were coming out of the kitchen with stacks of big and small take-out boxes, but most of the eat in customers were kept waiting. As the time went by I started to get impatient and wanted to leave.  Finally after 55 minutes, our two small 9 in. pizzas arrived separately.  But I had totally lost my appetite.  The deep dish mediterranean chicken is average and the thin crust pesto is nothing special.  We each had one slice and decided to leave. I will never go back.Total disappointment!  The food was definitely not worth the 55 min. wait time.  Final words: Don't go there when you are hungry, and prepare to wait an hour for something you can get at any pizzeria.
author: Mia C.

description: Last night we got a pizza to go from Little Star, our first shot after hearing lots of good things about this place.  We were on our way back from Ikea, in a daze that always seems to occur after walking through that maze, hungry, and we had furniture to put together, so pizza sounded like the perfect fix.  Since we didn't have a menu on hand, we ordered a deep dish pizza with tomatoes and bell peppers.  It was a good pizza, a darn good pizza in fact.  It's hard not to compare this place with Zachary's, since that's pretty much the only other deep dish pizza that we eat.  I won't say that either was any better, they are different.  Little Star's sauce has a cleaner tomato taste with less oregano and other spices.  The crust was good, it stayed crispy, even with all the fixins' on top.  Maybe I ate less, maybe it's less filling, but I felt a little less like stuffed pizza myself after eating the Little Star than I do after eating Zachary's.  Next time we'll eat at the restaurant and we'll definitely try the pizza with the chicken, feta and onions...
author: Jeffrey F.

description: Their thin crust pizza is delicious whether you pick it up or eat there.  I'm not a huge fan of deep dish but it looks good enough to try.  The service was good despite being packed and although there was a good amount of background noise it was a very comfortable environment for the four of us.
author: B B.

description: little star has the best chicago style pizza! yummmm.. The place is a little hard to find since its stuck between big houses but trust me once you walk in, you'll forget all about your worries. the place has a nice atmosphere. dim and clubby feel and a little tight in space. gets kinda loud at some parts but its okay when you're chowing down those delicious pizzas.
author: Rhonda H.

description: one of my favorite pizza place. i love the cornmeal in the crust. they have just enough of everything. some of those low rates i don't get. one said there's too much tomato and another said there's barely. OK.. doesn't sound accurate. to me i always leave full and beyond satisfied. i wished it was in a convenient place. you have to walk for your passion of "little star". my fiance and i just pick up and eat at home. after eating theirs and Zachery in Berkley i have no desire for pizza hut or round table (yuck).
author: maritess b.

description: I love my NY pizza so my bar is raised.  When a friend told me this pizza was great I was a bit skeptical.  As I expected, this was not NYC pizza.  However, for not being NY pizza, it was still very, very tasty!!  The crust on the think crust pizza was nice and crispy, not doughy.  Also, the deep dish that we order was tasty as well.  Service was very good also.  I highly recommend all San Fran visitors to stop by and give it a try!
author: Dorn E.

description: The pizza is decent, though Zachary's is better. Service was good but they give you the stink-eye and come by every 2 minutes to ensure table turn. We weren't there long but it was clear they wanted us there even less time. Lame.
author: Bob S.

description: I don't remember my deep dish experience when I was in Chicago 10 years ago.   I just moved to a new house one year ago.  It is 2 blocks from Little Star.  My roommate ordered a vegie deep dish, I feel in love with this pizza.  I think I have ordered it 2 times a month since then.  YUMMY
author: Antony E.

description: the pizza here is so delicious it makes you want smack every other pizzeria owner in the city. why can't all pizza be this good?! and now these Viv guys are doing some 50% off promotion. yayyyyy!
author: Zach L.

description: I had a friend visiting from DC  and during her visit we were both craving pizza.  But not just any sloppy pizza, well made pizza.  I live near this place and decided that we should check it out.  I am so glad we did!  The wait was pretty long, but we managed to snag seats at the bar.  I do recommend finding a spot at the bar if possible, so you don't have to wait too long.  We ordered garlic bread and we were a little bit disappointed.  It was literally warm bread, a roasted piece of garlic, and a side of melted butter.  I was not expecting that!  They should of just brought me dough to make the bread too!  Sure it was interesting and different, but they should of mentioned that on the menu.  Anyways, the pizza was AMAZING!  I had the white pie and my friend had a deep dish.  We both were in pizza heaven.  Both pies were flavorful and satisfying.  The true test came when we brought it home and had it the next day.  Left over pizza can sometimes fail, but this did not!
author: Dominique T.

description: I can't believe I just gave a pizza place in San Francisco four stars. I better write this review before I change my mind. Little Star Pizza is the best pizzeria in San Francisco, hands down. That does not, however, mean that they have great pizza. The four stars that I have awarded this establishment are for attitude and effort, not achievement. Little Star makes two types of pizza: a Chicago-inspired deep dish and a more standard thin crust. Unfortunately, both of these pizzas arrive with more than a tinge of California. Just look at the menu of pizza specials and toppings... feta? artichoke hearts? Please. Being a Chicagoan, of the two pizza styles, I prefer the deep dish. Chicago-style deep dish pizza should be hefty and artery-clogging. Little Star's version seems to be inspired by the top-notch pizza at Chicago's Gino's East, which has a cornmeal crust and, if you order right, an enormous thick Italian sausage patty. Little Star's got the cornmeal crust, but here it's a little more rustic... sort of polenta-y, almost. And it's particularly crumbly when cold, which sucks. The tomato sauce is good, with a nice herb flavor. But the toppings and cheese seem to get lost underneath the sauce. I prefer a thick well-done crust of cheese on top, a la Chicago's Carmen's Pizzeria. Vis a vis the thin crust pizza, it's passable. Who cares about thin crust when deep dish is on the menu? Recently, I enjoyed a Pompagne... a generous champagne cocktail with pomegranate juice. Yummy and drunk-making. Final gripe: why no delivery? What is it with you people?
author: Jon L.

description: little star is hands-down better than zachary's (sorry, zachary's). the cornmeal crust means it's less greasy. plus the ambiance is way nicer - you can actually go on a date here (if you're willing to scream the small talk). you must try the champagne cocktails - i recommend the 'hey kool aid.'
author: Lisa M.

description: With it's many votes for "Best Pizza in the City," the BF and I finally ventured to Little Star for a low-key, inexpensive casual outing (all those things that typically go hand in hand with pizza dining).  But there is nothing typical about Little Star---it's in a league all its own.  The dim candle lit, retro-hip ambiance was the last thing I expected in a pizza joint.  It ain't no Fat Slice, that's for sure.  I dare say, Little Star is even romantic, but totally unpretentious and friendly.  We arrived at primetime on a Saturday night and waited 15 minutes at the bar.  They have a great beer and wine selection, and super creative champagne cocktails (much better than Soju, if you know what I mean).  During our wait, we bonded with one of Star's regulars who insisted "Deep dish is the only way to go."  We took his recommendation and ordered a small "Little Star" pizza, add chicken. Deep dish rocks---crispy, hearty crust and fresh scrumptious toppings. We also shared chicken wings which were uniquely good---subtle simple flavor, but no buffalo sauce (if that's what you're looking for).  We had plenty of food with two slices to spare.  Did I mention the jukebox?  Now that should win an award!  It's curator did an excellent job of representing the best of all genres...Manu Chao, Modest Mouse, Tribe Called Quest, Stevie Wonder, Madonna, and many more.  Bring some singles and expect to hear your songs almost immediately.  I was not excited about going out for pizza, but Little Star proved it is a Star!  Expect to throw down more scrilla than you normally would for pizza though (3 beers + chicken wings + small za + tip=$50). I will be back to jam the juke and taste the buttery thin crust so many other yelpers are raving about.
author: Regan P.

description: By far, some of the best pizza in the city. It has amazing flavor, and the crust, whether deep dish or regular, is amazing. The first time I went there there was some PSYCHO girl there, who shoved me, my sister, and the couple in front of us to get to the bar.....THANK YOU to the manager who had her removed! I will always love this place. In fact, I want some now.
author: Brian O.

description: oh em gee. had the deep dish and i can not give less than 5 stars. i'm not gonna say it's better than zachary's, but i had absolutely no room (hahaaaa no pun intended) for complaints.
author: gina s.

description: When thinking about where to live it's always a good idea to consider your proximity to Little Star Pizza.  As such, I now live 3 short blocks away from the best pizza in SF (Za is a distant second).  Great place to take a date, friends from out of town, or even if you're looking for a low-key meal.  I guess it's a little pricey for being pizza and all, but a salad, small pizza, and two drinks will run you about $40 after tip.  Not bad for a great meal.
author: Conor S.

description: chicago style is not my favorite but you really can't find great new york style pizza on the west coast. that said their pizza is the best alternative i have found in the ten years i have lived here. try the wings too they're spicy from spices not sauce,mmm
author: brooke h.

description: Best deep dish pizza I have ever tried.  To be honest it's probably the best pizza, period, I have ever tried.  The only pain in the ass thing is the cash only, but they have a super cheap fee ATM right in the front.  The ambiance is interesting.  It is super dark, almost romantic, but then also gothic.  Go early cause the wait is also a big pain but the food is totally worth it!
author: L M K M.

description: This place was hard to find the first time. The sign is tiny and easy to miss. I'm glad we doubled back and found it, because the deep dish pizza is wonderful! We played it safe and had the classic, and it was just as good as back home in Chicago. The place is pretty packed, and after you order the pizza takes at least 30 minutes to make, so come early!
author: M. W.

description: my mouth says yes, my thighs say don't be a fatty mcfatterson fat.  it's so damn good but hard to stop eating even when you're full after the first piece.  friendly staff and decent prices.  eat it.
author: Jon K.

description: Authentic Chicago style pizza. The Italian is perfection at its very best. Better than Patxi's. Not as good as Zach's. Go here. Eat. Be happy.
author: Nyle O.

description: Yes, Little Star definitely gets 5 BIG stars in my book. We were in the mood for some thick ass deep dish pizza so, naturally, we left our decision up to the yelpers, and, obv, we were not disappointed. On the outside- this place kind of looks like a hole, but step inside and you'll find a sweet little place that looks like IKEA has decided to design restaurants. We couldn't get a table right away so we got a drink at the bar. The bartender gave us his attention immediately and we exchanged friendly and humorous banter while we waited. After we sat down at our table the waitress came and took our order. She was super nice and gave us her recommendations. A friendly staff is so key for me and I was glad to see that they weren't another pretentious restaurant with employees that think they're too cool for school. We ordered a salad and the Little Star deep dish (such a clutch decision- thanks waitress!). They say it takes around 30 minutes to cook the pizza but it sure didn't seem like it. Once it got to our table, talking ceased and the grubbing began. The pizza was cooked perfectly and we were incredibly satisfied when we were finished. I've never been to Chicago but something tells me that when I go to eat pizza there, I'll have something to compare it against. Thanks, Little Star!
author: Marjorie P.

description: We ordered two pizzas. The first, was a 16" medium crust cheese and pesto. The crusty, traditional flour crust gave a good solid, almost crunchy contrast to a hot, wet, topping of melted mozzarella and fresh pesto. It was a perfect combination. Our second pizza was a 14" vegetarian deep dish pizza with olives, mozzarella, tomatoes, zucchini, bell peppers and oregano. It usually comes with mushrooms, but we opted not to have them. This being said, I now believe the mushrooms would have been a fine addition. Even without the mushrooms, the pizza was fantastic. The crust was more of a corn meal mix with a gritty, well browned outside to it that give it a unique opposing texture in the mouth. The bed of the crust was lined with mozzarella, then the vegetables were in the middle, with a bed of tomatoes resting on top. Outstanding. The combinations are well thought out, balanced and tasty. The lighting was low, and the restaurant was large enough to feel like there was enough personal space, but cozy enough to feel warm amongst fellow pizza aficionados who also happened to be in the know as to where some of the best pizza is in San Fransisco is.
author: Dave S.

description: I have been to every one of they hyped Chicago deep dish places. I can tell you definitively that Little Star is superior. Better sauce, better tomatoes, better crust that is crisp.
author: Hal P.

description: My friends and I waited 45 minutes for a table here it was well worth the wait. I had their deep dish pizza before at a house birthday party so knew what I was waiting for. I don't even know if they have delivery service...I do know that they have mastered the deep dish pizza...it is fantastic! The aroma when you walk in the place is just amazing and has you salivating at the mouth. We also decided to order our pizza before we even sat at the table such a great idea because we didn't have to wait too long once we were actually seated. Fresh quality ingredients go into making their savory pizzas, they really ROCK the deep dish! I haven't tried any other dishes here because I can't get enough of their deep dish. They  give you warm sour dough bread, butter and a whole roasted garlic for starters. The garlic looked interesting, but I knew if I ate it I would smell like garlic for weeks and my boyfriend would be avoiding me like he was a vampire! Run to this place if you know what is good for you! ;)
author: Jennifer H.

description: OMG.  What can i say.  The garlic bread was so nice (Make it yourself style with rosted garlic), the pizza was out of this world.  Great service and food.  I cannot fault it.
author: Mary F.

description: Extraordinarily overrated in all aspects. My first complaint is that it ook the waitress almost ten minutes to recognize us and then  another ten minutes to get two beers, I mean, I'm no physicist, but pouring liquid into a 16 ounce glass just physically can't take ten minutes, I made a kinda kitschy joke along those lines, in good humor, and the girl sneered, actually sneered, like some kind of 1983 cheerleader Valley girl who loses the prom to the unpopular but goodhearted girl, and then, the fucking beer was flat, the pizza was delivered with the same pep of service and the couple next to us was also visibly  baffled by the inept ability of our service wench. The food, though good, by no means merits the praise accorded to it in any ay, and in fact, I'd highly recommend going down the street to the Fly Bar where the service is brilliant, the beer is not flat, and the pizza is better and cheaper, Little Star must have a crack team of PR guys cuz this place is mediocre!!
author: Steve l.

description: This is the best deep dish pizza around. The tomatoes on top aren't overly tart, it's perfect. Plus the cornmeal crust ensures that it won't come out soggy. Must try.
author: Helen L.

description: Good pizza!  I like Little Star's pizza -- it's tasty and creative, and generally excellent. I've had a number of their pizzas, including the 'white' pizza, which I would highly recommend.
author: Ron B.

description: For pizza, this place was excellent- I especially loved the thin corn meal crusts.
author: Lauren D.

description: ballz expensive, hence the 4 not 5 stars, but pizza is damnsure hella hecka hizzy good!  pizza in this city tends to suck, so i'm especially appreciative.  they only sell full, bigass pies, yet the vibe inside is pretty datey so you usually end up having to carry a doggy box around the rest of the night...which is why i usually order take out and save the rest for later.  think i want some now...
author: Hella M.

description:
this place is the sh*t.

i left town for a year, came back and just went to little star for the first time in a while and it hasn't changed one bit. it's still the best pizza in the city. the ingredients are good, the crust is delicious and original, there is just enough cheese, they have interesting toppings and flavors, it's not too expensive and you don't go home hungry.

to top it off, the staff have always been friendly even though it's a zoo in there. i can understand people complaining about the long wait and the staff's general lack of knowledge of what the hell is going on, but that's just how it is. people should stop bitching and just realize that this place is small, busy, and raucous. that's part of the fun.

and yes you might wait longer than expected for a table to open up, and someone else might slip in ahead of you. get over it. go get a beer across the street and wait it out like everyone else. you'll be happy once the pizza comes.

i wouldn't go here if you are in any kind of hurry, but in my opinion it's the best pizza around.
author: Raphael M.

description: Totally dig their deep dish and their crust. Normally I'm someone who leaves the crust behind, or give it to my dog, but not Little Star's! Like their menu and service is fairly nice. Bit of a scene to get seated there though.
author: gary a.

description: the pizza here is just straight delicious. ive only had it once, but only because the place is kinda far from my house and they dont deliver. otherwise, id be a regular. all i have to say is: chicago style pizza with a crunchy cornbread crust. period. I think its as good as zachary's in berkeley, but i would have to say that zachary's is better, due to the fact that zachary's feels like a pizza place, and not a dark, trendy restaurant like little star. but besides that, the food is great. better than any pizza ive had in the city.
author: Art V.

description: The pizza is very good here but the restaurant itself is noisy, crowded and full of wannabe hipsters. I came here a few days ago and my date and I had to scream at each other to carry on a conversation. Probably best to avoid this place entirely on the weekends, or maybe I will order carryout next time around. I actually prefer the thin crust pizza to the deep dish but it could be that I am a little weird. Salads were a little uninspired in my opinion. The waitstaff was fairly attentive and polite.   Oh yeah. cash only also, don't forget!
author: Amy O.

description: best pizza i have ever had.. there chicken wings are also off the hook.. i try and eat here every month
author: patrick blap S.

description: Just tried Little Star pizza for the first time last weekend.  Wow, it was worth it!  The selection is not great, but the pizzas that we ordered, both deep dish and thin crust were excellent.  We had friends in from LA and they thoroughly enjoyed the experience.  I don't have pizza too often during the year, but I will definitely be heading back to LSP sometime soon.
author: Brian L.

description: Not just the best Pizza in SF...this is the best deep dis pizza I gave ever had..that includes Chicago and NY  Bravo.....
author: Scott W. W.

description: This place has great Zachary's-style (or, if you like, Chicago-style) pizza with cornmeal crust and without the BART ride/plane to Chicago. It also has appealingly dim lighting and a near-perfect jukebox. The name makes Madonna's abominable "Little Star" get stuck in my head, but that's no one's fault but my own.
author: Page R.

description: The cosmopolitan atmosphere doesn't mask their attempt to imitate Zachary's success.  Pizza's great, but  Z's has more flavor and more deep dish options.   While it's the best pizza * in the City * it's definitely the worst service I've had in my ten years of SF dining.  I've been four times, and svc sucked every single time.  too-cool-for-work hipsters can be avoided-  GET TAKEOUT (albeit, I've heard the newer Valencia location hosts better staff)
author: C O.

description: Oh Little Star...  How I love you and your deep dish cornmeal crust goodness.  Would love you even more if you took credit cards, but I guess you can't have everything.
author: Alison D.

description: I'm not a big pizza fan, but the pizza here is delicious! I came with my sister and some friends and ordered the classic deep dish and the chicken pesto thin crust and both were amazing. The restaurant itself isn't very big, so it definitely fills up quickly, but it has a nice and relaxed atmosphere. Next time I visit my sister, I'll be sure to eat here.
author: Christiana C.

description: Best Pizza, period.  NY Pizza is soggy and gross and seem to be the only bad reviews abou this palce.  My advice, go back to NY and roll around in your greasy pizza.
author: Tyke J.

description: I discovered Little Star about 5 years ago....WOW...I thought that the chef owner must have worked at Zacahry's in Oakland to come up with his creations or lab-tested their pizza to copy it...perfect copy....unfortunately their quality has dropped in the past few years...their crust doesn't have the same texture, and their sauce and cheese has lost flavor....I brought home a Zachary's last week after having a Little Star the week before, and my girlfriend was astounded..."how could  Little Star  have gone downhill so quickly?" Try Pasquale's or Milano's for a greay cheesy thin crust in SF, but deep dish? drive to Oakland for Zachary's! There's no comparison anymore
author: SFNATIVE K.

description: best pizza in san francisco!  id even go so far as to say best pizza in the bay area (cheeseboard for thin crust).  if you order thin crust here, you are an idiot.  this place has better deep dish than zacharys because of its delicious crust.  we like to get the little star and add sausage.  you can eat there and it's fun but the real way to do this pizza is sitting in front of the TV with tons of napkins, beer, and a nice degrassi marathon.
author: noah s.

description: delicious...i love the cornmeal pizza crust...I eat here everytime I'm in the neighborhood!
author: meli r.

description: We showed up at Fly Bar at 10:37 p.m  with a pizza craving and learned the kitchen had closed 7 minutes earlier. The bouncer felt our pain and suggested we head down to Little Star. I love the great logo and as soon as I walked in and looked around, I knew I would want to give this place a 5. Our server (Richard?) was really nice, joked around with us for a bit and was fairly attentive. The salad was large and a decent way to tide us over while our Chicago Style pizza took 30 minutes to cook. We ordered the Little Star Pizza and unfortunately, it wasn't that hot when it came out to us. We asked them to reheat it but learned that because they use a conveyer belt, reheating it would totally burn the cheese. They gave us that as an option, but we opted to keep our lukewarm pizza. It was decent, but not worth all the hype. I did love the cornmeal crust and the cheese was really good but the sauce was too sweet and it certainly wasn't worth a 30 minute wait. They let us linger forever and we were the last ones there and they never pressured us to hurry up. Given everyone else's adoration for Little Star, my guess is we just ordered the wrong thing and I'll have to give these guys another shot.
author: Cher E.

description: i have to say first of all - i'm not a huge fan of deep dish pizza but this place has got amazing crust and i love crust. i started with the chicken wings which are really yummy. i've been meaning to go here again. great place if you're craving some heavy duty pizza.
author: Miss O.

description: let me start by warning that they don't take credit cards or reservations.  get here early to avoid the wait or show up when you're not already starving so that by the time you sit down, you'll be ready to eat.  we came here just this past saturday night at 7pm as a group of 5 adults and a toddler.  the place was packed.  we were told a half hour wait.  we finally got seated after over an hour wait and having noticed that the hostess screwed up and seated another group of 6 that came in after us!  she apologized.   anyway, that said, it was fantastic pizza!  we ordered the vegeratian deep dish and the italian combo thin crust.  wonderful!  our friends also had the caprese salad and we got an order of wings which had a little heat but otherwise very tasty!  our waitress was really nice and attentive - didn't get any attitude at all.  recommended but not for large groups - the place is too small.  KILLER JUKEBOX!
author: Cyn B.

description: if you like deep dish...this place is the best for it in the city.....lets go!
author: Manny C.

description: my first visit to little star was a saturday night. we went early - 6 pm to ensure a quick seating since the reviews mentioned it gets crowded. we sat right away and ordered a bottle of wine and two small pizzas for variety - a pepperoni thin crust and the chicken deep crust. deep crust was better than the thin crust ---good.  friendly and attentive service. check it out.
author: jen y.
